1 Iwanich , who felt sorry for the poor creature , seized it in his arms and flung it into the stream .
2 But no sooner did the fish find itself in the water again , than , to the Prince 's amazement , it swam up to the bank and said : ` My kind benefactor , how can I reward you for your goodness ? ' '
3 I desire nothing , ' answered the Prince . '
4 I am quite content to have been able to be of some service to you . '
5 ` You must do me the favour , ' replied the fish , ` to take a scale from my body , and keep it carefully .
6 If you should ever need my help , throw it into the river , and I will come to your aid at once . '
7 Iwanich bowed , loosened a scale from the body of the grateful beast , put it carefully away , and returned home .
8 A short time after this , when he was going early one morning to the usual grazing place with his horses , he noticed a flock of birds assembled together making a great noise and flying wildly backwards and forwards .
9 Full of curiosity , Iwanich hurried up to the spot , and saw that a large number of ravens had attacked an eagle , and although the eagle was big and powerful and was making a brave fight , it was overpowered at last by numbers , and had to give in .
10 But the Prince , who was sorry for the poor bird , seized the branch of a tree and hit out at the ravens with it ; terrified at this unexpected onslaught they flew away , leaving many of their number dead or wounded on the battlefield .
11 As soon as the eagle saw itself free from its tormentors it plucked a feather from its wing , and , handing it to the Prince , said : ` Here , my kind benefactor , take this feather as a proof of my gratitude ; should you ever be in need of my help blow this feather into the air , and I will help you as much as is in my power . '
12 Iwanich thanked the bird , and placing the feather beside the scale he drove the horses home .
13 Another day he had wandered farther than usual , and came close to a farmyard ; the place pleased the Prince , and as there was plenty of good grass for the horses he determined to spend the day there .
14 Just as he was sitting down under a tree he heard a cry close to him , and saw a fox which had been caught in a trap placed there by the farmer .
15 In vain did the poor beast try to free itself ; then the good-natured Prince came once more to the rescue , and let the fox out of the trap .
16 The fox thanked him heartily , tore two hairs out of his bushy tail , and said : ` Should you ever stand in need of my help throw these two hairs into the fire , and in a moment I shall be at your side ready to obey you . '
17 Iwanich put the fox 's hairs with the scale and the feather , and as it was getting dark he hastened home with his horses .
18 In the meantime his service was drawing near to an end , and in three more days the year was up , and he would be able to get his reward and leave the witch .

2 With what joy did he hurry now to his brothers ' house !
3 He burst into a room where they were all assembled , but no one knew who he was .
4 Only his bride , who was serving as cook to her sisters , recognised her lover at once .
5 His brothers , who had quite believed he was dead , yielded him up his treasures at once , and flew into the woods in terror .
6 But the good youth forgave them all they had done , and divided his treasures with them .
7 Then he built himself a big castle with golden windows , and there he lived happily with his golden-haired wife till the end of their lives .
8 THE BOY AND THE WOLVES , OR THE BROKEN PROMISE -LRB- 18 -RRB- -LRB- 18 -RRB- A North American Indian story .
9 Once upon a time an Indian hunter built himself a house in the middle of a great forest , far away from all his tribe ; for his heart was gentle and kind , and he was weary of the treachery and cruel deeds of those who had been his friends .
10 So he left them , and took his wife and three children , and they journeyed on until they found a spot near to a clear stream , where they began to cut down trees , and to make ready their wigwam .
11 For many years they lived peacefully and happily in this sheltered place , never leaving it except to hunt the wild animals , which served them both for food and clothes .
12 At last , however , the strong man felt sick , and before long he knew he must die .
13 So he gathered his family round him , and said his last words to them .
14 ` You , my wife , the companion of my days , will follow me ere many moons have waned to the island of the blest .
15 But for you , O my children , whose lives are but newly begun , the wickedness , unkindness , and ingratitude from which I fled are before you .
16 Yet I shall go hence in peace , my children , if you will promise always to love each other , and never to forsake your youngest brother .
17 ` Never ! '
18 they replied , holding out their hands .
19 And the hunter died content .
20 Scarcely eight moons had passed when , just as he had said , the wife went forth , and followed her husband ; but before leaving her children she bade the two elder ones think of their promise never to forsake the younger , for he was a child , and weak .
21 And while the snow lay thick upon the ground , they tended him and cherished him ; but when the earth showed green again , the XXXXX of the young man stirred within him , and he longed to see the wigwams of the village where his father 's youth was spent .	heart		O|brothers|companion|food|heart|ingratitude|joy|kind|man|middle

1 The following year Warza , the second brother , tried his luck , but with the same result .
2 Then it came to the turn of the third and youngest son .
3 Iwanich was not the least discouraged by the failure of his elder brothers , though they were both much older and stronger than he was , and when night came climbed up the tree as they had done , The moon had risen , and with her soft light lit up the whole neighbourhood , so that the observant Prince could distinguish the smallest object distinctly .
4 At midnight a gentle west wind shook the tree , and at the same moment a snow-white swan-like bird sank down gently on his breast .
5 The Prince hastily seized the bird 's wings in his hands , when , lo !
6 to his astonishment he found he was holding in his arms not a bird but the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
7 ` You need not fear Militza , ' said the beautiful girl , looking at the Prince with friendly eyes .
8 ` An evil magician has not robbed you of your fruit , but he stole the seed from my mother , and thereby caused her death .
9 When she was dying she bade me take the fruit , which you have no right to possess , from the trees every year as soon as it was ripe .
10 This I would have done to-night too , if you had not seized me with such force , and so broken the spell I was under . '
11 Iwanich , who had been prepared to meet a terrible magician and not a lovely girl , fell desperately in love with her .
12 They spent the rest of the night in pleasant conversation , and when Militza wished to go away he begged her not to leave him . '
13 I would gladly stay with you longer , ' said Militza , ` but a wicked witch once cut off a lock of my hair when I was asleep , which has put me in her power , and if morning were still to find me here she would do me some harm , and you , too , perhaps . '
14 Having said these words , she drew a sparkling diamond ring from her finger , which she handed to the Prince , saying : ` Keep this ring in memory of Militza , and think of her sometimes if you never see her again .
15 But if your love is really true , come and find me in my own kingdom .
16 I may not show you the way there , but this ring will guide you .
17 ` If you have love and courage enough to undertake this journey , whenever you come to a cross-road always look at this diamond before you settle which way you are going to take .
18 If it sparkles as brightly as ever go straight on , but if its lustre is dimmed choose another path . '
19 Then Militza bent over the Prince and kissed him on his forehead , and before he had time to say a word she vanished through the branches of the tree in a little white cloud .
20 Morning broke , and the Prince , still full of the wonderful apparition , left his perch and returned to the palace like one in a dream , without even knowing if the fruit had been taken or not ; for his whole mind was absorbed by thoughts of Militza and how he was to find her .

1 When she was gone the King felt how much he had loved her , and his grief was so great -LRB- though he never neglected his duties -RRB- that his subjects called him Peridor the Sorrowful .
2 It seems hardly possible that any man should live like Peridor for fifteen years plunged in such depth of grief , and most likely he would have died too if it had not been for the fairies .
3 The one comfort the poor King had was his son , Prince Saphir , who was only three years old at the time of his mother 's death , and great care was given to his education .
4 By the time he was fifteen Saphir had learnt everything that a prince should know , and he was , besides , charming and agreeable .
5 It was about this time that the fairies suddenly took fright lest his love for his father should interfere with the plans they had made for the young prince .
6 So , to prevent this , they placed in a pretty little room of which Saphir was very fond a little mirror in a black frame , such as were often brought from Venice .
7 The Prince did not notice for some days that there was anything new in the room , but at last he perceived it , and went up to look at it more closely .
8 What was his surprise to see reflected in the mirror , not his own face , but that of a young girl as lovely as the morning !
9 And , better still , every movement of the girl , just growing out of childhood , was also reflected in the wonderful glass .
10 As might have been expected , the young Prince lost his heart completely to the beautiful image , and it was impossible to get him out of the room , so busy was he in watching the lovely unknown .
11 Certainly it was very delightful to be able to see her whom he loved at any moment he chose , but his spirits sometimes sank when he wondered what was to be the end of this adventure .
12 The magic mirror had been for about a year in the Prince 's possession , when one day a new subject of disquiet seized upon him .
13 As usual , he was engaged in looking at the girl , when suddenly he thought he saw a second mirror reflected in the first , exactly like his own , and with the same power .
14 And in this he was perfectly right .
15 The young girl had only possessed it for a short time , and neglected all her duties for the sake of the mirror .
16 Now it was not difficult for Saphir to guess the reason of the change in her , nor why the new mirror was consulted so often ; but try as he would he could never see the face of the person who was reflected in it , for the young girl 's figure always came between .
17 All he knew was that the face was that of a man , and this was quite enough to make him madly jealous .
18 This was the doing of the fairies , and we must suppose that they had their reasons for acting as they did .
19 When these things happened Saphir was about eighteen years old , and fifteen years had passed away since the death of his mother .
20 King Peridor had grown more and more unhappy as time went on , and at last he fell so ill that it seemed as if his days were numbered .
21 He was so much beloved by his XXXXX that this sad news was heard with despair by the nation , and more than all by the Prince .	subjects		anything|death|frame|glass|image|mirror|person|plans|room|subjects

4 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
5 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
6 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
7 And now everything was up above and only he himself remained below .
8 But as he was a little suspicious of his brothers , he fastened a heavy stone on to the rope and let them pull it up .
9 At first they heaved with a will , but when the stone was half way up they let it drop suddenly , and it fell to the bottom broken into a hundred pieces .
10 ` So that 's what would have happened to my bones had I trusted myself to them , ' said the youth sadly ; and he began to cry bitterly , not because of the treasures , but because of the lovely girl with her swanlike neck and golden hair .
11 For a long time he wandered sadly all through the beautiful underworld , and one day he met a magician who asked him the cause of his tears .

16 Now I have hidden them in the apple-tree ; hide yourself there too , and at midnight you will see my enemy . '

1 They fastened some of the burning pine-wood to the end of the rope , and let it slowly down to the bottom of the abyss .
2 At first it was quite dark , and the flaming torch only lit up dirty grey stone walls .
3 But the youngest brother determined to explore the abyss , and letting himself down by the rope he soon reached the bottom .
4 Here he found a lovely meadow full of green trees and exquisite flowers .
5 In the middle of the meadow stood a huge stone castle , with an iron gate leading to it , which was wide open .
6 Everything in the castle seemed to be made of copper , and the only inhabitant he could discover was a lovely girl , who was combing her golden hair ; and he noticed that whenever one of her hairs fell on the ground it rang out like pure metal .
7 The youth looked at her more closely , and saw that her skin was smooth and fair , her blue eyes bright and sparkling , and her hair as golden as the sun .
8 He fell in love with her on the spot , and kneeling at her feet , he implored her to become his wife .
9 The lovely girl accepted his proposal gladly ; but at the same time she warned him that she could never come up to the world above till her mother , the old witch , was dead .
10 And she went on to tell him that the only way in which the old creature could be killed was with the sword that hung up in the castle ; but the sword was so heavy that no one could lift it .
11 Then the youth went into a room in the castle where everything was made of silver , and here he found another beautiful girl , the sister of his bride .
12 She was combing her silver hair , and every hair that fell on the ground rang out like pure metal .
13 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
14 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
15 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
16 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .

6 The next time he went to hunt he took care not to go far , and came in quite early .

13 Then you will be well , and I can touch you . '

7 PRINCE RING -LRB- 30 -RRB- -LRB- 30 -RRB- From the Icelandic .
8 Once upon a time there was a King and his Queen in their kingdom .
9 They had one daughter , who was called Ingiborg , and one son , whose name was Ring .
10 He was less fond of adventures than men of rank usually were in those days , and was not famous for strength or feats of arms .
11 When he was twelve years old , one fine winter day he rode into the forest along with his men to enjoy himself .
12 They went on a long way , until they caught sight of a hind with a gold ring on its horns .
13 The Prince was eager to catch it , if possible , so they gave chase and rode on without stopping until all the horses began to founder beneath them .
14 At last the Prince 's horse gave way too , and then there came over them a darkness so black that they could no longer see the hind .
15 By this time they were far away from any house , and thought it was high time to be making their way home again , but they found they had got lost now .
16 At first they all kept together , but soon each began to think that he knew the right way best ; so they separated , and all went in different directions .
17 The Prince , too , had got lost like the rest , and wandered on for a time until he came to a little clearing in the forest not far from the sea , where he saw a woman sitting on a chair and a big barrel standing beside her .
18 The Prince went up to her and saluted her politely , and she received him very graciously .
19 He looked down into the barrel then , and saw lying at the bottom an unusually beautiful gold ring , which pleased him so much that he could not take his eyes off it .
20 The woman saw this , and said that he might have it if he would take the trouble to get it ; for which the Prince thanked her , and said it was at least worth trying .

4 They crept into the corn , but the army did not march on , but remained encamped close around them .
5 They sat for two days and two nights in the corn , and grew so hungry that they nearly died ; but if they were to venture out , it was certain death .
6 They said at last , ` What use was it our deserting ?
7 We must perish here miserably . '
8 Whilst they were speaking a fiery dragon came flying through the air .
9 It hovered near them , and asked why they were hidden there .
10 They answered , ` We are three soldiers , and have deserted because our pay was so small .
11 Now if we remain here we shall die of hunger , and if we move out we shall be strung up on the gallows . '
12 ` If you will serve me for seven years , ' said the dragon , I will lead you through the midst of the army so that no one shall catch you . '
13 ` We have no choice , and must take your offer , ' said they .
14 Then the dragon seized them in his claws , took them through the air over the army , and set them down on the earth a long way from it .

1 Besides , Kotick was a white seal .
2 `` What you must do , '' said old Sea Catch , after he had heard his son 's adventures , `` is to grow up and be a big seal like your father , and have a nursery on the beach , and then they will leave you alone .
3 In another five years you ought to be able to fight for yourself . ''
4 Even gentle Matkah , his mother , said : `` You will never be able to stop the killing .
5 Go and play in the sea , Kotick . ''
6 And Kotick went off and danced the Fire-dance with a very heavy little heart .
7 That autumn he left the beach as soon as he could , and set off alone because of a notion in his bullet-head .
8 He was going to find Sea Cow , if there was such a person in the sea , and he was going to find a quiet island with good firm beaches for seals to live on , where men could not get at them .
9 So he explored and explored by himself from the North to the South Pacific , swimming as much as three hundred miles in a day and a night .
10 He met with more adventures than can be told , and narrowly escaped being caught by the Basking Shark , and the Spotted Shark , and the Hammerhead , and he met all the untrustworthy ruffians that loaf up and down the seas , and the heavy polite fish , and the scarlet spotted scallops that are moored in one place for hundreds of years , and grow very proud of it ; but he never met Sea Cow , and he never found an island that he could fancy .
11 If the beach was good and hard , with a slope behind it for seals to play on , there was always the smoke of a whaler on the horizon , boiling down blubber , and Kotick knew what that meant .
12 Or else he could see that seals had once visited the island and been killed off , and Kotick knew that where men had come once they would come again .
13 He picked up with an old stumpy-tailed albatross , who told him that Kerguelen Island was the very place for peace and quiet , and when Kotick went down there he was all but smashed to pieces against some wicked black cliffs in a heavy sleet-storm with lightning and thunder .
14 Yet as he pulled out against the gale he could see that even there had once been a seal nursery .
15 And it was so in all the other islands that he visited .
16 Limmershin gave a long list of them , for he said that Kotick spent five seasons exploring , with a four months ' rest each year at Novastoshnah , when the holluschickie used to make fun of him and his imaginary islands .
17 He went to the Gallapagos , a horrid dry place on the Equator , where he was nearly baked to death ; he went to the Georgia Islands , the Orkneys , Emerald Island , Little Nightingale Island , Gough 's Island , Bouvet 's Island , the Crossets , and even to a little speck of an island south of the Cape of Good Hope .
18 But everywhere the People of the Sea told him the same things .
19 Seals had come to those islands once upon a time , but men had killed them all off .
20 Even when he swam thousands of miles out of the Pacific and got to a place called Cape Corrientes -LRB- that was when he was coming back from Gough 's Island -RRB- , he found a few hundred mangy seals on a rock and they told him that men came there too .
21 That nearly broke his heart , and he headed round the Horn back to his own beaches ; and on his way north he hauled out on an island full of green trees , where he found an old , old seal who was dying , and Kotick caught XXXXX for him and told him all his sorrows .	fish		Basking|Sea|fancy|fish|gale|horizon|island|miles|mother|seal

1 Her skin was tanned and coarsened , but the warm crimson blood glowed in her cheeks with a dusky richness , and her face was a perfect oval , with features chiselled in almost classic regularity of outline .
2 Telford had a curious experience at that moment .
3 He seemed to see , looking out from behind this external mask of degraded beauty , the semblance of what this woman might have been under more favouring circumstance of birth and environment , wherein her rich , passionate nature , potent for either good or evil , might have been trained and swayed aright until it had developed grandly out into the glorious womanhood the Creator must have planned for her .
4 He knew , as if by revelation , that this woman had nothing in common with the narrow , self-righteous souls of Rykman 's Corner .
5 Warped and perverted though her nature might be , she was yet far nobler than those who sat in judgement upon her .

8 The platform loungers had been silent during her call , but now the talk bubbled forth anew .
9 Telford was sick at heart as he drove swiftly away .
10 He felt for Min Palmer a pity he could not understand or analyze .

3 Once upon a time there was a peasant whose wife died , leaving him with two children -- twins -- a boy and a girl .
4 For some years the poor man lived on alone with the children , caring for them as best he could ; but everything in the house seemed to go wrong without a woman to look after it , and at last he made up his mind to marry again , feeling that a wife would bring peace and order to his household and take care of his motherless children .
5 So he married , and in the following years several children were born to him ; but peace and order did not come to the household .
6 For the step-mother was very cruel to the twins , and beat them , and half-starved them , and constantly drove them out of the house ; for her one idea was to get them out of the way .
7 All day she thought of nothing but how she should get rid of them ; and at last an evil idea came into her head , and she determined to send them out into the great gloomy wood where a wicked witch lived .
8 And so one morning she spoke to them , saying : ` You have been such good children that I am going to send you to visit my granny , who lives in a dear little hut in the wood .
9 You will have to wait upon her and serve her , but you will be well rewarded , for she will give you the best of everything . '
10 So the children left the house together ; and the little sister , who was very wise for her years , said to the brother : ` We will first go and see our own dear grandmother , and tell her where our step-mother is sending us . '

14 Now listen to me , children .
15 You must be civil and kind to everyone , and never say a cross word to anyone , and never touch a crumb belonging to anyone else .

1 Once upon a time there were a man and his wife who lived in the forest , very far from the rest of the tribe .
2 Very often they spent the day in hunting together , but after a while the wife found that she had so many things to do that she was obliged to stay at home ; so he went alone , though he found that when his wife was not with him he never had any luck .
3 One day , when he was away hunting , the woman fell ill , and in a few days she died .
4 Her husband grieved bitterly , and buried her in the house where she had passed her life ; but as the time went on he felt so lonely without her that he made a wooden doll about her height and size for company , and dressed it in her clothes .
5 He seated it in front of the fire , and tried to think he had his wife back again .
6 The next day he went out to hunt , and when he came home the first thing he did was to go up to the doll and brush off some of the ashes from the fire which had fallen on its face .
7 But he was very busy now , for he had to cook and mend , besides getting food , for there was no one to help him .
8 And so a whole year passed away .
9 At the end of that time he came back from hunting one night and found some wood by the door and a fire within .
10 The next night there was not only wood and fire , but a piece of meat in the kettle , nearly ready for eating .
11 He searched all about to see who could have done this , but could find no one .
12 The next time he went to hunt he took care not to go far , and came in quite early .
13 And while he was still a long way off he saw a woman going into the house with wood on her shoulders .
14 So he made haste , and opened the door quickly , and instead of the wooden doll , his wife sat in front of the fire .
15 Then she spoke to him and said , ` The Great Spirit felt sorry for you , because you would not be comforted , so he let me come back to you , but you must not stretch out your hand to touch me till we have seen the rest of our people .
16 If you do , I shall die . '
17 So the man listened to her words , and the woman dwelt there , and brought the wood and kindled the fire , till one day her husband said to her , ` It is now two years since you died .
18 Let us now go back to our tribe .
19 Then you will be well , and I can touch you . '
20 And with that he prepared food for the journey , a string of deer 's flesh for her to carry , and one for himself ; and so they started .

3 ` Well , ' said the first bird , ` the spring is not far from here .
4 Shall we go and see how it is she does it ? '
5 ` Willingly , if you like , ' said the other .
6 The youth immediately resolved to follow the birds to the spring , only two things made him uneasy : first , lest he might be asleep when the birds went , and secondly , lest he might lose sight of them , since he had not wings to carry him along so swiftly .
7 He was too tired to keep awake all night , yet his anxiety prevented him from sleeping soundly , and when with the earliest dawn he looked up to the tree-top , he was glad to see his feathered companions still asleep with their heads under their wings .
8 He ate his breakfast , and waited until the birds should start , but they did not leave the place all day .

1 I think I could , if I only know how to begin . '
2 For , you see , so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately , that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible .
3 There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door , so she went back to the table , half hoping she might find another key on it , or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes : this time she found a little bottle on it , -LRB- ` which certainly was not here before , ' said Alice , -RRB- and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label , with the words ` DRINK ME ' beautifully printed on it in large letters .
4 It was all very well to say ` Drink me , ' but the wise little Alice was not going to do THAT in a hurry .
5 ` No , I 'll look first , ' she said , ` and see whether it 's marked `` poison '' or not ' ; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt , and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things , all because they WOULD not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them : such as , that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long ; and that if you cut your finger VERY deeply with a knife , it usually bleeds ; and she had never forgotten that , if you drink much from a bottle marked ` poison , ' it is almost certain to disagree with you , sooner or later .
6 However , this bottle was NOT marked ` poison , ' so Alice ventured to taste it , and finding it very nice , -LRB- it had , in fact , a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart , custard , pine-apple , roast turkey , toffee , and hot buttered toast , -RRB- she very soon finished it off .
7 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * ` What a curious feeling ! '
8 said Alice ; ' I must be shutting up like a telescope . '
9 And so it was indeed : she was now only ten inches high , and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden .
10 First , however , she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further : she felt a little nervous about this ; ` for it might end , you know , ' said Alice to herself , ` in my going out altogether , like a candle .
11 I wonder what I should be like then ? '
12 And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out , for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing .
13 After a while , finding that nothing more happened , she decided on going into the garden at once ; but , alas for poor Alice !
14 when she got to the door , she found she had forgotten the little golden key , and when she went back to the table for it , she found she could not possibly reach it : she could see it quite plainly through the glass , and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table , but it was too slippery ; and when she had tired herself out with trying , the poor little thing sat down and cried .
15 ` Come , there 's no use in crying like that ! '
16 said Alice to herself , rather sharply ; ' I advise you to leave off this minute ! '
17 She generally gave herself very good advice , -LRB- though she very seldom followed it -RRB- , and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes ; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself , for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people .
18 ` But it 's no use now , ' thought poor Alice , ` to pretend to be two people !
19 Why , there 's hardly enough of me left to make ONE respectable person ! '
20 Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table : she opened it , and found in it a very small cake , on which the words ` EAT ME ' were beautifully marked in currants .
21 ` Well , I 'll eat it , ' said Alice , ` and if it makes me grow larger , I can reach the key ; and if it makes me grow smaller , I can creep under the door ; so either way I 'll get into the XXXXX , and I do n't care which happens ! '	garden		garden|half|hurry|inches|minute|sort|tears|telescope|thought|use

1 Now the Prince was about to marry another princess , for he thought she was dead long ago .
2 In the evening , when she had washed up and was ready , she felt in her pocket and found the three nuts which the old toad had given her .
3 She cracked one and was going to eat the kernel , when behold !
4 there was a beautiful royal dress inside it !
5 When the bride heard of this , she came and begged for the dress , and wanted to buy it , saying that it was not a dress for a serving-maid .
6 Then she said she would not sell it unless she was granted one favour -- namely , to sleep by the Prince 's door .
7 The bride granted her this , because the dress was so beautiful and she had so few like it .
8 When it was evening she said to her bridegroom , ` That stupid maid wants to sleep by your door . '
9 ` If you are contented , I am , ' he said .
10 But she gave him a glass of wine in which she had poured a sleeping-draught .
11 Then they both went to his room , but he slept so soundly that she could not wake him .
12 The maid wept all night long , and said , ' I freed you in the wild wood out of the iron stove ; I have sought you , and have crossed a glassy mountain , three sharp swords , and a great lake before I found you , and will you not hear me now ? '
13 The servants outside heard how she cried the whole night , and they told their master in the morning .
14 When she had washed up the next evening she bit the second nut , and there was a still more beautiful dress inside .
15 When the bride saw it she wanted to buy it also .
16 But the maid did not want money , and asked that she should sleep again by the Prince 's door .
17 The bride , however , gave him a sleeping-draught , and he slept so soundly that he heard nothing .
18 But the kitchen-maid wept the whole night long , and said , ' I have freed you in a wood and from an iron stove ; I sought you and have crossed a glassy mountain , three sharp swords , and a great lake to find you , and now you will not hear me ! '
19 The servants outside heard how she cried the whole night , and in the morning they told their master .
20 And when she had washed up on the third night she bit the third nut , and there was a still more beautiful dress inside that was made of pure gold .

1 It was surely no harm to run away from a place where you were treated so bad and where they did not seem to want you .
2 Chester felt bitter whenever he thought of Aunt Harriet .
3 Presently he found himself in the market square of Montrose .
4 It was market day , and the place was thronged with people from the surrounding country settlements .
5 Chester had hoped that he might pick up a few cents , holding a horse or cow for somebody or carrying a market basket , but no such chance offered itself .
6 He climbed up on some bales of pressed hay in one corner and sat there moodily ; there was dejection in the very dangle of his legs over the bales .
7 Chester , you see , was discovering what many a boy before him has discovered -- that it is a good deal easier to sit down and make a fortune in dreams than it is to go out into the world and make it .
8 Two men were talking to each other near him .
9 At first Chester gave no heed to their conversation , but presently a sentence made him prick up his ears .
10 `` Yes , there 's a pretty fair crop out at Hopedale , '' one man was saying , `` but whether it 's going to be got in in good shape is another matter .
11 It 's terrible hard to get any help .
12 Every spare man-jack far and wide has gone West on them everlasting harvest excursions .
13 Salome Whitney at the Mount Hope Farm is in a predicament .
14 She 's got a hired man , but he ca n't harvest grain all by himself .
15 She spent the whole of yesterday driving around , trying to get a couple of men or boys to help him , but I dunno if she got anyone or not . ''
16 The men moved out of earshot at this juncture , but Chester got down from the bales with a determined look .
17 If workers were wanted in Hopedale , that was the place for him .
18 He had done a man 's work at harvest time in Upton the year before .
19 Lige Barton had said so himself .
20 Hope and courage returned with a rush .
21 He accosted the first XXXXX he met and asked if he could tell him the way to Hopedale .	man		boy|conversation|crop|grain|harm|help|look|man|rush|workers

1 Take off your clothes and spread them on the path which leads from here to the castle .
2 The King will then glide over something soft , which he likes very much , and he will be so pleased with that that he will not devour you .
3 He will give you some punishment , but then he will let you go . '
4 The men did as the Lake advised them , and waited for a time .
5 At noon the earth began to quake , and opened in many places , and out of the openings appeared lions , tigers , and other wild beasts , which surrounded the castle , and thousands and thousands of beasts came out of the castle following their king , the Seven-headed Serpent .
6 The Serpent glided over the clothes which were spread for him , came to the Lake , and asked it who had strewed those soft things on the path ?
7 The Lake answered that it had been done by people who had come to do him homage .
8 The King commanded that the men should be brought before him .
9 They came humbly on their knees , and in a few words told him their story .
10 Then he spoke to them with a mighty and terrible voice , and said , ` Because you have dared to come here , I lay upon you the punishment .
11 Every year you must bring me from among your people twelve youths and twelve maidens , that I may devour them .
12 If you do not do this , I will destroy your whole nation . '
13 Then he desired one of his beasts to show the men the way out of the garden , and dismissed them .
14 They then left the island and went back to their own country , where they related what had happened to them .
15 Soon the time came round when the king of the beasts would expect the youths and maidens to be brought to him .
16 The King therefore issued a proclamation inviting twelve youths and twelve maidens to offer themselves up to save their country ; and immediately many young people , far more than enough , hastened to do so .
17 A new ship was built , and set with black sails , and in it the youths and maidens who were appointed for the king of the beasts embarked and set out for his country .
18 When they arrived there they went at once to the Lake , and this time the lions did not stir , nor did the springs flow , and neither did the Lake speak .
19 So they waited then , and it was not long before the earth quaked even more terribly than the first time .
20 The Seven-headed Serpent came without his train of beasts , saw his prey waiting for him , and devoured it at one mouthful .
21 Then the XXXXX 's crew returned home , and the same thing happened yearly until many years had passed .	ship		Serpent|beasts|country|earth|maidens|punishment|ship|story|voice|words

1 When the miller heard how friendly her tone was , he plucked up heart and told her how rich and prosperous he had been all his life up till now , when he did n't know what he was to do for want and misery .
2 Then the nixy spoke comforting words to him , and promised that she would make him richer and more prosperous than he had ever been in his life before , if he would give her in return the youngest thing in his house .
3 The miller thought she must mean one of his puppies or kittens , so promised the nixy at once what she asked , and returned to his mill full of hope .
4 On the threshold he was greeted by a servant with the news that his wife had just given birth to a boy .
5 The poor miller was much horrified by these tidings , and went in to his wife with a heavy heart to tell her and his relations of the fatal bargain he had just struck with the nixy . '
6 I would gladly give up all the good fortune she promised me , ' he said , ` if I could only save my child . '
7 But no one could think of any advice to give him , beyond taking care that the child never went near the mill-pond .
8 So the boy throve and grew big , and in the meantime all prospered with the miller , and in a few years he was richer than he had ever been before .
9 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
10 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
11 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
12 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
13 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
14 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
15 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
16 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
17 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
18 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
19 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
20 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
21 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the XXXXX 's power to help her .	witch		care|childhood|happiness|morning|peace|round|shot|waves|witch|words

1 But this time he was not alone , and he had not to make his path .
2 That was made already , six feet wide , in front of him , where the bent jungle-grass was trying to recover itself and stand up .
3 Many elephants must have gone that way only a few minutes before .
4 Little Toomai looked back , and behind him a great wild tusker with his little pig 's eyes glowing like hot coals was just lifting himself out of the misty river .
5 Then the trees closed up again , and they went on and up , with trumpetings and crashings , and the sound of breaking branches on every side of them .
6 At last Kala Nag stood still between two tree-trunks at the very top of the hill .
7 They were part of a circle of trees that grew round an irregular space of some three or four acres , and in all that space , as Little Toomai could see , the ground had been trampled down as hard as a brick floor .
8 Some trees grew in the center of the clearing , but their bark was rubbed away , and the white wood beneath showed all shiny and polished in the patches of moonlight .
9 There were creepers hanging from the upper branches , and the bells of the flowers of the creepers , great waxy white things like convolvuluses , hung down fast asleep .
10 But within the limits of the clearing there was not a single blade of green -- nothing but the trampled earth .
11 The moonlight showed it all iron gray , except where some elephants stood upon it , and their shadows were inky black .
12 Little Toomai looked , holding his breath , with his eyes starting out of his head , and as he looked , more and more and more elephants swung out into the open from between the tree trunks .
13 Little Toomai could only count up to ten , and he counted again and again on his fingers till he lost count of the tens , and his head began to swim .
14 Outside the clearing he could hear them crashing in the undergrowth as they worked their way up the hillside , but as soon as they were within the circle of the tree trunks they moved like ghosts .
15 There were white-tusked wild males , with fallen leaves and nuts and twigs lying in the wrinkles of their necks and the folds of their ears ; fat , slow-footed she-elephants , with restless , little pinky black calves only three or four feet high running under their stomachs ; young elephants with their tusks just beginning to show , and very proud of them ; lanky , scraggy old-maid elephants , with their hollow anxious faces , and trunks like rough bark ; savage old bull elephants , scarred from shoulder to flank with great weals and cuts of bygone fights , and the caked dirt of their solitary mud baths dropping from their shoulders ; and there was one with a broken tusk and the marks of the full-stroke , the terrible drawing scrape , of a tiger 's claws on his side .
16 They were standing head to head , or walking to and fro across the ground in couples , or rocking and swaying all by themselves -- scores and scores of elephants .
17 Toomai knew that so long as he lay still on Kala Nag 's neck nothing would happen to him , for even in the rush and scramble of a Keddah drive a wild elephant does not reach up with his trunk and drag a man off the neck of a tame elephant .
18 And these elephants were not thinking of men that night .
19 Once they started and put their ears forward when they heard the chinking of a leg iron in the forest , but it was Pudmini , Petersen Sahib 's pet elephant , her chain snapped short off , grunting , snuffling up the hillside .
20 She must have broken her pickets and come straight from Petersen Sahib 's camp ; and Little Toomai saw another elephant , one that he did not know , with deep rope galls on his back and breast .
21 He , too , must have run away from some XXXXX in the hills about .	camp		breast|calves|camp|circle|ears|fat|hill|nothing|part|things

1 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
2 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
3 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
4 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
5 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
6 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
7 As soon as her feet touched the ground she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .
8 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
9 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
10 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
11 And now everything was up above and only he himself remained below .
12 But as he was a little suspicious of his brothers , he fastened a heavy stone on to the rope and let them pull it up .
13 At first they heaved with a will , but when the stone was half way up they let it drop suddenly , and it fell to the bottom broken into a hundred pieces .
14 ` So that 's what would have happened to my bones had I trusted myself to them , ' said the youth sadly ; and he began to cry bitterly , not because of the treasures , but because of the lovely girl with her swanlike neck and golden hair .
15 For a long time he wandered sadly all through the beautiful underworld , and one day he met a magician who asked him the cause of his tears .
16 The youth told him all that had befallen him , and the magician said : ` Do not grieve , young man !
17 If you will guard the children who are hidden in the golden apple-tree , I will bring you at once up to the earth .
18 Another magician who lives in this land always eats my children up .
19 It is in vain that I have hidden them under the earth and locked them into the castle .
20 Now I have hidden them in the apple-tree ; hide yourself there too , and at midnight you will see my enemy . '

1 ` Then you should say what you mean , ' the March Hare went on . '
2 I do , ' Alice hastily replied ; ` at least -- at least I mean what I say -- that 's the same thing , you know . '
3 ` Not the same thing a bit ! '
4 said the Hatter .
5 ` You might just as well say that `` I see what I eat '' is the same thing as `` I eat what I see '' ! '
6 ` You might just as well say , ' added the March Hare , ` that `` I like what I get '' is the same thing as `` I get what I like '' ! '
7 ` You might just as well say , ' added the Dormouse , who seemed to be talking in his sleep , ` that `` I breathe when I sleep '' is the same thing as `` I sleep when I breathe '' ! '
8 ` It IS the same thing with you , ' said the Hatter , and here the conversation dropped , and the party sat silent for a minute , while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks , which was n't much .
9 The Hatter was the first to break the silence .
10 ` What day of the month is it ? '
11 he said , turning to Alice : he had taken his watch out of his pocket , and was looking at it uneasily , shaking it every now and then , and holding it to his ear .

13 ` Two days wrong ! '
14 sighed the Hatter . '
15 I told you butter would n't suit the works ! '
16 he added looking angrily at the March Hare .
17 ` It was the BEST butter , ' the March Hare meekly replied .
18 ` Yes , but some crumbs must have got in as well , ' the Hatter grumbled : ` you should n't have put it in with the bread-knife . '
19 The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily : then he dipped it into his cup of tea , and looked at it again : but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark , ` It was the BEST butter , you know . '
20 Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity .

3 I loved and watched you day and night -- You were my joy , my one delight . '

5 Listen to that White Duck . '
6 But the witch answered , ` My dear husband , what do you mean ?
7 There is nothing wonderful in a duck 's quacking .
8 Here , servants !
9 Chase that duck out of the courtyard . '
10 But though the servants chased and chevied , they could not get rid of the duck ; for she circled round and round , and always came back to the spot where her children lay , crying : ` Quack , quack -- my little loves !
11 Quack , quack -- my turtle-doves !
12 The wicked witch your lives did take -- The wicked witch , the cunning snake .
13 First she stole my King away , Then my children did she slay .
14 Changed me , from a happy wife , To a duck for all my life .
15 Would I were the Queen again ; Would that you had never been slain . '

2 All his friends immediately recognised him again , and paid him great court .
3 One day he thought to himself : ` It is very strange that no one can get to see the Princess .
4 They all say she is very pretty , but what 's the use of that if she has to sit for ever in the great copper castle with all the towers ?
5 Can I not manage to see her somehow ?
6 Where is my tinder-box ? '
7 and so he struck a spark , and , presto !
8 there came the dog with eyes as large as saucers .
9 ` It is the middle of the night , I know , ' said the Soldier ; ` but I should very much like to see the Princess for a moment . '
10 The dog was already outside the door , and before the Soldier could look round , in he came with the Princess .
11 She was lying asleep on the dog 's back , and was so beautiful that anyone could see she was a real Princess .
12 The Soldier really could not refrain from kissing her -- he was such a thorough Soldier .
13 Then the dog ran back with the Princess .
14 But when it was morning , and the King and Queen were drinking tea , the Princess said that the night before she had had such a strange dream about a dog and a Soldier : she had ridden on the dog 's back , and the Soldier had kissed her .
15 ` That is certainly a fine story , ' said the Queen .
16 But the next night one of the ladies-in-waiting was to watch at the Princess 's bed , to see if it was only a dream , or if it had actually happened .

1 But when the doors were opened , there stood all Six , alive and well , saying they were glad they could come out to warm themselves , for the great cold in the room had frozen all the food hard in the dishes .
2 Then the King went angrily to the cook , and scolded him , and asked him why he had not done what he was told .
3 But the cook answered , ` There is heat enough there ; see for yourself . '
4 Then the King saw a huge fire burning under the iron room , and understood that he could do no harm to the Six in this way .
5 The King now began again to think how he could free himself from his unwelcome guests .
6 He commanded the master to come before him , and said , ` If you will take gold , and give up your right to my daughter , you shall have as much as you like . '
7 ` Oh , yes , your Majesty , ' answered he , ` give me as much as my servant can carry , and I will give up your daughter . '
8 The King was delighted , and the man said , ' I will come and fetch it in fourteen days . '
9 Then he called all the tailors in the kingdom together , and made them sit down for fourteen days sewing at a sack .
10 When it was finished , he made the strong man who had uprooted the trees take the sack on his shoulder and go with him to the King .
11 Then the King said , ` What a powerful fellow that is , carrying that bale of linen as large as a house on his shoulder ! '
12 and he was much frightened , and thought ` What a lot of gold he will make away with ! '
13 Then he had a ton of gold brought , which sixteen of the strongest men had to carry ; but the strong man seized it with one hand , put it in the sack , saying , ` Why do n't you bring me more ?
14 That scarcely covers the bottom ! '
15 Then the King had to send again and again to fetch his treasures , which the strong man shoved into the sack , and the sack was only half full .
16 ` Bring more , ' he cried , ` these crumbs do n't fill it . '
17 So seven thousand waggons of the gold of the whole kingdom were driven up ; these the strong man shoved into the sack , oxen and all . '
18 I will no longer be particular , ' he said , ` and will take what comes , so that the sack shall be full . '
19 When everything was put in and there was not yet enough , he said , ' I will make an end of this ; it is easy to fasten a sack when it is not full . '
20 Then he threw it on his back and went with his companions .

12 Nevertheless , he felt strangely interested .
13 This Min Palmer must at least be different from the rest of the Cornerites , if only in the greater force of her wickedness .
14 He almost felt as if her sins on the grand scale were less blameworthy than the petty vices of her censorious neighbours .
15 Galletly eagerly joined the group of loungers on the dirty wet platform , and Telford passed into the store .
16 A couple of slatternly women were talking to Mrs. Rykman about `` the Palmer row . ''
17 Telford made his small purchases hastily .
18 As he turned from the counter , he came face to face with a woman who had paused in the doorway to survey the scene with an air of sullen scorn .
19 By some subtle intuition Telford knew that this was Min Palmer .
20 The young man 's first feeling was one of admiration for the woman before him , who , in spite of her grotesque attire and defiant , unwomanly air , was strikingly beautiful .
21 She was tall , and not even the XXXXX 's ragged overcoat which she wore could conceal the grace of her figure .	man		Mr.|admiration|couple|intuition|man|ministers|platform|shoulder|spite|women

1 He was too tired to go any farther , when happily he discovered a little way off a bubbling fountain of the clearest water .
2 Being an experienced traveller , he drew from his pocket a little cup -LRB- without which no one should ever take a journey -RRB- , and was just about to dip it in the water , when a lovely little green frog , much prettier than frogs generally are , jumped into the cup .
3 Far from admiring its beauty , Saphir shook it impatiently off ; but it was no good , for quick as lightning the frog jumped back again .
4 Saphir , who was raging with thirst , was just about to shake it off anew , when the little creature fixed upon him the most beautiful eyes in the world , and said , ' I am a friend of the bird you are seeking , and when you have quenched your thirst listen to me . '
5 So the Prince drank his fill , and then , by the command of the Little Green Frog , he lay down on the grass to rest himself .
6 ` Now , ' she began , ` be sure you do exactly in every respect what I tell you .
7 First you must call together your attendants , and order them to remain in a little hamlet close by until you want them .
8 Then go , quite alone , down a road that you will find on your right hand , looking southwards .
9 This road is planted all the way with cedars of Lebanon ; and after going down it a long way you will come at last to a magnificent castle .
10 And now , ' she went on , ` attend carefully to what I am going to say .
11 Take this tiny grain of sand , and put it into the ground as close as you can to the gate of the castle .
12 It has the virtue both of opening the gate and also of sending to sleep all the inhabitants .
13 Then go at once to the stable , and pay no heed to anything except what I tell you .
14 Choose the handsomest of all the horses , leap quickly on its back , and come to me as fast as you can .
15 Farewell , Prince ; I wish you good luck , ' and with these words the Little Frog plunged into the water and disappeared .
16 The Prince , who felt more hopeful than he had done since he left home , did precisely as he had been ordered .
17 He left his attendants in the hamlet , found the road the frog had described to him , and followed it all alone , and at last he arrived at the gate of the castle , which was even more splendid than he had expected , for it was built of crystal , and all its ornaments were of massive gold .
18 However , he had no thoughts to spare for its beauty , and quickly buried his grain of sand in the earth .
19 In one instant the gates flew open , and all the dwellers inside fell sound asleep .
20 Saphir flew straight to the stable , and already had his hand on the finest horse it contained , when his eye was caught by a suit of magnificent harness hanging up close by .
21 It occurred to him directly that the XXXXX belonged to the horse , and without ever thinking of harm -LRB- for indeed he who steals a horse can hardly be blamed for taking his saddle -RRB- , he hastily placed it on the animal 's back .	harness		command|crystal|cup|frogs|gate|harness|respect|road|virtue|water

1 THE STORY OF KING FROST -LRB- 26 -RRB- -LRB- 26 -RRB- From the Russian .
2 There was once upon a time a peasant-woman who had a daughter and a step-daughter .
3 The daughter had her own way in everything , and whatever she did was right in her mother 's eyes ; but the poor step-daughter had a hard time .
4 Let her do what she would , she was always blamed , and got small thanks for all the trouble she took ; nothing was right , everything wrong ; and yet , if the truth were known , the girl was worth her weight in gold -- she was so unselfish and good-hearted .
5 But her step-mother did not like her , and the poor girl 's days were spent in weeping ; for it was impossible to live peacefully with the woman .
6 The wicked shrew was determined to get rid of the girl by fair means or foul , and kept saying to her father : ` Send her away , old man ; send her away -- anywhere so that my eyes sha 'n' t be plagued any longer by the sight of her , or my ears tormented by the sound of her voice .
7 Send her out into the fields , and let the cutting frost do for her . '
8 In vain did the poor old father weep and implore her pity ; she was firm , and he dared not gainsay her .
9 So he placed his daughter in a sledge , not even daring to give her a horse-cloth to keep herself warm with , and drove her out on to the bare , open fields , where he kissed her and left her , driving home as fast as he could , that he might not witness her miserable death .
10 Deserted by her father , the poor girl sat down under a fir-tree at the edge of the forest and began to weep silently .
11 Suddenly she heard a faint sound : it was King Frost springing from tree to tree , and cracking his fingers as he went .
12 At length he reached the fir-tree beneath which she was sitting , and with a crisp crackling sound he alighted beside her , and looked at her lovely face .
13 ` Well , maiden , ' he snapped out , ` do you know who I am ?
14 I am King Frost , king of the red-noses . '
15 ` All hail to you , great King ! '
16 answered the girl , in a gentle , trembling voice .
17 ` Have you come to take me ? '
18 ` Are you warm , maiden ? '
19 he replied .
20 ` Quite warm , King Frost , ' she answered , though she shivered as she spoke .
21 Then King Frost stooped down , and bent over the girl , and the crackling XXXXX grew louder , and the air seemed to be full of knives and darts ; and again he asked : ` Maiden , are you warm ?	sound		death|edge|everything|eyes|girl|hail|king|maiden|man|sound

1 She felt as though she should certainly expire , and it was with some difficulty that she dragged herself as far as a pretty little green and white house , which stood at no great distance .
2 Here she was received by a beautiful lady dressed in green and white to match the house , which apparently belonged to her , and of which she seemed the only inhabitant .
3 She greeted the fainting Princess most kindly , gave her an excellent supper , and after a long night 's rest in a delightful bed told her that after many troubles she should finally attain her desire .
4 As the green and white lady took leave of the Princess she gave her a nut , desiring her only to open it in the most urgent need .
5 After a long and tiring journey Fairer-than-a-Fairy was once more received in a house , and by a lady exactly like the one she had quitted .
6 Here again she received a present with the same injunctions , but instead of a nut this lady gave her a golden pomegranate .
7 The mournful Princess had to continue her weary way , and after many troubles and hardships she again found rest and shelter in a third house exactly similar to the two others .
8 These houses belonged to three sisters , all endowed with fairy gifts , and all so alike in mind and person that they wished their houses and garments to be equally alike .
9 Their occupation consisted in helping those in misfortune , and they were as gentle and benevolent as Lagree had been cruel and spiteful .
10 The third Fairy comforted the poor traveller , begged her not to lose heart , and assured her that her troubles should be rewarded .
11 She accompanied her advice by the gift of a crystal smelling-bottle , with strict orders only to open it in case of urgent need .
12 Fairer-than-a-Fairy thanked her warmly , and resumed her way cheered by pleasant thoughts .
13 After a time her road led through a wood , full of soft airs and sweet odours , and before she had gone a hundred yards she saw a wonderful silver Castle suspended by strong silver chains to four of the largest trees .
14 It was so perfectly hung that a gentle breeze rocked it sufficiently to send you pleasantly to sleep .
15 Fairer-than-a-Fairy felt a strong desire to enter this Castle , but besides being hung a little above the ground there seemed to be neither doors nor windows .
16 She had no doubt -LRB- though really I can not think why -RRB- that the moment had come in which to use the nut which had been given her .
17 She opened it , and out came a diminutive hall porter at whose belt hung a tiny chain , at the end of which was a golden key half as long as the smallest pin you ever saw .
18 The Princess climbed up one of the silver chains , holding in her hand the little porter who , in spite of his minute size , opened a secret door with his golden key and let her in .
19 She entered a magnificent room which appeared to occupy the entire Castle , and which was lighted by gold and jewelled stars in the ceiling .
20 In the midst of this room stood a couch , draped with curtains of all the colours of the rainbow , and suspended by golden cords so that it swayed with the Castle in a manner which rocked its occupant delightfully to sleep .
21 On this elegant XXXXX lay Prince Rainbow , looking more beautiful than ever , and sunk in profound slumber , in which he had been held ever since his disappearance .	couch		advice|couch|distance|gift|ground|manner|midst|nut|occupation|sisters

1 ` Well , if that is the case , ' said the manikin , ` sit down beside me ; we can rest for a little and have something to eat .
2 Give me what you have got in your satchel . '
3 Now , the poor Simpleton was ashamed to show what was in it .
4 However , he thought it best not to make a fuss , so he opened the satchel , and could scarcely believe his own eyes , for , instead of the hard crust , he saw two beautiful fresh rolls and some cold meat .
5 He shared them with the manikin , who licked his lips and said : ` Now , go into that wood , and stop in front of the first tree , bow three times , and then strike the tree with your axe , fall on your knees on the ground , with your face on the earth , and remain there till you are raised up .
6 You will then find a ship at your side , step into it and fly to the King 's Palace .
7 If you meet anyone on the way , take him with you . '
8 The Simpleton thanked the manikin very kindly , bade him farewell , and went into the road .
9 When he got to the first tree he stopped in front of it , did everything just as he had been told , and , kneeling on the ground with his face to the earth , fell asleep .
10 After a little time he was aroused ; he awoke and , rubbing his eyes , saw a ready-made ship at his side , and at once got into it .
11 And the ship rose and rose , and in another minute was flying through the air , when the Simpleton , who was on the look out , cast his eyes down to the earth and saw a man beneath him on the road , who was kneeling with his ear upon the damp ground .
12 ` Hallo ! '
13 he called out , ` what are you doing down there ? ' '
14 I am listening to what is going on in the world , ' replied the man .
15 ` Come with me in my ship , ' said the Simpleton .
16 So the man was only too glad , and got in beside him ; and the ship flew , and flew , and flew through the air , till again from his outlook the Simpleton saw a man on the road below , who was hopping on one leg , while his other leg was tied up behind his ear .
17 So he hailed him , calling out : ` Hallo !
18 what are you doing , hopping on one leg ? ' '
19 I ca n't help it , ' replied the man . '
20 I walk so fast that unless I tied up one leg I should be at the end of the earth in a bound . '
21 ` Come with us on my ship , ' he answered ; and the man made no objections , but joined them ; and the ship flew on , and on , and on , till suddenly the Simpleton , looking down on the road below , beheld a XXXXX aiming with a gun into the distance .	man		ear|earth|knees|leg|look|man|meat|time|tree|wood

1 He determined to be thorough , and he went straight into every place of business he came to , from a blacksmith 's forge to a department store , and boldly asked the first person he met if they wanted a boy there .
2 There was , however , one class of places Chester shunned determinedly .
3 He never went into a liquor saloon .
4 The last winter he had been allowed to go to school in Upton , his teacher had been a pale , patient little woman who hated the liquor traffic with all her heart .
5 She herself had suffered bitterly through it , and she instilled into her pupils a thorough aversion to it .
6 Chester would have chosen death by starvation before he would have sought for employment in a liquor saloon .
7 But there certainly did not seem room for him anywhere else .
8 Nobody wanted a boy .
9 The answer to his question was invariably `` No . ''
10 As the day wore on , Chester 's hopes and courage went down to zero , but he still tramped doggedly about .
11 He would be thorough , at least .
12 Surely somewhere in this big place , where everyone seemed so busy , there must be something for him to do .
13 Once there seemed a chance of success .
14 He had gone into a big provision store and asked the clerk behind the counter if they wanted a boy .

16 However , come in and see the boss . ''

1 `` All that Baloo has said about the Bandar-log is true , '' he thought to himself .
2 `` They have no Law , no Hunting Call , and no leaders -- nothing but foolish words and little picking thievish hands .
3 So if I am starved or killed here , it will be all my own fault .
4 But I must try to return to my own jungle .
5 Baloo will surely beat me , but that is better than chasing silly rose leaves with the Bandar-log . ''
6 No sooner had he walked to the city wall than the monkeys pulled him back , telling him that he did not know how happy he was , and pinching him to make him grateful .
7 He set his teeth and said nothing , but went with the shouting monkeys to a terrace above the red sandstone reservoirs that were half-full of rain water .
8 There was a ruined summer-house of white marble in the center of the terrace , built for queens dead a hundred years ago .
9 The domed roof had half fallen in and blocked up the underground passage from the palace by which the queens used to enter .
10 But the walls were made of screens of marble tracery -- beautiful milk-white fretwork , set with agates and cornelians and jasper and lapis lazuli , and as the moon came up behind the hill it shone through the open work , casting shadows on the ground like black velvet embroidery .
11 Sore , sleepy , and hungry as he was , Mowgli could not help laughing when the Bandar-log began , twenty at a time , to tell him how great and wise and strong and gentle they were , and how foolish he was to wish to leave them .
12 `` We are great .
13 We are free .
14 We are wonderful .
15 We are the most wonderful people in all the jungle !
16 We all say so , and so it must be true , '' they shouted .
17 `` Now as you are a new listener and can carry our words back to the Jungle-People so that they may notice us in future , we will tell you all about our most excellent selves . ''
18 Mowgli made no objection , and the monkeys gathered by hundreds and hundreds on the terrace to listen to their own speakers singing the praises of the Bandar-log , and whenever a speaker stopped for want of breath they would all shout together : `` This is true ; we all say so . ''
19 Mowgli nodded and blinked , and said `` Yes '' when they asked him a question , and his head spun with the noise .
20 `` Tabaqui the Jackal must have bitten all these people , '' he said to himself , `` and now they have madness .
21 Certainly this is dewanee , the XXXXX .	madness		head|madness|marble|objection|palace|queens|question|terrace|words|years

3 There they were married , and they remained in the castle , which was much larger than that of the Princess 's father 's .
4 But because the old man did not like being left alone , they went and fetched him .
5 So they had two kingdoms and lived in great wealth .
6 A mouse has run , My story 's done .
7 THE DRAGON AND HIS GRANDMOTHER There was once a great war , and the King had a great many soldiers , but he gave them so little pay that they could not live upon it .
8 Then three of them took counsel together and determined to desert .
9 One of them said to the others , ` If we are caught , we shall be hanged on the gallows ; how shall we set about it ? '
10 The other said , ` Do you see that large cornfield there ?
11 If we were to hide ourselves in that , no one could find us .
12 The army can not come into it , and to-morrow it is to march on . '
13 They crept into the corn , but the army did not march on , but remained encamped close around them .
14 They sat for two days and two nights in the corn , and grew so hungry that they nearly died ; but if they were to venture out , it was certain death .
15 They said at last , ` What use was it our deserting ?
16 We must perish here miserably . '
17 Whilst they were speaking a fiery dragon came flying through the air .
18 It hovered near them , and asked why they were hidden there .
19 They answered , ` We are three soldiers , and have deserted because our pay was so small .
20 Now if we remain here we shall die of hunger , and if we move out we shall be strung up on the gallows . '
21 ` If you will serve me for seven years , ' said the dragon , I will lead you through the midst of the army so that no XXXXX shall catch you . '	one		air|army|corn|counsel|dragon|father|kingdoms|one|pay|wealth

5 Ferko wandered out into the fields again , and sat down on the stump of a tree wondering what he should do next .
6 Suddenly a big wolf ran up to him , and standing still said , ` I 'm very glad to see you again , my kind benefactor .
7 What are you thinking about all alone by yourself ?
8 If I can help you in any way only say the word , for I would like to give you a proof of my gratitude . '
9 Ferko at once recognised the wolf whose broken leg he had healed , and told him what he had to do the following day if he wished to escape with his life .
10 ` But how in the world , ' he added , ` am I to collect all the wolves of the kingdom on to that hill over there ? '
11 ` If that 's all you want done , ' answered the wolf , ` you need n't worry yourself .
12 I 'll undertake the task , and you 'll hear from me again before sunset to-morrow .
13 Keep your spirits up . '
14 And with these words he trotted quickly away .
15 Then the youth rejoiced greatly , for now he felt that his life was safe ; but he grew very sad when he thought of the beautiful Princess , and that he would never see her again if he left the country .
16 He lay down once more on the grass and soon fell fast asleep .
17 All the next day he spent wandering about the fields , and toward evening the wolf came running to him in a great hurry and said , ' I have collected together all the wolves in the kingdom , and they are waiting for you in the wood .
18 Go quickly to the King , and tell him to go to the hill that he may see the wonder you have done with his own eyes .
19 Then return at once to me and get on my back , and I will help you to drive all the wolves together . '
20 Then Ferko went straight to the palace and told the King that he was ready to perform the third task if he would come to the hill and see it done .

1 She smiled promptly at him -- a smile that seemed fairly to irradiate her round face -- and then began fumbling in an old-fashioned reticule she carried , and from which she presently extracted a chubby little paper bag .
2 `` If you like candy , little boy , '' she said to Chester , `` here is some of my sugar taffy for you . ''
3 Chester did not exactly like being called a little boy .
4 But her voice and smile were irresistible and won his heart straightway .
5 He took the candy with a shy , `` Thank you , ma'am , '' and sat holding it in his hand .
6 `` Eat it , '' commanded the rosy lady authoritatively .
7 `` That is what taffy is for , you know . ''
8 So Chester ate it .
9 It was the most delicious thing he had ever tasted in his life , and filled a void which even the crackers and cheese had left vacant .
10 The rosy lady watched every mouthful he ate as if she enjoyed it more than he did .
11 When he had finished the taffy she smiled one of her sociable smiles again and said , `` Well , what do you think of it ? ''
12 `` It 's the nicest taffy I ever ate , '' answered Chester enthusiastically , as if he were a connoisseur in all kinds of taffies .
13 The rosy lady nodded , well pleased .
14 `` That is just what everyone says about my sugar taffy .
15 Nobody up our way can match it , though goodness knows they try hard enough .
16 My great-grandmother invented the recipe herself , and it has been in our family ever since .
17 I 'm real glad you liked it . ''
18 She smiled at him again , as if his appreciation of her taffy was a bond of good fellowship between them .
19 She did not know it but , nevertheless , she was filling the heart of a desperate small boy , who had run away from home , with hope and encouragement and self-reliance .
20 If there were such kind folks as this in the world , why , he would get along all right .

1 `` I do n't care -- I do n't care ! ''

3 When twilight came she went out to the front steps and leaned her aching head against the honeysuckle trellis .
4 The sun had just set and the whole world swam in dusky golden light .
5 The wonderful beauty frightened her .
6 She felt like a blot on it .
7 While she stood there , a buggy came driving up the lane and wheeled about at the steps .
8 In it was Spencer Morgan .
9 Estella saw him and , in spite of the maddening throb of hope that seemed suddenly to transfigure the world for her , her pride rose in arms .
10 Had Spencer come the night before , he would have found her loving and humble .
11 Even now , had she but been sure that he had come to see her , she would have unbent .
12 But was it the other ?
13 The torturing doubt stung her to the quick .
14 She waited , stubbornly resolved that she would not speak first .
15 It was not in her place .
