1 The King 's daughter often dreamed that her husband was going through some great suffering : she therefore begged her father to summon all the enchanters and magicians , that they might try to find out where the Prince was and how he could be set free .
2 But the magicians , with all their arts , could find out nothing , except that he was still living and undergoing great suffering ; but none could tell where he was to be found .
3 At last a celebrated magician from Finland was brought before the King , who had found out that the King 's son-in-law was imprisoned in the East , not by men , but by some more powerful being .
4 The King now sent messengers to the East to look for his son-in-law , and they by good luck met with the old magician who had interpreted the signs on King Solomon 's ring , and thus was possessed of more wisdom than anyone else in the world .
5 The magician soon found out what he wished to know , and pointed out the place where the Prince was imprisoned , but said : ` He is kept there by enchantment , and can not be set free without my help .
6 I will therefore go with you myself . '
7 So they all set out , guided by birds , and after some days came to the cave where the unfortunate Prince had been chained up for nearly seven years .
8 He recognised the magician immediately , but the old man did not know him , he had grown so thin .
9 However , he undid the chains by the help of magic , and took care of the Prince until he recovered and became strong enough to travel .
10 When he reached home he found that the old King had died that morning , so that he was now raised to the throne .
11 And now after his long suffering came prosperity , which lasted to the end of his life ; but he never got back the magic ring , nor has it ever again been seen by mortal eyes .
12 Now , if YOU had been the Prince , would you not rather have stayed with the pretty witch-maiden ?
13 STORY OF THE EMPEROR 'S NEW CLOTHES -LRB- 4 -RRB- -LRB- 4 -RRB- Andersen .
14 Many years ago there lived an Emperor who was so fond of new clothes that he spent all his money on them in order to be beautifully dressed .
15 He did not care about his soldiers , he did not care about the theatre ; he only liked to go out walking to show off his new clothes .
16 He had a coat for every hour of the day ; and just as they say of a king , ` He is in the council-chamber , ' they always said here , ` The Emperor is in the wardrobe . '
17 In the great city in which he lived there was always something going on ; every day many strangers came there .
18 One day two impostors arrived who gave themselves out as weavers , and said that they knew how to manufacture the most beautiful cloth imaginable .
19 Not only were the texture and pattern uncommonly beautiful , but the clothes which were made of the stuff possessed this wonderful property that they were invisible to anyone who was not fit for his office , or who was unpardonably stupid .
20 ` Those must indeed be splendid clothes , ' thought the Emperor .
21 ` If I had them on I could find out which XXXXX in my kingdom are unfit for the offices they hold ; I could distinguish the wise from the stupid !	men		clothes|enchantment|husband|men|messengers|none|order|strangers|texture|years

1 The King was so charmed by the Snow-daughter , that he asked her to be his wife .
2 The girl consented , and the wedding was held with much state .
3 The King had a huge house of ice made for his wife underground , so that even in summer it did not melt .
4 But for his brother-in-law he had a house built with huge ovens all round it , that were kept heated all day and night .
5 The Fire-son was delighted , but the perpetual heat in which he lived made his body so hot , that it was dangerous to go too close to him .
6 One day the King gave a great feast , and asked his brother-in-law among the other guests .
7 The Fire-son did not appear till everyone had assembled , and when he did , everyone fled outside to the open air , so intense was the heat he gave forth .
8 Then the King was very angry and said , ` If I had known what a lot of trouble you would have been , I would never have taken you into my house . '
9 Then the Fire-son replied with a laugh , ` Do n't be angry , dear brother !
10 I love heat and my sister loves cold -- come here and let me embrace you , and then I 'll go home at once . '
11 And before the King had time to reply , the Fire-son seized him in a tight embrace .
12 The King screamed aloud in agony , and when his wife , the Snow-daughter , who had taken refuge from her brother in the next room , hurried to him , the King lay dead on the ground burnt to a cinder .
13 When the Snow-daughter saw this she turned on her brother and flew at him .
14 Then a fight began , the like of which had never been seen on earth .
15 When the people , attracted by the noise , hurried to the spot , they saw the Snow-daughter melting into water and the Fire-son burn to a cinder .
16 And so ended the unhappy brother and sister .
17 THE STORY OF KING FROST -LRB- 26 -RRB- -LRB- 26 -RRB- From the Russian .
18 There was once upon a time a peasant-woman who had a daughter and a step-daughter .
19 The daughter had her own way in everything , and whatever she did was right in her mother 's eyes ; but the poor step-daughter had a hard time .
20 Let her do what she would , she was always blamed , and got small thanks for all the trouble she took ; nothing was right , everything wrong ; and yet , if the truth were known , the girl was worth her weight in gold -- she was so unselfish and good-hearted .

1 As , since he had been touched by the Giant 's ring , he had the power to live in the water as well as on land , he at once dived into the fountain .
2 He perceived in one corner a door leading into the mountain , and at the foot of the mountain was a high rock on which was fixed an iron ring with a cord attached .
3 The Prince promptly guessed that the cord was used to chain the Princess , and drew his sword and cut it .
4 In a moment he felt the Princess 's hand in his , for she had always kept her magic pebble in her mouth , in spite of the prayers and entreaties of the Prince of the Air to make herself visible .
5 So hand in hand the invisible Prince and Rosalie crossed the mountain ; but as the Princess had no power of living under water , she could not pass the Golden Fountain .
6 Speechless and invisible they clung together on the brink , trembling at the frightful tempest the Prince of the Air had raised in his fury .
7 The storm had already lasted many days when tremendous heat began to make itself felt .
8 The lightning flashed , the thunder rattled , fire bolts fell from heaven , burning up the forests and even the fields of corn .
9 In one instant the very streams were dried up , and the Prince , seizing his opportunity , carried the Princess over the Golden Fountain .
10 It took them a long time still to reach the Golden Isle , but at last they got there , and we may be quite sure they never wanted to leave it any more .
11 THE CROW -LRB- 13 -RRB- -LRB- 13 -RRB- From the Polish .
12 Kletke .
13 Once upon a time there were three Princesses who were all three young and beautiful ; but the youngest , although she was not fairer than the other two , was the most loveable of them all .
14 About half a mile from the palace in which they lived there stood a castle , which was uninhabited and almost a ruin , but the garden which surrounded it was a mass of blooming flowers , and in this garden the youngest Princess used often to walk .
15 One day when she was pacing to and fro under the lime trees , a black crow hopped out of a rose-bush in front of her .
16 The poor beast was all torn and bleeding , and the kind little Princess was quite unhappy about it .
17 When the crow saw this it turned to her and said : ' I am not really a black crow , but an enchanted Prince , who has been doomed to spend his youth in misery .
18 If you only liked , Princess , you could save me .
19 But you would have to say good-bye to all your own people and come and be my constant companion in this ruined castle .
20 There is one habitable room in it , in which there is a golden bed ; there you will have to live all by yourself , and do n't forget that whatever you may see or hear in the night you must not scream out , for if you give as much as a single cry my sufferings will be doubled . '

1 Now , in the middle of the garden there was a pond of water , clear as crystal , and the old woman said to the Queen : ` The day is so warm , and the sun 's rays so scorching , that the water in the pond looks very cool and inviting .
2 Would you not like to bathe in it , fair Queen ? '
3 ` No , I think not , ' answered the Queen ; but the next moment she regretted her words , and thought to herself : Why should n't I bathe in that cool , fresh water ?
4 No harm could come of it .
5 And , so saying , she slipped off her robes and stepped into the water .
6 But scarcely had her tender feet touched the cool ripples when she felt a great shove on her shoulders , and the wicked witch had pushed her into the deep water , exclaiming : ` Swim henceforth , White Duck ! '
7 And the witch herself assumed the form of the Queen , and decked herself out in the royal robes , and sat among the Court ladies , awaiting the King 's return .
8 And suddenly the tramp of horses ' hoofs was heard , and the barking of dogs , and the witch hastened forward to meet the royal carriages , and , throwing her arms round the King 's neck , kissed him .
9 And in his great joy the King did not know that the woman he held in his arms was not his own dear wife , but a wicked witch .
10 In the meantime , outside the palace walls , the poor White Duck swam up and down the pond ; and near it laid three eggs , out of which there came one morning two little fluffy ducklings and a little ugly drake .
11 And the White Duck brought the little creatures up , and they paddled after her in the pond , and caught gold-fish , and hopped upon the bank and waddled about , ruffling their feathers and saying ` Quack , quack ' as they strutted about on the green banks of the pond .
12 But their mother used to warn them not to stray too far , telling them that a wicked witch lived in the castle beyond the garden , adding , ` She has ruined me , and she will do her best to ruin you . '
13 But the young ones did not listen to their mother , and , playing about the garden one day , they strayed close up to the castle windows .
14 The witch at once recognised them by their smell , and ground her teeth with anger ; but she hid her feelings , and , pretending to be very kind she called them to her and joked with them , and led them into a beautiful room , where she gave them food to eat , and showed them a soft cushion on which they might sleep .
15 Then she left them and went down into the palace kitchens , where she told the servants to sharpen the knives , and to make a great fire ready , and hang a large kettleful of water over it .
16 In the meantime the two little ducklings had fallen asleep , and the little drake lay between them , covered up by their wings , to be kept warm under their feathers .
17 But the little drake could not go to sleep , and as he lay there wide awake in the night he heard the witch come to the door and say : ` Little ones , are you asleep ? '
18 And the little drake answered for the other two : ` We can not sleep , we wake and weep , Sharp is the knife , to take our life ; The fire is hot , now boils the pot , And so we wake , and lie and quake . '
19 ` They are not asleep yet , ' muttered the witch to herself ; and she walked up and down in the passage , and then came back to the door , and said : ` Little ones , are you asleep ? '
20 And again the little drake answered for his sisters : ` We can not sleep , we wake and weep , Sharp is the knife , to take our life ; The fire is hot , now boils the pot , And so we wake , and lie and quake . '
21 ` Just the same answer , ' muttered the XXXXX ; ' I think I 'll go in and see . '	witch		form|harm|joy|life|mother|ones|pot|water|weep|witch

12 The Princess came out of the copper castle , and became Queen ; and that pleased her very much .

16 The next few days were spent in getting the elephants together , in walking the newly caught wild elephants up and down between a couple of tame ones to prevent them giving too much trouble on the downward march to the plains , and in taking stock of the blankets and ropes and things that had been worn out or lost in the forest .
17 Petersen Sahib came in on his clever she-elephant Pudmini ; he had been paying off other camps among the hills , for the season was coming to an end , and there was a native clerk sitting at a table under a tree , to pay the drivers their wages .
18 As each man was paid he went back to his elephant , and joined the line that stood ready to start .

1 It is a very soothing lullaby , and the first verse says : Shiv , who poured the harvest and made the winds to blow , Sitting at the doorways of a day of long ago , Gave to each his portion , food and toil and fate , From the King upon the guddee to the Beggar at the gate .
2 All things made he -- Shiva the Preserver .
3 Mahadeo !
4 Mahadeo !
5 He made all -- Thorn for the camel , fodder for the kine , And mother 's heart for sleepy head , O little son of mine !
6 Little Toomai came in with a joyous tunk-a-tunk at the end of each verse , till he felt sleepy and stretched himself on the fodder at Kala Nag 's side .
7 At last the elephants began to lie down one after another as is their custom , till only Kala Nag at the right of the line was left standing up ; and he rocked slowly from side to side , his ears put forward to listen to the night wind as it blew very slowly across the hills .
8 The air was full of all the night noises that , taken together , make one big silence -- the click of one bamboo stem against the other , the rustle of something alive in the undergrowth , the scratch and squawk of a half-waked bird -LRB- birds are awake in the night much more often than we imagine -RRB- , and the fall of water ever so far away .
9 Little Toomai slept for some time , and when he waked it was brilliant moonlight , and Kala Nag was still standing up with his ears cocked .
10 Little Toomai turned , rustling in the fodder , and watched the curve of his big back against half the stars in heaven , and while he watched he heard , so far away that it sounded no more than a pinhole of noise pricked through the stillness , the `` hoot-toot '' of a wild elephant .
11 All the elephants in the lines jumped up as if they had been shot , and their grunts at last waked the sleeping mahouts , and they came out and drove in the picket pegs with big mallets , and tightened this rope and knotted that till all was quiet .
12 One new elephant had nearly grubbed up his picket , and Big Toomai took off Kala Nag 's leg chain and shackled that elephant fore-foot to hind-foot , but slipped a loop of grass string round Kala Nag 's leg , and told him to remember that he was tied fast .
13 He knew that he and his father and his grandfather had done the very same thing hundreds of times before .
14 Kala Nag did not answer to the order by gurgling , as he usually did .
15 He stood still , looking out across the moonlight , his head a little raised and his ears spread like fans , up to the great folds of the Garo hills .
16 `` Tend to him if he grows restless in the night , '' said Big Toomai to Little Toomai , and he went into the hut and slept .
17 Little Toomai was just going to sleep , too , when he heard the coir string snap with a little `` tang , '' and Kala Nag rolled out of his pickets as slowly and as silently as a cloud rolls out of the mouth of a valley .
18 Little Toomai pattered after him , barefooted , down the road in the moonlight , calling under his breath , `` Kala Nag !
19 Kala Nag !
20 Take me with you , O Kala Nag ! ''

7 CHAPTER I. Down the Rabbit-Hole Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank , and of having nothing to do : once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading , but it had no pictures or conversations in it , ` and what is the use of a book , ' thought Alice ` without pictures or conversation ? '
8 So she was considering in her own mind -LRB- as well as she could , for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid -RRB- , whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies , when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her .
9 There was nothing so VERY remarkable in that ; nor did Alice think it so VERY much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself , ` Oh dear !
10 Oh dear !
11 I shall be late ! '
12 -LRB- when she thought it over afterwards , it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this , but at the time it all seemed quite natural -RRB- ; but when the Rabbit actually TOOK A WATCH OUT OF ITS WAISTCOAT-POCKET , and looked at it , and then hurried on , Alice started to her feet , for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket , or a watch to take out of it , and burning with curiosity , she ran across the field after it , and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge .
13 In another moment down went Alice after it , never once considering how in the world she was to get out again .
14 The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way , and then dipped suddenly down , so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well .
15 Either the well was very deep , or she fell very slowly , for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next .
16 First , she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to , but it was too dark to see anything ; then she looked at the sides of the well , and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves ; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs .
17 She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed ; it was labelled ` ORANGE MARMALADE ' , but to her great disappointment it was empty : she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody , so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it .
18 ` Well ! '
19 thought Alice to herself , ` after such a fall as this , I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs !
20 How brave they 'll all think me at home !
21 Why , I would n't say XXXXX about it , even if I fell off the top of the house ! '	anything		anything|cupboards|feel|jar|mind|nothing|pleasure|trouble|tunnel|way

1 So he took heart of grace , and made Martin a Duke , and gave his daughter a rich dowry , and prepared the grandest wedding-feast that had ever been seen , so that to this day the old people in the country still talk of it .
2 After the wedding Martin and his royal bride went to dwell in the magnificent new palace , and here Martin lived in the greatest comfort and luxury , such luxury as he had never imagined .
3 But though he was as happy as the day was long , and as merry as a grig , the King 's daughter fretted all day , thinking of the indignity that had been done her in making her marry Martin , the poor widow 's son , instead of a rich young Prince from a foreign country .
4 So unhappy was she that she spent all her time wondering how she should get rid of her undesirable husband .
5 And first she determined to learn the secret of his power , and , with flattering , caressing words , she tried to coax him to tell her how he was so clever that there was nothing in the world that he could not do .
6 At first he would tell her nothing ; but once , when he was in a yielding mood , she approached him with a winning smile on her lovely face , and , speaking flattering words to him , she gave him a potion to drink , with a sweet , strong taste .
7 And when he had drunk it Martin 's lips were unsealed , and he told her that all his power lay in the magic ring that he wore on his finger , and he described to her how to use it , and , still speaking , he fell into a deep sleep .
8 And when she saw that the potion had worked , and that he was sound asleep , the Princess took the magic ring from his finger , and , going into the courtyard , she threw it from the palm of one hand into the other .
9 On the instant the twelve youths appeared , and asked her what she commanded them to do .
10 Then she told them that by the next morning they were to do away with the castle , and the bridge , and the church , and put in their stead the humble hut in which Martin used to live with his mother , and that while he slept her husband was to be carried to his old lowly room ; and that they were to bear her away to the utmost ends of the earth , where an old King lived who would make her welcome in his palace , and surround her with the state that befitted a royal Princess .
11 ` You shall be obeyed , ' answered the twelve youths at the same moment .
12 And lo and behold !
13 the following morning , when the King awoke and looked out of his window he beheld to his amazement that the palace , bridge , church , and trees had all vanished , and there was nothing in their place but a bare , miserable-looking hut .
14 Immediately the King sent for his son-in-law , and commanded him to explain what had happened .
15 But Martin looked at his royal father-in-law , and answered never a word .
16 Then the King was very angry , and , calling a council together , he charged Martin with having been guilty of witchcraft , and of having deceived the King , and having made away with the Princess ; and he was condemned to imprisonment in a high stone tower , with neither meat nor drink , till he should die of starvation .
17 Then , in the hour of his dire necessity , his old friends Schurka -LRB- the dog -RRB- and Waska -LRB- the cat -RRB- remembered how Martin had once saved them from a cruel death ; and they took counsel together as to how they should help him .
18 And Schurka growled , and was of opinion that he would like to tear everyone in pieces ; but Waska purred meditatively , and scratched the back of her ear with a velvet paw , and remained lost in thought .
19 At the end of a few minutes she had made up her mind , and , turning to Schurka , said : ` Let us go together into the town , and the moment we meet a baker you must make a rush between his legs and upset the tray from off his head ; I will lay hold of the rolls , and will carry them off to our master . '
20 No sooner said than done .

1 Alphege threw himself into his arms , and the brothers hastened to the royal palace , where in the presence of the entire court he received the crown from his brother 's hand .
2 To clear away any possible doubt , he showed the ruby which the Good Queen had given him in his childhood .
3 As they were gazing at it , it suddenly split with a loud noise , and at the same moment the Wicked Queen expired .
4 King Alphege lost no time in marrying his dear and lovely Zayda , and his joy was complete when the Good Queen appeared at his wedding .
5 She assured him that the Fairy of the Mountain had henceforth lost all power over him , and after spending some time with the young couple , and bestowing the most costly presents on them , she retired to her own country .
6 King Alphege insisted on his brother sharing his throne , and they all lived to a good old age , universally beloved and admired .
7 FAIRER-THAN-A-FAIRY Once there lived a King who had no children for many years after his marriage .
8 At length heaven granted him a daughter of such remarkable beauty that he could think of no name so appropriate for her as ` Fairer-than-a-Fairy . '
9 It never occurred to the good-natured monarch that such a name was certain to call down the hatred and jealousy of the fairies in a body on the child , but this was what happened .
10 No sooner had they heard of this presumptuous name than they resolved to gain possession of her who bore it , and either to torment her cruelly , or at least to conceal her from the eyes of all men .
11 The eldest of their tribe was entrusted to carry out their revenge .
12 This Fairy was named Lagree ; she was so old that she only had one eye and one tooth left , and even these poor remains she had to keep all night in a strengthening liquid .
13 She was also so spiteful that she gladly devoted all her time to carrying out all the mean or ill-natured tricks of the whole body of fairies .
14 With her large experience , added to her native spite , she found but little difficulty in carrying off Fairer-than-a-Fairy .
15 The poor child , who was only seven years old , nearly died of fear on finding herself in the power of this hideous creature .
16 However , when after an hour 's journey underground she found herself in a splendid palace with lovely gardens , she felt a little reassured , and was further cheered when she discovered that her pet cat and dog had followed her .
17 The old Fairy led her to a pretty room which she said should be hers , at the same time giving her the strictest orders never to let out the fire which was burning brightly in the grate .
18 She then gave two glass bottles into the Princess 's charge , desiring her to take the greatest care of them , and having enforced her orders with the most awful threats in case of disobedience , she vanished , leaving the little girl at liberty to explore the palace and grounds and a good deal relieved at having only two apparently easy tasks set her .
19 Several years passed , during which time the Princess grew accustomed to her lonely life , obeyed the Fairy 's orders , and by degrees forgot all about the court of the King her father .
20 One day , whilst passing near a fountain in the garden , she noticed that the sun 's rays fell on the water in such a manner as to produce a brilliant rainbow .
21 She stood still to admire it , when , to her great surprise , she heard a voice addressing her which seemed to come from the centre of its XXXXX .	rays		brothers|degrees|fountain|hatred|henceforth|life|orders|rays|spite|tribe

7 The moon was sinking behind the hills and the lines of trembling monkeys huddled together on the walls and battlements looked like ragged shaky fringes of things .

9 `` The moon sets , '' he said .
10 `` Is there yet light enough to see ? ''
11 From the walls came a moan like the wind in the tree-tops -- `` We see , O Kaa . ''
12 `` Good .
13 Begins now the dance -- the Dance of the Hunger of Kaa .
14 Sit still and watch . ''
15 He turned twice or thrice in a big circle , weaving his head from right to left .
16 Then he began making loops and figures of eight with his body , and soft , oozy triangles that melted into squares and five-sided figures , and coiled mounds , never resting , never hurrying , and never stopping his low humming song .
17 It grew darker and darker , till at last the dragging , shifting coils disappeared , but they could hear the rustle of the scales .

1 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
2 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
3 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
4 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
5 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
6 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
7 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
8 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
9 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
10 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
11 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
12 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
13 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
14 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
15 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
16 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
17 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
18 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
19 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .
20 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
21 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the XXXXX , and soon the head of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the water .	bank		arms|bank|despair|fatigue|meadow|round|shot|skin|sound|witch

1 On the first evening of these last three days , when he came home and was eating his supper , he noticed the old woman stealing into the stables .
2 The Prince followed her secretly to see what she was going to do .
3 He crouched down in the doorway and heard the wicked witch telling the horses to wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep , and then to go and hide themselves in the river , and to stay there till she told them to return ; and if they did n't do as she told them the old woman threatened to beat them till they bled .
4 When Iwanich heard all this he went back to his room , determined that nothing should induce him to fall asleep next day .
5 On the following morning he led the mare and foal to the fields as usual , but bound a cord round them both which he kept in his hand .
6 But after a few hours , by the magic arts of the old witch , he was overpowered by sleep , and the mare and foal escaped and did as they had been told to do .
7 The Prince did not awake till late in the evening ; and when he did , he found , to his horror , that the horses had disappeared .
8 Filled with despair , he cursed the moment when he had entered the service of the cruel witch , and already he saw his head sticking up on the sharp spike beside the others .
9 Then he suddenly remembered the fish 's scale , which , with the eagle 's feather and the fox 's hairs , he always carried about with him .
10 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the river he threw it in .
11 In a minute the grateful fish swam towards the bank on which Iwanich was standing , and said : ` What do you command , my friend and benefactor ? '
12 The Prince replied : ' I had to look after a mare and foal , and they have run away from me and have hidden themselves in the river ; if you wish to save my life drive them back to the land . '
13 ` Wait a moment , ' answered the fish , ` and I and my friends will soon drive them out of the water . '
14 With these words the creature disappeared into the depths of the stream .
15 Almost immediately a rushing hissing sound was heard in the waters , the waves dashed against the banks , the foam was tossed into the air , and the two horses leapt suddenly on to the dry land , trembling and shaking with fear .
16 Iwanich sprang at once on to the mare 's back , seized the foal by its bridle , and hastened home in the highest spirits .
17 When the witch saw the Prince bringing the horses home she could hardly conceal her wrath , and as soon as she had placed Iwanich 's supper before him she stole away again to the stables .
18 The Prince followed her , and heard her scolding the beasts harshly for not having hidden themselves better .
19 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .

4 Alice was not a bit hurt , and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment : she looked up , but it was all dark overhead ; before her was another long passage , and the White Rabbit was still in sight , hurrying down it .
5 There was not a moment to be lost : away went Alice like the wind , and was just in time to hear it say , as it turned a corner , ` Oh my ears and whiskers , how late it 's getting ! '
6 She was close behind it when she turned the corner , but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen : she found herself in a long , low hall , which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof .
7 There were doors all round the hall , but they were all locked ; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other , trying every door , she walked sadly down the middle , wondering how she was ever to get out again .
8 Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table , all made of solid glass ; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key , and Alice 's first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall ; but , alas !
9 either the locks were too large , or the key was too small , but at any rate it would not open any of them .
10 However , on the second time round , she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before , and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high : she tried the little golden key in the lock , and to her great delight it fitted !
11 Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage , not much larger than a rat-hole : she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw .
12 How she longed to get out of that dark hall , and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains , but she could not even get her head through the doorway ; ` and even if my head would go through , ' thought poor Alice , ` it would be of very little use without my shoulders .
13 Oh , how I wish I could shut up like a telescope !
14 I think I could , if I only know how to begin . '
15 For , you see , so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately , that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible .
16 There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door , so she went back to the table , half hoping she might find another key on it , or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes : this time she found a little bottle on it , -LRB- ` which certainly was not here before , ' said Alice , -RRB- and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label , with the words ` DRINK ME ' beautifully printed on it in large letters .
17 It was all very well to say ` Drink me , ' but the wise little Alice was not going to do THAT in a hurry .
18 ` No , I 'll look first , ' she said , ` and see whether it 's marked `` poison '' or not ' ; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt , and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things , all because they WOULD not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them : such as , that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long ; and that if you cut your finger VERY deeply with a knife , it usually bleeds ; and she had never forgotten that , if you drink much from a bottle marked ` poison , ' it is almost certain to disagree with you , sooner or later .
19 However , this bottle was NOT marked ` poison , ' so Alice ventured to taste it , and finding it very nice , -LRB- it had , in fact , a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart , custard , pine-apple , roast turkey , toffee , and hot buttered toast , -RRB- she very soon finished it off .

5 They found him stretched out on a warm ledge in the afternoon sun , admiring his beautiful new coat , for he had been in retirement for the last ten days changing his skin , and now he was very splendid -- darting his big blunt-nosed head along the ground , and twisting the thirty feet of his body into fantastic knots and curves , and licking his lips as he thought of his dinner to come .

1 It thanked the Princess most heartily for her goodness , and said that its sufferings had already been greatly lessened .
2 Now one of the Princess 's elder sisters , who was very inquisitive , had found out about everything , and went to pay her youngest sister a visit in the ruined castle .
3 She implored her so urgently to let her spend the night with her in the golden bed , that at last the good-natured little Princess consented .
4 But at midnight , when the odd folk appeared , the elder sister screamed with terror , and from this time on the youngest Princess insisted always on keeping watch alone .
5 So she lived in solitude all the daytime , and at night she would have been frightened , had she not been so brave ; but every day the crow came and thanked her for her endurance , and assured her that his sufferings were far less than they had been .
6 And so two years passed away , when one day the crow came to the Princess and said : ` In another year I shall be freed from the spell I am under at present , because then the seven years will be over .
7 But before I can resume my natural form , and take possession of the belongings of my forefathers , you must go out into the world and take service as a maidservant . '
8 The young Princess consented at once , and for a whole year she served as a maid ; but in spite of her youth and beauty she was very badly treated , and suffered many things .
9 One evening , when she was spinning flax , and had worked her little white hands weary , she heard a rustling beside her and a cry of joy .
10 Then she saw a handsome youth standing beside her ; who knelt down at her feet and kissed the little weary white hands . '

13 So they went to the castle where they had both endured so much .
14 But when they reached it , it was difficult to believe that it was the same , for it had all been rebuilt and done up again .
15 And there they lived for a hundred years , a hundred years of joy and happiness .

6 Once upon a time there was a King and his Queen in their kingdom .
7 They had one daughter , who was called Ingiborg , and one son , whose name was Ring .
8 He was less fond of adventures than men of rank usually were in those days , and was not famous for strength or feats of arms .
9 When he was twelve years old , one fine winter day he rode into the forest along with his men to enjoy himself .
10 They went on a long way , until they caught sight of a hind with a gold ring on its horns .
11 The Prince was eager to catch it , if possible , so they gave chase and rode on without stopping until all the horses began to founder beneath them .
12 At last the Prince 's horse gave way too , and then there came over them a darkness so black that they could no longer see the hind .
13 By this time they were far away from any house , and thought it was high time to be making their way home again , but they found they had got lost now .
14 At first they all kept together , but soon each began to think that he knew the right way best ; so they separated , and all went in different directions .
15 The Prince , too , had got lost like the rest , and wandered on for a time until he came to a little clearing in the forest not far from the sea , where he saw a woman sitting on a chair and a big barrel standing beside her .
16 The Prince went up to her and saluted her politely , and she received him very graciously .
17 He looked down into the barrel then , and saw lying at the bottom an unusually beautiful gold ring , which pleased him so much that he could not take his eyes off it .
18 The woman saw this , and said that he might have it if he would take the trouble to get it ; for which the Prince thanked her , and said it was at least worth trying .
19 So he leaned over into the barrel , which did not seem very deep , and thought he would easily reach the ring ; but the more he stretched down after it the deeper grew the barrel .

3 But Christmas is just a bore -- a regular bore . ''
4 That was what Uncle Edgar called things that did n't interest him , so that Frank felt pretty sure of his word .
5 Nevertheless , he wondered uncomfortably what made Cousin Myra smile so queerly .
6 `` Why , how dreadful ! ''
7 she said brightly .
8 `` I thought all boys and girls looked upon Christmas as the very best time in the year . ''
9 `` We do n't , '' said Frank gloomily .
10 `` It 's just the same old thing year in and year out .
11 We know just exactly what is going to happen .
12 We even know pretty well what presents we are going to get .
13 And Christmas Day itself is always the same .
14 We 'll get up in the morning , and our stockings will be full of things , and half of them we do n't want .

17 And all the uncles and aunts come to dinner -- just the same old crowd , every year , and they say just the same things .

1 But before the Prince had time to feel despondent the black girl beckoned to him in the distance from behind a rock , where she had hidden herself for fear her mother should catch sight of her .
2 Full of joy the youth hurried towards her , and begged her aid and counsel in the new piece of work he had been given to do .
3 But this time the Fairy had watched the Prince 's movements from her window , and she saw him hiding himself behind the rock with her daughter .
4 She uttered a piercing shriek so that the mountains re-echoed with the sound of it , and the terrified pair had hardly dared to look out from their hiding-place when the enraged woman , with her dress and hair flying in the wind , hurried over the bridge of clouds .
5 The Prince at once gave himself up for lost , but the girl told him to be of good courage and to follow her as quickly as he could .
6 But before they left their shelter she broke off a little bit of the rock , spoke some magic words over it , and threw it in the direction her mother was coming from .
7 In a moment a glittering palace arose before the eyes of the Fairy which blinded her with its dazzling splendour , and with its many doors and passages prevented her for some time from finding her way out of it .
8 In the meantime the black girl hurried on with the Prince , hastening to reach the river , where once on the other side they would for ever be out of the wicked Fairy 's power .
9 But before they had accomplished half the way they heard again the rustle of her garments and her muttered curses pursuing them closely .
10 The Prince was terrified ; he dared not look back , and he felt his strength giving way .
11 But before he had time to despair the girl uttered some more magic words , and immediately she herself was changed into a pond , and the Prince into a duck swimming on its surface .
12 When the Fairy saw this her rage knew no bounds , and she used all her magic wits to make the pond disappear ; she caused a hill of sand to arise at her feet , meaning it to dry up the water at once .
13 But the sand hill only drove the pond a little farther away , and its waters seemed to increase instead of diminishing .
14 When the old woman saw that the powers of her magic were of so little avail , she had recourse to cunning .
15 She threw a lot of gold nuts into the pond , hoping in this way to catch the duck , but all her efforts were fruitless , for the little creature refused to let itself be caught .
16 Then a new idea struck the wicked old woman , and hiding herself behind the rock which had sheltered the fugitives , she waited behind it , watching carefully for the moment when the Prince and her daughter should resume their natural forms and continue their journey .
17 She had not to wait long , for as soon as the girl thought her mother was safely out of the way , she changed herself and the Prince once more into their human shape , and set out cheerfully for the river .
18 But they had not gone many steps when the wicked Fairy hurried after them , a drawn dagger in her hand , and was close upon them , when suddenly , instead of the Prince and her daughter , she found herself in front of a great stone church , whose entrance was carefully guarded by a huge monk .
19 Breathless with rage and passion , she tried to plunge her dagger into the monk 's heart , but it fell shattered in pieces at her feet .
20 In her desperation she determined to pull down the church , and thus to destroy her two victims for ever .
21 She stamped three times on the ground , and the earth trembled , and both the church and the XXXXX began to shake .	monk		counsel|direction|garments|monk|mountains|pond|shriek|sight|steps|wits

1 ` Well , if that is the case , ' said the manikin , ` sit down beside me ; we can rest for a little and have something to eat .
2 Give me what you have got in your satchel . '
3 Now , the poor Simpleton was ashamed to show what was in it .
4 However , he thought it best not to make a fuss , so he opened the satchel , and could scarcely believe his own eyes , for , instead of the hard crust , he saw two beautiful fresh rolls and some cold meat .
5 He shared them with the manikin , who licked his lips and said : ` Now , go into that wood , and stop in front of the first tree , bow three times , and then strike the tree with your axe , fall on your knees on the ground , with your face on the earth , and remain there till you are raised up .
6 You will then find a ship at your side , step into it and fly to the King 's Palace .
7 If you meet anyone on the way , take him with you . '
8 The Simpleton thanked the manikin very kindly , bade him farewell , and went into the road .
9 When he got to the first tree he stopped in front of it , did everything just as he had been told , and , kneeling on the ground with his face to the earth , fell asleep .
10 After a little time he was aroused ; he awoke and , rubbing his eyes , saw a ready-made ship at his side , and at once got into it .
11 And the ship rose and rose , and in another minute was flying through the air , when the Simpleton , who was on the look out , cast his eyes down to the earth and saw a man beneath him on the road , who was kneeling with his ear upon the damp ground .
12 ` Hallo ! '
13 he called out , ` what are you doing down there ? ' '
14 I am listening to what is going on in the world , ' replied the man .
15 ` Come with me in my ship , ' said the Simpleton .
16 So the man was only too glad , and got in beside him ; and the ship flew , and flew , and flew through the air , till again from his outlook the Simpleton saw a man on the road below , who was hopping on one leg , while his other leg was tied up behind his ear .
17 So he hailed him , calling out : ` Hallo !
18 what are you doing , hopping on one leg ? ' '
19 I ca n't help it , ' replied the man . '
20 I walk so fast that unless I tied up one leg I should be at the end of the earth in a bound . '

1 he cried ; ` shall I never see my lovely Princess again ? '
2 Who knows where she may be , and what fairy may have her in his keeping ?
3 I am only a man , but I am strong in my love , and I will seek the whole world through till I find her . '
4 So saying , he left the court , and made ready for his journey .
5 He travelled many weary days without hearing a single word of the lost Princess , till one morning , as he was walking through a thick forest , he suddenly perceived a magnificent palace standing at the end of a pine avenue , and his heart bounded to think that he might be gazing on Rosalie 's prison .
6 He hastened his steps , and quickly arrived at the gate of the palace , which was formed of a single agate .
7 The gate swung open to let him through , and he next passed successively three courts , surrounded by deep ditches filled with running water , with birds of brilliant plumage flying about the banks .
8 Everything around was rare and beautiful , but the Prince scarcely raised his eyes to all these wonders .
9 He thought only of the Princess and where he should find her , but in vain he opened every door and searched in every corner ; he neither saw Rosalie nor anyone else .
10 At last there was no place left for him to search but a little wood , which contained in the centre a sort of hall built entirely of orange-trees , with four small rooms opening out of the corners .
11 Three of these were empty except for statues and wonderful things , but in the fourth the Invisible Prince caught sight of Rosalie .
12 His joy at beholding her again was , however , somewhat lessened by seeing that the Prince of the Air was kneeling at her feet , and pleading his own cause .
13 But it was in vain that he implored her to listen ; she only shook her head .
14 ` No , ' was all she would say ; ` you snatched me from my father whom I loved , and all the splendour in the world can never console me .
15 Go !
16 I can never feel anything towards you but hate and contempt . '
17 With these words she turned away and entered her own apartments .
18 Unknown to herself the Invisible Prince had followed her , but fearing to be discovered by the Princess in the presence of others , he made up his mind to wait quietly till dark ; and employed the long hours in writing a poem to the Princess , which he laid on the bed beside her .
19 This done , he thought of nothing but how best to deliver Rosalie , and he resolved to take advantage of a visit which the Prince of the Air paid every year to his mother and brothers in order to strike the blow .
20 One day Rosalie was sitting alone in her room thinking of her troubles when she suddenly saw a pen get up from off the desk and begin to write all by itself on a sheet of white paper .
21 As she did not know that it was guided by an invisible hand she was very much astonished , and the moment that the pen had ceased to move she instantly went over to the table , where she found some lovely verses , telling her that another shared her distresses , whatever they might be , and loved her with all his heart ; and that he would never rest until he had delivered her from the hands of the XXXXX she hated .	man		Everything|apartments|contempt|corner|courts|door|gate|man|palace|statues

1 But as he did not want the real story to be known , he said that about midnight a huge wasp had flown through the branches , and buzzed incessantly round him .
2 He had warded it off with his sword , and at dawn , when he was becoming quite worn out , the wasp had vanished as suddenly as it had appeared .
3 The King , who never doubted the truth of this tale , bade his son go to rest at once and recover from the fatigues of the night ; but he himself went and ordered many feasts to be held in honour of the preservation of the wonderful fruit .
4 The whole capital was in a stir , and everyone shared in the King 's joy ; the Prince alone took no part in the festivities .
5 While the King was at a banquet , Iwanich took some purses of gold , and mounting the quickest horse in the royal stable , he sped off like the wind without a single soul being any the wiser .
6 It was only on the next day that they missed him ; the King was very distressed at his disappearance , and sent search-parties all over the kingdom to look for him , but in vain ; and after six months they gave him up as dead , and in another six months they had forgotten all about him .
7 But in the meantime the Prince , with the help of his ring , had had a most successful journey , and no evil had befallen him .
8 At the end of three months he came to the entrance of a huge forest , which looked as if it had never been trodden by human foot before , and which seemed to stretch out indefinitely .
9 The Prince was about to enter the wood by a little path he had discovered , when he heard a voice shouting to him : ` Hold , youth !
10 Whither are you going ? '
11 Iwanich turned round , and saw a tall , gaunt-looking man , clad in miserable rags , leaning on a crooked staff and seated at the foot of an oak tree , which was so much the same colour as himself that it was little wonder the Prince had ridden past the tree without noticing him .
12 ` Where else should I be going , ' he said , ` than through the wood ? '
13 ` Through the wood ? '
14 said the old man in amazement .
15 ` It 's easily seen that you have heard nothing of this forest , that you rush so blindly to meet your doom .
16 Well , listen to me before you ride any further ; let me tell you that this wood hides in its depths a countless number of the fiercest tigers , hyenas , wolves , bears , and snakes , and all sorts of other monsters .
17 If I were to cut you and your horse up into tiny morsels and throw them to the beasts , there would n't be one bit for each hundred of them .
18 Take my advice , therefore , and if you wish to save your life follow some other path . '
19 The Prince was rather taken aback by the old man 's words , and considered for a minute what he should do ; then looking at his ring , and perceiving that it sparkled as brightly as ever , he called out : ` If this wood held even more terrible things than it does , I can not help myself , for I must go through it . '
20 Here he spurred his horse and rode on ; but the old beggar screamed so loudly after him that the Prince turned round and rode back to the oak tree . '

1 To him they were all just wriggling pollywogs .

3 IX THE SMILING POOL KINDERGARTEN Play a little , learn a little , grow a little too ; That 's what every pollywoggy tries his best to do .
4 Of course .
5 That 's what a kindergarten is for .
6 And you may be sure that the babies of Grandfather Frog and Old Mr. Toad and Stickytoes the Tree Toad did all of these things in the kindergarten of the Smiling Pool .
7 They looked considerably alike , did these little cousins , for they were all pollywogs to begin with .
8 Peter Rabbit came over every day to watch them .
9 Always he had thought pollywogs just homely , wriggling things , not the least bit interesting , but since he had discovered how proud of them were Grandfather Frog and Old Mr. Toad , he had begun to wonder about them and then to watch them .
10 `` There 's one thing about them , and that is they are not in danger the way any babies are , '' said Peter , talking to himself as is his way when there is no one else to talk to .
11 Just then a funny little black pollywog wriggled into sight , and while Peter was watching him , a stout-jawed water-beetle suddenly rushed from among the water grass , seized the pollywog by his tail , and dragged him down .
12 Peter stared .
13 Could it be that that ugly-looking bug was as dangerous an enemy to the baby Toad as Reddy Fox is to a baby Rabbit ?
14 He began to suspect so , and a little later he knew so , for there was that same little pollywog trying hard to swim and making bad work of it , because he had lost half of his long tail .
15 That set Peter to watching sharper than ever , and presently he discovered that pollywogs have to keep their eyes open quite as much as do baby Rabbits , if they would live to grow up .
16 There were several kinds of queer , ugly-looking bugs forever darting out at the wriggling pollywogs .
17 Hungry-looking fish lay in wait for them , and Longlegs the Blue Heron seemed to have a special liking for them .
18 But the pollywogs were spry , and seemed to have learned to watch out .
19 They seemed to Peter to spend all their time swimming and eating and growing .
20 They grew so fast that it seemed to him that he could almost see them grow .
21 And just imagine how surprised Peter was to discover one day that that very pollywog which he had seen lose his XXXXX had grown a new one .	tail		bit|bug|course|danger|half|kindergarten|one|tail|thing|way

6 After he had gone a long way without thinking where he was going , he saw at last a light far away , and made straight for it .

13 The Irishman stayed there all night , and as soon as morning came rose to go .

7 ` Touch me , ' said the Giant , ` so that you too may come with us under ground . '
8 The Herd-boy did as he was told , and before he could have believed it possible he found himself in a big hall , where even the walls were made of pure gold .
9 Then to his astonishment he saw that the hall was furnished with the tables and chairs that belonged to his master .
10 In a few minutes the company began to eat and drink .
11 The banquet was a very gorgeous one , and the poor youth fell to and ate and drank lustily .
12 When he had eaten and drunk as much as he could he thought to himself , ` Why should n't I put a loaf of bread in my pocket ?
13 I shall be glad of it to-morrow . '
14 So he seized a loaf when no one was looking and stowed it away under his tunic .
15 No sooner had he done so than the wounded Giant limped up to him and whispered softly , ` Herd-boy , where are you ? '
16 ` Here I am , ' replied the youth .
17 ` Then hold on to me , ' said the Giant , ` so that I may lead you up above again . '
18 So the Herd-boy held on to the Giant , and in a few moments he found himself on the earth once more , but the Giant had vanished .
19 The Herd-boy returned to his sheep , and took off the invisible belt which he hid carefully in his bag .
20 The next morning the lad felt hungry , and thought he would cut off a piece of the loaf he had carried away from the Giants ' wedding feast , and eat it .
21 But although he tried with all his might , he could n't cut off the smallest XXXXX .	piece		belt|company|front|hall|piece|plant|tables|walls|wedding|youth

1 The Prince sought for her in vain , and at last in despair sat down on a big stone and contemplated his sad fate .
2 As he sat thus lost in thought , he noticed an eagle flying over his head .
3 Then he suddenly bethought him of his little bell , and taking it out of his pocket he rang it once .
4 In a moment he heard a rustling sound in the air beside him , and the King of the Eagles sank at his feet . '
5 I know what you want of me , ' the bird said .
6 ` You are looking for the Mother Dragon 's mare who is galloping about among the clouds .
7 I will summon all the eagles of the air together , and order them to catch the mare and bring her to you . '
8 And with these words the King of the Eagles flew away .
9 Towards evening the Prince heard a mighty rushing sound in the air , and when he looked up he saw thousands of eagles driving the mare before them .
10 They sank at his feet on to the ground and gave the mare over to him .
11 Then the Prince rode home to the old Mother Dragon , who was full of wonder when she saw him , and said , ` You have succeeded to-day in looking after my mare , and as a reward you shall come to my ball to-night . '
12 She gave him at the same time a cloak made of copper , and led him to a big room where several young he-dragons and she-dragons were dancing together .
13 Here , too , was the Flower Queen 's beautiful daughter .
14 Her dress was woven out of the most lovely flowers in the world , and her complexion was like lilies and roses .
15 As the Prince was dancing with her he managed to whisper in her ear , ' I have come to set you free ! '
16 Then the beautiful girl said to him , ` If you succeed in bringing the mare back safely the third day , ask the Mother Dragon to give you a foal of the mare as a reward . '
17 The ball came to an end at midnight , and early next morning the Prince again led the Mother Dragon 's mare out into the meadow .
18 But again she vanished before his eyes .
19 Then he took out his little bell and rang it twice .
20 In a moment the King of the Foxes stood before him and said : ' I know already what you want , and will summon all the foxes of the world together to find the mare who has hidden herself in a hill . '
21 With these XXXXX the King of the Foxes disappeared , and in the evening many thousand foxes brought the mare to the Prince .	words		bird|complexion|eagle|ear|end|girl|mare|sound|wonder|words

1 But they were too much frightened to answer .
2 Then the Lake said , ` You do well to be afraid , for it is at your peril that you are come hither .
3 Our king , who has seven heads , is now asleep , but in a few minutes he will wake up and come to me to take his bath !
4 Woe to anyone who meets him in the garden , for it is impossible to escape from him .
5 This is what you must do if you wish to save your lives .
6 Take off your clothes and spread them on the path which leads from here to the castle .
7 The King will then glide over something soft , which he likes very much , and he will be so pleased with that that he will not devour you .
8 He will give you some punishment , but then he will let you go . '
9 The men did as the Lake advised them , and waited for a time .
10 At noon the earth began to quake , and opened in many places , and out of the openings appeared lions , tigers , and other wild beasts , which surrounded the castle , and thousands and thousands of beasts came out of the castle following their king , the Seven-headed Serpent .
11 The Serpent glided over the clothes which were spread for him , came to the Lake , and asked it who had strewed those soft things on the path ?
12 The Lake answered that it had been done by people who had come to do him homage .
13 The King commanded that the men should be brought before him .
14 They came humbly on their knees , and in a few words told him their story .
15 Then he spoke to them with a mighty and terrible voice , and said , ` Because you have dared to come here , I lay upon you the punishment .
16 Every year you must bring me from among your people twelve youths and twelve maidens , that I may devour them .
17 If you do not do this , I will destroy your whole nation . '
18 Then he desired one of his beasts to show the men the way out of the garden , and dismissed them .
19 They then left the island and went back to their own country , where they related what had happened to them .
20 Soon the time came round when the king of the beasts would expect the youths and maidens to be brought to him .

5 But he did not say so .
6 Both the impostors begged him to be so kind as to step closer , and asked him if it were not a beautiful texture and lovely colours .
7 They pointed to the empty loom , and the poor old minister went forward rubbing his eyes ; but he could see nothing , for there was nothing there .
8 ` Dear , dear ! '
9 thought he , ` can I be stupid ?
10 I have never thought that , and nobody must know it !
11 Can I be not fit for my office ?

3 None of his friends came to visit him there , for there were too many stairs to climb .
4 It was a dark evening , and he could not even buy a light .
5 But all at once it flashed across him that there was a little end of tinder in the tinder-box , which he had taken from the hollow tree into which the Witch had helped him down .
6 He found the box with the tinder in it ; but just as he was kindling a light , and had struck a spark out of the tinder-box , the door burst open , and the dog with eyes as large as saucers , which he had seen down in the tree , stood before him and said : ` What does my lord command ? '
7 ` What 's the meaning of this ? '
8 exclaimed the Soldier .
9 ` This is a pretty kind of tinder-box , if I can get whatever I want like this .
10 Get me money ! '
11 he cried to the dog , and hey , presto !
12 he was off and back again , holding a great purse full of money in his mouth .
13 Now the Soldier knew what a capital tinder-box this was .
14 If he rubbed once , the dog that sat on the chest of copper appeared ; if he rubbed twice , there came the dog that watched over the silver chest ; and if he rubbed three times , the one that guarded the gold appeared .
15 Now , the Soldier went down again to his beautiful rooms , and appeared once more in splendid clothes .
16 All his friends immediately recognised him again , and paid him great court .
17 One day he thought to himself : ` It is very strange that no one can get to see the Princess .
18 They all say she is very pretty , but what 's the use of that if she has to sit for ever in the great copper castle with all the towers ?
19 Can I not manage to see her somehow ?
20 Where is my tinder-box ? '

2 What had happened ?

7 She wished she had not acted as she had .
8 It looked spiteful and jealous , and Spencer did not like people who were spiteful and jealous .

1 `` I 'll have to dispose of him in the fall for I 've no place to keep him in , and anyway I could n't afford to feed him .
2 I 'll see if I can borrow Mr. Griggs 's express wagon for Saturday afternoons , and if I can those poor factory children in my grade shall have a weekly treat or my name is not Cordelia Herry .
3 I 'm not so sure but that John Drew has done a good thing after all .
4 Poor John !
5 He always did take things so for granted . ''
6 * * * * * All the point pleasant people soon knew about Miss Cordelia 's questionable windfall , and she was overwhelmed with advice and suggestions .
7 She listened to all tranquilly and then placidly followed her own way .
8 Mr. Griggs was very obliging in regard to his old express wagon , and the next Saturday Point Pleasant was treated to a mild sensation -- nothing less than Miss Cordelia rattling through the village , enthroned on the high seat of Mr. Griggs 's yellow express wagon , drawn by old Nap who , after a week of browsing idleness in the four-acre field , was quite frisky and went at a decided amble down Elm Street and across the bridge .
9 The long wagon had been filled up with board seats , and when Miss Cordelia came back over the bridge the boards were crowded with factory children -- pale-faced little creatures whose eyes were aglow with pleasure at this unexpected outing .
10 Miss Cordelia drove straight out to the big pine-clad hills of Deepdale , six miles from Pottstown .
11 Then she tied Nap in a convenient lane and turned the children loose to revel in the woods and fields .
12 How they did enjoy themselves !
13 And how Miss Cordelia enjoyed seeing them enjoy themselves !
14 When dinner time came she gathered them all around her and went to the wagon .
15 In it she had a basket of bread and butter .
16 `` I ca n't afford anything more , '' she told Cynthia Ann , `` but they must have something to stay their little stomachs .
17 And I can get some water at a farmhouse . ''

19 She did not know anything about the people who lived there , but she liked the looks of the place .

1 So I have resolved to put myself out of my pain by means of the Golden Fountain .
2 A single drop of its water falling on the sand around will trace the name of my rival in her heart .
3 I dread the test , and yet this very dread convinces me of my misfortune . '
4 It may be imagined that after listening to these words the Invisible Prince followed Prince Gnome like his shadow , and after walking some time they arrived at the Golden Fountain .
5 The unhappy lover stooped down with a sigh , and dipping his finger in the water let fall a drop on the sand .
6 It instantly wrote the name of Prince Flame , his brother .
7 The shock of this discovery was so real , that Prince Gnome sank fainting into the arms of his friend .
8 Meanwhile the Invisible Prince was turning over in his mind how he could best deliver Rosalie .
9 As , since he had been touched by the Giant 's ring , he had the power to live in the water as well as on land , he at once dived into the fountain .
10 He perceived in one corner a door leading into the mountain , and at the foot of the mountain was a high rock on which was fixed an iron ring with a cord attached .
11 The Prince promptly guessed that the cord was used to chain the Princess , and drew his sword and cut it .
12 In a moment he felt the Princess 's hand in his , for she had always kept her magic pebble in her mouth , in spite of the prayers and entreaties of the Prince of the Air to make herself visible .
13 So hand in hand the invisible Prince and Rosalie crossed the mountain ; but as the Princess had no power of living under water , she could not pass the Golden Fountain .
14 Speechless and invisible they clung together on the brink , trembling at the frightful tempest the Prince of the Air had raised in his fury .
15 The storm had already lasted many days when tremendous heat began to make itself felt .
16 The lightning flashed , the thunder rattled , fire bolts fell from heaven , burning up the forests and even the fields of corn .
17 In one instant the very streams were dried up , and the Prince , seizing his opportunity , carried the Princess over the Golden Fountain .
18 It took them a long time still to reach the Golden Isle , but at last they got there , and we may be quite sure they never wanted to leave it any more .

4 And at last one day they reached that distant kingdom , and , going at once to the palace , they began to make friends with all the dogs and cats in the place , and to question them about the Princess and the magic ring ; but no one could tell them much about either .
5 Now one day it chanced that Waska had gone down to the palace cellar to hunt for mice and rats , and seeing an especially fat , well-fed mouse , she pounced upon it , buried her claws in its soft fur , and was just going to gobble it up , when she was stopped by the pleading tones of the little creature , saying , ` If you will only spare my life I may be of great service to you .
6 I will do everything in my power for you ; for I am the King of the Mice , and if I perish the whole race will die out . '
7 ` So be it , ' said Waska . '
8 I will spare your life ; but in return you must do something for me .
9 In this castle there lives a Princess , the wicked wife of my dear master .
10 She has stolen away his magic ring .
11 You must get it away from her at whatever cost ; do you hear ?
12 Till you have done this I wo n't take my claws out of your fur . '
13 ` Good ! '
14 replied the mouse ; ' I will do what you ask . '
15 And , so saying , he summoned all the mice in his kingdom together .
16 A countless number of mice , small and big , brown and grey , assembled , and formed a circle round their king , who was a prisoner under Waska 's claws .
17 Turning to them he said : ` Dear and faithful subjects , who ever among you will steal the magic ring from the strange Princess will release me from a cruel death ; and I shall honour him above all the other mice in the kingdom . '

13 He asked if she would give him food and drink , and she answered kindly and heartily that she would , if he would only come inside .
14 This he did very willingly , and she set before him food and drink that he had never seen the like of before .

16 When she saw that he was not eating at all , she asked him what he wanted yet , to which he replied that he would neither eat nor drink until he knew who she was , or where she came from , or who had put her there . '

1 The King could not hide his amazement , but at the same time his wrath increased , and he was more ready than ever to believe the two brothers , who kept on repeating that Ferko was nothing more nor less than a wicked magician .
2 Only the beautiful Princess rejoiced over Ferko 's success , and looked on him with friendly glances , which the youth returned .
3 The more the cruel King gazed on the wonder before him , the more angry he became , for he could not , in the face of his promise , put the stranger to death .
4 He turned once more to the two brothers and said , ` His diabolical magic has helped him again , but now what third task shall we set him to do ?
5 No matter how impossible it is , he must do it or die . '
6 The eldest answered quickly , ` Let him drive all the wolves of the kingdom on to this hill before to-morrow night .
7 If he does this he may go free ; if not he shall be hung as you have said . '
8 At these words the Princess burst into tears , and when the King saw this he ordered her to be shut up in a high tower and carefully guarded till the dangerous magician should either have left the kingdom or been hung on the nearest tree .
9 Ferko wandered out into the fields again , and sat down on the stump of a tree wondering what he should do next .
10 Suddenly a big wolf ran up to him , and standing still said , ` I 'm very glad to see you again , my kind benefactor .
11 What are you thinking about all alone by yourself ?
12 If I can help you in any way only say the word , for I would like to give you a proof of my gratitude . '
13 Ferko at once recognised the wolf whose broken leg he had healed , and told him what he had to do the following day if he wished to escape with his life .
14 ` But how in the world , ' he added , ` am I to collect all the wolves of the kingdom on to that hill over there ? '
15 ` If that 's all you want done , ' answered the wolf , ` you need n't worry yourself .
16 I 'll undertake the task , and you 'll hear from me again before sunset to-morrow .
17 Keep your spirits up . '
18 And with these words he trotted quickly away .
19 Then the youth rejoiced greatly , for now he felt that his life was safe ; but he grew very sad when he thought of the beautiful Princess , and that he would never see her again if he left the country .

1 A camel had blundered into it , and wet and angry as I was , I could not help laughing .
2 Then I ran on , because I did not know how many camels might have got loose , and before long I was out of sight of the camp , plowing my way through the mud .
3 At last I fell over the tail-end of a gun , and by that knew I was somewhere near the artillery lines where the cannon were stacked at night .
4 As I did not want to plowter about any more in the drizzle and the dark , I put my waterproof over the muzzle of one gun , and made a sort of wigwam with two or three rammers that I found , and lay along the tail of another gun , wondering where Vixen had got to , and where I might be .
5 Just as I was getting ready to go to sleep I heard a jingle of harness and a grunt , and a mule passed me shaking his wet ears .
6 He belonged to a screw-gun battery , for I could hear the rattle of the straps and rings and chains and things on his saddle pad .
7 The screw-guns are tiny little cannon made in two pieces , that are screwed together when the time comes to use them .
8 They are taken up mountains , anywhere that a mule can find a road , and they are very useful for fighting in rocky country .
9 Behind the mule there was a camel , with his big soft feet squelching and slipping in the mud , and his neck bobbing to and fro like a strayed hen 's .
10 Luckily , I knew enough of beast language -- not wild-beast language , but camp-beast language , of course -- from the natives to know what he was saying .
11 He must have been the one that flopped into my tent , for he called to the mule , `` What shall I do ?
12 Where shall I go ?
13 I have fought with a white thing that waved , and it took a stick and hit me on the neck . ''

1 `` I am now teaching him the Master Words of the Jungle that shall protect him with the birds and the Snake People , and all that hunt on four feet , except his own pack .
2 He can now claim protection , if he will only remember the words , from all in the jungle .
3 Is not that worth a little beating ? ''
4 `` Well , look to it then that thou dost not kill the man-cub .
5 He is no tree trunk to sharpen thy blunt claws upon .
6 But what are those Master Words ?
7 I am more likely to give help than to ask it '' -- Bagheera stretched out one paw and admired the steel-blue , ripping-chisel talons at the end of it -- `` still I should like to know . ''
8 `` I will call Mowgli and he shall say them -- if he will .
9 Come , Little Brother ! ''
10 `` My head is ringing like a bee tree , '' said a sullen little voice over their heads , and Mowgli slid down a tree trunk very angry and indignant , adding as he reached the ground : `` I come for Bagheera and not for thee , fat old Baloo ! ''
