1 Outside in the brook grew many water-lilies , with broad green leaves , which looked as if they were swimming about on the water .
2 The leaf farthest away was the largest , and to this the old toad swam with Thumbelina in her walnut-shell .
3 The tiny Thumbelina woke up very early in the morning , and when she saw where she was she began to cry bitterly ; for on every side of the great green leaf was water , and she could not get to the land .
4 The old toad was down under the marsh , decorating her room with rushes and yellow marigold leaves , to make it very grand for her new daughter-in-law ; then she swam out with her ugly son to the leaf where Thumbelina lay .
5 She wanted to fetch the pretty cradle to put it into her room before Thumbelina herself came there .
6 The old toad bowed low in the water before her , and said : ` Here is my son ; you shall marry him , and live in great magnificence down under the marsh . '
7 ` Croak , croak , croak ! '
8 was all that the son could say .
9 Then they took the neat little cradle and swam away with it ; but Thumbelina sat alone on the great green leaf and wept , for she did not want to live with the clammy toad , or marry her ugly son .
10 The little fishes swimming about under the water had seen the toad quite plainly , and heard what she had said ; so they put up their heads to see the little girl .
11 When they saw her , they thought her so pretty that they were very sorry she should go down with the ugly toad to live .
12 No ; that must not happen .
13 They assembled in the water round the green stalk which supported the leaf on which she was sitting , and nibbled the stem in two .
14 Away floated the leaf down the stream , bearing Thumbelina far beyond the reach of the toad .
15 On she sailed past several towns , and the little birds sitting in the bushes saw her , and sang , ` What a pretty little girl ! '
16 The leaf floated farther and farther away ; thus Thumbelina left her native land .
17 A beautiful little white butterfly fluttered above her , and at last settled on the leaf .
18 Thumbelina pleased him , and she , too , was delighted , for now the toads could not reach her , and it was so beautiful where she was travelling ; the sun shone on the water and made it sparkle like the brightest silver .
19 She took off her sash , and tied one end round the butterfly ; the other end she fastened to the leaf , so that now it glided along with her faster than ever .
20 A great cockchafer came flying past ; he caught sight of Thumbelina , and in a moment had put his arms round her slender waist , and had flown off with her to a tree .
21 The green leaf floated away down the XXXXX , and the butterfly with it , for he was fastened to the leaf and could not get loose from it .	stream		butterfly|girl|land|magnificence|marsh|moment|sight|stream|toad|waist

1 He was in his shirt sleeves and wore a big straw hat , and seemed in nowise disconcerted thereby .
2 Corona introduced him , and he took Grey Tom away and put him in the barn .
3 Then he went back to his sweet peas .
4 He had had his tea , he said , so that Frances did not see him again until she went home .
5 She thought he was a very indifferent young man , and not half so nice as his sister .
6 But she went and sat up with Jacky Hart that night , getting to the Cove at dark , when the sea was a shimmer of fairy tints and the boats were coming in from the fishing grounds .
7 Jacky greeted her with a wonderful smile , and later on she found herself watching alone by his bed .
8 The tiny lamp on the table burned dim , and outside , on the rocks , there was loud laughing and talking until a late hour .
9 Afterwards a silence fell , through which the lap of the waves on the sands and the far-off moan of the Atlantic surges came sonorously .
10 Jacky was restless and wakeful , but did not suffer , and liked to talk .
11 Frances listened to him with a new-born power of sympathy , which she thought she must have caught from Corona .
12 He told her all the tragedy of his short life , and how bad he felt , about Dad 's taking to drink and Mammy 's having to work so hard .
13 The pitiful little sentences made Frances 's heart ache .
14 The maternal instinct of the true woman awoke in her .
15 She took a sudden liking to the child .
16 He was a spiritual little creature , and his sufferings had made him old and wise .
17 Once in the night he told Frances that he thought the angels must look like her .

1 Just as the horsemen were about to ford the river , a hare , startled by the sound of the horses ' hoofs , started up from the grass and ran towards the thicket .
2 The young Prince pursued the little creature , and had almost overtaken it , when the girth of his saddle suddenly broke in two and he fell heavily to the ground .
3 No sooner had his foot touched the earth than he disappeared before the eyes of the horrified courtiers .
4 They sought for him far and near , but all in vain , and they were forced to recognise the power of the evil Fairy , against which the Queen had warned them on her death-bed .
5 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
6 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen power , and hurried away he knew not whither .
7 A whole new world stretched out before him , quite unlike the one he had left .
8 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
9 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
10 No sooner had the Fairy reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .
11 Then she gave him an axe made of glass , and bade him cross the bridge of clouds and go into the wood beyond and cut down all the trees there before sunset .
12 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
13 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
14 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
15 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
16 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
17 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
18 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .
19 Mindful of the Fairy 's warning he did not dare to address her , but she on her part greeted him in the most friendly manner , and asked him at once if he were under the power of the wicked Fairy .
20 The Prince nodded his head silently in answer .
21 Then the black XXXXX told him that she too was in the power of the Fairy , who had doomed her to wander about in her present guise until some youth should take pity on her and bear her in safety to the other side of the river which they saw in the distance , and on the other side of which the Fairy 's domain and power ended .	girl		approach|blow|disappearance|eyes|girl|horsemen|news|nothing|punishment|youth

1 In a moment the King of the Fishes appeared , and said to him : ' I know quite well what you want me to do , and I will summon all the fishes of the sea together , and tell them to bring you back the mare , who is hiding herself in a river . '
2 Towards evening the mare was returned to him , and when he led her home to the Mother Dragon she said to him : ` You are a brave youth , and I will make you my body-servant .
3 But what shall I give you as a reward to begin with ? '
4 The Prince begged for a foal of the mare , which the Mother Dragon at once gave him , and over and above , a cloak made of gold , for she had fallen in love with him because he had praised her beauty .
5 So in the evening he appeared at the ball in his golden cloak ; but before the entertainment was over he slipped away , and went straight to the stables , where he mounted his foal and rode out into the meadow to wait for the Flower Queen 's daughter .
6 Towards midnight the beautiful girl appeared , and placing her in front of him on his horse , the Prince and she flew like the wind till they reached the Flower Queen 's dwelling .
7 But the dragons had noticed their flight , and woke their brother out of his year 's sleep .
8 He flew into a terrible rage when he heard what had happened , and determined to lay siege to the Flower Queen 's palace ; but the Queen caused a forest of flowers as high as the sky to grow up round her dwelling , through which no one could force a way .
9 When the Flower Queen heard that her daughter wanted to marry the Prince , she said to him : ' I will give my consent to your marriage gladly , but my daughter can only stay with you in summer .
10 In winter , when everything is dead and the ground covered with snow , she must come and live with me in my palace underground . '
11 The Prince consented to this , and led his beautiful bride home , where the wedding was held with great pomp and magnificence .
12 The young couple lived happily together till winter came , when the Flower Queen 's daughter departed and went home to her mother .
13 In summer she returned to her husband , and their life of joy and happiness began again , and lasted till the approach of winter , when the Flower Queen 's daughter went back again to her mother .
14 This coming and going continued all her life long , and in spite of it they always lived happily together .

1 Tell me his nest and his name .
2 Rikki , the valiant , the true , Tikki , with eyeballs of flame , Rikk-tikki-tikki , the ivory-fanged , the hunter with eyeballs of flame !
3 Give him the Thanks of the Birds , Bowing with tail feathers spread !
4 Praise him with nightingale words -- Nay , I will praise him instead .
5 Hear !
6 I will sing you the praise of the bottle-tailed Rikki , with eyeballs of red !
7 -LRB- Here Rikki-tikki interrupted , and the rest of the song is lost . -RRB-
8 Toomai of the Elephants I will remember what I was , I am sick of rope and chain -- I will remember my old strength and all my forest affairs .
9 I will not sell my back to man for a bundle of sugar-cane : I will go out to my own kind , and the wood-folk in their lairs .
10 I will go out until the day , until the morning break -- Out to the wind 's untainted kiss , the water 's clean caress ; I will forget my ankle-ring and snap my picket stake .
11 I will revisit my lost loves , and playmates masterless !
12 Kala Nag , which means Black Snake , had served the Indian Government in every way that an elephant could serve it for forty-seven years , and as he was fully twenty years old when he was caught , that makes him nearly seventy -- a ripe age for an elephant .
13 He remembered pushing , with a big leather pad on his forehead , at a gun stuck in deep mud , and that was before the Afghan War of 1842 , and he had not then come to his full strength .
14 His mother Radha Pyari , -- Radha the darling , -- who had been caught in the same drive with Kala Nag , told him , before his little milk tusks had dropped out , that elephants who were afraid always got hurt .
15 Kala Nag knew that that advice was good , for the first time that he saw a shell burst he backed , screaming , into a stand of piled rifles , and the bayonets pricked him in all his softest places .
16 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
17 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
18 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
19 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
20 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
21 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other XXXXX who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .	elephants		day|drive|elephants|eyeballs|nest|rope|service|tents|time|way

1 All the trees of the wood were cut up into firewood and arranged in bundles ready for use .
2 He returned to the castle as quickly as he could , and told the Fairy that her commands were obeyed .
3 She was even more amazed than she had been before , and asked him again if he had either seen or spoken to the black girl ; but the Prince knew better than to betray his word , and once more lied freely .
4 On the following day the Fairy set him a third task to do , even harder than the other two .
5 She told him he must build a castle on the other side of the lake , made of nothing but gold , silver , and precious stones , and unless he could accomplish this within an hour , the most frightful doom awaited him .
6 The Prince heard her words without anxiety , so entirely did he rely on the help of his black friend .
7 Full of hope he hurried across the bridge , and recognised at once the spot where the castle was to stand , for spades , hammers , axes , and every other building implement lay scattered on the ground ready for the workman 's hand , but of gold , silver , and precious stones there was not a sign .
8 But before the Prince had time to feel despondent the black girl beckoned to him in the distance from behind a rock , where she had hidden herself for fear her mother should catch sight of her .
9 Full of joy the youth hurried towards her , and begged her aid and counsel in the new piece of work he had been given to do .
10 But this time the Fairy had watched the Prince 's movements from her window , and she saw him hiding himself behind the rock with her daughter .
11 She uttered a piercing shriek so that the mountains re-echoed with the sound of it , and the terrified pair had hardly dared to look out from their hiding-place when the enraged woman , with her dress and hair flying in the wind , hurried over the bridge of clouds .
12 The Prince at once gave himself up for lost , but the girl told him to be of good courage and to follow her as quickly as he could .
13 But before they left their shelter she broke off a little bit of the rock , spoke some magic words over it , and threw it in the direction her mother was coming from .
14 In a moment a glittering palace arose before the eyes of the Fairy which blinded her with its dazzling splendour , and with its many doors and passages prevented her for some time from finding her way out of it .
15 In the meantime the black girl hurried on with the Prince , hastening to reach the river , where once on the other side they would for ever be out of the wicked Fairy 's power .
16 But before they had accomplished half the way they heard again the rustle of her garments and her muttered curses pursuing them closely .
17 The Prince was terrified ; he dared not look back , and he felt his strength giving way .
18 But before he had time to despair the girl uttered some more magic words , and immediately she herself was changed into a pond , and the Prince into a duck swimming on its surface .
19 When the Fairy saw this her rage knew no bounds , and she used all her magic wits to make the pond disappear ; she caused a hill of sand to arise at her feet , meaning it to dry up the water at once .
20 But the sand hill only drove the pond a little farther away , and its waters seemed to increase instead of diminishing .
21 When the old XXXXX saw that the powers of her magic were of so little avail , she had recourse to cunning .	woman		bundles|direction|dress|garments|meantime|rustle|shelter|sight|woman|workman

1 `` If he is living still , he 'll be able to tell you . ''
2 `` How shall I know Sea Cow when I meet him ? ''
3 said Kotick , sheering off .
4 `` He 's the only thing in the sea uglier than Sea Vitch , '' screamed a Burgomaster gull , wheeling under Sea Vitch 's nose .
5 `` Uglier , and with worse manners !
6 Stareek ! ''
7 Kotick swam back to Novastoshnah , leaving the gulls to scream .
8 There he found that no one sympathized with him in his little attempt to discover a quiet place for the seals .
9 They told him that men had always driven the holluschickie -- it was part of the day 's work -- and that if he did not like to see ugly things he should not have gone to the killing grounds .
10 But none of the other seals had seen the killing , and that made the difference between him and his friends .
11 Besides , Kotick was a white seal .
12 `` What you must do , '' said old Sea Catch , after he had heard his son 's adventures , `` is to grow up and be a big seal like your father , and have a nursery on the beach , and then they will leave you alone .
13 In another five years you ought to be able to fight for yourself . ''
14 Even gentle Matkah , his mother , said : `` You will never be able to stop the killing .
15 Go and play in the sea , Kotick . ''
16 And Kotick went off and danced the Fire-dance with a very heavy little heart .
17 That autumn he left the beach as soon as he could , and set off alone because of a notion in his bullet-head .
18 He was going to find Sea Cow , if there was such a person in the sea , and he was going to find a quiet island with good firm beaches for seals to live on , where men could not get at them .
19 So he explored and explored by himself from the North to the South Pacific , swimming as much as three hundred miles in a day and a night .
20 He met with more adventures than can be told , and narrowly escaped being caught by the Basking Shark , and the Spotted Shark , and the Hammerhead , and he met all the untrustworthy ruffians that loaf up and down the seas , and the heavy polite fish , and the scarlet spotted scallops that are moored in one place for hundreds of years , and grow very proud of it ; but he never met Sea Cow , and he never found an island that he could fancy .

1 He bit the bread a second and third time , and each time a piece of gold fell out of his mouth ; but the bread remained untouched .
2 The Herd-boy was very much delighted over his stroke of good fortune , and , hiding the magic loaf in his bag , he hurried off to the nearest village to buy himself something to eat , and then returned to his sheep .
3 Now the Lord whose sheep the Herd-boy looked after had a very lovely daughter , who always smiled and nodded to the youth when she walked with her father in his fields .
4 For a long time the Herd-boy had made up his mind to prepare a surprise for this beautiful creature on her birthday .
5 So when the day approached he put on his invisible belt , took a sack of gold pieces with him , and slipping into her room in the middle of the night , he placed the bag of gold beside her bed and returned to his sheep .
6 The girl 's joy was great , and so was her parents ' next day when they found the sack full of gold pieces .
7 The Herd-boy was so pleased to think what pleasure he had given that the next night he placed another bag of gold beside the girl 's bed .
8 And this he continued to do for seven nights , and the girl and her parents made up their minds that it must be a good Fairy who brought the gold every night .
9 But one night they determined to watch , and see from their hiding place who the bringer of the sack of gold really was .
10 On the eighth night a fearful storm of wind and rain came on while the Herd-boy was on his way to bring the beautiful girl another bag of gold .
11 Then for the first time he noticed , just as he reached his master 's house , that he had forgotten the belt which made him invisible .
12 He did n't like the idea of going back to his hut in the wind and wet , so he just stepped as he was into the girl 's room , laid the sack of gold beside her , and was turning to leave the room , when his master confronted him and said , ` You young rogue , so you were going to steal the gold that a good Fairy brings every night , were you ? '
13 The Herd-boy was so taken aback by his words , that he stood trembling before him , and did not dare to explain his presence .
14 Then his master spoke .
15 ` As you have hitherto always behaved well in my service I will not send you to prison ; but leave your place instantly and never let me see your face again . '
16 So the Herd-boy went back to his hut , and taking his loaf and belt with him , he went to the nearest town .
17 There he bought himself some fine clothes , and a beautiful coach with four horses , hired two servants , and drove back to his master .
18 You may imagine how astonished he was to see his Herd-boy returning to him in this manner !
19 Then the youth told him of the piece of good luck that had befallen him , and asked him for the hand of his beautiful daughter .
20 This was readily granted , and the two lived in peace and happiness to the end of their lives .

4 Her eyes glittered with an unearthly light .
5 She was talking incoherently .

7 Estella laughed hysterically .

1 ` And how can I do that ? '
2 asked the Prince .
3 ` With a little water , ' replied the man ; ` only sprinkle a few drops over me and I shall feel better . '
4 The Prince , moved by pity , without thinking what he was doing , ran to the courtyard of the castle , and filled a jug with water , which he poured over the man in the cauldron .
5 In a moment a most fearful crash was heard , as if all the pillars of the palace were giving way , and the palace itself , with towers and doors , windows and the cauldron , whirled round the bewildered Prince 's head .
6 This continued for a few minutes , and then everything vanished into thin air , and Iwanich found himself suddenly alone upon a desolate heath covered with rocks and stones .
7 The Prince , who now realised what his heedlessness had done , cursed too late his spirit of curiosity .
8 In his despair he wandered on over the heath , never looking where he put his feet , and full of sorrowful thoughts .
9 At last he saw a light in the distance , which came from a miserable-looking little hut .
10 The owner of it was none other than the kind-hearted gaunt grey beggar who had given the Prince the bag of bread-crumbs and the hare .
11 Without recognising Iwanich , he opened the door when he knocked and gave him shelter for the night .
12 On the following morning the Prince asked his host if he could get him any work to do , as he was quite unknown in the neighbourhood , and had not enough money to take him home .
13 ` My son , ' replied the old man , ` all this country round here is uninhabited ; I myself have to wander to distant villages for my living , and even then I do not very often find enough to satisfy my hunger .
14 But if you would like to take service with the old witch Corva , go straight up the little stream which flows below my hut for about three hours , and you will come to a sand-hill on the left-hand side ; that is where she lives . '
15 Iwanich thanked the gaunt grey beggar for his information , and went on his way .
16 After walking for about three hours the Prince came upon a dreary-looking grey stone wall ; this was the back of the building and did not attract him ; but when he came upon the front of the house he found it even less inviting , for the old witch had surrounded her dwelling with a fence of spikes , on every one of which a man 's skull was stuck .
17 In this horrible enclosure stood a small black house , which had only two grated windows , all covered with cobwebs , and a battered iron door .
18 The Prince knocked , and a rasping woman 's voice told him to enter .
19 Iwanich opened the door , and found himself in a smoke-begrimed kitchen , in the presence of a hideous old woman who was warming her skinny hands at a fire .
20 The Prince offered to become her servant , and the old hag told him she was badly in want of one , and he seemed to be just the person to suit her .
21 When Iwanich asked what his XXXXX , and how much his wages would be , the witch bade him follow her , and led the way through a narrow damp passage into a vault , which served as a stable .	work		cobwebs|courtyard|door|feet|none|presence|rocks|servant|water|work

11 So did Unc ' Billy Possum .

1 At first they all kept together , but soon each began to think that he knew the right way best ; so they separated , and all went in different directions .
2 The Prince , too , had got lost like the rest , and wandered on for a time until he came to a little clearing in the forest not far from the sea , where he saw a woman sitting on a chair and a big barrel standing beside her .
3 The Prince went up to her and saluted her politely , and she received him very graciously .
4 He looked down into the barrel then , and saw lying at the bottom an unusually beautiful gold ring , which pleased him so much that he could not take his eyes off it .
5 The woman saw this , and said that he might have it if he would take the trouble to get it ; for which the Prince thanked her , and said it was at least worth trying .
6 So he leaned over into the barrel , which did not seem very deep , and thought he would easily reach the ring ; but the more he stretched down after it the deeper grew the barrel .
7 As he was thus bending down into it the woman suddenly rose up and pushed him in head first , saying that now he could take up his quarters there .
8 Then she fixed the top on the barrel and threw it out into the sea .
9 The Prince thought himself in a bad plight now , as he felt the barrel floating out from the land and tossing about on the waves .
10 How many days he spent thus he could not tell , but at last he felt that the barrel was knocking against rocks , at which he was a little cheered , thinking it was probably land and not merely a reef in the sea .
11 Being something of a swimmer , he at last made up his mind to kick the bottom out of the barrel , and having done so he was able to get on shore , for the rocks by the sea were smooth and level ; but overhead there were high cliffs .
12 It seemed difficult to get up these , but he went along the foot of them for a little , till at last he tried to climb up , which at last he did .
13 Having got to the top , he looked round about him and saw that he was on an island , which was covered with forest , with apples growing , and altogether pleasant as far as the land was concerned .
14 After he had been there several days , he one day heard a great noise in the forest , which made him terribly afraid , so that he ran to hide himself among the trees .
15 Then he saw a Giant approaching , dragging a sledge loaded with wood , and making straight for him , so that he could see nothing for it but to lie down just where he was .
16 When the Giant came across him , he stood still and looked at the Prince for a little ; then he took him up in his arms and carried him home to his house , and was exceedingly kind to him .
17 He gave him to his wife , saying he had found this child in the wood , and she could have it to help her in the house .
18 The old woman was greatly pleased , and began to fondle the Prince with the utmost delight .
19 He stayed there with them , and was very willing and obedient to them in everything , while they grew kinder to him every day .
20 One day the Giant took him round and showed him all his rooms except the parlour ; this made the Prince curious to have a look into it , thinking there must be some very rare treasure there .
21 So one day , when the Giant had gone into the XXXXX , he tried to get into the parlour , and managed to get the door open half-way .	forest		foot|forest|home|house|noise|reef|round|shore|time|trees

8 So she went in search of her hedgehog .
9 The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog , which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other : the only difficulty was , that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden , where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree .
10 By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back , the fight was over , and both the hedgehogs were out of sight : ` but it does n't matter much , ' thought Alice , ` as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground . '
11 So she tucked it away under her arm , that it might not escape again , and went back for a little more conversation with her friend .

1 They will rush to eat them up greedily , and when you have scattered the last crumb you must lose no time in throwing the hare to them ; as soon as the hare feels itself on the ground it will run away as quickly as possible , and the wild beasts will turn to pursue it .
2 In this way you will be able to get through the wood unhurt . '
3 Iwanich thanked the old man for his counsel , dismounted from his horse , and , taking the bag and the hare in his arms , he entered the forest .
4 He had hardly lost sight of his gaunt grey friend when he heard growls and snarls in the thicket close to him , and before he had time to think he found himself surrounded by the most dreadful-looking creatures .
5 On one side he saw the glittering eye of a cruel tiger , on the other the gleaming teeth of a great she-wolf ; here a huge bear growled fiercely , and there a horrible snake coiled itself in the grass at his feet .
6 But Iwanich did not forget the old man 's advice , and quickly put his hand into the bag and took out as many bread-crumbs as he could hold in his hand at a time .
7 He threw them to the beasts , but soon the bag grew lighter and lighter , and the Prince began to feel a little frightened .
8 And now the last crumb was gone , and the hungry beasts thronged round him , greedy for fresh prey .
9 Then he seized the hare and threw it to them .
10 No sooner did the little creature feel itself on the ground than it lay back its ears and flew through the wood like an arrow from a bow , closely pursued by the wild beasts , and the Prince was left alone .
11 He looked at his ring , and when he saw that it sparkled as brightly as ever he went straight on through the forest .
12 He had n't gone very far when he saw a most extraordinary looking man coming towards him .
13 He was not more than three feet high , his legs were quite crooked , and all his body was covered with prickles like a hedgehog .
14 Two lions walked with him , fastened to his side by the two ends of his long beard .
15 He stopped the Prince and asked him in a harsh voice : ` Are you the man who has just fed my body-guard ? '
16 Iwanich was so startled that he could hardly reply , but the little man continued : ' I am most grateful to you for your kindness ; what can I give you as a reward ? '
17 ` All I ask , ' replied Iwanich , ` is , that I should be allowed to go through this wood in safety . '
18 ` Most certainly , ' answered the little man ; ` and for greater security I will give you one of my lions as a protector .
19 But when you leave this wood and come near a palace which does not belong to my domain , let the lion go , in order that he may not fall into the hands of an enemy and be killed . '
20 With these words he loosened the lion from his beard and bade the beast guard the youth carefully .
21 With this new protector Iwanich wandered on through the forest , and though he came upon a great many more wolves , hyenas , leopards , and other wild XXXXX , they always kept at a respectful distance when they saw what sort of an escort the Prince had with him .	beasts		bag|beard|beasts|domain|horse|prey|sight|teeth|voice|way

1 I will undertake , sire , to steal away the ring for you . '
2 And the tiny mouse tripped away into the bedroom of the Princess , and waited for nightfall ; then , when the Princess had fallen asleep , it crept up on to her bed , and gnawed a hole in the pillow , through which it dragged one by one little down feathers , and threw them under the Princess 's nose .
3 And the fluff flew into the Princess 's nose , and into her mouth , and starting up she sneezed and coughed , and the ring fell out of her mouth on to the coverlet .
4 In a flash the tiny mouse had seized it , and brought it to Waska as a ransom for the King of the Mice .
5 Thereupon Waska and Schurka started off , and travelled night and day till they reached the stone tower where Martin was imprisoned ; and the cat climbed up the window , and called out to him : ` Martin , dear master , are you still alive ? '
6 ` Ah !
7 Waska , my faithful little cat , is that you ? '
8 replied a weak voice . '
9 I am dying of hunger .
10 For three days I have not tasted food . '
11 ` Be of good heart , dear master , ' replied Waska ; ` from this day forth you will know nothing but happiness and prosperity .
12 If this were a moment to trouble you with riddles , I would make you guess what Schurka and I have brought you back .
13 Only think , we have got you your ring ! '
14 At these words Martin 's joy knew no bounds , and he stroked her fondly , and she rubbed up against him and purred happily , while below Schurka bounded in the air , and barked joyfully .
15 Then Martin took the ring , and threw it from one hand into the other , and instantly the twelve youths appeared and asked what they were to do .
16 ` Fetch me first something to eat and drink , as quickly as possible ; and after that bring musicians hither , and let us have music all day long . '
17 Now when the people in the town and palace heard music coming from the tower they were filled with amazement , and came to the King with the news that witchcraft must be going on in Martin 's Tower , for , instead of dying of starvation , he was seemingly making merry to the sound of music , and to the clatter of plates , and glass , and knives and forks ; and the music was so enchantingly sweet that all the passers-by stood still to listen to it .
18 On this the King sent at once a messenger to the Starvation Tower , and he was so astonished with what he saw that he remained rooted to the spot .
19 Then the King sent his chief counsellors , and they too were transfixed with wonder .
20 At last the King came himself , and he likewise was spellbound by the beauty of the music .
21 Then Martin summoned the twelve XXXXX , spoke to them , saying , ` Build up my castle again , and join it to the King 's Palace with a crystal bridge ; do not forget the trees with the golden and silver apples , and with the birds of Paradise in the branches ; and put back the church with the five cupolas , and let the bells ring out , summoning the people from the four corners of the kingdom .	youths		bed|bedroom|coverlet|music|musicians|nose|pillow|ring|wonder|youths

1 So he took the best horse in the stable and set out .
2 Three years he spent travelling through forests and wildernesses , but could find no one able to tell him anything of the Princess .
3 At last he fell into so great despair that he thought he would put an end to his own life , and for this purpose laid hold of the sword that she had given him by the hands of the fair-haired lad ; but on drawing it from its sheath he noticed that there was some writing on one side of the blade .
4 He looked at this , and read there , ` You will find me in the Blue Mountains . '
5 This made him take heart again , and he gave up the idea of killing himself , thinking that he would go on in hope of meeting some one who could tell him where the Blue Mountains were .
6 After he had gone a long way without thinking where he was going , he saw at last a light far away , and made straight for it .
7 On reaching it he found it came from a little house , and as soon as the man inside heard the noise of the horse 's feet he came out to see who was there .
8 Seeing a stranger on horseback , he asked what brought him there and where he was going . '
9 I have lived here , ' said he , ` for three hundred years , and all that time I have not seen a single human being but yourself . ' '
10 I have been going about for the last three years , ' said the Irishman , ` to see if I could find anyone who can tell me where the Blue Mountains are . '
11 ` Come in , ' said the old man , ` and stay with me all night .
12 I have a book which contains the history of the world , which I shall go through to-night , and if there is such a place as the Blue Mountains in it we shall find it out . '
13 The Irishman stayed there all night , and as soon as morning came rose to go .
14 The old man said he had not gone to sleep all night for going through the book , but there was not a word about the Blue Mountains in it .
15 ` But I 'll tell you what , ' he said , ` if there is such a place on earth at all , I have a brother who lives nine hundred miles from here , and he is sure to know where they are , if anyone in this world does . '
16 The Irishman answered that he could never go these nine hundred miles , for his horse was giving in already .
17 ` That does n't matter , ' said the old man ; ' I can do better than that .
18 I have only to blow my whistle and you will be at my brother 's house before nightfall . '
19 So he blew the whistle , and the Irishman did not know where on earth he was until he found himself at the other old man 's door , who also told him that it was three hundred years since he had seen anyone , and asked him where he was going . '
20 I am going to see if I can find anyone that can tell me where the Blue Mountains are , ' he said .
21 ` If you will stay with me to-night , ' said the old man , ' I have a book of the history of the XXXXX , and I shall know where they are before daylight , if there is such a place in it at all . '	world		anything|being|door|earth|end|history|house|noise|word|world

1 As Thumbelina pleased her , she said : ` As far as I am concerned you may spend the winter with me ; but you must keep my room clean and tidy , and tell me stories , for I like that very much . '
2 And Thumbelina did all that the kind old field-mouse asked , and did it remarkably well too .
3 ` Now I am expecting a visitor , ' said the field-mouse ; ` my neighbour comes to call on me once a week .
4 He is in better circumstances than I am , has great , big rooms , and wears a fine black-velvet coat .
5 If you could only marry him , you would be well provided for .
6 But he is blind .
7 You must tell him all the prettiest stories you know . '
8 But Thumbelina did not trouble her head about him , for he was only a mole .
9 He came and paid them a visit in his black-velvet coat .
10 ` He is so rich and so accomplished , ' the field-mouse told her .
11 ` His house is twenty times larger than mine ; he possesses great knowledge , but he can not bear the sun and the beautiful flowers , and speaks slightingly of them , for he has never seen them . '
12 Thumbelina had to sing to him , so she sang ` Lady-bird , lady-bird , fly away home ! '
13 and other songs so prettily that the mole fell in love with her ; but he did not say anything , he was a very cautious man .
14 A short time before he had dug a long passage through the ground from his own house to that of his neighbour ; in this he gave the field-mouse and Thumbelina permission to walk as often as they liked .
15 But he begged them not to be afraid of the dead bird that lay in the passage : it was a real bird with beak and feathers , and must have died a little time ago , and now laid buried just where he had made his tunnel .
16 The mole took a piece of rotten wood in his mouth , for that glows like fire in the dark , and went in front , lighting them through the long dark passage .
17 When they came to the place where the dead bird lay , the mole put his broad nose against the ceiling and pushed a hole through , so that the daylight could shine down .
18 In the middle of the path lay a dead swallow , his pretty wings pressed close to his sides , his claws and head drawn under his feathers ; the poor bird had evidently died of cold .
19 Thumbelina was very sorry , for she was very fond of all little birds ; they had sung and twittered so beautifully to her all through the summer .
20 But the mole kicked him with his bandy legs and said : ` Now he ca n't sing any more !
21 It must be very miserable to be a little XXXXX !	bird		bird|birds|claws|coat|feathers|home|piece|tunnel|visitor|winter

4 Frances looked up calmly .
5 Her clear , placid voice was audible not only to those in the nearby pews , but to the minister .
6 `` No , Mr. Craig .
7 You know if a woman is n't fit to speak in the church she ca n't be fit to sing in it either . ''
8 Eben Craig looked exceedingly foolish .
9 He tiptoed gingerly back to his place .
10 The minister , with an unusual flush on his thin , ascetic face , rose suddenly and gave out the opening hymn .
11 Nobody who heard the singing in Putney church that day ever forgot it .
12 Untrained basses and tenors , unrelieved by a single female voice , are not inspiring .
13 There were no announcements of society meetings for the forthcoming week .
14 On the way home from church that day irate husbands and fathers scolded , argued , or pleaded , according to their several dispositions .
15 One and all met with the same calm statement that if a noble , self-sacrificing woman like Mrs. Cotterell were not good enough to speak in the Putney church , ordinary , everyday women could not be fit to take any part whatever in its work .
16 Sunday School that afternoon was a harrowing failure .

19 The Putney women never did things by halves .

1 She directed him to do just as he had done before , with only this difference , that instead of going to the stable which had been the ruin of his hopes , he was to enter right into the castle itself , and to glide as fast as he could down the passages till he came to a room filled with perfume , where he would find a beautiful maiden asleep on a bed .
2 He was to wake the maiden instantly and carry her off , and to be sure not to pay any heed to whatever resistance she might make .
3 The Prince obeyed the Frog 's orders one by one , and all went well for this second time also .
4 The gate opened , the inhabitants fell sound asleep , and he walked down the passage till he found the girl on her bed , exactly as he had been told he would .
5 He woke her , and begged her firmly , but politely , to follow him quickly .
6 After a little persuasion the maiden consented , but only on condition that she was allowed first to put on her dress .
7 This sounded so reasonable and natural that it did not enter the Prince 's head to refuse her request .
8 But the maiden 's hand had hardly touched the dress when the palace suddenly awoke from its sleep , and the Prince was seized and bound .
9 He was so vexed with his own folly , and so taken aback at the disaster , that he did not attempt to explain his conduct , and things would have gone badly with him if his friends the fairies had not softened the hearts of his captors , so that they once more allowed him to leave quietly .
10 However , what troubled him most was the idea of having to meet the Frog who had been his benefactress .
11 How was he ever to appear before her with this tale ?
12 Still , after a long struggle with himself , he made up his mind that there was nothing else to be done , and that he deserved whatever she might say to him .
13 And she said a great deal , for she had worked herself into a terrible passion ; but the Prince humbly implored her pardon , and ventured to point out that it would have been very hard to refuse the young lady 's reasonable request .
14 ` You must learn to do as you are told , ' was all the Frog would reply .
15 But poor Saphir was so unhappy , and begged so hard for forgiveness , that at last the Frog 's anger gave way , and she held up to him a tiny diamond stone .
16 ` Go back , ' she said , ` to the castle , and bury this little diamond close to the door .
17 But be careful not to return to the stable or to the bedroom ; they have proved too fatal to you .

1 Never let my cheek grow pale !

4 The youth rose and stood waiting .
5 Then the maiden said , ` You ought to have a heavy punishment because you have presumed to watch my secret doings in the moonlight .
6 But I will forgive you this time , because you are a stranger and knew no better .
7 But you must tell me truly who you are and how you came to this place , where no mortal has ever set foot before . '
8 The youth answered humbly : ` Forgive me , beautiful maiden , if I have unintentionally offended you .
9 I chanced to come here after long wandering , and found a good place to sleep under this tree .
10 At your coming I did not know what to do , but stayed where I was , because I thought my silent watching could not offend you . '
11 The maiden answered kindly , ` Come and spend this night with us .
12 You will sleep better on a pillow than on damp moss . '
13 The youth hesitated for a little , but presently he heard the birds saying from the top of the tree , ` Go where she calls you , but take care to give no blood , or you will sell your soul . '
14 So the youth went with her , and soon they reached a beautiful garden , where stood a splendid house , which glittered in the moonlight as if it was all built out of gold and silver .

1 At the best there would be a storm of protest and objection on her brother 's and sister 's part , and Emily felt that she could not encounter that in her present mood .
2 It would drive her mad .
3 She lit a lamp and dressed herself noiselessly , but with feverish haste .
4 Then she listened .
5 The house was very still .
6 Amelia and John had gone to bed .
7 She wrapped herself in a heavy woollen shawl hanging in the hall and crept downstairs .
8 With numbed fingers she fumbled at the key of the hall door , turned it and slipped out into the night .
9 The storm seemed to reach out and clutch her and swallow her up .
10 She went through the garden , where the flowers already were crushed to earth ; she crossed the long field beyond , where the rain cut her face like a whip and the wind almost twisted her in its grasp like a broken reed .
11 Somehow or other , more by blind instinct than anything else , she found the path that led through commons and woods and waste valleys to her lost home .
12 In after years that frenzied walk through the storm and blackness seemed as an unbroken nightmare to Emily Fair 's recollection .
13 Often she fell .
14 Once as she did so a jagged , dead limb of fir struck her forehead and cut in it a gash that marked her for life .
15 As she struggled to her feet and found her way again the blood trickled down over her face .
16 `` Oh God , do n't let him die before I get to him -- do n't -- do n't -- do n't ! ''
17 she prayed desperately with more of defiance than entreaty in her voice .
18 Then , realizing this , she cried out in horror .
19 Surely some fearsome punishment would come upon her for her wickedness -- she would find her husband lying dead .

1 At last the nurse made up her mind to go to the King , and told him the whole story , and asked him to be present in person next day about the time when the woman usually came .
2 The King promised to do so , and came to the nurse 's room a little before the time , and sat down on a chair with his drawn sword in his hand .
3 Soon after the planks in the floor sprang up as before , and the woman came up , dressed in white , with the iron belt and chain .
4 The King saw at once that it was his own Queen , and immediately hewed asunder the iron chain that was fastened to the belt .
5 This was followed by such noises and crashings down in the earth that all the King 's Palace shook , so that no one expected anything else than to see every bit of it shaken to pieces .
6 At last , however , the noises and shaking stopped , and they began to come to themselves again .
7 The King and Queen embraced each other , and she told him the whole story -- how the Witch came to the ship when they were all asleep and sent her off in the boat .
8 After she had gone so far that she could not see the ship , she sailed on through darkness until she landed beside a three-headed Giant .
9 The Giant wished her to marry him , but she refused ; whereupon he shut her up by herself , and told her she would never get free until she consented .
10 After a time she began to plan how to get her freedom , and at last told him that she would consent if he would allow her to visit her son on earth three days on end .
11 This he agreed to , but put on her this iron belt and chain , the other end of which he fastened round his own waist , and the great noises that were heard when the King cut the chain must have been caused by the Giant 's falling down the underground passage when the chain gave way so suddenly .
12 The Giant 's dwelling , indeed , was right under the Palace , and the terrible shakings must have been caused by him in his death-throes .
13 The King now understood how the Queen he had had for some time past had been so ill-tempered .
14 He at once had a sack drawn over her head and made her be stoned to death , and after that torn in pieces by untamed horses .
15 The two young fellows also told now what they had heard and seen in the Queen 's room , for before this they had been afraid to say anything about it , on account of the Queen 's power .
16 The real Queen was now restored to all her dignity , and was beloved by all .
17 The nurse was married to a nobleman , and the King and Queen gave her splendid presents .

1 ` First and foremost , ' said Olof , ` you must get a wide cloak to wear over your other clothes , when you are put into the mound .
2 The Giant 's ghost will walk after you are both left together in there , and he will have two dogs along with him .
3 He will ask you to cut pieces out of his legs to give to the dogs , but that you must not promise to do unless he tells you where Hermod has gone to , and tells you how to find him .
4 He will then let you stand on his shoulders , so as to get out of the mound ; but he means to cheat you all the same , and will catch you by the cloak to pull you back again ; but you must take care to have the cloak loose on your shoulders , so that he will only get hold of that . '
5 The mound was all ready now , and the Giant laid in it , and into it Hadvor also had to go without being allowed to make any defence .
6 After they were both left there everything happened just as Olof had said .
7 The prince became a Giant again , and asked Hadvor to cut the pieces out of his legs for the dogs ; but she refused until he told her that Hermod was in a desert island , which she could not reach unless she took the skin off the soles of his feet and made shoes out of that ; with these shoes she could travel both on land and sea .
8 This Hadvor now did , and the Giant then let her get up on his shoulders to get out of the mound .
9 As she sprang out he caught hold of her cloak ; but she had taken care to let it lie loose on her shoulders , and so escaped .
10 She now made her way down to the sea , to where she knew there was the shortest distance over to the island in which Hermod was .
11 This strait she easily crossed , for the shoes kept her up .
12 On reaching the island she found a sandy beach all along by the sea , and high cliffs above .
13 Nor could she see any way to get up these , and so , being both sad at heart and tired with the long journey , she lay down and fell asleep .
14 As she slept she dreamed that a tall woman came to her and said , ' I know that you are Princess Hadvor , and are searching for Hermod .
15 He is on this island ; but it will be hard for you to get to him if you have no one to help you , for you can not climb the cliffs by your own strength .
16 I have therefore let down a rope , by which you will be able to climb up ; and as the island is so large that you might not find Hermod 's dwelling-place so easily , I lay down this clew beside you .
17 You need only hold the end of the thread , and the clew will run on before and show you the way .
18 I also lay this belt beside you , to put on when you awaken ; it will keep you from growing faint with hunger . '
19 The woman now disappeared , and Hadvor woke , and saw that all her dream had been true .
20 The rope hung down from the cliff , and the clew and belt lay beside her .
21 The belt she put on , the rope enabled her to climb up the XXXXX , and the clew led her on till she came to the mouth of a cave , which was not very big .	cliff		Giant|beach|cliff|dogs|hold|journey|legs|sea|shoes|strength

3 `` He came naked , by night , alone and very hungry ; yet he was not afraid !
4 Look , he has pushed one of my babes to one side already .
5 And that lame butcher would have killed him and would have run off to the Waingunga while the villagers here hunted through all our lairs in revenge !
6 Keep him ?
7 Assuredly I will keep him .
8 Lie still , little frog .
9 O thou Mowgli -- for Mowgli the Frog I will call thee -- the time will come when thou wilt hunt Shere Khan as he has hunted thee . ''
10 `` But what will our Pack say ? ''
11 said Father Wolf .
12 The Law of the Jungle lays down very clearly that any wolf may , when he marries , withdraw from the Pack he belongs to .
13 But as soon as his cubs are old enough to stand on their feet he must bring them to the Pack Council , which is generally held once a month at full moon , in order that the other wolves may identify them .
14 After that inspection the cubs are free to run where they please , and until they have killed their first buck no excuse is accepted if a grown wolf of the Pack kills one of them .
15 The punishment is death where the murderer can be found ; and if you think for a minute you will see that this must be so .
16 Father Wolf waited till his cubs could run a little , and then on the night of the Pack Meeting took them and Mowgli and Mother Wolf to the Council Rock -- a hilltop covered with stones and boulders where a hundred wolves could hide .
17 Akela , the great gray Lone Wolf , who led all the Pack by strength and cunning , lay out at full length on his rock , and below him sat forty or more wolves of every size and color , from badger-colored veterans who could handle a buck alone to young black three-year-olds who thought they could .
18 The Lone Wolf had led them for a year now .
19 He had fallen twice into a wolf trap in his youth , and once he had been beaten and left for dead ; so he knew the manners and customs of men .
20 There was very little talking at the Rock .
21 The cubs tumbled over each other in the center of the circle where their mothers and fathers sat , and now and again a senior wolf would go quietly up to a cub , look at him carefully , and return to his place on noiseless XXXXX .	feet		Council|O|buck|color|feet|order|rock|side|veterans|villagers

1 We will call you May Blossom . '
2 ` Farewell , farewell ! '
3 said the little swallow with a heavy heart , and flew away to farther lands , far , far away , right back to Denmark .
4 There he had a little nest above a window , where his wife lived , who can tell fairy-stories .
5 ` Tweet , tweet ! '
6 he sang to her .
7 And that is the way we learnt the whole story .
8 THE NIGHTINGALE In China , as I daresay you know , the Emperor is a Chinaman , and all his courtiers are also Chinamen .
9 The story I am going to tell you happened many years ago , but it is worth while for you to listen to it , before it is forgotten .
10 The Emperor 's Palace was the most splendid in the world , all made of priceless porcelain , but so brittle and delicate that you had to take great care how you touched it .
11 In the garden were the most beautiful flowers , and on the loveliest of them were tied silver bells which tinkled , so that if you passed you could not help looking at the flowers .
12 Everything in the Emperor 's garden was admirably arranged with a view to effect ; and the garden was so large that even the gardener himself did not know where it ended .
13 If you ever got beyond it , you came to a stately forest with great trees and deep lakes in it .
14 The forest sloped down to the sea , which was a clear blue .
15 Large ships could sail under the boughs of the trees , and in these trees there lived a Nightingale .
16 She sang so beautifully that even the poor fisherman who had so much to do stood and listened when he came at night to cast his nets .
17 ` How beautiful it is ! '
18 he said ; but he had to attend to his work , and forgot about the bird .
19 But when she sang the next night and the fisherman came there again , he said the same thing , ` How beautiful it is ! '
20 From all the countries round came travellers to the Emperor 's town , who were astonished at the Palace and the garden .
21 But when they heard the Nightingale they all said , ` This is the finest XXXXX after all ! '	thing		bird|blue|courtiers|heart|lands|porcelain|ships|thing|way|world

1 `` Oh , '' said Danny , `` he 's been to dine with Buster Bear , and now he has no use for his old friends . ''
2 Pretty soon along came Johnny Chuck , and he was very much put out because he had been treated by Old Mr. Toad just as Peter Rabbit had .
3 Striped Chipmunk told the same story .
4 So did Unc ' Billy Possum .
5 It was the same with all of Old Mr. Toad 's old friends and neighbors , excepting Bobby Coon , who , you know , is Buster Bear 's little cousin .
6 To him Old Mr. Toad was very polite and talked a great deal about Buster Bear , and thought that Bobby must be very proud to be related to Buster .
7 At first everybody thought it a great joke to see Old Mr. Toad so puffed up with , pride , but after a little they grew tired of being snubbed by their old friend and neighbor , and began to say unpleasant things about him .
8 Then they decided that what Old Mr. Toad needed was a lesson , so they put their heads together and planned how they would teach Old Mr. Toad how foolish it is for any one to be puffed up with pride .
9 XXI OLD MR. TOAD RECEIVES ANOTHER INVITATION The friends and neighbors of Old Mr. Toad decided that he needed to be taught a lesson .
10 At first , you know , every one had laughed at him , because he had grown too proud to speak to them , but after a little they grew tired of being treated so , and some of them put their heads together to think of some plan to teach Old Mr. Toad a lesson and what a very , very foolish thing false pride is .
11 The very next day Jimmy Skunk went into the Green Forest to look for Buster Bear .
12 You know Jimmy is n't afraid of Buster .
13 He did n't have to look long , and when he had found him , the very first thing he did was to ask Buster if he had seen any fat beetles that morning .
14 You know Jimmy is very fond of fat beetles , and the first thing he asks any one he may happen to meet is if they have seen any .
15 Buster Bear grinned and said he thought he knew where there might be a few , and he would be pleased to have Jimmy go with him to see .
16 Sure enough , under an old log he found five fat beetles , and these Jimmy gobbled up without even asking Buster if he would have one .
17 Jimmy is usually very polite , but this time he quite forgot politeness .
18 I am afraid he is rather apt to when fat beetles are concerned .

1 There the mouse lived warm and snug , with a store-room full of corn , a splendid kitchen and dining-room .
2 Poor little Thumbelina went up to the door and begged for a little piece of barley , for she had not had anything to eat for the last two days .
3 ` Poor little creature ! '
4 said the field-mouse , for she was a kind-hearted old thing at the bottom .
5 ` Come into my warm room and have some dinner with me . '
6 As Thumbelina pleased her , she said : ` As far as I am concerned you may spend the winter with me ; but you must keep my room clean and tidy , and tell me stories , for I like that very much . '
7 And Thumbelina did all that the kind old field-mouse asked , and did it remarkably well too .
8 ` Now I am expecting a visitor , ' said the field-mouse ; ` my neighbour comes to call on me once a week .
9 He is in better circumstances than I am , has great , big rooms , and wears a fine black-velvet coat .
10 If you could only marry him , you would be well provided for .
11 But he is blind .
12 You must tell him all the prettiest stories you know . '
13 But Thumbelina did not trouble her head about him , for he was only a mole .
14 He came and paid them a visit in his black-velvet coat .
15 ` He is so rich and so accomplished , ' the field-mouse told her .
16 ` His house is twenty times larger than mine ; he possesses great knowledge , but he can not bear the sun and the beautiful flowers , and speaks slightingly of them , for he has never seen them . '
17 Thumbelina had to sing to him , so she sang ` Lady-bird , lady-bird , fly away home ! '
18 and other songs so prettily that the mole fell in love with her ; but he did not say anything , he was a very cautious man .
19 A short time before he had dug a long passage through the ground from his own house to that of his neighbour ; in this he gave the field-mouse and Thumbelina permission to walk as often as they liked .
20 But he begged them not to be afraid of the dead bird that lay in the passage : it was a real bird with beak and feathers , and must have died a little time ago , and now laid buried just where he had made his tunnel .

6 HOW SIX MEN TRAVELLED THROUGH THE WIDE WORLD There was once upon a time a man who understood all sorts of arts ; he served in the war , and bore himself bravely and well ; but when the war was over , he got his discharge , and set out on his travels with three farthings of his pay in his pocket .
7 ` Wait , ' he said ; ` that does not please me ; only let me find the right people , and the King shall yet give me all the treasures of his kingdom . '
8 He strode angrily into the forest , and there he saw a man standing who had uprooted six trees as if they were straws .
9 He said to him , ` Will you be my servant and travel with me ? '
10 ` Yes , ' he answered ; ` but first of all I will take this little bundle of sticks home to my mother , ' and he took one of the trees and wound it round the other five , raised the bundle on his shoulders and bore it off .
11 Then he came back and went with his master , who said , ` We two ought to be able to travel through the wide world ! '
12 And when they had gone a little way they came upon a hunter , who was on his knees , his gun on his shoulder , aiming at something .
13 The master said to him , ` Hunter , what are you aiming at ? '
14 He answered , ` Two miles from this place sits a fly on a branch of an oak ; I want to shoot out its left eye . '
15 ` Oh , go with me , ' said the man ; ` if we three are together we shall easily travel through the wide world . '
16 The hunter agreed and went with him , and they came to seven windmills whose sails were going round quite fast , and yet there was not a breath of wind , nor was a leaf moving .
17 The man said , ' I do n't know what is turning those windmills ; there is not the slightest breeze blowing . '
18 So he walked on with his servants , and when they had gone two miles they saw a man sitting on a tree , holding one of his nostrils and blowing out of the other .

20 asked the man .
21 He replied , ` Two miles from this XXXXX are standing seven windmills ; see , I am blowing to drive them round . '	place		castle|eye|joy|master|place|sails|shape|something|way|world

1 -LRB- Here Rikki-tikki interrupted , and the rest of the song is lost . -RRB-
2 Toomai of the Elephants I will remember what I was , I am sick of rope and chain -- I will remember my old strength and all my forest affairs .
3 I will not sell my back to man for a bundle of sugar-cane : I will go out to my own kind , and the wood-folk in their lairs .
4 I will go out until the day , until the morning break -- Out to the wind 's untainted kiss , the water 's clean caress ; I will forget my ankle-ring and snap my picket stake .
5 I will revisit my lost loves , and playmates masterless !
6 Kala Nag , which means Black Snake , had served the Indian Government in every way that an elephant could serve it for forty-seven years , and as he was fully twenty years old when he was caught , that makes him nearly seventy -- a ripe age for an elephant .
7 He remembered pushing , with a big leather pad on his forehead , at a gun stuck in deep mud , and that was before the Afghan War of 1842 , and he had not then come to his full strength .
8 His mother Radha Pyari , -- Radha the darling , -- who had been caught in the same drive with Kala Nag , told him , before his little milk tusks had dropped out , that elephants who were afraid always got hurt .
9 Kala Nag knew that that advice was good , for the first time that he saw a shell burst he backed , screaming , into a stand of piled rifles , and the bayonets pricked him in all his softest places .
10 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
11 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
12 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
13 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
14 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
15 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other elephants who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .
16 Elephants are very strictly preserved by the Indian Government .
17 There is one whole department which does nothing else but hunt them , and catch them , and break them in , and send them up and down the country as they are needed for work .
18 Kala Nag stood ten fair feet at the shoulders , and his tusks had been cut off short at five feet , and bound round the ends , to prevent them splitting , with bands of copper ; but he could do more with those stumps than any untrained elephant could do with the real sharpened ones .
19 When , after weeks and weeks of cautious driving of scattered elephants across the hills , the forty or fifty wild monsters were driven into the last stockade , and the big drop gate , made of tree trunks lashed together , jarred down behind them , Kala Nag , at the word of command , would go into that flaring , trumpeting pandemonium -LRB- generally at night , when the flicker of the torches made it difficult to judge distances -RRB- , and , picking out the biggest and wildest tusker of the mob , would hammer him and hustle him into quiet while the men on the backs of the other elephants roped and tied the smaller ones .
20 There was nothing in the way of fighting that Kala Nag , the old wise Black Snake , did not know , for he had stood up more than once in his time to the charge of the wounded tiger , and , curling up his soft trunk to be out of harm 's way , had knocked the springing brute sideways in mid-air with a quick sickle cut of his head , that he had invented all by himself ; had knocked him over , and kneeled upon him with his huge knees till the life went out with a gasp and a howl , and there was only a fluffy striped thing on the ground for Kala Nag to pull by the tail .
21 `` Yes , '' said Big Toomai , his driver , the son of Black Toomai who had taken him to Abyssinia , and grandson of Toomai of the Elephants who had seen him caught , `` there is XXXXX that the Black Snake fears except me .	nothing		Elephants|advice|business|cut|hunt|nothing|rope|strength|tiger|water

8 There were once a King and a Queen , and they had a son called Sigurd , who was very strong and active , and good-looking .
9 When the King came to be bowed down with the weight of years he spoke to his son , and said that now it was time for him to look out for a fitting match for himself , for he did not know how long he might last now , and he would like to see him married before he died .
10 Sigurd was not averse to this , and asked his father where he thought it best to look for a wife .
11 The King answered that in a certain country there was a King who had a beautiful daughter , and he thought it would be most desirable if Sigurd could get her .
12 So the two parted , and Sigurd prepared for the journey , and went to where his father had directed him .
13 He came to the King and asked his daughter 's hand , which he readily granted him , but only on the condition that he should remain there as long as he could , for the King himself was not strong and not very able to govern his kingdom .
14 Sigurd accepted this condition , but added that he would have to get leave to go home again to his own country when he heard news of his father 's death .
15 After that Sigurd married the Princess , and helped his father-in-law to govern the kingdom .
16 He and the Princess loved each other dearly , and after a year a son came to them , who was two years old when word came to Sigurd that his father was dead .

1 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
2 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
3 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
4 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
5 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
6 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
7 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
8 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
9 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
10 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
11 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
12 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
13 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
14 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
15 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
16 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
17 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
18 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
19 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .
20 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
21 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the bank , and soon the XXXXX of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the water .	head		Time|arms|blood|childhood|flute|grief|head|home|hunting|water

6 Quick , now ! '
7 And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to , without trying to explain the mistake it had made .
8 ` He took me for his housemaid , ' she said to herself as she ran .
9 ` How surprised he 'll be when he finds out who I am !
10 But I 'd better take him his fan and gloves -- that is , if I can find them . '
11 As she said this , she came upon a neat little house , on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name ` W. RABBIT ' engraved upon it .
12 She went in without knocking , and hurried upstairs , in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann , and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves .
13 ` How queer it seems , ' Alice said to herself , ` to be going messages for a rabbit !
14 I suppose Dinah 'll be sending me on messages next ! '
15 And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen : ' `` Miss Alice !
16 Come here directly , and get ready for your walk ! ''
17 `` Coming in a minute , nurse !
18 But I 've got to see that the mouse does n't get out . ''
19 Only I do n't think , ' Alice went on , ` that they 'd let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that ! '
20 By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window , and on it -LRB- as she had hoped -RRB- a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves : she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves , and was just going to leave the room , when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass .

1 So he did what they said , and carried the sieve full of water into the hut without spilling a drop .
2 When they entered the hut the cat was curled up on the floor .
3 So they stroked her , and fed her with ham , and said to her : ` Pussy , grey pussy , tell us how we are to get away from the witch ? '
4 Then the cat thanked them for the ham , and gave them a pocket-handkerchief and a comb , and told them that when the witch pursued them , as she certainly would , all they had to do was to throw the handkerchief on the ground and run as fast as they could .
5 As soon as the handkerchief touched the ground a deep , broad river would spring up , which would hinder the witch 's progress .
6 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
7 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
8 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
9 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
10 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
11 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
12 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
13 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
14 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
15 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
16 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
17 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
18 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
19 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
20 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
