7 THE WITCH IN THE STONE BOAT -LRB- 31 -RRB- -LRB- 31 -RRB- From the Icelandic .
8 There were once a King and a Queen , and they had a son called Sigurd , who was very strong and active , and good-looking .
9 When the King came to be bowed down with the weight of years he spoke to his son , and said that now it was time for him to look out for a fitting match for himself , for he did not know how long he might last now , and he would like to see him married before he died .
10 Sigurd was not averse to this , and asked his father where he thought it best to look for a wife .
11 The King answered that in a certain country there was a King who had a beautiful daughter , and he thought it would be most desirable if Sigurd could get her .
12 So the two parted , and Sigurd prepared for the journey , and went to where his father had directed him .
13 He came to the King and asked his daughter 's hand , which he readily granted him , but only on the condition that he should remain there as long as he could , for the King himself was not strong and not very able to govern his kingdom .
14 Sigurd accepted this condition , but added that he would have to get leave to go home again to his own country when he heard news of his father 's death .
15 After that Sigurd married the Princess , and helped his father-in-law to govern the kingdom .
16 He and the Princess loved each other dearly , and after a year a son came to them , who was two years old when word came to Sigurd that his father was dead .
17 Sigurd now prepared to return home with his wife and child , and went on board ship to go by sea .

1 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
2 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen power , and hurried away he knew not whither .
3 A whole new world stretched out before him , quite unlike the one he had left .
4 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
5 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
6 No sooner had the Fairy reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .
7 Then she gave him an axe made of glass , and bade him cross the bridge of clouds and go into the wood beyond and cut down all the trees there before sunset .
8 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
9 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
10 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
11 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
12 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
13 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
14 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .
15 Mindful of the Fairy 's warning he did not dare to address her , but she on her part greeted him in the most friendly manner , and asked him at once if he were under the power of the wicked Fairy .
16 The Prince nodded his head silently in answer .
17 Then the black girl told him that she too was in the power of the Fairy , who had doomed her to wander about in her present guise until some youth should take pity on her and bear her in safety to the other side of the river which they saw in the distance , and on the other side of which the Fairy 's domain and power ended .
18 The girl 's words so inspired the Prince with confidence that he told her all his tale of woe , and ended up by asking her advice as to how he was to escape the punishment the Fairy would be sure to inflict on him when she discovered that he had not cut down the trees in the wood and that he had broken her axe .
19 ` You must know , ' answered the black girl , ` that the Fairy in whose power we both are is my own mother , but you must not betray this secret , for it would cost me my life .
20 If you will only promise to try and free me I will stand by you , and will accomplish for you all the tasks which my mother sets you . '
21 The Prince promised joyfully all she asked ; then having once more warned him not to betray her XXXXX , she handed him a draught to drink which very soon sunk his senses in a deep slumber .	confidence		blow|confidence|detail|domain|girl|guise|power|safety|step|wood

1 In the winter there was spare time to laugh and quarrel , woo and wed and -- were a man so minded -- dream , as did Rob Fletcher in his loneliness .
2 In a Racicot winter much was made of small things .
3 The arrival of Nora Shelley 's weekly letter to her father and mother was an event in the village .
4 The post-mistress in the Cove store spread the news that it had come , and that night the Shelley kitchen would be crowded .
5 Isobel Shelley , Nora 's younger sister , read the letter aloud by virtue of having gone to school long enough to be able to pronounce the words and tell where the places named were situated .
6 The Camerons had spent the autumn in New York and had then gone south for the winter .
7 Nora wrote freely of her new life .
8 In the beginning she admitted great homesickness , but after the first few letters she made no further mention of that .
9 She wrote little of herself , but she described fully the places she had visited , the people she had met , the wonderful things she had seen .
10 She sent affectionate messages to all her old friends and asked after all her old interests .
11 But the letters came to be more and more like those of a stranger and one apart from the Racicot life , and the father and mother felt it .
12 `` She 's changing , '' muttered old Nathan .
13 `` It had to be so -- it 's well for her that it is so -- but it hurts .
14 She ai n't ours any more .
15 We 've lost the girl , wife , lost her forever . ''
16 Rob Fletcher always came and listened to the letters in silence while the others buzzed and commented .

1 You see , Kotick had never fasted for four months as the big seals did every year , and his deep-sea swimming trips kept him in perfect condition , and , best of all , he had never fought before .
2 His curly white mane stood up with rage , and his eyes flamed , and his big dog teeth glistened , and he was splendid to look at .

4 Do n't tackle your father , my son !
5 He 's with you ! ''
6 Kotick roared in answer , and old Sea Catch waddled in with his mustache on end , blowing like a locomotive , while Matkah and the seal that was going to marry Kotick cowered down and admired their men-folk .
7 It was a gorgeous fight , for the two fought as long as there was a seal that dared lift up his head , and when there were none they paraded grandly up and down the beach side by side , bellowing .
8 At night , just as the Northern Lights were winking and flashing through the fog , Kotick climbed a bare rock and looked down on the scattered nurseries and the torn and bleeding seals .

1 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
2 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
3 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
4 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
5 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
6 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
7 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
8 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
9 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
10 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
11 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
12 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
13 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
14 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
15 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
16 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
17 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
18 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
19 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
20 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .

1 `` All right , '' replied Peter promptly , turning his back to Old Mr. Toad .

3 So Peter sat and gazed straight down the Crooked Little Path .
4 It was a great temptation to roll his eyes back and peep behind him , but he had given his word that he would n't , and he did n't .
5 When he thought the five minutes were up , he turned around .
6 Old Mr. Toad was nowhere to be seen .
7 Peter looked hastily this way and that way , but there was not a sign of Old Mr. Toad .
8 He had disappeared as completely as if he never had been there .
9 XV OLD MR. TOAD GIVES PETER A SCARE If you play pranks on other folks You may be sure that they Will take the first chance that they get A joke on you to play .
10 Old Mr. Toad was getting even with Peter for laughing at him .
11 While Peter 's back had been turned , Old Mr. Toad had disappeared .
12 It was too much for Peter .

16 Of course not .

18 Peter should have known better than to have looked there .
19 Old Mr. Toad had also said that he would not go three feet from the spot where he was sitting at the time , so Peter should have known better than to have raced up the Crooked Little Path as he did .
20 But if Old Mr. Toad had nothing to hide under , of course he must have hopped away , reasoned Peter .

1 He wandered about all day full of despair and misery , and when he lay down at night he could get no rest , but lay awake all night sunk in sorrowful thoughts .
2 One morning he rose up before dawn and went outside , for he thought his heart would be lighter in the open air .
3 As he wandered up and down on the banks of the mill-pond he heard a rustling in the water , and when he looked near he saw a white woman rising up from the waves .
4 He realised at once that this could be none other than the nixy of the mill-pond , and in his terror he did n't know if he should fly away or remain where he was .
5 While he hesitated the nixy spoke , called him by his name , and asked him why he was so sad .
6 When the miller heard how friendly her tone was , he plucked up heart and told her how rich and prosperous he had been all his life up till now , when he did n't know what he was to do for want and misery .
7 Then the nixy spoke comforting words to him , and promised that she would make him richer and more prosperous than he had ever been in his life before , if he would give her in return the youngest thing in his house .
8 The miller thought she must mean one of his puppies or kittens , so promised the nixy at once what she asked , and returned to his mill full of hope .
9 On the threshold he was greeted by a servant with the news that his wife had just given birth to a boy .
10 The poor miller was much horrified by these tidings , and went in to his wife with a heavy heart to tell her and his relations of the fatal bargain he had just struck with the nixy . '
11 I would gladly give up all the good fortune she promised me , ' he said , ` if I could only save my child . '
12 But no one could think of any advice to give him , beyond taking care that the child never went near the mill-pond .
13 So the boy throve and grew big , and in the meantime all prospered with the miller , and in a few years he was richer than he had ever been before .
14 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
15 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
16 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
17 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
18 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
19 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
20 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
21 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the XXXXX .	waves		advice|childhood|kittens|name|peace|rest|terror|thing|threshold|waves

1 The Queen consented with many tears , and the King at once bade his son set forth in search of the Tree of the Sun , from which he was to pluck a golden apple .
2 The Prince was delighted at the prospect , and set out on his travels that very day .
3 For a long time he wandered all through the world , and it was not till the ninety-ninth day after he started that he found an old man who was able to tell him where the Tree of the Sun grew .
4 He followed his directions , and rode on his way , and after another ninety-nine days he arrived at a golden castle , which stood in the middle of a vast wilderness .
5 He knocked at the door , which was opened noiselessly and by invisible hands .
6 Finding no one about , the Prince rode on , and came to a great meadow , where the Sun-Tree grew .
7 When he reached the tree he put out his hand to pick a golden apple ; but all of a sudden the tree grew higher , so that he could not reach its fruit .
8 Then he heard some one behind him laughing .
9 Turning round , he saw the girl in red walking towards him , who addressed him in these words : ` Do you really imagine , brave son of the earth , that you can pluck an apple so easily from the Tree of the Sun ?
10 Before you can do that , you have a difficult task before you .
11 You must guard the tree for nine days and nine nights from the ravages of two wild black wolves , who will try to harm it .
12 Do you think you can undertake this ? '
13 ` Yes , ' answered the Sun-Hero , ' I will guard the Tree of the Sun nine days and nine nights . '
14 Then the girl continued : ` Remember , though , if you do not succeed the Sun will kill you .
15 Now begin your watch . '
16 With these words the Red Girl went back into the golden castle .
17 She had hardly left him when the two black wolves appeared : but the Sun-Hero beat them off with his sword , and they retired , only , however , to reappear in a very short time .
18 The Sun-Hero chased them away once more , but he had hardly sat down to rest when the two black wolves were on the scene again .
19 This went on for seven days and nights , when the white horse , who had never done such a thing before , turned to the Sun-Hero and said in a human voice : ` Listen to what I am going to say .
20 A Fairy gave me to your mother in order that I might be of service to you ; so let me tell you , that if you go to sleep and let the wolves harm the tree , the Sun will surely kill you .
21 The Fairy , foreseeing this , put everyone in the world under a spell , which prevents their obeying the XXXXX 's command to take your life .	Sun		Sun|castle|door|girl|horse|ravages|round|sword|travels|wolves

7 Long time ago there lived a King who had three sons ; the eldest was called Szabo , the second Warza , and the youngest Iwanich .
8 One beautiful spring morning the King was walking through his gardens with these three sons , gazing with admiration at the various fruit-trees , some of which were a mass of blossom , whilst others were bowed to the ground laden with rich fruit .
9 During their wanderings they came unperceived on a piece of waste land where three splendid trees grew .
10 The King looked on them for a moment , and then , shaking his head sadly , he passed on in silence .
11 The sons , who could not understand why he did this , asked him the reason of his dejection , and the King told them as follows : ` These three trees , which I can not see without sorrow , were planted by me on this spot when I was a youth of twenty .
12 A celebrated magician , who had given the seed to my father , promised him that they would grow into the three finest trees the world had ever seen .
13 My father did not live to see his words come true ; but on his death-bed he bade me transplant them here , and to look after them with the greatest care , which I accordingly did .
14 At last , after the lapse of five long years , I noticed some blossoms on the branches , and a few days later the most exquisite fruit my eyes had ever seen . '
15 I gave my head-gardener the strictest orders to watch the trees carefully , for the magician had warned my father that if one unripe fruit were plucked from the tree , all the rest would become rotten at once .
16 When it was quite ripe the fruit would become a golden yellow .
17 ` Every day I gazed on the lovely fruit , which became gradually more and more tempting-looking , and it was all I could do not to break the magician 's commands .
18 ` One night I dreamt that the fruit was perfectly ripe ; I ate some of it , and it was more delicious than anything I had ever tasted in real life .
19 As soon as I awoke I sent for the gardener and asked him if the fruit on the three trees had not ripened in the night to perfection .
20 ` But instead of replying , the gardener threw himself at my feet and swore that he was innocent .

9 Road-Song of the Bandar-Log Here we go in a flung festoon , Half-way up to the jealous moon !
10 Do n't you envy our pranceful bands ?
11 Do n't you wish you had extra hands ?
12 Would n't you like if your tails were -- so -- Curved in the shape of a Cupid 's bow ?
13 Now you 're angry , but -- never mind , Brother , thy tail hangs down behind !
14 Here we sit in a branchy row , Thinking of beautiful things we know ; Dreaming of deeds that we mean to do , All complete , in a minute or two -- Something noble and wise and good , Done by merely wishing we could .

16 All the talk we ever have heard Uttered by bat or beast or bird -- Hide or fin or scale or feather -- Jabber it quickly and all together !

18 Wonderful !
19 Once again !

1 Before Hermod sat down , however , he went to where the rat and the mouse were fighting , and cut them in two with his sword .

6 THE STEADFAST TIN-SOLDIER There were once upon a time five-and twenty tin-soldiers -- all brothers , as they were made out of the same old tin spoon .
7 Their uniform was red and blue , and they shouldered their guns and looked straight in front of them .
8 The first words that they heard in this world , when the lid of the box in which they lay was taken off , were : ` Hurrah , tin-soldiers ! '
9 This was exclaimed by a little boy , clapping his hands ; they had been given to him because it was his birthday , and now he began setting them out on the table .
10 Each soldier was exactly like the other in shape , except just one , who had been made last when the tin had run short ; but there he stood as firmly on his one leg as the others did on two , and he is the one that became famous .
11 There were many other playthings on the table on which they were being set out , but the nicest of all was a pretty little castle made of cardboard , with windows through which you could see into the rooms .
12 In front of the castle stood some little trees surrounding a tiny mirror which looked like a lake .
13 Wax swans were floating about and reflecting themselves in it .
14 That was all very pretty ; but the most beautiful thing was a little lady , who stood in the open doorway .
15 She was cut out of paper , but she had on a dress of the finest muslin , with a scarf of narrow blue ribbon round her shoulders , fastened in the middle with a glittering rose made of gold paper , which was as large as her head .
16 The little lady was stretching out both her arms , for she was a Dancer , and was lifting up one leg so high in the air that the Tin-soldier could n't find it anywhere , and thought that she , too , had only one leg .
17 ` That 's the wife for me ! '
18 he thought ; ` but she is so grand , and lives in a castle , whilst I have only a box with four-and-twenty others .
19 This is no place for her !

4 ` One side of WHAT ?
5 The other side of WHAT ? '
6 thought Alice to herself .
7 ` Of the mushroom , ' said the Caterpillar , just as if she had asked it aloud ; and in another moment it was out of sight .
8 Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute , trying to make out which were the two sides of it ; and as it was perfectly round , she found this a very difficult question .
9 However , at last she stretched her arms round it as far as they would go , and broke off a bit of the edge with each hand .
10 ` And now which is which ? '
11 she said to herself , and nibbled a little of the right-hand bit to try the effect : the next moment she felt a violent blow underneath her chin : it had struck her foot !
12 She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change , but she felt that there was no time to be lost , as she was shrinking rapidly ; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit .
13 Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot , that there was hardly room to open her mouth ; but she did it at last , and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit .

4 Kletke .
5 Long time ago there lived a King who had three sons ; the eldest was called Szabo , the second Warza , and the youngest Iwanich .
6 One beautiful spring morning the King was walking through his gardens with these three sons , gazing with admiration at the various fruit-trees , some of which were a mass of blossom , whilst others were bowed to the ground laden with rich fruit .
7 During their wanderings they came unperceived on a piece of waste land where three splendid trees grew .
8 The King looked on them for a moment , and then , shaking his head sadly , he passed on in silence .
9 The sons , who could not understand why he did this , asked him the reason of his dejection , and the King told them as follows : ` These three trees , which I can not see without sorrow , were planted by me on this spot when I was a youth of twenty .
10 A celebrated magician , who had given the seed to my father , promised him that they would grow into the three finest trees the world had ever seen .
11 My father did not live to see his words come true ; but on his death-bed he bade me transplant them here , and to look after them with the greatest care , which I accordingly did .
12 At last , after the lapse of five long years , I noticed some blossoms on the branches , and a few days later the most exquisite fruit my eyes had ever seen . '
13 I gave my head-gardener the strictest orders to watch the trees carefully , for the magician had warned my father that if one unripe fruit were plucked from the tree , all the rest would become rotten at once .
14 When it was quite ripe the fruit would become a golden yellow .
15 ` Every day I gazed on the lovely fruit , which became gradually more and more tempting-looking , and it was all I could do not to break the magician 's commands .
16 ` One night I dreamt that the fruit was perfectly ripe ; I ate some of it , and it was more delicious than anything I had ever tasted in real life .
17 As soon as I awoke I sent for the gardener and asked him if the fruit on the three trees had not ripened in the night to perfection .
18 ` But instead of replying , the gardener threw himself at my feet and swore that he was innocent .
19 He said that he had watched by the trees all night , but in spite of it , and as if by magic , the beautiful trees had been robbed of all their fruit .
20 ` Grieved as I was over the theft , I did not punish the gardener , of whose fidelity I was well assured , but I determined to pluck off all the fruit in the following year before it was ripe , as I had not much belief in the magician 's warning . '
21 I carried out my intention , and had all the XXXXX picked off the tree , but when I tasted one of the apples it was bitter and unpleasant , and the next morning the rest of the fruit had all rotted away .	fruit		WITCH|admiration|command|fruit|magician|rest|seed|spring|world|youth

6 THE DEATH OF THE SUN-HERO -LRB- 27 -RRB- -LRB- 27 -RRB- From the Bukowinaer Tales and Legends .
7 Von Wliolocki .
8 Many , many thousand years ago there lived a mighty King whom heaven had blessed with a clever and beautiful son .
9 When he was only ten years old the boy was cleverer than all the King 's counsellors put together , and when he was twenty he was the greatest hero in the whole kingdom .
10 His father could not make enough of his son , and always had him clothed in golden garments which shone and sparkled like the sun ; and his mother gave him a white horse , which never slept , and which flew like the wind .
11 All the people in the land loved him dearly , and called him the Sun-Hero , for they did not think his like existed under the sun .
12 Now it happened one night that both his parents had the same extraordinary dream .
13 They dreamt that a girl all dressed in red had come to them and said : ` If you wish that your son should really become the Sun-Hero in deed and not only in name , let him go out into the world and search for the Tree of the Sun , and when he has found it , let him pluck a golden apple from it and bring it home . '
14 When the King and Queen had each related their dreams to the other , they were much amazed that they should both have dreamt exactly the same about their son , and the King said to his wife , ` This is clearly a sign from heaven that we should send our son out into the world in order that he may come home the great Sun-Hero , as the Red Girl said , not only in name but in deed . '
15 The Queen consented with many tears , and the King at once bade his son set forth in search of the Tree of the Sun , from which he was to pluck a golden apple .
16 The Prince was delighted at the prospect , and set out on his travels that very day .
17 For a long time he wandered all through the world , and it was not till the ninety-ninth day after he started that he found an old man who was able to tell him where the Tree of the Sun grew .
18 He followed his directions , and rode on his way , and after another ninety-nine days he arrived at a golden castle , which stood in the middle of a vast wilderness .
19 He knocked at the door , which was opened noiselessly and by invisible hands .
20 Finding no one about , the Prince rode on , and came to a great meadow , where the Sun-Tree grew .
21 When he reached the tree he put out his hand to pick a golden XXXXX ; but all of a sudden the tree grew higher , so that he could not reach its fruit .	apple		Sun|Tree|apple|castle|door|dreams|garments|gold|man|years

1 Three-and-thirty times it sang the same piece without being tired .
2 People would like to have heard it again , but the Emperor thought that the living Nightingale should sing now -- but where was she ?
3 No one had noticed that she had flown out of the open window away to her green woods .
4 ` What SHALL we do ! '
5 said the Emperor .
6 And all the Court scolded , and said that the Nightingale was very ungrateful .
7 ` But we have still the best bird ! '
8 they said and the artificial bird had to sing again , and that was the thirty-fourth time they had heard the same piece .
9 But they did not yet know it by heart ; it was much too difficult .
10 And the bandmaster praised the bird tremendously ; yes , he assured them it was better than a real nightingale , not only because of its beautiful plumage and diamonds , but inside as well .
11 ` For see , my Lords and Ladies and your Imperial Majesty , with the real Nightingale one can never tell what will come out , but all is known about the artificial bird !
12 You can explain it , you can open it and show people where the waltzes lie , how they go , and how one follows the other ! '
13 ` That 's just what we think ! '
14 said everyone ; and the bandmaster received permission to show the bird to the people the next Sunday .
15 They should hear it sing , commanded the Emperor .
16 And they heard it , and they were as pleased as if they had been intoxicated with tea , after the Chinese fashion , and they all said ` Oh ! '

19 The real Nightingale was banished from the kingdom .

8 The whole winter he remained down there , and Thumbelina looked after him and nursed him tenderly .

1 Iwanich was much horrified at the sight before him , and asked the man what terrible crime he had committed to be punished in this dreadful fashion . '
2 I will tell you everything , ' said the man in the cauldron ; ` but first relieve my torments a little , I implore you . '
3 ` And how can I do that ? '
4 asked the Prince .
5 ` With a little water , ' replied the man ; ` only sprinkle a few drops over me and I shall feel better . '
6 The Prince , moved by pity , without thinking what he was doing , ran to the courtyard of the castle , and filled a jug with water , which he poured over the man in the cauldron .
7 In a moment a most fearful crash was heard , as if all the pillars of the palace were giving way , and the palace itself , with towers and doors , windows and the cauldron , whirled round the bewildered Prince 's head .
8 This continued for a few minutes , and then everything vanished into thin air , and Iwanich found himself suddenly alone upon a desolate heath covered with rocks and stones .
9 The Prince , who now realised what his heedlessness had done , cursed too late his spirit of curiosity .
10 In his despair he wandered on over the heath , never looking where he put his feet , and full of sorrowful thoughts .
11 At last he saw a light in the distance , which came from a miserable-looking little hut .
12 The owner of it was none other than the kind-hearted gaunt grey beggar who had given the Prince the bag of bread-crumbs and the hare .
13 Without recognising Iwanich , he opened the door when he knocked and gave him shelter for the night .
14 On the following morning the Prince asked his host if he could get him any work to do , as he was quite unknown in the neighbourhood , and had not enough money to take him home .
15 ` My son , ' replied the old man , ` all this country round here is uninhabited ; I myself have to wander to distant villages for my living , and even then I do not very often find enough to satisfy my hunger .
16 But if you would like to take service with the old witch Corva , go straight up the little stream which flows below my hut for about three hours , and you will come to a sand-hill on the left-hand side ; that is where she lives . '
17 Iwanich thanked the gaunt grey beggar for his information , and went on his way .
18 After walking for about three hours the Prince came upon a dreary-looking grey stone wall ; this was the back of the building and did not attract him ; but when he came upon the front of the house he found it even less inviting , for the old witch had surrounded her dwelling with a fence of spikes , on every one of which a man 's skull was stuck .

1 On this elegant couch lay Prince Rainbow , looking more beautiful than ever , and sunk in profound slumber , in which he had been held ever since his disappearance .
2 Fairy-than-a-Fairy , who now saw him for the first time in his real shape , hardly dared to gaze at him , fearing lest his appearance might not be in keeping with the voice and language which had won her heart .
3 At the same time she could not help feeling rather hurt at the apparent indifference with which she was received .
4 She related all the dangers and difficulties she had gone through , and though she repeated the story twenty times in a loud clear voice , the Prince slept on and took no heed .
5 She then had recourse to the golden pomegranate , and on opening it found that all the seeds were as many little violins which flew up in the vaulted roof and at once began playing melodiously .
6 The Prince was not completely roused , but he opened his eyes a little and looked all the handsomer .
7 Impatient at not being recognised , Fairer-than-a-Fairy now drew out her third present , and on opening the crystal scent-bottle a little syren flew out , who silenced the violins and then sang close to the Prince 's ear the story of all his lady love had suffered in her search for him .
8 She added some gentle reproaches to her tale , but before she had got far he was wide awake , and transported with joy threw himself at the Princess 's feet .
9 At the same moment the walls of the room expanded and opened out , revealing a golden throne covered with jewels .
10 A magnificent Court now began to assemble , and at the same time several elegant carriages filled with ladies in magnificent dresses drove up .
11 In the first and most splendid of these carriages sat Prince Rainbow 's mother .
12 She fondly embraced her son , after which she informed him that his father had been dead for some years , that the anger of the Fairies was at length appeased , and that he might return in peace to reign over his people , who were longing for his presence .
13 The Court received the new King with joyful acclamations which would have delighted him at any other time , but all his thoughts were full of Fairer-than-a-Fairy .
14 He was just about to present her to his mother and the Court , feeling sure that her charms would win all hearts , when the three green and white sisters appeared .
15 They declared the secret of Fairy-than-a-Fairy 's royal birth , and the Queen taking the two lovers in her carriage set off with them for the capital of the kingdom .
16 Here they were received with tumultuous joy .
17 The wedding was celebrated without delay , and succeeding years diminished neither the virtues , beauty , nor the mutual affection of King Rainbow and his Queen , Fairer-than-a-Fairy .

2 ` How fond she is of finding morals in things ! '
3 Alice thought to herself . '
4 I dare say you 're wondering why I do n't put my arm round your waist , ' the Duchess said after a pause : ` the reason is , that I 'm doubtful about the temper of your flamingo .
5 Shall I try the experiment ? '
6 ` HE might bite , ' Alice cautiously replied , not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried .
7 ` Very true , ' said the Duchess : ` flamingoes and mustard both bite .
8 And the moral of that is -- `` Birds of a feather flock together . '' '
9 ` Only mustard is n't a bird , ' Alice remarked .
10 ` Right , as usual , ' said the Duchess : ` what a clear way you have of putting things ! '
11 ` It 's a mineral , I THINK , ' said Alice .
12 ` Of course it is , ' said the Duchess , who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said ; ` there 's a large mustard-mine near here .
13 And the moral of that is -- `` The more there is of mine , the less there is of yours . '' '
14 ` Oh , I know ! '
15 exclaimed Alice , who had not attended to this last remark , ` it 's a vegetable .
16 It does n't look like one , but it is . ' '
17 I quite agree with you , ' said the Duchess ; ` and the moral of that is -- `` Be what you would seem to be '' -- or if you 'd like it put more simply -- `` Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise . 7 If he does this he may go free ; if not he shall be hung as you have said . '
8 At these words the Princess burst into tears , and when the King saw this he ordered her to be shut up in a high tower and carefully guarded till the dangerous magician should either have left the kingdom or been hung on the nearest tree .

1 The King in his anguish of mind consented , and the old woman led him to her little house where her daughter was sitting by the fire .
2 She received the King as if she were expecting him , and he saw that she was certainly very beautiful ; but she did not please him , and he could not look at her without a secret feeling of horror .
3 As soon as he had lifted the maiden on to his horse the old woman showed him the way , and the King reached his palace , where the wedding was celebrated .
4 The King had already been married once , and had by his first wife seven children , six boys and one girl , whom he loved more than anything in the world .
5 And now , because he was afraid that their stepmother might not treat them well and might do them harm , he put them in a lonely castle that stood in the middle of a wood .
6 It lay so hidden , and the way to it was so hard to find , that he himself could not have found it out had not a wise-woman given him a reel of thread which possessed a marvellous property : when he threw it before him it unwound itself and showed him the way .
7 But the King went so often to his dear children that the Queen was offended at his absence .
8 She grew curious , and wanted to know what he had to do quite alone in the wood .
9 She gave his servants a great deal of money , and they betrayed the secret to her , and also told her of the reel which alone could point out the way .
10 She had no rest now till she had found out where the King guarded the reel , and then she made some little white shirts , and , as she had learnt from her witch-mother , sewed an enchantment in each of them .
11 And when the King had ridden off she took the little shirts and went into the wood , and the reel showed her the way .
12 The children , who saw someone coming in the distance , thought it was their dear father coming to them , and sprang to meet him very joyfully .
13 Then she threw over each one a little shirt , which when it had touched their bodies changed them into swans , and they flew away over the forest .
14 The Queen went home quite satisfied , and thought she had got rid of her step-children ; but the girl had not run to meet her with her brothers , and she knew nothing of her .

1 Kletke .
2 Long time ago there lived a King who had three sons ; the eldest was called Szabo , the second Warza , and the youngest Iwanich .
3 One beautiful spring morning the King was walking through his gardens with these three sons , gazing with admiration at the various fruit-trees , some of which were a mass of blossom , whilst others were bowed to the ground laden with rich fruit .
4 During their wanderings they came unperceived on a piece of waste land where three splendid trees grew .
5 The King looked on them for a moment , and then , shaking his head sadly , he passed on in silence .
6 The sons , who could not understand why he did this , asked him the reason of his dejection , and the King told them as follows : ` These three trees , which I can not see without sorrow , were planted by me on this spot when I was a youth of twenty .
7 A celebrated magician , who had given the seed to my father , promised him that they would grow into the three finest trees the world had ever seen .
8 My father did not live to see his words come true ; but on his death-bed he bade me transplant them here , and to look after them with the greatest care , which I accordingly did .
9 At last , after the lapse of five long years , I noticed some blossoms on the branches , and a few days later the most exquisite fruit my eyes had ever seen . '
10 I gave my head-gardener the strictest orders to watch the trees carefully , for the magician had warned my father that if one unripe fruit were plucked from the tree , all the rest would become rotten at once .
11 When it was quite ripe the fruit would become a golden yellow .
12 ` Every day I gazed on the lovely fruit , which became gradually more and more tempting-looking , and it was all I could do not to break the magician 's commands .
13 ` One night I dreamt that the fruit was perfectly ripe ; I ate some of it , and it was more delicious than anything I had ever tasted in real life .
14 As soon as I awoke I sent for the gardener and asked him if the fruit on the three trees had not ripened in the night to perfection .
15 ` But instead of replying , the gardener threw himself at my feet and swore that he was innocent .
16 He said that he had watched by the trees all night , but in spite of it , and as if by magic , the beautiful trees had been robbed of all their fruit .
17 ` Grieved as I was over the theft , I did not punish the gardener , of whose fidelity I was well assured , but I determined to pluck off all the fruit in the following year before it was ripe , as I had not much belief in the magician 's warning . '
18 I carried out my intention , and had all the fruit picked off the tree , but when I tasted one of the apples it was bitter and unpleasant , and the next morning the rest of the fruit had all rotted away .
19 ` After this I had the beautiful fruit of these trees carefully guarded by my most faithful servants ; but every year , on this very night , the fruit was plucked and stolen by an invisible hand , and next morning not a single apple remained on the trees .
20 For some time past I have given up even having the trees watched . '
21 When the King had finished his story , Szabo , his eldest son , said to him : ` Forgive me , XXXXX , if I say I think you are mistaken .	father		days|father|hand|life|magician|morning|orders|servants|spot|wanderings

1 `` Do n't you ever trip ? ''
2 said the troop-horse .
3 `` They say that when a mule trips you can split a hen 's ear , '' said Billy .
4 `` Now and again perhaps a badly packed saddle will upset a mule , but it 's very seldom .
5 I wish I could show you our business .
6 It 's beautiful .
7 Why , it took me three years to find out what the men were driving at .
8 The science of the thing is never to show up against the sky line , because , if you do , you may get fired at .
9 Remember that , young un .
10 Always keep hidden as much as possible , even if you have to go a mile out of your way .
11 I lead the battery when it comes to that sort of climbing . ''
12 `` Fired at without the chance of running into the people who are firing ! ''
13 said the troop-horse , thinking hard .
14 `` I could n't stand that .
15 I should want to charge -- with Dick . ''
16 `` Oh , no , you would n't .
17 You know that as soon as the guns are in position they 'll do all the charging .
18 That 's scientific and neat .
19 But knives -- pah ! ''

1 All things made he -- Shiva the Preserver .
2 Mahadeo !
3 Mahadeo !
4 He made all -- Thorn for the camel , fodder for the kine , And mother 's heart for sleepy head , O little son of mine !
5 Little Toomai came in with a joyous tunk-a-tunk at the end of each verse , till he felt sleepy and stretched himself on the fodder at Kala Nag 's side .
6 At last the elephants began to lie down one after another as is their custom , till only Kala Nag at the right of the line was left standing up ; and he rocked slowly from side to side , his ears put forward to listen to the night wind as it blew very slowly across the hills .
7 The air was full of all the night noises that , taken together , make one big silence -- the click of one bamboo stem against the other , the rustle of something alive in the undergrowth , the scratch and squawk of a half-waked bird -LRB- birds are awake in the night much more often than we imagine -RRB- , and the fall of water ever so far away .
8 Little Toomai slept for some time , and when he waked it was brilliant moonlight , and Kala Nag was still standing up with his ears cocked .
9 Little Toomai turned , rustling in the fodder , and watched the curve of his big back against half the stars in heaven , and while he watched he heard , so far away that it sounded no more than a pinhole of noise pricked through the stillness , the `` hoot-toot '' of a wild elephant .
10 All the elephants in the lines jumped up as if they had been shot , and their grunts at last waked the sleeping mahouts , and they came out and drove in the picket pegs with big mallets , and tightened this rope and knotted that till all was quiet .
11 One new elephant had nearly grubbed up his picket , and Big Toomai took off Kala Nag 's leg chain and shackled that elephant fore-foot to hind-foot , but slipped a loop of grass string round Kala Nag 's leg , and told him to remember that he was tied fast .
12 He knew that he and his father and his grandfather had done the very same thing hundreds of times before .
13 Kala Nag did not answer to the order by gurgling , as he usually did .
14 He stood still , looking out across the moonlight , his head a little raised and his ears spread like fans , up to the great folds of the Garo hills .
15 `` Tend to him if he grows restless in the night , '' said Big Toomai to Little Toomai , and he went into the hut and slept .
16 Little Toomai was just going to sleep , too , when he heard the coir string snap with a little `` tang , '' and Kala Nag rolled out of his pickets as slowly and as silently as a cloud rolls out of the mouth of a valley .
17 Little Toomai pattered after him , barefooted , down the road in the moonlight , calling under his breath , `` Kala Nag !
18 Kala Nag !
19 Take me with you , O Kala Nag ! ''
20 The elephant turned , without a sound , took three strides back to the boy in the moonlight , put down his trunk , swung him up to his neck , and almost before Little Toomai had settled his knees , slipped into the forest .
21 There was one blast of furious trumpeting from the XXXXX , and then the silence shut down on everything , and Kala Nag began to move .	lines		air|camel|father|grandfather|head|lines|order|road|strides|things

2 When he got to the first tree he stopped in front of it , did everything just as he had been told , and , kneeling on the ground with his face to the earth , fell asleep .
3 After a little time he was aroused ; he awoke and , rubbing his eyes , saw a ready-made ship at his side , and at once got into it .
4 And the ship rose and rose , and in another minute was flying through the air , when the Simpleton , who was on the look out , cast his eyes down to the earth and saw a man beneath him on the road , who was kneeling with his ear upon the damp ground .
5 ` Hallo ! '
6 he called out , ` what are you doing down there ? ' '
7 I am listening to what is going on in the world , ' replied the man .
8 ` Come with me in my ship , ' said the Simpleton .
9 So the man was only too glad , and got in beside him ; and the ship flew , and flew , and flew through the air , till again from his outlook the Simpleton saw a man on the road below , who was hopping on one leg , while his other leg was tied up behind his ear .
10 So he hailed him , calling out : ` Hallo !
11 what are you doing , hopping on one leg ? ' '
12 I ca n't help it , ' replied the man . '
13 I walk so fast that unless I tied up one leg I should be at the end of the earth in a bound . '

20 That is the kind of shot I enjoy . '

1 Who Stole the Tarts ?
2 The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived , with a great crowd assembled about them -- all sorts of little birds and beasts , as well as the whole pack of cards : the Knave was standing before them , in chains , with a soldier on each side to guard him ; and near the King was the White Rabbit , with a trumpet in one hand , and a scroll of parchment in the other .
3 In the very middle of the court was a table , with a large dish of tarts upon it : they looked so good , that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them -- ' I wish they 'd get the trial done , ' she thought , ` and hand round the refreshments ! '
4 But there seemed to be no chance of this , so she began looking at everything about her , to pass away the time .
5 Alice had never been in a court of justice before , but she had read about them in books , and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there .
6 ` That 's the judge , ' she said to herself , ` because of his great wig . '
7 The judge , by the way , was the King ; and as he wore his crown over the wig , -LRB- look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it , -RRB- he did not look at all comfortable , and it was certainly not becoming .
8 ` And that 's the jury-box , ' thought Alice , ` and those twelve creatures , ' -LRB- she was obliged to say ` creatures , ' you see , because some of them were animals , and some were birds , -RRB- ' I suppose they are the jurors . '
9 She said this last word two or three times over to herself , being rather proud of it : for she thought , and rightly too , that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all .
10 However , ` jury-men ' would have done just as well .

1 Upon which she said : ` Dear master , Schurka and I are going off to a distant kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth to fetch you back your magic ring .

3 And Waska took leave of her beloved master , and set off with Schurka on their journey .
4 On and on they travelled , looking always to right and left for traces of the Princess , following up every track , making inquiries of every cat and dog they met , listening to the talk of every wayfarer they passed ; and at last they heard that the kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth where the twelve youths had borne the Princess was not very far off .
5 And at last one day they reached that distant kingdom , and , going at once to the palace , they began to make friends with all the dogs and cats in the place , and to question them about the Princess and the magic ring ; but no one could tell them much about either .
6 Now one day it chanced that Waska had gone down to the palace cellar to hunt for mice and rats , and seeing an especially fat , well-fed mouse , she pounced upon it , buried her claws in its soft fur , and was just going to gobble it up , when she was stopped by the pleading tones of the little creature , saying , ` If you will only spare my life I may be of great service to you .
7 I will do everything in my power for you ; for I am the King of the Mice , and if I perish the whole race will die out . '
8 ` So be it , ' said Waska . '
9 I will spare your life ; but in return you must do something for me .

11 She has stolen away his magic ring .
12 You must get it away from her at whatever cost ; do you hear ?
13 Till you have done this I wo n't take my claws out of your fur . '
14 ` Good ! '
15 replied the mouse ; ' I will do what you ask . '
16 And , so saying , he summoned all the mice in his kingdom together .

1 Long years ago the tree had given up blooming , nor could all the pruning and care given it coax a single blossom from it .
2 Miss Corona , tinctured with the superstition apt to wait on a lonely womanhood , believed in her heart that the rosebush had a secret sympathy with the fortunes of the Gordon women .
3 She , the last of them on the old homestead , would never need the bride roses .
4 Wherefore , then , should the old tree bloom ?
5 And now , after all these years , it had flung all its long-hoarded sweetness into blossom again .
6 Miss Corona thrilled at the thought .
7 The rosebush had bloomed again for a Gordon bride , but Miss Corona was sure there was another meaning in it too ; she believed it foretokened some change in her own life , some rejuvenescence of love and beauty like to that of the ancient rose-tree .
8 She bent over its foam of loveliness almost reverently .
9 `` They have bloomed for Juliet 's wedding , '' she murmured .
10 `` A Gordon bride must wear the bride roses , indeed she must .
11 And this -- why , it is almost a miracle . ''
12 She ran , light-footedly as a girl , to the house for scissors and a basket .
13 She would send Juliet Gordon the bride roses .
14 Her cheeks were pink from excitement as she snipped them off .
15 How lovely they were !
16 How very large and fragrant !
17 It was as if all the grace and perfume and beauty and glory of those twenty lost summers were found here at once in them .
18 When Miss Corona had them ready , she went to the door and called , `` Charlotte !
19 Charlotte ! ''
20 Now Charlotta , having atoned to her conscience for the destruction of the green and yellow bowl by faithfully weeding the garden , a task which she hated above all else , was singing a hymn among the sweet peas , and her red braids were over her shoulders .
21 This ought to have warned Miss Corona , but Miss Corona was thinking of other things , and kept on calling patiently , while Charlotta weeded away for dear XXXXX , and seemed smitten with treble deafness .	life		beauty|blossom|bowl|glory|heart|homestead|life|meaning|superstition|womanhood

1 But the youngest brother determined to explore the abyss , and letting himself down by the rope he soon reached the bottom .
2 Here he found a lovely meadow full of green trees and exquisite flowers .
3 In the middle of the meadow stood a huge stone castle , with an iron gate leading to it , which was wide open .
4 Everything in the castle seemed to be made of copper , and the only inhabitant he could discover was a lovely girl , who was combing her golden hair ; and he noticed that whenever one of her hairs fell on the ground it rang out like pure metal .
5 The youth looked at her more closely , and saw that her skin was smooth and fair , her blue eyes bright and sparkling , and her hair as golden as the sun .
6 He fell in love with her on the spot , and kneeling at her feet , he implored her to become his wife .
7 The lovely girl accepted his proposal gladly ; but at the same time she warned him that she could never come up to the world above till her mother , the old witch , was dead .
8 And she went on to tell him that the only way in which the old creature could be killed was with the sword that hung up in the castle ; but the sword was so heavy that no one could lift it .
9 Then the youth went into a room in the castle where everything was made of silver , and here he found another beautiful girl , the sister of his bride .
10 She was combing her silver hair , and every hair that fell on the ground rang out like pure metal .
11 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
12 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
13 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
14 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
15 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
16 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
17 As soon as her feet touched the ground she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .
18 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
19 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
20 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
21 And now XXXXX was up above and only he himself remained below .	everything		arrival|creature|everything|hairs|one|proposal|sun|sword|time|treasures

1 It seems Father had had relations after all -- a brother and a sister in particular .
2 But when he was a young man he quarrelled with his brother , who did n't treat him very well -- but he 's been dead for years , so I wo n't say a word against him -- and had gone away from home .
3 He never went back , and he never even let them know he was living .
4 Father says that this was very wrong of him , and I suppose it was , since he says so ; but I do n't see how Father could do anything wrong .
5 Anyway , he had a sister Esther whom he loved very much ; but he felt bitter against her too , because he thought she took his brother 's part too much .
6 So , though a letter of hers , asking him to go back , did reach him , he never answered it , and he never heard anything more .
7 Years afterward he felt sorry and went back , but his brother was dead and his sister had gone away , and he could n't find out a single thing about her .
8 So much for that ; and now about the kite .
9 The letter Father had just received was from his sister , our Aunt Esther and the mother of Dick and Mimi .
10 She was living at a place hundreds of miles inland .
11 Her husband was dead and , as we found out later , although she did not say a word about it in the letter , she was very poor .
12 One day when Dick and Mimi were out in the woods looking for botany specimens they saw something funny in the top of a tree .
13 Dick climbed up and got it .
14 It was a big red kite with a patch on each side and names written on it .
15 They carried it home to their mother .
16 Dick has since told us that she turned as pale as the dead when she saw our names on it .
17 You see , Philippa was her mother 's name and Claude was her father 's .
18 And when she read the letter that was pasted over the hole in the kite she knew who we must be , for it was the very letter she had written to her brother so long ago .
19 So she sat right down and wrote again , and this was the letter Jake Wiggins brought to the Big Half Moon .
20 It was a beautiful letter .
21 I loved XXXXX Esther before I ever saw her , just from that letter .	Aunt		Aunt|father|home|husband|kite|man|name|part|relations|word

1 He bit the bread a second and third time , and each time a piece of gold fell out of his mouth ; but the bread remained untouched .
2 The Herd-boy was very much delighted over his stroke of good fortune , and , hiding the magic loaf in his bag , he hurried off to the nearest village to buy himself something to eat , and then returned to his sheep .
3 Now the Lord whose sheep the Herd-boy looked after had a very lovely daughter , who always smiled and nodded to the youth when she walked with her father in his fields .
4 For a long time the Herd-boy had made up his mind to prepare a surprise for this beautiful creature on her birthday .
5 So when the day approached he put on his invisible belt , took a sack of gold pieces with him , and slipping into her room in the middle of the night , he placed the bag of gold beside her bed and returned to his sheep .
6 The girl 's joy was great , and so was her parents ' next day when they found the sack full of gold pieces .
7 The Herd-boy was so pleased to think what pleasure he had given that the next night he placed another bag of gold beside the girl 's bed .
8 And this he continued to do for seven nights , and the girl and her parents made up their minds that it must be a good Fairy who brought the gold every night .
9 But one night they determined to watch , and see from their hiding place who the bringer of the sack of gold really was .
10 On the eighth night a fearful storm of wind and rain came on while the Herd-boy was on his way to bring the beautiful girl another bag of gold .
11 Then for the first time he noticed , just as he reached his master 's house , that he had forgotten the belt which made him invisible .
12 He did n't like the idea of going back to his hut in the wind and wet , so he just stepped as he was into the girl 's room , laid the sack of gold beside her , and was turning to leave the room , when his master confronted him and said , ` You young rogue , so you were going to steal the gold that a good Fairy brings every night , were you ? '
13 The Herd-boy was so taken aback by his words , that he stood trembling before him , and did not dare to explain his presence .
14 Then his master spoke .
15 ` As you have hitherto always behaved well in my service I will not send you to prison ; but leave your place instantly and never let me see your face again . '
16 So the Herd-boy went back to his hut , and taking his loaf and belt with him , he went to the nearest town .
17 There he bought himself some fine clothes , and a beautiful coach with four horses , hired two servants , and drove back to his master .
18 You may imagine how astonished he was to see his Herd-boy returning to him in this manner !
19 Then the youth told him of the piece of good luck that had befallen him , and asked him for the hand of his beautiful daughter .
20 This was readily granted , and the two lived in peace and happiness to the end of their lives .

1 He went at once to his son Iwanich , and after embracing him tenderly and heaping praises on him , he asked him how he had succeeded in protecting the costly fruit from the power of the magician .
2 This question placed Iwanich in a dilemma .
3 But as he did not want the real story to be known , he said that about midnight a huge wasp had flown through the branches , and buzzed incessantly round him .
4 He had warded it off with his sword , and at dawn , when he was becoming quite worn out , the wasp had vanished as suddenly as it had appeared .
5 The King , who never doubted the truth of this tale , bade his son go to rest at once and recover from the fatigues of the night ; but he himself went and ordered many feasts to be held in honour of the preservation of the wonderful fruit .
6 The whole capital was in a stir , and everyone shared in the King 's joy ; the Prince alone took no part in the festivities .
7 While the King was at a banquet , Iwanich took some purses of gold , and mounting the quickest horse in the royal stable , he sped off like the wind without a single soul being any the wiser .
8 It was only on the next day that they missed him ; the King was very distressed at his disappearance , and sent search-parties all over the kingdom to look for him , but in vain ; and after six months they gave him up as dead , and in another six months they had forgotten all about him .
9 But in the meantime the Prince , with the help of his ring , had had a most successful journey , and no evil had befallen him .
10 At the end of three months he came to the entrance of a huge forest , which looked as if it had never been trodden by human foot before , and which seemed to stretch out indefinitely .
11 The Prince was about to enter the wood by a little path he had discovered , when he heard a voice shouting to him : ` Hold , youth !
12 Whither are you going ? '
13 Iwanich turned round , and saw a tall , gaunt-looking man , clad in miserable rags , leaning on a crooked staff and seated at the foot of an oak tree , which was so much the same colour as himself that it was little wonder the Prince had ridden past the tree without noticing him .
14 ` Where else should I be going , ' he said , ` than through the wood ? '
15 ` Through the wood ? '
16 said the old man in amazement .
17 ` It 's easily seen that you have heard nothing of this forest , that you rush so blindly to meet your doom .
18 Well , listen to me before you ride any further ; let me tell you that this wood hides in its depths a countless number of the fiercest tigers , hyenas , wolves , bears , and snakes , and all sorts of other monsters .
19 If I were to cut you and your horse up into tiny morsels and throw them to the beasts , there would n't be one bit for each hundred of them .
20 Take my advice , therefore , and if you wish to save your life follow some other path . '
21 The Prince was rather taken aback by the old man 's words , and considered for a minute what he should do ; then looking at his XXXXX , and perceiving that it sparkled as brightly as ever , he called out : ` If this wood held even more terrible things than it does , I can not help myself , for I must go through it . '	ring		bit|day|foot|forest|help|man|ring|tigers|wolves|wood

1 ` You useless ne'er - do-weel ! '
2 exclaimed his mother in a great passion .
3 ` Leave the house at once , and go and beg your bread among strangers ; ' and as Martin did not dare to contradict her , he called Schurka and Waska and started off with them to the nearest village in search of work .
4 On the way he met a rich peasant , who asked him where he was going . '
5 I want to get work as a day labourer , ' he answered .
6 ` Come along with me , then .
7 But I must tell you I engage my labourers without wages .
8 If you serve me faithfully for a year , I promise you it shall be for your advantage . '
9 So Martin consented , and for a year he worked diligently , and served his master faithfully , not sparing himself in any way .
10 When the day of reckoning had come the peasant led him into a barn , and pointing to two full sacks , said : ` Take whichever of these you choose . '
11 Martin examined the contents of the sacks , and seeing that one was full of silver and the other of sand , he said to himself : ` There must be some trick about this ; I had better take the sand . '
12 And throwing the sack over his shoulders he started out into the world , in search of fresh work .
13 On and on he walked , and at last he reached a great gloomy wood .
14 In the middle of the wood he came upon a meadow , where a fire was burning , and in the midst of the fire , surrounded by flames , was a lovely damsel , more beautiful than anything that Martin had ever seen , and when she saw him she called to him : ` Martin , if you would win happiness , save my life .
15 Extinguish the flames with the sand that you earned in payment of your faithful service . '
16 ` Truly , ' thought Martin to himself , ` it would be more sensible to save a fellow-being 's life with this sand than to drag it about on one 's back , seeing what a weight it is . '
17 And forthwith he lowered the sack from his shoulders and emptied its contents on the flames , and instantly the fire was extinguished ; but at the same moment lo !
18 and behold the lovely damsel turned into a Serpent , and , darting upon him , coiled itself round his neck , and whispered lovingly in his ear : ` Do not be afraid of me , Martin ; I love you , and will go with you through the world .
19 But first you must follow me boldly into my Father 's Kingdom , underneath the earth ; and when we get there , remember this -- he will offer you gold and silver , and dazzling gems , but do not touch them .
20 Ask him , instead , for the ring which he wears on his little finger , for in that ring lies a magic power ; you have only to throw it from one hand to the other , and at once twelve young men will appear , who will do your bidding , no matter how difficult , in a single night . '
21 So they started on their XXXXX , and after much wandering they reached a spot where a great rock rose straight up in the middle of the road .	way		damsel|ear|meadow|midst|passion|payment|trick|wages|way|world

1 When the boat could no longer be seen the child began to cry , and though the Witch tried to quiet it she could not manage it ; so she went below to where the King was sleeping with the child on her arm , and awakened him , scolding him for leaving them alone on deck , while he and all the crew were asleep .
2 It was great carelessness of him , she said , to leave no one to watch the ship with her .
3 Sigurd was greatly surprised to hear his Queen scold him so much , for she had never said an angry word to him before ; but he thought it was quite excusable in this case , and tried to quiet the child along with her , but it was no use .
4 Then he went and wakened the sailors , and bade them hoist the sails , for a breeze had sprung up and was blowing straight towards the harbour .
5 They soon reached the land which Sigurd was to rule over , and found all the people sorrowful for the old King 's death , but they became glad when they got Sigurd back to the Court , and made him King over them .
6 The King 's son , however , hardly ever stopped crying from the time he had been taken from his mother on the deck of the ship , although he had always been such a good child before , so that at last the King had to get a nurse for him -- one of the maids of the Court .
7 As soon as the child got into her charge he stopped crying , and behaved well as before .
8 After the sea-voyage it seemed to the King that the Queen had altered very much in many ways , and not for the better .
9 He thought her much more haughty and stubborn and difficult to deal with than she used to be .
10 Before long others began to notice this as well as the King .
11 In the Court there were two young fellows , one of eighteen years old , the other of nineteen , who were very fond of playing chess , and often sat long inside playing at it .
12 Their room was next the Queen 's , and often during the day they heard the Queen talking .
13 One day they paid more attention than usual when they heard her talk , and put their ears close to a crack in the wall between the rooms , and heard the Queen say quite plainly , ` When I yawn a little , then I am a nice little maiden ; when I yawn half-way , then I am half a troll ; and when I yawn fully , then I am a troll altogether . '
14 As she said this she yawned tremendously , and in a moment had put on the appearance of a fearfully ugly troll .
15 Then there came up through the floor of the room a three-headed Giant with a trough full of meat , who saluted her as his sister and set down the trough before her .
16 She began to eat out of it , and never stopped till she had finished it .
17 The young fellows saw all this going on , but did not hear the two of them say anything to each other .
18 They were astonished though at how greedily the Queen devoured the meat , and how much she ate of it , and were no longer surprised that she took so little when she sat at table with the King .
19 As soon as she had finished it the Giant disappeared with the trough by the same way as he had come , and the Queen returned to her human shape .
20 Now we must go back to the King 's son after he had been put in charge of the nurse .

2 In a moment the King of the Foxes stood before him and said : ' I know already what you want , and will summon all the foxes of the world together to find the mare who has hidden herself in a hill . '
3 With these words the King of the Foxes disappeared , and in the evening many thousand foxes brought the mare to the Prince .
4 Then he rode home to the Mother-Dragon , from whom he received this time a cloak made of silver , and again she led him to the ball-room .
5 The Flower Queen 's daughter was delighted to see him safe and sound , and when they were dancing together she whispered in his ear : ` If you succeed again to-morrow , wait for me with the foal in the meadow .
6 After the ball we will fly away together . '
7 On the third day the Prince led the mare to the meadow again ; but once more she vanished before his eyes .
8 Then the Prince took out his little bell and rang it three times .
9 In a moment the King of the Fishes appeared , and said to him : ' I know quite well what you want me to do , and I will summon all the fishes of the sea together , and tell them to bring you back the mare , who is hiding herself in a river . '
10 Towards evening the mare was returned to him , and when he led her home to the Mother Dragon she said to him : ` You are a brave youth , and I will make you my body-servant .
11 But what shall I give you as a reward to begin with ? '
12 The Prince begged for a foal of the mare , which the Mother Dragon at once gave him , and over and above , a cloak made of gold , for she had fallen in love with him because he had praised her beauty .
13 So in the evening he appeared at the ball in his golden cloak ; but before the entertainment was over he slipped away , and went straight to the stables , where he mounted his foal and rode out into the meadow to wait for the Flower Queen 's daughter .
14 Towards midnight the beautiful girl appeared , and placing her in front of him on his horse , the Prince and she flew like the wind till they reached the Flower Queen 's dwelling .
15 But the dragons had noticed their flight , and woke their brother out of his year 's sleep .
16 He flew into a terrible rage when he heard what had happened , and determined to lay siege to the Flower Queen 's palace ; but the Queen caused a forest of flowers as high as the sky to grow up round her dwelling , through which no one could force a way .
17 When the Flower Queen heard that her daughter wanted to marry the Prince , she said to him : ' I will give my consent to your marriage gladly , but my daughter can only stay with you in summer .
18 In winter , when everything is dead and the ground covered with snow , she must come and live with me in my palace underground . '
19 The Prince consented to this , and led his beautiful bride home , where the wedding was held with great pomp and magnificence .
20 The young couple lived happily together till winter came , when the Flower Queen 's daughter departed and went home to her mother .

4 `` I did n't have the least idea that you were there , '' continued Peter .
5 `` When I found who it was , and what you were doing , I could n't help watching because it was so interesting , and I could n't help laughing because you really did look so funny .

7 Truly I am .
8 I did n't mean to be so impolite .

12 Now I know it is so and just how you do it , and I feel as if I had learned something worth knowing .

9 Then Rikki-tikki danced in a circle to get behind her , and Nagaina spun round to keep her head to his head , so that the rustle of her tail on the matting sounded like dry leaves blown along by the wind .
10 He had forgotten the egg .
11 It still lay on the veranda , and Nagaina came nearer and nearer to it , till at last , while Rikki-tikki was drawing breath , she caught it in her mouth , turned to the veranda steps , and flew like an arrow down the path , with Rikki-tikki behind her .
12 When the cobra runs for her life , she goes like a whip-lash flicked across a horse 's neck .

16 She flew off her nest as Nagaina came along , and flapped her wings about Nagaina 's head .

2 Then King Frost stooped down , and bent over the girl , and the crackling sound grew louder , and the air seemed to be full of knives and darts ; and again he asked : ` Maiden , are you warm ?
3 Are you warm , you beautiful girl ? '
4 And though her breath was almost frozen on her lips , she whispered gently , ` Quite warm , King Frost . '
5 Then King Frost gnashed his teeth , and cracked his fingers , and his eyes sparkled , and the crackling , crisp sound was louder than ever , and for the last time he asked her : ` Maiden , are you still warm ?
6 Are you still warm , little love ? '
7 And the poor girl was so stiff and numb that she could just gasp , ` Still warm , O King ! '
8 Now her gentle , courteous words and her uncomplaining ways touched King Frost , and he had pity on her , and he wrapped her up in furs , and covered her with blankets , and he fetched a great box , in which were beautiful jewels and a rich robe embroidered in gold and silver .
9 And she put it on , and looked more lovely than ever , and King Frost stepped with her into his sledge , with six white horses .
10 In the meantime the wicked step-mother was waiting at home for news of the girl 's death , and preparing pancakes for the funeral feast .
11 And she said to her husband : ` Old man , you had better go out into the fields and find your daughter 's body and bury her . '
12 Just as the old man was leaving the house the little dog under the table began to bark , saying : ` YOUR daughter shall live to be your delight ; HER daughter shall die this very night . '
13 ` Hold your tongue , you foolish beast ! '
14 scolded the woman .
15 ` There 's a pancake for you , but you must say : `` HER daughter shall have much silver and gold ; HIS daughter is frozen quite stiff and cold . '' '
16 But the doggie ate up the pancake and barked , saying : ` His daughter shall wear a crown on her head ; Her daughter shall die unwooed , unwed . '
17 Then the old woman tried to coax the doggie with more pancakes and to terrify it with blows , but he barked on , always repeating the same words .
18 And suddenly the door creaked and flew open , and a great heavy chest was pushed in , and behind it came the step-daughter , radiant and beautiful , in a dress all glittering with silver and gold .
19 For a moment the step-mother 's eyes were dazzled .
20 Then she called to her husband : ` Old man , yoke the horses at once into the sledge , and take my daughter to the same field and leave her on the same spot exactly ; ` and so the old man took the girl and left her beneath the same tree where he had parted from his daughter .

3 No , sir !
