6 `` Just wait a moment , Mr. Dutcher , '' he said respectfully .
7 `` I want you to hear my proposition before you refuse definitely .
8 First , I 'll give you ten dollars for the rent of the pond ; then I 'll see that there will be no running over your fields and climbing your fences , no lighting of fire or matches about it , and no ` whooping and yelling ' at nights .
9 My rink will be open only from two to six in the afternoon and from seven to ten in the evening .
10 During that time I shall always be at the pond to keep everything in order .
11 The skaters will come and go by the lane leading from the barn to the road .
12 I think that if you agree to my proposition , Mr. Dutcher , you will not regret it . ''

1 Then the youth went into a room in the castle where everything was made of silver , and here he found another beautiful girl , the sister of his bride .
2 She was combing her silver hair , and every hair that fell on the ground rang out like pure metal .
3 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
4 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
5 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
6 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
7 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
8 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
9 As soon as her feet touched the ground she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .
10 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
11 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
12 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
13 And now everything was up above and only he himself remained below .
14 But as he was a little suspicious of his brothers , he fastened a heavy stone on to the rope and let them pull it up .
15 At first they heaved with a will , but when the stone was half way up they let it drop suddenly , and it fell to the bottom broken into a hundred pieces .
16 ` So that 's what would have happened to my bones had I trusted myself to them , ' said the youth sadly ; and he began to cry bitterly , not because of the treasures , but because of the lovely girl with her swanlike neck and golden hair .
17 For a long time he wandered sadly all through the beautiful underworld , and one day he met a magician who asked him the cause of his tears .
18 The youth told him all that had befallen him , and the magician said : ` Do not grieve , young man !
19 If you will guard the children who are hidden in the golden apple-tree , I will bring you at once up to the earth .
20 Another magician who lives in this land always eats my children up .
21 It is in vain that I have hidden them under the earth and locked them into the XXXXX .	castle		air|blood|bones|bride|castle|chests|ground|room|sister|way

1 The King replied , ` Then both your heads must be staked , and your head and his must be guaranteed for the winner . '
2 When this was agreed upon and settled , the man strapped on the runner 's other leg , saying to him , ` Now be nimble , and see that we win ! '
3 It was arranged that whoever should first bring water out of a stream a long way off , should be the victor .
4 Then the runner got a pitcher , and the King 's daughter another , and they began to run at the same time ; but in a moment , when the King 's daughter was only just a little way off , no spectator could see the runner , and it seemed as if the wind had whistled past .
5 In a short time he reached the stream , filled his pitcher with water , and turned round again .
6 But , half way home , a great drowsiness came over him ; he put down his pitcher , lay down , and fell asleep .
7 He had , however , put a horse 's skull which was lying on the ground , for his pillow , so that he should not be too comfortable and might soon wake up .
8 In the meantime the King 's daughter , who could also run well , as well as an ordinary man could , reached the stream , and hastened back with her pitcher full of water .
9 When she saw the runner lying there asleep , she was delighted , and said , ` My enemy is given into my hands ! '
10 She emptied his pitcher and ran on .
11 Everything now would have been lost , if by good luck the hunter had not been standing on the castle tower and had seen everything with his sharp eyes .
12 ` Ah , ' said he , ` the King 's daughter shall not overreach us ; ' and , loading his gun , he shot so cleverly , that he shot away the horse 's skull from under the runner 's head , without its hurting him .
13 Then the runner awoke , jumped up , and saw that his pitcher was empty and the King 's daughter far ahead .
14 But he did not lose courage , and ran back to the stream with his pitcher , filled it once more with water , and was home ten minutes before the King 's daughter arrived .
15 ` Look , ' said he , ' I have only just exercised my legs ; that was nothing of a run . '
16 But the King was angry , and his daughter even more so , that she should be carried away by a common , discharged soldier .
17 They consulted together how they could destroy both him and his companions .
18 ` Then , ' said the King to her , ' I have found a way .
19 Do n't be frightened ; they shall not come home again . '
20 He said to them , ` You must now make merry together , and eat and drink , ' and he led them into a room which had a floor of iron ; the doors were also of iron , and the windows were barred with iron .

7 CHAPTER XII .
8 Alice 's Evidence ` Here ! '
9 cried Alice , quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes , and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt , upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below , and there they lay sprawling about , reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before .
10 ` Oh , I BEG your pardon ! '
11 she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay , and began picking them up again as quickly as she could , for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head , and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box , or they would die .
12 ` The trial can not proceed , ' said the King in a very grave voice , ` until all the jurymen are back in their proper places -- ALL , ' he repeated with great emphasis , looking hard at Alice as he said do .
13 Alice looked at the jury-box , and saw that , in her haste , she had put the Lizard in head downwards , and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way , being quite unable to move .
14 She soon got it out again , and put it right ; ` not that it signifies much , ' she said to herself ; ' I should think it would be QUITE as much use in the trial one way up as the other . '
15 As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset , and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them , they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident , all except the Lizard , who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open , gazing up into the roof of the court .

1 Let her do what she would , she was always blamed , and got small thanks for all the trouble she took ; nothing was right , everything wrong ; and yet , if the truth were known , the girl was worth her weight in gold -- she was so unselfish and good-hearted .
2 But her step-mother did not like her , and the poor girl 's days were spent in weeping ; for it was impossible to live peacefully with the woman .
3 The wicked shrew was determined to get rid of the girl by fair means or foul , and kept saying to her father : ` Send her away , old man ; send her away -- anywhere so that my eyes sha 'n' t be plagued any longer by the sight of her , or my ears tormented by the sound of her voice .

5 In vain did the poor old father weep and implore her pity ; she was firm , and he dared not gainsay her .
6 So he placed his daughter in a sledge , not even daring to give her a horse-cloth to keep herself warm with , and drove her out on to the bare , open fields , where he kissed her and left her , driving home as fast as he could , that he might not witness her miserable death .
7 Deserted by her father , the poor girl sat down under a fir-tree at the edge of the forest and began to weep silently .

1 They have no remembrance .
2 They boast and chatter and pretend that they are a great people about to do great affairs in the jungle , but the falling of a nut turns their minds to laughter and all is forgotten .
3 We of the jungle have no dealings with them .
4 We do not drink where the monkeys drink ; we do not go where the monkeys go ; we do not hunt where they hunt ; we do not die where they die .
5 Hast thou ever heard me speak of the Bandar-log till today ? ''
6 `` No , '' said Mowgli in a whisper , for the forest was very still now Baloo had finished .
7 `` The Jungle-People put them out of their mouths and out of their minds .
8 They are very many , evil , dirty , shameless , and they desire , if they have any fixed desire , to be noticed by the Jungle People .
9 But we do not notice them even when they throw nuts and filth on our heads . ''
10 He had hardly spoken when a shower of nuts and twigs spattered down through the branches ; and they could hear coughings and howlings and angry jumpings high up in the air among the thin branches .

12 Remember . ''

1 At last the elephants began to lie down one after another as is their custom , till only Kala Nag at the right of the line was left standing up ; and he rocked slowly from side to side , his ears put forward to listen to the night wind as it blew very slowly across the hills .
2 The air was full of all the night noises that , taken together , make one big silence -- the click of one bamboo stem against the other , the rustle of something alive in the undergrowth , the scratch and squawk of a half-waked bird -LRB- birds are awake in the night much more often than we imagine -RRB- , and the fall of water ever so far away .
3 Little Toomai slept for some time , and when he waked it was brilliant moonlight , and Kala Nag was still standing up with his ears cocked .
4 Little Toomai turned , rustling in the fodder , and watched the curve of his big back against half the stars in heaven , and while he watched he heard , so far away that it sounded no more than a pinhole of noise pricked through the stillness , the `` hoot-toot '' of a wild elephant .
5 All the elephants in the lines jumped up as if they had been shot , and their grunts at last waked the sleeping mahouts , and they came out and drove in the picket pegs with big mallets , and tightened this rope and knotted that till all was quiet .
6 One new elephant had nearly grubbed up his picket , and Big Toomai took off Kala Nag 's leg chain and shackled that elephant fore-foot to hind-foot , but slipped a loop of grass string round Kala Nag 's leg , and told him to remember that he was tied fast .
7 He knew that he and his father and his grandfather had done the very same thing hundreds of times before .
8 Kala Nag did not answer to the order by gurgling , as he usually did .
9 He stood still , looking out across the moonlight , his head a little raised and his ears spread like fans , up to the great folds of the Garo hills .
10 `` Tend to him if he grows restless in the night , '' said Big Toomai to Little Toomai , and he went into the hut and slept .
11 Little Toomai was just going to sleep , too , when he heard the coir string snap with a little `` tang , '' and Kala Nag rolled out of his pickets as slowly and as silently as a cloud rolls out of the mouth of a valley .
12 Little Toomai pattered after him , barefooted , down the road in the moonlight , calling under his breath , `` Kala Nag !
13 Kala Nag !
14 Take me with you , O Kala Nag ! ''
15 The elephant turned , without a sound , took three strides back to the boy in the moonlight , put down his trunk , swung him up to his neck , and almost before Little Toomai had settled his knees , slipped into the forest .
16 There was one blast of furious trumpeting from the lines , and then the silence shut down on everything , and Kala Nag began to move .
17 Sometimes a tuft of high grass washed along his sides as a wave washes along the sides of a ship , and sometimes a cluster of wild-pepper vines would scrape along his back , or a bamboo would creak where his shoulder touched it .
18 But between those times he moved absolutely without any sound , drifting through the thick Garo forest as though it had been smoke .
19 He was going uphill , but though Little Toomai watched the stars in the rifts of the trees , he could not tell in what direction .
20 Then Kala Nag reached the crest of the ascent and stopped for a minute , and Little Toomai could see the tops of the trees lying all speckled and furry under the moonlight for miles and miles , and the blue-white mist over the river in the hollow .
21 Toomai leaned forward and looked , and he felt that the XXXXX was awake below him -- awake and alive and crowded .	forest		ascent|custom|ears|elephants|forest|shoulder|sides|smoke|trees|valley

1 Then the Giant rose up and said , ` Now come and I will reward you .
2 We are going to celebrate a marriage to-day , and I promise you we shall have plenty of fun .
3 Come and enjoy yourself , but in order that my brothers may n't see you , put this band round your waist and then you 'll be invisible . '
4 With these words he handed the Herd-boy a belt , and walking on in front he led him to a fountain where hundreds of Giants and Giantesses were assembled preparing to hold a wedding .
5 They danced and played different games till midnight ; then one of the Giants tore up a plant by its roots , and all the Giants and Giantesses made themselves so thin that they disappeared into the earth through the hole made by the uprooting of the plant .
6 The wounded Giant remained behind to the last and called out , ` Herd-boy , where are you ? '
7 ` Here I am , close to you , ' was the reply .
8 ` Touch me , ' said the Giant , ` so that you too may come with us under ground . '
9 The Herd-boy did as he was told , and before he could have believed it possible he found himself in a big hall , where even the walls were made of pure gold .
10 Then to his astonishment he saw that the hall was furnished with the tables and chairs that belonged to his master .
11 In a few minutes the company began to eat and drink .
12 The banquet was a very gorgeous one , and the poor youth fell to and ate and drank lustily .
13 When he had eaten and drunk as much as he could he thought to himself , ` Why should n't I put a loaf of bread in my pocket ?
14 I shall be glad of it to-morrow . '
15 So he seized a loaf when no one was looking and stowed it away under his tunic .
16 No sooner had he done so than the wounded Giant limped up to him and whispered softly , ` Herd-boy , where are you ? '
17 ` Here I am , ' replied the youth .
18 ` Then hold on to me , ' said the Giant , ` so that I may lead you up above again . '
19 So the Herd-boy held on to the Giant , and in a few moments he found himself on the earth once more , but the Giant had vanished .
20 The Herd-boy returned to his sheep , and took off the invisible belt which he hid carefully in his bag .

1 -LRB- 10 -RRB- Convent Gnothi .
2 The Queen gave money to the old woman , and bought the apple from her .
3 Then she peeled it , ate it , and threw the rind out of the window , and it so happened that a mare that was running loose in the court below ate up the rind .
4 After a time the Queen had a little boy , and the mare also had a male foal .
5 The boy and the foal grew up together and loved each other like brothers .
6 In course of time the King died , and so did the Queen , and their son , who was now nineteen years old , was left alone .
7 One day , when he and his horse were talking together , the Horse said to him , ` Listen to me , for I love you and wish for your good and that of the country .
8 If you go on every year sending twelve youths and twelve maidens to the King of the Beasts , your country will very soon be ruined .
9 Mount upon my back : I will take you to a woman who can direct you how to kill the Seven-headed Serpent . '
10 Then the youth mounted his horse , who carried him far away to a mountain which was hollow , for in its side was a great underground cavern .
11 In the cavern sat an old woman spinning .
12 This was the cloister of the nuns , and the old woman was the Abbess .
13 They all spent their time in spinning , and that is why the convent has this name .
14 All round the walls of the cavern there were beds cut out of the solid rock , upon which the nuns slept , and in the middle a light was burning .
15 It was the duty of the nuns to watch the light in turns , that it might never go out , and if anyone of them let it go out the others put her to death .
16 As soon as the King 's son saw the old Abbess spinning he threw himself at her feet and entreated her to tell him how he could kill the Seven-headed Serpent .
17 She made the youth rise , embraced him , and said , ` Know , my son , that it is I who sent the nun to your mother and caused you to be born , and with you the horse , with whose help you will be able to free the world from the monster .
18 I will tell you what you have to do .
19 Load your horse with cotton , and go by a secret passage which I will show you , which is hidden from the wild beasts , to the Serpent 's palace .
20 You will find the King asleep upon his bed , which is all hung round with bells , and over his bed you will see a sword hanging .
21 With this sword only it is possible to kill the XXXXX , because even if its blade breaks a new one will grow again for every head the monster has .	Serpent		Beasts|Load|Serpent|apple|boy|brothers|convent|light|round|walls

1 He did not know what to do with himself when he saw that she was gone , but before she went she had given him a little rod , with which he could , when he pleased , waken the men who had been sleeping there , some of them for sixteen years .
2 After being thus left alone , he went in and stretched himself on three chairs that were in the room , when what does he see coming in at the door but a little fair-haired lad .
3 ` Where did you come from , my lad ? '
4 said the Irishman . '
5 I came to make ready your food for you , ' said he .
6 ` Who told you to do that ? '
7 said the Irishman .
8 ` My mistress , ' answered the lad -- ` the Princess that was under the spell and is now free . '
9 By this the Irishman knew that she had sent the lad to wait on him .
10 The lad also told him that his mistress wished him to be ready next morning at nine o'clock , when she would come for him with the carriage , as she had promised .
11 He was greatly pleased at this , and next morning , when the time was drawing near , went out into the garden ; but the little fair-haired lad took a big pin out of his pocket , and stuck it into the back of the Irishman 's coat without his noticing it , whereupon he fell sound asleep .
12 Before long the Princess came with the carriage and four horses , and asked the lad whether his master was awake .
13 He said that he was n't .
14 ` It is bad for him , ' said she , ` when the night is not long enough for him to sleep .
15 Tell him that if he does n't meet me at this time to-morrow it is not likely that he will ever see me again all his life . '
16 As soon as she was gone the lad took the pin out of his master 's coat , who instantly awoke .
17 The first word he said to the lad was , ` Have you seen her ? '
18 ` Yes , ' said he , ` and she bade me tell you that if you do n't meet her at nine o'clock to-morrow you will never see her again . '
19 He was very sorry when he heard this , and could not understand why the sleep should have fallen upon him just when she was coming .
20 He decided , however , to go early to bed that night , in order to rise in time nest morning , and so he did .
21 When it was getting near nine o'clock he went out to the XXXXX to wait till she came , and the fair-haired lad along with him ; but as soon as the lad got the chance he stuck the pin into his master 's coat again and he fell asleep as before .	garden		bed|coat|garden|horses|lad|master|pin|sleep|spell|time

1 He put aside his bow , and went neither to fight nor to hunt , but from sunrise to sunset he sat by the place where she was laid , thinking of his happiness that was buried there .
2 At last , after many days , a light seemed to come to him out of the darkness .
3 He remembered having heard from the old , old people of the tribe , that there was a path that led to the Land of Souls -- that if you sought carefully you could find it .
4 So the next morning he got up early , and put some food in his pouch and slung an extra skin over his shoulders , for he knew not how long his journey would take , nor what sort of country he would have to go through .
5 Only one thing he knew , that if the path was there , he would find it .
6 At first he was puzzled , as there seemed no reason he should go in one direction more than another .
7 Then all at once he thought he had heard one of the old men say that the Land of Souls lay to the south , and so , filled with new hope and courage , he set his face southwards .
8 For many , many miles the country looked the same as it did round his own home .
9 The forests , the hills , and the rivers all seemed exactly like the ones he had left .
10 The only thing that was different was the snow , which had lain thick upon the hills and trees when he started , but grew less and less the farther he went south , till it disappeared altogether .
11 Soon the trees put forth their buds , and flowers sprang up under his feet , and instead of thick clouds there was blue sky over his head , and everywhere the birds were singing .
12 Then he knew that he was in the right road .
13 The thought that he should soon behold his lost bride made his heart beat for joy , and he sped along lightly and swiftly .
14 Now his way led through a dark wood , and then over some steep cliffs , and on the top of these he found a hut or wigwam .
15 An old man clothed in skins , and holding a staff in his hand , stood in the doorway ; and he said to the young chief who was beginning to tell his story , ' I was waiting for you , wherefore you have come I know .
16 It is but a short while since she whom you seek was here .
17 Rest in my hut , as she also rested , and I will tell you what you ask , and whither you should go . '
18 On hearing these words , the young man entered the hut , but his heart was too eager within him to suffer him to rest , and when he arose , the old man rose too , and stood with him at the door .
19 ` Look , ' he said , ` at the water which lies far out yonder , and the plains which stretch beyond .
20 That is the Land of Souls , but no man enters it without leaving his body behind him .
21 So , lay down your body here ; your bow and arrows , your XXXXX and your dog .	skin		bride|cliffs|clouds|door|path|people|rivers|shoulders|skin|snow

1 Now the Lord whose sheep the Herd-boy looked after had a very lovely daughter , who always smiled and nodded to the youth when she walked with her father in his fields .
2 For a long time the Herd-boy had made up his mind to prepare a surprise for this beautiful creature on her birthday .
3 So when the day approached he put on his invisible belt , took a sack of gold pieces with him , and slipping into her room in the middle of the night , he placed the bag of gold beside her bed and returned to his sheep .
4 The girl 's joy was great , and so was her parents ' next day when they found the sack full of gold pieces .
5 The Herd-boy was so pleased to think what pleasure he had given that the next night he placed another bag of gold beside the girl 's bed .
6 And this he continued to do for seven nights , and the girl and her parents made up their minds that it must be a good Fairy who brought the gold every night .
7 But one night they determined to watch , and see from their hiding place who the bringer of the sack of gold really was .
8 On the eighth night a fearful storm of wind and rain came on while the Herd-boy was on his way to bring the beautiful girl another bag of gold .
9 Then for the first time he noticed , just as he reached his master 's house , that he had forgotten the belt which made him invisible .
10 He did n't like the idea of going back to his hut in the wind and wet , so he just stepped as he was into the girl 's room , laid the sack of gold beside her , and was turning to leave the room , when his master confronted him and said , ` You young rogue , so you were going to steal the gold that a good Fairy brings every night , were you ? '
11 The Herd-boy was so taken aback by his words , that he stood trembling before him , and did not dare to explain his presence .
12 Then his master spoke .
13 ` As you have hitherto always behaved well in my service I will not send you to prison ; but leave your place instantly and never let me see your face again . '
14 So the Herd-boy went back to his hut , and taking his loaf and belt with him , he went to the nearest town .
15 There he bought himself some fine clothes , and a beautiful coach with four horses , hired two servants , and drove back to his master .
16 You may imagine how astonished he was to see his Herd-boy returning to him in this manner !
17 Then the youth told him of the piece of good luck that had befallen him , and asked him for the hand of his beautiful daughter .
18 This was readily granted , and the two lived in peace and happiness to the end of their lives .
19 THE INVISIBLE PRINCE Once upon a time there lived a Fairy who had power over the earth , the sea , fire , and the air ; and this Fairy had four sons .
20 The eldest , who was quick and lively , with a vivid imagination , she made Lord of Fire , which was in her opinion the noblest of all the elements .
21 To the second son , whose wisdom and prudence made amends for his being rather dull , she gave the government of the XXXXX .	earth		Lord|air|clothes|earth|eldest|happiness|power|prison|room|youth

1 One day the Crab said to the fisherman 's wife , ` Go to the King and tell him I wish to marry his younger daughter . '
2 The old woman went accordingly , and laid the matter before the King , who laughed a little at the notion of his daughter marrying a crab , but did not decline the proposal altogether , because he was a prudent monarch , and knew that the Crab was likely to be a prince in disguise .
3 He said , therefore , to the fisherman 's wife , ` Go , old woman , and tell the Crab I will give him my daughter if by to-morrow morning he can build a wall in front of my castle much higher than my tower , upon which all the flowers of the world must grow and bloom . '
4 The fisherman 's wife went home and gave this message .
5 Then the Crab gave her a golden rod , and said , ` Go and strike with this rod three times upon the ground on the place which the King showed you , and to-morrow morning the wall will be there . '
6 The old woman did so and went away again .
7 The next morning , when the King awoke , what do you think he saw ?
8 The wall stood there before his eyes , exactly as he had bespoken it !
9 Then the old woman went back to the King and said to him , ` Your Majesty 's orders have been fulfilled . '
10 ` That is all very well , ' said the King , ` but I can not give away my daughter until there stands in front of my palace a garden in which there are three fountains , of which the first must play gold , the second diamonds , and the third brilliants . '
11 So the old woman had to strike again three times upon the ground with the rod , and the next morning the garden was there .
12 The King now gave his consent , and the wedding was fixed for the very next day .
13 Then the Crab said to the old fisherman , ` Now take this rod ; go and knock with it on a certain mountain ; then a black man -LRB- 6 -RRB- will come out and ask you what you wish for .
14 Answer him thus : '' Your master , the King , has sent me to tell you that you must send him his golden garment that is like the sun . ''
15 Make him give you , besides , the queenly robes of gold and precious stones which are like the flowery meadows , and bring them both to me .
16 And bring me also the golden cushion . '
17 -LRB- 6 -RRB- Ein Mohr .
18 The old man went and did his errand .
19 When he had brought the precious robes , the Crab put on the golden garment and then crept upon the golden cushion , and in this way the fisherman carried him to the castle , where the Crab presented the other garment to his bride .
20 Now the ceremony took place , and when the married pair were alone together the Crab made himself known to his young wife , and told her how he was the son of the greatest king in the world , and how he was enchanted , so that he became a crab by day and was a man only at night ; and he could also change himself into an eagle as often as he wished .

2 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
3 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
4 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
5 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
6 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
7 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her parrot again .
8 As they rose through the air the Princess remarked a figure mounted on an eagle 's back flying in front of the chariot .
9 She was rather alarmed , but the Prince reassured her , telling her it was the good Fairy to whom she owed so much , and who was now conducting her in safety to her mother .
10 That same morning the King woke suddenly from a troubled sleep .
11 He had dreamt that the Princess was being carried off from him , and , transforming himself into an eagle , he flew to the palace .
12 When he failed to find her he flew into a terrible rage , and hastened home to consult his books , by which means he discovered that it was his son who had deprived him of this precious treasure .
13 Immediately he took the shape of a harpy , and , filled with rage , was determined to devour his son , and even the Princess too , if only he could overtake them .
14 He set out at full speed ; but he started too late , and was further delayed by a strong wind which the Fairy raised behind the young couple so as to baffle any pursuit .
15 You may imagine the rapture with which the Queen received the daughter she had given up for lost , as well as the amiable Prince who had rescued her .
16 The Fairy entered with them , and warned the Queen that the Wizard King would shortly arrive , infuriated by his loss , and that nothing could preserve the Prince and Princess from his rage and magic unless they were actually married .
17 The Queen hastened to inform the King her husband , and the wedding took place on the spot .
18 As the ceremony was completed the Wizard King arrived .
19 His despair at being so late bewildered him so entirely that he appeared in his natural form and attempted to sprinkle some black liquid over the bride and bridegroom , which was intended to kill them , but the Fairy stretched out her wand and the liquid dropped on the Magician himself .
20 He fell down senseless , and the Princess 's father , deeply offended at the cruel revenge which had been attempted , ordered him to be removed and locked up in prison .
21 Now as magicians lose all their power as soon as they are in XXXXX , the King felt himself much embarrassed at being thus at the mercy of those he had so greatly offended .	prison		books|bridegroom|ceremony|daughter|harpy|help|liberty|liquid|palace|prison

1 ` Why not ? '
2 answered the maiden .
3 ` Take some weeks to consider if you like , and take counsel with your own heart . '
4 And to make the time pass pleasantly , she took the youth over every part of her beautiful dwelling , and showed him all her splendid treasures .
5 But these treasures were all produced by enchantment , for the maiden could make anything she wished appear by the help of King Solomon 's signet ring ; only none of these things remained fixed ; they passed away like the wind without leaving a trace behind .
6 But the youth did not know this ; he thought they were all real .
7 One day the maiden took him into a secret chamber , where a little gold box was standing on a silver table .
8 Pointing to the box , she said , ` Here is my greatest treasure , whose like is not to be found in the whole world .
9 It is a precious gold ring .
10 When you marry me , I will give you this ring as a marriage gift , and it will make you the happiest of mortal men .
11 But in order that our love may last for ever , you must give me for the ring three drops of blood from the little finger of your left hand . '
12 When the youth heard these words a cold shudder ran over him , for he remembered that his soul was at stake .
13 He was cunning enough , however , to conceal his feelings and to make no direct answer , but he only asked the maiden , as if carelessly , what was remarkable about the ring ?
14 She answered , ` No mortal is able entirely to understand the power of this ring , because no one thoroughly understands the secret signs engraved upon it .
15 But even with my half-knowledge I can work great wonders .
16 If I put the ring upon the little finger of my left hand , then I can fly like a bird through the air wherever I wish to go .
17 If I put it on the third finger of my left hand I am invisible , and I can see everything that passes around me , though no one can see me .
18 If I put the ring upon the middle finger of my left hand , then neither fire nor water nor any sharp weapon can hurt me .
19 If I put it on the forefinger of my left hand , then I can with its help produce whatever I wish .
20 I can in a single moment build houses or anything I desire .
21 Finally , as long as I wear the ring on the thumb of my left hand , that XXXXX is so strong that it can break down rocks and walls .	hand		answer|anything|finger|forefinger|hand|time|treasures|water|weapon|wonders

2 In silence they glided along , and thought themselves already safe , when a furious monster dashed itself by accident against Rosalie and the Invisible Prince , and in her fright she let go his hand .
3 No one can speak as long as he is invisible , and besides , they knew that the spirits were all around them , and at the slightest sound they would be recognised ; so all they could do was to feel about in the hope that their hands might once more meet .
4 But , alas !
5 the joy of liberty lasted but a short time .
6 The Princess , having wandered in vain up and down the forest , stopped at last on the edge of a fountain .
7 As she walked she wrote on the trees : ` If ever the Prince , my lover , comes this way , let him know that it is here I dwell , and that I sit daily on the edge of this fountain , mingling my tears with its waters . '
8 These words were read by one of the genii , who repeated them to his master .
9 The Prince of the Air , in his turn making himself invisible , was led to the fountain , and waited for Rosalie .
10 When she drew near he held out his hand , which she grasped eagerly , taking it for that of her lover ; and , seizing his opportunity , the Prince passed a cord round her arms , and throwing off his invisibility cried to his spirits to drag her into the lowest pit .
11 It was at this moment that the Invisible Prince appeared , and at the sight of the Prince of the Genii mounting into the air , holding a silken cord , he guessed instantly that he was carrying off Rosalie .
12 He felt so overwhelmed by despair that he thought for an instant of putting an end to his life .
13 ` Can I survive my misfortunes ? '
14 he cried . '
15 I fancied I had come to an end of my troubles , and now they are worse than ever .
16 What will become of me ?
17 Never can I discover the place where this monster will hide Rosalie . '

19 So he continued to walk on through the forest , and after some hours he arrived at the gate of a temple , guarded by two huge lions .

1 The cook did so , and the Six sitting round the table felt it grow very warm , and they thought this was because of their good fare ; but when the heat became still greater and they wanted to go out , but found the doors and windows fastened , then they knew that the King meant them harm and was trying to suffocate them .
2 ` But he shall not succeed , ' cried he of the little hat , ' I will make a frost come which shall make the fire ashamed and die out ! '
3 So he put his hat on straight , and at once there came such a frost that all the heat disappeared and the food on the dishes began to freeze .
4 When a couple of hours had passed , and the King thought they must be quite dead from the heat , he had the doors opened and went in himself to see .
5 But when the doors were opened , there stood all Six , alive and well , saying they were glad they could come out to warm themselves , for the great cold in the room had frozen all the food hard in the dishes .
6 Then the King went angrily to the cook , and scolded him , and asked him why he had not done what he was told .
7 But the cook answered , ` There is heat enough there ; see for yourself . '
8 Then the King saw a huge fire burning under the iron room , and understood that he could do no harm to the Six in this way .
9 The King now began again to think how he could free himself from his unwelcome guests .

1 He had formed no plan , and there was no reason that he should choose one path more than another .
2 His only idea was to make straight for those spots which were the favourite haunts of birds .
3 But in vain he examined all the hedges and all the thickets ; in vain he questioned everyone he met along the road .
4 The more he sought the less he found .
5 At last he came to one of the largest forests in all the world , composed entirely of cedars .
6 But in spite of the deep shadows cast by the wide-spreading branches of the trees , the grass underneath was soft and green , and covered with the rarest flowers .
7 It seemed to Saphir that this was exactly the place where the birds would choose to live , and he determined not to quit the wood until he had examined it from end to end .
8 And he did more .
9 He ordered some nets to be prepared and painted of the same colours as the bird 's plumage , thinking that we are all easily caught by what is like ourselves .
10 In this he had to help him not only the fowlers by profession , but also his attendants , who excelled in this art .
11 For a man is not a courtier unless he can do everything .
12 After searching as usual for nearly a whole day Prince Saphir began to feel overcome with thirst .
13 He was too tired to go any farther , when happily he discovered a little way off a bubbling fountain of the clearest water .
14 Being an experienced traveller , he drew from his pocket a little cup -LRB- without which no one should ever take a journey -RRB- , and was just about to dip it in the water , when a lovely little green frog , much prettier than frogs generally are , jumped into the cup .
15 Far from admiring its beauty , Saphir shook it impatiently off ; but it was no good , for quick as lightning the frog jumped back again .
16 Saphir , who was raging with thirst , was just about to shake it off anew , when the little creature fixed upon him the most beautiful eyes in the world , and said , ' I am a friend of the bird you are seeking , and when you have quenched your thirst listen to me . '
17 So the Prince drank his fill , and then , by the command of the Little Green Frog , he lay down on the grass to rest himself .

1 Summer had arrived to stay .
2 On every side he heard glad voices .
3 Bumble the Bee was humming a song .
4 Best of all , Jimmy had found three beetles that very morning , and he knew that there were more if he could find them .
5 So why should n't he feel good ?
6 Jimmy had laughed at Peter Rabbit for being so anxious for Summer to arrive , but he was just as glad as Peter that she had come , although he would n't have said so for the world .
7 His sharp little eyes twinkled as he ambled along , and there was n't much that they missed .
8 As he walked he talked , quite to himself of course , because there was nobody near to hear , and this is what he was saying : `` Beetle , beetle , smooth and smug , You are nothing but a bug .
9 Bugs were made for Skunks to eat , So come out from your retreat .
10 `` Hello !
11 There 's a nice big piece of bark over there that looks as if it ought to have a dozen fat beetles under it .
12 It 's great fun to pull over pieces of bark and see fat beetles run all ways at once .
13 I 'll just have to see what is under that piece . ''
14 Jimmy tiptoed softly over to the big piece of bark , and then as he made ready to turn it over , he began again that foolish little verse .
15 `` Beetle , beetle , smooth and smug , You are nothing but a bug . ''
16 As he said the last word , he suddenly pulled the piece of bark over .
17 `` Who 's a bug ? ''
18 asked a funny voice , and it sounded rather cross .
19 Jimmy Skunk nearly tumbled over backward in surprise , and for a minute he could n't find his tongue .
20 There , instead of the fat beetles he had been so sure of , sat Old Mr. Toad , and he did n't look at all pleased .
21 `` Who 's a XXXXX ? ''	bug		Best|Summer|beetles|bug|eyes|fun|side|tongue|word|world

1 He has driven game for us .

14 In truth , I have lived too long .

16 Therefore I know ye to be cowards , and it is to cowards I speak .
17 It is certain that I must die , and my life is of no worth , or I would offer that in the man-cub 's place .
18 But for the sake of the Honor of the Pack , -- a little matter that by being without a leader ye have forgotten , -- I promise that if ye let the man-cub go to his own place , I will not , when my time comes to die , bare one tooth against ye .
19 I will die without fighting .
20 That will at least save the Pack three lives .

1 To talk of the soul of a money-lender in a beast that never had the courage of a jackal is child 's talk . ''
2 Buldeo was speechless with surprise for a moment , and the head-man stared .
3 `` Oho !
4 It is the jungle brat , is it ? ''
5 said Buldeo .
6 `` If thou art so wise , better bring his hide to Khanhiwara , for the Government has set a hundred rupees on his life .
7 Better still , talk not when thy elders speak . ''
8 Mowgli rose to go .
9 `` All the evening I have lain here listening , '' he called back over his shoulder , `` and , except once or twice , Buldeo has not said one word of truth concerning the jungle , which is at his very doors .
10 How , then , shall I believe the tales of ghosts and gods and goblins which he says he has seen ? ''
11 `` It is full time that boy went to herding , '' said the head-man , while Buldeo puffed and snorted at Mowgli 's impertinence .
12 The custom of most Indian villages is for a few boys to take the cattle and buffaloes out to graze in the early morning , and bring them back at night .
13 The very cattle that would trample a white man to death allow themselves to be banged and bullied and shouted at by children that hardly come up to their noses .
14 So long as the boys keep with the herds they are safe , for not even the tiger will charge a mob of cattle .
15 But if they straggle to pick flowers or hunt lizards , they are sometimes carried off .
16 Mowgli went through the village street in the dawn , sitting on the back of Rama , the great herd bull .
17 The slaty-blue buffaloes , with their long , backward-sweeping horns and savage eyes , rose out their byres , one by one , and followed him , and Mowgli made it very clear to the children with him that he was the master .
18 He beat the buffaloes with a long , polished bamboo , and told Kamya , one of the boys , to graze the cattle by themselves , while he went on with the buffaloes , and to be very careful not to stray away from the herd .
19 An Indian grazing ground is all rocks and scrub and tussocks and little ravines , among which the herds scatter and disappear .
20 The buffaloes generally keep to the pools and muddy places , where they lie wallowing or basking in the warm mud for hours .
21 Mowgli drove them on to the edge of the plain where the Waingunga came out of the XXXXX ; then he dropped from Rama 's neck , trotted off to a bamboo clump , and found Gray Brother .	jungle		buffaloes|children|herd|herds|jungle|mud|pools|soul|talk|tiger

1 On the threshold he was greeted by a servant with the news that his wife had just given birth to a boy .
2 The poor miller was much horrified by these tidings , and went in to his wife with a heavy heart to tell her and his relations of the fatal bargain he had just struck with the nixy . '
3 I would gladly give up all the good fortune she promised me , ' he said , ` if I could only save my child . '
4 But no one could think of any advice to give him , beyond taking care that the child never went near the mill-pond .
5 So the boy throve and grew big , and in the meantime all prospered with the miller , and in a few years he was richer than he had ever been before .
6 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
7 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
8 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
9 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
10 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
11 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
12 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
13 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
14 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
15 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
16 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
17 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
18 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
19 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
20 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
21 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden XXXXX , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .	comb		bargain|birth|comb|dream|grief|meadow|news|peace|relations|threshold

1 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
2 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
3 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
4 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
5 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
6 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
7 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
8 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
9 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
10 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
11 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
12 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
13 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
14 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
15 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
16 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
17 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
18 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
19 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
20 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .

5 An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet . '
6 Then they both bowed low , and their curls got entangled together .

9 ` There 's no sort of use in knocking , ' said the Footman , ` and that for two reasons .
10 First , because I 'm on the same side of the door as you are ; secondly , because they 're making such a noise inside , no one could possibly hear you . '
11 And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise going on within -- a constant howling and sneezing , and every now and then a great crash , as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces .

1 So the old woman continued , ` The most beautiful woman in the whole world is the daughter of the Queen of the Flowers , who has been captured by a dragon .
2 If you wish to marry her , you must first set her free , and this I will help you to do .
3 I will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the King of the Eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the King of the Foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the King of the Fishes by your side .
4 These will help you if you are in any difficulty .
5 Now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . '
6 She handed him the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed her up .
7 Then it dawned on the Prince that he had been speaking to a good fairy , and putting the little bell carefully in his pocket , he rode home and told his father that he meant to set the daughter of the Flower Queen free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid .
8 So the next morning the Prince mounted his fine horse and left his home .
9 He had roamed round the world for a whole year , and his horse had died of exhaustion , while he himself had suffered much from want and misery , but still he had come on no trace of her he was in search of .
10 At last one day he came to a hut , in front of which sat a very old man .
11 The Prince asked him , ` Do you not know where the Dragon lives who keeps the daughter of the Flower Queen prisoner ? '
12 ` No , I do not , ' answered the old man .
13 ` But if you go straight along this road for a year , you will reach a hut where my father lives , and possibly he may be able to tell you . '
14 The Prince thanked him for his information , and continued his journey for a whole year along the same road , and at the end of it came to the little hut , where he found a very old man .
15 He asked him the same question , and the old man answered , ` No , I do not know where the Dragon lives .
16 But go straight along this road for another year , and you will come to a hut in which my father lives .
17 I know he can tell you . '
18 And so the Prince wandered on for another year , always on the same road , and at last reached the hut where he found the third old man .
19 He put the same question to him as he had put to his son and grandson ; but this time the old man answered , ` The Dragon lives up there on the mountain , and he has just begun his year of sleep .
20 For one whole year he is always awake , and the next he sleeps .

13 In very ancient times there lived a King , whose power lay not only in the vast extent of his dominions , but also in the magic secrets of which he was master .
14 After spending the greater part of his early youth in pleasure , he met a Princess of such remarkable beauty that he at once asked her hand in marriage , and , having obtained it , considered himself the happiest of men .

17 I said secretly , because the Fairy had warned the Queen that the King was a magician ; and as from time immemorial there had been a standing feud between the Fairies and the Wizards , he might not have approved of his wife 's visit .

1 The Queen 's decision was that the King should make a big grave-mound for her brother , and put Hadvor into it beside him .
2 Olof knew all the plans of the Queen , and went to tell the Princess what had been done , whereupon Hadvor earnestly entreated her to tell her what to do .
3 ` First and foremost , ' said Olof , ` you must get a wide cloak to wear over your other clothes , when you are put into the mound .
4 The Giant 's ghost will walk after you are both left together in there , and he will have two dogs along with him .
5 He will ask you to cut pieces out of his legs to give to the dogs , but that you must not promise to do unless he tells you where Hermod has gone to , and tells you how to find him .
6 He will then let you stand on his shoulders , so as to get out of the mound ; but he means to cheat you all the same , and will catch you by the cloak to pull you back again ; but you must take care to have the cloak loose on your shoulders , so that he will only get hold of that . '
7 The mound was all ready now , and the Giant laid in it , and into it Hadvor also had to go without being allowed to make any defence .
8 After they were both left there everything happened just as Olof had said .
9 The prince became a Giant again , and asked Hadvor to cut the pieces out of his legs for the dogs ; but she refused until he told her that Hermod was in a desert island , which she could not reach unless she took the skin off the soles of his feet and made shoes out of that ; with these shoes she could travel both on land and sea .
10 This Hadvor now did , and the Giant then let her get up on his shoulders to get out of the mound .
11 As she sprang out he caught hold of her cloak ; but she had taken care to let it lie loose on her shoulders , and so escaped .
12 She now made her way down to the sea , to where she knew there was the shortest distance over to the island in which Hermod was .
13 This strait she easily crossed , for the shoes kept her up .
14 On reaching the island she found a sandy beach all along by the sea , and high cliffs above .
15 Nor could she see any way to get up these , and so , being both sad at heart and tired with the long journey , she lay down and fell asleep .
16 As she slept she dreamed that a tall woman came to her and said , ' I know that you are Princess Hadvor , and are searching for Hermod .
17 He is on this island ; but it will be hard for you to get to him if you have no one to help you , for you can not climb the cliffs by your own strength .
18 I have therefore let down a rope , by which you will be able to climb up ; and as the island is so large that you might not find Hermod 's dwelling-place so easily , I lay down this clew beside you .
19 You need only hold the end of the thread , and the clew will run on before and show you the way .
20 I also lay this belt beside you , to put on when you awaken ; it will keep you from growing faint with hunger . '
21 The XXXXX now disappeared , and Hadvor woke , and saw that all her dream had been true .	woman		cloak|defence|dogs|journey|mound|strait|strength|thread|whereupon|woman

7 But it was impossible to make this long explanation , so I merely replied : `` Not here . ''
8 `` Will you not go tomorrow morning ? ''
9 `` Aunt will not let me . ''
10 `` Coax her . ''
11 `` Coaxing never has any effect on her . ''
12 `` Would she relent if Mrs. Allardyce were to call for you ? ''
13 Now , I have been cautiously sounding Aunt about Mrs. Allardyce , and I have discovered that she disapproves of her .
14 So I said : `` It would be useless .
15 I will ask Aunt if I may go , but I feel almost sure that she will not consent . ''
16 This evening , when Aunt was in an unusually genial mood , I plucked up heart of grace and asked her .
17 `` Marguer_ite , '' she said impressively , `` you know that I do not attend church here . ''
18 `` But , Aunt , '' I persisted , quakingly , `` could n't I go alone ?
19 It is not very far -- and I will be very careful . ''
20 Aunt merely gave me a look that said about forty distinct and separate things , and I was turning away in despair when Mrs. Saxby -- bless her heart -- said : `` I really think it would be no harm to let the child go . ''
21 As XXXXX attaches great importance to Mrs. Saxby 's opinion , she looked at me relentingly and said : `` Well , I will think it over and let you know in the morning , Marguer_ite . ''	Aunt		Aunt|Message|child|church|despair|evening|explanation|harm|heart|things

1 Then Ferko buried his face in the ground till his eyes were damp with dewdrops , and in a moment he saw clearer than he had ever done in his life before .
2 The moon was shining brightly , and lighted him to the lake where he could bathe his poor broken legs .
3 Then Ferko crawled to the edge of the lake and dipped his limbs in the water .
4 No sooner had he done so than his legs felt as sound and strong as they had been before , and Ferko thanked the kind fate that had led him to the hill where he had overheard the ravens ' conversation .
5 He filled a bottle with the healing water , and then continued his journey in the best of spirits .
6 He had not gone far before he met a wolf , who was limping disconsolately along on three legs , and who on perceiving Ferko began to howl dismally .
7 ` My good friend , ' said the youth , ` be of good cheer , for I can soon heal your leg , ' and with these words he poured some of the precious water over the wolf 's paw , and in a minute the animal was springing about sound and well on all fours .
8 The grateful creature thanked his benefactor warmly , and promised Ferko to do him a good turn if he should ever need it .
9 Ferko continued his way till he came to a ploughed field .
10 Here he noticed a little mouse creeping wearily along on its hind paws , for its front paws had both been broken in a trap .
11 Ferko felt so sorry for the little beast that he spoke to it in the most friendly manner , and washed its small paws with the healing water .
12 In a moment the mouse was sound and whole , and after thanking the kind physician it scampered away over the ploughed furrows .
13 Ferko again proceeded on his journey , but he had n't gone far before a queen bee flew against him , trailing one wing behind her , which had been cruelly torn in two by a big bird .
14 Ferko was no less willing to help her than he had been to help the wolf and the mouse , so he poured some healing drops over the wounded wing .
15 On the spot the queen bee was cured , and turning to Ferko she said , ' I am most grateful for your kindness , and shall reward you some day . '
16 And with these words she flew away humming , gaily .
17 Then Ferko wandered on for many a long day , and at length reached a strange kingdom .
18 Here , he thought to himself , he might as well go straight to the palace and offer his services to the King of the country , for he had heard that the King 's daughter was as beautiful as the day .
19 So he went to the royal palace , and as he entered the door the first people he saw were his two brothers who had so shamefully ill-treated him .
20 They had managed to obtain places in the King 's service , and when they recognised Ferko with his eyes and legs sound and well they were frightened to death , for they feared he would tell the King of their conduct , and that they would be hung .
21 No sooner had Ferko entered the palace than all XXXXX were turned on the handsome youth , and the King 's daughter herself was lost in admiration , for she had never seen anyone so handsome in her life before .	eyes		country|day|dewdrops|door|eyes|kingdom|life|moon|people|youth

1 I shall indeed be sea-sick now .
2 I am breaking ! '
3 CHAPTER I. Down the Rabbit-Hole Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank , and of having nothing to do : once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading , but it had no pictures or conversations in it , ` and what is the use of a book , ' thought Alice ` without pictures or conversation ? '
4 So she was considering in her own mind -LRB- as well as she could , for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid -RRB- , whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies , when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her .
5 There was nothing so VERY remarkable in that ; nor did Alice think it so VERY much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself , ` Oh dear !
6 Oh dear !
7 I shall be late ! '
8 -LRB- when she thought it over afterwards , it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this , but at the time it all seemed quite natural -RRB- ; but when the Rabbit actually TOOK A WATCH OUT OF ITS WAISTCOAT-POCKET , and looked at it , and then hurried on , Alice started to her feet , for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket , or a watch to take out of it , and burning with curiosity , she ran across the field after it , and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge .
9 In another moment down went Alice after it , never once considering how in the world she was to get out again .
10 The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way , and then dipped suddenly down , so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well .
11 Either the well was very deep , or she fell very slowly , for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next .
12 First , she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to , but it was too dark to see anything ; then she looked at the sides of the well , and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves ; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs .
13 She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed ; it was labelled ` ORANGE MARMALADE ' , but to her great disappointment it was empty : she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody , so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it .
14 ` Well ! '
15 thought Alice to herself , ` after such a fall as this , I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs !
16 How brave they 'll all think me at home !
17 Why , I would n't say anything about it , even if I fell off the top of the house ! '
18 -LRB- Which was very likely true . -RRB-
19 Down , down , down .
20 Would the fall NEVER come to an end ! '

1 She told him he must build a castle on the other side of the lake , made of nothing but gold , silver , and precious stones , and unless he could accomplish this within an hour , the most frightful doom awaited him .
2 The Prince heard her words without anxiety , so entirely did he rely on the help of his black friend .
3 Full of hope he hurried across the bridge , and recognised at once the spot where the castle was to stand , for spades , hammers , axes , and every other building implement lay scattered on the ground ready for the workman 's hand , but of gold , silver , and precious stones there was not a sign .
4 But before the Prince had time to feel despondent the black girl beckoned to him in the distance from behind a rock , where she had hidden herself for fear her mother should catch sight of her .
5 Full of joy the youth hurried towards her , and begged her aid and counsel in the new piece of work he had been given to do .
6 But this time the Fairy had watched the Prince 's movements from her window , and she saw him hiding himself behind the rock with her daughter .
7 She uttered a piercing shriek so that the mountains re-echoed with the sound of it , and the terrified pair had hardly dared to look out from their hiding-place when the enraged woman , with her dress and hair flying in the wind , hurried over the bridge of clouds .
8 The Prince at once gave himself up for lost , but the girl told him to be of good courage and to follow her as quickly as he could .
9 But before they left their shelter she broke off a little bit of the rock , spoke some magic words over it , and threw it in the direction her mother was coming from .
10 In a moment a glittering palace arose before the eyes of the Fairy which blinded her with its dazzling splendour , and with its many doors and passages prevented her for some time from finding her way out of it .
11 In the meantime the black girl hurried on with the Prince , hastening to reach the river , where once on the other side they would for ever be out of the wicked Fairy 's power .
12 But before they had accomplished half the way they heard again the rustle of her garments and her muttered curses pursuing them closely .
13 The Prince was terrified ; he dared not look back , and he felt his strength giving way .
14 But before he had time to despair the girl uttered some more magic words , and immediately she herself was changed into a pond , and the Prince into a duck swimming on its surface .
15 When the Fairy saw this her rage knew no bounds , and she used all her magic wits to make the pond disappear ; she caused a hill of sand to arise at her feet , meaning it to dry up the water at once .
16 But the sand hill only drove the pond a little farther away , and its waters seemed to increase instead of diminishing .
17 When the old woman saw that the powers of her magic were of so little avail , she had recourse to cunning .
18 She threw a lot of gold nuts into the pond , hoping in this way to catch the duck , but all her efforts were fruitless , for the little creature refused to let itself be caught .
19 Then a new idea struck the wicked old woman , and hiding herself behind the rock which had sheltered the fugitives , she waited behind it , watching carefully for the moment when the Prince and her daughter should resume their natural forms and continue their journey .
20 She had not to wait long , for as soon as the girl thought her mother was safely out of the way , she changed herself and the Prince once more into their human shape , and set out cheerfully for the river .
21 But they had not gone many steps when the wicked XXXXX hurried after them , a drawn dagger in her hand , and was close upon them , when suddenly , instead of the Prince and her daughter , she found herself in front of a great stone church , whose entrance was carefully guarded by a huge monk . 1 So off they started after Old Mr. Toad , Peter Rabbit in the lead as usual , Unc ' Billy Possum next , grinning as only he can grin , and in the rear Jimmy Skunk , taking his time and keeping a sharp eye out for fat beetles .
2 III THE HUNT FOR OLD MR. TOAD Now , though Old Mr. Toad was hurrying as fast as ever he could and was quite out of breath , he was n't getting along very fast compared with the way Peter Rabbit or Jimmy Skunk or Unc ' Billy Possum could cover the ground .
3 You see he can not make long jumps like his cousin , Grandfather Frog , but only little short hops .
4 So Peter and Jimmy and Unc ' Billy took their time about following him .
5 They stopped to hunt for fat beetles for Jimmy Skunk , and at every little patch of sweet clover for Peter Rabbit to help himself .
6 Once they wasted a lot of time while Unc ' Billy Possum hunted for a nest of Carol the Meadow Lark , on the chance that he would find some fresh eggs there .
7 He did n't find the nest for the very good reason that Carol had n't built one yet .
8 Peter was secretly glad .
9 You know he does n't eat eggs , and he is always sorry for his feathered friends when their eggs are stolen .
10 Half way across the Green Meadows they stopped to play with the Merry Little Breezes , and because it was very pleasant there , they played longer than they realized .
11 When at last they started on again , Old Mr. Toad was out of sight .
12 You see all the time he had kept right on going , hop , hop , hipperty-hop .
13 `` Never mind , '' said Peter , `` we can catch up with him easy enough , he 's such a slow-poke . ''
14 But even a slow-poke who keeps right on doing a thing without wasting any time always gets somewhere sooner or later , very often sooner than those who are naturally quicker , but who waste their time .
15 So it was with Old Mr. Toad .
16 He kept right on , hop , hop , hipperty-hop , while the others were playing , and so it happened that when at last Peter and Jimmy and Unc ' Billy reached the Smiling Pool , they had n't caught another glimpse of Old Mr. Toad .

1 Fairer-than-a-Fairy lost no moment in which she could meet her lover , and they enjoyed many long and interesting interviews .
2 One day , however , their conversation became so absorbing and time passed so quickly that the Princess forgot to attend to the fire , and it went out .
3 Lagree , on her return , soon found out the neglect , and seemed only too pleased to have the opportunity of showing her spite to her lovely prisoner .
4 She ordered Fairer-than-a-Fairy to start next day at dawn to ask Locrinos for fire with which to relight the one she had allowed to go out .
5 Now this Locrinos was a cruel monster who devoured everyone he came across , and especially enjoyed a chance of catching and eating any young girls .
6 Our heroine obeyed with great sweetness , and without having been able to take leave of her lover she set off to go to Locrinos as to certain death .
7 As she was crossing a wood a bird sang to her to pick up a shining pebble which she would find in a fountain close by , and to use it when needed .
8 She took the bird 's advice , and in due time arrived at the house of Locrinos .
9 Luckily she only found his wife at home , who was much struck by the Princess 's youth and beauty and sweet gentle manners , and still further impressed by the present of the shining pebble .
10 She readily let Fairer-than-a-Fairy have the fire , and in return for the stone she gave her another , which , she said , might prove useful some day .
11 Then she sent her away without doing her any harm .
12 Lagree was as much surprised as displeased at the happy result of this expedition , and Fairer-than-a Fairy waited anxiously for an opportunity of meeting Prince Rainbow and telling him her adventures .
13 She found , however , that he had already been told all about them by a Fairy who protected him , and to whom he was related .
14 The dread of fresh dangers to his beloved Princess made him devise some more convenient way of meeting than by the garden fountain , and Fairer-than-a-Fairy carried out his plan daily with entire success .
15 Every morning she placed a large basin full of water on her window-sill , and as soon as the sun 's rays fell on the water the Rainbow appeared as clearly as it had ever done in the fountain .
16 By this means they were able to meet without losing sight of the fire or of the two bottles in which the old Fairy kept her eye and her tooth at night , and for some time the lovers enjoyed every hour of sunshine together .

1 He worked his way desperately , inch by inch , straight for the reservoirs , halting in silence .
2 Then from the ruined wall nearest the jungle rose up the rumbling war-shout of Baloo .
3 The old Bear had done his best , but he could not come before .
4 `` Bagheera , '' he shouted , `` I am here .
5 I climb !
6 I haste !
7 Ahuwora !
8 The stones slip under my feet !
9 Wait my coming , O most infamous Bandar-log ! ''
10 He panted up the terrace only to disappear to the head in a wave of monkeys , but he threw himself squarely on his haunches , and , spreading out his forepaws , hugged as many as he could hold , and then began to hit with a regular bat-bat-bat , like the flipping strokes of a paddle wheel .
11 A crash and a splash told Mowgli that Bagheera had fought his way to the tank where the monkeys could not follow .
12 The Panther lay gasping for breath , his head just out of the water , while the monkeys stood three deep on the red steps , dancing up and down with rage , ready to spring upon him from all sides if he came out to help Baloo .
13 It was then that Bagheera lifted up his dripping chin , and in despair gave the Snake 's Call for protection -- `` We be of one blood , ye and I '' -- for he believed that Kaa had turned tail at the last minute .
14 Even Baloo , half smothered under the monkeys on the edge of the terrace , could not help chuckling as he heard the Black Panther asking for help .
15 Kaa had only just worked his way over the west wall , landing with a wrench that dislodged a coping stone into the ditch .
16 He had no intention of losing any advantage of the ground , and coiled and uncoiled himself once or twice , to be sure that every foot of his long body was in working order .
17 All that while the fight with Baloo went on , and the monkeys yelled in the tank round Bagheera , and Mang the Bat , flying to and fro , carried the news of the great battle over the jungle , till even Hathi the Wild Elephant trumpeted , and , far away , scattered bands of the Monkey-Folk woke and came leaping along the tree-roads to help their comrades in the Cold Lairs , and the noise of the fight roused all the day birds for miles round .
18 Then Kaa came straight , quickly , and anxious to kill .
19 The fighting strength of a python is in the driving blow of his head backed by all the strength and weight of his body .
20 If you can imagine a lance , or a battering ram , or a hammer weighing nearly half a ton driven by a cool , quiet mind living in the handle of it , you can roughly imagine what Kaa was like when he fought .
21 A python four or five XXXXX long can knock a man down if he hits him fairly in the chest , and Kaa was thirty feet long , as you know .	feet		edge|feet|foot|ground|head|lance|monkeys|order|python|wall

5 A new ship was built , and set with black sails , and in it the youths and maidens who were appointed for the king of the beasts embarked and set out for his country .
