1 His mother Radha Pyari , -- Radha the darling , -- who had been caught in the same drive with Kala Nag , told him , before his little milk tusks had dropped out , that elephants who were afraid always got hurt .
2 Kala Nag knew that that advice was good , for the first time that he saw a shell burst he backed , screaming , into a stand of piled rifles , and the bayonets pricked him in all his softest places .
3 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
4 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
5 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
6 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
7 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
8 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other elephants who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .
9 Elephants are very strictly preserved by the Indian Government .
10 There is one whole department which does nothing else but hunt them , and catch them , and break them in , and send them up and down the country as they are needed for work .
11 Kala Nag stood ten fair feet at the shoulders , and his tusks had been cut off short at five feet , and bound round the ends , to prevent them splitting , with bands of copper ; but he could do more with those stumps than any untrained elephant could do with the real sharpened ones .
12 When , after weeks and weeks of cautious driving of scattered elephants across the hills , the forty or fifty wild monsters were driven into the last stockade , and the big drop gate , made of tree trunks lashed together , jarred down behind them , Kala Nag , at the word of command , would go into that flaring , trumpeting pandemonium -LRB- generally at night , when the flicker of the torches made it difficult to judge distances -RRB- , and , picking out the biggest and wildest tusker of the mob , would hammer him and hustle him into quiet while the men on the backs of the other elephants roped and tied the smaller ones .
13 There was nothing in the way of fighting that Kala Nag , the old wise Black Snake , did not know , for he had stood up more than once in his time to the charge of the wounded tiger , and , curling up his soft trunk to be out of harm 's way , had knocked the springing brute sideways in mid-air with a quick sickle cut of his head , that he had invented all by himself ; had knocked him over , and kneeled upon him with his huge knees till the life went out with a gasp and a howl , and there was only a fluffy striped thing on the ground for Kala Nag to pull by the tail .
14 `` Yes , '' said Big Toomai , his driver , the son of Black Toomai who had taken him to Abyssinia , and grandson of Toomai of the Elephants who had seen him caught , `` there is nothing that the Black Snake fears except me .
15 He has seen three generations of us feed him and groom him , and he will live to see four . ''
16 `` He is afraid of me also , '' said Little Toomai , standing up to his full height of four feet , with only one rag upon him .
17 He was ten years old , the eldest son of Big Toomai , and , according to custom , he would take his father 's place on Kala Nag 's neck when he grew up , and would handle the heavy iron ankus , the elephant goad , that had been worn smooth by his father , and his grandfather , and his great-grandfather .
18 He knew what he was talking of ; for he had been born under Kala Nag 's shadow , had played with the end of his trunk before he could walk , had taken him down to water as soon as he could walk , and Kala Nag would no more have dreamed of disobeying his shrill little orders than he would have dreamed of killing him on that day when Big Toomai carried the little brown baby under Kala Nag 's tusks , and told him to salute his master that was to be .
19 `` Yes , '' said Little Toomai , `` he is afraid of me , '' and he took long strides up to Kala Nag , called him a fat old pig , and made him lift up his feet one after the other .
20 `` Wah ! ''
21 said Little Toomai , `` thou art a big elephant , '' and he wagged his fluffy head , quoting his XXXXX .	father		Snake|advice|custom|elephants|father|feet|howl|hunt|strides|tents

3 PRINCE RING -LRB- 30 -RRB- -LRB- 30 -RRB- From the Icelandic .
4 Once upon a time there was a King and his Queen in their kingdom .
5 They had one daughter , who was called Ingiborg , and one son , whose name was Ring .
6 He was less fond of adventures than men of rank usually were in those days , and was not famous for strength or feats of arms .
7 When he was twelve years old , one fine winter day he rode into the forest along with his men to enjoy himself .
8 They went on a long way , until they caught sight of a hind with a gold ring on its horns .
9 The Prince was eager to catch it , if possible , so they gave chase and rode on without stopping until all the horses began to founder beneath them .
10 At last the Prince 's horse gave way too , and then there came over them a darkness so black that they could no longer see the hind .
11 By this time they were far away from any house , and thought it was high time to be making their way home again , but they found they had got lost now .
12 At first they all kept together , but soon each began to think that he knew the right way best ; so they separated , and all went in different directions .
13 The Prince , too , had got lost like the rest , and wandered on for a time until he came to a little clearing in the forest not far from the sea , where he saw a woman sitting on a chair and a big barrel standing beside her .
14 The Prince went up to her and saluted her politely , and she received him very graciously .
15 He looked down into the barrel then , and saw lying at the bottom an unusually beautiful gold ring , which pleased him so much that he could not take his eyes off it .
16 The woman saw this , and said that he might have it if he would take the trouble to get it ; for which the Prince thanked her , and said it was at least worth trying .
17 So he leaned over into the barrel , which did not seem very deep , and thought he would easily reach the ring ; but the more he stretched down after it the deeper grew the barrel .
18 As he was thus bending down into it the woman suddenly rose up and pushed him in head first , saying that now he could take up his quarters there .
19 Then she fixed the top on the barrel and threw it out into the sea .
20 The Prince thought himself in a bad plight now , as he felt the barrel floating out from the land and tossing about on the waves .
21 How many days he spent thus he could not tell , but at last he felt that the XXXXX was knocking against rocks , at which he was a little cheered , thinking it was probably land and not merely a reef in the sea .	barrel		barrel|chair|chase|forest|home|kingdom|land|sight|son|woman

6 With this Snati leapt at the big one , and was not long in bringing him down .
7 Meanwhile the Prince went against the other with fear and trembling , and by the time Snati came to help him the ox had nearly got him under , but Snati was not slow in helping his master to kill it .
8 Each of them then began to flay their own ox , but Ring was only half through by the time Snati had finished his .

10 The Prince agreed , and laid everything on the Dog except the skin of the smaller ox , which he staggered along with himself .

2 Then she put twenty mattresses on top of the pea , and twenty eider-down quilts on the top of the mattresses .
3 And this was the bed in which the Princess was to sleep .
4 The next morning she was asked how she had slept .
5 ` Oh , very badly ! '
6 said the Princess . '
7 I scarcely closed my eyes all night !
8 I am sure I do n't know what was in the bed .
9 I laid on something so hard that my whole body is black and blue .
10 It is dreadful ! '
11 Now they perceived that she was a true Princess , because she had felt the pea through the twenty mattresses and the twenty eider-down quilts .
12 No one but a true Princess could be so sensitive .
13 So the Prince married her , for now he knew that at last he had got hold of a true Princess .
14 And the pea was put into the Royal Museum , where it is still to be seen if no one has stolen it .
15 Now this is a true story .
16 THE BLUE MOUNTAINS There were once a Scotsman and an Englishman and an Irishman serving in the army together , who took it into their heads to run away on the first opportunity they could get .
17 The chance came and they took it .
18 They went on travelling for two days through a great forest , without food or drink , and without coming across a single house , and every night they had to climb up into the trees through fear of the wild beasts that were in the wood .
19 On the second morning the Scotsman saw from the top of his tree a great castle far away .
20 He said to himself that he would certainly die if he stayed in the forest without anything to eat but the roots of grass , which would not keep him alive very long .
21 As soon , then , as he got down out of the tree he set off towards the XXXXX , without so much as telling his companions that he had seen it at all ; perhaps the hunger and want they had suffered had changed their nature so much that the one did not care what became of the other if he could save himself .	castle		bed|body|bottom|castle|chance|drink|heads|one|opportunity|top

17 No sooner , however , had she swallowed them than she lost human form , and ran into the courtyard in the shape of a donkey .

1 exclaimed his mother in a great passion .
2 ` Leave the house at once , and go and beg your bread among strangers ; ' and as Martin did not dare to contradict her , he called Schurka and Waska and started off with them to the nearest village in search of work .
3 On the way he met a rich peasant , who asked him where he was going . '
4 I want to get work as a day labourer , ' he answered .
5 ` Come along with me , then .
6 But I must tell you I engage my labourers without wages .
7 If you serve me faithfully for a year , I promise you it shall be for your advantage . '
8 So Martin consented , and for a year he worked diligently , and served his master faithfully , not sparing himself in any way .
9 When the day of reckoning had come the peasant led him into a barn , and pointing to two full sacks , said : ` Take whichever of these you choose . '
10 Martin examined the contents of the sacks , and seeing that one was full of silver and the other of sand , he said to himself : ` There must be some trick about this ; I had better take the sand . '
11 And throwing the sack over his shoulders he started out into the world , in search of fresh work .
12 On and on he walked , and at last he reached a great gloomy wood .
13 In the middle of the wood he came upon a meadow , where a fire was burning , and in the midst of the fire , surrounded by flames , was a lovely damsel , more beautiful than anything that Martin had ever seen , and when she saw him she called to him : ` Martin , if you would win happiness , save my life .
14 Extinguish the flames with the sand that you earned in payment of your faithful service . '
15 ` Truly , ' thought Martin to himself , ` it would be more sensible to save a fellow-being 's life with this sand than to drag it about on one 's back , seeing what a weight it is . '
16 And forthwith he lowered the sack from his shoulders and emptied its contents on the flames , and instantly the fire was extinguished ; but at the same moment lo !
17 and behold the lovely damsel turned into a Serpent , and , darting upon him , coiled itself round his neck , and whispered lovingly in his ear : ` Do not be afraid of me , Martin ; I love you , and will go with you through the world .
18 But first you must follow me boldly into my Father 's Kingdom , underneath the earth ; and when we get there , remember this -- he will offer you gold and silver , and dazzling gems , but do not touch them .
19 Ask him , instead , for the ring which he wears on his little finger , for in that ring lies a magic power ; you have only to throw it from one hand to the other , and at once twelve young men will appear , who will do your bidding , no matter how difficult , in a single night . '
20 So they started on their way , and after much wandering they reached a spot where a great rock rose straight up in the middle of the road .
21 Instantly the Serpent uncoiled itself from his XXXXX , and , as it touched the damp earth , it resumed the shape of the lovely damsel .	neck		bidding|ear|finger|matter|men|neck|rock|sack|sand|trick

1 If you read the old books of natural history , you will find they say that when the mongoose fights the snake and happens to get bitten , he runs off and eats some herb that cures him .
2 That is not true .
3 The victory is only a matter of quickness of eye and quickness of foot -- snake 's blow against mongoose 's jump -- and as no eye can follow the motion of a snake 's head when it strikes , this makes things much more wonderful than any magic herb .
4 Rikki-tikki knew he was a young mongoose , and it made him all the more pleased to think that he had managed to escape a blow from behind .
5 It gave him confidence in himself , and when Teddy came running down the path , Rikki-tikki was ready to be petted .
6 But just as Teddy was stooping , something wriggled a little in the dust , and a tiny voice said : `` Be careful .
7 I am Death ! ''
8 It was Karait , the dusty brown snakeling that lies for choice on the dusty earth ; and his bite is as dangerous as the cobra 's .
9 But he is so small that nobody thinks of him , and so he does the more harm to people .
10 Rikki-tikki 's eyes grew red again , and he danced up to Karait with the peculiar rocking , swaying motion that he had inherited from his family .
11 It looks very funny , but it is so perfectly balanced a gait that you can fly off from it at any angle you please , and in dealing with snakes this is an advantage .
12 If Rikki-tikki had only known , he was doing a much more dangerous thing than fighting Nag , for Karait is so small , and can turn so quickly , that unless Rikki bit him close to the back of the head , he would get the return stroke in his eye or his lip .
13 But Rikki did not know .
14 His eyes were all red , and he rocked back and forth , looking for a good place to hold .
15 Karait struck out .
16 Rikki jumped sideways and tried to run in , but the wicked little dusty gray head lashed within a fraction of his shoulder , and he had to jump over the body , and the head followed his heels close .
17 Teddy shouted to the house : `` Oh , look here !
18 Our mongoose is killing a snake . ''
19 And Rikki-tikki heard a scream from Teddy 's mother .
20 His father ran out with a stick , but by the time he came up , Karait had lunged out once too far , and Rikki-tikki had sprung , jumped on the snake 's back , dropped his head far between his forelegs , bitten as high up the back as he could get hold , and rolled away .
21 That XXXXX paralyzed Karait , and Rikki-tikki was just going to eat him up from the tail , after the custom of his family at dinner , when he remembered that a full meal makes a slow mongoose , and if he wanted all his strength and quickness ready , he must keep himself thin .	bite		bite|dust|earth|father|herb|history|house|place|snake|victory

1 `` Lawful heart ! ''
2 said Clemantiny .
3 She set down her pail and came out to the lane on a run .
4 She caught Chester as he sprang from the wagon and gave him a hearty hug .
5 `` I 'm glad clean down to my boot soles to see you back again , '' she said .
6 `` He 's back for good , '' said Miss Salome .
7 `` Chester , you 'd better go in and study up your lessons for tomorrow . ''
8 The Strike at Putney The church at Putney was one that gladdened the hearts of all the ministers in the presbytery whenever they thought about it .
9 It was such a satisfactory church .
10 While other churches here and there were continually giving trouble in one way or another , the Putneyites were never guilty of brewing up internal or presbyterial strife .
11 The Exeter church people were always quarrelling among themselves and carrying their quarrels to the courts of the church .
12 The very name of Exeter gave the members of presbytery the cold creeps .
13 But the Putney church people never quarrelled .
14 Danbridge church was in a chronic state of ministerlessness .
15 No minister ever stayed in Danbridge longer than he could help .
16 The people were too critical , and they were also noted heresy hunters .
17 Good ministers fought shy of Danbridge , and poor ones met with a chill welcome .
18 The harassed presbytery , worn out with `` supplying , '' were disposed to think that the millennium would come if ever the Danbridgians got a minister whom they liked .
19 At Putney they had had the same minister for fifteen years and hoped and expected to have him for fifteen more .
20 They looked with horror-stricken eyes on the Danbridge theological coquetries .
21 Bloom Valley XXXXX was over head and heels in debt and had no visible prospect of ever getting out .	church		church|lane|members|millennium|minister|people|run|state|trouble|wagon

1 said the King .

3 The King replied that he thought it altogether unbecoming to propose such a thing to Ring , seeing that he could not tell him where the things were ; but Red pretended not to hear the King 's excuses , and went on talking about it until the King gave in to him .
4 One day , a month or so before Christmas , the King spoke to Ring , saying that he wished to ask a great favour of him .
5 ` What is that ? '
6 said Ring .
7 ` It is this , ' said the King : ` that you find for me my gold cloak , my gold chess-board , and my bright gold piece , that were stolen from me about a year ago .
8 If you can bring them to me before Christmas I will give you my daughter in marriage . '
9 ` Where am I to look for them , then ? '
10 said Ring .
11 ` That you must find out for yourself , ' said the King : ' I do n't know . '
12 Ring now left the King , and was very silent , for he saw he was in a great difficulty : but , on the other hand , he thought it was excellent to have such a chance of winning the King 's daughter .
13 Snati noticed that his master was at a loss , and said to him that he should not disregard what the King had asked him to do ; but he would have to act upon his advice , otherwise he would get into great difficulties .

1 For she had no idea that the kind-looking old woman leaning on her crutch was in reality a wicked witch , who envied the Queen her good fortune , and was determined to ruin her .
2 And so , in all ignorance , the Queen followed her out into the garden and listened to her smooth , flattering words .
3 Now , in the middle of the garden there was a pond of water , clear as crystal , and the old woman said to the Queen : ` The day is so warm , and the sun 's rays so scorching , that the water in the pond looks very cool and inviting .
4 Would you not like to bathe in it , fair Queen ? '
5 ` No , I think not , ' answered the Queen ; but the next moment she regretted her words , and thought to herself : Why should n't I bathe in that cool , fresh water ?
6 No harm could come of it .
7 And , so saying , she slipped off her robes and stepped into the water .
8 But scarcely had her tender feet touched the cool ripples when she felt a great shove on her shoulders , and the wicked witch had pushed her into the deep water , exclaiming : ` Swim henceforth , White Duck ! '
9 And the witch herself assumed the form of the Queen , and decked herself out in the royal robes , and sat among the Court ladies , awaiting the King 's return .
10 And suddenly the tramp of horses ' hoofs was heard , and the barking of dogs , and the witch hastened forward to meet the royal carriages , and , throwing her arms round the King 's neck , kissed him .
11 And in his great joy the King did not know that the woman he held in his arms was not his own dear wife , but a wicked witch .
12 In the meantime , outside the palace walls , the poor White Duck swam up and down the pond ; and near it laid three eggs , out of which there came one morning two little fluffy ducklings and a little ugly drake .
13 And the White Duck brought the little creatures up , and they paddled after her in the pond , and caught gold-fish , and hopped upon the bank and waddled about , ruffling their feathers and saying ` Quack , quack ' as they strutted about on the green banks of the pond .
14 But their mother used to warn them not to stray too far , telling them that a wicked witch lived in the castle beyond the garden , adding , ` She has ruined me , and she will do her best to ruin you . '
15 But the young ones did not listen to their mother , and , playing about the garden one day , they strayed close up to the castle windows .
16 The witch at once recognised them by their smell , and ground her teeth with anger ; but she hid her feelings , and , pretending to be very kind she called them to her and joked with them , and led them into a beautiful room , where she gave them food to eat , and showed them a soft cushion on which they might sleep .
17 Then she left them and went down into the palace kitchens , where she told the servants to sharpen the knives , and to make a great fire ready , and hang a large kettleful of water over it .
18 In the meantime the two little ducklings had fallen asleep , and the little drake lay between them , covered up by their wings , to be kept warm under their feathers .
19 But the little drake could not go to sleep , and as he lay there wide awake in the night he heard the witch come to the door and say : ` Little ones , are you asleep ? '
20 And the little drake answered for the other two : ` We can not sleep , we wake and weep , Sharp is the knife , to take our life ; The fire is hot , now boils the pot , And so we wake , and lie and quake . '
21 ` They are not asleep yet , ' muttered the XXXXX to herself ; and she walked up and down in the passage , and then came back to the door , and said : ` Little ones , are you asleep ? '	witch		castle|drake|ignorance|joy|knife|lie|mother|water|witch|woman

1 Lagree was as much surprised as displeased at the happy result of this expedition , and Fairer-than-a Fairy waited anxiously for an opportunity of meeting Prince Rainbow and telling him her adventures .
2 She found , however , that he had already been told all about them by a Fairy who protected him , and to whom he was related .
3 The dread of fresh dangers to his beloved Princess made him devise some more convenient way of meeting than by the garden fountain , and Fairer-than-a-Fairy carried out his plan daily with entire success .
4 Every morning she placed a large basin full of water on her window-sill , and as soon as the sun 's rays fell on the water the Rainbow appeared as clearly as it had ever done in the fountain .
5 By this means they were able to meet without losing sight of the fire or of the two bottles in which the old Fairy kept her eye and her tooth at night , and for some time the lovers enjoyed every hour of sunshine together .
6 One day Prince Rainbow appeared in the depths of woe .
7 He had just heard that he was to be banished from this lovely spot , but he had no idea where he was to go .
8 The poor young couple were in despair , and only parted with the last ray of sunshine , and in hopes of meeting next morning .
9 Alas !
10 next day was dark and gloomy , and it was only late in the afternoon that the sun broke through the clouds for a few minutes .
11 Fairer-than-a-Fairy eagerly ran to the window , but in her haste she upset the basin , and spilt all the water with which she had carefully filled it overnight .
12 No other water was at hand except that in the two bottles .
13 It was the only chance of seeing her lover before they were separated , and she did not hesitate to break the bottle and pour their contents into the basin , when the Rainbow appeared at once .
14 Their farewells were full of tenderness ; the Prince made the most ardent and sincere protestations , and promised to neglect nothing which might help to deliver his dear Fairer-than-a-Fairy from her captivity , and implored her to consent to their marriage as soon as they should both be free .
15 The Princess , on her side , vowed to have no other husband , and declared herself willing to brave death itself in order to rejoin him .
16 They were not allowed much time for their adieus ; the Rainbow vanished , and the Princess , resolved to run all risks , started off at once , taking nothing with her but her dog , her cat , a sprig of myrtle , and the stone which the wife of Locrinos gave her .

1 ` The Queen will hear you !
2 You see , she came rather late , and the Queen said -- ' ` Get to your places ! '
3 shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder , and people began running about in all directions , tumbling up against each other ; however , they got settled down in a minute or two , and the game began .
4 Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life ; it was all ridges and furrows ; the balls were live hedgehogs , the mallets live flamingoes , and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet , to make the arches .
5 The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo : she succeeded in getting its body tucked away , comfortably enough , under her arm , with its legs hanging down , but generally , just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out , and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head , it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face , with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing : and when she had got its head down , and was going to begin again , it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself , and was in the act of crawling away : besides all this , there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to , and , as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground , Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed .
6 The players all played at once without waiting for turns , quarrelling all the while , and fighting for the hedgehogs ; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion , and went stamping about , and shouting ` Off with his head ! '
7 or ` Off with her head ! '
8 about once in a minute .
9 Alice began to feel very uneasy : to be sure , she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen , but she knew that it might happen any minute , ` and then , ' thought she , ` what would become of me ?
10 They 're dreadfully fond of beheading people here ; the great wonder is , that there 's any one left alive ! '
11 She was looking about for some way of escape , and wondering whether she could get away without being seen , when she noticed a curious appearance in the air : it puzzled her very much at first , but , after watching it a minute or two , she made it out to be a grin , and she said to herself ` It 's the Cheshire Cat : now I shall have somebody to talk to . 2 THE WITCH AND HER SERVANTS -LRB- 22 -RRB- -LRB- 22 -RRB- From the Russian .
3 Kletke .
4 Long time ago there lived a King who had three sons ; the eldest was called Szabo , the second Warza , and the youngest Iwanich .
5 One beautiful spring morning the King was walking through his gardens with these three sons , gazing with admiration at the various fruit-trees , some of which were a mass of blossom , whilst others were bowed to the ground laden with rich fruit .
6 During their wanderings they came unperceived on a piece of waste land where three splendid trees grew .
7 The King looked on them for a moment , and then , shaking his head sadly , he passed on in silence .
8 The sons , who could not understand why he did this , asked him the reason of his dejection , and the King told them as follows : ` These three trees , which I can not see without sorrow , were planted by me on this spot when I was a youth of twenty .
9 A celebrated magician , who had given the seed to my father , promised him that they would grow into the three finest trees the world had ever seen .
10 My father did not live to see his words come true ; but on his death-bed he bade me transplant them here , and to look after them with the greatest care , which I accordingly did .
11 At last , after the lapse of five long years , I noticed some blossoms on the branches , and a few days later the most exquisite fruit my eyes had ever seen . '
12 I gave my head-gardener the strictest orders to watch the trees carefully , for the magician had warned my father that if one unripe fruit were plucked from the tree , all the rest would become rotten at once .
13 When it was quite ripe the fruit would become a golden yellow .
14 ` Every day I gazed on the lovely fruit , which became gradually more and more tempting-looking , and it was all I could do not to break the magician 's commands .
15 ` One night I dreamt that the fruit was perfectly ripe ; I ate some of it , and it was more delicious than anything I had ever tasted in real life .
16 As soon as I awoke I sent for the gardener and asked him if the fruit on the three trees had not ripened in the night to perfection .
17 ` But instead of replying , the gardener threw himself at my feet and swore that he was innocent .
18 He said that he had watched by the trees all night , but in spite of it , and as if by magic , the beautiful trees had been robbed of all their fruit .
19 ` Grieved as I was over the theft , I did not punish the gardener , of whose fidelity I was well assured , but I determined to pluck off all the fruit in the following year before it was ripe , as I had not much belief in the magician 's warning . '
20 I carried out my intention , and had all the fruit picked off the tree , but when I tasted one of the apples it was bitter and unpleasant , and the next morning the rest of the fruit had all rotted away .
21 ` After this I had the beautiful fruit of these trees carefully guarded by my most faithful servants ; but every year , on this very night , the XXXXX was plucked and stolen by an invisible hand , and next morning not a single apple remained on the trees .	fruit		admiration|days|end|eyes|fruit|gardens|head|wanderings|witch|words

1 Sometimes a mother would push her cub far out into the moonlight to be sure that he had not been overlooked .

3 Look well , O Wolves ! ''
4 And the anxious mothers would take up the call : `` Look -- look well , O Wolves ! ''
5 At last -- and Mother Wolf 's neck bristles lifted as the time came -- Father Wolf pushed `` Mowgli the Frog , '' as they called him , into the center , where he sat laughing and playing with some pebbles that glistened in the moonlight .
6 Akela never raised his head from his paws , but went on with the monotonous cry : `` Look well ! ''

8 Give him to me .
9 What have the Free People to do with a man 's cub ? ''
10 Akela never even twitched his ears .
11 All he said was : `` Look well , O Wolves !
12 What have the Free People to do with the orders of any save the Free People ?
13 Look well ! ''
14 There was a chorus of deep growls , and a young wolf in his fourth year flung back Shere Khan 's question to Akela : `` What have the Free People to do with a man 's cub ? ''
15 Now , the Law of the Jungle lays down that if there is any dispute as to the right of a cub to be accepted by the Pack , he must be spoken for by at least two members of the Pack who are not his father and mother .
16 `` Who speaks for this cub ? ''
17 said Akela .

5 THE DRAGON AND HIS GRANDMOTHER There was once a great war , and the King had a great many soldiers , but he gave them so little pay that they could not live upon it .
6 Then three of them took counsel together and determined to desert .
7 One of them said to the others , ` If we are caught , we shall be hanged on the gallows ; how shall we set about it ? '
8 The other said , ` Do you see that large cornfield there ?
9 If we were to hide ourselves in that , no one could find us .
10 The army can not come into it , and to-morrow it is to march on . '
11 They crept into the corn , but the army did not march on , but remained encamped close around them .
12 They sat for two days and two nights in the corn , and grew so hungry that they nearly died ; but if they were to venture out , it was certain death .
13 They said at last , ` What use was it our deserting ?
14 We must perish here miserably . '
15 Whilst they were speaking a fiery dragon came flying through the air .
16 It hovered near them , and asked why they were hidden there .
17 They answered , ` We are three soldiers , and have deserted because our pay was so small .
18 Now if we remain here we shall die of hunger , and if we move out we shall be strung up on the gallows . '
19 ` If you will serve me for seven years , ' said the dragon , I will lead you through the midst of the army so that no one shall catch you . '
20 ` We have no choice , and must take your offer , ' said they .
21 Then the XXXXX seized them in his claws , took them through the air over the army , and set them down on the earth a long way from it .	dragon		corn|counsel|death|dragon|gallows|man|midst|pay|story|wealth

1 In this way the Dragon was able to feed upon both men and beasts without the least trouble to itself , as it needed not to move from the spot where it was lying .
2 All the neighbouring kings had offered rich rewards to anyone who should be able to destroy the monster , either by force or enchantment , and many had tried their luck , but all had miserably failed .
3 Once a great forest in which the Dragon lay had been set on fire ; the forest was burnt down , but the fire did not do the monster the least harm .
4 However , there was a tradition amongst the wise men of the country that the Dragon might be overcome by one who possessed King Solomon 's signet-ring , upon which a secret writing was engraved .
5 This inscription would enable anyone who was wise enough to interpret it to find out how the Dragon could be destroyed .
6 Only no one knew where the ring was hidden , nor was there any sorcerer or learned man to be found who would be able to explain the inscription .
7 At last a young man , with a good heart and plenty of courage , set out to search for the ring .
8 He took his way towards the sunrising , because he knew that all the wisdom of old time comes from the East .
9 After some years he met with a famous Eastern magician , and asked for his advice in the matter .
10 The magician answered : ` Mortal men have but little wisdom , and can give you no help , but the birds of the air would be better guides to you if you could learn their language .
11 I can help you to understand it if you will stay with me a few days . '
12 The youth thankfully accepted the magician 's offer , and said , ' I can not now offer you any reward for your kindness , but should my undertaking succeed your trouble shall be richly repaid . '
13 Then the magician brewed a powerful potion out of nine sorts of herbs which he had gathered himself all alone by moonlight , and he gave the youth nine spoonfuls of it daily for three days , which made him able to understand the language of birds .
14 At parting the magician said to him .
15 ` If you ever find Solomon 's ring and get possession of it , then come back to me , that I may explain the inscription on the ring to you , for there is no one else in the world who can do this . '
16 From that time the youth never felt lonely as he walked along ; he always had company , because he understood the language of birds ; and in this way he learned many things which mere human knowledge could never have taught him .
17 But time went on , and he heard nothing about the ring .
18 It happened one evening , when he was hot and tired with walking , and had sat down under a tree in a forest to eat his supper , that he saw two gaily-plumaged birds , that were strange to him , sitting at the top of the tree talking to one another about him .
19 The first bird said : ' I know that wandering fool under the tree there , who has come so far without finding what he seeks .
20 He is trying to find King Solomon 's lost ring . '

1 But no one could think of any advice to give him , beyond taking care that the child never went near the mill-pond .
2 So the boy throve and grew big , and in the meantime all prospered with the miller , and in a few years he was richer than he had ever been before .
3 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
4 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
5 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
6 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
7 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
8 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
9 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
10 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
11 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
12 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
13 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
14 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
15 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
16 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
17 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
18 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
19 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
20 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
21 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's XXXXX was not a bit better off than she had been before .	wife		dream|hair|husband|round|service|shot|skin|sorrow|wife|word

1 For a minute it seemed as though he were going to draw his sword and slash his way out through the English men and women in the carriages at the back .
2 Then the advance stopped dead , the ground stood still , the whole line saluted , and thirty bands began to play all together .
3 That was the end of the review , and the regiments went off to their camps in the rain , and an infantry band struck up with -- The animals went in two by two , Hurrah !
4 The animals went in two by two , The elephant and the battery mul ' , and they all got into the Ark For to get out of the rain !
5 Then I heard an old grizzled , long-haired Central Asian chief , who had come down with the Amir , asking questions of a native officer .
6 `` Now , '' said he , `` in what manner was this wonderful thing done ? ''
7 And the officer answered , `` An order was given , and they obeyed . ''
8 `` But are the beasts as wise as the men ? ''
9 said the chief .
10 `` They obey , as the men do .
11 Mule , horse , elephant , or bullock , he obeys his driver , and the driver his sergeant , and the sergeant his lieutenant , and the lieutenant his captain , and the captain his major , and the major his colonel , and the colonel his brigadier commanding three regiments , and the brigadier the general , who obeys the Viceroy , who is the servant of the Empress .
12 Thus it is done . ''
13 `` Would it were so in Afghanistan ! ''
14 said the chief , `` for there we obey only our own wills . ''
15 `` And for that reason , '' said the native officer , twirling his mustache , `` your Amir whom you do not obey must come here and take orders from our Viceroy . ''
16 Parade Song of the Camp Animals ELEPHANTS OF THE GUN TEAMS We lent to Alexander the strength of Hercules , The wisdom of our foreheads , the cunning of our knees ; We bowed our necks to service : they ne'er were loosed again , -- Make way there -- way for the ten-foot teams Of the Forty-Pounder train !
17 GUN BULLOCKS Those heroes in their harnesses avoid a cannon-ball , And what they know of powder upsets them one and all ; Then we come into action and tug the guns again -- Make way there -- way for the twenty yoke Of the Forty-Pounder train !
18 CAVALRY HORSES By the brand on my shoulder , the finest of tunes Is played by the Lancers , Hussars , and Dragoons , And it 's sweeter than `` Stables '' or `` Water '' to me -- The Cavalry Canter of `` Bonnie Dundee '' !

4 `` This is all she says about the chest .
5 ` If it were not for one thing that is in it , I would ask you to open the chest and burn all its contents .
6 But I can not bear that anyone but myself should see or touch that one thing .
7 So please leave the chest as it is , dear Aunt .
8 It is no matter if the moths do get in . '
9 That is all , '' continued Mrs. DeLisle , `` and I must confess that I am disappointed .
10 I have always had an almost childish curiosity about that old chest , but I seem fated not to have it gratified .
11 That ` one thing ' must be her wedding dress .
12 I have always thought that she locked it away there . ''
13 `` Her answer is just what I expected of her , '' said Grandmother impatiently .
14 `` Evidently the years have not made her more sensible .
15 Well , I wash my hands of her belongings , moths or no moths . ''

1 The ` Good Queen ' on her side watched carefully over her godson .
2 She was obliged to do so from a distance , her own country being a remote one , but she was well informed of all that went on and knew all about the Queen 's wicked designs .
3 She therefore sent the Prince a large and splendid ruby , with injunctions to wear it night and day as it would protect him from all attacks , but added that the talisman only retained its power as long as the Prince remained within his father 's dominions .
4 The Wicked Queen knowing this made every attempt to get the Prince out of the country , but her efforts failed , till one day accident did what she was unable to accomplish .
5 The King had an only sister who was deeply attached to him , and who was married to the sovereign of a distant country .
6 She had always kept up a close correspondence with her brother , and the accounts she heard of Prince Alphege made her long to become acquainted with so charming a nephew .
7 She entreated the King to allow the Prince to visit her , and after some hesitation which was overruled by his wife , he finally consented .
8 Prince Alphege was at this time fourteen years old , and the handsomest and most engaging youth imaginable .
9 In his infancy he had been placed in the charge of one of the great ladies of the Court , who , according to the prevailing custom , acted first as his head nurse and then as his governess .
10 When he outgrew her care her husband was appointed as his tutor and governor , so that he had never been separated from this excellent couple , who loved him as tenderly as they did their only daughter Zayda , and were warmly loved by him in return .
11 When the Prince set forth on his travels it was but natural that this devoted couple should accompany him , and accordingly he started with them and attended by a numerous retinue .
12 For some time he travelled through his father 's dominions and all went well ; but soon after passing the frontier they had to cross a desert plain under a burning sun .
13 They were glad to take shelter under a group of trees near , and here the Prince complained of burning thirst .
14 Luckily a tiny stream ran close by and some water was soon procured , but no sooner had he tasted it than he sprang from his carriage and disappeared in a moment .
15 In vain did his anxious followers seek for him , he was nowhere to be found .
16 As they were hunting and shouting through the trees a black monkey suddenly appeared on a point of rock and said : ` Poor sorrowing people , you are seeking your Prince in vain .
17 Return to your own country and know that he will not be restored to you till you have for some time failed to recognise him . '
18 With these words he vanished , leaving the courtiers sadly perplexed ; but as all their efforts to find the Prince were useless they had no choice but to go home , bringing with them the sad news , which so greatly distressed the King that he fell ill and died not long after .
19 The Queen , whose ambition was boundless , was delighted to see the crown on her son 's head and to have the power in her own hands .
20 Her hard rule made her very unpopular , and it was commonly believed that she had made away with Prince Alphege .
21 Indeed , had the King her XXXXX not been deservedly beloved a revolution would certainly have arisen .	son		Return|ambition|distance|followers|frontier|home|ladies|shelter|son|trees

1 Alice thought she might as well go back , and see how the game was going on , as she heard the Queen 's voice in the distance , screaming with passion .
2 She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns , and she did not like the look of things at all , as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not .
3 So she went in search of her hedgehog .
4 The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog , which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other : the only difficulty was , that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden , where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree .
5 By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back , the fight was over , and both the hedgehogs were out of sight : ` but it does n't matter much , ' thought Alice , ` as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground . '
6 So she tucked it away under her arm , that it might not escape again , and went back for a little more conversation with her friend .
7 When she got back to the Cheshire Cat , she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it : there was a dispute going on between the executioner , the King , and the Queen , who were all talking at once , while all the rest were quite silent , and looked very uncomfortable .
8 The moment Alice appeared , she was appealed to by all three to settle the question , and they repeated their arguments to her , though , as they all spoke at once , she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said .
9 The executioner 's argument was , that you could n't cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from : that he had never had to do such a thing before , and he was n't going to begin at HIS time of life .
10 The King 's argument was , that anything that had a head could be beheaded , and that you were n't to talk nonsense .
11 The Queen 's argument was , that if something was n't done about it in less than no time she 'd have everybody executed , all round .
12 -LRB- It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious . -RRB-
13 Alice could think of nothing else to say but ` It belongs to the Duchess : you 'd better ask HER about it . '
14 ` She 's in prison , ' the Queen said to the executioner : ` fetch her here . '
15 And the executioner went off like an arrow .
16 The Cat 's head began fading away the moment he was gone , and , by the time he had come back with the Duchess , it had entirely disappeared ; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it , while the rest of the party went back to the game .

1 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
2 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the bank , and soon the head of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the water .
3 Then he gazed sadly at his wife and stretched out his arms towards her .
4 But another rushing wave arose and dragged him under once more .
5 The hunter 's wife , who had stood on the bank full of joy and hope , sank into despair when she saw her husband snatched away again before her eyes .
6 But for her comfort she dreamt the same dream a third time , and betook herself once more to the old witch 's hut in the flowery meadow .
7 This time the old woman told her to go the next full moon to the mill-pond , and to spin there with a golden spinning-wheel , and then to leave the spinning-wheel on the bank .
8 The hunter 's wife did as she was advised , and the first night the moon was full she sat and spun with a golden spinning-wheel , and then left the wheel on the bank .
9 In a few minutes a rushing sound was heard in the waters , and a wave swept the spinning-wheel from the bank .
10 Immediately the head of the hunter rose up from the pond , getting higher and higher each moment , till at length he stepped on to the bank and fell on his wife 's neck .
11 But the waters of the pond rose up suddenly , overflowed the bank where the couple stood , and dragged them under the flood .
12 In her despair the young wife called on the old witch to help her , and in a moment the hunter was turned into a frog and his wife into a toad .
13 But they were not able to remain together , for the water tore them apart , and when the flood was over they both resumed their own shapes again , but the hunter and the hunter 's wife found themselves each in a strange country , and neither knew what had become of the other .
14 The hunter determined to become a shepherd , and his wife too became a shepherdess .
15 So they herded their sheep for many years in solitude and sadness .
16 Now it happened once that the shepherd came to the country where the shepherdess lived .
17 The neighbourhood pleased him , and he saw that the pasture was rich and suitable for his flocks .
18 So he brought his sheep there , and herded them as before .
19 The shepherd and shepherdess became great friends , but they did not recognise each other in the least .
20 But one evening when the moon was full they sat together watching their flocks , and the shepherd played upon his flute .
21 Then the shepherdess thought of that evening when she had sat at the full XXXXX by the mill-pond and had played on the golden flute ; the recollection was too much for her , and she burst into tears .	moon		comfort|friends|frog|hut|length|moon|sadness|sheep|solitude|wife

1 When he at length lost power to move his tail , the youth with the help of the ring took up a stone which twenty ordinary men could not have moved , and beat the Dragon so hard about the head with it that very soon the monster lay lifeless before him .
2 You can fancy how great was the rejoicing when the news was spread abroad that the terrible monster was dead .
3 His conqueror was received into the city with as much pomp as if he had been the mightiest of kings .
4 The old King did not need to urge his daughter to marry the slayer of the Dragon ; he found her already willing to bestow her hand upon this hero , who had done all alone what whole armies had tried in vain to do .
5 In a few days a magnificent wedding was celebrated , at which the rejoicings lasted four whole weeks , for all the neighbouring kings had met together to thank the man who had freed the world from their common enemy .
6 But everyone forgot amid the general joy that they ought to have buried the Dragon 's monstrous body , for it began now to have such a bad smell that no one could live in the neighbourhood , and before long the whole air was poisoned , and a pestilence broke out which destroyed many hundreds of people .
7 In this distress , the King 's son-in-law resolved to seek help once more from the Eastern magician , to whom he at once travelled through the air like a bird by the help of the ring .
8 But there is a proverb which says that ill-gotten gains never prosper , and the Prince found that the stolen ring brought him ill-luck after all .
9 The Witch-maiden had never rested night nor day until she had found out where the ring was .
10 As soon as she had discovered by means of magical arts that the Prince in the form of a bird was on his way to the Eastern magician , she changed herself into an eagle and watched in the air until the bird she was waiting for came in sight , for she knew him at once by the ring which was hung round his neck by a ribbon .
11 Then the eagle pounced upon the bird , and the moment she seized him in her talons she tore the ring from his neck before the man in bird 's shape had time to prevent her .
12 Then the eagle flew down to the earth with her prey , and the two stood face to face once more in human form .
13 ` Now , villain , you are in my power ! '

1 But he is blind .

3 But Thumbelina did not trouble her head about him , for he was only a mole .
4 He came and paid them a visit in his black-velvet coat .
5 ` He is so rich and so accomplished , ' the field-mouse told her .
6 ` His house is twenty times larger than mine ; he possesses great knowledge , but he can not bear the sun and the beautiful flowers , and speaks slightingly of them , for he has never seen them . '
7 Thumbelina had to sing to him , so she sang ` Lady-bird , lady-bird , fly away home ! '
8 and other songs so prettily that the mole fell in love with her ; but he did not say anything , he was a very cautious man .
9 A short time before he had dug a long passage through the ground from his own house to that of his neighbour ; in this he gave the field-mouse and Thumbelina permission to walk as often as they liked .
10 But he begged them not to be afraid of the dead bird that lay in the passage : it was a real bird with beak and feathers , and must have died a little time ago , and now laid buried just where he had made his tunnel .
11 The mole took a piece of rotten wood in his mouth , for that glows like fire in the dark , and went in front , lighting them through the long dark passage .
12 When they came to the place where the dead bird lay , the mole put his broad nose against the ceiling and pushed a hole through , so that the daylight could shine down .
13 In the middle of the path lay a dead swallow , his pretty wings pressed close to his sides , his claws and head drawn under his feathers ; the poor bird had evidently died of cold .
14 Thumbelina was very sorry , for she was very fond of all little birds ; they had sung and twittered so beautifully to her all through the summer .
15 But the mole kicked him with his bandy legs and said : ` Now he ca n't sing any more !
16 It must be very miserable to be a little bird !
17 I 'm thankful that none of my little children are ; birds always starve in winter . '
18 ` Yes , you speak like a sensible man , ' said the field-mouse .
19 ` What has a bird , in spite of all his singing , in the winter-time ?
20 He must starve and freeze , and that must be very pleasant for him , I must say ! '

1 She was a harsh woman , with a violent temper , and she had scolded and worried the boy all his short life .
2 Upton people said it was a shame , but nobody felt called upon to interfere .
3 Mrs. Elwell was not a person one would care to make an enemy of .
4 She eyed Chester sourly when he went in , expecting some request to be allowed to go with Henry , and prepared to refuse it sharply .
5 `` Aunt Harriet , '' said Chester suddenly , `` can I go to school this year ?
6 It begins tomorrow . ''
7 `` No , '' said Mrs. Elwell , when she had recovered from her surprise at this unexpected question .
8 `` You 've had schoolin ' in plenty -- more 'n I ever had , and all you 're goin ' to get ! ''
9 `` But , Aunt Harriet , '' persisted Chester , his face flushed with earnestness , `` I 'm nearly thirteen , and I can barely read and write a little .
10 The other boys are ever so far ahead of me .
11 I do n't know anything . ''
12 `` You know enough to be disrespectful ! ''
13 exclaimed Mrs. Elwell .
14 `` I suppose you want to go to school to idle away your time , as you do at home -- lazy good-for-nothing that you are ! ''
15 Chester thought of the drudgery that had been his portion all his life .
16 He resented being called lazy when he was willing enough to work , but he made one more appeal .
17 `` If you 'll let me go to school this year , I 'll work twice as hard out of school to make up for it -- indeed , I will .
18 Do let me go , Aunt Harriet .
19 I have n't been to school a day for over a year . ''

1 The King replied that it was only a short time since he had come there .
2 Red then asked him to send them both to cut down wood next morning , and see which of them could do most work .
3 Snati-Snati heard this and told it to Ring , advising him to ask the King for two axes , so that he might have one in reserve if the first one got broken .
4 Next morning the King asked Ring and Red to go and cut down trees for him , and both agreed .
5 Ring got the two axes , and each went his own way ; but when the Prince had got out into the wood Snati took one of the axes and began to hew along with him .
6 In the evening the King came to look over their day 's work , as Red had proposed , and found that Ring 's wood-heap was more than twice as big . '
7 I suspected , ' said the King , ` that Ring was not quite useless ; never have I seen such a day 's work . '
8 Ring was now in far greater esteem with the King than before , and Red was all the more discontented .
9 One day he came to the King and said , ` If Ring is such a mighty man , I think you might ask him to kill the wild oxen in the wood here , and flay them the same day , and bring you the horns and the hides in the evening . '
10 ` Do n't you think that a desperate errand ? '
11 said the King , ` seeing they are so dangerous , and no one has ever yet ventured to go against them ? '
12 Red answered that he had only one life to lose , and it would be interesting to see how brave he was ; besides , the King would have good reason to ennoble him if he overcame them .
13 The King at last allowed himself , though rather unwillingly , to be won over by Red 's persistency , and one day asked Ring to go and kill the oxen that were in the wood for him , and bring their horns and hides to him in the evening .
14 Not knowing how dangerous the oxen were , Ring was quite ready , and went off at once , to the great delight of Red , who was now sure of his death .
15 As soon as Ring came in sight of the oxen they came bellowing to meet him ; one of them was tremendously big , the other rather less .
16 Ring grew terribly afraid .
17 ` How do you like them ? '
18 asked Snati .
19 ` Not well at all , ' said the Prince .
20 ` We can do nothing else , ' said Snati , ` than attack them , if it is to go well ; you will go against the little one , and I shall take the other . '
21 With this Snati leapt at the big XXXXX , and was not long in bringing him down .	one		esteem|horns|life|man|morning|nothing|one|oxen|time|trees

1 But after a few hours , by the magic arts of the old witch , he was overpowered by sleep , and the mare and foal escaped and did as they had been told to do .
2 The Prince did not awake till late in the evening ; and when he did , he found , to his horror , that the horses had disappeared .
3 Filled with despair , he cursed the moment when he had entered the service of the cruel witch , and already he saw his head sticking up on the sharp spike beside the others .
4 Then he suddenly remembered the fish 's scale , which , with the eagle 's feather and the fox 's hairs , he always carried about with him .
5 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the river he threw it in .
6 In a minute the grateful fish swam towards the bank on which Iwanich was standing , and said : ` What do you command , my friend and benefactor ? '
7 The Prince replied : ' I had to look after a mare and foal , and they have run away from me and have hidden themselves in the river ; if you wish to save my life drive them back to the land . '
8 ` Wait a moment , ' answered the fish , ` and I and my friends will soon drive them out of the water . '
9 With these words the creature disappeared into the depths of the stream .
10 Almost immediately a rushing hissing sound was heard in the waters , the waves dashed against the banks , the foam was tossed into the air , and the two horses leapt suddenly on to the dry land , trembling and shaking with fear .
11 Iwanich sprang at once on to the mare 's back , seized the foal by its bridle , and hastened home in the highest spirits .
12 When the witch saw the Prince bringing the horses home she could hardly conceal her wrath , and as soon as she had placed Iwanich 's supper before him she stole away again to the stables .
13 The Prince followed her , and heard her scolding the beasts harshly for not having hidden themselves better .
14 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .
15 If they did not do as she told them she would beat them till they bled .
16 The next morning , after Iwanich had led his horses to the fields , he fell once more into a magic sleep .
17 The horses at once ran away and hid themselves in the clouds , which hung down from the mountains in soft billowy masses .
18 When the Prince awoke and found that both the mare and the foal had disappeared , he bethought him at once of the eagle , and taking the feather out of his pocket he blew it into the air .
19 In a moment the bird swooped down beside him and asked : ` What do you wish me to do ? '

1 ` Tell me , then , ' said the Irishman , ` what is the spell that has been laid on you , and how you can be freed from it . '
2 ` There is a little room there , ' said the Princess , ` and if I could get a man to stay in it from ten o'clock till midnight for three nights on end I should be freed from the spell . ' '
3 I am the man for you , then , ' said he ; ' I will take on hand to do it . '
4 Thereupon she brought him a pipe and tobacco , and he went into the room ; but before long he heard a hammering and knocking on the outside of the door , and was told to open it . '
5 I wo n't , ' he said .
6 The next moment the door came flying in , and those outside along with it .
7 They knocked him down , and kicked him , and knelt on his body till it came to midnight ; but as soon as the cock crew they all disappeared .
8 The Irishman was little more than alive by this time .
9 As soon as daylight appeared the Princess came , and found him lying full length on the floor , unable to speak a word .
10 She took a bottle , rubbed him from head to foot with something from it , and thereupon he was as sound as ever ; but after what he had got that night he was very unwilling to try it a second time .
11 The Princess , however , entreated him to stay , saying that the next night would not be so bad , and in the end he gave in and stayed .
12 When it was getting near midnight he heard them ordering him to open the door , and there were three of them for every one that there had been the previous evening .
13 He did not make the slightest movement to go out to them or to open the door , but before long they broke it up , and were in on top of him .
14 They laid hold of him , and kept throwing him between them up to the ceiling , or jumping above him , until the cock crew , when they all disappeared .
15 When day came the Princess went to the room to see if he was still alive , and taking the bottle put it to his nostrils , which soon brought him to himself .
16 The first thing he said then was that he was a fool to go on getting himself killed for anyone he ever saw , and was determined to be off and stay there no longer , When the Princess learned his intention she entreated him to stay , reminding him that another night would free her from the spell .
17 ` Besides , ' she said , ` if there is a single spark of life in you when the day comes , the stuff that is in this bottle will make you as sound as ever you were . '
18 With all this the Irishman decided to stay ; but that night there were three at him for every one that was there the two nights before , and it looked very unlikely that he would be alive in the morning after all that he got .
19 When morning dawned , and the Princess came to see if he was still alive , she found him lying on the floor as if dead .
20 She tried to see if there was breath in him , but could not quite make it out .

1 He realized that , come what might , he would always have a good friend in Miss Salome -- aye , and in Clemantiny , too .
2 Chester never knew it , but after he had fallen asleep , with the tears still glistening on his brown cheeks , Clemantiny tiptoed silently in with a candle in her hand and bent over him with an expression of almost maternal tenderness on her face .
3 It was late and an aroma of boiling sugar hung about her .
4 She had sat up long after Miss Salome was abed , to boil another saucepan of taffy for Chester to eat on his journey .
5 `` Poor , dear child ! ''
6 she said , softly touching one of his crisp curls .
7 `` It 's a shame in Salome to insist on his going back .
8 She does n't know what she 's sending him to , or she would n't .
9 He did n't say much against his aunt , and Salome thinks she was only just a little bit cranky .
10 But I could guess . ''
11 Early in the morning Miss Salome and Chester started .
12 They were to drive to Montrose , leave their team there and take the boat for Belltown .
13 Chester bade farewell to the porch chamber and the long , white kitchen and the friendly barns with a full heart .

5 Sea Catch sunk his head proudly between his fat shoulders and pretended to go to sleep for a few minutes , but all the time he was keeping a sharp lookout for a fight .
6 Now that all the seals and their wives were on the land , you could hear their clamor miles out to sea above the loudest gales .
7 At the lowest counting there were over a million seals on the beach -- old seals , mother seals , tiny babies , and holluschickie , fighting , scuffling , bleating , crawling , and playing together -- going down to the sea and coming up from it in gangs and regiments , lying over every foot of ground as far as the eye could reach , and skirmishing about in brigades through the fog .
8 It is nearly always foggy at Novastoshnah , except when the sun comes out and makes everything look all pearly and rainbow-colored for a little while .
9 Kotick , Matkah 's baby , was born in the middle of that confusion , and he was all head and shoulders , with pale , watery blue eyes , as tiny seals must be , but there was something about his coat that made his mother look at him very closely .
10 `` Sea Catch , '' she said , at last , `` our baby 's going to be white ! ''
11 `` Empty clam-shells and dry seaweed ! ''
12 snorted Sea Catch .
13 `` There never has been such a thing in the world as a white seal . ''
14 `` I ca n't help that , '' said Matkah ; `` there 's going to be now . ''
15 And she sang the low , crooning seal song that all the mother seals sing to their babies : You must n't swim till you 're six weeks old , Or your head will be sunk by your heels ; And summer gales and Killer Whales Are bad for baby seals .
16 Are bad for baby seals , dear rat , As bad as bad can be ; But splash and grow strong , And you ca n't be wrong .
17 Child of the Open Sea !
18 Of course the little fellow did not understand the words at first .

20 Matkah used to go to sea to get things to eat , and the baby was fed only once in two days , but then he ate all he could and throve upon it .

1 The architecture was imposing , and in the interior the rooms were handsome and furnished in the best possible taste .
2 The Princess , who expected to be quite alone , was pleased at finding herself surrounded by a number of pretty girls , all anxious to wait on her , whilst a brilliantly-coloured parrot said the most agreeable things in the world .
3 On arriving at this palace the King had resumed his own form , and though no longer young , he might well have pleased any other than this Princess , who had been so prejudiced against him by his violence that she could only regard him with feelings of hatred , which she was at no pains to conceal .
4 The King hoped , however , that time might not only soften her anger , but accustom her to his sight .
5 He took the precaution of surrounding the palace with a dense cloud , and then hastened to his Court , where his prolonged absence was causing much anxiety .
6 The Prince and all the courtiers were delighted to see their beloved King again , but they had to submit themselves to more frequent absences than ever on his part .
7 He made business a pretext for shutting himself up in his study , but it was really in order to spend the time with the Princess , who remained inflexible .
8 Not being able to imagine what could be the cause of so much obstinacy the King began to fear , lest , in spite of all his precautions , she might have heard of the charms of the Prince his son , whose goodness , youth and beauty , made him adored at Court .
9 This idea made him horribly uneasy , and he resolved to remove the cause of his fears by sending the Prince on his travels escorted by a magnificent retinue .
10 The Prince , after visiting several Courts , arrived at the one where the lost Princess was still deeply mourned .
11 The King and Queen received him most graciously , and some festivities were revived to do him honour .
12 One day when the Prince was visiting the Queen in her own apartments he was much struck by a most beautiful portrait .
13 He eagerly inquired whose it was , and the Queen , with many tears , told him it was all that was left her of her beloved daughter , who had suddenly been carried off , she knew neither where nor how .
14 The Prince was deeply moved , and vowed that he would search the world for the Princess , and take no rest till he had found and restored her to her mother 's arms .
15 The Queen assured him of her eternal gratitude , and promised , should he succeed , to give him her daughter in marriage , together with all the estates she herself owned .
16 The Prince , far more attracted by the thoughts of possessing the Princess than her promised dower , set forth in his quest after taking leave of the King and Queen , the latter giving him a miniature of her daughter which she was in the habit of wearing .
17 His first act was to seek the Fairy under whose protection he had been placed , and he implored her to give him all the assistance of her art and counsel in this important matter .
18 After listening attentively to the whole adventure , the Fairy asked for time to consult her books .
19 After due consideration she informed the Prince that the object of his search was not far distant , but that it was too difficult for him to attempt to enter the enchanted palace where she was , as the King his father had surrounded it with a thick cloud , and that the only expedient she could think of would be to gain possession of the Princess 's parrot .

5 So she went in search of her hedgehog .
6 The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog , which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other : the only difficulty was , that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden , where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree .
7 By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back , the fight was over , and both the hedgehogs were out of sight : ` but it does n't matter much , ' thought Alice , ` as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground . '
8 So she tucked it away under her arm , that it might not escape again , and went back for a little more conversation with her friend .
9 When she got back to the Cheshire Cat , she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it : there was a dispute going on between the executioner , the King , and the Queen , who were all talking at once , while all the rest were quite silent , and looked very uncomfortable .
10 The moment Alice appeared , she was appealed to by all three to settle the question , and they repeated their arguments to her , though , as they all spoke at once , she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said .
11 The executioner 's argument was , that you could n't cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from : that he had never had to do such a thing before , and he was n't going to begin at HIS time of life .
12 The King 's argument was , that anything that had a head could be beheaded , and that you were n't to talk nonsense .
13 The Queen 's argument was , that if something was n't done about it in less than no time she 'd have everybody executed , all round .
14 -LRB- It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious . -RRB-

1 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
2 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
3 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
4 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
5 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
6 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
7 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
8 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
9 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
10 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
11 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
12 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
13 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
14 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
15 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
16 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
17 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
18 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
19 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
20 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
