1 After wandering through many marble halls , he came to a huge staircase made of porphyry , leading down to a lovely garden .
2 The Prince burst into a shout of joy when he suddenly perceived Militza in the centre of a group of girls who were weaving wreaths of flowers with which to deck their mistress .
3 As soon as Militza saw the Prince she ran up to him and embraced him tenderly ; and after he had told her all his adventures , they went into the palace , where a sumptuous meal awaited them .
4 Then the Princess called her court together , and introduced Iwanich to them as her future husband .
5 Preparations were at once made for the wedding , which was held soon after with great pomp and magnificence .
6 Three months of great happiness followed , when Militza received one day an invitation to visit her mother 's sister .
7 Although the Princess was very unhappy at leaving her husband , she did not like to refuse the invitation , and , promising to return in seven days at the latest , she took a tender farewell of the Prince , and said : ` Before I go I will hand you over all the keys of the castle .
8 Go everywhere and do anything you like ; only one thing I beg and beseech you , do not open the little iron door in the north tower , which is closed with seven locks and seven bolts ; for if you do , we shall both suffer for it . '
9 Iwanich promised what she asked , and Militza departed , repeating her promise to return in seven days .
10 When the Prince found himself alone he began to be tormented by pangs of curiosity as to what the room in the tower contained .
11 For two days he resisted the temptation to go and look , but on the third he could stand it no longer , and taking a torch in his hand he hurried to the tower , and unfastened one lock after the other of the little iron door until it burst open .
12 What an unexpected sight met his gaze !
13 The Prince perceived a small room black with smoke , lit up feebly by a fire from which issued long blue flames .
14 Over the fire hung a huge cauldron full of boiling pitch , and fastened into the cauldron by iron chains stood a wretched man screaming with agony .
15 Iwanich was much horrified at the sight before him , and asked the man what terrible crime he had committed to be punished in this dreadful fashion . '
16 I will tell you everything , ' said the man in the cauldron ; ` but first relieve my torments a little , I implore you . '
17 ` And how can I do that ? '
18 asked the Prince .
19 ` With a little water , ' replied the man ; ` only sprinkle a few drops over me and I shall feel better . '
20 The Prince , moved by pity , without thinking what he was doing , ran to the courtyard of the castle , and filled a jug with water , which he poured over the man in the cauldron .
21 In a moment a most fearful crash was heard , as if all the pillars of the palace were giving way , and the XXXXX itself , with towers and doors , windows and the cauldron , whirled round the bewildered Prince 's head .	palace		Preparations|courtyard|lock|magnificence|mother|palace|pitch|room|smoke|wedding

1 He did n't care for pride any longer ; he just cried and did n't even pretend he was n't crying when Miss Salome came in to sit by him a little while and talk to him .
2 That talk comforted Chester .
3 He realized that , come what might , he would always have a good friend in Miss Salome -- aye , and in Clemantiny , too .
4 Chester never knew it , but after he had fallen asleep , with the tears still glistening on his brown cheeks , Clemantiny tiptoed silently in with a candle in her hand and bent over him with an expression of almost maternal tenderness on her face .
5 It was late and an aroma of boiling sugar hung about her .
6 She had sat up long after Miss Salome was abed , to boil another saucepan of taffy for Chester to eat on his journey .
7 `` Poor , dear child ! ''
8 she said , softly touching one of his crisp curls .
9 `` It 's a shame in Salome to insist on his going back .
10 She does n't know what she 's sending him to , or she would n't .
11 He did n't say much against his aunt , and Salome thinks she was only just a little bit cranky .
12 But I could guess . ''
13 Early in the morning Miss Salome and Chester started .
14 They were to drive to Montrose , leave their team there and take the boat for Belltown .
15 Chester bade farewell to the porch chamber and the long , white kitchen and the friendly barns with a full heart .
16 When he climbed into the wagon , Clemantiny put a big bagful of taffy into his hands .
17 `` Good-by , Chester , '' she said .
18 `` And remember , you 've always got a friend in me , anyhow . ''
19 Then Clemantiny went back into the kitchen and cried -- good , rough-spoken , tender-hearted Clemantiny sat down and cried .
20 It was an ideal day for travelling -- crisp , clear and sunny -- but neither Chester nor Miss Salome was in a mood for enjoyment .
21 Back over Chester 's runaway route they went , and reached Belltown on the XXXXX that evening .	boat		Miss|Poor|aye|boat|cheeks|child|friend|tenderness|wagon|while

1 ` My esteemed little Nightingale , ' said the First Lord , ' I have the great pleasure to invite you to Court this evening , where His Gracious Imperial Highness will be enchanted with your charming song ! '
2 ` It sounds best in the green wood , ' said the Nightingale ; but still , she came gladly when she heard that the Emperor wished it .
3 At the Palace everything was splendidly prepared .
4 The porcelain walls and floors glittered in the light of many thousand gold lamps ; the most gorgeous flowers which tinkled out well were placed in the corridors .
5 There was such a hurrying and draught that all the bells jingled so much that one could not hear oneself speak .
6 In the centre of the great hall where the Emperor sat was a golden perch , on which the Nightingale sat .
7 The whole Court was there , and the little kitchenmaid was allowed to stand behind the door , now that she was a Court-cook .
8 Everyone was dressed in his best , and everyone was looking towards the little grey bird to whom the Emperor nodded .
9 The Nightingale sang so gloriously that the tears came into the Emperor 's eyes and ran down his cheeks .
10 Then the Nightingale sang even more beautifully ; it went straight to all hearts .
11 The Emperor was so delighted that he said she should wear his gold slipper round her neck .
12 But the Nightingale thanked him , and said she had had enough reward already . '
13 I have seen tears in the Emperor 's eyes -- that is a great reward .
14 An Emperor 's tears have such power ! '
15 Then she sang again with her gloriously sweet voice .
16 ` That is the most charming coquetry I have ever seen ! '
17 said all the ladies round .
18 And they all took to holding water in their mouths that they might gurgle whenever anyone spoke to them .
19 Then they thought themselves nightingales .
20 Yes , the lackeys and chambermaids announced that they were pleased ; which means a great deal , for they are the most difficult people of all to satisfy .
21 In short , the XXXXX was a real success .	Nightingale		Nightingale|anyone|draught|hall|lackeys|nightingales|perch|tears|water|wood

1 I am off to the King 's Court , ' he answered .
2 ` He has promised to give his daughter to whoever can make a flying ship . '
3 ` And can you make such a ship ? '
4 ` Not I. ' ` Then why in the world are you going ? '
5 ` Ca n't tell , ' replied the Simpleton .
6 ` Well , if that is the case , ' said the manikin , ` sit down beside me ; we can rest for a little and have something to eat .
7 Give me what you have got in your satchel . '
8 Now , the poor Simpleton was ashamed to show what was in it .
9 However , he thought it best not to make a fuss , so he opened the satchel , and could scarcely believe his own eyes , for , instead of the hard crust , he saw two beautiful fresh rolls and some cold meat .
10 He shared them with the manikin , who licked his lips and said : ` Now , go into that wood , and stop in front of the first tree , bow three times , and then strike the tree with your axe , fall on your knees on the ground , with your face on the earth , and remain there till you are raised up .
11 You will then find a ship at your side , step into it and fly to the King 's Palace .
12 If you meet anyone on the way , take him with you . '
13 The Simpleton thanked the manikin very kindly , bade him farewell , and went into the road .
14 When he got to the first tree he stopped in front of it , did everything just as he had been told , and , kneeling on the ground with his face to the earth , fell asleep .
15 After a little time he was aroused ; he awoke and , rubbing his eyes , saw a ready-made ship at his side , and at once got into it .
16 And the ship rose and rose , and in another minute was flying through the air , when the Simpleton , who was on the look out , cast his eyes down to the earth and saw a man beneath him on the road , who was kneeling with his ear upon the damp ground .
17 ` Hallo ! '
18 he called out , ` what are you doing down there ? ' '
19 I am listening to what is going on in the world , ' replied the man .
20 ` Come with me in my ship , ' said the Simpleton .
21 So the man was only too glad , and got in beside him ; and the ship flew , and flew , and flew through the air , till again from his outlook the Simpleton saw a XXXXX on the road below , who was hopping on one leg , while his other leg was tied up behind his ear .	man		air|ear|eyes|fall|fuss|knees|man|manikin|times|world

8 I knew I would be taken , too , to be kept out of mischief , and my heart gave a great bound of hope .

1 ` That 's the first question , you know . '
2 It was , no doubt : only Alice did not like to be told so .
3 ` It 's really dreadful , ' she muttered to herself , ` the way all the creatures argue .
4 It 's enough to drive one crazy ! '
5 The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his remark , with variations . '
6 I shall sit here , ' he said , ` on and off , for days and days . '
7 ` But what am I to do ? '
8 said Alice .
9 ` Anything you like , ' said the Footman , and began whistling .
10 ` Oh , there 's no use in talking to him , ' said Alice desperately : ` he 's perfectly idiotic ! '
11 And she opened the door and went in .
12 The door led right into a large kitchen , which was full of smoke from one end to the other : the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle , nursing a baby ; the cook was leaning over the fire , stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup .
13 ` There 's certainly too much pepper in that soup ! '
14 Alice said to herself , as well as she could for sneezing .
15 There was certainly too much of it in the air .
16 Even the Duchess sneezed occasionally ; and as for the baby , it was sneezing and howling alternately without a moment 's pause .
17 The only things in the kitchen that did not sneeze , were the cook , and a large cat which was sitting on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear .
18 ` Please would you tell me , ' said Alice , a little timidly , for she was not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first , ` why your cat grins like that ? '
19 ` It 's a Cheshire cat , ' said the Duchess , ` and that 's why .
20 Pig ! '
21 She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite jumped ; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the XXXXX , and not to her , so she took courage , and went on again : -- ' I did n't know that Cheshire cats always grinned ; in fact , I did n't know that cats COULD grin . 1 ` Do let me try , ' said the youth , ` whether I can do these wonderful things . '
2 The maiden , suspecting no treachery , gave him the magic ring .
3 The youth pretended to have forgotten what to do , and asked what finger he must put the ring on so that no sharp weapon could hurt him ? '
4 ` Oh , the middle finger of your left hand , ' the maiden answered , laughing .
5 She took the knife and tried to strike the youth , and he even tried to cut himself with it , but found it impossible .
6 Then he asked the maiden to show him how to split stones and rocks with the help of the ring .
7 So she led him into a courtyard where stood a great boulder-stone .
8 ` Now , ' she said , ` put the ring upon the thumb of your left hand , and you will see how strong that hand has become .
9 The youth did so , and found to his astonishment that with a single blow of his fist the stone flew into a thousand pieces .
10 Then the youth bethought him that he who does not use his luck when he has it is a fool , and that this was a chance which once lost might never return .
11 So while they stood laughing at the shattered stone he placed the ring , as if in play , upon the third finger of his left hand .
12 ` Now , ' said the maiden , ` you are invisible to me until you take the ring off again . '
13 But the youth had no mind to do that ; on the contrary , he went farther off , then put the ring on the little finger of his left hand , and soared into the air like a bird .
14 When the maiden saw him flying away she thought at first that he was still in play , and cried , ` Come back , friend , for now you see I have told you the truth . '
15 But the young man never came back .
16 Then the maiden saw she was deceived , and bitterly repented that she had ever trusted him with the ring .
17 The young man never halted in his flight until he reached the dwelling of the wise magician who had taught him the speech of birds .
18 The magician was delighted to find that his search had been successful , and at once set to work to interpret the secret signs engraved upon the ring , but it took him seven weeks to make them out clearly .
19 Then he gave the youth the following instructions how to overcome the Dragon of the North : ` You must have an iron horse cast , which must have little wheels under each foot .
20 You must also be armed with a spear two fathoms long , which you will be able to wield by means of the magic ring upon your left thumb .
21 The XXXXX must be as thick in the middle as a large tree , and both its ends must be sharp .	spear		Dragon|North|air|astonishment|courtyard|finger|fist|man|pieces|spear

2 ` Call the first witness , ' said the King ; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet , and called out , ` First witness ! '
3 The first witness was the Hatter .
4 He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other . '
5 I beg pardon , your Majesty , ' he began , ` for bringing these in : but I had n't quite finished my tea when I was sent for . '
6 ` You ought to have finished , ' said the King .
7 ` When did you begin ? '
8 The Hatter looked at the March Hare , who had followed him into the court , arm-in-arm with the Dormouse .
9 ` Fourteenth of March , I think it was , ' he said .
10 ` Fifteenth , ' said the March Hare .
11 ` Sixteenth , ' added the Dormouse .
12 ` Write that down , ' the King said to the jury , and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates , and then added them up , and reduced the answer to shillings and pence .
13 ` Take off your hat , ' the King said to the Hatter .
14 ` It is n't mine , ' said the Hatter .
15 ` Stolen ! '
16 the King exclaimed , turning to the jury , who instantly made a memorandum of the fact . '
17 I keep them to sell , ' the Hatter added as an explanation ; ` I 've none of my own .
18 I 'm a hatter . '

1 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
2 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
3 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
4 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
5 And as the children ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the cat had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .
6 So when the witch came up to it on her broom she found that there was nothing for it but to turn round and go back to her hut .
7 But the twins ran straight on till they reached their own home .
8 Then they told their father all that they had suffered , and he was so angry with their step-mother that he drove her out of the house , and never let her return ; but he and the children lived happily together ; and he took care of them himself , and never let a stranger come near them .
9 THE HAZEL-NUT CHILD -LRB- 29 -RRB- -LRB- 29 -RRB- From the Bukowniaer .
10 Van Wliolocki .
11 There was once upon a time a couple who had no children , and they prayed Heaven every day to send them a child , though it were no bigger than a hazel-nut .
12 At last Heaven heard their prayer and sent them a child exactly the size of a hazel-nut , and it never grew an inch .
13 The parents were very devoted to the little creature , and nursed and tended it carefully .
14 Their tiny son too was as clever as he could be , and so sharp and sensible that all the neighbours marvelled over the wise things he said and did .
15 When the Hazel-nut child was fifteen years old , and was sitting one day in an egg-shell on the table beside his mother , she turned to him and said , ` You are now fifteen years old , and nothing can be done with you .
16 What do you intend to be ? ' '
17 A messenger , ' answered the Hazel-nut child .
18 Then his mother burst out laughing and said , ` What an idea !
19 You a messenger !
20 Why , your little feet would take an hour to go the distance an ordinary person could do in a minute ! '
21 But the Hazel-nut XXXXX replied , ` Nevertheless I mean to be a messenger !	child		chase|child|couple|creature|ear|hut|moment|son|twins|witch

1 `` We be one blood , thou and I , '' Mowgli answered .
2 `` I take my life from thee tonight .
3 My kill shall be thy kill if ever thou art hungry , O Kaa . ''
4 `` All thanks , Little Brother , '' said Kaa , though his eyes twinkled .
5 `` And what may so bold a hunter kill ?
6 I ask that I may follow when next he goes abroad . ''
7 `` I kill nothing , -- I am too little , -- but I drive goats toward such as can use them .
8 When thou art empty come to me and see if I speak the truth .
9 I have some skill in these -LSB- he held out his hands -RSB- , and if ever thou art in a trap , I may pay the debt which I owe to thee , to Bagheera , and to Baloo , here .
10 Good hunting to ye all , my masters . ''
11 `` Well said , '' growled Baloo , for Mowgli had returned thanks very prettily .
12 The Python dropped his head lightly for a minute on Mowgli 's shoulder .
13 `` A brave heart and a courteous tongue , '' said he .
14 `` They shall carry thee far through the jungle , manling .
15 But now go hence quickly with thy friends .
16 Go and sleep , for the moon sets , and what follows it is not well that thou shouldst see . ''
17 The moon was sinking behind the hills and the lines of trembling monkeys huddled together on the walls and battlements looked like ragged shaky fringes of things .
18 Baloo went down to the tank for a drink and Bagheera began to put his fur in order , as Kaa glided out into the center of the terrace and brought his jaws together with a ringing snap that drew all the monkeys ' eyes upon him .
19 `` The moon sets , '' he said .
20 `` Is there yet light enough to see ? ''

1 So she was taken on as a kitchen-maid for very small wages .
2 Now the Prince was about to marry another princess , for he thought she was dead long ago .
3 In the evening , when she had washed up and was ready , she felt in her pocket and found the three nuts which the old toad had given her .
4 She cracked one and was going to eat the kernel , when behold !
5 there was a beautiful royal dress inside it !
6 When the bride heard of this , she came and begged for the dress , and wanted to buy it , saying that it was not a dress for a serving-maid .
7 Then she said she would not sell it unless she was granted one favour -- namely , to sleep by the Prince 's door .
8 The bride granted her this , because the dress was so beautiful and she had so few like it .
9 When it was evening she said to her bridegroom , ` That stupid maid wants to sleep by your door . '
10 ` If you are contented , I am , ' he said .
11 But she gave him a glass of wine in which she had poured a sleeping-draught .
12 Then they both went to his room , but he slept so soundly that she could not wake him .
13 The maid wept all night long , and said , ' I freed you in the wild wood out of the iron stove ; I have sought you , and have crossed a glassy mountain , three sharp swords , and a great lake before I found you , and will you not hear me now ? '
14 The servants outside heard how she cried the whole night , and they told their master in the morning .
15 When she had washed up the next evening she bit the second nut , and there was a still more beautiful dress inside .
16 When the bride saw it she wanted to buy it also .
17 But the maid did not want money , and asked that she should sleep again by the Prince 's door .
18 The bride , however , gave him a sleeping-draught , and he slept so soundly that he heard nothing .
19 But the kitchen-maid wept the whole night long , and said , ' I have freed you in a wood and from an iron stove ; I sought you and have crossed a glassy mountain , three sharp swords , and a great lake to find you , and now you will not hear me ! '

1 ` That depends a good deal on where you want to get to , ' said the Cat . '
2 I do n't much care where -- ' said Alice .
3 ` Then it does n't matter which way you go , ' said the Cat . '
4 -- so long as I get SOMEWHERE , ' Alice added as an explanation .
5 ` Oh , you 're sure to do that , ' said the Cat , ` if you only walk long enough . '
6 Alice felt that this could not be denied , so she tried another question .
7 ` What sort of people live about here ? '
8 ` In THAT direction , ' the Cat said , waving its right paw round , ` lives a Hatter : and in THAT direction , ' waving the other paw , ` lives a March Hare .

10 ` But I do n't want to go among mad people , ' Alice remarked .
11 ` Oh , you ca n't help that , ' said the Cat : ` we 're all mad here .

1 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
2 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
3 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
4 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
5 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
6 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
7 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
8 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
9 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a spell on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .
10 After this Hermod disappeared , and no one knew what had become of him ; the Queen caused search to be made for him , but he could nowhere be found .
11 One time , when Olof was in the castle beside Hadvor , she asked the Princess if she knew where Hermod had gone to .
12 At this Hadvor became very sad , and said that she did not . '
13 I shall tell you then , ' said Olof , ` for I know all about it .
14 Hermod has disappeared through the wicked devices of the Queen , for she is a witch , and so is her daughter , though they have put on these beautiful forms .
15 Because Hermod would not fall in with the Queen 's plans , and marry her daughter , she has laid a spell on him , to go on an island and be a lion by day and a man by night , and never be freed from this until you burn the lion 's skin .
16 Besides , ' said Olof , ` she has looked out a match for you ; she has a brother in the Underworld , a three-headed Giant , whom she means to turn into a beautiful prince and get him married to you .
17 This is no new thing for the Queen ; she took me away from my parents ' house and compelled me to serve her ; but she has never done me any harm , for the green cloak I wear protects me against all mischief .
18 Hadvor now became still sadder than before at the thought of the marriage destined for her , and entreated Olof to think of some plan to save her . '
19 I think , ' said Olof , ` that your wooer will come up through the floor of the castle to you , and so you must be prepared when you hear the noise of his coming and the floor begins to open , and have at hand blazing pitch , and pour plenty of it into the opening .
20 That will prove too much for him . '
21 About this time the King came home from his expedition , and thought it a great blow that no XXXXX knew what had become of Hermod ; but the Queen consoled him as best she could , and after a time the King thought less about his disappearance .	one		Underworld|brother|castle|cloak|country|one|plan|rat|speech|woman

1 `` Happen !
2 The worst that can happen .
3 Petersen Sahib is a madman .
4 Else why should he go hunting these wild devils ?
5 He may even require thee to be an elephant catcher , to sleep anywhere in these fever-filled jungles , and at last to be trampled to death in the Keddah .
6 It is well that this nonsense ends safely .
7 Next week the catching is over , and we of the plains are sent back to our stations .
8 Then we will march on smooth roads , and forget all this hunting .
9 But , son , I am angry that thou shouldst meddle in the business that belongs to these dirty Assamese jungle folk .
10 Kala Nag will obey none but me , so I must go with him into the Keddah , but he is only a fighting elephant , and he does not help to rope them .
11 So I sit at my ease , as befits a mahout , -- not a mere hunter , -- a mahout , I say , and a man who gets a pension at the end of his service .
12 Is the family of Toomai of the Elephants to be trodden underfoot in the dirt of a Keddah ?

14 Wicked one !
15 Worthless son !

1 In short , the Nightingale was a real success .
2 She had to stay at Court now ; she had her own cage , and permission to walk out twice in the day and once at night .
3 She was given twelve servants , who each held a silken string which was fastened round her leg .
4 There was little pleasure in flying about like this .
5 The whole town was talking about the wonderful bird , and when two people met each other one would say ` Nightin , ' and the other ` Gale , ' and then they would both sigh and understand one another .
6 Yes , and eleven grocer 's children were called after her , but not one of them could sing a note .
7 One day the Emperor received a large parcel on which was written ` The Nightingale . '
8 ` Here is another new book about our famous bird ! '
9 said the Emperor .
10 But it was not a book , but a little mechanical toy , which lay in a box -- an artificial nightingale which was like the real one , only that it was set all over with diamonds , rubies , and sapphires .
11 When it was wound up , it could sing the piece the real bird sang , and moved its tail up and down , and glittered with silver and gold .
12 Round its neck was a little collar on which was written , ` The Nightingale of the Emperor of Japan is nothing compared to that of the Emperor of China . '
13 ` This is magnificent ! '
14 they all said , and the man who had brought the clockwork bird received on the spot the title of ` Bringer of the Imperial First Nightingale . '
15 ` Now they must sing together ; what a duet we shall have ! '
16 And so they sang together , but their voices did not blend , for the real Nightingale sang in her way and the clockwork bird sang waltzes .
17 ` It is not its fault ! '
18 said the bandmaster ; ` it keeps very good time and is quite after my style ! '
19 Then the artificial bird had to sing alone .
20 It gave just as much pleasure as the real one , and then it was so much prettier to look at ; it sparkled like bracelets and necklaces .
21 Three-and-thirty times it sang the same XXXXX without being tired .	piece		bird|box|duet|gold|leg|piece|string|success|title|voices

1 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
2 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
3 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
4 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
5 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
6 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
7 As soon as her feet touched the ground she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .
8 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
9 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
10 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
11 And now everything was up above and only he himself remained below .
12 But as he was a little suspicious of his brothers , he fastened a heavy stone on to the rope and let them pull it up .
13 At first they heaved with a will , but when the stone was half way up they let it drop suddenly , and it fell to the bottom broken into a hundred pieces .
14 ` So that 's what would have happened to my bones had I trusted myself to them , ' said the youth sadly ; and he began to cry bitterly , not because of the treasures , but because of the lovely girl with her swanlike neck and golden hair .
15 For a long time he wandered sadly all through the beautiful underworld , and one day he met a magician who asked him the cause of his tears .
16 The youth told him all that had befallen him , and the magician said : ` Do not grieve , young man !
17 If you will guard the children who are hidden in the golden apple-tree , I will bring you at once up to the earth .
18 Another magician who lives in this land always eats my children up .
19 It is in vain that I have hidden them under the earth and locked them into the castle .
20 Now I have hidden them in the apple-tree ; hide yourself there too , and at midnight you will see my enemy . '
21 The XXXXX climbed up the tree , and picked some of the beautiful golden apples , which he ate for his supper .	youth		chests|children|fear|girl|man|moment|sister|time|witch|youth

1 ` Yes , it IS his business ! '
2 said Five , ` and I 'll tell him -- it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions . '
3 Seven flung down his brush , and had just begun ` Well , of all the unjust things -- ' when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice , as she stood watching them , and he checked himself suddenly : the others looked round also , and all of them bowed low .
4 ` Would you tell me , ' said Alice , a little timidly , ` why you are painting those roses ? '
5 Five and Seven said nothing , but looked at Two .
6 Two began in a low voice , ` Why the fact is , you see , Miss , this here ought to have been a RED rose-tree , and we put a white one in by mistake ; and if the Queen was to find it out , we should all have our heads cut off , you know .
7 So you see , Miss , we 're doing our best , afore she comes , to -- ' At this moment Five , who had been anxiously looking across the garden , called out ` The Queen !
8 The Queen ! '
9 and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces .
10 There was a sound of many footsteps , and Alice looked round , eager to see the Queen .
11 First came ten soldiers carrying clubs ; these were all shaped like the three gardeners , oblong and flat , with their hands and feet at the corners : next the ten courtiers ; these were ornamented all over with diamonds , and walked two and two , as the soldiers did .
12 After these came the royal children ; there were ten of them , and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand , in couples : they were all ornamented with hearts .
13 Next came the guests , mostly Kings and Queens , and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit : it was talking in a hurried nervous manner , smiling at everything that was said , and went by without noticing her .
14 Then followed the Knave of Hearts , carrying the King 's crown on a crimson velvet cushion ; and , last of all this grand procession , came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS .
15 Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners , but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions ; ` and besides , what would be the use of a procession , ' thought she , ` if people had all to lie down upon their faces , so that they could n't see it ? '
16 So she stood still where she was , and waited .
17 When the procession came opposite to Alice , they all stopped and looked at her , and the Queen said severely ` Who is this ? '
18 She said it to the Knave of Hearts , who only bowed and smiled in reply .
19 ` Idiot ! '
20 said the Queen , tossing her head impatiently ; and , turning to Alice , she went on , ` What 's your name , child ? '

1 Above the noise of the water , as it swirled round the elephant 's legs , Little Toomai could hear more splashing and some trumpeting both upstream and down -- great grunts and angry snortings , and all the mist about him seemed to be full of rolling , wavy shadows .
2 `` Ai ! ''
3 he said , half aloud , his teeth chattering .
4 `` The elephant-folk are out tonight .
5 It is the dance , then ! ''
6 Kala Nag swashed out of the water , blew his trunk clear , and began another climb .
7 But this time he was not alone , and he had not to make his path .
8 That was made already , six feet wide , in front of him , where the bent jungle-grass was trying to recover itself and stand up .
9 Many elephants must have gone that way only a few minutes before .
10 Little Toomai looked back , and behind him a great wild tusker with his little pig 's eyes glowing like hot coals was just lifting himself out of the misty river .
11 Then the trees closed up again , and they went on and up , with trumpetings and crashings , and the sound of breaking branches on every side of them .
12 At last Kala Nag stood still between two tree-trunks at the very top of the hill .
13 They were part of a circle of trees that grew round an irregular space of some three or four acres , and in all that space , as Little Toomai could see , the ground had been trampled down as hard as a brick floor .
14 Some trees grew in the center of the clearing , but their bark was rubbed away , and the white wood beneath showed all shiny and polished in the patches of moonlight .
15 There were creepers hanging from the upper branches , and the bells of the flowers of the creepers , great waxy white things like convolvuluses , hung down fast asleep .
16 But within the limits of the clearing there was not a single blade of green -- nothing but the trampled earth .
17 The moonlight showed it all iron gray , except where some elephants stood upon it , and their shadows were inky black .
18 Little Toomai looked , holding his breath , with his eyes starting out of his head , and as he looked , more and more and more elephants swung out into the open from between the tree trunks .
19 Little Toomai could only count up to ten , and he counted again and again on his fingers till he lost count of the tens , and his head began to swim .
20 Outside the clearing he could hear them crashing in the undergrowth as they worked their way up the hillside , but as soon as they were within the circle of the tree trunks they moved like ghosts .
21 There were white-tusked wild males , with fallen leaves and nuts and twigs lying in the wrinkles of their necks and the folds of their ears ; fat , slow-footed she-elephants , with restless , little pinky black calves only three or four feet high running under their stomachs ; young XXXXX with their tusks just beginning to show , and very proud of them ; lanky , scraggy old-maid elephants , with their hollow anxious faces , and trunks like rough bark ; savage old bull elephants , scarred from shoulder to flank with great weals and cuts of bygone fights , and the caked dirt of their solitary mud baths dropping from their shoulders ; and there was one with a broken tusk and the marks of the full-stroke , the terrible drawing scrape , of a tiger 's claws on his side .	elephants		clearing|climb|count|dance|elephants|head|moonlight|nothing|trees|way

7 He was the spirit of the flower .
8 In each blossom there dwelt a tiny man or woman ; but this one was the King over the others .

10 whispered Thumbelina to the swallow .
11 The little Prince was very much frightened at the swallow , for in comparison with one so tiny as himself he seemed a giant .

7 Then she took him up and placed him on a dish .
8 When her husband came home and they sat down to dinner , they presently heard the Crab 's little voice saying , ` Give me some too . '
9 They were all very much surprised , but they gave him something to eat .
10 When the old man came to take away the plate which had contained the Crab 's dinner , he found it full of gold , and as the same thing happened every day he soon became very fond of the Crab .
11 One day the Crab said to the fisherman 's wife , ` Go to the King and tell him I wish to marry his younger daughter . '
12 The old woman went accordingly , and laid the matter before the King , who laughed a little at the notion of his daughter marrying a crab , but did not decline the proposal altogether , because he was a prudent monarch , and knew that the Crab was likely to be a prince in disguise .
13 He said , therefore , to the fisherman 's wife , ` Go , old woman , and tell the Crab I will give him my daughter if by to-morrow morning he can build a wall in front of my castle much higher than my tower , upon which all the flowers of the world must grow and bloom . '
14 The fisherman 's wife went home and gave this message .
15 Then the Crab gave her a golden rod , and said , ` Go and strike with this rod three times upon the ground on the place which the King showed you , and to-morrow morning the wall will be there . '
16 The old woman did so and went away again .
17 The next morning , when the King awoke , what do you think he saw ?
18 The wall stood there before his eyes , exactly as he had bespoken it !
19 Then the old woman went back to the King and said to him , ` Your Majesty 's orders have been fulfilled . '
20 ` That is all very well , ' said the King , ` but I can not give away my daughter until there stands in front of my palace a garden in which there are three fountains , of which the first must play gold , the second diamonds , and the third brilliants . '

1 Here she was received by a beautiful lady dressed in green and white to match the house , which apparently belonged to her , and of which she seemed the only inhabitant .
2 She greeted the fainting Princess most kindly , gave her an excellent supper , and after a long night 's rest in a delightful bed told her that after many troubles she should finally attain her desire .
3 As the green and white lady took leave of the Princess she gave her a nut , desiring her only to open it in the most urgent need .
4 After a long and tiring journey Fairer-than-a-Fairy was once more received in a house , and by a lady exactly like the one she had quitted .
5 Here again she received a present with the same injunctions , but instead of a nut this lady gave her a golden pomegranate .
6 The mournful Princess had to continue her weary way , and after many troubles and hardships she again found rest and shelter in a third house exactly similar to the two others .
7 These houses belonged to three sisters , all endowed with fairy gifts , and all so alike in mind and person that they wished their houses and garments to be equally alike .
8 Their occupation consisted in helping those in misfortune , and they were as gentle and benevolent as Lagree had been cruel and spiteful .
9 The third Fairy comforted the poor traveller , begged her not to lose heart , and assured her that her troubles should be rewarded .
10 She accompanied her advice by the gift of a crystal smelling-bottle , with strict orders only to open it in case of urgent need .
11 Fairer-than-a-Fairy thanked her warmly , and resumed her way cheered by pleasant thoughts .
12 After a time her road led through a wood , full of soft airs and sweet odours , and before she had gone a hundred yards she saw a wonderful silver Castle suspended by strong silver chains to four of the largest trees .
13 It was so perfectly hung that a gentle breeze rocked it sufficiently to send you pleasantly to sleep .
14 Fairer-than-a-Fairy felt a strong desire to enter this Castle , but besides being hung a little above the ground there seemed to be neither doors nor windows .
15 She had no doubt -LRB- though really I can not think why -RRB- that the moment had come in which to use the nut which had been given her .
16 She opened it , and out came a diminutive hall porter at whose belt hung a tiny chain , at the end of which was a golden key half as long as the smallest pin you ever saw .
17 The Princess climbed up one of the silver chains , holding in her hand the little porter who , in spite of his minute size , opened a secret door with his golden key and let her in .
18 She entered a magnificent room which appeared to occupy the entire Castle , and which was lighted by gold and jewelled stars in the ceiling .
19 In the midst of this room stood a couch , draped with curtains of all the colours of the rainbow , and suspended by golden cords so that it swayed with the Castle in a manner which rocked its occupant delightfully to sleep .
20 On this elegant couch lay Prince Rainbow , looking more beautiful than ever , and sunk in profound slumber , in which he had been held ever since his disappearance .

1 They assembled in the water round the green stalk which supported the leaf on which she was sitting , and nibbled the stem in two .
2 Away floated the leaf down the stream , bearing Thumbelina far beyond the reach of the toad .
3 On she sailed past several towns , and the little birds sitting in the bushes saw her , and sang , ` What a pretty little girl ! '
4 The leaf floated farther and farther away ; thus Thumbelina left her native land .
5 A beautiful little white butterfly fluttered above her , and at last settled on the leaf .
6 Thumbelina pleased him , and she , too , was delighted , for now the toads could not reach her , and it was so beautiful where she was travelling ; the sun shone on the water and made it sparkle like the brightest silver .
7 She took off her sash , and tied one end round the butterfly ; the other end she fastened to the leaf , so that now it glided along with her faster than ever .
8 A great cockchafer came flying past ; he caught sight of Thumbelina , and in a moment had put his arms round her slender waist , and had flown off with her to a tree .
9 The green leaf floated away down the stream , and the butterfly with it , for he was fastened to the leaf and could not get loose from it .
10 Oh , dear !
11 how terrified poor little Thumbelina was when the cockchafer flew off with her to the tree !
12 But she was especially distressed on the beautiful white butterfly 's account , as she had tied him fast , so that if he could not get away he must starve to death .
13 But the cockchafer did not trouble himself about that ; he sat down with her on a large green leaf , gave her the honey out of the flowers to eat , and told her that she was very pretty , although she was n't in the least like a cockchafer .
14 Later on , all the other cockchafers who lived in the same tree came to pay calls ; they examined Thumbelina closely , and remarked , ` Why , she has only two legs !
15 How very miserable ! '
16 ` She has no feelers ! '
17 cried another .
18 ` How ugly she is ! '
19 said all the lady chafers -- and yet Thumbelina was really very pretty .
20 The cockchafer who had stolen her knew this very well ; but when he heard all the ladies saying she was ugly , he began to think so too , and would not keep her ; she might go wherever she liked .

1 The Young Man shook his head , but did not look at her .
2 `` It 's pretty bad , '' he admitted .
3 `` You see , '' said the Girl pathetically , `` the shadow of it has been over my whole life .
4 Of course , when I was a very little girl I did n't mind it so much .
5 It was such a long way off and lots of things might happen .
6 The Creature might run away with some other girl -- or I might have the smallpox -- or Beatrix 's nose might be straight when she grew up .
7 And if Beatrix 's nose were straight she 'd be a great deal prettier than I am .
8 But nothing did happen -- and her nose is puggier than ever .
9 Then when I grew up things were horrid .
10 I never could have a single little bit of fun .
11 And Beatrix had such a good time !
12 She had scores of lovers in spite of her nose .
13 To be sure , she 's engaged now -- and he 's a horrid , faddy little creature .
14 But he is her own choice .
15 She was n't told that there was a man in England whom she must marry by and by , when he got sufficiently reconciled to the idea to come and ask her .

1 But after a few hours , by the magic arts of the old witch , he was overpowered by sleep , and the mare and foal escaped and did as they had been told to do .
2 The Prince did not awake till late in the evening ; and when he did , he found , to his horror , that the horses had disappeared .
3 Filled with despair , he cursed the moment when he had entered the service of the cruel witch , and already he saw his head sticking up on the sharp spike beside the others .
4 Then he suddenly remembered the fish 's scale , which , with the eagle 's feather and the fox 's hairs , he always carried about with him .
5 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the river he threw it in .
6 In a minute the grateful fish swam towards the bank on which Iwanich was standing , and said : ` What do you command , my friend and benefactor ? '
7 The Prince replied : ' I had to look after a mare and foal , and they have run away from me and have hidden themselves in the river ; if you wish to save my life drive them back to the land . '
8 ` Wait a moment , ' answered the fish , ` and I and my friends will soon drive them out of the water . '
9 With these words the creature disappeared into the depths of the stream .
10 Almost immediately a rushing hissing sound was heard in the waters , the waves dashed against the banks , the foam was tossed into the air , and the two horses leapt suddenly on to the dry land , trembling and shaking with fear .
11 Iwanich sprang at once on to the mare 's back , seized the foal by its bridle , and hastened home in the highest spirits .
12 When the witch saw the Prince bringing the horses home she could hardly conceal her wrath , and as soon as she had placed Iwanich 's supper before him she stole away again to the stables .
13 The Prince followed her , and heard her scolding the beasts harshly for not having hidden themselves better .
14 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .
15 If they did not do as she told them she would beat them till they bled .
16 The next morning , after Iwanich had led his horses to the fields , he fell once more into a magic sleep .
17 The horses at once ran away and hid themselves in the clouds , which hung down from the mountains in soft billowy masses .
18 When the Prince awoke and found that both the mare and the foal had disappeared , he bethought him at once of the eagle , and taking the feather out of his pocket he blew it into the air .
19 In a moment the bird swooped down beside him and asked : ` What do you wish me to do ? '
20 ` My mare and foal , ' replied the Prince , ` have run away from me , and have hidden themselves in the clouds ; if you wish to save my life , restore both animals to me . '

1 They were astonished though at how greedily the Queen devoured the meat , and how much she ate of it , and were no longer surprised that she took so little when she sat at table with the King .
2 As soon as she had finished it the Giant disappeared with the trough by the same way as he had come , and the Queen returned to her human shape .
3 Now we must go back to the King 's son after he had been put in charge of the nurse .
4 One evening , after she had lit a candle and was holding the child , several planks sprang up in the floor of the room , and out at the opening came a beautiful woman dressed in white , with an iron belt round her waist , to which was fastened an iron chain that went down into the ground .
5 The woman came up to the nurse , took the child from her , and pressed it to her breast ; then she gave it back to the nurse and returned by the same way as she had come , and the floor closed over her again .
6 Although the woman had not spoken a single word to her , the nurse was very much frightened , but told no one about it .
7 Next evening the same thing happened again , just as before , but as the woman was going away she said in a sad tone , ` Two are gone , and one only is left , ' and then disappeared as before .
8 The nurse was still more frightened when she heard the woman say this , and thought that perhaps some danger was hanging over the child , though she had no ill-opinion of the unknown woman , who , indeed , had behaved towards the child as if it were her own .
9 The most mysterious thing was the woman saying ` and only one is left ; ' but the nurse guessed that this must mean that only one day was left , since she had come for two days already .
10 At last the nurse made up her mind to go to the King , and told him the whole story , and asked him to be present in person next day about the time when the woman usually came .
11 The King promised to do so , and came to the nurse 's room a little before the time , and sat down on a chair with his drawn sword in his hand .
12 Soon after the planks in the floor sprang up as before , and the woman came up , dressed in white , with the iron belt and chain .
13 The King saw at once that it was his own Queen , and immediately hewed asunder the iron chain that was fastened to the belt .
14 This was followed by such noises and crashings down in the earth that all the King 's Palace shook , so that no one expected anything else than to see every bit of it shaken to pieces .
15 At last , however , the noises and shaking stopped , and they began to come to themselves again .
16 The King and Queen embraced each other , and she told him the whole story -- how the Witch came to the ship when they were all asleep and sent her off in the boat .
17 After she had gone so far that she could not see the ship , she sailed on through darkness until she landed beside a three-headed Giant .
18 The Giant wished her to marry him , but she refused ; whereupon he shut her up by herself , and told her she would never get free until she consented .
19 After a time she began to plan how to get her freedom , and at last told him that she would consent if he would allow her to visit her son on earth three days on end .
20 This he agreed to , but put on her this iron belt and chain , the other end of which he fastened round his own waist , and the great noises that were heard when the King cut the chain must have been caused by the Giant 's falling down the underground passage when the chain gave way so suddenly .

7 When nightfall and the time of the wild beasts came upon these , the Englishman happened to climb up into the very same tree on which the Scotsman was when he got a sight of the castle ; and as soon as the day began to dawn and the Englishman looked to the four quarters of heaven , what did he see but the castle too !
8 Off he went without saying a word to the Irishman , and everything happened to him just as it had done to the Scotsman .
9 The poor Irishman was now left all alone , and did not know where the others had gone to , so he just stayed where he was , very sad and miserable .
10 When night came he climbed up into the same tree as the Englishman had been on the night before .
11 As soon as day came he also saw the castle , and set out towards it ; but when he reached it he could see no signs of fire or living being about it .
12 Before long , however , he heard the window opened above his head , looked up , and beheld the most beautiful woman he had ever seen .
13 He asked if she would give him food and drink , and she answered kindly and heartily that she would , if he would only come inside .
14 This he did very willingly , and she set before him food and drink that he had never seen the like of before .
15 In the room there was a bed , with diamond rings hanging at every loop of the curtains , and everything that was in the room besides astonished him so much that he actually forgot that he was hungry .
16 When she saw that he was not eating at all , she asked him what he wanted yet , to which he replied that he would neither eat nor drink until he knew who she was , or where she came from , or who had put her there . '

1 While he was riding over the heath in the highest of spirits the mare suddenly said to her rider : ` You are the first person who has ever succeeded in outwitting the old witch Corva , and now you may ask what reward you like for your service .
2 If you promise never to betray me I will give you a piece of advice which you will do well to follow . '
3 The Prince promised never to betray her confidence , and the mare continued : ` Ask nothing else as a reward than my foal , for it has not its like in the world , and is not to be bought for love or money ; for it can go from one end of the earth to another in a few minutes .
4 Of course the cunning Corva will do her best to dissuade you from taking the foal , and will tell you that it is both idle and sickly ; but do not believe her , and stick to your point . '
5 Iwanich longed to possess such an animal , and promised the mare to follow her advice .
6 This time Corva received him in the most friendly manner , and set a sumptuous repast before him .
7 As soon as he had finished she asked him what reward he demanded for his year 's service .
8 ` Nothing more nor less , ' replied the Prince , ` than the foal of your mare . '
9 The witch pretended to be much astonished at his request , and said that he deserved something much better than the foal , for the beast was lazy and nervous , blind in one eye , and , in short , was quite worthless .
10 But the Prince knew what he wanted , and when the old witch saw that he had made up his mind to have the foal , she said , ' I am obliged to keep my promise and to hand you over the foal ; and as I know who you are and what you want , I will tell you in what way the animal will be useful to you .
11 The man in the cauldron of boiling pitch , whom you set free , is a mighty magician ; through your curiosity and thoughtlessness Militza came into his power , and he has transported her and her castle and belongings into a distant country .
12 ` You are the only person who can kill him ; and in consequence he fears you to such an extent that he has set spies to watch you , and they report your movements to him daily .
13 ` When you have reached him , beware of speaking a single word to him , or you will fall into the power of his friends .
14 Seize him at once by the beard and dash him to the ground . '
15 Iwanich thanked the old witch , mounted his foal , put spurs to its sides , and they flew like lightning through the air .
16 Already it was growing dark , when Iwanich perceived some figures in the distance ; they soon came up to them , and then the Prince saw that it was the magician and his friends who were driving through the air in a carriage drawn by owls .
17 When the magician found himself face to face with Iwanich , without hope of escape , he turned to him with false friendliness and said : ` Thrice my kind benefactor ! '
18 But the Prince , without saying a word , seized him at once by his beard and dashed him to the ground .
19 At the same moment the foal sprang on the top of the magician and kicked and stamped on him with his hoofs till he died .
20 Then Iwanich found himself once more in the palace of his bride , and Militza herself flew into his arms .

1 ` But where is he to find the Witch-maiden ? '
2 said the first bird .
3 ` She has no settled dwelling , but is here to-day and gone to-morrow .
4 He might as well try to catch the wind . '
5 The other replied , ' I do not know , certainly , where she is at present , but in three nights from now she will come to the spring to wash her face , as she does every month when the moon is full , in order that she may never grow old nor wrinkled , but may always keep the bloom of youth . '
6 ` Well , ' said the first bird , ` the spring is not far from here .
7 Shall we go and see how it is she does it ? '
8 ` Willingly , if you like , ' said the other .
9 The youth immediately resolved to follow the birds to the spring , only two things made him uneasy : first , lest he might be asleep when the birds went , and secondly , lest he might lose sight of them , since he had not wings to carry him along so swiftly .
10 He was too tired to keep awake all night , yet his anxiety prevented him from sleeping soundly , and when with the earliest dawn he looked up to the tree-top , he was glad to see his feathered companions still asleep with their heads under their wings .
11 He ate his breakfast , and waited until the birds should start , but they did not leave the place all day .
12 They hopped about from one tree to another looking for food , all day long until the evening , when they went back to their old perch to sleep .
13 The next day the same thing happened , but on the third morning one bird said to the other , ` To-day we must go to the spring to see the Witch-maiden wash her face . '
14 They remained on the tree till noon ; then they flew away and went towards the south .

6 Because Hermod would not fall in with the Queen 's plans , and marry her daughter , she has laid a spell on him , to go on an island and be a lion by day and a man by night , and never be freed from this until you burn the lion 's skin .
7 Besides , ' said Olof , ` she has looked out a match for you ; she has a brother in the Underworld , a three-headed Giant , whom she means to turn into a beautiful prince and get him married to you .
8 This is no new thing for the Queen ; she took me away from my parents ' house and compelled me to serve her ; but she has never done me any harm , for the green cloak I wear protects me against all mischief .

1 The Josephs were poor at any time , but this winter they were poorer than ever .
2 The crops had failed in the summer , and as a consequence the family were , as Jimmy said , `` on short commons . ''
3 But they made the brave best of their small resources , and on Christmas Eve every little Joseph went to bed with a clear conscience , for was there not on the corner table in the kitchen a small mountain of tiny -- sometimes very tiny -- gifts labelled with the names of recipients and givers , and worth their weight in gold if love and good wishes count for anything ?
4 It was beginning to snow when the small small Josephs went to bed , and when the big small Josephs climbed the stairs it was snowing thickly .
5 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph sat before the fire and listened to the wind howling about the house .
6 `` I 'm glad I 'm not driving over the prairie tonight , '' said Mr. Joseph .
7 `` It 's quite a storm .
8 I hope it will be fine tomorrow , for the children 's sake .
9 They 've set their hearts on having a sleigh ride , and it will be too bad if they ca n't have it when it 's about all the Christmas they 'll have this year .
10 Mary , this is the first Christmas since we came west that we could n't afford some little extras for them , even if 't was only a box of nuts and candy . ''
11 Mrs. Joseph sighed over Jimmy 's worn jacket which she was mending .
12 Then she smiled .
13 `` Never mind , John .
14 Things will be better next Christmas , we 'll hope .
15 The children will not mind , bless their hearts .
16 Look at all the little knick-knacks they 've made for each other .
17 Last week when I was over at Taunton , Mr. Fisher had his store all gayified up , ' as Jim says , with Christmas presents .
18 I did feel that I 'd ask nothing better than to go in and buy all the lovely things I wanted , just for once , and give them to the children tomorrow morning .
19 They 've never had anything really nice for Christmas .
20 But there !

1 ` You are a fine fellow ! '
2 said the Soldier , and put him on the Witch 's apron , took as much copper as his pockets could hold ; then he shut the chest , put the dog on it again , and went into the second room .
3 Sure enough there sat the dog with eyes as large as mill-wheels .
4 ` You had better not look at me so hard ! '
5 said the Soldier .
6 ` Your eyes will come out of their sockets ! '
7 And then he set the dog on the apron .
8 When he saw all the silver in the chest , he threw away the copper he had taken , and filled his pockets and knapsack with nothing but silver .
9 Then he went into the third room .
10 Horrors !
11 the dog there had two eyes , each as large as the Round Tower at Copenhagen , spinning round in his head like wheels .
12 ` Good evening ! '
13 said the Soldier and saluted , for he had never seen a dog like this before .
14 But when he had examined him more closely , he thought to himself : ` Now then , I 've had enough of this ! '
15 and put him down on the floor , and opened the chest .
16 Heavens !
17 what a heap of gold there was !
18 With all that he could buy up the whole town , and all the sugar pigs , all the tin soldiers , whips and rocking-horses in the whole world .
19 Now he threw away all the silver with which he had filled his pockets and knapsack , and filled them with gold instead -- yes , all his pockets , his knapsack , cap and boots even , so that he could hardly walk .
20 Now he was rich indeed .

1 But when he saw Thumbelina , he was delighted , for she was the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
2 So he took his golden crown from off his head and put it on hers , asking her her name , and if she would be his wife , and then she would be Queen of all the flowers .
3 Yes !
4 he was a different kind of husband to the son of the toad and the mole with the black-velvet coat .
5 So she said ` Yes ' to the noble Prince .
6 And out of each flower came a lady and gentleman , each so tiny and pretty that it was a pleasure to see them .
7 Each brought Thumbelina a present , but the best of all was a beautiful pair of wings which were fastened on to her back , and now she too could fly from flower to flower .
8 They all wished her joy , and the swallow sat above in his nest and sang the wedding march , and that he did as well as he could ; but he was sad , because he was very fond of Thumbelina and did not want to be separated from her .
9 ` You shall not be called Thumbelina ! '
10 said the spirit of the flower to her ; ` that is an ugly name , and you are much too pretty for that .
11 We will call you May Blossom . '
12 ` Farewell , farewell ! '
13 said the little swallow with a heavy heart , and flew away to farther lands , far , far away , right back to Denmark .
14 There he had a little nest above a window , where his wife lived , who can tell fairy-stories .
15 ` Tweet , tweet ! '
16 he sang to her .
17 And that is the way we learnt the whole story .

1 She had hardly left him when the two black wolves appeared : but the Sun-Hero beat them off with his sword , and they retired , only , however , to reappear in a very short time .
2 The Sun-Hero chased them away once more , but he had hardly sat down to rest when the two black wolves were on the scene again .
3 This went on for seven days and nights , when the white horse , who had never done such a thing before , turned to the Sun-Hero and said in a human voice : ` Listen to what I am going to say .
4 A Fairy gave me to your mother in order that I might be of service to you ; so let me tell you , that if you go to sleep and let the wolves harm the tree , the Sun will surely kill you .
5 The Fairy , foreseeing this , put everyone in the world under a spell , which prevents their obeying the Sun 's command to take your life .
6 But all the same , she has forgotten one person , who will certainly kill you if you fall asleep and let the wolves damage the tree .
7 So watch and keep the wolves away . '
8 Then the Sun-Hero strove with all his might and kept the black wolves at bay , and conquered his desire to sleep ; but on the eighth night his strength failed him , and he fell fast asleep .
9 When he awoke a woman in black stood beside him , who said : ` You have fulfilled your task very badly , for you have let the two black wolves damage the Tree of the Sun .
10 I am the mother of the Sun , and I command you to ride away from here at once , and I pronounce sentence of death upon you , for you proudly let yourself be called the Sun-Hero without having done anything to deserve the name . '
11 The youth mounted his horse sadly , and rode home .
12 The people all thronged round him on his return , anxious to hear his adventures , but he told them nothing , and only to his mother did he confide what had befallen him .
13 But the old Queen laughed , and said to her son : ` Do n't worry , my child ; you see , the Fairy has protected you so far , and the Sun has found no one to kill you .
14 So cheer up and be happy . '
15 After a time the Prince forgot all about his adventure , and married a beautiful Princess , with whom he lived very happily for some time .
16 But one day when he was out hunting he felt very thirsty , and coming to a stream he stooped down to drink from it , and this caused his death , for a crab came swimming up , and with its claws tore out his tongue .
17 He was carried home in a dying condition , and as he lay on his death-bed the black woman appeared and said : ` So the Sun has , after all , found someone , who was not under the Fairy 's spell , who has caused your death .
18 And a similar fate will overtake everyone under the Sun who wrongfully assumes a title to which he has no right . '

1 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
2 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
3 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
4 And as the children ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the cat had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .
5 So when the witch came up to it on her broom she found that there was nothing for it but to turn round and go back to her hut .
6 But the twins ran straight on till they reached their own home .
7 Then they told their father all that they had suffered , and he was so angry with their step-mother that he drove her out of the house , and never let her return ; but he and the children lived happily together ; and he took care of them himself , and never let a stranger come near them .
8 THE HAZEL-NUT CHILD -LRB- 29 -RRB- -LRB- 29 -RRB- From the Bukowniaer .

10 There was once upon a time a couple who had no children , and they prayed Heaven every day to send them a child , though it were no bigger than a hazel-nut .
11 At last Heaven heard their prayer and sent them a child exactly the size of a hazel-nut , and it never grew an inch .
12 The parents were very devoted to the little creature , and nursed and tended it carefully .
13 Their tiny son too was as clever as he could be , and so sharp and sensible that all the neighbours marvelled over the wise things he said and did .
14 When the Hazel-nut child was fifteen years old , and was sitting one day in an egg-shell on the table beside his mother , she turned to him and said , ` You are now fifteen years old , and nothing can be done with you .

1 ` You had best call me Snati-Snati , ' said the Dog .
2 ` Now we are coming to a King 's seat , and you must ask the King to keep us all winter , and to give you a little room for both of us . '
3 The Prince now began to be less afraid of the Dog .
4 They came to the King and asked him to keep them all the winter , to which he agreed .
5 When the King 's men saw the Dog they began to laugh at it , and make as if they would tease it ; but when the Prince saw this he advised them not to do it , or they might have the worst of it .
6 They replied that they did n't care a bit what he thought .
7 After Ring had been with the King for some days the latter began to think there was a great deal in him , and esteemed him more than the others .
8 The King , however , had a counsellor called Red , who became very jealous when he saw how much the King esteemed Ring ; and one day he talked to him , and said he could not understand why he had so good an opinion of this stranger , who had not yet shown himself superior to other men in anything .
9 The King replied that it was only a short time since he had come there .
10 Red then asked him to send them both to cut down wood next morning , and see which of them could do most work .
11 Snati-Snati heard this and told it to Ring , advising him to ask the King for two axes , so that he might have one in reserve if the first one got broken .
12 Next morning the King asked Ring and Red to go and cut down trees for him , and both agreed .
13 Ring got the two axes , and each went his own way ; but when the Prince had got out into the wood Snati took one of the axes and began to hew along with him .
14 In the evening the King came to look over their day 's work , as Red had proposed , and found that Ring 's wood-heap was more than twice as big . '
15 I suspected , ' said the King , ` that Ring was not quite useless ; never have I seen such a day 's work . '
16 Ring was now in far greater esteem with the King than before , and Red was all the more discontented .
17 One day he came to the King and said , ` If Ring is such a mighty man , I think you might ask him to kill the wild oxen in the wood here , and flay them the same day , and bring you the horns and the hides in the evening . '
18 ` Do n't you think that a desperate errand ? '
19 said the King , ` seeing they are so dangerous , and no one has ever yet ventured to go against them ? '
20 Red answered that he had only one life to lose , and it would be interesting to see how brave he was ; besides , the King would have good reason to ennoble him if he overcame them .
21 The King at last allowed himself , though rather unwillingly , to be won over by Red 's persistency , and one day asked Ring to go and kill the oxen that were in the wood for him , and bring their XXXXX and hides to him in the evening .	horns		Ring|bit|day|errand|horns|life|reserve|way|winter|work

1 When he was not learning he sat out in the sun and slept , and ate and went to sleep again .
2 When he felt dirty or hot he swam in the forest pools ; and when he wanted honey -LRB- Baloo told him that honey and nuts were just as pleasant to eat as raw meat -RRB- he climbed up for it , and that Bagheera showed him how to do .
3 Bagheera would lie out on a branch and call , `` Come along , Little Brother , '' and at first Mowgli would cling like the sloth , but afterward he would fling himself through the branches almost as boldly as the gray ape .
4 He took his place at the Council Rock , too , when the Pack met , and there he discovered that if he stared hard at any wolf , the wolf would be forced to drop his eyes , and so he used to stare for fun .
5 At other times he would pick the long thorns out of the pads of his friends , for wolves suffer terribly from thorns and burs in their coats .
6 He would go down the hillside into the cultivated lands by night , and look very curiously at the villagers in their huts , but he had a mistrust of men because Bagheera showed him a square box with a drop gate so cunningly hidden in the jungle that he nearly walked into it , and told him that it was a trap .
7 He loved better than anything else to go with Bagheera into the dark warm heart of the forest , to sleep all through the drowsy day , and at night see how Bagheera did his killing .
8 Bagheera killed right and left as he felt hungry , and so did Mowgli -- with one exception .
9 As soon as he was old enough to understand things , Bagheera told him that he must never touch cattle because he had been bought into the Pack at the price of a bull 's life .
10 `` All the jungle is thine , '' said Bagheera , `` and thou canst kill everything that thou art strong enough to kill ; but for the sake of the bull that bought thee thou must never kill or eat any cattle young or old .
11 That is the Law of the Jungle . ''
12 Mowgli obeyed faithfully .
13 And he grew and grew strong as a boy must grow who does not know that he is learning any lessons , and who has nothing in the world to think of except things to eat .
14 Mother Wolf told him once or twice that Shere Khan was not a creature to be trusted , and that some day he must kill Shere Khan .
15 But though a young wolf would have remembered that advice every hour , Mowgli forgot it because he was only a boy -- though he would have called himself a wolf if he had been able to speak in any human tongue .
16 Shere Khan was always crossing his path in the jungle , for as Akela grew older and feebler the lame tiger had come to be great friends with the younger wolves of the Pack , who followed him for scraps , a thing Akela would never have allowed if he had dared to push his authority to the proper bounds .
17 Then Shere Khan would flatter them and wonder that such fine young hunters were content to be led by a dying wolf and a man 's cub .
18 `` They tell me , '' Shere Khan would say , `` that at Council ye dare not look him between the eyes . ''
19 And the young wolves would growl and bristle .
20 Bagheera , who had eyes and ears everywhere , knew something of this , and once or twice he told Mowgli in so many words that Shere Khan would kill him some day .
21 Mowgli would laugh and answer : `` I have the Pack and I have thee ; and Baloo , though he is so lazy , might strike a blow or two for my XXXXX .	sake		Jungle|Law|advice|anything|branches|day|fun|hillside|pads|sake

1 He was scarred all over with the marks of savage fights , but he was always ready for just one fight more .
2 He would put his head on one side , as though he were afraid to look his enemy in the face ; then he would shoot it out like lightning , and when the big teeth were firmly fixed on the other seal 's neck , the other seal might get away if he could , but Sea Catch would not help him .
3 Yet Sea Catch never chased a beaten seal , for that was against the Rules of the Beach .
4 He only wanted room by the sea for his nursery .
5 But as there were forty or fifty thousand other seals hunting for the same thing each spring , the whistling , bellowing , roaring , and blowing on the beach was something frightful .
6 From a little hill called Hutchinson 's Hill , you could look over three and a half miles of ground covered with fighting seals ; and the surf was dotted all over with the heads of seals hurrying to land and begin their share of the fighting .
7 They fought in the breakers , they fought in the sand , and they fought on the smooth-worn basalt rocks of the nurseries , for they were just as stupid and unaccommodating as men .
8 Their wives never came to the island until late in May or early in June , for they did not care to be torn to pieces ; and the young two - , three - , and four-year-old seals who had not begun housekeeping went inland about half a mile through the ranks of the fighters and played about on the sand dunes in droves and legions , and rubbed off every single green thing that grew .
9 They were called the holluschickie -- the bachelors -- and there were perhaps two or three hundred thousand of them at Novastoshnah alone .
10 Sea Catch had just finished his forty-fifth fight one spring when Matkah , his soft , sleek , gentle-eyed wife , came up out of the sea , and he caught her by the scruff of the neck and dumped her down on his reservation , saying gruffly : `` Late as usual .
11 Where have you been ? ''
12 It was not the fashion for Sea Catch to eat anything during the four months he stayed on the beaches , and so his temper was generally bad .
13 Matkah knew better than to answer back .
14 She looked round and cooed : `` How thoughtful of you .
