1 In the middle of the spear you must have two strong chains ten fathoms in length .
2 As soon as the Dragon has made himself fast to the spear , which you must thrust through his jaws , you must spring quickly from the iron horse and fasten the ends of the chains firmly to the ground with iron stakes , so that he can not get away from them .
3 After two or three days the monster 's strength will be so far exhausted that you will be able to come near him .
4 Then you can put Solomon 's ring upon your left thumb and give him the finishing stroke , but keep the ring on your third finger until you have come close to him , so that the monster can not see you , else he might strike you dead with his long tail .
5 But when all is done , take care you do not lose the ring , and that no one takes it from you by cunning . '
6 The young man thanked the magician for his directions , and promised , should they succeed , to reward him .
7 But the magician answered , ' I have profited so much by the wisdom the ring has taught me that I desire no other reward . '
8 Then they parted , and the youth quickly flew home through the air .
9 After remaining in his own home for some weeks , he heard people say that the terrible Dragon of the North was not far off , and might shortly be expected in the country .
10 The King announced publicly that he would give his daughter in marriage , as well as a large part of his kingdom , to whosoever should free the country from the monster .
11 The youth then went to the King and told him that he had good hopes of subduing the Dragon , if the King would grant him all he desired for the purpose .
12 The King willingly agreed , and the iron horse , the great spear , and the chains were all prepared as the youth requested .
13 When all was ready , it was found that the iron horse was so heavy that a hundred men could not move it from the spot , so the youth found there was nothing for it but to move it with his own strength by means of the magic ring .
14 The Dragon was now so near that in a couple of springs he would be over the frontier .
15 The youth now began to consider how he should act , for if he had to push the iron horse from behind he could not ride upon it as the sorcerer had said he must .
16 But a raven unexpectedly gave him this advice : ` Ride upon the horse , and push the spear against the ground , as if you were pushing off a boat from the land . '
17 The youth did so , and found that in this way he could easily move forwards .
18 The Dragon had his monstrous jaws wide open , all ready for his expected prey .
19 A few paces nearer , and man and horse would have been swallowed up by them !
20 The youth trembled with horror , and his blood ran cold , yet he did not lose his courage ; but , holding the iron spear upright in his hand , he brought it down with all his might right through the monster 's lower jaw .
21 Then quick as lightning he sprang from his horse before the XXXXX had time to shut his mouth .	Dragon		Dragon|North|advice|frontier|land|paces|purpose|spear|thumb|youth

1 One day , whilst passing near a fountain in the garden , she noticed that the sun 's rays fell on the water in such a manner as to produce a brilliant rainbow .
2 She stood still to admire it , when , to her great surprise , she heard a voice addressing her which seemed to come from the centre of its rays .
3 The voice was that of a young man , and its sweetness of tone and the agreeable things it uttered , led one to infer that its owner must be equally charming ; but this had to be a mere matter of fancy , for no one was visible .
4 The beautiful Rainbow informed Fairer-than-a-Fairy that he was young , the son of a powerful king , and that the Fairy , Lagree , who owed his parents a grudge , had revenged herself by depriving him of his natural shape for some years ; that she had imprisoned him in the palace , where he had found his confinement hard to bear for some time , but now , he owned , he no longer sighed for freedom since he had seen and learned to love Fairer-than-a-Fairy .
5 He added many other tender speeches to this declaration , and the Princess , to whom such remarks were a new experience , could not help feeling pleased and touched by his attentions .
6 The Prince could only appear or speak under the form of a Rainbow , and it was therefore necessary that the sun should shine on water so as to enable the rays to form themselves .
7 Fairer-than-a-Fairy lost no moment in which she could meet her lover , and they enjoyed many long and interesting interviews .
8 One day , however , their conversation became so absorbing and time passed so quickly that the Princess forgot to attend to the fire , and it went out .
9 Lagree , on her return , soon found out the neglect , and seemed only too pleased to have the opportunity of showing her spite to her lovely prisoner .
10 She ordered Fairer-than-a-Fairy to start next day at dawn to ask Locrinos for fire with which to relight the one she had allowed to go out .
11 Now this Locrinos was a cruel monster who devoured everyone he came across , and especially enjoyed a chance of catching and eating any young girls .
12 Our heroine obeyed with great sweetness , and without having been able to take leave of her lover she set off to go to Locrinos as to certain death .
13 As she was crossing a wood a bird sang to her to pick up a shining pebble which she would find in a fountain close by , and to use it when needed .
14 She took the bird 's advice , and in due time arrived at the house of Locrinos .
15 Luckily she only found his wife at home , who was much struck by the Princess 's youth and beauty and sweet gentle manners , and still further impressed by the present of the shining pebble .
16 She readily let Fairer-than-a-Fairy have the fire , and in return for the stone she gave her another , which , she said , might prove useful some day .
17 Then she sent her away without doing her any harm .
18 Lagree was as much surprised as displeased at the happy result of this expedition , and Fairer-than-a Fairy waited anxiously for an opportunity of meeting Prince Rainbow and telling him her adventures .
19 She found , however , that he had already been told all about them by a Fairy who protected him , and to whom he was related .
20 The dread of fresh dangers to his beloved Princess made him devise some more convenient way of meeting than by the garden fountain , and Fairer-than-a-Fairy carried out his plan daily with entire success .
21 Every morning she placed a large basin full of water on her window-sill , and as soon as the sun 's rays fell on the water the Rainbow appeared as clearly as it had ever done in the XXXXX .	fountain		death|fountain|house|leave|man|monster|parents|pebble|son|surprise

5 If you strew it about even in the hottest summer the air at once becomes cold , and snow falls , and the people freeze . '
6 Then the Simpleton asked him also to join them .
7 At last the ship , with its strange crew , arrived at the King 's Court .
8 The King was having his dinner , but he at once despatched one of his courtiers to find out what the huge , strange new bird could be that had come flying through the air .
9 The courtier peeped into the ship , and , seeing what it was , instantly went back to the King and told him that it was a flying ship , and that it was manned by a few peasants .
10 Then the King remembered his royal oath ; but he made up his mind that he would never consent to let the Princess marry a poor peasant .
11 So he thought and thought , and then said to himself : ' I will give him some impossible tasks to perform ; that will be the best way of getting rid of him . '
12 And he there and then decided to despatch one of his courtiers to the Simpleton , with the command that he was to fetch the King the healing water from the world 's end before he had finished his dinner .
13 But while the King was still instructing the courtier exactly what he was to say , the first man of the ship 's company , the one with the miraculous power of hearing , had overheard the King 's words , and hastily reported them to the poor Simpleton .
14 ` Alas , alas ! '
15 he cried ; ` what am I to do now ?
16 It would take me quite a year , possibly my whole life , to find the water . '
17 ` Never fear , ' said his fleet-footed comrade , ' I will fetch what the King wants . '
18 Just then the courtier arrived , bearing the King 's command .
19 ` Tell his Majesty , ' said the Simpleton , ` that his orders shall be obeyed ; ` and forthwith the swift runner unbound the foot that was strung up behind his ear and started off , and in less than no time had reached the world 's end and drawn the healing water from the well .

1 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
2 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
3 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
4 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
5 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
6 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
7 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
8 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
9 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
10 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
11 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
12 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
13 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
14 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
15 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
16 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
17 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
18 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
19 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
20 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
21 And as the children ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the XXXXX had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .	cat		bit|cat|comb|ground|leaves|limb|oven|pieces|river|sight

1 But it was not a book , but a little mechanical toy , which lay in a box -- an artificial nightingale which was like the real one , only that it was set all over with diamonds , rubies , and sapphires .
2 When it was wound up , it could sing the piece the real bird sang , and moved its tail up and down , and glittered with silver and gold .

4 ` This is magnificent ! '

6 ` Now they must sing together ; what a duet we shall have ! '
7 And so they sang together , but their voices did not blend , for the real Nightingale sang in her way and the clockwork bird sang waltzes .
8 ` It is not its fault ! '
9 said the bandmaster ; ` it keeps very good time and is quite after my style ! '
10 Then the artificial bird had to sing alone .
11 It gave just as much pleasure as the real one , and then it was so much prettier to look at ; it sparkled like bracelets and necklaces .
12 Three-and-thirty times it sang the same piece without being tired .
13 People would like to have heard it again , but the Emperor thought that the living Nightingale should sing now -- but where was she ?

14 He did n't find the nest for the very good reason that Carol had n't built one yet .

1 Now the story comes back to Red , who came into the hall and showed the King his right arm wanting the hand , and said that now he could see what kind of a man his intended son-in-law was , for he had done this to him without any cause whatever .
2 The King became very angry , and said he would soon find out the truth about it , and if Ring had cut off his hand without good cause he should be hanged ; but if it was otherwise , then Red should die .
3 So the King sent for Ring and asked him for what reason he had done this .
4 Snati , however , had just told Ring what had happened during the night , and in reply he asked the King to go with him and he would show him something .
5 The King went with him to his sleeping-room , and saw lying on the bed a man 's hand holding a sword .
6 ` This hand , ' said Ring , ` came over the partition during the night , and was about to run me through in my bed , if I had not defended myself . '
7 The King answered that in that case he could not blame him for protecting his own life , and that Red was well worthy of death .
8 So Red was hanged , and Ring married the King 's daughter .
9 The first night that they went to bed together Snati asked Ring to allow him to lie at their feet , and this Ring allowed him to do .

7 ` Do n't you think that a desperate errand ? '
8 said the King , ` seeing they are so dangerous , and no one has ever yet ventured to go against them ? '
9 Red answered that he had only one life to lose , and it would be interesting to see how brave he was ; besides , the King would have good reason to ennoble him if he overcame them .
10 The King at last allowed himself , though rather unwillingly , to be won over by Red 's persistency , and one day asked Ring to go and kill the oxen that were in the wood for him , and bring their horns and hides to him in the evening .

5 The neighbourhood pleased him , and he saw that the pasture was rich and suitable for his flocks .
6 So he brought his sheep there , and herded them as before .
7 The shepherd and shepherdess became great friends , but they did not recognise each other in the least .

15 Once upon a time there was a Glass Mountain at the top of which stood a castle made of pure gold , and in front of the castle there grew an apple-tree on which there were golden apples .
16 Anyone who picked an apple gained admittance into the golden castle , and there in a silver room sat an enchanted Princess of surpassing fairness and beauty .
17 She was as rich too as she was beautiful , for the cellars of the castle were full of precious stones , and great chests of the finest gold stood round the walls of all the rooms .

6 The walls , washed by the quiet waters , were covered with gold , which made one think of the yellow sands .
7 Above them was a rampart of orange and lemon trees , and all the streets were paved with gold .
8 The King of this beautiful island had one son , for whom a life of adventure had been foretold at his birth .
9 This so frightened his father and mother that in order to comfort them a Fairy , who happened to be present at the time , produced a little pebble which she told them to keep for the Prince till he grew up , as by putting it in his mouth he would become invisible , as long as he did not try to speak , for if he did the stone would lose all its virtue .
10 In this way the good fairy hoped that the Prince would be protected against all dangers .
11 No sooner did the Prince begin to grow out of boyhood than he longed to see if the other countries of the world were as splendid as the one in which he lived .
12 So , under pretence of visiting some small islands that belonged to his father , he set out .
13 But a frightful storm drove his ship on to unknown shores , where most of his followers were put to death by the savages , and the Prince himself only managed to escape by making use of his magic pebble .
14 By this means he passed through the midst of them unseen , and wandered on till he reached the coast , where he re-embarked on board his ship .

1 He listened to all he heard , and determined that he too would try his luck .
2 But first he went to the forest and caught a lynx , and cutting off the creature 's sharp claws , he fastened them on to his own hands and feet .
3 Armed with these weapons he boldly started up the Glass Mountain .
4 The sun was nearly going down , and the youth had not got more than half-way up .
5 He could hardly draw breath he was so worn out , and his mouth was parched by thirst .
6 A huge black cloud passed over his head , but in vain did he beg and beseech her to let a drop of water fall on him .
7 He opened his mouth , but the black cloud sailed past and not as much as a drop of dew moistened his dry lips .
8 His feet were torn and bleeding , and he could only hold on now with his hands .
9 Evening closed in , and he strained his eyes to see if he could behold the top of the mountain .
10 Then he gazed beneath him , and what a sight met his eyes !
11 A yawning abyss , with certain and terrible death at the bottom , reeking with half-decayed bodies of horses and riders !
12 And this had been the end of all the other brave men who like himself had attempted the ascent .
13 It was almost pitch dark now , and only the stars lit up the Glass Mountain .
14 The poor boy still clung on as if glued to the glass by his blood-stained hands .
15 He made no struggle to get higher , for all his strength had left him , and seeing no hope he calmly awaited death .
16 Then all of a sudden he fell into a deep sleep , and forgetful of his dangerous position , he slumbered sweetly .
17 But all the same , although he slept , he had stuck his sharp claws so firmly into the glass that he was quite safe not to fall .
18 Now the golden apple-tree was guarded by the eagle which had overthrown the golden knight and his horse .
19 Every night it flew round the Glass Mountain keeping a careful look-out , and no sooner had the moon emerged from the clouds than the bird rose up from the apple-tree , and circling round in the air , caught sight of the sleeping youth .
20 Greedy for carrion , and sure that this must be a fresh corpse , the bird swooped down upon the boy .
21 But he was awake now , and perceiving the XXXXX , he determined by its help to save himself .	eagle		bleeding|breath|eagle|forest|forgetful|head|mountain|sleep|weapons|youth

7 I wish you were down here with me !
8 There are no mice in the air , I 'm afraid , but you might catch a bat , and that 's very like a mouse , you know .
9 But do cats eat bats , I wonder ? '
10 And here Alice began to get rather sleepy , and went on saying to herself , in a dreamy sort of way , ` Do cats eat bats ?
11 Do cats eat bats ? '
12 and sometimes , ` Do bats eat cats ? '
13 for , you see , as she could n't answer either question , it did n't much matter which way she put it .
14 She felt that she was dozing off , and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah , and saying to her very earnestly , ` Now , Dinah , tell me the truth : did you ever eat a bat ? '
15 when suddenly , thump !
16 thump !
17 down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves , and the fall was over .
18 Alice was not a bit hurt , and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment : she looked up , but it was all dark overhead ; before her was another long passage , and the White Rabbit was still in sight , hurrying down it .
19 There was not a moment to be lost : away went Alice like the wind , and was just in time to hear it say , as it turned a corner , ` Oh my ears and whiskers , how late it 's getting ! '
20 She was close behind it when she turned the corner , but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen : she found herself in a long , low hall , which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof .
21 There were doors all round the hall , but they were all locked ; and when Alice had been all the XXXXX down one side and up the other , trying every door , she walked sadly down the middle , wondering how she was ever to get out again .	way		Rabbit|air|ears|matter|mice|nothing|question|thump|way|whiskers

1 I wo n't go , ' said he , ` unless I get the gold cloak . '
2 ` Though I should die you sha n't have that , ' said the hag .
3 ` Die , then , ' said the son .
4 ` Well , then , take it , ' said the old hag , ` and be off with you , but you must make haste with the water . '
5 He put on the cloak , and when he came outside it shone so bright that he could see to go with it .
6 On reaching the river he went to take a drink like his sister , but at that moment Ring and Snati sprang upon him , took the cloak from him , and threw him into the river .
7 The old hag could stand the thirst no longer , and asked her husband to go for a drink for her ; the brats , she said , were of course running about and playing themselves , just as she had expected they would , little wretches that they were . '
8 I wo n't go , ' said the old troll , ` unless you lend me the gold chess-board . '
9 ` Though I should die you sha n't have that , ' said the hag . '
10 I think you may just as well do that , ' said he , ` since you wo n't grant me such a little favour . '
11 ` Take it , then , you utter disgrace ! '
12 said the old hag , ` since you are just like these two brats . '
13 The old troll now went out with the gold chess-board , and down to the river , and was about to take a drink , when Ring and Snati came upon him , took the chess-board from him , and threw him into the river .
14 Before they had got back again , however , and up on top of the cave , they saw the poor old fellow 's ghost come marching up from the river .
15 Snati immediately sprang upon him , and Ring assisted in the attack , and after a hard struggle they mastered him a second time .
16 When they got back again to the window they saw that the old hag was moving towards the door .
17 ` Now we must go in at once , ' said Snati , ` and try to master her there , for if she once gets out we shall have no chance with her .
18 She is the worst witch that ever lived , and no iron can cut her .
19 One of us must pour boiling porridge out of the pot on her , and the other punch her with red-hot iron . '

6 `` Stand what ? ''
7 I asked .

10 If your aunt were not so -- unreasonable , I should never have stooped to it . ''
11 `` It is all my fault , '' I said contritely .
12 `` Well , I hardly meant that , '' he said grimly .
13 `` But had n't I better go frankly to your aunt and lay the whole case before her ? ''
14 `` You would never see me again if you did that , '' I said hastily -- and then wished I had n't .
15 `` That is the worst threat you could make , '' he said .
16 July Twenty-fifth .

3 She also sent a message to the Prince 's attendants that they might travel slowly back to the Court of King Peridor , and that the beautiful bird had really been found .
4 This matter being comfortably arranged , she started off her chariot .
5 But in spite of the swiftness with which they flew through the air , the time passed even quicker for Saphir and Serpentine , who had so much to think about .
6 They were still quite confused with the pleasure of seeing each other , when the chariot arrived at King Peridor 's palace .
7 He had had himself carried to a room on the roof , where his nurses thought that he would die at any moment .
8 Directly the chariot drew within sight of the castle the beautiful bird took flight , and , making straight for the dying King , at once cured him of his sickness .
9 Then she resumed her natural shape , and he found that the bird was no other than the Queen Constance , whom he had long believed to be dead .
10 Peridor was rejoiced to embrace his wife and his son once more , and with the help of the fairies began to make preparations for the marriage of Saphir and Serpentine , who turned out to be the daughter of Aglantine and Diamantino , and as much a princess as he was a prince .
11 The people of the kingdom were delighted , and everybody lived happy and contented to the end of their lives .

1 He collected a heap of gold , but at last he thought to himself , ` What good is all my gold to me if I stay at home ?
2 I will travel and look a bit about me in the world . '
3 So he took leave of his parents , slung his hunting knapsack and his gun round him , and journeyed into the world .
4 It happened that one day he went through a thick wood , and when he came to the end of it there lay in the plain before him a large castle .
5 At one of the windows in it stood an old woman with a most beautiful maiden by her side , looking out .
6 But the old woman was a witch , and she said to the girl , ` There comes one out of the wood who has a wonderful treasure in his body which we must manage to possess ourselves of , darling daughter ; we have more right to it than he .
7 He has a bird 's heart in him , and so every morning there lies a gold piece under his pillow . '
8 She told her how they could get hold of it , and how she was to coax it from him , and at last threatened her angrily , saying , ` And if you do not obey me , you shall repent it ! '
9 When the Hunter came nearer he saw the maiden , and said to himself , ' I have travelled so far now that I will rest , and turn into this beautiful castle ; money I have in plenty . '
10 But the real reason was that he had caught sight of the lovely face .
11 He went into the house , and was kindly received and hospitably entertained .
12 It was not long before he was so much in love with the witch-maiden that he thought of nothing else , and only looked in her eyes , and whatever she wanted , that he gladly did .
13 Then the old witch said , ` Now we must have the bird-heart ; he will not feel when it is gone . '
14 She prepared a drink , and when it was ready she poured it in a goblet and gave it to the maiden , who had to hand it to the hunter .
15 ` Drink to me now , my dearest , ' she said .
16 Then he took the goblet , and when he had swallowed the drink the bird-heart came out of his mouth .
17 The maiden had to get hold of it secretly and then swallow it herself , for the old witch wanted to have it .
18 Thenceforward he found no more gold under his pillow , and it lay under the maiden 's ; but he was so much in love and so much bewitched that he thought of nothing except spending all his time with the maiden .

1 To be sure , Charlotta 's intentions were always good .
2 But Miss Corona was not thinking about Charlotta this morning , and she felt so strong a distaste for her lonely , purposeless life that she was in no haste to go forth to meet another day of it .
3 Miss Corona felt just the least little bit tired of living , although she feared it was very wicked of her to feel so .
4 She lay there listlessly for half an hour longer , looking through a mist of tears at the portrait of her stern old father hanging on the wall at the foot of the bed , and thinking over the Quarrel .
5 It had happened thirty years ago , when Miss Corona had been a girl of twenty , living alone with her father at the old Gordon homestead on the hill , with the big black spruce grove behind it on the north and far-reaching slopes of green fields before it on the south .
6 Down in the little northern valley below the spruce grove lived her uncle , Alexis Gordon .
7 His son , Meredith , had seemed to Corona as her own brother .
8 The mothers of both were dead ; neither had any other brother or sister .
9 The two children had grown up together , playmates and devoted friends .
10 There had never been any sentiment or lovemaking between them to mar a perfect comradeship .
11 They were only the best of friends , whatever plans the fathers might have cherished for the union of their estates and children , putting the property consideration first , as the Gordons were always prone to do .
12 But , if Roderick and Alexis Gordon had any such plans , all went by the board when they quarreled .
13 Corona shivered yet over the bitterness of that time .
14 The Gordons never did anything half-heartedly .
15 The strife between the two brothers was determined and irreconcilable .
16 Corona 's father forbade her to speak to her uncle and cousin or to hold any communication with them .
17 Corona wept and obeyed him .
18 She had always obeyed her father ; it had never entered into her mind to do anything else .
19 Meredith had resented her attitude hotly , and from that day they had never spoken or met , while the years came and went , each making a little wider and more hopeless the gulf of coldness and anger and distrust .
20 Ten years later Roderick Gordon died , and in five months Alexis Gordon followed him to the grave .
21 The two XXXXX who had hated each other so unyieldingly in life slept very peaceably side by side in the old Gordon plot of the country graveyard , but their rancour still served to embitter the lives of their descendants .	brothers		brothers|communication|comradeship|homestead|mothers|plans|playmates|son|strife|years

1 Only the children had no fear , and reached the other side in safety .
2 Still , though the chief and the young girl quailed in terror at these horrible sights and sounds , no harm came to them , for their lives had been free from evil , and the Master of Life had said that no evil should happen unto them .
3 So they reached unhurt the shore of the Happy Island , and wandered through the flowery fields and by the banks of rushing streams , and they knew not hunger nor thirst ; neither cold nor heat .
4 The air fed them and the sun warmed them , and they forgot the dead , for they saw no graves , and the young man 's thoughts turned not to wars , neither to the hunting of animals .
5 And gladly would these two have walked thus for ever , but in the murmur of the wind he heard the Master of Life saying to him , ` Return whither you came , for I have work for you to do , and your people need you , and for many years you shall rule over them .
6 At the gate my messenger awaits you , and you shall take again your body which you left behind , and he will show you what you are to do .
7 Listen to him , and have patience , and in time to come you shall rejoin her whom you must now leave , for she is accepted , and will remain ever young and beautiful , as when I called her hence from the Land of Snows . '
8 THE WHITE DUCK Once upon a time a great and powerful King married a lovely Princess .
9 No couple were ever so happy ; but before their honeymoon was over they were forced to part , for the King had to go on a warlike expedition to a far country , and leave his young wife alone at home .
10 Bitter were the tears she shed , while her husband sought in vain to soothe her with words of comfort and counsel , warning her , above all things , never to leave the castle , to hold no intercourse with strangers , to beware of evil counsellors , and especially to be on her guard against strange women .
11 And the Queen promised faithfully to obey her royal lord and master in these four matters .
12 So when the King set out on his expedition she shut herself up with her ladies in her own apartments , and spent her time in spinning and weaving , and in thinking of her royal husband .
13 Often she was very sad and lonely , and it happened that one day while she was seated at the window , letting salt tears drop on her work , an old woman , a kind , homely-looking old body , stepped up to the window , and , leaning upon her crutch , addressed the Queen in friendly , flattering tones , saying : ` Why are you sad and cast down , fair Queen ?
14 You should not mope all day in your rooms , but should come out into the green garden , and hear the birds sing with joy among the trees , and see the butterflies fluttering above the flowers , and hear the bees and insects hum , and watch the sunbeams chase the dew-drops through the rose-leaves and in the lily-cups .
15 All the brightness outside would help to drive away your cares , O Queen . '
16 For long the Queen resisted her coaxing words , remembering the promise she had given the King , her husband ; but at last she thought to herself : After all , what harm would it do if I were to go into the garden for a short time and enjoy myself among the trees and flowers , and the singing birds and fluttering butterflies and humming insects , and look at the dew-drops hiding from the sunbeams in the hearts of the roses and lilies , and wander about in the sunshine , instead of remaining all day in this room ?
17 For she had no idea that the kind-looking old woman leaning on her crutch was in reality a wicked witch , who envied the Queen her good fortune , and was determined to ruin her .
18 And so , in all ignorance , the Queen followed her out into the garden and listened to her smooth , flattering words .
19 Now , in the middle of the garden there was a pond of water , clear as crystal , and the old woman said to the Queen : ` The day is so warm , and the sun 's rays so scorching , that the water in the pond looks very cool and inviting .
20 Would you not like to bathe in it , fair Queen ? '
21 ` No , I think not , ' answered the Queen ; but the next moment she regretted her XXXXX , and thought to herself : Why should n't I bathe in that cool , fresh water ?	words		garden|graves|home|husband|idea|shore|tears|thoughts|time|words

2 PRINCE RING -LRB- 30 -RRB- -LRB- 30 -RRB- From the Icelandic .
3 Once upon a time there was a King and his Queen in their kingdom .
4 They had one daughter , who was called Ingiborg , and one son , whose name was Ring .
5 He was less fond of adventures than men of rank usually were in those days , and was not famous for strength or feats of arms .
6 When he was twelve years old , one fine winter day he rode into the forest along with his men to enjoy himself .
7 They went on a long way , until they caught sight of a hind with a gold ring on its horns .
8 The Prince was eager to catch it , if possible , so they gave chase and rode on without stopping until all the horses began to founder beneath them .
9 At last the Prince 's horse gave way too , and then there came over them a darkness so black that they could no longer see the hind .
10 By this time they were far away from any house , and thought it was high time to be making their way home again , but they found they had got lost now .
11 At first they all kept together , but soon each began to think that he knew the right way best ; so they separated , and all went in different directions .
12 The Prince , too , had got lost like the rest , and wandered on for a time until he came to a little clearing in the forest not far from the sea , where he saw a woman sitting on a chair and a big barrel standing beside her .
13 The Prince went up to her and saluted her politely , and she received him very graciously .
14 He looked down into the barrel then , and saw lying at the bottom an unusually beautiful gold ring , which pleased him so much that he could not take his eyes off it .
15 The woman saw this , and said that he might have it if he would take the trouble to get it ; for which the Prince thanked her , and said it was at least worth trying .
16 So he leaned over into the barrel , which did not seem very deep , and thought he would easily reach the ring ; but the more he stretched down after it the deeper grew the barrel .
17 As he was thus bending down into it the woman suddenly rose up and pushed him in head first , saying that now he could take up his quarters there .
18 Then she fixed the top on the barrel and threw it out into the sea .
19 The Prince thought himself in a bad plight now , as he felt the barrel floating out from the land and tossing about on the waves .
20 How many days he spent thus he could not tell , but at last he felt that the barrel was knocking against rocks , at which he was a little cheered , thinking it was probably land and not merely a reef in the sea .
21 Being something of a swimmer , he at last made up his mind to kick the XXXXX out of the barrel , and having done so he was able to get on shore , for the rocks by the sea were smooth and level ; but overhead there were high cliffs .	bottom		Ring|bottom|directions|forest|home|house|name|sea|son|winter

3 ` Fellow , what are you puffing at up there ? '
4 asked the man .
5 He replied , ` Two miles from this place are standing seven windmills ; see , I am blowing to drive them round . '
6 ` Oh , go with me , ' said the man ; ` if we four are together we shall easily travel through the wide world . '
7 So the blower got down and went with him , and after a time they saw a man who was standing on one leg , and had unstrapped the other and laid it near him .
8 Then said the master , ` You have made yourself very comfortable to rest ! ' '
9 I am a runner , ' answered he ; ` and so that I shall not go too quickly , I have unstrapped one leg ; when I run with two legs , I go faster than a bird flies . '
10 ` Oh , go with me ; if we five are together , we shall easily travel through the wide world . '
11 So he went with him , and , not long afterwards , they met a man who wore a little hat , but he had it slouched over one ear .

18 The King replied , ` Then both your heads must be staked , and your head and his must be guaranteed for the winner . '

7 They should hear it sing , commanded the Emperor .
8 And they heard it , and they were as pleased as if they had been intoxicated with tea , after the Chinese fashion , and they all said ` Oh ! '
9 and held up their forefingers and nodded time .
10 But the poor fishermen who had heard the real Nightingale said : ` This one sings well enough , the tunes glide out ; but there is something wanting -- I do n't know what ! '
11 The real Nightingale was banished from the kingdom .
12 The artificial bird was put on silken cushions by the Emperor 's bed , all the presents which it received , gold and precious stones , lay round it , and it was given the title of Imperial Night-singer , First from the left .
13 For the Emperor counted that side as the more distinguished , being the side on which the heart is ; the Emperor 's heart is also on the left .
14 And the bandmaster wrote a work of twenty-five volumes about the artificial bird .
15 It was so learned , long , and so full of the hardest Chinese words that everyone said they had read it and understood it ; for once they had been very stupid about a book , and had been trampled under foot in consequence .
16 So a whole year passed .

1 ` See that you do it well , then , ' growled the witch .
2 ` If I am pleased with you , I 'll reward you ; but if I am not , I 'll put you in a pan and fry you in the oven -- that 's what I 'll do with you , my pretty dears !
3 You have been gently reared , but you 'll find my work hard enough .
4 See if you do n't . '
5 And , so saying , she set the girl down to spin yarn , and she gave the boy a sieve in which to carry water from the well , and she herself went out into the wood .
6 Now , as the girl was sitting at her distaff , weeping bitterly because she could not spin , she heard the sound of hundreds of little feet , and from every hole and corner in the hut mice came pattering along the floor , squeaking and saying : ` Little girl , why are your eyes so red ?
7 If you want help , then give us some bread . '
8 And the girl gave them the bread that her grandmother had given her .
9 Then the mice told her that the witch had a cat , and the cat was very fond of ham ; if she would give the cat her ham , it would show her the way out of the wood , and in the meantime they would spin the yarn for her .
10 So the girl set out to look for the cat , and , as she was hunting about , she met her brother , in great trouble because he could not carry water from the well in a sieve , as it came pouring out as fast as he put it in .
11 And as she was trying to comfort him they heard a rustling of wings , and a flight of wrens alighted on the ground beside them .
12 And the wrens said : ` Give us some crumbs , then you need not grieve .
13 For you 'll find that water will stay in the sieve . '
14 Then the twins crumbled their bread on the ground , and the wrens pecked it , and chirruped and chirped .
15 And when they had eaten the last crumb they told the boy to fill up the holes of the sieve with clay , and then to draw water from the well .
16 So he did what they said , and carried the sieve full of water into the hut without spilling a drop .
17 When they entered the hut the cat was curled up on the floor .
18 So they stroked her , and fed her with ham , and said to her : ` Pussy , grey pussy , tell us how we are to get away from the witch ? '
19 Then the cat thanked them for the ham , and gave them a pocket-handkerchief and a comb , and told them that when the witch pursued them , as she certainly would , all they had to do was to throw the handkerchief on the ground and run as fast as they could .
20 As soon as the handkerchief touched the ground a deep , broad river would spring up , which would hinder the witch 's progress .
21 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the XXXXX so long that they would be able to get safely away .	witch		bread|floor|fry|ham|help|hunting|mice|trouble|way|witch

1 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
2 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
3 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
4 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
5 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
6 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
7 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
8 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
9 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
10 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
11 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
12 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
13 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
14 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
15 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
16 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
17 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
18 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
19 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
20 And as the children ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the cat had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .
21 So when the XXXXX came up to it on her broom she found that there was nothing for it but to turn round and go back to her hut .	witch		eyes|forest|fright|girl|help|ribbons|thought|time|twigs|witch

1 I think I could , if I only know how to begin . '
2 For , you see , so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately , that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible .
3 There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door , so she went back to the table , half hoping she might find another key on it , or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes : this time she found a little bottle on it , -LRB- ` which certainly was not here before , ' said Alice , -RRB- and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label , with the words ` DRINK ME ' beautifully printed on it in large letters .
4 It was all very well to say ` Drink me , ' but the wise little Alice was not going to do THAT in a hurry .
5 ` No , I 'll look first , ' she said , ` and see whether it 's marked `` poison '' or not ' ; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt , and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things , all because they WOULD not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them : such as , that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long ; and that if you cut your finger VERY deeply with a knife , it usually bleeds ; and she had never forgotten that , if you drink much from a bottle marked ` poison , ' it is almost certain to disagree with you , sooner or later .
6 However , this bottle was NOT marked ` poison , ' so Alice ventured to taste it , and finding it very nice , -LRB- it had , in fact , a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart , custard , pine-apple , roast turkey , toffee , and hot buttered toast , -RRB- she very soon finished it off .
7 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * ` What a curious feeling ! '
8 said Alice ; ' I must be shutting up like a telescope . '
9 And so it was indeed : she was now only ten inches high , and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden .
10 First , however , she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further : she felt a little nervous about this ; ` for it might end , you know , ' said Alice to herself , ` in my going out altogether , like a candle .
11 I wonder what I should be like then ? '
12 And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out , for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing .
13 After a while , finding that nothing more happened , she decided on going into the garden at once ; but , alas for poor Alice !
14 when she got to the door , she found she had forgotten the little golden key , and when she went back to the table for it , she found she could not possibly reach it : she could see it quite plainly through the glass , and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table , but it was too slippery ; and when she had tired herself out with trying , the poor little thing sat down and cried .
15 ` Come , there 's no use in crying like that ! '
16 said Alice to herself , rather sharply ; ' I advise you to leave off this minute ! '
17 She generally gave herself very good advice , -LRB- though she very seldom followed it -RRB- , and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes ; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself , for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people .
18 ` But it 's no use now , ' thought poor Alice , ` to pretend to be two people !
19 Why , there 's hardly enough of me left to make ONE respectable person ! '
20 Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table : she opened it , and found in it a very small cake , on which the words ` EAT ME ' were beautifully marked in currants .
21 ` Well , I 'll eat it , ' said Alice , ` and if it makes me grow larger , I can reach the key ; and if it makes me grow smaller , I can creep under the XXXXX ; so either way I 'll get into the garden , and I do n't care which happens ! 5 Once upon a time when wishes came true there was a king 's son who was enchanted by an old witch , so that he was obliged to sit in a large iron stove in a wood .
6 There he lived for many years , and no one could free him .
7 At last a king 's daughter came into the wood ; she had lost her way , and could not find her father 's kingdom again .
8 She had been wandering round and round for nine days , and she came at last to the iron case .
9 A voice came from within and asked her , ` Where do you come from , and where do you want to go ? '
10 She answered , ' I have lost my way to my father 's kingdom , and I shall never get home again . '
11 Then the voice from the iron stove said , ' I will help you to find your home again , and that in a very short time , if you will promise to do what I ask you .
12 I am a greater prince than you are a princess , and I will marry you . '

1 Once upon a time there was a king who determined to take a long voyage .
2 He assembled his fleet and all the seamen , and set out .
3 They went straight on night and day , until they came to an island which was covered with large trees , and under every tree lay a lion .
4 As soon as the King had landed his men , the lions all rose up together and tried to devour them .
5 After a long battle they managed to overcome the wild beasts , but the greater number of the men were killed .
6 Those who remained alive now went on through the forest and found on the other side of it a beautiful garden , in which all the plants of the world flourished together .
7 There were also in the garden three springs : the first flowed with silver , the second with gold , and the third with pearls .
8 The men unbuckled their knapsacks and filled them with those precious things .
9 In the middle of the garden they found a large lake , and when they reached the edge of it the Lake began to speak , and said to them , ` What men are you , and what brings you here ?
10 Are you come to visit our king ? '
11 But they were too much frightened to answer .
12 Then the Lake said , ` You do well to be afraid , for it is at your peril that you are come hither .
13 Our king , who has seven heads , is now asleep , but in a few minutes he will wake up and come to me to take his bath !
14 Woe to anyone who meets him in the garden , for it is impossible to escape from him .
15 This is what you must do if you wish to save your lives .
16 Take off your clothes and spread them on the path which leads from here to the castle .
17 The King will then glide over something soft , which he likes very much , and he will be so pleased with that that he will not devour you .
18 He will give you some punishment , but then he will let you go . '
19 The men did as the Lake advised them , and waited for a time .

1 For two days he resisted the temptation to go and look , but on the third he could stand it no longer , and taking a torch in his hand he hurried to the tower , and unfastened one lock after the other of the little iron door until it burst open .
2 What an unexpected sight met his gaze !
3 The Prince perceived a small room black with smoke , lit up feebly by a fire from which issued long blue flames .
4 Over the fire hung a huge cauldron full of boiling pitch , and fastened into the cauldron by iron chains stood a wretched man screaming with agony .
5 Iwanich was much horrified at the sight before him , and asked the man what terrible crime he had committed to be punished in this dreadful fashion . '
6 I will tell you everything , ' said the man in the cauldron ; ` but first relieve my torments a little , I implore you . '
7 ` And how can I do that ? '
8 asked the Prince .
9 ` With a little water , ' replied the man ; ` only sprinkle a few drops over me and I shall feel better . '
10 The Prince , moved by pity , without thinking what he was doing , ran to the courtyard of the castle , and filled a jug with water , which he poured over the man in the cauldron .
11 In a moment a most fearful crash was heard , as if all the pillars of the palace were giving way , and the palace itself , with towers and doors , windows and the cauldron , whirled round the bewildered Prince 's head .
12 This continued for a few minutes , and then everything vanished into thin air , and Iwanich found himself suddenly alone upon a desolate heath covered with rocks and stones .
13 The Prince , who now realised what his heedlessness had done , cursed too late his spirit of curiosity .
14 In his despair he wandered on over the heath , never looking where he put his feet , and full of sorrowful thoughts .
15 At last he saw a light in the distance , which came from a miserable-looking little hut .
16 The owner of it was none other than the kind-hearted gaunt grey beggar who had given the Prince the bag of bread-crumbs and the hare .
17 Without recognising Iwanich , he opened the door when he knocked and gave him shelter for the night .
18 On the following morning the Prince asked his host if he could get him any work to do , as he was quite unknown in the neighbourhood , and had not enough money to take him home .

1 The King and Queen were sitting on a magnificent throne opposite the judges and the whole council .
2 The Soldier was already standing on the top of the ladder ; but when they wanted to put the rope round his neck , he said that the fulfilment of one innocent request was always granted to a poor criminal before he underwent his punishment .
3 He would so much like to smoke a small pipe of tobacco ; it would be his last pipe in this world .
4 The King could not refuse him this , and so he took out his tinder-box , and rubbed it once , twice , three times .
5 And lo , and behold I there stood all three dogs -- the one with eyes as large as saucers , the second with eyes as large as mill-wheels , and the third with eyes each as large as the Round Tower of Copenhagen .
6 ` Help me now , so that I may not be hanged ! '
7 cried the Soldier .
8 And thereupon the dogs fell upon the judges and the whole council , seized some by the legs , others by the nose , and threw them so high into the air that they fell and were smashed into pieces . '
9 I wo n't stand this ! '
10 said the King ; but the largest dog seized him too , and the Queen as well , and threw them up after the others .
11 This frightened the soldiers , and all the people cried : ` Good Soldier , you shall be our King , and marry the beautiful Princess ! '
12 Then they put the Soldier into the King 's coach , and the three dogs danced in front , crying ` Hurrah ! '
13 And the boys whistled and the soldiers presented arms .
14 The Princess came out of the copper castle , and became Queen ; and that pleased her very much .
15 The wedding festivities lasted for eight days , and the dogs sat at table and made eyes at everyone .

1 One day the maiden took him into a secret chamber , where a little gold box was standing on a silver table .
2 Pointing to the box , she said , ` Here is my greatest treasure , whose like is not to be found in the whole world .
3 It is a precious gold ring .
4 When you marry me , I will give you this ring as a marriage gift , and it will make you the happiest of mortal men .
5 But in order that our love may last for ever , you must give me for the ring three drops of blood from the little finger of your left hand . '
6 When the youth heard these words a cold shudder ran over him , for he remembered that his soul was at stake .
7 He was cunning enough , however , to conceal his feelings and to make no direct answer , but he only asked the maiden , as if carelessly , what was remarkable about the ring ?
8 She answered , ` No mortal is able entirely to understand the power of this ring , because no one thoroughly understands the secret signs engraved upon it .
9 But even with my half-knowledge I can work great wonders .
10 If I put the ring upon the little finger of my left hand , then I can fly like a bird through the air wherever I wish to go .
11 If I put it on the third finger of my left hand I am invisible , and I can see everything that passes around me , though no one can see me .
12 If I put the ring upon the middle finger of my left hand , then neither fire nor water nor any sharp weapon can hurt me .
13 If I put it on the forefinger of my left hand , then I can with its help produce whatever I wish .
14 I can in a single moment build houses or anything I desire .
15 Finally , as long as I wear the ring on the thumb of my left hand , that hand is so strong that it can break down rocks and walls .
16 Besides these , the ring has other secret signs which , as I said , no one can understand .
17 No doubt it contains secrets of great importance .
18 The ring formerly belonged to King Solomon , the wisest of kings , during whose reign the wisest men lived .
19 But it is not known whether this ring was ever made by mortal hands : it is supposed that an angel gave it to the wise King . '
20 When the youth heard all this he determined to try and get possession of the ring , though he did not quite believe in all its wonderful gifts .
21 He wished the XXXXX would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .	maiden		bird|box|everything|feelings|help|maiden|secrets|shudder|walls|world

1 As I told you , my going to Court has been as much as our lives are worth , and now we will both be tarred and feathered , and burnt in the public market-place .
2 It is terrible ! '
3 and she moaned and cried .
4 ` Never fear , little mother , ' answered Martin ; ` trust me , and you will see all will be well .
5 You may go to sleep with a quiet mind . '
6 And , stepping to the front of the hut , Martin threw his ring from the palm of one hand into the other , upon which twelve youths instantly appeared , and demanded what he wanted them to do .
7 Then he told them the King 's commands , and they answered that by next morning all should be accomplished exactly as the King had ordered .
8 Next morning when the King awoke , and looked out of his window , to his amazement he beheld a magnificent castle , just opposite his own palace , and joined to it a bridge of pure crystal .
9 At each side of the bridge trees were growing , from whose branches hung golden and silver apples , among which birds of Paradise perched .
10 At the right , gleaming in the sun , were the five golden cupolas of a splendid church , whose bells rang out , as if they would summon people from all corners of the earth to come and behold the wonder .
11 Now , though the King would much rather have seen his future son-in-law tarred , feathered , and burnt at the stake , he remembered his royal oath , and had to make the best of a bad business .
12 So he took heart of grace , and made Martin a Duke , and gave his daughter a rich dowry , and prepared the grandest wedding-feast that had ever been seen , so that to this day the old people in the country still talk of it .
13 After the wedding Martin and his royal bride went to dwell in the magnificent new palace , and here Martin lived in the greatest comfort and luxury , such luxury as he had never imagined .
14 But though he was as happy as the day was long , and as merry as a grig , the King 's daughter fretted all day , thinking of the indignity that had been done her in making her marry Martin , the poor widow 's son , instead of a rich young Prince from a foreign country .
15 So unhappy was she that she spent all her time wondering how she should get rid of her undesirable husband .
16 And first she determined to learn the secret of his power , and , with flattering , caressing words , she tried to coax him to tell her how he was so clever that there was nothing in the world that he could not do .
17 At first he would tell her nothing ; but once , when he was in a yielding mood , she approached him with a winning smile on her lovely face , and , speaking flattering words to him , she gave him a potion to drink , with a sweet , strong taste .
18 And when he had drunk it Martin 's lips were unsealed , and he told her that all his power lay in the magic ring that he wore on his finger , and he described to her how to use it , and , still speaking , he fell into a deep sleep .
19 And when she saw that the potion had worked , and that he was sound asleep , the Princess took the magic ring from his finger , and , going into the courtyard , she threw it from the palm of one hand into the other .
20 On the instant the twelve youths appeared , and asked her what she commanded them to do .
21 Then she told them that by the next morning they were to do away with the castle , and the XXXXX , and the church , and put in their stead the humble hut in which Martin used to live with his mother , and that while he slept her husband was to be carried to his old lowly room ; and that they were to bear her away to the utmost ends of the earth , where an old King lived who would make her welcome in his palace , and surround her with the state that befitted a royal Princess .	bridge		bridge|castle|finger|lives|market-place|secret|taste|thinking|world|youths

5 Then he threw it on his back and went with his companions .
6 Now , when the King saw how a single man was carrying away the wealth of the whole country he was very angry , and made his cavalry mount and pursue the Six , and bring back the strong man with the sack .
7 Two regiments soon overtook them , and called to them , ` You are prisoners !
8 lay down the sack of gold or you shall be cut down . '
9 ` What do you say ? '
10 said the blower , ` we are prisoners ?
11 Before that , you shall dance in the air ! '
12 And he held one nostril and blew with the other at the two regiments ; they were separated and blown away in the blue sky over the mountains , one this way , and the other that .
13 A sergeant-major cried for mercy , saying he had nine wounds , and was a brave fellow , and did not deserve this disgrace .
14 So the blower let him off , and he came down without hurt .
15 Then he said to him , ` Now go home to the King , and say that if he sends any more cavalry I will blow them all into the air . '
16 When the King received the message , he said , ` Let the fellows go ; they are bewitched . '
17 Then the Six brought the treasure home , shared it among themselves , and lived contentedly till the end of their days .

1 Being invisible , he was able to enter unharmed .
2 In the middle of the temple was an altar , on which lay a book , and behind the altar hung a great curtain .
3 The Prince approached the altar and opened the book , which contained the names of all the lovers in the world : and in it he read that Rosalie had been carried off by the Prince of the Air to an abyss which had no entrance except the one that lay by way of the Fountain of Gold .
4 Now , as the Prince had not the smallest idea where this fountain was to be found , it might be thought that he was not much nearer Rosalie than before .
5 This was not , however , the view taken by the Prince .
6 ` Though every step that I take may perhaps lead me further from her , ' he said to himself , ' I am still thankful to know that she is alive somewhere . '
7 On leaving the temple the Invisible Prince saw six paths lying before him , each of which led through the wood .
8 He was hesitating which to choose , when he suddenly beheld two people coming towards him , down the track which lay most to his right .
9 They turned out to be the Prince Gnome and his friend , and the sudden desire to get some news of his sister , Princess Argentine , caused the Invisible Prince to follow them and to listen to their conversation .
10 ` Do you think , ' the Prince Gnome was saying , ` do you think that I would not break my chains if I could ?
11 I know that the Princess Argentine will never love me , yet each day I feel her dearer still .
12 And as if this were not enough , I have the horror of feeling that she probably loves another .
13 So I have resolved to put myself out of my pain by means of the Golden Fountain .
14 A single drop of its water falling on the sand around will trace the name of my rival in her heart .
15 I dread the test , and yet this very dread convinces me of my misfortune . '
16 It may be imagined that after listening to these words the Invisible Prince followed Prince Gnome like his shadow , and after walking some time they arrived at the Golden Fountain .
17 The unhappy lover stooped down with a sigh , and dipping his finger in the water let fall a drop on the sand .
18 It instantly wrote the name of Prince Flame , his brother .
19 The shock of this discovery was so real , that Prince Gnome sank fainting into the arms of his friend .

1 But before they left their shelter she broke off a little bit of the rock , spoke some magic words over it , and threw it in the direction her mother was coming from .
2 In a moment a glittering palace arose before the eyes of the Fairy which blinded her with its dazzling splendour , and with its many doors and passages prevented her for some time from finding her way out of it .
3 In the meantime the black girl hurried on with the Prince , hastening to reach the river , where once on the other side they would for ever be out of the wicked Fairy 's power .
4 But before they had accomplished half the way they heard again the rustle of her garments and her muttered curses pursuing them closely .
5 The Prince was terrified ; he dared not look back , and he felt his strength giving way .
6 But before he had time to despair the girl uttered some more magic words , and immediately she herself was changed into a pond , and the Prince into a duck swimming on its surface .
7 When the Fairy saw this her rage knew no bounds , and she used all her magic wits to make the pond disappear ; she caused a hill of sand to arise at her feet , meaning it to dry up the water at once .
8 But the sand hill only drove the pond a little farther away , and its waters seemed to increase instead of diminishing .
9 When the old woman saw that the powers of her magic were of so little avail , she had recourse to cunning .
10 She threw a lot of gold nuts into the pond , hoping in this way to catch the duck , but all her efforts were fruitless , for the little creature refused to let itself be caught .
11 Then a new idea struck the wicked old woman , and hiding herself behind the rock which had sheltered the fugitives , she waited behind it , watching carefully for the moment when the Prince and her daughter should resume their natural forms and continue their journey .
12 She had not to wait long , for as soon as the girl thought her mother was safely out of the way , she changed herself and the Prince once more into their human shape , and set out cheerfully for the river .
13 But they had not gone many steps when the wicked Fairy hurried after them , a drawn dagger in her hand , and was close upon them , when suddenly , instead of the Prince and her daughter , she found herself in front of a great stone church , whose entrance was carefully guarded by a huge monk .
14 Breathless with rage and passion , she tried to plunge her dagger into the monk 's heart , but it fell shattered in pieces at her feet .
15 In her desperation she determined to pull down the church , and thus to destroy her two victims for ever .
16 She stamped three times on the ground , and the earth trembled , and both the church and the monk began to shake .
17 As soon as the Fairy saw this she retreated to some distance from the building , so as not to be hurt herself by its fall .
18 But once more her scheme was doomed to failure , for hardly had she gone a yard from the church than both it and the monk disappeared , and she found herself in a wood black as night , and full of wolves and bears and wild animals of all sorts and descriptions .
19 Then her wrath gave place to terror , for she feared every moment to be torn in pieces by the beasts who one and all seemed to defy her power .
20 She thought it wisest to make her way as best she could out of the forest , and then to pursue the fugitives once more and accomplish their destruction either by force or cunning .

1 The one was saying to the other as the weary youth lay down , ` Is there anything the least wonderful or remarkable about this neighbourhood ? ' '
2 I should just think there was , ' replied the other ; ` many things that do n't exist anywhere else in the world .
3 There is a lake down there below us , and anyone who bathes in it , though he were at death 's door , becomes sound and well on the spot , and those who wash their eyes with the dew on this hill become as sharp-sighted as the eagle , even if they have been blind from their youth . '
4 ` Well , ' answered the first raven , ` my eyes are in no want of this healing bath , for , Heaven be praised , they are as good as ever they were ; but my wing has been very feeble and weak ever since it was shot by an arrow many years ago , so let us fly at once to the lake that I may be restored to health and strength again . '
5 And so they flew away .
6 Their words rejoiced Ferko 's heart , and he waited impatiently till evening should come and he could rub the precious dew on his sightless eyes .
7 At last it began to grow dusk , and the sun sank behind the mountains ; gradually it became cooler on the hill , and the grass grew wet with dew .
8 Then Ferko buried his face in the ground till his eyes were damp with dewdrops , and in a moment he saw clearer than he had ever done in his life before .
9 The moon was shining brightly , and lighted him to the lake where he could bathe his poor broken legs .
10 Then Ferko crawled to the edge of the lake and dipped his limbs in the water .
11 No sooner had he done so than his legs felt as sound and strong as they had been before , and Ferko thanked the kind fate that had led him to the hill where he had overheard the ravens ' conversation .
12 He filled a bottle with the healing water , and then continued his journey in the best of spirits .
13 He had not gone far before he met a wolf , who was limping disconsolately along on three legs , and who on perceiving Ferko began to howl dismally .
14 ` My good friend , ' said the youth , ` be of good cheer , for I can soon heal your leg , ' and with these words he poured some of the precious water over the wolf 's paw , and in a minute the animal was springing about sound and well on all fours .
15 The grateful creature thanked his benefactor warmly , and promised Ferko to do him a good turn if he should ever need it .
16 Ferko continued his way till he came to a ploughed field .
17 Here he noticed a little mouse creeping wearily along on its hind paws , for its front paws had both been broken in a trap .
18 Ferko felt so sorry for the little beast that he spoke to it in the most friendly manner , and washed its small paws with the healing water .
19 In a moment the mouse was sound and whole , and after thanking the kind physician it scampered away over the ploughed furrows .
20 Ferko again proceeded on his journey , but he had n't gone far before a queen bee flew against him , trailing one wing behind her , which had been cruelly torn in two by a big bird .
21 Ferko was no less willing to help her than he had been to help the XXXXX and the mouse , so he poured some healing drops over the wounded wing .	wolf		anyone|beast|dewdrops|dusk|howl|limbs|moon|mouse|trap|wolf

1 Get round with your hind legs under you the instant you feel the rein on your neck .
2 If you have n't room to swing round , rear up a little and come round on your hind legs .
3 That 's being bridle-wise . ''
4 `` We are n't taught that way , '' said Billy the mule stiffly .
5 `` We 're taught to obey the man at our head : step off when he says so , and step in when he says so .
6 I suppose it comes to the same thing .
7 Now , with all this fine fancy business and rearing , which must be very bad for your hocks , what do you do ? ''
8 `` That depends , '' said the troop-horse .
9 `` Generally I have to go in among a lot of yelling , hairy men with knives -- long shiny knives , worse than the farrier 's knives -- and I have to take care that Dick 's boot is just touching the next man 's boot without crushing it .
10 I can see Dick 's lance to the right of my right eye , and I know I 'm safe .
11 I should n't care to be the man or horse that stood up to Dick and me when we 're in a hurry . ''
12 `` Do n't the knives hurt ? ''
13 said the young mule .
14 `` Well , I got one cut across the chest once , but that was n't Dick 's fault -- '' `` A lot I should have cared whose fault it was , if it hurt ! ''
15 said the young mule .
