19 That 's what some of our horses do , and I do n't blame them .
20 As I was saying , it was n't Dick 's fault .
21 The XXXXX was lying on the ground , and I stretched myself not to tread on him , and he slashed up at me .	man		death|fault|hurry|instant|knives|legs|life|man|rearing|thing

1 In his despair he wandered on over the heath , never looking where he put his feet , and full of sorrowful thoughts .
2 At last he saw a light in the distance , which came from a miserable-looking little hut .
3 The owner of it was none other than the kind-hearted gaunt grey beggar who had given the Prince the bag of bread-crumbs and the hare .
4 Without recognising Iwanich , he opened the door when he knocked and gave him shelter for the night .
5 On the following morning the Prince asked his host if he could get him any work to do , as he was quite unknown in the neighbourhood , and had not enough money to take him home .
6 ` My son , ' replied the old man , ` all this country round here is uninhabited ; I myself have to wander to distant villages for my living , and even then I do not very often find enough to satisfy my hunger .
7 But if you would like to take service with the old witch Corva , go straight up the little stream which flows below my hut for about three hours , and you will come to a sand-hill on the left-hand side ; that is where she lives . '
8 Iwanich thanked the gaunt grey beggar for his information , and went on his way .
9 After walking for about three hours the Prince came upon a dreary-looking grey stone wall ; this was the back of the building and did not attract him ; but when he came upon the front of the house he found it even less inviting , for the old witch had surrounded her dwelling with a fence of spikes , on every one of which a man 's skull was stuck .
10 In this horrible enclosure stood a small black house , which had only two grated windows , all covered with cobwebs , and a battered iron door .
11 The Prince knocked , and a rasping woman 's voice told him to enter .
12 Iwanich opened the door , and found himself in a smoke-begrimed kitchen , in the presence of a hideous old woman who was warming her skinny hands at a fire .
13 The Prince offered to become her servant , and the old hag told him she was badly in want of one , and he seemed to be just the person to suit her .
14 When Iwanich asked what his work , and how much his wages would be , the witch bade him follow her , and led the way through a narrow damp passage into a vault , which served as a stable .
15 Here he perceived two pitch-black horses in a stall .
16 ` You see before you , ' said the old woman , ' a mare and her foal ; you have nothing to do but to lead them out to the fields every day , and to see that neither of them runs away from you .
17 If you look after them both for a whole year I will give you anything you like to ask ; but if , on the other hand , you let either of the animals escape you , your last hour is come , and your head shall be stuck on the last spike of my fence .
18 The other spikes , as you see , are already adorned , and the skulls are all those of different servants I have had who have failed to do what I demanded . '
19 Iwanich , who thought he could not be much worse off than he was already , agreed to the witch 's proposal .
20 At daybreak nest morning he drove his horses to the field , and brought them back in the evening without their ever having attempted to break away from him .
21 The XXXXX stood at her door and received him kindly , and set a good meal before him .	witch		fence|foal|hare|man|passage|servant|service|vault|windows|witch

1 ` You must learn to do as you are told , ' was all the Frog would reply .
2 But poor Saphir was so unhappy , and begged so hard for forgiveness , that at last the Frog 's anger gave way , and she held up to him a tiny diamond stone .
3 ` Go back , ' she said , ` to the castle , and bury this little diamond close to the door .
4 But be careful not to return to the stable or to the bedroom ; they have proved too fatal to you .
5 Walk straight to the garden and enter through a portico , into a small green wood , in the midst of which is a tree with a trunk of gold and leaves of emeralds .
6 Perched on this tree you will see the beautiful bird you have been seeking so long .
7 You must cut the branch on which it is sitting , and bring it back to me without delay .
8 But I warn you solemnly that if you disobey my directions , as you have done twice before , you have nothing more to expect either of me or anyone else . '
9 With these words she jumped into the water , and the Prince , who had taken her threats much to heart , took his departure , firmly resolved not to deserve them .
10 He found it all just as he had been told : the portico , the wood , the magnificent tree , and the beautiful bird , which was sleeping soundly on one of the branches .
11 He speedily lopped off the branch , and though he noticed a splendid golden cage hanging close by , which would have been very useful for the bird to travel in , he left it alone , and came back to the fountain , holding his breath and walking on tip-toe all the way , for fear lest he should awake his prize .
12 But what was his surprise , when instead of finding the fountain in the spot where he had left it , he saw in its place a little rustic palace built in the best taste , and standing in the doorway a charming maiden , at whose sight his mind seemed to give way .
13 ` What !
14 Madam ! '
15 he cried , hardly knowing what he said .
16 ` What !
17 Is it you ? '
18 The maiden blushed and answered : ` Ah , my lord , it is long since I first beheld your face , but I did not think you had ever seen mine . '
19 ` Oh , madam , ' replied he , ` you can never guess the days and the hours I have passed lost in admiration of you . '
20 And after these words they each related all the strange things that had happened , and the more they talked the more they felt convinced of the truth of the images they had seen in their mirrors .
21 After some time spent in the most tender conversation , the Prince could not restrain himself from asking the lovely unknown by what lucky chance she was wandering in the forest ; where the fountain had gone ; and if she knew anything of the XXXXX to whom he owed all his happiness , and to whom he must give up the bird , which , somehow or other , was still sound asleep . 1 I know what you want of me , ' the bird said .
2 ` You are looking for the Mother Dragon 's mare who is galloping about among the clouds .
3 I will summon all the eagles of the air together , and order them to catch the mare and bring her to you . '
4 And with these words the King of the Eagles flew away .
5 Towards evening the Prince heard a mighty rushing sound in the air , and when he looked up he saw thousands of eagles driving the mare before them .
6 They sank at his feet on to the ground and gave the mare over to him .
7 Then the Prince rode home to the old Mother Dragon , who was full of wonder when she saw him , and said , ` You have succeeded to-day in looking after my mare , and as a reward you shall come to my ball to-night . '
8 She gave him at the same time a cloak made of copper , and led him to a big room where several young he-dragons and she-dragons were dancing together .
9 Here , too , was the Flower Queen 's beautiful daughter .
10 Her dress was woven out of the most lovely flowers in the world , and her complexion was like lilies and roses .
11 As the Prince was dancing with her he managed to whisper in her ear , ' I have come to set you free ! '
12 Then the beautiful girl said to him , ` If you succeed in bringing the mare back safely the third day , ask the Mother Dragon to give you a foal of the mare as a reward . '
13 The ball came to an end at midnight , and early next morning the Prince again led the Mother Dragon 's mare out into the meadow .
14 But again she vanished before his eyes .
15 Then he took out his little bell and rang it twice .
16 In a moment the King of the Foxes stood before him and said : ' I know already what you want , and will summon all the foxes of the world together to find the mare who has hidden herself in a hill . '
17 With these words the King of the Foxes disappeared , and in the evening many thousand foxes brought the mare to the Prince .
18 Then he rode home to the Mother-Dragon , from whom he received this time a cloak made of silver , and again she led him to the ball-room .
19 The Flower Queen 's daughter was delighted to see him safe and sound , and when they were dancing together she whispered in his ear : ` If you succeed again to-morrow , wait for me with the foal in the meadow .
20 After the ball we will fly away together . '

1 `` I should think I had , '' said Sea Catch .
2 `` Look at me ! ''
3 He was scratched and bleeding in twenty places ; one eye was almost out , and his sides were torn to ribbons .
4 `` Oh , you men , you men ! ''
5 Matkah said , fanning herself with her hind flipper .
6 `` Why ca n't you be sensible and settle your places quietly ?
7 You look as though you had been fighting with the Killer Whale . ''
8 `` I have n't been doing anything but fight since the middle of May .
9 The beach is disgracefully crowded this season .
10 I 've met at least a hundred seals from Lukannon Beach , house hunting .
11 Why ca n't people stay where they belong ? ''
12 `` I 've often thought we should be much happier if we hauled out at Otter Island instead of this crowded place , '' said Matkah .
13 `` Bah !
14 Only the holluschickie go to Otter Island .
15 If we went there they would say we were afraid .
16 We must preserve appearances , my dear . ''
17 Sea Catch sunk his head proudly between his fat shoulders and pretended to go to sleep for a few minutes , but all the time he was keeping a sharp lookout for a fight .
18 Now that all the seals and their wives were on the land , you could hear their clamor miles out to sea above the loudest gales .
19 At the lowest counting there were over a million seals on the beach -- old seals , mother seals , tiny babies , and holluschickie , fighting , scuffling , bleating , crawling , and playing together -- going down to the sea and coming up from it in gangs and regiments , lying over every foot of ground as far as the eye could reach , and skirmishing about in brigades through the fog .
20 It is nearly always foggy at Novastoshnah , except when the sun comes out and makes everything look all pearly and rainbow-colored for a little while .

4 THE GLASS AXE -LRB- 19 -RRB- -LRB- 19 -RRB- From the Hungarian .
5 Kletke .
6 There was once upon a time a King and Queen who had everything they could possibly wish for in this world except a child .
7 At last , after twelve years , the Queen gave birth to a son ; but she did not live long to enjoy her happiness , for on the following day she died .
8 But before her death she called her husband to her and said , ` Never let the child put his feet on the ground , for as soon as he does so he will fall into the power of a wicked Fairy , who will do him much harm . '
9 And these were the last words the poor Queen spoke .
10 The boy throve and grew big , and when he was too heavy for his nurse to carry , a chair was made for him on little wheels , in which he could wander through the palace gardens without help ; at other times he was carried about on a litter , and he was always carefully watched and guarded for fear he should at any time put his feet to the ground .
11 But as this sort of life was bad for his health , the doctors ordered him horse exercise , and he soon became a first-rate rider , and used to go out for long excursions on horseback , accompanied always by his father 's stud-groom and a numerous retinue .
12 Every day he rode through the neighbouring fields and woods , and always returned home in the evening safe and well .
13 In this way many years passed , and the Prince grew to manhood , and hardly anyone remembered the Queen 's warning , though precautions were still taken , more from use and wont than for any other reason .
14 One day the Prince and his suite went out for a ride in a wood where his father sometimes held a hunt .
15 Their way led through a stream whose banks were overgrown with thick brushwood .
16 Just as the horsemen were about to ford the river , a hare , startled by the sound of the horses ' hoofs , started up from the grass and ran towards the thicket .
17 The young Prince pursued the little creature , and had almost overtaken it , when the girth of his saddle suddenly broke in two and he fell heavily to the ground .
18 No sooner had his foot touched the earth than he disappeared before the eyes of the horrified courtiers .
19 They sought for him far and near , but all in vain , and they were forced to recognise the power of the evil Fairy , against which the Queen had warned them on her death-bed .
20 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
21 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen XXXXX , and hurried away he knew not whither .	power		brothers|eyes|power|shame|time|village|warning|wolf|wolves|wood

4 ` What a blind old fool you must be to ask such a question ! '
5 she answered angrily .
6 ` Ca n't you see that my hands and feet are nearly frozen ? '
7 Then King Frost sprang to and fro in front of her , questioning her , and getting only rude , rough words in reply , till at last he got very angry , and cracked his fingers , and gnashed his teeth , and froze her to death .
8 But in the hut her mother was waiting for her return , and as she grew impatient she said to her husband : ` Get out the horses , old man , to go and fetch her home ; but see that you are careful not to upset the sledge and lose the chest . '
9 But the doggie beneath the table began to bark , saying : ` Your daughter is frozen quite stiff and cold , And shall never have a chest full of gold . '
10 ` Do n't tell such wicked lies ! '
11 scolded the woman .

13 At that moment the door flew open , and she rushed out to meet her daughter , and as she took her frozen body in her arms she too was chilled to death .

16 Many , many thousand years ago there lived a mighty King whom heaven had blessed with a clever and beautiful son .
17 When he was only ten years old the boy was cleverer than all the King 's counsellors put together , and when he was twenty he was the greatest hero in the whole kingdom .
18 His father could not make enough of his son , and always had him clothed in golden garments which shone and sparkled like the sun ; and his mother gave him a white horse , which never slept , and which flew like the wind .
19 All the people in the land loved him dearly , and called him the Sun-Hero , for they did not think his like existed under the sun .

11 But I have a plan .
12 Meanwhile , I ca n't feed Nap on geraniums . ''

14 `` It is never any use to get in a stew about things , '' she was wont to say .
15 So now she untied Nap gingerly , with many rueful glances at her geraniums , and led him away to the field behind the house , where she tied him safely to a post with such an abundance of knots that there was small fear of his getting away .
16 When the mystified Cynthia Ann had returned home Miss Cordelia set about getting her tea and thinking over the plan that had come to her concerning her white elephant .

5 Prizes ! '
6 Alice had no idea what to do , and in despair she put her hand in her pocket , and pulled out a box of comfits , -LRB- luckily the salt water had not got into it -RRB- , and handed them round as prizes .
7 There was exactly one a-piece all round .
8 ` But she must have a prize herself , you know , ' said the Mouse .
9 ` Of course , ' the Dodo replied very gravely .
10 ` What else have you got in your pocket ? '
11 he went on , turning to Alice .
12 ` Only a thimble , ' said Alice sadly .
13 ` Hand it over here , ' said the Dodo .
14 Then they all crowded round her once more , while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble , saying ` We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble ' ; and , when it had finished this short speech , they all cheered .
15 Alice thought the whole thing very absurd , but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh ; and , as she could not think of anything to say , she simply bowed , and took the thimble , looking as solemn as she could .
16 The next thing was to eat the comfits : this caused some noise and confusion , as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs , and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back .
17 However , it was over at last , and they sat down again in a ring , and begged the Mouse to tell them something more .

8 A young Prince was riding one day through a meadow that stretched for miles in front of him , when he came to a deep open ditch .
9 He was turning aside to avoid it , when he heard the sound of someone crying in the ditch .
10 He dismounted from his horse , and stepped along in the direction the sound came from .
11 To his astonishment he found an old woman , who begged him to help her out of the ditch .
12 The Prince bent down and lifted her out of her living grave , asking her at the same time how she had managed to get there .
13 ` My son , ' answered the old woman , ' I am a very poor woman , and soon after midnight I set out for the neighbouring town in order to sell my eggs in the market on the following morning ; but I lost my way in the dark , and fell into this deep ditch , where I might have remained for ever but for your kindness . '
14 Then the Prince said to her , ` You can hardly walk ; I will put you on my horse and lead you home .
15 Where do you live ? '

17 The Prince lifted her on to his horse , and soon they reached the hut , where the old woman got down , and turning to the Prince said , ` Just wait a moment , and I will give you something . '
18 And she disappeared into her hut , but returned very soon and said , ` You are a mighty Prince , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded .

1 Some king had built it long ago on a little hill .
2 You could still trace the stone causeways that led up to the ruined gates where the last splinters of wood hung to the worn , rusted hinges .
3 Trees had grown into and out of the walls ; the battlements were tumbled down and decayed , and wild creepers hung out of the windows of the towers on the walls in bushy hanging clumps .
4 A great roofless palace crowned the hill , and the marble of the courtyards and the fountains was split , and stained with red and green , and the very cobblestones in the courtyard where the king 's elephants used to live had been thrust up and apart by grasses and young trees .
5 From the palace you could see the rows and rows of roofless houses that made up the city looking like empty honeycombs filled with blackness ; the shapeless block of stone that had been an idol in the square where four roads met ; the pits and dimples at street corners where the public wells once stood , and the shattered domes of temples with wild figs sprouting on their sides .
6 The monkeys called the place their city , and pretended to despise the Jungle-People because they lived in the forest .
7 And yet they never knew what the buildings were made for nor how to use them .
8 They would sit in circles on the hall of the king 's council chamber , and scratch for fleas and pretend to be men ; or they would run in and out of the roofless houses and collect pieces of plaster and old bricks in a corner , and forget where they had hidden them , and fight and cry in scuffling crowds , and then break off to play up and down the terraces of the king 's garden , where they would shake the rose trees and the oranges in sport to see the fruit and flowers fall .
9 They explored all the passages and dark tunnels in the palace and the hundreds of little dark rooms , but they never remembered what they had seen and what they had not ; and so drifted about in ones and twos or crowds telling each other that they were doing as men did .
10 They drank at the tanks and made the water all muddy , and then they fought over it , and then they would all rush together in mobs and shout : `` There is no one in the jungle so wise and good and clever and strong and gentle as the Bandar-log . ''
11 Then all would begin again till they grew tired of the city and went back to the tree-tops , hoping the Jungle-People would notice them .
12 Mowgli , who had been trained under the Law of the Jungle , did not like or understand this kind of life .
13 The monkeys dragged him into the Cold Lairs late in the afternoon , and instead of going to sleep , as Mowgli would have done after a long journey , they joined hands and danced about and sang their foolish songs .
14 One of the monkeys made a speech and told his companions that Mowgli 's capture marked a new thing in the history of the Bandar-log , for Mowgli was going to show them how to weave sticks and canes together as a protection against rain and cold .
15 Mowgli picked up some creepers and began to work them in and out , and the monkeys tried to imitate ; but in a very few minutes they lost interest and began to pull their friends ' tails or jump up and down on all fours , coughing .
16 `` I wish to eat , '' said Mowgli .
17 `` I am a stranger in this part of the jungle .
18 Bring me food , or give me leave to hunt here . ''
19 Twenty or thirty monkeys bounded away to bring him nuts and wild pawpaws .
20 But they fell to fighting on the road , and it was too much trouble to go back with what was left of the fruit .
21 Mowgli was sore and angry as well as hungry , and he roamed through the empty XXXXX giving the Strangers ' Hunting Call from time to time , but no one answered him , and Mowgli felt that he had reached a very bad place indeed .	city		buildings|city|food|hill|jungle|marble|ones|stranger|tanks|trees

1 ` Did I not see her caught up into the air , in spite of cries which would have softened the heart of any one but the barbarian who has robbed me of her ?
2 The unfortunate girl is pining away in some unknown land , where perhaps no foot of man has ever trod , and I shall see her no more .
3 But go , generous stranger ; bring back Rosalie if you can , and live happy with her ever after in this country , of which I now declare you heir . '
4 Although the stranger 's name and rank were unknown to Rosalie 's father , he was really the son of the King of the Golden Isle , which had for capital a city that extended from one sea to another .
5 The walls , washed by the quiet waters , were covered with gold , which made one think of the yellow sands .
6 Above them was a rampart of orange and lemon trees , and all the streets were paved with gold .
7 The King of this beautiful island had one son , for whom a life of adventure had been foretold at his birth .
8 This so frightened his father and mother that in order to comfort them a Fairy , who happened to be present at the time , produced a little pebble which she told them to keep for the Prince till he grew up , as by putting it in his mouth he would become invisible , as long as he did not try to speak , for if he did the stone would lose all its virtue .
9 In this way the good fairy hoped that the Prince would be protected against all dangers .
10 No sooner did the Prince begin to grow out of boyhood than he longed to see if the other countries of the world were as splendid as the one in which he lived .
11 So , under pretence of visiting some small islands that belonged to his father , he set out .
12 But a frightful storm drove his ship on to unknown shores , where most of his followers were put to death by the savages , and the Prince himself only managed to escape by making use of his magic pebble .
13 By this means he passed through the midst of them unseen , and wandered on till he reached the coast , where he re-embarked on board his ship .
14 The first land he sighted was the Island of Roses , and he went at once to the court of the King , Rosalie 's father .
15 The moment his eyes beheld the Princess , he fell in love with her like everyone else .
16 He had already spent several months in this condition when the Prince of the Air whirled her away , to the grief and despair of every man on the island .
17 But sad though everybody was , the Prince of the Golden Isle was perfectly inconsolable , and he passed both days and nights in bemoaning his loss .
18 ` Alas ! '
19 he cried ; ` shall I never see my lovely Princess again ? '
20 Who knows where she may be , and what fairy may have her in his keeping ?

1 At length they reached a chamber where a table was spread with the most costly dishes .
2 At the table were placed two chairs , one of silver , the other of gold .
3 The maiden seated herself upon the golden chair , and offered the silver one to her companion .
4 They were served by maidens dressed in white , whose feet made no sound as they moved about , and not a word was spoken during the meal .
5 Afterwards the youth and the Witch-maiden conversed pleasantly together , until a woman , dressed in red , came in to remind them that it was bedtime .
6 The youth was now shown into another room , containing a silken bed with down cushions , where he slept delightfully , yet he seemed to hear a voice near his bed which repeated to him , ` Remember to give no blood ! '
7 The next morning the maiden asked him whether he would not like to stay with her always in this beautiful place , and as he did not answer immediately , she continued : ` You see how I always remain young and beautiful , and I am under no one 's orders , but can do just what I like , so that I have never thought of marrying before .
8 But from the moment I saw you I took a fancy to you , so if you agree , we might be married and might live together like princes , because I have great riches . '
9 The youth could not but be tempted with the beautiful maiden 's offer , but he remembered how the birds had called her the witch , and their warning always sounded in his ears .
10 Therefore he answered cautiously , ` Do not be angry , dear maiden , if I do not decide immediately on this important matter .
11 Give me a few days to consider before we come to an understanding . '
12 ` Why not ? '
13 answered the maiden .
14 ` Take some weeks to consider if you like , and take counsel with your own heart . '
15 And to make the time pass pleasantly , she took the youth over every part of her beautiful dwelling , and showed him all her splendid treasures .
16 But these treasures were all produced by enchantment , for the maiden could make anything she wished appear by the help of King Solomon 's signet ring ; only none of these things remained fixed ; they passed away like the wind without leaving a trace behind .
17 But the youth did not know this ; he thought they were all real .
18 One day the maiden took him into a secret chamber , where a little gold box was standing on a silver table .
19 Pointing to the box , she said , ` Here is my greatest treasure , whose like is not to be found in the whole world .
20 It is a precious gold ring .

1 The swallow flew down with Thumbelina , and set her upon one of the broad leaves .
2 But there , to her astonishment , she found a tiny little man sitting in the middle of the flower , as white and transparent as if he were made of glass ; he had the prettiest golden crown on his head , and the most beautiful wings on his shoulders ; he himself was no bigger than Thumbelina .
3 He was the spirit of the flower .
4 In each blossom there dwelt a tiny man or woman ; but this one was the King over the others .
5 ` How handsome he is ! '
6 whispered Thumbelina to the swallow .
7 The little Prince was very much frightened at the swallow , for in comparison with one so tiny as himself he seemed a giant .
8 But when he saw Thumbelina , he was delighted , for she was the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
9 So he took his golden crown from off his head and put it on hers , asking her her name , and if she would be his wife , and then she would be Queen of all the flowers .
10 Yes !
11 he was a different kind of husband to the son of the toad and the mole with the black-velvet coat .
12 So she said ` Yes ' to the noble Prince .
13 And out of each flower came a lady and gentleman , each so tiny and pretty that it was a pleasure to see them .
14 Each brought Thumbelina a present , but the best of all was a beautiful pair of wings which were fastened on to her back , and now she too could fly from flower to flower .
15 They all wished her joy , and the swallow sat above in his nest and sang the wedding march , and that he did as well as he could ; but he was sad , because he was very fond of Thumbelina and did not want to be separated from her .
16 ` You shall not be called Thumbelina ! '
17 said the spirit of the flower to her ; ` that is an ugly name , and you are much too pretty for that .
18 We will call you May Blossom . '
19 ` Farewell , farewell ! '
20 said the little swallow with a heavy heart , and flew away to farther lands , far , far away , right back to Denmark .
21 There he had a little XXXXX above a window , where his wife lived , who can tell fairy-stories .	nest		astonishment|blossom|gentleman|girl|heart|joy|nest|pleasure|wife|wings

3 The Duchess took no notice of them even when they hit her ; and the baby was howling so much already , that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not .

8 ` Which would NOT be an advantage , ' said Alice , who felt very glad to get an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge .

1 The Cat had no cousin , and had not been asked to be godmother .
2 She went straight to the church , slunk to the little pot of fat , began to lick it , and licked the top off .
3 Then she took a walk on the roofs of the town , looked at the view , stretched herself out in the sun , and licked her lips whenever she thought of the little pot of fat .
4 As soon as it was evening she went home again .
5 ` Ah , here you are again ! '
6 said the Mouse ; ` you must certainly have had an enjoyable day . '
7 ` It went off very well , ' answered the Cat .
8 ` What was the child 's name ? '
9 asked the Mouse .
10 ` Top Off , ' said the Cat drily .
11 ` Topoff ! '
12 echoed the Mouse , ` it is indeed a wonderful and curious name .
13 Is it in your family ? '
14 ` What is there odd about it ? '
15 said the Cat .
16 ` It is not worse than Breadthief , as your godchild is called . '
17 Not long after this another great longing came over the Cat .
18 She said to the Mouse , ` You must again be kind enough to look after the house alone , for I have been asked a second time to stand godmother , and as this child has a white ring round its neck , I can not refuse . '
19 The kind Mouse agreed , but the Cat slunk under the town wall to the church , and ate up half of the pot of fat .

1 Never before had so grand a wedding been seen , and there was so much food and wine that even the glutton and the thirsty comrade had enough to eat and drink .
2 THE SNOW-DAUGHTER AND THE FIRE-SON -LRB- 25 -RRB- -LRB- 25 -RRB- From the Bukowinaer Tales and Legends .
3 Von Wliolocki .
4 There was once upon a time a man and his wife , and they had no children , which was a great grief to them .
5 One winter 's day , when the sun was shining brightly , the couple were standing outside their cottage , and the woman was looking at all the little icicles which hung from the roof .
6 She sighed , and turning to her husband said , ' I wish I had as many children as there are icicles hanging there . '
7 ` Nothing would please me more either , ' replied her husband .
8 Then a tiny icicle detached itself from the roof , and dropped into the woman 's mouth , who swallowed it with a smile , and said , ` Perhaps I shall give birth to a snow child now ! '
9 Her husband laughed at his wife 's strange idea , and they went back into the house .
10 But after a short time the woman gave birth to a little girl , who was as white as snow and as cold as ice .
11 If they brought the child anywhere near the fire , it screamed loudly till they put it back into some cool place .
12 The little maid throve wonderfully , and in a few months she could run about and speak .
13 But she was not altogether easy to bring up , and gave her parents much trouble and anxiety , for all summer she insisted on spending in the cellar , and in the winter she would sleep outside in the snow , and the colder it was the happier she seemed to be .
14 Her father and mother called her simply ` Our Snow-daughter , ' and this name stuck to her all her life .
15 One day her parents sat by the fire , talking over the extraordinary behaviour of their daughter , who was disporting herself in the snowstorm that raged outside .
16 The woman sighed deeply and said , ' I wish I had given birth to a Fire-son ! '
17 As she said these words , a spark from the big wood fire flew into the woman 's lap , and she said with a laugh , ` Now perhaps I shall give birth to a Fire-son ! '
18 The man laughed at his wife 's words , and thought it was a good joke .
19 But he ceased to think it a joke when his wife shortly afterwards gave birth to a boy , who screamed lustily till he was put quite close to the fire , and who nearly yelled himself into a fit if the Snow-daughter came anywhere near him .
20 The Snow-daughter herself avoided him as much as she could , and always crept into a corner as far away from him as possible .
21 The parents called the boy simply ` Our Fire-son , ' a XXXXX which stuck to him all his life .	name		Nothing|behaviour|birth|day|grief|icicle|maid|mother|name|wine

4 Bad one !
5 Wicked one !
6 Worthless son !
7 Go and wash Kala Nag and attend to his ears , and see that there are no thorns in his feet .

10 Shame !
11 Go ! ''

17 The next few days were spent in getting the elephants together , in walking the newly caught wild elephants up and down between a couple of tame ones to prevent them giving too much trouble on the downward march to the plains , and in taking stock of the blankets and ropes and things that had been worn out or lost in the forest .
18 Petersen Sahib came in on his clever she-elephant Pudmini ; he had been paying off other camps among the hills , for the season was coming to an end , and there was a native clerk sitting at a table under a tree , to pay the drivers their wages .
19 As each man was paid he went back to his elephant , and joined the line that stood ready to start .

1 And she said to her husband : ` Old man , you had better go out into the fields and find your daughter 's body and bury her . '
2 Just as the old man was leaving the house the little dog under the table began to bark , saying : ` YOUR daughter shall live to be your delight ; HER daughter shall die this very night . '
3 ` Hold your tongue , you foolish beast ! '
4 scolded the woman .
5 ` There 's a pancake for you , but you must say : `` HER daughter shall have much silver and gold ; HIS daughter is frozen quite stiff and cold . '' '
6 But the doggie ate up the pancake and barked , saying : ` His daughter shall wear a crown on her head ; Her daughter shall die unwooed , unwed . '
7 Then the old woman tried to coax the doggie with more pancakes and to terrify it with blows , but he barked on , always repeating the same words .
8 And suddenly the door creaked and flew open , and a great heavy chest was pushed in , and behind it came the step-daughter , radiant and beautiful , in a dress all glittering with silver and gold .
9 For a moment the step-mother 's eyes were dazzled .
10 Then she called to her husband : ` Old man , yoke the horses at once into the sledge , and take my daughter to the same field and leave her on the same spot exactly ; ` and so the old man took the girl and left her beneath the same tree where he had parted from his daughter .
11 In a few minutes King Frost came past , and , looking at the girl , he said : ` Are you warm , maiden ? '
12 ` What a blind old fool you must be to ask such a question ! '
13 she answered angrily .
14 ` Ca n't you see that my hands and feet are nearly frozen ? '
15 Then King Frost sprang to and fro in front of her , questioning her , and getting only rude , rough words in reply , till at last he got very angry , and cracked his fingers , and gnashed his teeth , and froze her to death .
16 But in the hut her mother was waiting for her return , and as she grew impatient she said to her husband : ` Get out the horses , old man , to go and fetch her home ; but see that you are careful not to upset the sledge and lose the chest . '
17 But the doggie beneath the table began to bark , saying : ` Your daughter is frozen quite stiff and cold , And shall never have a chest full of gold . '
18 ` Do n't tell such wicked lies ! '
19 scolded the woman .

7 `` Well done for a yearling ! ''
8 said the Sea Lion , who could appreciate good swimming .
9 `` I suppose it is rather awful from your way of looking at it , but if you seals will come here year after year , of course the men get to know of it , and unless you can find an island where no men ever come you will always be driven . ''
10 `` Is n't there any such island ? ''
11 began Kotick .
12 `` I 've followed the poltoos -LSB- the halibut -RSB- for twenty years , and I ca n't say I 've found it yet .
13 But look here -- you seem to have a fondness for talking to your betters -- suppose you go to Walrus Islet and talk to Sea Vitch .
14 He may know something .

16 It 's a six-mile swim , and if I were you I should haul out and take a nap first , little one . ''
17 Kotick thought that that was good advice , so he swam round to his own beach , hauled out , and slept for half an hour , twitching all over , as seals will .
18 Then he headed straight for Walrus Islet , a little low sheet of rocky island almost due northeast from Novastoshnah , all ledges and rock and gulls ' nests , where the walrus herded by themselves .
19 He landed close to old Sea Vitch -- the big , ugly , bloated , pimpled , fat-necked , long-tusked walrus of the North Pacific , who has no manners except when he is asleep -- as he was then , with his hind flippers half in and half out of the surf .

1 The other replied , ' I do not know , certainly , where she is at present , but in three nights from now she will come to the spring to wash her face , as she does every month when the moon is full , in order that she may never grow old nor wrinkled , but may always keep the bloom of youth . '
2 ` Well , ' said the first bird , ` the spring is not far from here .
3 Shall we go and see how it is she does it ? '
4 ` Willingly , if you like , ' said the other .
5 The youth immediately resolved to follow the birds to the spring , only two things made him uneasy : first , lest he might be asleep when the birds went , and secondly , lest he might lose sight of them , since he had not wings to carry him along so swiftly .
6 He was too tired to keep awake all night , yet his anxiety prevented him from sleeping soundly , and when with the earliest dawn he looked up to the tree-top , he was glad to see his feathered companions still asleep with their heads under their wings .
7 He ate his breakfast , and waited until the birds should start , but they did not leave the place all day .
8 They hopped about from one tree to another looking for food , all day long until the evening , when they went back to their old perch to sleep .
9 The next day the same thing happened , but on the third morning one bird said to the other , ` To-day we must go to the spring to see the Witch-maiden wash her face . '
10 They remained on the tree till noon ; then they flew away and went towards the south .
11 The young man 's heart beat with anxiety lest he should lose sight of his guides , but he managed to keep the birds in view until they again perched upon a tree .
12 The young man ran after them until he was quite exhausted and out of breath , and after three short rests the birds at length reached a small open space in the forest , on the edge of which they placed themselves on the top of a high tree .
13 When the youth had overtaken them , he saw that there was a clear spring in the middle of the space .
14 He sat down at the foot of the tree upon which the birds were perched , and listened attentively to what they were saying to each other .
15 ` The sun is not down yet , ' said the first bird ; ` we must wait yet awhile till the moon rises and the maiden comes to the spring .
16 Do you think she will see that young man sitting under the tree ? '
17 ` Nothing is likely to escape her eyes , certainly not a young man , said the other bird .
18 ` Will the youth have the sense not to let himself be caught in her toils ? '
19 ` We will wait , ' said the first bird , ` and see how they get on together . '
20 The evening light had quite faded , and the full moon was already shining down upon the forest , when the young man heard a slight rustling sound .

1 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
2 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the parrot , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .
3 This soon reassured the Prince , and encouraged him to play his part well , and he began to say a thousand agreeable things which charmed the Princess .
4 Presently the King appeared , and the parrot noticed with joy how much he was disliked .
5 As soon as the King left , the Princess retired to her dressing-room , the parrot flew after her and overheard her lamentations at the continued persecutions of the King , who had pressed her to consent to their marriage .
6 The parrot said so many clever and tender things to comfort her that she began to doubt whether this could indeed be her own parrot .
7 When he saw her well-disposed towards him , he exclaimed : ` Madam , I have a most important secret to confide to you , and I beg you not to be alarmed by what I am about to say .
8 I am here on behalf of the Queen your mother , with the object of delivering your Highness ; to prove which , behold this portrait which she gave me herself . '
9 So saying he drew forth the miniature from under his wing .
10 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
11 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
12 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
13 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
14 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
15 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her parrot again .
16 As they rose through the air the Princess remarked a figure mounted on an eagle 's back flying in front of the chariot .
17 She was rather alarmed , but the Prince reassured her , telling her it was the good Fairy to whom she owed so much , and who was now conducting her in safety to her mother .
18 That same morning the King woke suddenly from a troubled sleep .
19 He had dreamt that the Princess was being carried off from him , and , transforming himself into an eagle , he flew to the palace .
20 When he failed to find her he flew into a terrible rage , and hastened home to consult his books , by which means he discovered that it was his son who had deprived him of this precious treasure .
21 Immediately he took the shape of a harpy , and , filled with XXXXX , was determined to devour his son , and even the Princess too , if only he could overtake them .	rage		bird|cage|chariot|help|liberty|likeness|mother|person|rage|shape

1 Chester would have chosen death by starvation before he would have sought for employment in a liquor saloon .
2 But there certainly did not seem room for him anywhere else .
3 Nobody wanted a boy .
4 The answer to his question was invariably `` No . ''
5 As the day wore on , Chester 's hopes and courage went down to zero , but he still tramped doggedly about .
6 He would be thorough , at least .
7 Surely somewhere in this big place , where everyone seemed so busy , there must be something for him to do .
8 Once there seemed a chance of success .

10 `` Well , we do , '' said the clerk , looking him over critically , `` but I hardly think you 'll fill the bill .
11 However , come in and see the boss . ''
12 He took Chester into a dark , grimy little inner office where a fat , stubby man was sitting before a desk with his feet upon it .

1 Then the ship 's crew returned home , and the same thing happened yearly until many years had passed .
2 Now the King of this unhappy country was growing old , and so was the Queen , and they had no children .
3 One day the Queen was sitting at the window weeping bitterly because she was childless , and knew that the crown would therefore pass to strangers after the King 's death .
4 Suddenly a little old woman appeared before her , holding an apple in her hand , and said , ` Why do you weep , my Queen , and what makes you so unhappy ? '
5 ` Alas , good mother , ' answered the Queen , ' I am unhappy because I have no children . '
6 ` Is that what vexes you ? '
7 said the old woman .
8 ` Listen to me .
9 I am a nun from the Spinning Convent , -LRB- 10 -RRB- and my mother when she died left me this apple .
10 Whoever eats this apple shall have a child . '
11 -LRB- 10 -RRB- Convent Gnothi .
12 The Queen gave money to the old woman , and bought the apple from her .
13 Then she peeled it , ate it , and threw the rind out of the window , and it so happened that a mare that was running loose in the court below ate up the rind .
14 After a time the Queen had a little boy , and the mare also had a male foal .
15 The boy and the foal grew up together and loved each other like brothers .
16 In course of time the King died , and so did the Queen , and their son , who was now nineteen years old , was left alone .

1 And gladly would these two have walked thus for ever , but in the murmur of the wind he heard the Master of Life saying to him , ` Return whither you came , for I have work for you to do , and your people need you , and for many years you shall rule over them .
2 At the gate my messenger awaits you , and you shall take again your body which you left behind , and he will show you what you are to do .
3 Listen to him , and have patience , and in time to come you shall rejoin her whom you must now leave , for she is accepted , and will remain ever young and beautiful , as when I called her hence from the Land of Snows . '
4 THE WHITE DUCK Once upon a time a great and powerful King married a lovely Princess .
5 No couple were ever so happy ; but before their honeymoon was over they were forced to part , for the King had to go on a warlike expedition to a far country , and leave his young wife alone at home .
6 Bitter were the tears she shed , while her husband sought in vain to soothe her with words of comfort and counsel , warning her , above all things , never to leave the castle , to hold no intercourse with strangers , to beware of evil counsellors , and especially to be on her guard against strange women .
7 And the Queen promised faithfully to obey her royal lord and master in these four matters .
8 So when the King set out on his expedition she shut herself up with her ladies in her own apartments , and spent her time in spinning and weaving , and in thinking of her royal husband .
9 Often she was very sad and lonely , and it happened that one day while she was seated at the window , letting salt tears drop on her work , an old woman , a kind , homely-looking old body , stepped up to the window , and , leaning upon her crutch , addressed the Queen in friendly , flattering tones , saying : ` Why are you sad and cast down , fair Queen ?
10 You should not mope all day in your rooms , but should come out into the green garden , and hear the birds sing with joy among the trees , and see the butterflies fluttering above the flowers , and hear the bees and insects hum , and watch the sunbeams chase the dew-drops through the rose-leaves and in the lily-cups .
11 All the brightness outside would help to drive away your cares , O Queen . '
12 For long the Queen resisted her coaxing words , remembering the promise she had given the King , her husband ; but at last she thought to herself : After all , what harm would it do if I were to go into the garden for a short time and enjoy myself among the trees and flowers , and the singing birds and fluttering butterflies and humming insects , and look at the dew-drops hiding from the sunbeams in the hearts of the roses and lilies , and wander about in the sunshine , instead of remaining all day in this room ?
13 For she had no idea that the kind-looking old woman leaning on her crutch was in reality a wicked witch , who envied the Queen her good fortune , and was determined to ruin her .
14 And so , in all ignorance , the Queen followed her out into the garden and listened to her smooth , flattering words .
15 Now , in the middle of the garden there was a pond of water , clear as crystal , and the old woman said to the Queen : ` The day is so warm , and the sun 's rays so scorching , that the water in the pond looks very cool and inviting .
16 Would you not like to bathe in it , fair Queen ? '
17 ` No , I think not , ' answered the Queen ; but the next moment she regretted her words , and thought to herself : Why should n't I bathe in that cool , fresh water ?
18 No harm could come of it .
19 And , so saying , she slipped off her robes and stepped into the water .
20 But scarcely had her tender feet touched the cool ripples when she felt a great shove on her shoulders , and the wicked witch had pushed her into the deep water , exclaiming : ` Swim henceforth , White Duck ! '
21 And the witch herself assumed the form of the Queen , and decked herself out in the royal XXXXX , and sat among the Court ladies , awaiting the King 's return .	robes		apartments|couple|harm|idea|ignorance|murmur|patience|robes|water|window

1 Hadvor made no sign , but waited till he had fallen asleep , and then crept out and burned the lion 's skin , which he had left outside .
2 Then she went back into the cave and wakened Hermod , and they had a most joyful meeting .
3 In the morning they talked over their plans , and were most at a loss to know how to get out of the island .
4 Hadvor told Hermod her dream , and said she suspected there was some one in the island who would be able to help them .
5 Hermod said he knew of a Witch there , who was very ready to help anyone , and that the only plan was to go to her .
6 So they went to the Witch 's cave , and found her there with her fifteen young sons , and asked her to help them to get to the mainland .
7 ` There are other things easier than that , ' said she , ` for the Giant that was buried will be waiting for you , and will attack you on the way , as he has turned himself into a big whale .
8 I shall lend you a boat , however , and if you meet the whale and think your lives are in danger , then you can name me by name . '
9 They thanked her greatly for her help and advice , and set out from the island , but on the way they saw a huge fish coming towards them , with great splashing and dashing of waves .
10 They were sure of what it was , and thought they had as good reason as ever they would have to call on the Witch , and so they did .
11 The next minute they saw coming after them another huge whale , followed by fifteen smaller ones .
12 All of these swam past the boat and went on to meet the whale .
13 There was a fierce battle then , and the sea became so stormy that it was not very easy to keep the boat from being filled by the waves .
14 After this fight had gone on for some time , they saw that the sea was dyed with blood ; the big whale and the fifteen smaller ones disappeared , and they got to land safe and sound .
15 Now the story goes back to the King 's hall , where strange things had happened in the meantime .
16 The Queen and her daughter had disappeared , but a rat and a mouse were always fighting with each other there .
17 Ever so many people had tried to drive them away , but no one could manage it .
18 Thus some time went on , while the King was almost beside himself with sorrow and care for the loss of his Queen , and because these monsters destroyed all mirth in the hall .
19 One evening , however , while they all sat dull and down-hearted , in came Hermod with a sword by his side , and saluted the King , who received him with the greatest joy , as if he had come back from the dead .
20 Before Hermod sat down , however , he went to where the rat and the mouse were fighting , and cut them in two with his sword .

5 The house itself was in the shadow of the firs , but the yard lay out in the moonlight and the strange visitor did not elect to cross it .
6 Instead , he turned aside into the shadow of the trees around the garden and , leaning against the old rail fence , gave himself up to contemplation of some kind .

8 The window-blind was not down and he had a fairly good view of the room .

3 ` Never fear , ' said the glutton .
4 ` It will scarcely be enough for me , I 'm so hungry . '
5 So when the courtier arrived with the royal message he was told to take back word to the King that his orders should be obeyed .
6 Then twelve roasted oxen and twelve tons of bread were brought alongside of the ship , and at one sitting the glutton had devoured it all . '
7 I call that a small meal , ' he said . '
8 I wish they 'd brought me some more . '
9 Next , the King ordered that forty casks of wine , containing forty gallons each , were to be drunk up on the spot by the Simpleton and his party .
10 When these words were overheard by the sharp-eared comrade and repeated to the Simpleton , he was in despair .
11 ` Alas , alas ! '
12 he exclaimed ; ` what is to be done ?
13 It would take us a year , possibly our whole lives , to drink so much . '
14 ` Never fear , ' said his thirsty comrade .
15 ` I 'll drink it all up at a gulp , see if I do n't . '
16 And sure enough , when the forty casks of wine containing forty gallons each were brought alongside of the ship , they disappeared down the thirsty comrade 's throat in no time ; and when they were empty he remarked : ` Why , I 'm still thirsty .
17 I should have been glad of two more casks . '

1 Their words rejoiced Ferko 's heart , and he waited impatiently till evening should come and he could rub the precious dew on his sightless eyes .
2 At last it began to grow dusk , and the sun sank behind the mountains ; gradually it became cooler on the hill , and the grass grew wet with dew .
3 Then Ferko buried his face in the ground till his eyes were damp with dewdrops , and in a moment he saw clearer than he had ever done in his life before .
4 The moon was shining brightly , and lighted him to the lake where he could bathe his poor broken legs .
5 Then Ferko crawled to the edge of the lake and dipped his limbs in the water .
6 No sooner had he done so than his legs felt as sound and strong as they had been before , and Ferko thanked the kind fate that had led him to the hill where he had overheard the ravens ' conversation .
7 He filled a bottle with the healing water , and then continued his journey in the best of spirits .
8 He had not gone far before he met a wolf , who was limping disconsolately along on three legs , and who on perceiving Ferko began to howl dismally .
9 ` My good friend , ' said the youth , ` be of good cheer , for I can soon heal your leg , ' and with these words he poured some of the precious water over the wolf 's paw , and in a minute the animal was springing about sound and well on all fours .
10 The grateful creature thanked his benefactor warmly , and promised Ferko to do him a good turn if he should ever need it .
11 Ferko continued his way till he came to a ploughed field .
12 Here he noticed a little mouse creeping wearily along on its hind paws , for its front paws had both been broken in a trap .
13 Ferko felt so sorry for the little beast that he spoke to it in the most friendly manner , and washed its small paws with the healing water .
14 In a moment the mouse was sound and whole , and after thanking the kind physician it scampered away over the ploughed furrows .
15 Ferko again proceeded on his journey , but he had n't gone far before a queen bee flew against him , trailing one wing behind her , which had been cruelly torn in two by a big bird .
16 Ferko was no less willing to help her than he had been to help the wolf and the mouse , so he poured some healing drops over the wounded wing .
17 On the spot the queen bee was cured , and turning to Ferko she said , ' I am most grateful for your kindness , and shall reward you some day . '
18 And with these words she flew away humming , gaily .
19 Then Ferko wandered on for many a long day , and at length reached a strange kingdom .

1 ` You need not fear Militza , ' said the beautiful girl , looking at the Prince with friendly eyes .
2 ` An evil magician has not robbed you of your fruit , but he stole the seed from my mother , and thereby caused her death .
3 When she was dying she bade me take the fruit , which you have no right to possess , from the trees every year as soon as it was ripe .
4 This I would have done to-night too , if you had not seized me with such force , and so broken the spell I was under . '
5 Iwanich , who had been prepared to meet a terrible magician and not a lovely girl , fell desperately in love with her .
6 They spent the rest of the night in pleasant conversation , and when Militza wished to go away he begged her not to leave him . '
7 I would gladly stay with you longer , ' said Militza , ` but a wicked witch once cut off a lock of my hair when I was asleep , which has put me in her power , and if morning were still to find me here she would do me some harm , and you , too , perhaps . '
8 Having said these words , she drew a sparkling diamond ring from her finger , which she handed to the Prince , saying : ` Keep this ring in memory of Militza , and think of her sometimes if you never see her again .
9 But if your love is really true , come and find me in my own kingdom .
10 I may not show you the way there , but this ring will guide you .
11 ` If you have love and courage enough to undertake this journey , whenever you come to a cross-road always look at this diamond before you settle which way you are going to take .
12 If it sparkles as brightly as ever go straight on , but if its lustre is dimmed choose another path . '
13 Then Militza bent over the Prince and kissed him on his forehead , and before he had time to say a word she vanished through the branches of the tree in a little white cloud .
14 Morning broke , and the Prince , still full of the wonderful apparition , left his perch and returned to the palace like one in a dream , without even knowing if the fruit had been taken or not ; for his whole mind was absorbed by thoughts of Militza and how he was to find her .
15 As soon as the head-gardener saw the Prince going towards the palace he ran to the trees , and when he saw them laden with ripe fruit he hastened to tell the King the joyful news .
16 The King was beside himself for joy , and hurried at once to the garden and made the gardener pick him some of the fruit .
17 He tasted it , and found the apple quite as luscious as it had been in his dream .

1 Snati immediately sprang upon him , and Ring assisted in the attack , and after a hard struggle they mastered him a second time .
2 When they got back again to the window they saw that the old hag was moving towards the door .
3 ` Now we must go in at once , ' said Snati , ` and try to master her there , for if she once gets out we shall have no chance with her .
4 She is the worst witch that ever lived , and no iron can cut her .
5 One of us must pour boiling porridge out of the pot on her , and the other punch her with red-hot iron . '
6 In they went then , and no sooner did the hag see them than she said , ` So you have come , Prince Ring ; you must have seen to my husband and children . '
7 Snati saw that she was about to attack them , and sprang at her with a red-hot iron from the fire , while Ring kept pouring boiling porridge on her without stopping , and in this way they at last got her killed .
8 Then they burned the old troll and her to ashes , and explored the cave , where they found plenty of gold and treasures .
9 The most valuable of these they carried with them as far as the cliff , and left them there .
10 Then they hastened home to the King with his three treasures , where they arrived late on Christmas night , and Ring handed them over to him .
11 The King was beside himself with joy , and was astonished at how clever a man Ring was in all kinds of feats , so that he esteemed him still more highly than before , and betrothed his daughter to him ; and the feast for this was to last all through Christmastide .
12 Ring thanked the King courteously for this and all his other kindnesses , and as soon as he had finished eating and drinking in the hall went off to sleep in his own room .

14 Ring said he was welcome to do so , and that he deserved more from him than that came to .

1 Striped Chipmunk told the same story .
2 So did Unc ' Billy Possum .
3 It was the same with all of Old Mr. Toad 's old friends and neighbors , excepting Bobby Coon , who , you know , is Buster Bear 's little cousin .
4 To him Old Mr. Toad was very polite and talked a great deal about Buster Bear , and thought that Bobby must be very proud to be related to Buster .
5 At first everybody thought it a great joke to see Old Mr. Toad so puffed up with , pride , but after a little they grew tired of being snubbed by their old friend and neighbor , and began to say unpleasant things about him .
6 Then they decided that what Old Mr. Toad needed was a lesson , so they put their heads together and planned how they would teach Old Mr. Toad how foolish it is for any one to be puffed up with pride .
7 XXI OLD MR. TOAD RECEIVES ANOTHER INVITATION The friends and neighbors of Old Mr. Toad decided that he needed to be taught a lesson .
8 At first , you know , every one had laughed at him , because he had grown too proud to speak to them , but after a little they grew tired of being treated so , and some of them put their heads together to think of some plan to teach Old Mr. Toad a lesson and what a very , very foolish thing false pride is .
9 The very next day Jimmy Skunk went into the Green Forest to look for Buster Bear .
10 You know Jimmy is n't afraid of Buster .
11 He did n't have to look long , and when he had found him , the very first thing he did was to ask Buster if he had seen any fat beetles that morning .
12 You know Jimmy is very fond of fat beetles , and the first thing he asks any one he may happen to meet is if they have seen any .
13 Buster Bear grinned and said he thought he knew where there might be a few , and he would be pleased to have Jimmy go with him to see .
14 Sure enough , under an old log he found five fat beetles , and these Jimmy gobbled up without even asking Buster if he would have one .
15 Jimmy is usually very polite , but this time he quite forgot politeness .
16 I am afraid he is rather apt to when fat beetles are concerned .
17 But Buster did n't seem to mind .
18 When the last beetle had disappeared Jimmy smacked his lips , and then he told Buster Bear what he had come for .

1 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
2 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
3 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
4 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
5 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
6 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
7 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
8 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
9 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
10 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
11 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
12 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
13 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
14 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
15 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
16 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
17 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
18 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
19 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
20 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
21 And as the XXXXX ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the cat had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .	children		children|eyes|ground|help|pieces|ribbons|tasks|thing|threads|wood

2 But if your love is really true , come and find me in my own kingdom .
3 I may not show you the way there , but this ring will guide you .
4 ` If you have love and courage enough to undertake this journey , whenever you come to a cross-road always look at this diamond before you settle which way you are going to take .
5 If it sparkles as brightly as ever go straight on , but if its lustre is dimmed choose another path . '
6 Then Militza bent over the Prince and kissed him on his forehead , and before he had time to say a word she vanished through the branches of the tree in a little white cloud .
7 Morning broke , and the Prince , still full of the wonderful apparition , left his perch and returned to the palace like one in a dream , without even knowing if the fruit had been taken or not ; for his whole mind was absorbed by thoughts of Militza and how he was to find her .
8 As soon as the head-gardener saw the Prince going towards the palace he ran to the trees , and when he saw them laden with ripe fruit he hastened to tell the King the joyful news .
9 The King was beside himself for joy , and hurried at once to the garden and made the gardener pick him some of the fruit .
10 He tasted it , and found the apple quite as luscious as it had been in his dream .
11 He went at once to his son Iwanich , and after embracing him tenderly and heaping praises on him , he asked him how he had succeeded in protecting the costly fruit from the power of the magician .
12 This question placed Iwanich in a dilemma .
13 But as he did not want the real story to be known , he said that about midnight a huge wasp had flown through the branches , and buzzed incessantly round him .
14 He had warded it off with his sword , and at dawn , when he was becoming quite worn out , the wasp had vanished as suddenly as it had appeared .
15 The King , who never doubted the truth of this tale , bade his son go to rest at once and recover from the fatigues of the night ; but he himself went and ordered many feasts to be held in honour of the preservation of the wonderful fruit .
16 The whole capital was in a stir , and everyone shared in the King 's joy ; the Prince alone took no part in the festivities .
17 While the King was at a banquet , Iwanich took some purses of gold , and mounting the quickest horse in the royal stable , he sped off like the wind without a single soul being any the wiser .
18 It was only on the next day that they missed him ; the King was very distressed at his disappearance , and sent search-parties all over the kingdom to look for him , but in vain ; and after six months they gave him up as dead , and in another six months they had forgotten all about him .
19 But in the meantime the Prince , with the help of his ring , had had a most successful journey , and no evil had befallen him .
20 At the end of three months he came to the entrance of a huge forest , which looked as if it had never been trodden by human foot before , and which seemed to stretch out indefinitely .

3 A young Prince was riding one day through a meadow that stretched for miles in front of him , when he came to a deep open ditch .
4 He was turning aside to avoid it , when he heard the sound of someone crying in the ditch .
5 He dismounted from his horse , and stepped along in the direction the sound came from .
6 To his astonishment he found an old woman , who begged him to help her out of the ditch .
7 The Prince bent down and lifted her out of her living grave , asking her at the same time how she had managed to get there .
8 ` My son , ' answered the old woman , ' I am a very poor woman , and soon after midnight I set out for the neighbouring town in order to sell my eggs in the market on the following morning ; but I lost my way in the dark , and fell into this deep ditch , where I might have remained for ever but for your kindness . '
9 Then the Prince said to her , ` You can hardly walk ; I will put you on my horse and lead you home .
10 Where do you live ? '
11 ` Over there , at the edge of the forest in the little hut you see in the distance , ' replied the old woman .
12 The Prince lifted her on to his horse , and soon they reached the hut , where the old woman got down , and turning to the Prince said , ` Just wait a moment , and I will give you something . '
13 And she disappeared into her hut , but returned very soon and said , ` You are a mighty Prince , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded .
14 Would you like to have the most beautiful woman in the world for your wife ? '
15 ` Most certainly I would , ' replied the Prince .
16 So the old woman continued , ` The most beautiful woman in the whole world is the daughter of the Queen of the Flowers , who has been captured by a dragon .
17 If you wish to marry her , you must first set her free , and this I will help you to do .
18 I will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the King of the Eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the King of the Foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the King of the Fishes by your side .
19 These will help you if you are in any difficulty .
20 Now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . '

1 He took his place at the Council Rock , too , when the Pack met , and there he discovered that if he stared hard at any wolf , the wolf would be forced to drop his eyes , and so he used to stare for fun .
2 At other times he would pick the long thorns out of the pads of his friends , for wolves suffer terribly from thorns and burs in their coats .
3 He would go down the hillside into the cultivated lands by night , and look very curiously at the villagers in their huts , but he had a mistrust of men because Bagheera showed him a square box with a drop gate so cunningly hidden in the jungle that he nearly walked into it , and told him that it was a trap .
4 He loved better than anything else to go with Bagheera into the dark warm heart of the forest , to sleep all through the drowsy day , and at night see how Bagheera did his killing .
5 Bagheera killed right and left as he felt hungry , and so did Mowgli -- with one exception .
6 As soon as he was old enough to understand things , Bagheera told him that he must never touch cattle because he had been bought into the Pack at the price of a bull 's life .
7 `` All the jungle is thine , '' said Bagheera , `` and thou canst kill everything that thou art strong enough to kill ; but for the sake of the bull that bought thee thou must never kill or eat any cattle young or old .
8 That is the Law of the Jungle . ''
9 Mowgli obeyed faithfully .
10 And he grew and grew strong as a boy must grow who does not know that he is learning any lessons , and who has nothing in the world to think of except things to eat .
11 Mother Wolf told him once or twice that Shere Khan was not a creature to be trusted , and that some day he must kill Shere Khan .
12 But though a young wolf would have remembered that advice every hour , Mowgli forgot it because he was only a boy -- though he would have called himself a wolf if he had been able to speak in any human tongue .
13 Shere Khan was always crossing his path in the jungle , for as Akela grew older and feebler the lame tiger had come to be great friends with the younger wolves of the Pack , who followed him for scraps , a thing Akela would never have allowed if he had dared to push his authority to the proper bounds .
14 Then Shere Khan would flatter them and wonder that such fine young hunters were content to be led by a dying wolf and a man 's cub .
15 `` They tell me , '' Shere Khan would say , `` that at Council ye dare not look him between the eyes . ''
16 And the young wolves would growl and bristle .
17 Bagheera , who had eyes and ears everywhere , knew something of this , and once or twice he told Mowgli in so many words that Shere Khan would kill him some day .
18 Mowgli would laugh and answer : `` I have the Pack and I have thee ; and Baloo , though he is so lazy , might strike a blow or two for my sake .
19 Why should I be afraid ? ''
20 It was one very warm day that a new notion came to Bagheera -- born of something that he had heard .

1 In a moment a glittering palace arose before the eyes of the Fairy which blinded her with its dazzling splendour , and with its many doors and passages prevented her for some time from finding her way out of it .
2 In the meantime the black girl hurried on with the Prince , hastening to reach the river , where once on the other side they would for ever be out of the wicked Fairy 's power .
3 But before they had accomplished half the way they heard again the rustle of her garments and her muttered curses pursuing them closely .
4 The Prince was terrified ; he dared not look back , and he felt his strength giving way .
5 But before he had time to despair the girl uttered some more magic words , and immediately she herself was changed into a pond , and the Prince into a duck swimming on its surface .
6 When the Fairy saw this her rage knew no bounds , and she used all her magic wits to make the pond disappear ; she caused a hill of sand to arise at her feet , meaning it to dry up the water at once .
7 But the sand hill only drove the pond a little farther away , and its waters seemed to increase instead of diminishing .
8 When the old woman saw that the powers of her magic were of so little avail , she had recourse to cunning .
9 She threw a lot of gold nuts into the pond , hoping in this way to catch the duck , but all her efforts were fruitless , for the little creature refused to let itself be caught .
10 Then a new idea struck the wicked old woman , and hiding herself behind the rock which had sheltered the fugitives , she waited behind it , watching carefully for the moment when the Prince and her daughter should resume their natural forms and continue their journey .
11 She had not to wait long , for as soon as the girl thought her mother was safely out of the way , she changed herself and the Prince once more into their human shape , and set out cheerfully for the river .
12 But they had not gone many steps when the wicked Fairy hurried after them , a drawn dagger in her hand , and was close upon them , when suddenly , instead of the Prince and her daughter , she found herself in front of a great stone church , whose entrance was carefully guarded by a huge monk .
13 Breathless with rage and passion , she tried to plunge her dagger into the monk 's heart , but it fell shattered in pieces at her feet .
14 In her desperation she determined to pull down the church , and thus to destroy her two victims for ever .
15 She stamped three times on the ground , and the earth trembled , and both the church and the monk began to shake .
16 As soon as the Fairy saw this she retreated to some distance from the building , so as not to be hurt herself by its fall .
17 But once more her scheme was doomed to failure , for hardly had she gone a yard from the church than both it and the monk disappeared , and she found herself in a wood black as night , and full of wolves and bears and wild animals of all sorts and descriptions .
18 Then her wrath gave place to terror , for she feared every moment to be torn in pieces by the beasts who one and all seemed to defy her power .
19 She thought it wisest to make her way as best she could out of the forest , and then to pursue the fugitives once more and accomplish their destruction either by force or cunning .
20 In the meantime the Prince and the black girl had again assumed their natural forms , and were hurrying on as fast as they could to reach the river .
