1 There he bought himself some fine clothes , and a beautiful coach with four horses , hired two servants , and drove back to his master .
2 You may imagine how astonished he was to see his Herd-boy returning to him in this manner !
3 Then the youth told him of the piece of good luck that had befallen him , and asked him for the hand of his beautiful daughter .
4 This was readily granted , and the two lived in peace and happiness to the end of their lives .
5 THE INVISIBLE PRINCE Once upon a time there lived a Fairy who had power over the earth , the sea , fire , and the air ; and this Fairy had four sons .
6 The eldest , who was quick and lively , with a vivid imagination , she made Lord of Fire , which was in her opinion the noblest of all the elements .
7 To the second son , whose wisdom and prudence made amends for his being rather dull , she gave the government of the earth .
8 The third was wild and savage , and of monstrous stature ; and the Fairy , his mother , who was ashamed of his defects , hoped to hide them by creating him King of the Seas .
9 The youngest , who was the slave of his passions and of a very uncertain temper , became Prince of the Air .
10 Being the youngest , he was naturally his mother 's favourite ; but this did not blind her to his weaknesses , and she foresaw that some day he would suffer much pain through falling in love .
11 So she thought the best thing she could do was to bring him up with a horror of women ; and , to her great delight , she saw this dislike only increased as he grew older .
12 From his earliest childhood he heard nothing but stories of princes who had fallen into all sorts of troubles through love ; and she drew such terrible pictures of poor little Cupid that the young man had no difficulty in believing that he was the root of all evil .
13 All the time that this wise mother could spare from filling her son with hatred for all womenkind she passed in giving him a love of the pleasures of the chase , which henceforth became his chief joy .
14 For his amusement she had made a new forest , planted with the most splendid trees , and turned loose in it every animal that could be found in any of the four quarters of the globe .
15 In the midst of this forest she built a palace which had not its equal for beauty in the whole world , and then she considered that she had done enough to make any prince happy .
16 Now it is all very well to abuse the God of Love , but a man can not struggle against his fate .
17 In his secret heart the Prince got tired of his mother 's constant talk on this subject ; and when one day she quitted the palace to attend to some business , begging him never to go beyond the grounds , he at once jumped at the chance of disobeying her .
18 Left to himself the Prince soon forgot the wise counsels of his mother , and feeling very much bored with his own company , he ordered some of the spirits of the air to carry him to the court of a neighbouring sovereign .
19 This kingdom was situated in the Island of Roses , where the climate is so delicious that the grass is always green and the flowers always sweet .
20 The waves , instead of beating on the rocks , seemed to die gently on the shore ; clusters of golden bushes covered the land , and the vines were bent low with grapes .
21 The King of this island had a XXXXX named Rosalie , who was more lovely than any girl in the whole world .	daughter		PRINCE|chance|daughter|elements|happiness|luck|nothing|passions|talk|vines

1 When the youth heard these words a cold shudder ran over him , for he remembered that his soul was at stake .
2 He was cunning enough , however , to conceal his feelings and to make no direct answer , but he only asked the maiden , as if carelessly , what was remarkable about the ring ?
3 She answered , ` No mortal is able entirely to understand the power of this ring , because no one thoroughly understands the secret signs engraved upon it .
4 But even with my half-knowledge I can work great wonders .
5 If I put the ring upon the little finger of my left hand , then I can fly like a bird through the air wherever I wish to go .
6 If I put it on the third finger of my left hand I am invisible , and I can see everything that passes around me , though no one can see me .
7 If I put the ring upon the middle finger of my left hand , then neither fire nor water nor any sharp weapon can hurt me .
8 If I put it on the forefinger of my left hand , then I can with its help produce whatever I wish .
9 I can in a single moment build houses or anything I desire .
10 Finally , as long as I wear the ring on the thumb of my left hand , that hand is so strong that it can break down rocks and walls .
11 Besides these , the ring has other secret signs which , as I said , no one can understand .
12 No doubt it contains secrets of great importance .
13 The ring formerly belonged to King Solomon , the wisest of kings , during whose reign the wisest men lived .
14 But it is not known whether this ring was ever made by mortal hands : it is supposed that an angel gave it to the wise King . '
15 When the youth heard all this he determined to try and get possession of the ring , though he did not quite believe in all its wonderful gifts .
16 He wished the maiden would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .
17 A few days after they were again speaking of the magic ring , and the youth said , ' I do not think it possible that the ring can have all the power you say it has . '
18 Then the maiden opened the box and took the ring out , and it glittered as she held it like the clearest sunbeam .

1 ` Do n't be impertinent , ' said the King , ` and do n't look at me like that ! '
2 He got behind Alice as he spoke . '
3 A cat may look at a king , ' said Alice .
4 ` I 've read that in some book , but I do n't remember where . '
5 ` Well , it must be removed , ' said the King very decidedly , and he called the Queen , who was passing at the moment , ` My dear !
6 I wish you would have this cat removed ! '
7 The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties , great or small .
8 ` Off with his head ! '
9 she said , without even looking round .
10 ` I 'll fetch the executioner myself , ' said the King eagerly , and he hurried off .
11 Alice thought she might as well go back , and see how the game was going on , as she heard the Queen 's voice in the distance , screaming with passion .
12 She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns , and she did not like the look of things at all , as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not .
13 So she went in search of her hedgehog .
14 The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog , which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other : the only difficulty was , that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden , where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree .
15 By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back , the fight was over , and both the hedgehogs were out of sight : ` but it does n't matter much , ' thought Alice , ` as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground . '
16 So she tucked it away under her arm , that it might not escape again , and went back for a little more conversation with her friend .
17 When she got back to the Cheshire Cat , she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it : there was a dispute going on between the executioner , the King , and the Queen , who were all talking at once , while all the rest were quite silent , and looked very uncomfortable .
18 The moment Alice appeared , she was appealed to by all three to settle the question , and they repeated their arguments to her , though , as they all spoke at once , she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said .
19 The executioner 's argument was , that you could n't cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from : that he had never had to do such a thing before , and he was n't going to begin at HIS time of life .
20 The King 's argument was , that anything that had a head could be beheaded , and that you were n't to talk nonsense .
21 The Queen 's XXXXX was , that if something was n't done about it in less than no time she 'd have everybody executed , all round .	argument		anything|argument|difficulties|distance|fight|king|opportunity|turns|voice|way

1 Dick says there is no such thing as a kelpy .
2 But then Dick has no imagination .
3 It is no argument against a thing that you 've never seen it .
4 I have never seen the pyramids , either , but I know that there are pyramids .
5 Every summer we had some hobby .
6 The last summer before Dick and Mimi came we were crazy about kites .
7 A winter boy on the mainland showed Claude how to make them , and when we went back to the Big Half Moon we made kites galore .
8 Even pirating was n't such good fun .
9 Claude would go around to the other side of the Big Half Moon and we would play shipwrecked mariners signalling to each other with kites .
10 Oh , it was very exciting .
11 We had one kite that was a dandy .
12 It was as big as we could make it and covered with lovely red paper ; we had pasted gold tinsel stars all over it and written our names out in full on it -- Claude Martin Leete and Philippa Brewster Leete , Big Half Moon Lighthouse .
13 That kite had the most magnificent tail , too .
14 It used to scare the gulls nearly to death when we sent up our kites .
15 They did n't know what to make of them .
16 And the Big Half Moon is such a place for gulls -- there are hundreds of them here .
17 One day there was a grand wind for kite-flying , and Claude and I were having a splendid time .
18 We used our smaller kites for signalling , and when we got tired of that Claude sent me to the house for the big one .
19 I 'm sure I do n't know how it happened , but when I was coming back over the rocks I tripped and fell , and my elbow went clear through that lovely kite .
20 You would never have believed that one small elbow could make such a big hole .
21 Claude said it was just like a girl to fall and stick her XXXXX through a kite , but I do n't see why it should be any more like a girl than a boy .	elbow		elbow|hobby|hole|hundreds|imagination|one|paper|pyramids|rocks|thing

1 `` They obey , as the men do .
2 Mule , horse , elephant , or bullock , he obeys his driver , and the driver his sergeant , and the sergeant his lieutenant , and the lieutenant his captain , and the captain his major , and the major his colonel , and the colonel his brigadier commanding three regiments , and the brigadier the general , who obeys the Viceroy , who is the servant of the Empress .
3 Thus it is done . ''
4 `` Would it were so in Afghanistan ! ''
5 said the chief , `` for there we obey only our own wills . ''
6 `` And for that reason , '' said the native officer , twirling his mustache , `` your Amir whom you do not obey must come here and take orders from our Viceroy . ''
7 Parade Song of the Camp Animals ELEPHANTS OF THE GUN TEAMS We lent to Alexander the strength of Hercules , The wisdom of our foreheads , the cunning of our knees ; We bowed our necks to service : they ne'er were loosed again , -- Make way there -- way for the ten-foot teams Of the Forty-Pounder train !
8 GUN BULLOCKS Those heroes in their harnesses avoid a cannon-ball , And what they know of powder upsets them one and all ; Then we come into action and tug the guns again -- Make way there -- way for the twenty yoke Of the Forty-Pounder train !
9 CAVALRY HORSES By the brand on my shoulder , the finest of tunes Is played by the Lancers , Hussars , and Dragoons , And it 's sweeter than `` Stables '' or `` Water '' to me -- The Cavalry Canter of `` Bonnie Dundee '' !
10 Then feed us and break us and handle and groom , And give us good riders and plenty of room , And launch us in column of squadron and see The way of the war-horse to `` Bonnie Dundee '' !
11 SCREW-GUN MULES As me and my companions were scrambling up a hill , The path was lost in rolling stones , but we went forward still ; For we can wriggle and climb , my lads , and turn up everywhere , Oh , it 's our delight on a mountain height , with a leg or two to spare !

1 ` Well , I must lie down outside , ' said Little Klaus ; and the farmer 's wife shut the door in his face .
2 Close by stood a large haystack , and between it and the house a little out-house , covered with a flat thatched roof . '
3 I can lie down there , ' thought Little Klaus , looking at the roof ; ` it will make a splendid bed , if only the stork wo n't fly down and bite my legs . '
4 For a live stork was standing on the roof , where it had its nest .
5 So Little Klaus crept up into the out-house , where he lay down , and made himself comfortable for the night .
6 The wooden shutters over the windows were not shut at the top , and he could just see into the room .
7 There stood a large table , spread with wine and roast meat and a beautiful fish .
8 The farmer 's wife and the sexton sat at the table , but there was no one else .
9 She was filling up his glass , while he stuck his fork into the fish which was his favourite dish .
10 ` If one could only get some of that ! '
11 thought Little Klaus , stretching his head towards the window .
12 Ah , what delicious cakes he saw standing there !
13 It WAS a feast !
14 Then he heard someone riding along the road towards the house .
15 It was the farmer coming home .
16 He was a very worthy man ; but he had one great peculiarity -- namely , that he could not bear to see a sexton .
17 If he saw one he was made quite mad .
18 That was why the sexton had gone to say good-day to the farmer 's wife when he knew that her husband was not at home , and the good woman therefore put in front of him the best food she had .
19 But when they heard the farmer coming they were frightened , and the farmer 's wife begged the sexton to creep into a great empty chest .

1 After walking for some time he came to a forest , into which he went a little way and stopped .
2 Then he heard sweet music from a harp , and went in the direction of the sound until he came to a clearing , and there he saw three women , one of whom sat on a golden chair , and was beautifully and grandly dressed ; she held a harp in her hands , and was very sorrowful .
3 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
4 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
5 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
6 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
7 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
8 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
9 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
10 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
11 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
12 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
13 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
14 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
15 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a spell on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .
16 After this Hermod disappeared , and no one knew what had become of him ; the Queen caused search to be made for him , but he could nowhere be found .
17 One time , when Olof was in the castle beside Hadvor , she asked the Princess if she knew where Hermod had gone to .
18 At this Hadvor became very sad , and said that she did not . '
19 I shall tell you then , ' said Olof , ` for I know all about it .
20 Hermod has disappeared through the wicked devices of the Queen , for she is a witch , and so is her daughter , though they have put on these beautiful forms .
21 Because Hermod would not fall in with the Queen 's plans , and marry her daughter , she has laid a XXXXX on him , to go on an island and be a lion by day and a man by night , and never be freed from this until you burn the lion 's skin .	spell		country|daughter|devices|fight|fortune|mouse|nothing|skin|spell|time

1 Take me with you , O Kala Nag ! ''
2 The elephant turned , without a sound , took three strides back to the boy in the moonlight , put down his trunk , swung him up to his neck , and almost before Little Toomai had settled his knees , slipped into the forest .
3 There was one blast of furious trumpeting from the lines , and then the silence shut down on everything , and Kala Nag began to move .
4 Sometimes a tuft of high grass washed along his sides as a wave washes along the sides of a ship , and sometimes a cluster of wild-pepper vines would scrape along his back , or a bamboo would creak where his shoulder touched it .
5 But between those times he moved absolutely without any sound , drifting through the thick Garo forest as though it had been smoke .
6 He was going uphill , but though Little Toomai watched the stars in the rifts of the trees , he could not tell in what direction .
7 Then Kala Nag reached the crest of the ascent and stopped for a minute , and Little Toomai could see the tops of the trees lying all speckled and furry under the moonlight for miles and miles , and the blue-white mist over the river in the hollow .
8 Toomai leaned forward and looked , and he felt that the forest was awake below him -- awake and alive and crowded .
9 A big brown fruit-eating bat brushed past his ear ; a porcupine 's quills rattled in the thicket ; and in the darkness between the tree stems he heard a hog-bear digging hard in the moist warm earth , and snuffing as it digged .
10 Then the branches closed over his head again , and Kala Nag began to go down into the valley -- not quietly this time , but as a runaway gun goes down a steep bank -- in one rush .
11 The huge limbs moved as steadily as pistons , eight feet to each stride , and the wrinkled skin of the elbow points rustled .
12 The undergrowth on either side of him ripped with a noise like torn canvas , and the saplings that he heaved away right and left with his shoulders sprang back again and banged him on the flank , and great trails of creepers , all matted together , hung from his tusks as he threw his head from side to side and plowed out his pathway .
13 Then Little Toomai laid himself down close to the great neck lest a swinging bough should sweep him to the ground , and he wished that he were back in the lines again .
14 The grass began to get squashy , and Kala Nag 's feet sucked and squelched as he put them down , and the night mist at the bottom of the valley chilled Little Toomai .
15 There was a splash and a trample , and the rush of running water , and Kala Nag strode through the bed of a river , feeling his way at each step .
16 Above the noise of the water , as it swirled round the elephant 's legs , Little Toomai could hear more splashing and some trumpeting both upstream and down -- great grunts and angry snortings , and all the mist about him seemed to be full of rolling , wavy shadows .
17 `` Ai ! ''
18 he said , half aloud , his teeth chattering .
19 `` The elephant-folk are out tonight .
20 It is the dance , then ! ''
21 Kala Nag swashed out of the water , blew his XXXXX clear , and began another climb .	trunk		O|back|grass|mist|noise|smoke|sound|teeth|trunk|valley

10 Min The morning sun hung , a red , lustreless ball , in the dull grey sky .
11 A light snow had fallen in the night and the landscape , crossed by spider-like trails of fences , was as white and lifeless as if wrapped in a shroud .
12 A young man was driving down the road to Rykman 's Corner ; the youthful face visible above the greatcoat was thoughtful and refined , the eyes deep blue and peculiarly beautiful , the mouth firm yet sensitive .
13 It was not a handsome face , but there was a strangely subtle charm about it .
14 The chill breathlessness of the air seemed prophetic of more snow .
15 The Reverend Allan Telford looked across the bare wastes and cold white hills and shivered , as if the icy lifelessness about him were slowly and relentlessly creeping into his own heart and life .
16 He felt utterly discouraged .
17 In his soul he was asking bitterly what good had come of all his prayerful labours among the people of this pinched , narrow world , as rugged and unbeautiful in form and life as the barren hills that shut them in .
18 He had been two years among them and he counted it two years of failure .
19 He had been too outspoken for them ; they resented sullenly his direct and incisive tirades against their pet sins .

1 The noise and thundering grew louder and louder , until the floor began to open , whereupon Hadvor made them take the caldron of pitch and pour plenty of it into the opening .
2 With that the noises grew fainter and fainter , till at last they ceased altogether .
3 Next morning the Queen rose early , and went out to the Palace gate , and there she found her brother the Giant lying dead .
4 She went up to him and said , ' I pronounce this spell , that you become a beautiful prince , and that Hadvor shall be unable to say anything against the charges that I shall bring against her . '
5 The body of the dead Giant now became that of a beautiful prince , and the Queen went in again . '
6 I do n't think , ' said she to the King , ` that your daughter is as good as she is said to be .
7 My brother came and asked her hand , and she has had him put to death .
8 I have just found his dead body lying at the Palace gate . '
9 The King went along with the Queen to see the body , and thought it all very strange ; so beautiful a youth , he said , would have been a worthy match for Hadvor , and he would readily have agreed to their marriage .
10 The Queen asked leave to decide what Hadvor 's punishment should be , which the King was very willing to allow , so as to escape from punishing his own daughter .
11 The Queen 's decision was that the King should make a big grave-mound for her brother , and put Hadvor into it beside him .
12 Olof knew all the plans of the Queen , and went to tell the Princess what had been done , whereupon Hadvor earnestly entreated her to tell her what to do .
13 ` First and foremost , ' said Olof , ` you must get a wide cloak to wear over your other clothes , when you are put into the mound .
14 The Giant 's ghost will walk after you are both left together in there , and he will have two dogs along with him .
15 He will ask you to cut pieces out of his legs to give to the dogs , but that you must not promise to do unless he tells you where Hermod has gone to , and tells you how to find him .
16 He will then let you stand on his shoulders , so as to get out of the mound ; but he means to cheat you all the same , and will catch you by the cloak to pull you back again ; but you must take care to have the cloak loose on your shoulders , so that he will only get hold of that . '
17 The mound was all ready now , and the Giant laid in it , and into it Hadvor also had to go without being allowed to make any defence .
18 After they were both left there everything happened just as Olof had said .
19 The prince became a Giant again , and asked Hadvor to cut the pieces out of his legs for the dogs ; but she refused until he told her that Hermod was in a desert island , which she could not reach unless she took the skin off the soles of his feet and made shoes out of that ; with these shoes she could travel both on land and sea .
20 This Hadvor now did , and the Giant then let her get up on his shoulders to get out of the mound .

1 So the children left the house together ; and the little sister , who was very wise for her years , said to the brother : ` We will first go and see our own dear grandmother , and tell her where our step-mother is sending us . '
2 And when the grandmother heard where they were going , she cried and said : ` You poor motherless children !
3 How I pity you ; and yet I can do nothing to help you !
4 Your step-mother is not sending you to her granny , but to a wicked witch who lives in that great gloomy wood .
5 Now listen to me , children .
6 You must be civil and kind to everyone , and never say a cross word to anyone , and never touch a crumb belonging to anyone else .
7 Who knows if , after all , help may not be sent to you ? '
8 And she gave her grandchildren a bottle of milk and a piece of ham and a loaf of bread , and they set out for the great gloomy wood .
9 When they reached it they saw in front of them , in the thickest of the trees , a queer little hut , and when they looked into it , there lay the witch , with her head on the threshold of the door , with one foot in one corner and the other in the other corner , and her knees cocked up , almost touching the ceiling .
10 ` Who 's there ? '
11 she snarled , in an awful voice , when she saw the children .
12 And they answered civilly , though they were so terrified that they hid behind one another , and said : ` Good-morning , granny ; our step-mother has sent us to wait upon you , and serve you . '
13 ` See that you do it well , then , ' growled the witch .
14 ` If I am pleased with you , I 'll reward you ; but if I am not , I 'll put you in a pan and fry you in the oven -- that 's what I 'll do with you , my pretty dears !
15 You have been gently reared , but you 'll find my work hard enough .
16 See if you do n't . '
17 And , so saying , she set the girl down to spin yarn , and she gave the boy a sieve in which to carry water from the well , and she herself went out into the wood .

10 THE DEATH OF THE SUN-HERO -LRB- 27 -RRB- -LRB- 27 -RRB- From the Bukowinaer Tales and Legends .
11 Von Wliolocki .
12 Many , many thousand years ago there lived a mighty King whom heaven had blessed with a clever and beautiful son .
13 When he was only ten years old the boy was cleverer than all the King 's counsellors put together , and when he was twenty he was the greatest hero in the whole kingdom .
14 His father could not make enough of his son , and always had him clothed in golden garments which shone and sparkled like the sun ; and his mother gave him a white horse , which never slept , and which flew like the wind .
15 All the people in the land loved him dearly , and called him the Sun-Hero , for they did not think his like existed under the sun .
16 Now it happened one night that both his parents had the same extraordinary dream .
17 They dreamt that a girl all dressed in red had come to them and said : ` If you wish that your son should really become the Sun-Hero in deed and not only in name , let him go out into the world and search for the Tree of the Sun , and when he has found it , let him pluck a golden apple from it and bring it home . '
18 When the King and Queen had each related their dreams to the other , they were much amazed that they should both have dreamt exactly the same about their son , and the King said to his wife , ` This is clearly a sign from heaven that we should send our son out into the world in order that he may come home the great Sun-Hero , as the Red Girl said , not only in name but in deed . '
19 The Queen consented with many tears , and the King at once bade his son set forth in search of the Tree of the Sun , from which he was to pluck a golden apple .
20 The Prince was delighted at the prospect , and set out on his travels that very day .
21 For a long time he wandered all through the world , and it was not till the ninety-ninth day after he started that he found an old XXXXX who was able to tell him where the Tree of the Sun grew .	man		apple|body|death|feet|garments|hut|man|prospect|red|return

14 cried the Gryphon , and , taking Alice by the hand , it hurried off , without waiting for the end of the song .
15 ` What trial is it ? '
16 Alice panted as she ran ; but the Gryphon only answered ` Come on ! '
17 and ran the faster , while more and more faintly came , carried on the breeze that followed them , the melancholy words : -- ` Soo -- oop of the e -- e -- evening , Beautiful , beautiful Soup ! '
18 CHAPTER XI .
19 Who Stole the Tarts ?
20 The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived , with a great crowd assembled about them -- all sorts of little birds and beasts , as well as the whole pack of cards : the Knave was standing before them , in chains , with a soldier on each side to guard him ; and near the King was the White Rabbit , with a trumpet in one hand , and a scroll of parchment in the other .
21 In the very middle of the court was a table , with a large XXXXX of tarts upon it : they looked so good , that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them -- ' I wish they 'd get the trial done , ' she thought , ` and hand round the refreshments ! 1 `` A boy who can face a full Keddah at his age does not end in jails .
2 See , little one , here are four annas to spend in sweetmeats because thou hast a little head under that great thatch of hair .
3 In time thou mayest become a hunter too . ''
4 Big Toomai scowled more than ever .
5 `` Remember , though , that Keddahs are not good for children to play in , '' Petersen Sahib went on .
6 `` Must I never go there , Sahib ? ''
7 asked Little Toomai with a big gasp .
8 `` Yes . ''
9 Petersen Sahib smiled again .
10 `` When thou hast seen the elephants dance .
11 That is the proper time .
12 Come to me when thou hast seen the elephants dance , and then I will let thee go into all the Keddahs . ''
13 There was another roar of laughter , for that is an old joke among elephant-catchers , and it means just never .
14 There are great cleared flat places hidden away in the forests that are called elephants ' ball-rooms , but even these are only found by accident , and no man has ever seen the elephants dance .
15 When a driver boasts of his skill and bravery the other drivers say , `` And when didst thou see the elephants dance ? ''
16 Kala Nag put Little Toomai down , and he bowed to the earth again and went away with his father , and gave the silver four-anna piece to his mother , who was nursing his baby brother , and they all were put up on Kala Nag 's back , and the line of grunting , squealing elephants rolled down the hill path to the plains .
17 It was a very lively march on account of the new elephants , who gave trouble at every ford , and needed coaxing or beating every other minute .
18 Big Toomai prodded Kala Nag spitefully , for he was very angry , but Little Toomai was too happy to speak .
19 Petersen Sahib had noticed him , and given him money , so he felt as a private soldier would feel if he had been called out of the ranks and praised by his commander-in-chief .
20 `` What did Petersen Sahib mean by the elephant dance ? ''
21 he said , at last , softly to his XXXXX .	mother		boy|bravery|forests|jails|man|money|mother|places|silver|time

1 He has eyes like red fire .
2 By my honor , Messua , he is not unlike thy boy that was taken by the tiger . ''
3 `` Let me look , '' said a woman with heavy copper rings on her wrists and ankles , and she peered at Mowgli under the palm of her hand .
4 `` Indeed he is not .
5 He is thinner , but he has the very look of my boy . ''
6 The priest was a clever man , and he knew that Messua was wife to the richest villager in the place .
7 So he looked up at the sky for a minute and said solemnly : `` What the jungle has taken the jungle has restored .
8 Take the boy into thy house , my sister , and forget not to honor the priest who sees so far into the lives of men . ''
9 `` By the Bull that bought me , '' said Mowgli to himself , `` but all this talking is like another looking-over by the Pack !
10 Well , if I am a man , a man I must become . ''
11 The crowd parted as the woman beckoned Mowgli to her hut , where there was a red lacquered bedstead , a great earthen grain chest with funny raised patterns on it , half a dozen copper cooking pots , an image of a Hindu god in a little alcove , and on the wall a real looking glass , such as they sell at the country fairs .
12 She gave him a long drink of milk and some bread , and then she laid her hand on his head and looked into his eyes ; for she thought perhaps that he might be her real son come back from the jungle where the tiger had taken him .
13 So she said , `` Nathoo , O Nathoo ! ''
14 Mowgli did not show that he knew the name .
15 `` Dost thou not remember the day when I gave thee thy new shoes ? ''
16 She touched his foot , and it was almost as hard as horn .
17 `` No , '' she said sorrowfully , `` those feet have never worn shoes , but thou art very like my Nathoo , and thou shalt be my son . ''
18 Mowgli was uneasy , because he had never been under a roof before .
19 But as he looked at the thatch , he saw that he could tear it out any time if he wanted to get away , and that the window had no fastenings .
20 `` What is the good of a man , '' he said to himself at last , `` if he does not understand man 's talk ?
21 Now I am as silly and dumb as a man would be with us in the XXXXX .	jungle		O|art|boy|day|eyes|hut|jungle|look|roof|shoes

1 ` Now you must empty all the salt into the porridge-pot , ' said Snati .
2 Ring did so , and soon the trolls wakened up .
3 The old hag , who was the most frightful of them all , went first to taste the porridge .
4 ` How comes this ? '
5 she said ; ` the porridge is salt !
6 I got the milk by witchcraft yesterday out of four kingdoms , and now it is salt ! '
7 All the others then came to taste the porridge , and thought it nice , but after they had finished it the old hag grew so thirsty that she could stand it no longer , and asked her daughter to go out and bring her some water from the river that ran near by . '
8 I wo n't go , ' said she , ` unless you lend me your bright gold piece . '
9 ` Though I should die you sha n't have that , ' said the hag .
10 ` Die , then , ' said the girl .
11 ` Well , then , take it , you brat , ' said the old hag , ` and be off with you , and make haste with the water . '
12 The girl took the gold and ran out with it , and it was so bright that it shone all over the plain .
13 As soon as she came to the river she lay down to take a drink of the water , but meanwhile the two of them had got down off the roof and thrust her , head first , into the river .
14 The old hag began now to long for the water , and said that the girl would be running about with the gold piece all over the plain , so she asked her son to go and get her a drop of water . '
15 I wo n't go , ' said he , ` unless I get the gold cloak . '
16 ` Though I should die you sha n't have that , ' said the hag .
17 ` Die , then , ' said the son .
18 ` Well , then , take it , ' said the old hag , ` and be off with you , but you must make haste with the water . '
19 He put on the cloak , and when he came outside it shone so bright that he could see to go with it .
20 On reaching the river he went to take a drink like his sister , but at that moment Ring and Snati sprang upon him , took the cloak from him , and threw him into the river .
21 The old hag could stand the thirst no longer , and asked her husband to go for a XXXXX for her ; the brats , she said , were of course running about and playing themselves , just as she had expected they would , little wretches that they were . 1 He felt sure that Johnny would never have acted as he had , and if Chester now had one dear ambition on earth , it was to be as good and manly a fellow as Johnny must have been .
2 But he could never be that as long as he kept the truth about himself from Miss Salome .
3 `` That boy has got something on his mind , '' said the terrible Clemantiny , who , Chester felt convinced , could see through a stone wall .
4 `` Nonsense !
5 What could he have on his mind ? ''
6 said Miss Salome .
7 But she said it a little anxiously .
8 She , too , had noticed Chester 's absent ways and abstracted face .
9 `` Goodness me , I do n't know !
10 I do n't suppose he has robbed a bank or murdered anybody .
11 But he is worrying over something , as plain as plain . ''
12 `` He is getting on very well at school , '' said Miss Salome .
13 `` His teacher says so , and he is very eager to learn .
14 I do n't know what can be troubling him . ''
15 She was fated not to know for a fortnight longer .
16 During that time Chester fought out his struggle with himself , and conquered .
17 He must tell Miss Salome , he decided , with a long sigh .
18 He knew that it would mean going back to Upton and Aunt Harriet and the old , hard life , but he would not sail under false colours any longer .

14 `` It was well done , '' said Akela .

16 He may be a help in time . ''

18 Akela said nothing .
19 He was thinking of the time that comes to every leader of every pack when his strength goes from him and he gets feebler and feebler , till at last he is killed by the wolves and a new leader comes up -- to be killed in his turn .
20 `` Take him away , '' he said to Father Wolf , `` and train him as befits one of the Free People . ''

1 In the meantime I will slip in among the hens through a hole in the wall and give them a good chase , so that the noise they make will arouse the royal henwives , and they will come to see what is the matter .
2 When they see the horses they will at once imagine them to be the cause of the disturbance , and will drive them out .
3 Then you must lay hands on the mare and foal and catch them .
4 All turned out exactly as the sly fox had foreseen .
5 The Prince swung himself on the mare , seized the foal by its bridle , and hurried home .
6 While he was riding over the heath in the highest of spirits the mare suddenly said to her rider : ` You are the first person who has ever succeeded in outwitting the old witch Corva , and now you may ask what reward you like for your service .
7 If you promise never to betray me I will give you a piece of advice which you will do well to follow . '
8 The Prince promised never to betray her confidence , and the mare continued : ` Ask nothing else as a reward than my foal , for it has not its like in the world , and is not to be bought for love or money ; for it can go from one end of the earth to another in a few minutes .
9 Of course the cunning Corva will do her best to dissuade you from taking the foal , and will tell you that it is both idle and sickly ; but do not believe her , and stick to your point . '
10 Iwanich longed to possess such an animal , and promised the mare to follow her advice .
11 This time Corva received him in the most friendly manner , and set a sumptuous repast before him .
12 As soon as he had finished she asked him what reward he demanded for his year 's service .
13 ` Nothing more nor less , ' replied the Prince , ` than the foal of your mare . '
14 The witch pretended to be much astonished at his request , and said that he deserved something much better than the foal , for the beast was lazy and nervous , blind in one eye , and , in short , was quite worthless .
15 But the Prince knew what he wanted , and when the old witch saw that he had made up his mind to have the foal , she said , ' I am obliged to keep my promise and to hand you over the foal ; and as I know who you are and what you want , I will tell you in what way the animal will be useful to you .
16 The man in the cauldron of boiling pitch , whom you set free , is a mighty magician ; through your curiosity and thoughtlessness Militza came into his power , and he has transported her and her castle and belongings into a distant country .
17 ` You are the only person who can kill him ; and in consequence he fears you to such an extent that he has set spies to watch you , and they report your movements to him daily .
18 ` When you have reached him , beware of speaking a single word to him , or you will fall into the power of his friends .
19 Seize him at once by the beard and dash him to the ground . '
20 Iwanich thanked the old witch , mounted his foal , put spurs to its sides , and they flew like lightning through the air .
21 Already it was growing dark , when Iwanich perceived some figures in the distance ; they soon came up to them , and then the Prince saw that it was the XXXXX and his friends who were driving through the air in a carriage drawn by owls .	magician		country|eye|foal|magician|mare|matter|point|promise|sides|way

1 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
2 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
3 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
4 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
5 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
6 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
7 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
8 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
9 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
10 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
11 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .
12 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
13 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the bank , and soon the head of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the water .
14 Then he gazed sadly at his wife and stretched out his arms towards her .
15 But another rushing wave arose and dragged him under once more .
16 The hunter 's wife , who had stood on the bank full of joy and hope , sank into despair when she saw her husband snatched away again before her eyes .
17 But for her comfort she dreamt the same dream a third time , and betook herself once more to the old witch 's hut in the flowery meadow .
18 This time the old woman told her to go the next full moon to the mill-pond , and to spin there with a golden spinning-wheel , and then to leave the spinning-wheel on the bank .
19 The hunter 's wife did as she was advised , and the first night the moon was full she sat and spun with a golden spinning-wheel , and then left the wheel on the bank .
20 In a few minutes a rushing sound was heard in the waters , and a wave swept the spinning-wheel from the bank .
21 Immediately the head of the hunter rose up from the XXXXX , getting higher and higher each moment , till at length he stepped on to the bank and fell on his wife 's neck .	pond		flute|hut|joy|moon|pond|sleep|sound|time|wife|woman

1 `` How do you know where to go to ? ''
2 he panted .
3 The leader of the school rolled his white eye and ducked under .
4 `` My tail tingles , youngster , '' he said .
5 `` That means there 's a gale behind me .
6 Come along !
7 When you 're south of the Sticky Water -LSB- he meant the Equator -RSB- and your tail tingles , that means there 's a gale in front of you and you must head north .
8 Come along !
9 The water feels bad here . ''
10 This was one of very many things that Kotick learned , and he was always learning .
11 Matkah taught him to follow the cod and the halibut along the under-sea banks and wrench the rockling out of his hole among the weeds ; how to skirt the wrecks lying a hundred fathoms below water and dart like a rifle bullet in at one porthole and out at another as the fishes ran ; how to dance on the top of the waves when the lightning was racing all over the sky , and wave his flipper politely to the stumpy-tailed Albatross and the Man-of-war Hawk as they went down the wind ; how to jump three or four feet clear of the water like a dolphin , flippers close to the side and tail curved ; to leave the flying fish alone because they are all bony ; to take the shoulder-piece out of a cod at full speed ten fathoms deep , and never to stop and look at a boat or a ship , but particularly a row-boat .
12 At the end of six months what Kotick did not know about deep-sea fishing was not worth the knowing .
13 And all that time he never set flipper on dry ground .
14 One day , however , as he was lying half asleep in the warm water somewhere off the Island of Juan Fernandez , he felt faint and lazy all over , just as human people do when the spring is in their legs , and he remembered the good firm beaches of Novastoshnah seven thousand miles away , the games his companions played , the smell of the seaweed , the seal roar , and the fighting .
15 That very minute he turned north , swimming steadily , and as he went on he met scores of his mates , all bound for the same place , and they said : `` Greeting , Kotick !
16 This year we are all holluschickie , and we can dance the Fire-dance in the breakers off Lukannon and play on the new grass .
17 But where did you get that coat ? ''
18 Kotick 's fur was almost pure white now , and though he felt very proud of it , he only said , `` Swim quickly !
19 My bones are aching for the land . ''
20 And so they all came to the beaches where they had been born , and heard the old seals , their fathers , fighting in the rolling mist .
21 That night Kotick danced the Fire-dance with the yearling XXXXX .	seals		banks|fathers|gale|land|leader|mates|mist|seals|skirt|youngster

5 Whereupon his mother became very angry , and abused him roundly .

1 My tail 's all muddy , and he 'll have two hours ' hard work dressing me for parade . ''
2 The big parade of all the thirty thousand men was held that afternoon , and Vixen and I had a good place close to the Viceroy and the Amir of Afghanistan , with high , big black hat of astrakhan wool and the great diamond star in the center .
3 The first part of the review was all sunshine , and the regiments went by in wave upon wave of legs all moving together , and guns all in a line , till our eyes grew dizzy .
4 Then the cavalry came up , to the beautiful cavalry canter of `` Bonnie Dundee , '' and Vixen cocked her ear where she sat on the dog-cart .
5 The second squadron of the Lancers shot by , and there was the troop-horse , with his tail like spun silk , his head pulled into his breast , one ear forward and one back , setting the time for all his squadron , his legs going as smoothly as waltz music .
6 Then the big guns came by , and I saw Two Tails and two other elephants harnessed in line to a forty-pounder siege gun , while twenty yoke of oxen walked behind .
7 The seventh pair had a new yoke , and they looked rather stiff and tired .
8 Last came the screw guns , and Billy the mule carried himself as though he commanded all the troops , and his harness was oiled and polished till it winked .
9 I gave a cheer all by myself for Billy the mule , but he never looked right or left .
10 The rain began to fall again , and for a while it was too misty to see what the troops were doing .
11 They had made a big half circle across the plain , and were spreading out into a line .
12 That line grew and grew and grew till it was three-quarters of a mile long from wing to wing -- one solid wall of men , horses , and guns .
13 Then it came on straight toward the Viceroy and the Amir , and as it got nearer the ground began to shake , like the deck of a steamer when the engines are going fast .
14 Unless you have been there you can not imagine what a frightening effect this steady come-down of troops has on the spectators , even when they know it is only a review .
15 I looked at the Amir .
16 Up till then he had not shown the shadow of a sign of astonishment or anything else .
17 But now his eyes began to get bigger and bigger , and he picked up the reins on his horse 's neck and looked behind him .
18 For a minute it seemed as though he were going to draw his sword and slash his way out through the English men and women in the carriages at the back .
19 Then the advance stopped dead , the ground stood still , the whole line saluted , and thirty bands began to play all together .
20 That was the end of the review , and the regiments went off to their camps in the rain , and an infantry band struck up with -- The animals went in two by two , Hurrah !
21 The XXXXX went in two by two , The elephant and the battery mul ' , and they all got into the Ark For to get out of the rain !	animals		animals|back|band|ear|effect|neck|parade|spectators|steamer|sword

1 they all said , and the man who had brought the clockwork bird received on the spot the title of ` Bringer of the Imperial First Nightingale . '
2 ` Now they must sing together ; what a duet we shall have ! '
3 And so they sang together , but their voices did not blend , for the real Nightingale sang in her way and the clockwork bird sang waltzes .
4 ` It is not its fault ! '
5 said the bandmaster ; ` it keeps very good time and is quite after my style ! '
6 Then the artificial bird had to sing alone .
7 It gave just as much pleasure as the real one , and then it was so much prettier to look at ; it sparkled like bracelets and necklaces .
8 Three-and-thirty times it sang the same piece without being tired .
9 People would like to have heard it again , but the Emperor thought that the living Nightingale should sing now -- but where was she ?
10 No one had noticed that she had flown out of the open window away to her green woods .
11 ` What SHALL we do ! '
12 said the Emperor .
13 And all the Court scolded , and said that the Nightingale was very ungrateful .
14 ` But we have still the best bird ! '
15 they said and the artificial bird had to sing again , and that was the thirty-fourth time they had heard the same piece .
16 But they did not yet know it by heart ; it was much too difficult .
17 And the bandmaster praised the bird tremendously ; yes , he assured them it was better than a real nightingale , not only because of its beautiful plumage and diamonds , but inside as well .
18 ` For see , my Lords and Ladies and your Imperial Majesty , with the real Nightingale one can never tell what will come out , but all is known about the artificial bird !
19 You can explain it , you can open it and show people where the waltzes lie , how they go , and how one follows the other ! '
20 ` That 's just what we think ! '
21 said everyone ; and the bandmaster received permission to show the bird to the XXXXX the next Sunday .	people		Nightingale|diamonds|duet|fault|one|people|piece|pleasure|time|way

1 ` Never fear , dear master .
2 Schurka and I will look after you , ' said Waska .
3 And in another moment she had climbed down and brought him back a roll , and then another , and another , till she had brought him the whole tray-load .
4 Upon which she said : ` Dear master , Schurka and I are going off to a distant kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth to fetch you back your magic ring .
5 You must be careful that the rolls last till our return . '
6 And Waska took leave of her beloved master , and set off with Schurka on their journey .
7 On and on they travelled , looking always to right and left for traces of the Princess , following up every track , making inquiries of every cat and dog they met , listening to the talk of every wayfarer they passed ; and at last they heard that the kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth where the twelve youths had borne the Princess was not very far off .
8 And at last one day they reached that distant kingdom , and , going at once to the palace , they began to make friends with all the dogs and cats in the place , and to question them about the Princess and the magic ring ; but no one could tell them much about either .
9 Now one day it chanced that Waska had gone down to the palace cellar to hunt for mice and rats , and seeing an especially fat , well-fed mouse , she pounced upon it , buried her claws in its soft fur , and was just going to gobble it up , when she was stopped by the pleading tones of the little creature , saying , ` If you will only spare my life I may be of great service to you .
10 I will do everything in my power for you ; for I am the King of the Mice , and if I perish the whole race will die out . '
11 ` So be it , ' said Waska . '
12 I will spare your life ; but in return you must do something for me .
13 In this castle there lives a Princess , the wicked wife of my dear master .
14 She has stolen away his magic ring .
15 You must get it away from her at whatever cost ; do you hear ?
16 Till you have done this I wo n't take my claws out of your fur . '
17 ` Good ! '
18 replied the mouse ; ' I will do what you ask . '
19 And , so saying , he summoned all the mice in his kingdom together .
20 A countless number of mice , small and big , brown and grey , assembled , and formed a circle round their king , who was a prisoner under Waska 's claws .
21 Turning to them he said : ` Dear and faithful subjects , who ever among you will steal the magic ring from the strange Princess will release me from a cruel death ; and I shall honour him above all the other mice in the XXXXX . '	kingdom		cats|ends|everything|fur|kingdom|life|mouse|place|roll|wife

1 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
2 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
3 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
4 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
5 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
6 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
7 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
8 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
9 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
10 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
11 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
12 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
13 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a spell on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .
14 After this Hermod disappeared , and no one knew what had become of him ; the Queen caused search to be made for him , but he could nowhere be found .
15 One time , when Olof was in the castle beside Hadvor , she asked the Princess if she knew where Hermod had gone to .
16 At this Hadvor became very sad , and said that she did not . '
17 I shall tell you then , ' said Olof , ` for I know all about it .
18 Hermod has disappeared through the wicked devices of the Queen , for she is a witch , and so is her daughter , though they have put on these beautiful forms .
19 Because Hermod would not fall in with the Queen 's plans , and marry her daughter , she has laid a spell on him , to go on an island and be a lion by day and a man by night , and never be freed from this until you burn the lion 's skin .
20 Besides , ' said Olof , ` she has looked out a match for you ; she has a brother in the Underworld , a three-headed Giant , whom she means to turn into a beautiful prince and get him married to you .
21 This is no new thing for the Queen ; she took me away from my parents ' house and compelled me to serve her ; but she has never done me any harm , for the green XXXXX I wear protects me against all mischief .	cloak		cloak|forms|man|name|pirates|prince|proposal|rat|sorrow|witch

1 But we do not notice them even when they throw nuts and filth on our heads . ''
2 He had hardly spoken when a shower of nuts and twigs spattered down through the branches ; and they could hear coughings and howlings and angry jumpings high up in the air among the thin branches .
3 `` The Monkey-People are forbidden , '' said Baloo , `` forbidden to the Jungle-People .
4 Remember . ''
5 `` Forbidden , '' said Bagheera , `` but I still think Baloo should have warned thee against them . ''
6 `` I -- I ?
7 How was I to guess he would play with such dirt .
8 The Monkey People !
9 Faugh ! ''
10 A fresh shower came down on their heads and the two trotted away , taking Mowgli with them .
11 What Baloo had said about the monkeys was perfectly true .
12 They belonged to the tree-tops , and as beasts very seldom look up , there was no occasion for the monkeys and the Jungle-People to cross each other 's path .
13 But whenever they found a sick wolf , or a wounded tiger , or bear , the monkeys would torment him , and would throw sticks and nuts at any beast for fun and in the hope of being noticed .
14 Then they would howl and shriek senseless songs , and invite the Jungle-People to climb up their trees and fight them , or would start furious battles over nothing among themselves , and leave the dead monkeys where the Jungle-People could see them .
15 They were always just going to have a leader , and laws and customs of their own , but they never did , because their memories would not hold over from day to day , and so they compromised things by making up a saying , `` What the Bandar-log think now the jungle will think later , '' and that comforted them a great deal .
16 None of the beasts could reach them , but on the other hand none of the beasts would notice them , and that was why they were so pleased when Mowgli came to play with them , and they heard how angry Baloo was .
17 They never meant to do any more -- the Bandar-log never mean anything at all ; but one of them invented what seemed to him a brilliant idea , and he told all the others that Mowgli would be a useful person to keep in the tribe , because he could weave sticks together for protection from the wind ; so , if they caught him , they could make him teach them .
18 Of course Mowgli , as a woodcutter 's child , inherited all sorts of instincts , and used to make little huts of fallen branches without thinking how he came to do it .
19 The Monkey-People , watching in the trees , considered his play most wonderful .
20 This time , they said , they were really going to have a leader and become the wisest people in the jungle -- so wise that everyone else would notice and envy them .
21 Therefore they followed Baloo and Bagheera and Mowgli through the jungle very quietly till it was XXXXX for the midday nap , and Mowgli , who was very much ashamed of himself , slept between the Panther and the Bear , resolving to have no more to do with the Monkey People .	time		beasts|dirt|howl|leader|others|songs|tiger|time|tribe|wind

1 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
2 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
3 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
4 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
5 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
6 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
7 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
8 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
9 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
10 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
11 When the witch saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?
12 Why did you not scratch their eyes out ? '
13 But the cat curled up its tail and put its back up , and answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never even threw me a bone , but the dear children gave me their own piece of ham . '
14 Then the witch was furious with the watch-dog and with the birch-trees , because they had let the children pass .
15 But the dog answered : ' I have served you all these years and you never gave me so much as a hard crust , but the dear children gave me their own loaf of bread . '
16 And the birch rustled its leaves , and said : ' I have served you longer than I can say , and you never tied a bit of twine even round my branches ; and the dear children bound them up with their brightest ribbons . '
17 So the witch saw there was no help to be got from her old servants , and that the best thing she could do was to mount on her broom and set off in pursuit of the children .
18 And as the children ran they heard the sound of the broom sweeping the ground close behind them , so instantly they threw the handkerchief down over their shoulder , and in a moment a deep , broad river flowed behind them .
19 When the witch came up to it , it took her a long time before she found a place which she could ford over on her broom-stick ; but at last she got across , and continued the chase faster than before .
20 And as the children ran they heard a sound , and the little sister put her ear to the ground , and heard the broom sweeping the earth close behind them ; so , quick as thought , she threw the comb down on the ground , and in an instant , as the cat had said , a dense forest sprung up , in which the roots and branches were so closely intertwined , that it was impossible to force a way through it .
21 So when the witch came up to it on her XXXXX she found that there was nothing for it but to turn round and go back to her hut .	broom		birch|bit|broom|dog|girl|granny|meantime|river|shoulder|witch

1 He was cunning enough , however , to conceal his feelings and to make no direct answer , but he only asked the maiden , as if carelessly , what was remarkable about the ring ?
2 She answered , ` No mortal is able entirely to understand the power of this ring , because no one thoroughly understands the secret signs engraved upon it .
3 But even with my half-knowledge I can work great wonders .
4 If I put the ring upon the little finger of my left hand , then I can fly like a bird through the air wherever I wish to go .
5 If I put it on the third finger of my left hand I am invisible , and I can see everything that passes around me , though no one can see me .
6 If I put the ring upon the middle finger of my left hand , then neither fire nor water nor any sharp weapon can hurt me .
7 If I put it on the forefinger of my left hand , then I can with its help produce whatever I wish .
8 I can in a single moment build houses or anything I desire .
9 Finally , as long as I wear the ring on the thumb of my left hand , that hand is so strong that it can break down rocks and walls .
10 Besides these , the ring has other secret signs which , as I said , no one can understand .
11 No doubt it contains secrets of great importance .
12 The ring formerly belonged to King Solomon , the wisest of kings , during whose reign the wisest men lived .
13 But it is not known whether this ring was ever made by mortal hands : it is supposed that an angel gave it to the wise King . '
14 When the youth heard all this he determined to try and get possession of the ring , though he did not quite believe in all its wonderful gifts .
15 He wished the maiden would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .
16 A few days after they were again speaking of the magic ring , and the youth said , ' I do not think it possible that the ring can have all the power you say it has . '
17 Then the maiden opened the box and took the ring out , and it glittered as she held it like the clearest sunbeam .
18 She put it on the middle finger of her left hand , and told the youth to take a knife and try as hard as he could to cut her with it , for he would not be able to hurt her .
19 He was unwilling at first , but the maiden insisted .
20 Then he tried , at first only in play , and then seriously , to strike her with the knife , but an invisible wall of iron seemed to be between them , and the maiden stood before him laughing and unhurt .
21 Then she put the ring on her third XXXXX , and in an instant she had vanished from his eyes .	finger		air|finger|knife|maiden|one|possession|ring|speaking|weapon|youth

1 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
2 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
3 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
4 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
5 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
6 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other elephants who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .
7 Elephants are very strictly preserved by the Indian Government .
8 There is one whole department which does nothing else but hunt them , and catch them , and break them in , and send them up and down the country as they are needed for work .
9 Kala Nag stood ten fair feet at the shoulders , and his tusks had been cut off short at five feet , and bound round the ends , to prevent them splitting , with bands of copper ; but he could do more with those stumps than any untrained elephant could do with the real sharpened ones .
10 When , after weeks and weeks of cautious driving of scattered elephants across the hills , the forty or fifty wild monsters were driven into the last stockade , and the big drop gate , made of tree trunks lashed together , jarred down behind them , Kala Nag , at the word of command , would go into that flaring , trumpeting pandemonium -LRB- generally at night , when the flicker of the torches made it difficult to judge distances -RRB- , and , picking out the biggest and wildest tusker of the mob , would hammer him and hustle him into quiet while the men on the backs of the other elephants roped and tied the smaller ones .
11 There was nothing in the way of fighting that Kala Nag , the old wise Black Snake , did not know , for he had stood up more than once in his time to the charge of the wounded tiger , and , curling up his soft trunk to be out of harm 's way , had knocked the springing brute sideways in mid-air with a quick sickle cut of his head , that he had invented all by himself ; had knocked him over , and kneeled upon him with his huge knees till the life went out with a gasp and a howl , and there was only a fluffy striped thing on the ground for Kala Nag to pull by the tail .
12 `` Yes , '' said Big Toomai , his driver , the son of Black Toomai who had taken him to Abyssinia , and grandson of Toomai of the Elephants who had seen him caught , `` there is nothing that the Black Snake fears except me .
13 He has seen three generations of us feed him and groom him , and he will live to see four . ''
14 `` He is afraid of me also , '' said Little Toomai , standing up to his full height of four feet , with only one rag upon him .
15 He was ten years old , the eldest son of Big Toomai , and , according to custom , he would take his father 's place on Kala Nag 's neck when he grew up , and would handle the heavy iron ankus , the elephant goad , that had been worn smooth by his father , and his grandfather , and his great-grandfather .
16 He knew what he was talking of ; for he had been born under Kala Nag 's shadow , had played with the end of his trunk before he could walk , had taken him down to water as soon as he could walk , and Kala Nag would no more have dreamed of disobeying his shrill little orders than he would have dreamed of killing him on that day when Big Toomai carried the little brown baby under Kala Nag 's tusks , and told him to salute his master that was to be .
17 `` Yes , '' said Little Toomai , `` he is afraid of me , '' and he took long strides up to Kala Nag , called him a fat old pig , and made him lift up his feet one after the other .
18 `` Wah ! ''
19 said Little Toomai , `` thou art a big elephant , '' and he wagged his fluffy head , quoting his father .
20 `` The Government may pay for elephants , but they belong to us mahouts .
21 When thou art old , Kala Nag , there will come some rich rajah , and he will buy thee from the XXXXX , on account of thy size and thy manners , and then thou wilt have nothing to do but to carry gold earrings in thy ears , and a gold howdah on thy back , and a red cloth covered with gold on thy sides , and walk at the head of the processions of the King .
