1 It was they who changed the little house you saw before you into the fountain for which you are now asking , and , having turned me into a frog , they ordered me to say to the first person who came to the fountain exactly what I repeated to you .
2 But , my lord , when you stood before me , it was agony to my heart , filled as it was with thoughts of you , to appear to your eyes under so monstrous a form .
3 However , there was no help for it , and , painful as it was , I had to submit .
4 I desired your success with all my soul , not only for your own sake , but also for my own , because I could not get back my proper shape till you had become master of the beautiful bird , though I am quite ignorant as to your reason for seeking it . '
5 On this Saphir explained about the state of his father 's health , and all that has been told before .
6 On hearing this story Serpentine grew very sad , and her lovely eyes filled with tears .
7 ` Ah , my lord , ' she said , ` you know nothing of me but what you have seen in the mirror ; and I , who can not even name my parents , learn that you are a king 's son . '
8 In vain Saphir declared that love made them equal ; Serpentine would only reply : ' I love you too much to allow you to marry beneath your rank .
9 I shall be very unhappy , of course , but I shall never alter my mind .
10 If I do not find from the fairies that my birth is worthy of you , then , whatever be my feelings , I will never accept your hand . '
11 The conversation was at this point , and bid fair to last some time longer , when one of the fairies appeared in her ivory car , accompanied by a beautiful woman past her early youth .
12 At this moment the bird suddenly awakened , and , flying on to Saphir 's shoulder -LRB- which it never afterwards left -RRB- , began fondling him as well as a bird can do .
13 The fairy told Serpentine that she was quite satisfied with her conduct , and made herself very agreeable to Saphir , whom she presented to the lady she had brought with her , explaining that the lady was no other than his Aunt Aglantine , widow of Diamantino .
14 Then they all fell into each other 's arms , till the fairy mounted her chariot , placed Aglantine by her side , and Saphir and Serpentine on the front seat .
15 She also sent a message to the Prince 's attendants that they might travel slowly back to the Court of King Peridor , and that the beautiful bird had really been found .
16 This matter being comfortably arranged , she started off her chariot .
17 But in spite of the swiftness with which they flew through the air , the time passed even quicker for Saphir and Serpentine , who had so much to think about .
18 They were still quite confused with the pleasure of seeing each other , when the chariot arrived at King Peridor 's palace .
19 He had had himself carried to a room on the roof , where his nurses thought that he would die at any moment .
20 Directly the chariot drew within sight of the castle the beautiful bird took flight , and , making straight for the dying King , at once cured him of his sickness .
21 Then she resumed her natural XXXXX , and he found that the bird was no other than the Queen Constance , whom he had long believed to be dead .	shape		conversation|feelings|frog|health|message|person|roof|shape|spite|success

1 Ferko continued his way till he came to a ploughed field .
2 Here he noticed a little mouse creeping wearily along on its hind paws , for its front paws had both been broken in a trap .
3 Ferko felt so sorry for the little beast that he spoke to it in the most friendly manner , and washed its small paws with the healing water .
4 In a moment the mouse was sound and whole , and after thanking the kind physician it scampered away over the ploughed furrows .
5 Ferko again proceeded on his journey , but he had n't gone far before a queen bee flew against him , trailing one wing behind her , which had been cruelly torn in two by a big bird .
6 Ferko was no less willing to help her than he had been to help the wolf and the mouse , so he poured some healing drops over the wounded wing .
7 On the spot the queen bee was cured , and turning to Ferko she said , ' I am most grateful for your kindness , and shall reward you some day . '
8 And with these words she flew away humming , gaily .
9 Then Ferko wandered on for many a long day , and at length reached a strange kingdom .
10 Here , he thought to himself , he might as well go straight to the palace and offer his services to the King of the country , for he had heard that the King 's daughter was as beautiful as the day .
11 So he went to the royal palace , and as he entered the door the first people he saw were his two brothers who had so shamefully ill-treated him .
12 They had managed to obtain places in the King 's service , and when they recognised Ferko with his eyes and legs sound and well they were frightened to death , for they feared he would tell the King of their conduct , and that they would be hung .
13 No sooner had Ferko entered the palace than all eyes were turned on the handsome youth , and the King 's daughter herself was lost in admiration , for she had never seen anyone so handsome in her life before .
14 His brothers noticed this , and envy and jealousy were added to their fear , so much so that they determined once more to destroy him .
15 They went to the King and told him that Ferko was a wicked magician , who had come to the palace with the intention of carrying off the Princess .
16 Then the King had Ferko brought before him , and said , ` You are accused of being a magician who wishes to rob me of my daughter , and I condemn you to death ; but if you can fulfil three tasks which I shall set you to do your life shall be spared , on condition you leave the country ; but if you can not perform what I demand you shall be hung on the nearest tree . '
17 And turning to the two wicked brothers he said , ` Suggest something for him to do ; no matter how difficult , he must succeed in it or die . '
18 They did not think long , but replied , ` Let him build your Majesty in one day a more beautiful palace than this , and if he fails in the attempt let him be hung . '
19 The King was pleased with this proposal , and commanded Ferko to set to work on the following day .
20 The two brothers were delighted , for they thought they had now got rid of Ferko for ever .
21 The poor XXXXX himself was heart-broken , and cursed the hour he had crossed the boundary of the King 's domain .	youth		admiration|brothers|condition|fear|field|intention|magician|proposal|way|youth

1 The other herd children , watching with the cattle half a mile away , hurried to the village as fast as their legs could carry them , crying that the buffaloes had gone mad and run away .
2 But Mowgli 's plan was simple enough .
3 All he wanted to do was to make a big circle uphill and get at the head of the ravine , and then take the bulls down it and catch Shere Khan between the bulls and the cows ; for he knew that after a meal and a full drink Shere Khan would not be in any condition to fight or to clamber up the sides of the ravine .
4 He was soothing the buffaloes now by voice , and Akela had dropped far to the rear , only whimpering once or twice to hurry the rear-guard .
5 It was a long , long circle , for they did not wish to get too near the ravine and give Shere Khan warning .
6 At last Mowgli rounded up the bewildered herd at the head of the ravine on a grassy patch that sloped steeply down to the ravine itself .
7 From that height you could see across the tops of the trees down to the plain below ; but what Mowgli looked at was the sides of the ravine , and he saw with a great deal of satisfaction that they ran nearly straight up and down , while the vines and creepers that hung over them would give no foothold to a tiger who wanted to get out .
8 `` Let them breathe , Akela , '' he said , holding up his hand .
9 `` They have not winded him yet .
10 Let them breathe .
11 I must tell Shere Khan who comes .
12 We have him in the trap . ''
13 He put his hands to his mouth and shouted down the ravine -- it was almost like shouting down a tunnel -- and the echoes jumped from rock to rock .
14 After a long time there came back the drawling , sleepy snarl of a full-fed tiger just wakened .
15 `` Who calls ? ''
16 said Shere Khan , and a splendid peacock fluttered up out of the ravine screeching .
17 `` I , Mowgli .
18 Cattle thief , it is time to come to the Council Rock !
19 Down -- hurry them down , Akela !
20 Down , Rama , down ! ''
21 The XXXXX paused for an instant at the edge of the slope , but Akela gave tongue in the full hunting-yell , and they pitched over one after the other , just as steamers shoot rapids , the sand and stones spurting up round them .	herd		bulls|circle|drink|hand|herd|meal|time|tops|trap|voice

1 That night she went back to John and Amelia .
2 They , on their part , welcomed her back gladly , believing her to be a wronged and ill-used woman .
3 They hated Stephen Fair with a new and personal rancour .
4 The one thing they could hardly have forgiven Emily would have been the fact of her relenting towards him .
5 But she did not relent .
6 In her soul she knew that , with all her just grievances , she had been in the wrong , and for that she could not forgive him !
7 Two years after she had left Stephen Mrs. Fair died , and his widowed sister-in-law went to keep house for him .
8 If he thought of Emily he made no sign .
9 Stephen Fair never broke a word once passed .
10 Since their separation no greeting or look had ever passed between husband and wife .
11 When they met , as they occasionally did , neither impassive face changed .
12 Emily Fair had buried her love deeply .
13 In her pride and anger she would not let herself remember even where she had dug its grave .
14 And now Stephen was ill .
15 The strange woman felt a certain pride in her own inflexibility because the fact did not affect her .
16 She told herself that she could not have felt more unconcerned had he been the merest stranger .
17 Nevertheless she waited and watched for John Phillips ' homecoming .
18 At ten o'clock she heard his voice in the kitchen .
19 She leaned out of the bed and pulled open her door .
20 She heard voices below , but could not distinguish the words , so she rose and went noiselessly out into the hall , knelt down by the stair railing and listened .
21 The door of the kitchen was open below her and a narrow shaft of light struck on her white , intent XXXXX .	face		bed|face|grievances|hall|love|pride|separation|sign|voices|woman

1 Then the twins crumbled their bread on the ground , and the wrens pecked it , and chirruped and chirped .
2 And when they had eaten the last crumb they told the boy to fill up the holes of the sieve with clay , and then to draw water from the well .
3 So he did what they said , and carried the sieve full of water into the hut without spilling a drop .
4 When they entered the hut the cat was curled up on the floor .
5 So they stroked her , and fed her with ham , and said to her : ` Pussy , grey pussy , tell us how we are to get away from the witch ? '
6 Then the cat thanked them for the ham , and gave them a pocket-handkerchief and a comb , and told them that when the witch pursued them , as she certainly would , all they had to do was to throw the handkerchief on the ground and run as fast as they could .
7 As soon as the handkerchief touched the ground a deep , broad river would spring up , which would hinder the witch 's progress .
8 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
9 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
10 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
11 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
12 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
13 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
14 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the handkerchief , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .
15 And first they met the watch-dog , who was going to leap on them and tear them to pieces ; but they threw the remains of their bread to him , and he ate them and wagged his tail .
16 Then they were hindered by the birch-trees , whose branches almost put their eyes out .
17 But the little sister tied the twigs together with a piece of ribbon , and they got past safely , and , after running through the wood , came out on to the open fields .
18 In the meantime in the hut the cat was busy weaving the linen and tangling the threads as it wove .
19 And the witch returned to see how the children were getting on ; and she crept up to the window , and whispered : ` Are you weaving , my little dear ? '
20 ` Yes , granny , I am weaving , ' answered the cat .
21 When the XXXXX saw that the children had escaped her , she was furious , and , hitting the cat with a porringer , she said : ` Why did you let the children leave the hut ?	witch		boy|bread|comb|ham|limb|pieces|remains|tail|witch|wood

1 asked Margaret absently , wondering why there had been no letter for her that morning -- and this was the third day too !
2 Could Gilbert be ill ?
3 Or was he flirting with some other girl and forgetting her ?
4 Margaret swallowed a big lump in her throat , and resolved that she would go home next week -- no , she would n't , either -- if he was as hateful and fickle as that -- what was Aunt Beatrice saying ?
5 `` Well , I 'm -- I 'm not used to going to parties now , my dear .
6 And the truth is I have no dress fit to wear .
7 At least Bella said so , because the party was to be a very fashionable affair .
8 She said my old grey silk would n't do at all .
9 Of course she knows .
10 She had to have a new dress for it , and , we could n't both have that .
11 George could n't afford it these hard times .
12 And , as Bella said , it would be very foolish of me to get an expensive dress that would be no use to me afterward .
13 But it does n't matter .
14 And , of course , somebody had to stay with the children . ''
15 `` Of course , '' assented Margaret dreamily .
16 Mrs. Cunningham 's `` at home '' was of no particular interest .

1 The Queen ! '
2 and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces .
3 There was a sound of many footsteps , and Alice looked round , eager to see the Queen .
4 First came ten soldiers carrying clubs ; these were all shaped like the three gardeners , oblong and flat , with their hands and feet at the corners : next the ten courtiers ; these were ornamented all over with diamonds , and walked two and two , as the soldiers did .
5 After these came the royal children ; there were ten of them , and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand , in couples : they were all ornamented with hearts .
6 Next came the guests , mostly Kings and Queens , and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit : it was talking in a hurried nervous manner , smiling at everything that was said , and went by without noticing her .
7 Then followed the Knave of Hearts , carrying the King 's crown on a crimson velvet cushion ; and , last of all this grand procession , came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS .
8 Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners , but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions ; ` and besides , what would be the use of a procession , ' thought she , ` if people had all to lie down upon their faces , so that they could n't see it ? '
9 So she stood still where she was , and waited .
10 When the procession came opposite to Alice , they all stopped and looked at her , and the Queen said severely ` Who is this ? '
11 She said it to the Knave of Hearts , who only bowed and smiled in reply .
12 ` Idiot ! '
13 said the Queen , tossing her head impatiently ; and , turning to Alice , she went on , ` What 's your name , child ? '
14 ` My name is Alice , so please your Majesty , ' said Alice very politely ; but she added , to herself , ` Why , they 're only a pack of cards , after all .
15 I need n't be afraid of them ! '
16 ` And who are THESE ? '
17 said the Queen , pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rosetree ; for , you see , as they were lying on their faces , and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack , she could not tell whether they were gardeners , or soldiers , or courtiers , or three of her own children .
18 ` How should I know ? '
19 said Alice , surprised at her own courage .
20 ` It 's no business of MINE . '
21 The Queen turned crimson with fury , and , after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast , screamed ` Off with her XXXXX !	head		backs|face|faces|footsteps|gardeners|head|name|rest|soldiers|sound

1 I might have said to Claude , So like a boy !
2 but I did n't .
3 Instead , I sympathized with him , and pointed out that it really did n't matter because I had spoiled it by jabbing my elbow through it .
4 By this time the kite was out of sight , and we never expected to see or hear of it again .
5 * * * * * A month later a letter came to the Big Half Moon for Father .
6 Jake Wiggins brought it over in his sloop .
7 Father went off by himself to read it , and such a queer-looking face as he had when he came back !
8 His eyes looked as if he had been crying , but that could n't be , I suppose , because Claude says men never cry .
9 Anyhow , his face was all glad and soft and smiley .
10 `` Do you two young pirates and freebooters want to know what has become of your kite ? ''
11 he said .
12 Then he sat down beside us on the rocks at the Mermaid 's Pool and told us the whole story , and read his letter to us .
13 It was the most amazing thing .
14 It seems Father had had relations after all -- a brother and a sister in particular .
15 But when he was a young man he quarrelled with his brother , who did n't treat him very well -- but he 's been dead for years , so I wo n't say a word against him -- and had gone away from home .
16 He never went back , and he never even let them know he was living .
17 Father says that this was very wrong of him , and I suppose it was , since he says so ; but I do n't see how Father could do anything wrong .
18 Anyway , he had a sister Esther whom he loved very much ; but he felt bitter against her too , because he thought she took his brother 's part too much .
19 So , though a letter of hers , asking him to go back , did reach him , he never answered it , and he never heard anything more .
20 Years afterward he felt sorry and went back , but his brother was dead and his sister had gone away , and he could n't find out a single thing about her .
21 So much for that ; and now about the XXXXX .	kite		Pool|eyes|face|freebooters|kite|matter|part|rocks|thing|word

4 said Little Klaus . '
5 I will tell you the whole story , and I thank you for having drowned me , because now I am on dry land and really rich !
6 How frightened I was when I was in the sack !
7 How the wind whistled in my ears as you threw me from the bridge into the cold water !
8 I sank at once to the bottom ; but I did not hurt myself for underneath was growing the most beautiful soft grass .
9 I fell on this , and immediately the sack opened ; the loveliest maiden in snow-white garments , with a green garland round her wet hair , took me by the hand , and said ! ''

13 Along it they travel underneath from the sea to the land till the river ends .
14 It was so beautiful , full of flowers and fresh grass ; the fishes which were swimming in the water shot past my ears as the birds do here in the air .

1 One day , whilst passing near a fountain in the garden , she noticed that the sun 's rays fell on the water in such a manner as to produce a brilliant rainbow .
2 She stood still to admire it , when , to her great surprise , she heard a voice addressing her which seemed to come from the centre of its rays .
3 The voice was that of a young man , and its sweetness of tone and the agreeable things it uttered , led one to infer that its owner must be equally charming ; but this had to be a mere matter of fancy , for no one was visible .
4 The beautiful Rainbow informed Fairer-than-a-Fairy that he was young , the son of a powerful king , and that the Fairy , Lagree , who owed his parents a grudge , had revenged herself by depriving him of his natural shape for some years ; that she had imprisoned him in the palace , where he had found his confinement hard to bear for some time , but now , he owned , he no longer sighed for freedom since he had seen and learned to love Fairer-than-a-Fairy .
5 He added many other tender speeches to this declaration , and the Princess , to whom such remarks were a new experience , could not help feeling pleased and touched by his attentions .
6 The Prince could only appear or speak under the form of a Rainbow , and it was therefore necessary that the sun should shine on water so as to enable the rays to form themselves .
7 Fairer-than-a-Fairy lost no moment in which she could meet her lover , and they enjoyed many long and interesting interviews .
8 One day , however , their conversation became so absorbing and time passed so quickly that the Princess forgot to attend to the fire , and it went out .
9 Lagree , on her return , soon found out the neglect , and seemed only too pleased to have the opportunity of showing her spite to her lovely prisoner .
10 She ordered Fairer-than-a-Fairy to start next day at dawn to ask Locrinos for fire with which to relight the one she had allowed to go out .
11 Now this Locrinos was a cruel monster who devoured everyone he came across , and especially enjoyed a chance of catching and eating any young girls .
12 Our heroine obeyed with great sweetness , and without having been able to take leave of her lover she set off to go to Locrinos as to certain death .
13 As she was crossing a wood a bird sang to her to pick up a shining pebble which she would find in a fountain close by , and to use it when needed .
14 She took the bird 's advice , and in due time arrived at the house of Locrinos .
15 Luckily she only found his wife at home , who was much struck by the Princess 's youth and beauty and sweet gentle manners , and still further impressed by the present of the shining pebble .
16 She readily let Fairer-than-a-Fairy have the fire , and in return for the stone she gave her another , which , she said , might prove useful some day .
17 Then she sent her away without doing her any harm .
18 Lagree was as much surprised as displeased at the happy result of this expedition , and Fairer-than-a Fairy waited anxiously for an opportunity of meeting Prince Rainbow and telling him her adventures .
19 She found , however , that he had already been told all about them by a Fairy who protected him , and to whom he was related .
20 The dread of fresh dangers to his beloved Princess made him devise some more convenient way of meeting than by the garden fountain , and Fairer-than-a-Fairy carried out his plan daily with entire success .
21 Every morning she placed a large basin full of water on her window-sill , and as soon as the sun 's rays fell on the XXXXX the Rainbow appeared as clearly as it had ever done in the fountain .	water		dread|everyone|fountain|heroine|neglect|palace|prisoner|result|voice|water

1 They will rush to eat them up greedily , and when you have scattered the last crumb you must lose no time in throwing the hare to them ; as soon as the hare feels itself on the ground it will run away as quickly as possible , and the wild beasts will turn to pursue it .
2 In this way you will be able to get through the wood unhurt . '
3 Iwanich thanked the old man for his counsel , dismounted from his horse , and , taking the bag and the hare in his arms , he entered the forest .
4 He had hardly lost sight of his gaunt grey friend when he heard growls and snarls in the thicket close to him , and before he had time to think he found himself surrounded by the most dreadful-looking creatures .
5 On one side he saw the glittering eye of a cruel tiger , on the other the gleaming teeth of a great she-wolf ; here a huge bear growled fiercely , and there a horrible snake coiled itself in the grass at his feet .
6 But Iwanich did not forget the old man 's advice , and quickly put his hand into the bag and took out as many bread-crumbs as he could hold in his hand at a time .
7 He threw them to the beasts , but soon the bag grew lighter and lighter , and the Prince began to feel a little frightened .
8 And now the last crumb was gone , and the hungry beasts thronged round him , greedy for fresh prey .
9 Then he seized the hare and threw it to them .
10 No sooner did the little creature feel itself on the ground than it lay back its ears and flew through the wood like an arrow from a bow , closely pursued by the wild beasts , and the Prince was left alone .
11 He looked at his ring , and when he saw that it sparkled as brightly as ever he went straight on through the forest .
12 He had n't gone very far when he saw a most extraordinary looking man coming towards him .
13 He was not more than three feet high , his legs were quite crooked , and all his body was covered with prickles like a hedgehog .
14 Two lions walked with him , fastened to his side by the two ends of his long beard .
15 He stopped the Prince and asked him in a harsh voice : ` Are you the man who has just fed my body-guard ? '
16 Iwanich was so startled that he could hardly reply , but the little man continued : ' I am most grateful to you for your kindness ; what can I give you as a reward ? '
17 ` All I ask , ' replied Iwanich , ` is , that I should be allowed to go through this wood in safety . '
18 ` Most certainly , ' answered the little man ; ` and for greater security I will give you one of my lions as a protector .
19 But when you leave this wood and come near a palace which does not belong to my domain , let the lion go , in order that he may not fall into the hands of an enemy and be killed . '
20 With these words he loosened the lion from his beard and bade the beast guard the youth carefully .
21 With this new protector Iwanich wandered on through the XXXXX , and though he came upon a great many more wolves , hyenas , leopards , and other wild beasts , they always kept at a respectful distance when they saw what sort of an escort the Prince had with him .	forest		advice|arms|beasts|ends|forest|hands|palace|reward|security|sight

1 The miller thought she must mean one of his puppies or kittens , so promised the nixy at once what she asked , and returned to his mill full of hope .
2 On the threshold he was greeted by a servant with the news that his wife had just given birth to a boy .
3 The poor miller was much horrified by these tidings , and went in to his wife with a heavy heart to tell her and his relations of the fatal bargain he had just struck with the nixy . '
4 I would gladly give up all the good fortune she promised me , ' he said , ` if I could only save my child . '
5 But no one could think of any advice to give him , beyond taking care that the child never went near the mill-pond .
6 So the boy throve and grew big , and in the meantime all prospered with the miller , and in a few years he was richer than he had ever been before .
7 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
8 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
9 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
10 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
11 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
12 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
13 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
14 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
15 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
16 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
17 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
18 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
19 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
20 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
21 The hunter 's wife gave the XXXXX a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .	witch		arms|bargain|comb|home|land|meantime|round|skin|sorrow|witch

1 Then the Hunter did as the old woman had told him : he cut open the bird , found its heart , swallowed it , and took the cloak home with him .
2 The next morning when he awoke he remembered the promise , and wanted to see if it had come true .
3 But when he lifted up his pillow , there sparkled the gold piece , and the next morning he found another , and so on every time he got up .
4 He collected a heap of gold , but at last he thought to himself , ` What good is all my gold to me if I stay at home ?
5 I will travel and look a bit about me in the world . '
6 So he took leave of his parents , slung his hunting knapsack and his gun round him , and journeyed into the world .
7 It happened that one day he went through a thick wood , and when he came to the end of it there lay in the plain before him a large castle .
8 At one of the windows in it stood an old woman with a most beautiful maiden by her side , looking out .
9 But the old woman was a witch , and she said to the girl , ` There comes one out of the wood who has a wonderful treasure in his body which we must manage to possess ourselves of , darling daughter ; we have more right to it than he .
10 He has a bird 's heart in him , and so every morning there lies a gold piece under his pillow . '
11 She told her how they could get hold of it , and how she was to coax it from him , and at last threatened her angrily , saying , ` And if you do not obey me , you shall repent it ! '
12 When the Hunter came nearer he saw the maiden , and said to himself , ' I have travelled so far now that I will rest , and turn into this beautiful castle ; money I have in plenty . '
13 But the real reason was that he had caught sight of the lovely face .
14 He went into the house , and was kindly received and hospitably entertained .
15 It was not long before he was so much in love with the witch-maiden that he thought of nothing else , and only looked in her eyes , and whatever she wanted , that he gladly did .
16 Then the old witch said , ` Now we must have the bird-heart ; he will not feel when it is gone . '
17 She prepared a drink , and when it was ready she poured it in a goblet and gave it to the maiden , who had to hand it to the hunter .
18 ` Drink to me now , my dearest , ' she said .
19 Then he took the goblet , and when he had swallowed the drink the bird-heart came out of his mouth .
20 The maiden had to get hold of it secretly and then swallow it herself , for the old witch wanted to have it .
21 Thenceforward he found no more gold under his pillow , and it lay under the maiden 's ; but he was so much in XXXXX and so much bewitched that he thought of nothing except spending all his time with the maiden .	love		bit|body|end|face|love|maiden|money|pillow|promise|woman

1 As time went on the Queen fell sick , and suspecting that it was her last illness , sent for the King to come to her .
2 When he came she told him that she had no long time to live , and therefore wished to ask one thing of him , which was , that if he married another wife he should promise to take no other one than the Queen of Hetland the Good .
3 The King gave the promise , and thereafter the Queen died .
4 Time went past , and the King , growing tired of living alone , fitted out his ship and sailed out to sea .
5 As he sailed there came upon him so thick a mist that he altogether lost his bearings , but after long trouble he found land .
6 There he laid his ship to , and went on shore all alone .
7 After walking for some time he came to a forest , into which he went a little way and stopped .
8 Then he heard sweet music from a harp , and went in the direction of the sound until he came to a clearing , and there he saw three women , one of whom sat on a golden chair , and was beautifully and grandly dressed ; she held a harp in her hands , and was very sorrowful .
9 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
10 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
11 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
12 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
13 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
14 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
15 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
16 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
17 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
18 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
19 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
20 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
21 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a XXXXX on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .	spell		country|fortune|hand|king|maid|nothing|spell|time|way|woman

1 Stand at the door of the hen-house , and wait there for your horses .
2 In the meantime I will slip in among the hens through a hole in the wall and give them a good chase , so that the noise they make will arouse the royal henwives , and they will come to see what is the matter .
3 When they see the horses they will at once imagine them to be the cause of the disturbance , and will drive them out .
4 Then you must lay hands on the mare and foal and catch them .
5 All turned out exactly as the sly fox had foreseen .
6 The Prince swung himself on the mare , seized the foal by its bridle , and hurried home .
7 While he was riding over the heath in the highest of spirits the mare suddenly said to her rider : ` You are the first person who has ever succeeded in outwitting the old witch Corva , and now you may ask what reward you like for your service .
8 If you promise never to betray me I will give you a piece of advice which you will do well to follow . '
9 The Prince promised never to betray her confidence , and the mare continued : ` Ask nothing else as a reward than my foal , for it has not its like in the world , and is not to be bought for love or money ; for it can go from one end of the earth to another in a few minutes .
10 Of course the cunning Corva will do her best to dissuade you from taking the foal , and will tell you that it is both idle and sickly ; but do not believe her , and stick to your point . '
11 Iwanich longed to possess such an animal , and promised the mare to follow her advice .
12 This time Corva received him in the most friendly manner , and set a sumptuous repast before him .
13 As soon as he had finished she asked him what reward he demanded for his year 's service .
14 ` Nothing more nor less , ' replied the Prince , ` than the foal of your mare . '
15 The witch pretended to be much astonished at his request , and said that he deserved something much better than the foal , for the beast was lazy and nervous , blind in one eye , and , in short , was quite worthless .
16 But the Prince knew what he wanted , and when the old witch saw that he had made up his mind to have the foal , she said , ' I am obliged to keep my promise and to hand you over the foal ; and as I know who you are and what you want , I will tell you in what way the animal will be useful to you .
17 The man in the cauldron of boiling pitch , whom you set free , is a mighty magician ; through your curiosity and thoughtlessness Militza came into his power , and he has transported her and her castle and belongings into a distant country .
18 ` You are the only person who can kill him ; and in consequence he fears you to such an extent that he has set spies to watch you , and they report your movements to him daily .
19 ` When you have reached him , beware of speaking a single word to him , or you will fall into the power of his friends .
20 Seize him at once by the beard and dash him to the ground . '
21 Iwanich thanked the old witch , mounted his XXXXX , put spurs to its sides , and they flew like lightning through the air .	foal		disturbance|door|foal|horses|magician|manner|money|power|rider|wall

1 The Queen hastened to inform the King her husband , and the wedding took place on the spot .
2 As the ceremony was completed the Wizard King arrived .
3 His despair at being so late bewildered him so entirely that he appeared in his natural form and attempted to sprinkle some black liquid over the bride and bridegroom , which was intended to kill them , but the Fairy stretched out her wand and the liquid dropped on the Magician himself .
4 He fell down senseless , and the Princess 's father , deeply offended at the cruel revenge which had been attempted , ordered him to be removed and locked up in prison .
5 Now as magicians lose all their power as soon as they are in prison , the King felt himself much embarrassed at being thus at the mercy of those he had so greatly offended .
6 The Prince implored and obtained his father 's pardon , and the prison doors were opened .
7 No sooner was this done than the Wizard King was seen in the air under the form of some unknown bird , exclaiming as he flew off that he would never forgive either his son or the Fairy the cruel wrong they had done him .
8 Everyone entreated the Fairy to settle in the kingdom where she now was , to which she consented .
9 She built herself a magnificent palace , to which she transported her books and fairy secrets , and where she enjoyed the sight of the perfect happiness she had helped to bestow on the entire royal family .
10 THE NIXY -LRB- 15 -RRB- -LRB- 15 -RRB- From the German .
11 Kletke .
12 There was once upon a time a miller who was very well off , and had as much money and as many goods as he knew what to do with .
13 But sorrow comes in the night , and the miller all of a sudden became so poor that at last he could hardly call the mill in which he sat his own .
14 He wandered about all day full of despair and misery , and when he lay down at night he could get no rest , but lay awake all night sunk in sorrowful thoughts .
15 One morning he rose up before dawn and went outside , for he thought his heart would be lighter in the open air .
16 As he wandered up and down on the banks of the mill-pond he heard a rustling in the water , and when he looked near he saw a white woman rising up from the waves .
17 He realised at once that this could be none other than the nixy of the mill-pond , and in his terror he did n't know if he should fly away or remain where he was .
18 While he hesitated the nixy spoke , called him by his name , and asked him why he was so sad .
19 When the miller heard how friendly her tone was , he plucked up heart and told her how rich and prosperous he had been all his life up till now , when he did n't know what he was to do for want and misery .
20 Then the nixy spoke comforting words to him , and promised that she would make him richer and more prosperous than he had ever been in his life before , if he would give her in return the youngest thing in his house .
21 The miller thought she must mean one of his puppies or kittens , so promised the nixy at once what she asked , and returned to his XXXXX full of hope .	mill		bird|goods|house|life|magicians|mill|money|son|woman|words

1 The old witch grew angry , and said , ` Such a cloak is a wonderful thing , it is seldom to be had in the world , and have it I must and will . '
2 She beat the maiden , and said that if she did not obey it would go ill with her .
3 So she did her mother 's bidding , and , standing one day by the window , she looked away into the far distance as if she were very sad .
4 ` Why are you standing there looking so sad ? '
5 asked the Hunter .
6 ` Alas , my love , ' she replied , ` over there lies the granite mountain where the costly precious stones grow .
7 I have a great longing to go there , so that when I think of it I am very sad .
8 For who can fetch them ?
9 Only the birds who fly ; a man , never . '
10 ` If you have no other trouble , ' said the Hunter , ` that one I can easily remove from your heart . '
11 So he wrapped her round in his cloak and wished themselves to the granite mountain , and in an instant there they were , sitting on it !
12 The precious stones sparkled so brightly on all sides that it was a pleasure to see them , and they collected the most beautiful and costly together .
13 But now the old witch had through her caused the Hunter 's eyes to become heavy .

15 So they sat down , and he laid his head on her lap and fell asleep .

1 Soon the time came round when the king of the beasts would expect the youths and maidens to be brought to him .
2 The King therefore issued a proclamation inviting twelve youths and twelve maidens to offer themselves up to save their country ; and immediately many young people , far more than enough , hastened to do so .
3 A new ship was built , and set with black sails , and in it the youths and maidens who were appointed for the king of the beasts embarked and set out for his country .
4 When they arrived there they went at once to the Lake , and this time the lions did not stir , nor did the springs flow , and neither did the Lake speak .
5 So they waited then , and it was not long before the earth quaked even more terribly than the first time .
6 The Seven-headed Serpent came without his train of beasts , saw his prey waiting for him , and devoured it at one mouthful .
7 Then the ship 's crew returned home , and the same thing happened yearly until many years had passed .
8 Now the King of this unhappy country was growing old , and so was the Queen , and they had no children .
9 One day the Queen was sitting at the window weeping bitterly because she was childless , and knew that the crown would therefore pass to strangers after the King 's death .
10 Suddenly a little old woman appeared before her , holding an apple in her hand , and said , ` Why do you weep , my Queen , and what makes you so unhappy ? '
11 ` Alas , good mother , ' answered the Queen , ' I am unhappy because I have no children . '
12 ` Is that what vexes you ? '
13 said the old woman .
14 ` Listen to me .
15 I am a nun from the Spinning Convent , -LRB- 10 -RRB- and my mother when she died left me this apple .
16 Whoever eats this apple shall have a child . '

18 The Queen gave money to the old woman , and bought the apple from her .
19 Then she peeled it , ate it , and threw the rind out of the window , and it so happened that a mare that was running loose in the court below ate up the rind .
20 After a time the Queen had a little boy , and the mare also had a male foal .
21 The XXXXX and the foal grew up together and loved each other like brothers .	boy		Convent|Serpent|boy|child|country|flow|foal|lions|mare|people

1 whispered Thumbelina to the swallow .
2 The little Prince was very much frightened at the swallow , for in comparison with one so tiny as himself he seemed a giant .
3 But when he saw Thumbelina , he was delighted , for she was the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
4 So he took his golden crown from off his head and put it on hers , asking her her name , and if she would be his wife , and then she would be Queen of all the flowers .
5 Yes !
6 he was a different kind of husband to the son of the toad and the mole with the black-velvet coat .
7 So she said ` Yes ' to the noble Prince .
8 And out of each flower came a lady and gentleman , each so tiny and pretty that it was a pleasure to see them .
9 Each brought Thumbelina a present , but the best of all was a beautiful pair of wings which were fastened on to her back , and now she too could fly from flower to flower .
10 They all wished her joy , and the swallow sat above in his nest and sang the wedding march , and that he did as well as he could ; but he was sad , because he was very fond of Thumbelina and did not want to be separated from her .
11 ` You shall not be called Thumbelina ! '
12 said the spirit of the flower to her ; ` that is an ugly name , and you are much too pretty for that .
13 We will call you May Blossom . '
14 ` Farewell , farewell ! '
15 said the little swallow with a heavy heart , and flew away to farther lands , far , far away , right back to Denmark .
16 There he had a little nest above a window , where his wife lived , who can tell fairy-stories .
17 ` Tweet , tweet ! '
18 he sang to her .
19 And that is the way we learnt the whole story .

1 The King gave the promise , and thereafter the Queen died .
2 Time went past , and the King , growing tired of living alone , fitted out his ship and sailed out to sea .
3 As he sailed there came upon him so thick a mist that he altogether lost his bearings , but after long trouble he found land .
4 There he laid his ship to , and went on shore all alone .
5 After walking for some time he came to a forest , into which he went a little way and stopped .
6 Then he heard sweet music from a harp , and went in the direction of the sound until he came to a clearing , and there he saw three women , one of whom sat on a golden chair , and was beautifully and grandly dressed ; she held a harp in her hands , and was very sorrowful .
7 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
8 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
9 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
10 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
11 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
12 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
13 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
14 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
15 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
16 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
17 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
18 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
19 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a spell on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .
20 After this Hermod disappeared , and no one knew what had become of him ; the Queen caused search to be made for him , but he could nowhere be found .
21 One XXXXX , when Olof was in the castle beside Hadvor , she asked the Princess if she knew where Hermod had gone to .	time		case|castle|country|hall|maid|sea|sword|time|voyage|women

1 ` Here I am , ' replied the youth .
2 ` Then hold on to me , ' said the Giant , ` so that I may lead you up above again . '
3 So the Herd-boy held on to the Giant , and in a few moments he found himself on the earth once more , but the Giant had vanished .
4 The Herd-boy returned to his sheep , and took off the invisible belt which he hid carefully in his bag .
5 The next morning the lad felt hungry , and thought he would cut off a piece of the loaf he had carried away from the Giants ' wedding feast , and eat it .
6 But although he tried with all his might , he could n't cut off the smallest piece .
7 Then in despair he bit the loaf , and what was his astonishment when a piece of gold fell out of his mouth and rolled at his feet .
8 He bit the bread a second and third time , and each time a piece of gold fell out of his mouth ; but the bread remained untouched .
9 The Herd-boy was very much delighted over his stroke of good fortune , and , hiding the magic loaf in his bag , he hurried off to the nearest village to buy himself something to eat , and then returned to his sheep .
10 Now the Lord whose sheep the Herd-boy looked after had a very lovely daughter , who always smiled and nodded to the youth when she walked with her father in his fields .
11 For a long time the Herd-boy had made up his mind to prepare a surprise for this beautiful creature on her birthday .
12 So when the day approached he put on his invisible belt , took a sack of gold pieces with him , and slipping into her room in the middle of the night , he placed the bag of gold beside her bed and returned to his sheep .
13 The girl 's joy was great , and so was her parents ' next day when they found the sack full of gold pieces .
14 The Herd-boy was so pleased to think what pleasure he had given that the next night he placed another bag of gold beside the girl 's bed .
15 And this he continued to do for seven nights , and the girl and her parents made up their minds that it must be a good Fairy who brought the gold every night .
16 But one night they determined to watch , and see from their hiding place who the bringer of the sack of gold really was .
17 On the eighth night a fearful storm of wind and rain came on while the Herd-boy was on his way to bring the beautiful girl another bag of gold .
18 Then for the first time he noticed , just as he reached his master 's house , that he had forgotten the belt which made him invisible .
19 He did n't like the idea of going back to his hut in the wind and wet , so he just stepped as he was into the girl 's room , laid the sack of gold beside her , and was turning to leave the room , when his master confronted him and said , ` You young rogue , so you were going to steal the gold that a good Fairy brings every night , were you ? '
20 The Herd-boy was so taken aback by his words , that he stood trembling before him , and did not dare to explain his presence .
21 Then his XXXXX spoke .	master		Fairy|Giant|Lord|birthday|lad|master|morning|piece|wind|youth

9 Once upon a time when wishes came true there was a king 's son who was enchanted by an old witch , so that he was obliged to sit in a large iron stove in a wood .
10 There he lived for many years , and no one could free him .
11 At last a king 's daughter came into the wood ; she had lost her way , and could not find her father 's kingdom again .
12 She had been wandering round and round for nine days , and she came at last to the iron case .
13 A voice came from within and asked her , ` Where do you come from , and where do you want to go ? '
14 She answered , ' I have lost my way to my father 's kingdom , and I shall never get home again . '

3 The evening light had quite faded , and the full moon was already shining down upon the forest , when the young man heard a slight rustling sound .
4 After a few moments there came out of the forest a maiden , gliding over the grass so lightly that her feet seemed scarcely to touch the ground , and stood beside the spring .
5 The youth could not turn away his eyes from the maiden , for he had never in his life seen a woman so beautiful .
6 Without seeming to notice anything , she went to the spring , looked up to the full moon , then knelt down and bathed her face nine times , then looked up to the moon again and walked nine times round the well , and as she walked she sang this song : ` Full-faced moon with light unshaded , Let my beauty ne'er be faded .
7 Never let my cheek grow pale !
8 While the moon is waning nightly , May the maiden bloom more brightly , May her freshness never fail ! '
9 Then she dried her face with her long hair , and was about to go away , when her eye suddenly fell upon the spot where the young man was sitting , and she turned towards the tree .
10 The youth rose and stood waiting .
11 Then the maiden said , ` You ought to have a heavy punishment because you have presumed to watch my secret doings in the moonlight .
12 But I will forgive you this time , because you are a stranger and knew no better .
13 But you must tell me truly who you are and how you came to this place , where no mortal has ever set foot before . '
14 The youth answered humbly : ` Forgive me , beautiful maiden , if I have unintentionally offended you .
15 I chanced to come here after long wandering , and found a good place to sleep under this tree .
16 At your coming I did not know what to do , but stayed where I was , because I thought my silent watching could not offend you . '
17 The maiden answered kindly , ` Come and spend this night with us .
18 You will sleep better on a pillow than on damp moss . '
19 The youth hesitated for a little , but presently he heard the birds saying from the top of the tree , ` Go where she calls you , but take care to give no blood , or you will sell your soul . '

6 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .

8 The next morning , after Iwanich had led his horses to the fields , he fell once more into a magic sleep .
9 The horses at once ran away and hid themselves in the clouds , which hung down from the mountains in soft billowy masses .
10 When the Prince awoke and found that both the mare and the foal had disappeared , he bethought him at once of the eagle , and taking the feather out of his pocket he blew it into the air .

13 ` Wait a minute , ' answered the eagle ; ` with the help of my friends I will soon drive them back to you . '

1 One night , not long after , a loud noise and rumbling was heard under the castle .
2 Hadvor at once guessed what it was , and told her maids to be ready to help her .
3 The noise and thundering grew louder and louder , until the floor began to open , whereupon Hadvor made them take the caldron of pitch and pour plenty of it into the opening .
4 With that the noises grew fainter and fainter , till at last they ceased altogether .
5 Next morning the Queen rose early , and went out to the Palace gate , and there she found her brother the Giant lying dead .
6 She went up to him and said , ' I pronounce this spell , that you become a beautiful prince , and that Hadvor shall be unable to say anything against the charges that I shall bring against her . '
7 The body of the dead Giant now became that of a beautiful prince , and the Queen went in again . '
8 I do n't think , ' said she to the King , ` that your daughter is as good as she is said to be .
9 My brother came and asked her hand , and she has had him put to death .
10 I have just found his dead body lying at the Palace gate . '
11 The King went along with the Queen to see the body , and thought it all very strange ; so beautiful a youth , he said , would have been a worthy match for Hadvor , and he would readily have agreed to their marriage .
12 The Queen asked leave to decide what Hadvor 's punishment should be , which the King was very willing to allow , so as to escape from punishing his own daughter .
13 The Queen 's decision was that the King should make a big grave-mound for her brother , and put Hadvor into it beside him .
14 Olof knew all the plans of the Queen , and went to tell the Princess what had been done , whereupon Hadvor earnestly entreated her to tell her what to do .
15 ` First and foremost , ' said Olof , ` you must get a wide cloak to wear over your other clothes , when you are put into the mound .
16 The Giant 's ghost will walk after you are both left together in there , and he will have two dogs along with him .
17 He will ask you to cut pieces out of his legs to give to the dogs , but that you must not promise to do unless he tells you where Hermod has gone to , and tells you how to find him .
18 He will then let you stand on his shoulders , so as to get out of the mound ; but he means to cheat you all the same , and will catch you by the cloak to pull you back again ; but you must take care to have the cloak loose on your shoulders , so that he will only get hold of that . '
19 The mound was all ready now , and the Giant laid in it , and into it Hadvor also had to go without being allowed to make any defence .
20 After they were both left there everything happened just as Olof had said .
21 The XXXXX became a Giant again , and asked Hadvor to cut the pieces out of his legs for the dogs ; but she refused until he told her that Hermod was in a desert island , which she could not reach unless she took the skin off the soles of his feet and made shoes out of that ; with these shoes she could travel both on land and sea .	prince		body|castle|charges|clothes|defence|marriage|noise|pitch|prince|whereupon

1 As Kala Nag sat down , he slid off his neck in a dead faint .
2 But , since native children have no nerves worth speaking of , in two hours he was lying very contentedly in Petersen Sahib 's hammock with Petersen Sahib 's shooting-coat under his head , and a glass of warm milk , a little brandy , with a dash of quinine , inside of him , and while the old hairy , scarred hunters of the jungles sat three deep before him , looking at him as though he were a spirit , he told his tale in short words , as a child will , and wound up with : `` Now , if I lie in one word , send men to see , and they will find that the elephant folk have trampled down more room in their dance-room , and they will find ten and ten , and many times ten , tracks leading to that dance-room .
3 They made more room with their feet .
4 I have seen it .
5 Kala Nag took me , and I saw .
6 Also Kala Nag is very leg-weary ! ''
7 Little Toomai lay back and slept all through the long afternoon and into the twilight , and while he slept Petersen Sahib and Machua Appa followed the track of the two elephants for fifteen miles across the hills .
8 Petersen Sahib had spent eighteen years in catching elephants , and he had only once before found such a dance-place .
9 Machua Appa had no need to look twice at the clearing to see what had been done there , or to scratch with his toe in the packed , rammed earth .
10 `` The child speaks truth , '' said he .
11 `` All this was done last night , and I have counted seventy tracks crossing the river .
12 See , Sahib , where Pudmini 's leg-iron cut the bark of that tree !
13 Yes ; she was there too . ''
14 They looked at one another and up and down , and they wondered .
15 For the ways of elephants are beyond the wit of any man , black or white , to fathom .
16 `` Forty years and five , '' said Machua Appa , `` have I followed my lord , the elephant , but never have I heard that any child of man had seen what this child has seen .
17 By all the Gods of the Hills , it is -- what can we say ? ''
18 and he shook his head .
19 When they got back to camp it was time for the evening meal .
20 Petersen Sahib ate alone in his tent , but he gave orders that the camp should have two sheep and some fowls , as well as a double ration of flour and rice and salt , for he knew that there would be a feast .
21 Big Toomai had come up hotfoot from the XXXXX in the plains to search for his son and his elephant , and now that he had found them he looked at them as though he were afraid of them both .	camp		camp|elephant|hammock|lord|meal|men|orders|speaking|tent|time

1 No , Sir , it was n't for the fat beetles at all .
2 It was to get Buster Bear 's help in a plan to teach Old Mr. Toad a lesson .
3 First Jimmy told Buster all about how puffed up Old Mr. Toad was because he had dined with Buster , and how ever since then he had refused even to speak to his old friends and neighbors .
4 It tickled Buster Bear so to think that little homely Old Mr. Toad could be proud of anything that he laughed and laughed , and his laugh was deep and grumbly-rumbly .
5 Then Jimmy told him the plan to teach Old Mr. Toad a lesson and asked Buster if he would help .
6 Buster 's eyes twinkled as he promised to do what Jimmy asked .
7 Then Jimmy went straight to where Old Mr. Toad was sitting all puffed up , taking a sun-bath .
8 `` Buster Bear has just sent word by me to ask if you will honor him by dining with him to-morrow at the rotted chestnut stump near the edge of the Green Forest , '' said Jimmy in his politest manner .
9 Now if Old Mr. Toad was puffed up before , just think how he swelled out when he heard that .
10 Jimmy Skunk was actually afraid that he would burst .
11 `` You may tell my friend , Buster Bear , that I shall be very happy to honor him by dining with him , '' replied Old Mr. Toad with a very grand air .
12 Jimmy went off to deliver his reply , and Old Mr. Toad sat and puffed himself out until he could hardly breathe .
13 `` Honor him by dining with him , '' said he over and over to himself .
14 `` I never was so flattered in my life . ''
15 XXII OLD MR. TOAD LEARNS A LESSON Pride is like a great big bubble ; You 'll find there 's nothing in it .
16 Prick it and for all your trouble It has vanished in a minute .
17 Old Mr. Toad was so puffed out with pride as he started for the Green Forest to dine with Buster Bear that those who saw him wondered if he would n't burst before he got there .
18 Everybody knew where he was going , and this made Old Mr. Toad feel more important and proud than ever .
19 He might not have felt quite so puffed up if he had known just how it had come about that he received this second invitation to dine with Buster Bear .
20 When Jimmy Skunk brought it to him , Jimmy did n't tell him that Buster had been asked to send the invitation , and that it was all part of a plan on the part of some of Old Mr. Toad 's old friends and neighbors to teach him a lesson .

1 Their occupation consisted in helping those in misfortune , and they were as gentle and benevolent as Lagree had been cruel and spiteful .
2 The third Fairy comforted the poor traveller , begged her not to lose heart , and assured her that her troubles should be rewarded .
3 She accompanied her advice by the gift of a crystal smelling-bottle , with strict orders only to open it in case of urgent need .
4 Fairer-than-a-Fairy thanked her warmly , and resumed her way cheered by pleasant thoughts .
5 After a time her road led through a wood , full of soft airs and sweet odours , and before she had gone a hundred yards she saw a wonderful silver Castle suspended by strong silver chains to four of the largest trees .
6 It was so perfectly hung that a gentle breeze rocked it sufficiently to send you pleasantly to sleep .
7 Fairer-than-a-Fairy felt a strong desire to enter this Castle , but besides being hung a little above the ground there seemed to be neither doors nor windows .
8 She had no doubt -LRB- though really I can not think why -RRB- that the moment had come in which to use the nut which had been given her .
9 She opened it , and out came a diminutive hall porter at whose belt hung a tiny chain , at the end of which was a golden key half as long as the smallest pin you ever saw .
10 The Princess climbed up one of the silver chains , holding in her hand the little porter who , in spite of his minute size , opened a secret door with his golden key and let her in .
11 She entered a magnificent room which appeared to occupy the entire Castle , and which was lighted by gold and jewelled stars in the ceiling .
12 In the midst of this room stood a couch , draped with curtains of all the colours of the rainbow , and suspended by golden cords so that it swayed with the Castle in a manner which rocked its occupant delightfully to sleep .
13 On this elegant couch lay Prince Rainbow , looking more beautiful than ever , and sunk in profound slumber , in which he had been held ever since his disappearance .
14 Fairy-than-a-Fairy , who now saw him for the first time in his real shape , hardly dared to gaze at him , fearing lest his appearance might not be in keeping with the voice and language which had won her heart .
15 At the same time she could not help feeling rather hurt at the apparent indifference with which she was received .
16 She related all the dangers and difficulties she had gone through , and though she repeated the story twenty times in a loud clear voice , the Prince slept on and took no heed .
17 She then had recourse to the golden pomegranate , and on opening it found that all the seeds were as many little violins which flew up in the vaulted roof and at once began playing melodiously .
18 The Prince was not completely roused , but he opened his eyes a little and looked all the handsomer .
19 Impatient at not being recognised , Fairer-than-a-Fairy now drew out her third present , and on opening the crystal scent-bottle a little syren flew out , who silenced the violins and then sang close to the Prince 's ear the story of all his lady love had suffered in her search for him .
20 She added some gentle reproaches to her tale , but before she had got far he was wide awake , and transported with joy threw himself at the Princess 's feet .
21 At the same moment the walls of the XXXXX expanded and opened out , revealing a golden throne covered with jewels .	room		advice|desire|difficulties|gift|heart|orders|rainbow|room|seeds|voice

8 `` A bull paid ten years ago ! ''

1 When the summer came Frances asserted herself .
2 The Farquhars went to Green Harbour every summer .
3 But this time Frances said she would not go , and stuck to it .
4 The whole family took turns coaxing her and had nothing to show for their pains .
5 `` I 'm going up to Windy Meadows to stay with Aunt Eleanor while you are at the Harbour , '' she declared .
6 `` She has invited me often enough . ''
7 Ned whistled .
8 `` Jolly time you 'll have of it , Sis .
9 Windy Meadows is about as festive as a funeral .
10 And Aunt Eleanor is n't lively , to put it in the mildest possible way . ''
11 `` I do n't care if she is n't .
12 I want to get somewhere where people wo n't look at me and talk about -- that , '' said Frances , looking ready to cry .
13 Ned went out and swore at Holcomb again , and then advised his mother to humour Frances .
14 Accordingly , Frances went to Windy Meadows .
15 Windy Meadows was , as Ned had said , the reverse of lively .
16 It was a pretty country place , with a sort of fag-end by way of a little fishing village , huddled on a wind-swept bit of beach , locally known as the `` Cove . ''
17 Aunt Eleanor was one of those delightful people , so few and far between in this world , who have perfectly mastered the art of minding their own business exclusively .
18 She left Frances in peace .
19 She knew that her niece had had `` some love trouble or other , '' and had n't gotten over it rightly .

1 But like all the rest , I was blinded by his charm .

3 `` From the first he had paid Eliza marked attention and seemed utterly bewitched by her .
4 Well , his was an easy winning .

6 `` I shall never forget the night they were first engaged .
7 It was Eliza 's birthday , and we were invited to a ball that evening .
8 This yellow gown is the very one she wore .
9 I suppose that is why she put it away here -- the gown she wore on the happiest night of her life .
10 I had never seen her look more beautiful -- her neck and arms were bare , and she wore this string of pearls and carried a bouquet of her favourite white roses .
11 `` When we reached home after the dance , Eliza had her happy secret to tell us .
12 She was engaged to Willis Starr , and they were to be married in early spring .
13 `` Willis Starr certainly seemed to be an ideal lover , and Eliza was so perfectly happy that she seemed to grow more beautiful and radiant every day .
14 `` Well , Amy , the wedding day was set .

16 We made her wedding dress together , she and I. Girls were not above making their own gowns then , and not a stitch was set in Eliza 's save those put there by loving fingers and blessed by loving wishes .
17 It was I who draped the veil over her sunny curls -- see how yellow and creased it is now , but it was as white as snow that day .

1 Then the elephants were chained by their hind legs to their big stumps of pickets , and extra ropes were fitted to the new elephants , and the fodder was piled before them , and the hill drivers went back to Petersen Sahib through the afternoon light , telling the plains drivers to be extra careful that night , and laughing when the plains drivers asked the reason .
2 Little Toomai attended to Kala Nag 's supper , and as evening fell , wandered through the camp , unspeakably happy , in search of a tom-tom .
3 When an Indian child 's heart is full , he does not run about and make a noise in an irregular fashion .
4 He sits down to a sort of revel all by himself .
5 And Little Toomai had been spoken to by Petersen Sahib !
6 If he had not found what he wanted , I believe he would have been ill .
7 But the sweetmeat seller in the camp lent him a little tom-tom -- a drum beaten with the flat of the hand -- and he sat down , cross-legged , before Kala Nag as the stars began to come out , the tom-tom in his lap , and he thumped and he thumped and he thumped , and the more he thought of the great honor that had been done to him , the more he thumped , all alone among the elephant fodder .
8 There was no tune and no words , but the thumping made him happy .
9 The new elephants strained at their ropes , and squealed and trumpeted from time to time , and he could hear his mother in the camp hut putting his small brother to sleep with an old , old song about the great God Shiv , who once told all the animals what they should eat .
10 It is a very soothing lullaby , and the first verse says : Shiv , who poured the harvest and made the winds to blow , Sitting at the doorways of a day of long ago , Gave to each his portion , food and toil and fate , From the King upon the guddee to the Beggar at the gate .
11 All things made he -- Shiva the Preserver .
12 Mahadeo !
13 Mahadeo !
14 He made all -- Thorn for the camel , fodder for the kine , And mother 's heart for sleepy head , O little son of mine !
15 Little Toomai came in with a joyous tunk-a-tunk at the end of each verse , till he felt sleepy and stretched himself on the fodder at Kala Nag 's side .
16 At last the elephants began to lie down one after another as is their custom , till only Kala Nag at the right of the line was left standing up ; and he rocked slowly from side to side , his ears put forward to listen to the night wind as it blew very slowly across the hills .
17 The air was full of all the night noises that , taken together , make one big silence -- the click of one bamboo stem against the other , the rustle of something alive in the undergrowth , the scratch and squawk of a half-waked bird -LRB- birds are awake in the night much more often than we imagine -RRB- , and the fall of water ever so far away .
18 Little Toomai slept for some time , and when he waked it was brilliant moonlight , and Kala Nag was still standing up with his ears cocked .
19 Little Toomai turned , rustling in the fodder , and watched the curve of his big back against half the stars in heaven , and while he watched he heard , so far away that it sounded no more than a pinhole of noise pricked through the stillness , the `` hoot-toot '' of a wild elephant .
20 All the elephants in the lines jumped up as if they had been shot , and their grunts at last waked the sleeping mahouts , and they came out and drove in the picket pegs with big mallets , and tightened this rope and knotted that till all was quiet .
21 One new elephant had nearly grubbed up his XXXXX , and Big Toomai took off Kala Nag 's leg chain and shackled that elephant fore-foot to hind-foot , but slipped a loop of grass string round Kala Nag 's leg , and told him to remember that he was tied fast .	picket		Beggar|camel|camp|custom|elephants|lullaby|picket|ropes|silence|time

1 The blind was up and she could see Miss LeMar writing at her table .
2 Her profile was clear and distinct against the lamplight .
3 Estella reflected without the least envy that Miss LeMar was very beautiful .
4 She had never seen anyone who was really beautiful before -- beautiful with the loveliness of the heroines in the novels she sometimes read or the pictures she had seen .
5 Estella Bowes was not pretty .
6 She was a nice-looking girl , with clear eyes , rosy cheeks , and a pervading air of the content and happiness her life had always known .
