1 I will not sell my back to man for a bundle of sugar-cane : I will go out to my own kind , and the wood-folk in their lairs .
2 I will go out until the day , until the morning break -- Out to the wind 's untainted kiss , the water 's clean caress ; I will forget my ankle-ring and snap my picket stake .
3 I will revisit my lost loves , and playmates masterless !
4 Kala Nag , which means Black Snake , had served the Indian Government in every way that an elephant could serve it for forty-seven years , and as he was fully twenty years old when he was caught , that makes him nearly seventy -- a ripe age for an elephant .
5 He remembered pushing , with a big leather pad on his forehead , at a gun stuck in deep mud , and that was before the Afghan War of 1842 , and he had not then come to his full strength .
6 His mother Radha Pyari , -- Radha the darling , -- who had been caught in the same drive with Kala Nag , told him , before his little milk tusks had dropped out , that elephants who were afraid always got hurt .
7 Kala Nag knew that that advice was good , for the first time that he saw a shell burst he backed , screaming , into a stand of piled rifles , and the bayonets pricked him in all his softest places .
8 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
9 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
10 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
11 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
12 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
13 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other elephants who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .
14 Elephants are very strictly preserved by the Indian Government .
15 There is one whole department which does nothing else but hunt them , and catch them , and break them in , and send them up and down the country as they are needed for work .
16 Kala Nag stood ten fair feet at the shoulders , and his tusks had been cut off short at five feet , and bound round the ends , to prevent them splitting , with bands of copper ; but he could do more with those stumps than any untrained elephant could do with the real sharpened ones .
17 When , after weeks and weeks of cautious driving of scattered elephants across the hills , the forty or fifty wild monsters were driven into the last stockade , and the big drop gate , made of tree trunks lashed together , jarred down behind them , Kala Nag , at the word of command , would go into that flaring , trumpeting pandemonium -LRB- generally at night , when the flicker of the torches made it difficult to judge distances -RRB- , and , picking out the biggest and wildest tusker of the mob , would hammer him and hustle him into quiet while the men on the backs of the other elephants roped and tied the smaller ones .
18 There was nothing in the way of fighting that Kala Nag , the old wise Black Snake , did not know , for he had stood up more than once in his time to the charge of the wounded tiger , and , curling up his soft trunk to be out of harm 's way , had knocked the springing brute sideways in mid-air with a quick sickle cut of his head , that he had invented all by himself ; had knocked him over , and kneeled upon him with his huge knees till the life went out with a gasp and a howl , and there was only a fluffy striped thing on the ground for Kala Nag to pull by the tail .
19 `` Yes , '' said Big Toomai , his driver , the son of Black Toomai who had taken him to Abyssinia , and grandson of Toomai of the Elephants who had seen him caught , `` there is nothing that the Black Snake fears except me .
20 He has seen three generations of us feed him and groom him , and he will live to see four . ''
21 `` He is afraid of me also , '' said Little Toomai , standing up to his full height of four XXXXX , with only one rag upon him .	feet		Elephants|feet|generations|grandson|ground|head|kiss|mother|shoulders|tusks

1 He wished the maiden would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .
2 A few days after they were again speaking of the magic ring , and the youth said , ' I do not think it possible that the ring can have all the power you say it has . '
3 Then the maiden opened the box and took the ring out , and it glittered as she held it like the clearest sunbeam .
4 She put it on the middle finger of her left hand , and told the youth to take a knife and try as hard as he could to cut her with it , for he would not be able to hurt her .
5 He was unwilling at first , but the maiden insisted .
6 Then he tried , at first only in play , and then seriously , to strike her with the knife , but an invisible wall of iron seemed to be between them , and the maiden stood before him laughing and unhurt .
7 Then she put the ring on her third finger , and in an instant she had vanished from his eyes .
8 Presently she was beside him again laughing , and holding the ring between her fingers .
9 ` Do let me try , ' said the youth , ` whether I can do these wonderful things . '
10 The maiden , suspecting no treachery , gave him the magic ring .
11 The youth pretended to have forgotten what to do , and asked what finger he must put the ring on so that no sharp weapon could hurt him ? '
12 ` Oh , the middle finger of your left hand , ' the maiden answered , laughing .
13 She took the knife and tried to strike the youth , and he even tried to cut himself with it , but found it impossible .
14 Then he asked the maiden to show him how to split stones and rocks with the help of the ring .
15 So she led him into a courtyard where stood a great boulder-stone .
16 ` Now , ' she said , ` put the ring upon the thumb of your left hand , and you will see how strong that hand has become .
17 The youth did so , and found to his astonishment that with a single blow of his fist the stone flew into a thousand pieces .
18 Then the youth bethought him that he who does not use his luck when he has it is a fool , and that this was a chance which once lost might never return .
19 So while they stood laughing at the shattered stone he placed the ring , as if in play , upon the third finger of his left hand .
20 ` Now , ' said the maiden , ` you are invisible to me until you take the ring off again . '
21 But the XXXXX had no mind to do that ; on the contrary , he went farther off , then put the ring on the little finger of his left hand , and soared into the air like a bird .	youth		eyes|fingers|maiden|pieces|play|power|speaking|stones|weapon|youth

1 After this the Giant accompanied him down to the sea , where he saw a stone boat which was just big enough to hold the two of them and the Dog .
2 On reaching the mainland the Giant took a friendly farewell of Ring , and told him he might take possession of all that was in the island after he and his wife died , which would happen within two weeks from that time .
3 The Prince thanked him for this and for all his other kindnesses , and the Giant returned home , while Ring went up some distance from the sea ; but he did not know what land he had come to , and was afraid to speak to the Dog .
4 After he had walked on in silence for a time the Dog spoke to him and said : ` You do n't seem to have much curiosity , seeing you never ask my name . '
5 The Prince then forced himself to ask , ` What is your name ? '
6 ` You had best call me Snati-Snati , ' said the Dog .
7 ` Now we are coming to a King 's seat , and you must ask the King to keep us all winter , and to give you a little room for both of us . '
8 The Prince now began to be less afraid of the Dog .
9 They came to the King and asked him to keep them all the winter , to which he agreed .
10 When the King 's men saw the Dog they began to laugh at it , and make as if they would tease it ; but when the Prince saw this he advised them not to do it , or they might have the worst of it .
11 They replied that they did n't care a bit what he thought .
12 After Ring had been with the King for some days the latter began to think there was a great deal in him , and esteemed him more than the others .
13 The King , however , had a counsellor called Red , who became very jealous when he saw how much the King esteemed Ring ; and one day he talked to him , and said he could not understand why he had so good an opinion of this stranger , who had not yet shown himself superior to other men in anything .
14 The King replied that it was only a short time since he had come there .
15 Red then asked him to send them both to cut down wood next morning , and see which of them could do most work .
16 Snati-Snati heard this and told it to Ring , advising him to ask the King for two axes , so that he might have one in reserve if the first one got broken .
17 Next morning the King asked Ring and Red to go and cut down trees for him , and both agreed .
18 Ring got the two axes , and each went his own way ; but when the Prince had got out into the wood Snati took one of the axes and began to hew along with him .
19 In the evening the King came to look over their day 's work , as Red had proposed , and found that Ring 's wood-heap was more than twice as big . '
20 I suspected , ' said the King , ` that Ring was not quite useless ; never have I seen such a day 's work . '
21 XXXXX was now in far greater esteem with the King than before , and Red was all the more discontented .	Ring		Dog|Ring|bit|deal|mainland|reserve|room|silence|stranger|time

1 The courtier peeped into the ship , and , seeing what it was , instantly went back to the King and told him that it was a flying ship , and that it was manned by a few peasants .
2 Then the King remembered his royal oath ; but he made up his mind that he would never consent to let the Princess marry a poor peasant .
3 So he thought and thought , and then said to himself : ' I will give him some impossible tasks to perform ; that will be the best way of getting rid of him . '
4 And he there and then decided to despatch one of his courtiers to the Simpleton , with the command that he was to fetch the King the healing water from the world 's end before he had finished his dinner .
5 But while the King was still instructing the courtier exactly what he was to say , the first man of the ship 's company , the one with the miraculous power of hearing , had overheard the King 's words , and hastily reported them to the poor Simpleton .
6 ` Alas , alas ! '
7 he cried ; ` what am I to do now ?
8 It would take me quite a year , possibly my whole life , to find the water . '
9 ` Never fear , ' said his fleet-footed comrade , ' I will fetch what the King wants . '
10 Just then the courtier arrived , bearing the King 's command .
11 ` Tell his Majesty , ' said the Simpleton , ` that his orders shall be obeyed ; ` and forthwith the swift runner unbound the foot that was strung up behind his ear and started off , and in less than no time had reached the world 's end and drawn the healing water from the well .
12 ` Dear me , ' he thought to himself , ` that 's rather tiring !
13 I 'll just rest for a few minutes ; it will be some little time yet before the King has got to dessert . '
14 So he threw himself down on the grass , and , as the sun was very dazzling , he closed his eyes , and in a few seconds had fallen sound asleep .
15 In the meantime all the ship 's crew were anxiously awaiting him ; the King 's dinner would soon be finished , and their comrade had not yet returned .
16 So the man with the marvellous quick hearing lay down and , putting his ear to the ground , listened .
17 ` That 's a nice sort of fellow ! '
18 he suddenly exclaimed .
19 ` He 's lying on the ground , snoring hard ! '
20 At this the marksman seized his gun , took aim , and fired in the direction of the world 's end , in order to awaken the sluggard .

4 Bagheera heard , and the cry that told him Mowgli was safe gave him new courage .
5 He worked his way desperately , inch by inch , straight for the reservoirs , halting in silence .
6 Then from the ruined wall nearest the jungle rose up the rumbling war-shout of Baloo .

11 Ahuwora !

13 Wait my coming , O most infamous Bandar-log ! ''
14 He panted up the terrace only to disappear to the head in a wave of monkeys , but he threw himself squarely on his haunches , and , spreading out his forepaws , hugged as many as he could hold , and then began to hit with a regular bat-bat-bat , like the flipping strokes of a paddle wheel .
15 A crash and a splash told Mowgli that Bagheera had fought his way to the tank where the monkeys could not follow .
16 The Panther lay gasping for breath , his head just out of the water , while the monkeys stood three deep on the red steps , dancing up and down with rage , ready to spring upon him from all sides if he came out to help Baloo .
17 It was then that Bagheera lifted up his dripping chin , and in despair gave the Snake 's Call for protection -- `` We be of one blood , ye and I '' -- for he believed that Kaa had turned tail at the last minute .
18 Even Baloo , half smothered under the monkeys on the edge of the terrace , could not help chuckling as he heard the Black Panther asking for help .
19 Kaa had only just worked his way over the west wall , landing with a wrench that dislodged a coping stone into the ditch .
20 He had no intention of losing any advantage of the ground , and coiled and uncoiled himself once or twice , to be sure that every foot of his long body was in working order .
21 All that while the fight with Baloo went on , and the XXXXX yelled in the tank round Bagheera , and Mang the Bat , flying to and fro , carried the news of the great battle over the jungle , till even Hathi the Wild Elephant trumpeted , and , far away , scattered bands of the Monkey-Folk woke and came leaping along the tree-roads to help their comrades in the Cold Lairs , and the noise of the fight roused all the day birds for miles round .	monkeys		courage|feet|ground|half|haste|monkeys|plunge|stones|wall|water

1 ` You , my wife , the companion of my days , will follow me ere many moons have waned to the island of the blest .
2 But for you , O my children , whose lives are but newly begun , the wickedness , unkindness , and ingratitude from which I fled are before you .
3 Yet I shall go hence in peace , my children , if you will promise always to love each other , and never to forsake your youngest brother .
4 ` Never ! '
5 they replied , holding out their hands .
6 And the hunter died content .
7 Scarcely eight moons had passed when , just as he had said , the wife went forth , and followed her husband ; but before leaving her children she bade the two elder ones think of their promise never to forsake the younger , for he was a child , and weak .
8 And while the snow lay thick upon the ground , they tended him and cherished him ; but when the earth showed green again , the heart of the young man stirred within him , and he longed to see the wigwams of the village where his father 's youth was spent .
9 Therefore he opened all his heart to his sister , who answered : ` My brother , I understand your longing for our fellow-men , whom here we can not see .
10 But remember our father 's words .
11 Shall we not seek our own pleasures , and forget the little one ? '
12 But he would not listen , and , making no reply , he took his bow and arrows and left the hut .
13 The snows fell and melted , yet he never returned ; and at last the heart of the girl grew cold and hard , and her little boy became a burden in her eyes , till one day she spoke thus to him : ` See , there is food for many days to come .
14 Stay here within the shelter of the hut .
15 I go to seek our brother , and when I have found him I shall return hither . '
16 But when , after hard journeying , she reached the village where her brother dwelt , and saw that he had a wife and was happy , and when she , too , was sought by a young brave , then she also forgot the boy alone in the forest , and thought only of her husband .
17 Now as soon as the little boy had eaten all the food which his sister had left him , he went out into the woods , and gathered berries and dug up roots , and while the sun shone he was contented and had his fill .
18 But when the snows began and the wind howled , then his stomach felt empty and his limbs cold , and he hid in trees all the night , and only crept out to eat what the wolves had left behind .
19 And by-and-by , having no other friends , he sought their company , and sat by while they devoured their prey , and they grew to know him , and gave him food .
20 And without them he would have died in the snow .

1 Next night she crept out again to him .

4 said the swallow to her . '
5 I am so beautifully warm !
6 Soon I shall regain my strength , and then I shall be able to fly out again into the warm sunshine . '
7 ` Oh ! '
8 she said , ` it is very cold outside ; it is snowing and freezing !
9 stay in your warm bed ; I will take care of you ! '
10 Then she brought him water in a petal , which he drank , after which he related to her how he had torn one of his wings on a bramble , so that he could not fly as fast as the other swallows , who had flown far away to warmer lands .
11 So at last he had dropped down exhausted , and then he could remember no more .
12 The whole winter he remained down there , and Thumbelina looked after him and nursed him tenderly .
13 Neither the mole nor the field-mouse learnt anything of this , for they could not bear the poor swallow .
14 When the spring came , and the sun warmed the earth again , the swallow said farewell to Thumbelina , who opened the hole in the roof for him which the mole had made .

1 But a raven unexpectedly gave him this advice : ` Ride upon the horse , and push the spear against the ground , as if you were pushing off a boat from the land . '
2 The youth did so , and found that in this way he could easily move forwards .
3 The Dragon had his monstrous jaws wide open , all ready for his expected prey .
4 A few paces nearer , and man and horse would have been swallowed up by them !
5 The youth trembled with horror , and his blood ran cold , yet he did not lose his courage ; but , holding the iron spear upright in his hand , he brought it down with all his might right through the monster 's lower jaw .
6 Then quick as lightning he sprang from his horse before the Dragon had time to shut his mouth .
7 A fearful clap like thunder , which could be heard for miles around , now warned him that the Dragon 's jaws had closed upon the spear .
8 When the youth turned round he saw the point of the spear sticking up high above the Dragon 's upper jaw , and knew that the other end must be fastened firmly to the ground ; but the Dragon had got his teeth fixed in the iron horse , which was now useless .
9 The youth now hastened to fasten down the chains to the ground by means of the enormous iron pegs which he had provided .
10 The death struggle of the monster lasted three days and three nights ; in his writhing he beat his tail so violently against the ground , that at ten miles ' distance the earth trembled as if with an earthquake .
11 When he at length lost power to move his tail , the youth with the help of the ring took up a stone which twenty ordinary men could not have moved , and beat the Dragon so hard about the head with it that very soon the monster lay lifeless before him .
12 You can fancy how great was the rejoicing when the news was spread abroad that the terrible monster was dead .
13 His conqueror was received into the city with as much pomp as if he had been the mightiest of kings .
14 The old King did not need to urge his daughter to marry the slayer of the Dragon ; he found her already willing to bestow her hand upon this hero , who had done all alone what whole armies had tried in vain to do .
15 In a few days a magnificent wedding was celebrated , at which the rejoicings lasted four whole weeks , for all the neighbouring kings had met together to thank the man who had freed the world from their common enemy .
16 But everyone forgot amid the general joy that they ought to have buried the Dragon 's monstrous body , for it began now to have such a bad smell that no one could live in the neighbourhood , and before long the whole air was poisoned , and a pestilence broke out which destroyed many hundreds of people .
17 In this distress , the King 's son-in-law resolved to seek help once more from the Eastern magician , to whom he at once travelled through the air like a bird by the help of the ring .
18 But there is a proverb which says that ill-gotten gains never prosper , and the Prince found that the stolen ring brought him ill-luck after all .
19 The Witch-maiden had never rested night nor day until she had found out where the ring was .
20 As soon as she had discovered by means of magical arts that the Prince in the form of a bird was on his way to the Eastern magician , she changed herself into an eagle and watched in the air until the bird she was waiting for came in sight , for she knew him at once by the ring which was hung round his neck by a ribbon .

3 But he was awake now , and perceiving the eagle , he determined by its help to save himself .
4 The eagle dug its sharp claws into the tender flesh of the youth , but he bore the pain without a sound , and seized the bird 's two feet with his hands .
5 The creature in terror lifted him high up into the air and began to circle round the tower of the castle .
6 The youth held on bravely .
7 He saw the glittering palace , which by the pale rays of the moon looked like a dim lamp ; and he saw the high windows , and round one of them a balcony in which the beautiful Princess sat lost in sad thoughts .
8 Then the boy saw that he was close to the apple-tree , and drawing a small knife from his belt , he cut off both the eagle 's feet .
9 The bird rose up in the air in its agony and vanished into the clouds , and the youth fell on to the broad branches of the apple-tree .
10 Then he drew out the claws of the eagle 's feet that had remained in his flesh , and put the peel of one of the golden apples on the wound , and in one moment it was healed and well again .
11 He pulled several of the beautiful apples and put them in his pocket ; then he entered the castle .
12 The door was guarded by a great dragon , but as soon as he threw an apple at it , the beast vanished .
13 At the same moment a gate opened , and the youth perceived a courtyard full of flowers and beautiful trees , and on a balcony sat the lovely enchanted Princess with her retinue .
14 As soon as she saw the youth , she ran towards him and greeted him as her husband and master .

1 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
2 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
3 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
4 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
5 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
6 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
7 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .
8 Mindful of the Fairy 's warning he did not dare to address her , but she on her part greeted him in the most friendly manner , and asked him at once if he were under the power of the wicked Fairy .
9 The Prince nodded his head silently in answer .
10 Then the black girl told him that she too was in the power of the Fairy , who had doomed her to wander about in her present guise until some youth should take pity on her and bear her in safety to the other side of the river which they saw in the distance , and on the other side of which the Fairy 's domain and power ended .
11 The girl 's words so inspired the Prince with confidence that he told her all his tale of woe , and ended up by asking her advice as to how he was to escape the punishment the Fairy would be sure to inflict on him when she discovered that he had not cut down the trees in the wood and that he had broken her axe .
12 ` You must know , ' answered the black girl , ` that the Fairy in whose power we both are is my own mother , but you must not betray this secret , for it would cost me my life .
13 If you will only promise to try and free me I will stand by you , and will accomplish for you all the tasks which my mother sets you . '
14 The Prince promised joyfully all she asked ; then having once more warned him not to betray her confidence , she handed him a draught to drink which very soon sunk his senses in a deep slumber .
15 His astonishment was great when he awoke to find the glass axe whole and unbroken at his side , and all the trees of the wood lying felled around him !
16 He made all haste across the bridge of clouds , and told the Fairy that her commands were obeyed .
17 She was much amazed when she heard that all the wood was cut down , and saw the axe unbroken in his hand , and since she could not believe that he had done all this by himself , she questioned him narrowly if he had seen or spoken to the black girl .
18 But the Prince lied manfully , and swore he had never looked up from his work for a moment .
19 Seeing she could get nothing more out of him , she gave him a little bread and water , and showing him to a small dark cupboard she told him he might sleep there .
20 Morning had hardly dawned when the Fairy awoke the Prince , and giving him the glass axe again she told him to cut up all the wood he had felled the day before , and to put it in bundles ready for firewood ; at the same time she warned him once more against approaching or speaking a word to the black girl if he met her in the wood .

1 Little Vixen , my fox terrier , went out through the other side ; and then there was a roaring and a grunting and bubbling , and I saw the tent cave in , as the pole snapped , and begin to dance about like a mad ghost .
2 A camel had blundered into it , and wet and angry as I was , I could not help laughing .
3 Then I ran on , because I did not know how many camels might have got loose , and before long I was out of sight of the camp , plowing my way through the mud .
4 At last I fell over the tail-end of a gun , and by that knew I was somewhere near the artillery lines where the cannon were stacked at night .
5 As I did not want to plowter about any more in the drizzle and the dark , I put my waterproof over the muzzle of one gun , and made a sort of wigwam with two or three rammers that I found , and lay along the tail of another gun , wondering where Vixen had got to , and where I might be .
6 Just as I was getting ready to go to sleep I heard a jingle of harness and a grunt , and a mule passed me shaking his wet ears .
7 He belonged to a screw-gun battery , for I could hear the rattle of the straps and rings and chains and things on his saddle pad .
8 The screw-guns are tiny little cannon made in two pieces , that are screwed together when the time comes to use them .
9 They are taken up mountains , anywhere that a mule can find a road , and they are very useful for fighting in rocky country .
10 Behind the mule there was a camel , with his big soft feet squelching and slipping in the mud , and his neck bobbing to and fro like a strayed hen 's .
11 Luckily , I knew enough of beast language -- not wild-beast language , but camp-beast language , of course -- from the natives to know what he was saying .
12 He must have been the one that flopped into my tent , for he called to the mule , `` What shall I do ?
13 Where shall I go ?
14 I have fought with a white thing that waved , and it took a stick and hit me on the neck . ''
15 -LRB- That was my broken tent pole , and I was very glad to know it . -RRB-
16 `` Shall we run on ? ''
17 `` Oh , it was you , '' said the mule , `` you and your friends , that have been disturbing the camp ?
18 All right .
19 You 'll be beaten for this in the morning .
20 But I may as well give you something on account now . ''

1 Just stay here till I come again and tell you that it is finished . '
2 Having said this she flew merrily away , and Ferko , reassured by her words , lay down on the grass and slept peacefully till the next morning .
3 Early on the following day the whole town was on its feet , and everyone wondered how and where the stranger would build the wonderful palace .
4 The Princess alone was silent and sorrowful , and had cried all night till her pillow was wet , so much did she take the fate of the beautiful youth to heart .
5 Ferko spent the whole day in the meadows waiting the return of the bee .
6 And when evening was come the queen bee flew by , and perching on his shoulder she said , ` The wonderful palace is ready .
7 Be of good cheer , and lead the King to the hill just outside the city walls . '
8 And humming gaily she flew away again .
9 Ferko went at once to the King and told him the palace was finished .
10 The whole court went out to see the wonder , and their astonishment was great at the sight which met their eyes .
11 A splendid palace reared itself on the hill just outside the walls of the city , made of the most exquisite flowers that ever grew in mortal garden .
12 The roof was all of crimson roses , the windows of lilies , the walls of white carnations , the floors of glowing auriculas and violets , the doors of gorgeous tulips and narcissi with sunflowers for knockers , and all round hyacinths and other sweet-smelling flowers bloomed in masses , so that the air was perfumed far and near and enchanted all who were present .
13 This splendid palace had been built by the grateful queen bee , who had summoned all the other bees in the kingdom to help her .
14 The King 's amazement knew no bounds , and the Princess 's eyes beamed with delight as she turned them from the wonderful building on the delighted Ferko .
15 But the two brothers had grown quite green with envy , and only declared the more that Ferko was nothing but a wicked magician .
16 The King , although he had been surprised and astonished at the way his commands had been carried out , was very vexed that the stranger should escape with his life , and turning to the two brothers he said , ` He has certainly accomplished the first task , with the aid no doubt of his diabolical magic ; but what shall we give him to do now ?
17 Let us make it as difficult as possible , and if he fails he shall die . '
18 Then the eldest brother replied , ` The corn has all been cut , but it has not yet been put into barns ; let the knave collect all the grain in the kingdom into one big heap before to-morrow night , and if as much as a stalk of corn is left let him be put to death .
19 The Princess grew white with terror when she heard these words ; but Ferko felt much more cheerful than he had done the first time , and wandered out into the meadows again , wondering how he was to get out of the difficulty .
20 But he could think of no way of escape .
21 The sun sank to rest and night came on , when a little mouse started out of the XXXXX at Ferko 's feet , and said to him , ` I 'm delighted to see you , my kind benefactor ; but why are you looking so sad ?	grass		barns|city|commands|corn|death|difficulty|everyone|grass|magic|pillow

1 ` Would you tell me , ' said Alice , a little timidly , ` why you are painting those roses ? '
2 Five and Seven said nothing , but looked at Two .
3 Two began in a low voice , ` Why the fact is , you see , Miss , this here ought to have been a RED rose-tree , and we put a white one in by mistake ; and if the Queen was to find it out , we should all have our heads cut off , you know .
4 So you see , Miss , we 're doing our best , afore she comes , to -- ' At this moment Five , who had been anxiously looking across the garden , called out ` The Queen !
5 The Queen ! '
6 and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces .
7 There was a sound of many footsteps , and Alice looked round , eager to see the Queen .
8 First came ten soldiers carrying clubs ; these were all shaped like the three gardeners , oblong and flat , with their hands and feet at the corners : next the ten courtiers ; these were ornamented all over with diamonds , and walked two and two , as the soldiers did .
9 After these came the royal children ; there were ten of them , and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand , in couples : they were all ornamented with hearts .
10 Next came the guests , mostly Kings and Queens , and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit : it was talking in a hurried nervous manner , smiling at everything that was said , and went by without noticing her .
11 Then followed the Knave of Hearts , carrying the King 's crown on a crimson velvet cushion ; and , last of all this grand procession , came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS .
12 Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners , but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions ; ` and besides , what would be the use of a procession , ' thought she , ` if people had all to lie down upon their faces , so that they could n't see it ? '
13 So she stood still where she was , and waited .
14 When the procession came opposite to Alice , they all stopped and looked at her , and the Queen said severely ` Who is this ? '
15 She said it to the Knave of Hearts , who only bowed and smiled in reply .
16 ` Idiot ! '
17 said the Queen , tossing her head impatiently ; and , turning to Alice , she went on , ` What 's your name , child ? '
18 ` My name is Alice , so please your Majesty , ' said Alice very politely ; but she added , to herself , ` Why , they 're only a pack of cards , after all .
19 I need n't be afraid of them ! '
20 ` And who are THESE ? '
21 said the Queen , pointing to the three XXXXX who were lying round the rosetree ; for , you see , as they were lying on their faces , and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack , she could not tell whether they were gardeners , or soldiers , or courtiers , or three of her own children .	gardeners		Majesty|children|garden|gardeners|guests|head|name|people|reply|roses

1 The train reached Belltown about noon .
2 He did not mean to stop long there -- it was too near Upton .
3 From the conductor on the train , he found that a boat left Belltown for Montrose at two in the afternoon .
4 Montrose was a hundred miles from Upton , and Chester thought he would be safe there .
5 To Montrose , accordingly , he decided to go , but the first thing was to get some dinner .
6 He went into a grocery store and bought some crackers and a bit of cheese .
7 He had somewhere picked up the idea that crackers and cheese were about as economical food as you could find for adventurous youths starting out on small capital .
8 He found his way to the only public square Belltown boasted , and munched his food hungrily on a bench under the trees .
9 He would go to Montrose and there find something to do .
10 Later on he would gradually work his way out West , where there was more room for an ambitious small boy to expand and grow .
11 Chester dreamed some dazzling dreams as he sat there on the bench under the Belltown chestnuts .
12 Passers-by , if they noticed him at all , saw merely a rather small , poorly clad boy , with a great many freckles , a square jaw and shrewd , level-gazing grey eyes .
13 But this same lad was mapping out a very brilliant future for himself as people passed him heedlessly by .
14 He would get out West , somehow or other , some time or other , and make a fortune .
15 Then , perhaps , he would go back to Upton for a visit and shine in his splendour before all his old neighbours .
16 It all seemed very easy and alluring , sitting there in the quiet little Belltown square .
17 Chester , you see , possessed imagination .
18 That , together with the crackers and cheese , so cheered him up that he felt ready for anything .
19 He was aroused from a dream of passing Aunt Harriet by in lofty scorn and a glittering carriage , by the shrill whistle of the boat .
20 Chester pocketed his remaining crackers and cheese and his visions also , and was once more his alert , wide-awake self .
21 He had inquired the XXXXX to the wharf from the grocer , so he found no difficulty in reaching it .	way		alert|boat|boy|conductor|crackers|jaw|people|something|visions|way

1 He supposed they would have to let the women have their own way .
2 The next Sunday evening after service Mr. Sinclair arose hesitatingly .
3 His face was flushed , and Alethea Craig always declared that he looked `` just plain everyday cross . ''
4 He announced briefly that the session after due deliberation had concluded that Mrs. Cotterell might occupy the pulpit on the evening appointed for her address .
5 The women all over the church smiled broadly .
6 Frances Spenslow got up and went to the organ stool .
7 The singing in the last hymn was good and hearty .
8 Going down the steps after dismissal Mrs. Elder Knox caught the secretary of the Church Aid by the arm .
9 `` I guess , '' she whispered anxiously , `` you 'd better call a special meeting of the Aids at my house tomorrow afternoon .
10 If we 're to get that social over before haying begins we 've got to do some smart scurrying . ''
11 The strike in the Putney church was over .
12 The Unhappiness of Miss Farquhar Frances Farquhar was a beauty and was sometimes called a society butterfly by people who did n't know very much about it .
13 Her father was wealthy and her mother came of an extremely blue-blooded family .
14 Frances had been out for three years , and was a social favourite .
15 Consequently , it may be wondered why she was unhappy .
16 In plain English , Frances Farquhar had been jilted -- just a commonplace , everyday jilting !
17 She had been engaged to Paul Holcomb ; he was a very handsome fellow , somewhat too evidently aware of the fact , and Frances was very deeply in love with him -- or thought herself so , which at the time comes to pretty much the same thing .
18 Everybody in her set knew of her engagement , and all her girl friends envied her , for Holcomb was a matrimonial catch .
19 Then the crash came .
20 Nobody outside the family knew exactly what did happen , but everybody knew that the Holcomb-Farquhar match was off , and everybody had a different story to account for it .
21 The simple truth was that Holcomb was fickle and had fallen in XXXXX with another girl .	love		Mrs.|briefly|commonplace|cross|deliberation|engagement|fact|love|singing|story

1 His first act was to seek the Fairy under whose protection he had been placed , and he implored her to give him all the assistance of her art and counsel in this important matter .
2 After listening attentively to the whole adventure , the Fairy asked for time to consult her books .
3 After due consideration she informed the Prince that the object of his search was not far distant , but that it was too difficult for him to attempt to enter the enchanted palace where she was , as the King his father had surrounded it with a thick cloud , and that the only expedient she could think of would be to gain possession of the Princess 's parrot .
4 This , she added , did not appear impossible , as it often flew about to some distance in the neighbourhood .
5 Having told the Prince all this , the Fairy went out in hopes of seeing the parrot , and soon returned with the bird in her hand .
6 She promptly shut it up in a cage , and , touching the Prince with her wand , transformed him into an exactly similar parrot ; after which , she instructed him how to reach the Princess .
7 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
8 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the parrot , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .
9 This soon reassured the Prince , and encouraged him to play his part well , and he began to say a thousand agreeable things which charmed the Princess .
10 Presently the King appeared , and the parrot noticed with joy how much he was disliked .
11 As soon as the King left , the Princess retired to her dressing-room , the parrot flew after her and overheard her lamentations at the continued persecutions of the King , who had pressed her to consent to their marriage .
12 The parrot said so many clever and tender things to comfort her that she began to doubt whether this could indeed be her own parrot .
13 When he saw her well-disposed towards him , he exclaimed : ` Madam , I have a most important secret to confide to you , and I beg you not to be alarmed by what I am about to say .
14 I am here on behalf of the Queen your mother , with the object of delivering your Highness ; to prove which , behold this portrait which she gave me herself . '
15 So saying he drew forth the miniature from under his wing .
16 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
17 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
18 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
19 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
20 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
21 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her XXXXX again .	parrot		Fairy|adventure|counsel|father|lamentations|marriage|matter|mother|parrot|wing

1 `` Ye can hear Shere Khan below in the thickets .
2 I might have saved myself the message . ''
3 Father Wolf listened , and below in the valley that ran down to a little river he heard the dry , angry , snarly , singsong whine of a tiger who has caught nothing and does not care if all the jungle knows it .
4 `` The fool ! ''
5 said Father Wolf .
6 `` To begin a night 's work with that noise !
7 Does he think that our buck are like his fat Waingunga bullocks ? ''
8 `` H'sh .
9 It is neither bullock nor buck he hunts to-night , '' said Mother Wolf .
10 `` It is Man . ''
11 The whine had changed to a sort of humming purr that seemed to come from every quarter of the compass .
12 It was the noise that bewilders woodcutters and gypsies sleeping in the open , and makes them run sometimes into the very mouth of the tiger .
13 `` Man ! ''
14 said Father Wolf , showing all his white teeth .
15 `` Faugh !
16 Are there not enough beetles and frogs in the tanks that he must eat Man , and on our ground too ! ''
17 The Law of the Jungle , which never orders anything without a reason , forbids every beast to eat Man except when he is killing to show his children how to kill , and then he must hunt outside the hunting grounds of his pack or tribe .
18 The real reason for this is that man-killing means , sooner or later , the arrival of white men on elephants , with guns , and hundreds of brown men with gongs and rockets and torches .
19 Then everybody in the jungle suffers .
20 The reason the beasts give among themselves is that Man is the weakest and most defenseless of all living things , and it is unsportsmanlike to touch him .

1 replied Old Mr. Toad indignantly .
2 `` If it was fastened at the other end , how could I run it out so far ? ''
3 `` But mine and all other tongues that I ever have seen are fastened way down in the throat , '' protested Peter .
4 `` Yours is fastened at the other end , way in the very front of your mouth .
5 I never heard of such a thing . ''
6 `` There are a great many things you have never heard of , Peter Rabbit , '' replied Old Mr. Toad drily .
7 `` Mine is the right way to have a tongue .
8 Because it is fastened way up in the front of my mouth that way , I can use the whole of it .
9 You see it goes out its full length .
10 Then , when I draw it in with a bug on the end of it , I just turn it over so that the end that was out goes way back in my throat and takes the bug with it to just the right place to swallow . ''
11 Peter thought this over for a few minutes before he ventured another question .
12 `` I begin to understand , '' said he , `` but how do you hold on to the bug with your tongue ? ''
13 `` My tongue is sticky , of course , Mr. Stupid , '' replied Old Mr. Toad , looking very much disgusted .
14 `` Just let me touch a bug with it , and he 's mine every time . ''
15 Peter thought this over .
16 Then he felt of his own tongue .
17 `` Mine is n't sticky , '' said he very innocently .
18 Old Mr. Toad laughed right out .
19 `` Perhaps if it was , you could n't ask so many questions , '' said he .
20 `` Now watch me catch that fly . ''
21 His funny little tongue darted out , and the XXXXX was gone .	fly		Mine|course|fly|length|questions|things|throat|time|tongues|whole

1 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
2 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
3 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
4 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
5 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
6 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
7 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
8 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
9 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
10 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
11 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
12 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
13 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
14 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
15 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
16 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
17 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
18 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
19 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .
20 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
21 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the bank , and soon the head of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the XXXXX .	water		feet|hands|home|hunter|hunting|sound|water|wave|waves|witch

1 She went up to him and said , ' I pronounce this spell , that you become a beautiful prince , and that Hadvor shall be unable to say anything against the charges that I shall bring against her . '
2 The body of the dead Giant now became that of a beautiful prince , and the Queen went in again . '
3 I do n't think , ' said she to the King , ` that your daughter is as good as she is said to be .
4 My brother came and asked her hand , and she has had him put to death .
5 I have just found his dead body lying at the Palace gate . '
6 The King went along with the Queen to see the body , and thought it all very strange ; so beautiful a youth , he said , would have been a worthy match for Hadvor , and he would readily have agreed to their marriage .
7 The Queen asked leave to decide what Hadvor 's punishment should be , which the King was very willing to allow , so as to escape from punishing his own daughter .
8 The Queen 's decision was that the King should make a big grave-mound for her brother , and put Hadvor into it beside him .
9 Olof knew all the plans of the Queen , and went to tell the Princess what had been done , whereupon Hadvor earnestly entreated her to tell her what to do .
10 ` First and foremost , ' said Olof , ` you must get a wide cloak to wear over your other clothes , when you are put into the mound .
11 The Giant 's ghost will walk after you are both left together in there , and he will have two dogs along with him .
12 He will ask you to cut pieces out of his legs to give to the dogs , but that you must not promise to do unless he tells you where Hermod has gone to , and tells you how to find him .
13 He will then let you stand on his shoulders , so as to get out of the mound ; but he means to cheat you all the same , and will catch you by the cloak to pull you back again ; but you must take care to have the cloak loose on your shoulders , so that he will only get hold of that . '
14 The mound was all ready now , and the Giant laid in it , and into it Hadvor also had to go without being allowed to make any defence .
15 After they were both left there everything happened just as Olof had said .
16 The prince became a Giant again , and asked Hadvor to cut the pieces out of his legs for the dogs ; but she refused until he told her that Hermod was in a desert island , which she could not reach unless she took the skin off the soles of his feet and made shoes out of that ; with these shoes she could travel both on land and sea .
17 This Hadvor now did , and the Giant then let her get up on his shoulders to get out of the mound .
18 As she sprang out he caught hold of her cloak ; but she had taken care to let it lie loose on her shoulders , and so escaped .
19 She now made her way down to the sea , to where she knew there was the shortest distance over to the island in which Hermod was .
20 This strait she easily crossed , for the shoes kept her up .
21 On reaching the island she found a sandy beach all along by the XXXXX , and high cliffs above .	sea		anything|care|cloak|clothes|leave|pieces|plans|sea|shoes|spell

1 But as there were forty or fifty thousand other seals hunting for the same thing each spring , the whistling , bellowing , roaring , and blowing on the beach was something frightful .
2 From a little hill called Hutchinson 's Hill , you could look over three and a half miles of ground covered with fighting seals ; and the surf was dotted all over with the heads of seals hurrying to land and begin their share of the fighting .
3 They fought in the breakers , they fought in the sand , and they fought on the smooth-worn basalt rocks of the nurseries , for they were just as stupid and unaccommodating as men .
4 Their wives never came to the island until late in May or early in June , for they did not care to be torn to pieces ; and the young two - , three - , and four-year-old seals who had not begun housekeeping went inland about half a mile through the ranks of the fighters and played about on the sand dunes in droves and legions , and rubbed off every single green thing that grew .
5 They were called the holluschickie -- the bachelors -- and there were perhaps two or three hundred thousand of them at Novastoshnah alone .
6 Sea Catch had just finished his forty-fifth fight one spring when Matkah , his soft , sleek , gentle-eyed wife , came up out of the sea , and he caught her by the scruff of the neck and dumped her down on his reservation , saying gruffly : `` Late as usual .
7 Where have you been ? ''
8 It was not the fashion for Sea Catch to eat anything during the four months he stayed on the beaches , and so his temper was generally bad .
9 Matkah knew better than to answer back .
10 She looked round and cooed : `` How thoughtful of you .
11 You 've taken the old place again . ''
12 `` I should think I had , '' said Sea Catch .
13 `` Look at me ! ''
14 He was scratched and bleeding in twenty places ; one eye was almost out , and his sides were torn to ribbons .
15 `` Oh , you men , you men ! ''
16 Matkah said , fanning herself with her hind flipper .
17 `` Why ca n't you be sensible and settle your places quietly ?
18 You look as though you had been fighting with the Killer Whale . ''
19 `` I have n't been doing anything but fight since the middle of May .
20 The beach is disgracefully crowded this season .
21 I 've met at least a hundred XXXXX from Lukannon Beach , house hunting .	seals		Killer|May|breakers|eye|hill|island|pieces|rocks|seals|wives

6 He did not wait for anything more , but dashed on ; and the yells grew fainter behind him as he ran into the croplands where the villagers lived .
7 `` Bagheera spoke truth , '' he panted , as he nestled down in some cattle fodder by the window of a hut .
8 `` To-morrow is one day both for Akela and for me . ''
9 Then he pressed his face close to the window and watched the fire on the hearth .
10 He saw the husbandman 's wife get up and feed it in the night with black lumps .
11 And when the morning came and the mists were all white and cold , he saw the man 's child pick up a wicker pot plastered inside with earth , fill it with lumps of red-hot charcoal , put it under his blanket , and go out to tend the cows in the byre .
12 `` Is that all ? ''
13 said Mowgli .
14 `` If a cub can do it , there is nothing to fear . ''
15 So he strode round the corner and met the boy , took the pot from his hand , and disappeared into the mist while the boy howled with fear .
16 `` They are very like me , '' said Mowgli , blowing into the pot as he had seen the woman do .

1 They had sailed for several days , when the breeze suddenly fell , and there came a dead calm , at a time when they needed only one day 's voyage to reach home .
2 Sigurd and his Queen were one day on deck , when most of the others on the ship had fallen asleep .
3 There they sat and talked for a while , and had their little son along with them .
4 After a time Sigurd became so heavy with sleep that he could no longer keep awake , so he went below and lay down , leaving the Queen alone on the deck , playing with her son .
5 A good while after Sigurd had gone below the Queen saw something black on the sea , which seemed to be coming nearer .
6 As it approached she could make out that it was a boat , and could see the figure of some one sitting in it and rowing it .
7 At last the boat came alongside the ship , and now the Queen saw that it was a stone boat , out of which there came up on board the ship a fearfully ugly Witch .
8 The Queen was more frightened than words can describe , and could neither speak a word nor move from the place so as to awaken the King or the sailors .
9 The Witch came right up to the Queen , took the child from her and laid it on the deck ; then she took the Queen , and stripped her of all her fine clothes , which she proceeded to put on herself , and looked then like a human being .
10 Last of all she took the Queen , put her into the boat , and said -- ` This spell I lay upon you , that you slacken not your course until you come to my brother in the Underworld . '
11 The Queen sat stunned and motionless , but the boat at once shot away from the ship with her , and before long she was out of sight .
12 When the boat could no longer be seen the child began to cry , and though the Witch tried to quiet it she could not manage it ; so she went below to where the King was sleeping with the child on her arm , and awakened him , scolding him for leaving them alone on deck , while he and all the crew were asleep .
13 It was great carelessness of him , she said , to leave no one to watch the ship with her .
14 Sigurd was greatly surprised to hear his Queen scold him so much , for she had never said an angry word to him before ; but he thought it was quite excusable in this case , and tried to quiet the child along with her , but it was no use .
15 Then he went and wakened the sailors , and bade them hoist the sails , for a breeze had sprung up and was blowing straight towards the harbour .
16 They soon reached the land which Sigurd was to rule over , and found all the people sorrowful for the old King 's death , but they became glad when they got Sigurd back to the Court , and made him King over them .
17 The King 's son , however , hardly ever stopped crying from the time he had been taken from his mother on the deck of the ship , although he had always been such a good child before , so that at last the King had to get a nurse for him -- one of the maids of the Court .
18 As soon as the child got into her charge he stopped crying , and behaved well as before .
19 After the sea-voyage it seemed to the King that the Queen had altered very much in many ways , and not for the better .
20 He thought her much more haughty and stubborn and difficult to deal with than she used to be .
21 Before long XXXXX began to notice this as well as the King .	others		arm|breeze|carelessness|deck|maids|mother|others|sails|word|words

2 ` Well , I 've tried to say `` HOW DOTH THE LITTLE BUSY BEE , '' but it all came different ! '
3 Alice replied in a very melancholy voice .
4 ` Repeat , `` YOU ARE OLD , FATHER WILLIAM , '' ' said the Caterpillar .
5 Alice folded her hands , and began : -- ` You are old , Father William , ' the young man said , ` And your hair has become very white ; And yet you incessantly stand on your head -- Do you think , at your age , it is right ? '
6 ` In my youth , ' Father William replied to his son , ' I feared it might injure the brain ; But , now that I 'm perfectly sure I have none , Why , I do it again and again . '
7 ` You are old , ' said the youth , ` as I mentioned before , And have grown most uncommonly fat ; Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door -- Pray , what is the reason of that ? '
8 ` In my youth , ' said the sage , as he shook his grey locks , ' I kept all my limbs very supple By the use of this ointment -- one shilling the box -- Allow me to sell you a couple ? '
9 ` You are old , ' said the youth , ` and your jaws are too weak For anything tougher than suet ; Yet you finished the goose , with the bones and the beak -- Pray how did you manage to do it ? '
10 ` In my youth , ' said his father , ' I took to the law , And argued each case with my wife ; And the muscular strength , which it gave to my jaw , Has lasted the rest of my life . '
11 ` You are old , ' said the youth , ` one would hardly suppose That your eye was as steady as ever ; Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose -- What made you so awfully clever ? ' '
12 I have answered three questions , and that is enough , ' Said his father ; ` do n't give yourself airs !
13 Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff ?
14 Be off , or I 'll kick you down stairs ! '
15 ` That is not said right , ' said the Caterpillar .
16 ` Not QUITE right , I 'm afraid , ' said Alice , timidly ; ` some of the words have got altered . '
17 ` It is wrong from beginning to end , ' said the Caterpillar decidedly , and there was silence for some minutes .

1 Mowgli 's Brothers Now Rann the Kite brings home the night That Mang the Bat sets free -- The herds are shut in byre and hut For loosed till dawn are we .
2 This is the hour of pride and power , Talon and tush and claw .
3 Oh , hear the call !
4 -- Good hunting all That keep the Jungle Law !
5 Night-Song in the Jungle It was seven o'clock of a very warm evening in the Seeonee hills when Father Wolf woke up from his day 's rest , scratched himself , yawned , and spread out his paws one after the other to get rid of the sleepy feeling in their tips .
6 Mother Wolf lay with her big gray nose dropped across her four tumbling , squealing cubs , and the moon shone into the mouth of the cave where they all lived .
7 `` Augrh ! ''
8 said Father Wolf .
9 `` It is time to hunt again . ''
10 He was going to spring down hill when a little shadow with a bushy tail crossed the threshold and whined : `` Good luck go with you , O Chief of the Wolves .
11 And good luck and strong white teeth go with noble children that they may never forget the hungry in this world . ''
12 It was the jackal -- Tabaqui , the Dish-licker -- and the wolves of India despise Tabaqui because he runs about making mischief , and telling tales , and eating rags and pieces of leather from the village rubbish-heaps .
13 But they are afraid of him too , because Tabaqui , more than anyone else in the jungle , is apt to go mad , and then he forgets that he was ever afraid of anyone , and runs through the forest biting everything in his way .
14 Even the tiger runs and hides when little Tabaqui goes mad , for madness is the most disgraceful thing that can overtake a wild creature .
15 We call it hydrophobia , but they call it dewanee -- the madness -- and run .
16 `` Enter , then , and look , '' said Father Wolf stiffly , `` but there is no food here . ''
17 `` For a wolf , no , '' said Tabaqui , `` but for so mean a person as myself a dry bone is a good feast .
18 Who are we , the Gidur-log -LSB- the jackal people -RSB- , to pick and choose ? ''
19 He scuttled to the back of the cave , where he found the bone of a buck with some meat on it , and sat cracking the end merrily .
20 `` All thanks for this good meal , '' he said , licking his lips .

1 `` Forty years and five , '' said Machua Appa , `` have I followed my lord , the elephant , but never have I heard that any child of man had seen what this child has seen .
2 By all the Gods of the Hills , it is -- what can we say ? ''
3 and he shook his head .
4 When they got back to camp it was time for the evening meal .
5 Petersen Sahib ate alone in his tent , but he gave orders that the camp should have two sheep and some fowls , as well as a double ration of flour and rice and salt , for he knew that there would be a feast .
6 Big Toomai had come up hotfoot from the camp in the plains to search for his son and his elephant , and now that he had found them he looked at them as though he were afraid of them both .
7 And there was a feast by the blazing campfires in front of the lines of picketed elephants , and Little Toomai was the hero of it all .
8 And the big brown elephant catchers , the trackers and drivers and ropers , and the men who know all the secrets of breaking the wildest elephants , passed him from one to the other , and they marked his forehead with blood from the breast of a newly killed jungle-cock , to show that he was a forester , initiated and free of all the jungles .
9 And at last , when the flames died down , and the red light of the logs made the elephants look as though they had been dipped in blood too , Machua Appa , the head of all the drivers of all the Keddahs -- Machua Appa , Petersen Sahib 's other self , who had never seen a made road in forty years : Machua Appa , who was so great that he had no other name than Machua Appa , -- leaped to his feet , with Little Toomai held high in the air above his head , and shouted : `` Listen , my brothers .
10 Listen , too , you my lords in the lines there , for I , Machua Appa , am speaking !
11 This little one shall no more be called Little Toomai , but Toomai of the Elephants , as his great-grandfather was called before him .
12 What never man has seen he has seen through the long night , and the favor of the elephant-folk and of the Gods of the Jungles is with him .
13 He shall become a great tracker .
14 He shall become greater than I , even I , Machua Appa !
15 He shall follow the new trail , and the stale trail , and the mixed trail , with a clear eye !
16 He shall take no harm in the Keddah when he runs under their bellies to rope the wild tuskers ; and if he slips before the feet of the charging bull elephant , the bull elephant shall know who he is and shall not crush him .
17 Aihai !
18 my lords in the chains , '' -- he whirled up the line of pickets -- `` here is the little one that has seen your dances in your hidden places , -- the sight that never man saw !
19 Give him honor , my lords !
20 Salaam karo , my children .
21 Make your salute to Toomai of the XXXXX !	Elephants		Elephants|chains|drivers|elephant|feast|feet|harm|light|lord|meal

1 She was rather alarmed , but the Prince reassured her , telling her it was the good Fairy to whom she owed so much , and who was now conducting her in safety to her mother .
2 That same morning the King woke suddenly from a troubled sleep .
3 He had dreamt that the Princess was being carried off from him , and , transforming himself into an eagle , he flew to the palace .
4 When he failed to find her he flew into a terrible rage , and hastened home to consult his books , by which means he discovered that it was his son who had deprived him of this precious treasure .
5 Immediately he took the shape of a harpy , and , filled with rage , was determined to devour his son , and even the Princess too , if only he could overtake them .
6 He set out at full speed ; but he started too late , and was further delayed by a strong wind which the Fairy raised behind the young couple so as to baffle any pursuit .
7 You may imagine the rapture with which the Queen received the daughter she had given up for lost , as well as the amiable Prince who had rescued her .
8 The Fairy entered with them , and warned the Queen that the Wizard King would shortly arrive , infuriated by his loss , and that nothing could preserve the Prince and Princess from his rage and magic unless they were actually married .
9 The Queen hastened to inform the King her husband , and the wedding took place on the spot .
10 As the ceremony was completed the Wizard King arrived .
11 His despair at being so late bewildered him so entirely that he appeared in his natural form and attempted to sprinkle some black liquid over the bride and bridegroom , which was intended to kill them , but the Fairy stretched out her wand and the liquid dropped on the Magician himself .
12 He fell down senseless , and the Princess 's father , deeply offended at the cruel revenge which had been attempted , ordered him to be removed and locked up in prison .
13 Now as magicians lose all their power as soon as they are in prison , the King felt himself much embarrassed at being thus at the mercy of those he had so greatly offended .
14 The Prince implored and obtained his father 's pardon , and the prison doors were opened .
15 No sooner was this done than the Wizard King was seen in the air under the form of some unknown bird , exclaiming as he flew off that he would never forgive either his son or the Fairy the cruel wrong they had done him .
16 Everyone entreated the Fairy to settle in the kingdom where she now was , to which she consented .
17 She built herself a magnificent palace , to which she transported her books and fairy secrets , and where she enjoyed the sight of the perfect happiness she had helped to bestow on the entire royal family .

7 He did not pass me or go out of the door .

13 `` In my mental confusion one thought stood out sharply -- Dolly was in danger of some kind , and if the warning was really from a supernatural source , it must not be disregarded .

1 The young Prince pursued the little creature , and had almost overtaken it , when the girth of his saddle suddenly broke in two and he fell heavily to the ground .
2 No sooner had his foot touched the earth than he disappeared before the eyes of the horrified courtiers .
3 They sought for him far and near , but all in vain , and they were forced to recognise the power of the evil Fairy , against which the Queen had warned them on her death-bed .
4 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
5 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen power , and hurried away he knew not whither .
6 A whole new world stretched out before him , quite unlike the one he had left .
7 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
8 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
9 No sooner had the Fairy reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .
10 Then she gave him an axe made of glass , and bade him cross the bridge of clouds and go into the wood beyond and cut down all the trees there before sunset .
11 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
12 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
13 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
14 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
15 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
16 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
17 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .
18 Mindful of the Fairy 's warning he did not dare to address her , but she on her part greeted him in the most friendly manner , and asked him at once if he were under the power of the wicked Fairy .
19 The Prince nodded his head silently in answer .
20 Then the black girl told him that she too was in the power of the Fairy , who had doomed her to wander about in her present guise until some youth should take pity on her and bear her in safety to the other side of the river which they saw in the distance , and on the other side of which the Fairy 's domain and power ended .

2 There was a knocking heard at the Palace gate , and the old King went to open it .

7 thought the old Queen .
8 But she said nothing , and went into the sleeping-room , took off all the bed-clothes , and laid a pea on the bottom of the bed .

13 said the Princess . '
14 I scarcely closed my eyes all night !

17 It is dreadful ! '

7 Once you have that , there will be no further difficulty in the way of escape . '

9 He had , however , entirely forgotten the road by which he had come , and lost himself for so long in the forest , that when at last he reached home the Fairy had already left , and , in spite of all his grief , there was nothing for it but to wait till the Fairy 's next visit , and allow Rosalie to suffer three months longer .

16 You know that I have in my palace the cabinets of the years .
17 In the first , great mirrors reflect the past ; in the second , we contemplate the present ; in the third , the future can be read .
