1 A celebrated magician , who had given the seed to my father , promised him that they would grow into the three finest trees the world had ever seen .
2 My father did not live to see his words come true ; but on his death-bed he bade me transplant them here , and to look after them with the greatest care , which I accordingly did .
3 At last , after the lapse of five long years , I noticed some blossoms on the branches , and a few days later the most exquisite fruit my eyes had ever seen . '
4 I gave my head-gardener the strictest orders to watch the trees carefully , for the magician had warned my father that if one unripe fruit were plucked from the tree , all the rest would become rotten at once .
5 When it was quite ripe the fruit would become a golden yellow .
6 ` Every day I gazed on the lovely fruit , which became gradually more and more tempting-looking , and it was all I could do not to break the magician 's commands .
7 ` One night I dreamt that the fruit was perfectly ripe ; I ate some of it , and it was more delicious than anything I had ever tasted in real life .
8 As soon as I awoke I sent for the gardener and asked him if the fruit on the three trees had not ripened in the night to perfection .
9 ` But instead of replying , the gardener threw himself at my feet and swore that he was innocent .
10 He said that he had watched by the trees all night , but in spite of it , and as if by magic , the beautiful trees had been robbed of all their fruit .
11 ` Grieved as I was over the theft , I did not punish the gardener , of whose fidelity I was well assured , but I determined to pluck off all the fruit in the following year before it was ripe , as I had not much belief in the magician 's warning . '
12 I carried out my intention , and had all the fruit picked off the tree , but when I tasted one of the apples it was bitter and unpleasant , and the next morning the rest of the fruit had all rotted away .
13 ` After this I had the beautiful fruit of these trees carefully guarded by my most faithful servants ; but every year , on this very night , the fruit was plucked and stolen by an invisible hand , and next morning not a single apple remained on the trees .
14 For some time past I have given up even having the trees watched . '
15 When the King had finished his story , Szabo , his eldest son , said to him : ` Forgive me , father , if I say I think you are mistaken .
16 I am sure there are many men in your kingdom who could protect these trees from the cunning arts of a thieving magician ; I myself , who as your eldest son claim the first right to do so , will mount guard over the fruit this very night . '
17 The King consented , and as soon as evening drew on Szabo climbed up on to one of the trees , determined to protect the fruit even if it cost him his life .
18 So he kept watch half the night ; but a little after midnight he was overcome by an irresistible drowsiness , and fell fast asleep .
19 He did not awake till it was bright daylight , and all the fruit on the trees had vanished .
20 The following year Warza , the second brother , tried his luck , but with the same result .
21 Then it came to the turn of the third and youngest XXXXX .	son		belief|commands|magic|magician|orders|seed|son|theft|world|year

1 `` Take him away , '' he said to Father Wolf , `` and train him as befits one of the Free People . ''
2 And that is how Mowgli was entered into the Seeonee Wolf Pack for the price of a bull and on Baloo 's good word .
3 Now you must be content to skip ten or eleven whole years , and only guess at all the wonderful life that Mowgli led among the wolves , because if it were written out it would fill ever so many books .
4 He grew up with the cubs , though they , of course , were grown wolves almost before he was a child .
5 And Father Wolf taught him his business , and the meaning of things in the jungle , till every rustle in the grass , every breath of the warm night air , every note of the owls above his head , every scratch of a bat 's claws as it roosted for a while in a tree , and every splash of every little fish jumping in a pool meant just as much to him as the work of his office means to a business man .
6 When he was not learning he sat out in the sun and slept , and ate and went to sleep again .
7 When he felt dirty or hot he swam in the forest pools ; and when he wanted honey -LRB- Baloo told him that honey and nuts were just as pleasant to eat as raw meat -RRB- he climbed up for it , and that Bagheera showed him how to do .
8 Bagheera would lie out on a branch and call , `` Come along , Little Brother , '' and at first Mowgli would cling like the sloth , but afterward he would fling himself through the branches almost as boldly as the gray ape .
9 He took his place at the Council Rock , too , when the Pack met , and there he discovered that if he stared hard at any wolf , the wolf would be forced to drop his eyes , and so he used to stare for fun .
10 At other times he would pick the long thorns out of the pads of his friends , for wolves suffer terribly from thorns and burs in their coats .
11 He would go down the hillside into the cultivated lands by night , and look very curiously at the villagers in their huts , but he had a mistrust of men because Bagheera showed him a square box with a drop gate so cunningly hidden in the jungle that he nearly walked into it , and told him that it was a trap .
12 He loved better than anything else to go with Bagheera into the dark warm heart of the forest , to sleep all through the drowsy day , and at night see how Bagheera did his killing .
13 Bagheera killed right and left as he felt hungry , and so did Mowgli -- with one exception .
14 As soon as he was old enough to understand things , Bagheera told him that he must never touch cattle because he had been bought into the Pack at the price of a bull 's life .
15 `` All the jungle is thine , '' said Bagheera , `` and thou canst kill everything that thou art strong enough to kill ; but for the sake of the bull that bought thee thou must never kill or eat any cattle young or old .
16 That is the Law of the Jungle . ''
17 Mowgli obeyed faithfully .
18 And he grew and grew strong as a boy must grow who does not know that he is learning any lessons , and who has nothing in the world to think of except things to eat .
19 Mother Wolf told him once or twice that Shere Khan was not a creature to be trusted , and that some day he must kill Shere Khan .
20 But though a young wolf would have remembered that advice every hour , Mowgli forgot it because he was only a boy -- though he would have called himself a wolf if he had been able to speak in any human tongue .
21 Shere Khan was always crossing his path in the jungle , for as Akela grew older and feebler the lame tiger had come to be great XXXXX with the younger wolves of the Pack , who followed him for scraps , a thing Akela would never have allowed if he had dared to push his authority to the proper bounds .	friends		Jungle|creature|day|everything|forest|friends|lessons|nothing|price|thorns

1 She had never seen anyone who was really beautiful before -- beautiful with the loveliness of the heroines in the novels she sometimes read or the pictures she had seen .
2 Estella Bowes was not pretty .
3 She was a nice-looking girl , with clear eyes , rosy cheeks , and a pervading air of the content and happiness her life had always known .
4 She was an orphan and lived with her uncle and aunt .
5 In the summer they sometimes took a boarder for a month or two , and this summer Miss LeMar had come .
6 She had been with them about a week .
7 She was an actress from the city and had around her all the glamour of a strange , unknown life .
8 Nothing was known about her .
9 The Boweses liked her well enough as a boarder .
10 Estella admired and held her in awe .
11 She wondered what Spencer would think of this beautiful woman .
12 He had not yet seen her .

1 And a smile played round the King 's lips as he finished speaking , and his courtiers and counsellors shook with laughter when they thought of the old woman 's folly , and praised the King 's wise device , and said to each other , ` What a joke it will be when we see the pair of them tarred and feathered !
2 The son is just as able to grow a beard on the palm of his hand as to execute such a task in twenty-four hours . '
3 Now the poor old woman was mortally afraid and , in a trembling voice she asked : ` Is that really your royal will , O King ?
4 Must I take this order to my poor son ? '
5 ` Yes , old dame ; such is my command .
6 If your son carries out my order , he shall be rewarded with my daughter ; but if he fails , away to the tar-barrel and the stake with you both ! '
7 On her way home the poor old woman shed bitter tears , and when she saw Martin she told him what the King had said , and sobbed out : ` Did n't I tell you , my son , that you should marry someone of your own rank ?
8 It would have been better for us this day if you had .
9 As I told you , my going to Court has been as much as our lives are worth , and now we will both be tarred and feathered , and burnt in the public market-place .
10 It is terrible ! '
11 and she moaned and cried .
12 ` Never fear , little mother , ' answered Martin ; ` trust me , and you will see all will be well .
13 You may go to sleep with a quiet mind . '
14 And , stepping to the front of the hut , Martin threw his ring from the palm of one hand into the other , upon which twelve youths instantly appeared , and demanded what he wanted them to do .
15 Then he told them the King 's commands , and they answered that by next morning all should be accomplished exactly as the King had ordered .
16 Next morning when the King awoke , and looked out of his window , to his amazement he beheld a magnificent castle , just opposite his own palace , and joined to it a bridge of pure crystal .
17 At each side of the bridge trees were growing , from whose branches hung golden and silver apples , among which birds of Paradise perched .
18 At the right , gleaming in the sun , were the five golden cupolas of a splendid church , whose bells rang out , as if they would summon people from all corners of the earth to come and behold the wonder .
19 Now , though the King would much rather have seen his future son-in-law tarred , feathered , and burnt at the stake , he remembered his royal oath , and had to make the best of a bad business .
20 So he took heart of grace , and made Martin a Duke , and gave his daughter a rich dowry , and prepared the grandest wedding-feast that had ever been seen , so that to this day the old people in the country still talk of it .
21 After the wedding Martin and his royal bride went to dwell in the magnificent new XXXXX , and here Martin lived in the greatest comfort and luxury , such luxury as he had never imagined .	palace		beard|castle|commands|market-place|order|palace|ring|side|task|wonder

1 So he leaned over into the barrel , which did not seem very deep , and thought he would easily reach the ring ; but the more he stretched down after it the deeper grew the barrel .
2 As he was thus bending down into it the woman suddenly rose up and pushed him in head first , saying that now he could take up his quarters there .
3 Then she fixed the top on the barrel and threw it out into the sea .
4 The Prince thought himself in a bad plight now , as he felt the barrel floating out from the land and tossing about on the waves .
5 How many days he spent thus he could not tell , but at last he felt that the barrel was knocking against rocks , at which he was a little cheered , thinking it was probably land and not merely a reef in the sea .
6 Being something of a swimmer , he at last made up his mind to kick the bottom out of the barrel , and having done so he was able to get on shore , for the rocks by the sea were smooth and level ; but overhead there were high cliffs .
7 It seemed difficult to get up these , but he went along the foot of them for a little , till at last he tried to climb up , which at last he did .
8 Having got to the top , he looked round about him and saw that he was on an island , which was covered with forest , with apples growing , and altogether pleasant as far as the land was concerned .
9 After he had been there several days , he one day heard a great noise in the forest , which made him terribly afraid , so that he ran to hide himself among the trees .
10 Then he saw a Giant approaching , dragging a sledge loaded with wood , and making straight for him , so that he could see nothing for it but to lie down just where he was .
11 When the Giant came across him , he stood still and looked at the Prince for a little ; then he took him up in his arms and carried him home to his house , and was exceedingly kind to him .
12 He gave him to his wife , saying he had found this child in the wood , and she could have it to help her in the house .
13 The old woman was greatly pleased , and began to fondle the Prince with the utmost delight .
14 He stayed there with them , and was very willing and obedient to them in everything , while they grew kinder to him every day .
15 One day the Giant took him round and showed him all his rooms except the parlour ; this made the Prince curious to have a look into it , thinking there must be some very rare treasure there .
16 So one day , when the Giant had gone into the forest , he tried to get into the parlour , and managed to get the door open half-way .
17 Then he saw that some living creature moved inside and ran along the floor towards him and said something , which made him so frightened that he sprang back from the door and shut it again .
18 As soon as the fright began to pass off he tried it again , for he thought it would be interesting to hear what it said ; but things went just as before with him .
19 He then got angry with himself , and , summoning up all his courage , tried it a third time , and opened the door of the room and stood firm .
20 Then he saw that it was a big Dog , which spoke to him and said : ` Choose me , Prince Ring . '
21 The Prince went away rather afraid , thinking with himself that it was no great treasure after all ; but all the same what it had said to him stuck in his XXXXX .	mind		Ring|cliffs|courage|delight|mind|top|trees|waves|wife|wood

1 As for their dancing , I have seen the place where -- Bapree-bap !
2 How many windings has the Dihang River ?
3 Here is another ford , and we must swim the calves .
4 Stop still , you behind there . ''
5 And in this way , talking and wrangling and splashing through the rivers , they made their first march to a sort of receiving camp for the new elephants .
6 But they lost their tempers long before they got there .
7 Then the elephants were chained by their hind legs to their big stumps of pickets , and extra ropes were fitted to the new elephants , and the fodder was piled before them , and the hill drivers went back to Petersen Sahib through the afternoon light , telling the plains drivers to be extra careful that night , and laughing when the plains drivers asked the reason .
8 Little Toomai attended to Kala Nag 's supper , and as evening fell , wandered through the camp , unspeakably happy , in search of a tom-tom .
9 When an Indian child 's heart is full , he does not run about and make a noise in an irregular fashion .
10 He sits down to a sort of revel all by himself .
11 And Little Toomai had been spoken to by Petersen Sahib !
12 If he had not found what he wanted , I believe he would have been ill .
13 But the sweetmeat seller in the camp lent him a little tom-tom -- a drum beaten with the flat of the hand -- and he sat down , cross-legged , before Kala Nag as the stars began to come out , the tom-tom in his lap , and he thumped and he thumped and he thumped , and the more he thought of the great honor that had been done to him , the more he thumped , all alone among the elephant fodder .
14 There was no tune and no words , but the thumping made him happy .
15 The new elephants strained at their ropes , and squealed and trumpeted from time to time , and he could hear his mother in the camp hut putting his small brother to sleep with an old , old song about the great God Shiv , who once told all the animals what they should eat .
16 It is a very soothing lullaby , and the first verse says : Shiv , who poured the harvest and made the winds to blow , Sitting at the doorways of a day of long ago , Gave to each his portion , food and toil and fate , From the King upon the guddee to the Beggar at the gate .
17 All things made he -- Shiva the Preserver .
18 Mahadeo !
19 Mahadeo !
20 He made all -- Thorn for the camel , fodder for the kine , And mother 's heart for sleepy head , O little son of mine !

14 Darzee 's wife knew better than to do that , for a bird who looks at a snake 's eyes gets so frightened that she can not move .
15 Darzee 's wife fluttered on , piping sorrowfully , and never leaving the ground , and Nagaina quickened her pace .
16 Rikki-tikki heard them going up the path from the stables , and he raced for the end of the melon patch near the wall .
17 There , in the warm litter above the melons , very cunningly hidden , he found twenty-five eggs , about the size of a bantam 's eggs , but with whitish skin instead of shell .
18 `` I was not a day too soon , '' he said , for he could see the baby cobras curled up inside the skin , and he knew that the minute they were hatched they could each kill a man or a mongoose .
19 He bit off the tops of the eggs as fast as he could , taking care to crush the young cobras , and turned over the litter from time to time to see whether he had missed any .
20 At last there were only three eggs left , and Rikki-tikki began to chuckle to himself , when he heard Darzee 's wife screaming : `` Rikki-tikki , I led Nagaina toward the house , and she has gone into the veranda , and -- oh , come quickly -- she means killing ! ''

1 Certainly it was very delightful to be able to see her whom he loved at any moment he chose , but his spirits sometimes sank when he wondered what was to be the end of this adventure .
2 The magic mirror had been for about a year in the Prince 's possession , when one day a new subject of disquiet seized upon him .
3 As usual , he was engaged in looking at the girl , when suddenly he thought he saw a second mirror reflected in the first , exactly like his own , and with the same power .
4 And in this he was perfectly right .
5 The young girl had only possessed it for a short time , and neglected all her duties for the sake of the mirror .
6 Now it was not difficult for Saphir to guess the reason of the change in her , nor why the new mirror was consulted so often ; but try as he would he could never see the face of the person who was reflected in it , for the young girl 's figure always came between .
7 All he knew was that the face was that of a man , and this was quite enough to make him madly jealous .
8 This was the doing of the fairies , and we must suppose that they had their reasons for acting as they did .
9 When these things happened Saphir was about eighteen years old , and fifteen years had passed away since the death of his mother .
10 King Peridor had grown more and more unhappy as time went on , and at last he fell so ill that it seemed as if his days were numbered .
11 He was so much beloved by his subjects that this sad news was heard with despair by the nation , and more than all by the Prince .
12 During his whole illness the King never spoke of anything but the Queen , his sorrow at having grieved her , and his hope of one day seeing her again .
13 All the doctors and all the water-cures in the kingdom had been tried , and nothing would do him any good .
14 At last he persuaded them to let him lie quietly in his room , where no one came to trouble him .
15 Perhaps the worst pain he had to bear was a sort of weight on his chest , which made it very hard for him to breathe .
16 So he commanded his servants to leave the windows open in order that he might get more air .
17 One day , when he had been left alone for a few minutes , a bird with brilliant plumage came and fluttered round the window , and finally rested on the sill .
18 His feathers were sky-blue and gold , his feet and his beak of such glittering rubies that no one could bear to look at them , his eyes made the brightest diamonds look dull , and on his head he wore a crown .
19 I can not tell you what the crown was made of , but I am quite certain that it was still more splendid than all the rest .
20 As to his voice I can say nothing about that , for the bird never sang at all .

1 And the Big Half Moon is such a place for gulls -- there are hundreds of them here .
2 One day there was a grand wind for kite-flying , and Claude and I were having a splendid time .
3 We used our smaller kites for signalling , and when we got tired of that Claude sent me to the house for the big one .
4 I 'm sure I do n't know how it happened , but when I was coming back over the rocks I tripped and fell , and my elbow went clear through that lovely kite .
5 You would never have believed that one small elbow could make such a big hole .
6 Claude said it was just like a girl to fall and stick her elbow through a kite , but I do n't see why it should be any more like a girl than a boy .
7 Do you ?
8 We had to hurry to fix the kite if we wanted to send it up before the wind fell , so we rushed into the lighthouse to get some paper .
9 We knew there was no more red paper , and the looks of the kite were spoiled , anyhow , so we just took the first thing that came handy -- an old letter that was lying on the bookcase in the sitting-room .
10 I suppose we should n't have taken it , although , as matters turned out , it was the best thing we could have done ; but Father was away to the mainland to buy things , and we never thought it could make any difference about an old yellow letter .
11 It was one Father had taken from a drawer in the bookcase which he had cleaned out the night before .
12 We patched the kite up with the letter , a sheet on each side , and dried it by the fire .
13 Then we started out , and up went the kite like a bird .
14 The wind was glorious , and it soared and strained like something alive .
15 All at once -- snap !
16 And there was Claude , standing with a bit of cord in his hand , looking as foolish as a flatfish , and our kite sailing along at a fearful rate of speed over to the mainland .
17 I might have said to Claude , So like a boy !
18 but I did n't .
19 Instead , I sympathized with him , and pointed out that it really did n't matter because I had spoiled it by jabbing my elbow through it .
20 By this time the kite was out of sight , and we never expected to see or hear of it again .

1 Then they burned the old troll and her to ashes , and explored the cave , where they found plenty of gold and treasures .
2 The most valuable of these they carried with them as far as the cliff , and left them there .
3 Then they hastened home to the King with his three treasures , where they arrived late on Christmas night , and Ring handed them over to him .
4 The King was beside himself with joy , and was astonished at how clever a man Ring was in all kinds of feats , so that he esteemed him still more highly than before , and betrothed his daughter to him ; and the feast for this was to last all through Christmastide .
5 Ring thanked the King courteously for this and all his other kindnesses , and as soon as he had finished eating and drinking in the hall went off to sleep in his own room .
6 Snati , however , asked permission to sleep in the Prince 's bed for that night , while the Prince should sleep where the Dog usually lay .
7 Ring said he was welcome to do so , and that he deserved more from him than that came to .
8 So Snati went up into the Prince 's bed , but after a time he came back , and told Ring he could go there himself now , but to take care not to meddle with anything that was in the bed .
9 Now the story comes back to Red , who came into the hall and showed the King his right arm wanting the hand , and said that now he could see what kind of a man his intended son-in-law was , for he had done this to him without any cause whatever .
10 The King became very angry , and said he would soon find out the truth about it , and if Ring had cut off his hand without good cause he should be hanged ; but if it was otherwise , then Red should die .
11 So the King sent for Ring and asked him for what reason he had done this .
12 Snati , however , had just told Ring what had happened during the night , and in reply he asked the King to go with him and he would show him something .
13 The King went with him to his sleeping-room , and saw lying on the bed a man 's hand holding a sword .
14 ` This hand , ' said Ring , ` came over the partition during the night , and was about to run me through in my bed , if I had not defended myself . '
15 The King answered that in that case he could not blame him for protecting his own life , and that Red was well worthy of death .
16 So Red was hanged , and Ring married the King 's daughter .
17 The first night that they went to bed together Snati asked Ring to allow him to lie at their feet , and this Ring allowed him to do .

1 So he brought his sheep there , and herded them as before .

6 Then the scales fell from the shepherd 's eyes , and he recognised his wife , and she him .
7 So they returned joyfully to their own home , and lived in peace and happiness ever after .
8 THE GLASS MOUNTAIN -LRB- 16 -RRB- -LRB- 16 -RRB- From the Polish .
9 Kletke .
10 Once upon a time there was a Glass Mountain at the top of which stood a castle made of pure gold , and in front of the castle there grew an apple-tree on which there were golden apples .
11 Anyone who picked an apple gained admittance into the golden castle , and there in a silver room sat an enchanted Princess of surpassing fairness and beauty .
12 She was as rich too as she was beautiful , for the cellars of the castle were full of precious stones , and great chests of the finest gold stood round the walls of all the rooms .
13 Many knights had come from afar to try their luck , but it was in vain they attempted to climb the mountain .
14 In spite of having their horses shod with sharp nails , no one managed to get more than half-way up , and then they all fell back right down to the bottom of the steep slippery hill .
15 Sometimes they broke an arm , sometimes a leg , and many a brave man had broken his neck even .
16 The beautiful Princess sat at her window and watched the bold knights trying to reach her on their splendid horses .
17 The sight of her always gave men fresh courage , and they flocked from the four quarters of the globe to attempt the work of rescuing her .
18 But all in vain , and for seven years the Princess had sat now and waited for some one to scale the Glass Mountain .
19 A heap of corpses both of riders and horses lay round the mountain , and many dying men lay groaning there unable to go any farther with their wounded limbs .
20 The whole neighbourhood had the appearance of a vast churchyard .
21 In three more days the seven years would be at an end , when a knight in golden armour and mounted on a spirited steed was seen making his way towards the fatal XXXXX .	hill		arm|cellars|hill|knights|man|peace|recollection|sight|thought|time

6 I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered ' ; and she walked off , leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon .
7 Alice did not quite like the look of the creature , but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen : so she waited .
8 The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes : then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight : then it chuckled .

19 She pitied him deeply .

1 And here Alice began to get rather sleepy , and went on saying to herself , in a dreamy sort of way , ` Do cats eat bats ?
2 Do cats eat bats ? '
3 and sometimes , ` Do bats eat cats ? '
4 for , you see , as she could n't answer either question , it did n't much matter which way she put it .
5 She felt that she was dozing off , and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah , and saying to her very earnestly , ` Now , Dinah , tell me the truth : did you ever eat a bat ? '
6 when suddenly , thump !
7 thump !
8 down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves , and the fall was over .
9 Alice was not a bit hurt , and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment : she looked up , but it was all dark overhead ; before her was another long passage , and the White Rabbit was still in sight , hurrying down it .
10 There was not a moment to be lost : away went Alice like the wind , and was just in time to hear it say , as it turned a corner , ` Oh my ears and whiskers , how late it 's getting ! '
11 She was close behind it when she turned the corner , but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen : she found herself in a long , low hall , which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof .
12 There were doors all round the hall , but they were all locked ; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other , trying every door , she walked sadly down the middle , wondering how she was ever to get out again .
13 Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table , all made of solid glass ; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key , and Alice 's first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall ; but , alas !
14 either the locks were too large , or the key was too small , but at any rate it would not open any of them .
15 However , on the second time round , she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before , and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high : she tried the little golden key in the lock , and to her great delight it fitted !
16 Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage , not much larger than a rat-hole : she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw .
17 How she longed to get out of that dark hall , and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains , but she could not even get her head through the doorway ; ` and even if my head would go through , ' thought poor Alice , ` it would be of very little use without my shoulders .
18 Oh , how I wish I could shut up like a telescope !
19 I think I could , if I only know how to begin . '
20 For , you see , so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately , that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible .

7 ` Listen !
8 When you reach the bottom of the tree you will find yourself in a large hall ; it is light there , for there are more than three hundred lamps burning .
9 Then you will see three doors , which you can open -- the keys are in the locks .
10 If you go into the first room , you will see a great chest in the middle of the floor with a dog sitting upon it ; he has eyes as large as saucers , but you need n't trouble about him .
11 I will give you my blue-check apron , which you must spread out on the floor , and then go back quickly and fetch the dog and set him upon it ; open the chest and take as much money as you like .
12 It is copper there .
13 If you would rather have silver , you must go into the next room , where there is a dog with eyes as large as mill-wheels .
14 But do n't take any notice of him ; just set him upon my apron , and help yourself to the money .
15 If you prefer gold , you can get that too , if you go into the third room , and as much as you like to carry .
16 But the dog that guards the chest there has eyes as large as the Round Tower at Copenhagen !

20 said the Soldier .

1 As soon as she was small enough to get through the door , she ran out of the house , and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside .
2 The poor little Lizard , Bill , was in the middle , being held up by two guinea-pigs , who were giving it something out of a bottle .
3 They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared ; but she ran off as hard as she could , and soon found herself safe in a thick wood .
4 ` The first thing I 've got to do , ' said Alice to herself , as she wandered about in the wood , ` is to grow to my right size again ; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden .
5 I think that will be the best plan . '
6 It sounded an excellent plan , no doubt , and very neatly and simply arranged ; the only difficulty was , that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it ; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees , a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry .
7 An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes , and feebly stretching out one paw , trying to touch her .
8 ` Poor little thing ! '
9 said Alice , in a coaxing tone , and she tried hard to whistle to it ; but she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be hungry , in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of all her coaxing .
10 Hardly knowing what she did , she picked up a little bit of stick , and held it out to the puppy ; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off all its feet at once , with a yelp of delight , and rushed at the stick , and made believe to worry it ; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle , to keep herself from being run over ; and the moment she appeared on the other side , the puppy made another rush at the stick , and tumbled head over heels in its hurry to get hold of it ; then Alice , thinking it was very like having a game of play with a cart-horse , and expecting every moment to be trampled under its feet , ran round the thistle again ; then the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick , running a very little way forwards each time and a long way back , and barking hoarsely all the while , till at last it sat down a good way off , panting , with its tongue hanging out of its mouth , and its great eyes half shut .
11 This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape ; so she set off at once , and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath , and till the puppy 's bark sounded quite faint in the distance .
12 ` And yet what a dear little puppy it was ! '
13 said Alice , as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself , and fanned herself with one of the leaves : ' I should have liked teaching it tricks very much , if -- if I 'd only been the right size to do it !
14 Oh dear !
15 I 'd nearly forgotten that I 've got to grow up again !
16 Let me see -- how IS it to be managed ?
17 I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other ; but the great question is , what ? '
18 The great question certainly was , what ?
19 Alice looked all round her at the flowers and the blades of grass , but she did not see anything that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances .
20 There was a large mushroom growing near her , about the same height as herself ; and when she had looked under it , and on both sides of it , and behind it , it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what was on the top of it .
21 She stretched herself up on tiptoe , and peeped over the edge of the XXXXX , and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar , that was sitting on the top with its arms folded , quietly smoking a long hookah , and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else .	mushroom		animals|door|doubt|idea|look|mushroom|puppy|question|time|way

7 And so , of course , it WAS just as good as before .
8 So five years passed , and then a great sorrow came to the nation .
9 The Chinese look upon their Emperor as everything , and now he was ill , and not likely to live it was said .

7 He was opening and shutting his big mouth , and drawing his hind legs under him , and rubbing them against his body .

1 ` But he shall not succeed , ' cried he of the little hat , ' I will make a frost come which shall make the fire ashamed and die out ! '
2 So he put his hat on straight , and at once there came such a frost that all the heat disappeared and the food on the dishes began to freeze .
3 When a couple of hours had passed , and the King thought they must be quite dead from the heat , he had the doors opened and went in himself to see .
4 But when the doors were opened , there stood all Six , alive and well , saying they were glad they could come out to warm themselves , for the great cold in the room had frozen all the food hard in the dishes .
5 Then the King went angrily to the cook , and scolded him , and asked him why he had not done what he was told .
6 But the cook answered , ` There is heat enough there ; see for yourself . '
7 Then the King saw a huge fire burning under the iron room , and understood that he could do no harm to the Six in this way .
8 The King now began again to think how he could free himself from his unwelcome guests .
9 He commanded the master to come before him , and said , ` If you will take gold , and give up your right to my daughter , you shall have as much as you like . '

3 So the youth went with her , and soon they reached a beautiful garden , where stood a splendid house , which glittered in the moonlight as if it was all built out of gold and silver .
4 When the youth entered he found many splendid chambers , each one finer than the last .
5 Hundreds of tapers burnt upon golden candlesticks , and shed a light like the brightest day .
6 At length they reached a chamber where a table was spread with the most costly dishes .
7 At the table were placed two chairs , one of silver , the other of gold .
8 The maiden seated herself upon the golden chair , and offered the silver one to her companion .
9 They were served by maidens dressed in white , whose feet made no sound as they moved about , and not a word was spoken during the meal .
10 Afterwards the youth and the Witch-maiden conversed pleasantly together , until a woman , dressed in red , came in to remind them that it was bedtime .
11 The youth was now shown into another room , containing a silken bed with down cushions , where he slept delightfully , yet he seemed to hear a voice near his bed which repeated to him , ` Remember to give no blood ! '
12 The next morning the maiden asked him whether he would not like to stay with her always in this beautiful place , and as he did not answer immediately , she continued : ` You see how I always remain young and beautiful , and I am under no one 's orders , but can do just what I like , so that I have never thought of marrying before .

1 A heap of corpses both of riders and horses lay round the mountain , and many dying men lay groaning there unable to go any farther with their wounded limbs .
2 The whole neighbourhood had the appearance of a vast churchyard .
3 In three more days the seven years would be at an end , when a knight in golden armour and mounted on a spirited steed was seen making his way towards the fatal hill .
4 Sticking his spurs into his horse he made a rush at the mountain , and got up half-way , then he calmly turned his horse 's head and came down again without a slip or stumble .
5 The following day he started in the same way ; the horse trod on the glass as if it had been level earth , and sparks of fire flew from its hoofs .
6 All the other knights gazed in astonishment , for he had almost gained the summit , and in another moment he would have reached the apple-tree ; but of a sudden a huge eagle rose up and spread its mighty wings , hitting as it did so the knight 's horse in the eye .
7 The beast shied , opened its wide nostrils and tossed its mane , then rearing high up in the air , its hind feet slipped and it fell with its rider down the steep mountain side .
8 Nothing was left of either of them except their bones , which rattled in the battered golden armour like dry peas in a pod .
9 And now there was only one more day before the close of the seven years .
10 Then there arrived on the scene a mere schoolboy -- a merry , happy-hearted youth , but at the same time strong and well-grown .
11 He saw how many knights had broken their necks in vain , but undaunted he approached the steep mountain on foot and began the ascent .
12 For long he had heard his parents speak of the beautiful Princess who sat in the golden castle at the top of the Glass Mountain .
13 He listened to all he heard , and determined that he too would try his luck .
14 But first he went to the forest and caught a lynx , and cutting off the creature 's sharp claws , he fastened them on to his own hands and feet .
15 Armed with these weapons he boldly started up the Glass Mountain .
16 The sun was nearly going down , and the youth had not got more than half-way up .
17 He could hardly draw breath he was so worn out , and his mouth was parched by thirst .
18 A huge black cloud passed over his head , but in vain did he beg and beseech her to let a drop of water fall on him .
19 He opened his mouth , but the black cloud sailed past and not as much as a drop of dew moistened his dry lips .
20 His feet were torn and bleeding , and he could only hold on now with his hands .
21 Evening closed in , and he strained his eyes to see if he could behold the XXXXX of the mountain .	top		claws|close|day|end|knights|merry|rider|thirst|top|youth

1 But all the same he did not enjoy his good fortune , for he could not forget his compact with the nixy , and he knew that sooner or later she would demand his fulfilment of it .
2 But year after year went by , and the boy grew up and became a great hunter , and the lord of the land took him into his service , for he was as smart and bold a hunter as you would wish to see .
3 In a short time he married a pretty young wife , and lived with her in great peace and happiness .
4 One day when he was out hunting a hare sprang up at his feet , and ran for some way in front of him in the open field .
5 The hunter pursued it hotly for some time , and at last shot it dead .
6 Then he proceeded to skin it , never noticing that he was close to the mill-pond , which from childhood up he had been taught to avoid .
7 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
8 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
9 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
10 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
11 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
12 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
13 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
14 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
15 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
16 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
17 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
18 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
19 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
20 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
21 So next morning she went again to the flowery XXXXX and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .	meadow		bank|blood|childhood|hands|hunter|meadow|service|shot|skin|word

1 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
2 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
3 No sooner had the Fairy reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .
4 Then she gave him an axe made of glass , and bade him cross the bridge of clouds and go into the wood beyond and cut down all the trees there before sunset .
5 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
6 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
7 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
8 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
9 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
10 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
11 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .
12 Mindful of the Fairy 's warning he did not dare to address her , but she on her part greeted him in the most friendly manner , and asked him at once if he were under the power of the wicked Fairy .
13 The Prince nodded his head silently in answer .
14 Then the black girl told him that she too was in the power of the Fairy , who had doomed her to wander about in her present guise until some youth should take pity on her and bear her in safety to the other side of the river which they saw in the distance , and on the other side of which the Fairy 's domain and power ended .
15 The girl 's words so inspired the Prince with confidence that he told her all his tale of woe , and ended up by asking her advice as to how he was to escape the punishment the Fairy would be sure to inflict on him when she discovered that he had not cut down the trees in the wood and that he had broken her axe .
16 ` You must know , ' answered the black girl , ` that the Fairy in whose power we both are is my own mother , but you must not betray this secret , for it would cost me my life .
17 If you will only promise to try and free me I will stand by you , and will accomplish for you all the tasks which my mother sets you . '
18 The Prince promised joyfully all she asked ; then having once more warned him not to betray her confidence , she handed him a draught to drink which very soon sunk his senses in a deep slumber .
19 His astonishment was great when he awoke to find the glass axe whole and unbroken at his side , and all the trees of the wood lying felled around him !
20 He made all haste across the bridge of clouds , and told the Fairy that her commands were obeyed .
21 She was much amazed when she heard that all the XXXXX was cut down , and saw the axe unbroken in his hand , and since she could not believe that he had done all this by himself , she questioned him narrowly if he had seen or spoken to the black girl .	wood		answer|astonishment|guise|life|secret|silence|step|tree|wood|woods

1 ` Take off your hat , ' the King said to the Hatter .
2 ` It is n't mine , ' said the Hatter .
3 ` Stolen ! '
4 the King exclaimed , turning to the jury , who instantly made a memorandum of the fact . '
5 I keep them to sell , ' the Hatter added as an explanation ; ` I 've none of my own .
6 I 'm a hatter . '
7 Here the Queen put on her spectacles , and began staring at the Hatter , who turned pale and fidgeted .
8 ` Give your evidence , ' said the King ; ` and do n't be nervous , or I 'll have you executed on the spot . '
9 This did not seem to encourage the witness at all : he kept shifting from one foot to the other , looking uneasily at the Queen , and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter .
10 Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation , which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was : she was beginning to grow larger again , and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court ; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her . 11 I wish you would n't squeeze so . '

13 I can hardly breathe . ' '

17 ` Yes , but I grow at a reasonable pace , ' said the Dormouse : ` not in that ridiculous fashion . '

1 She handed him the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed her up .
2 Then it dawned on the Prince that he had been speaking to a good fairy , and putting the little bell carefully in his pocket , he rode home and told his father that he meant to set the daughter of the Flower Queen free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid .
3 So the next morning the Prince mounted his fine horse and left his home .
4 He had roamed round the world for a whole year , and his horse had died of exhaustion , while he himself had suffered much from want and misery , but still he had come on no trace of her he was in search of .
5 At last one day he came to a hut , in front of which sat a very old man .
6 The Prince asked him , ` Do you not know where the Dragon lives who keeps the daughter of the Flower Queen prisoner ? '
7 ` No , I do not , ' answered the old man .
8 ` But if you go straight along this road for a year , you will reach a hut where my father lives , and possibly he may be able to tell you . '
9 The Prince thanked him for his information , and continued his journey for a whole year along the same road , and at the end of it came to the little hut , where he found a very old man .
10 He asked him the same question , and the old man answered , ` No , I do not know where the Dragon lives .
11 But go straight along this road for another year , and you will come to a hut in which my father lives .
12 I know he can tell you . '
13 And so the Prince wandered on for another year , always on the same road , and at last reached the hut where he found the third old man .
14 He put the same question to him as he had put to his son and grandson ; but this time the old man answered , ` The Dragon lives up there on the mountain , and he has just begun his year of sleep .
15 For one whole year he is always awake , and the next he sleeps .
16 But if you wish to see the Flower Queen 's daughter go up the second mountain : the Dragon 's old mother lives there , and she has a ball every night , to which the Flower Queen 's daughter goes regularly . '
17 So the Prince went up the second mountain , where he found a castle all made of gold with diamond windows .
18 He opened the big gate leading into the courtyard , and was just going to walk in , when seven dragons rushed on him and asked him what he wanted ?
19 The Prince replied , ' I have heard so much of the beauty and kindness of the Dragon 's Mother , and would like to enter her service . '
20 This flattering speech pleased the dragons , and the eldest of them said , ` Well , you may come with me , and I will take you to the Mother Dragon . '

1 ` Where else should I be going , ' he said , ` than through the wood ? '
2 ` Through the wood ? '
3 said the old man in amazement .
4 ` It 's easily seen that you have heard nothing of this forest , that you rush so blindly to meet your doom .
5 Well , listen to me before you ride any further ; let me tell you that this wood hides in its depths a countless number of the fiercest tigers , hyenas , wolves , bears , and snakes , and all sorts of other monsters .
6 If I were to cut you and your horse up into tiny morsels and throw them to the beasts , there would n't be one bit for each hundred of them .
7 Take my advice , therefore , and if you wish to save your life follow some other path . '
8 The Prince was rather taken aback by the old man 's words , and considered for a minute what he should do ; then looking at his ring , and perceiving that it sparkled as brightly as ever , he called out : ` If this wood held even more terrible things than it does , I can not help myself , for I must go through it . '
9 Here he spurred his horse and rode on ; but the old beggar screamed so loudly after him that the Prince turned round and rode back to the oak tree . '
10 I am really sorry for you , ' said the beggar , ` but if you are quite determined to brave the dangers of the forest , let me at least give you a piece of advice which will help you against these monsters .
11 ` Take this bagful of bread-crumbs and this live hare .
12 I will make you a present of them both , as I am anxious to save your life ; but you must leave your horse behind you , for it would stumble over the fallen trees or get entangled in the briers and thorns .
13 When you have gone about a hundred yards into the wood the wild beasts will surround you .
14 Then you must instantly seize your bag , and scatter the bread-crumbs among them .
15 They will rush to eat them up greedily , and when you have scattered the last crumb you must lose no time in throwing the hare to them ; as soon as the hare feels itself on the ground it will run away as quickly as possible , and the wild beasts will turn to pursue it .
16 In this way you will be able to get through the wood unhurt . '
17 Iwanich thanked the old man for his counsel , dismounted from his horse , and , taking the bag and the hare in his arms , he entered the forest .
18 He had hardly lost sight of his gaunt grey friend when he heard growls and snarls in the thicket close to him , and before he had time to think he found himself surrounded by the most dreadful-looking creatures .
19 On one side he saw the glittering eye of a cruel tiger , on the other the gleaming teeth of a great she-wolf ; here a huge bear growled fiercely , and there a horrible snake coiled itself in the grass at his feet .
20 But Iwanich did not forget the old man 's advice , and quickly put his hand into the bag and took out as many bread-crumbs as he could hold in his hand at a time .
21 He threw them to the beasts , but soon the XXXXX grew lighter and lighter , and the Prince began to feel a little frightened .	bag		bag|crumb|doom|eye|friend|ground|snake|snakes|things|way

1 They headed for a cliff by the shore -- a cliff that ran down into deep water , and plunged into a dark hole at the foot of it , twenty fathoms under the sea .
2 It was a long , long swim , and Kotick badly wanted fresh air before he was out of the dark tunnel they led him through .
3 `` My wig ! ''
4 he said , when he rose , gasping and puffing , into open water at the farther end .
5 `` It was a long dive , but it was worth it . ''
6 The sea cows had separated and were browsing lazily along the edges of the finest beaches that Kotick had ever seen .
7 There were long stretches of smooth-worn rock running for miles , exactly fitted to make seal-nurseries , and there were play-grounds of hard sand sloping inland behind them , and there were rollers for seals to dance in , and long grass to roll in , and sand dunes to climb up and down , and , best of all , Kotick knew by the feel of the water , which never deceives a true sea catch , that no men had ever come there .
8 The first thing he did was to assure himself that the fishing was good , and then he swam along the beaches and counted up the delightful low sandy islands half hidden in the beautiful rolling fog .
9 Away to the northward , out to sea , ran a line of bars and shoals and rocks that would never let a ship come within six miles of the beach , and between the islands and the mainland was a stretch of deep water that ran up to the perpendicular cliffs , and somewhere below the cliffs was the mouth of the tunnel .
10 `` It 's Novastoshnah over again , but ten times better , '' said Kotick .
11 `` Sea Cow must be wiser than I thought .
12 Men ca n't come down the cliffs , even if there were any men ; and the shoals to seaward would knock a ship to splinters .
13 If any place in the sea is safe , this is it . ''
14 He began to think of the seal he had left behind him , but though he was in a hurry to go back to Novastoshnah , he thoroughly explored the new country , so that he would be able to answer all questions .
15 Then he dived and made sure of the mouth of the tunnel , and raced through to the southward .
16 No one but a sea cow or a seal would have dreamed of there being such a place , and when he looked back at the cliffs even Kotick could hardly believe that he had been under them .
17 He was six days going home , though he was not swimming slowly ; and when he hauled out just above Sea Lion 's Neck the first person he met was the seal who had been waiting for him , and she saw by the look in his eyes that he had found his island at last .
18 But the holluschickie and Sea Catch , his father , and all the other seals laughed at him when he told them what he had discovered , and a young seal about his own age said , `` This is all very well , Kotick , but you ca n't come from no one knows where and order us off like this .
19 Remember we 've been fighting for our nurseries , and that 's a thing you never did .
20 You preferred prowling about in the sea . ''
21 The other XXXXX laughed at this , and the young seal began twisting his head from side to side .	seals		cliff|fathoms|fishing|hole|hurry|one|questions|seals|southward|stretches

1 On and on they travelled , looking always to right and left for traces of the Princess , following up every track , making inquiries of every cat and dog they met , listening to the talk of every wayfarer they passed ; and at last they heard that the kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth where the twelve youths had borne the Princess was not very far off .
2 And at last one day they reached that distant kingdom , and , going at once to the palace , they began to make friends with all the dogs and cats in the place , and to question them about the Princess and the magic ring ; but no one could tell them much about either .
3 Now one day it chanced that Waska had gone down to the palace cellar to hunt for mice and rats , and seeing an especially fat , well-fed mouse , she pounced upon it , buried her claws in its soft fur , and was just going to gobble it up , when she was stopped by the pleading tones of the little creature , saying , ` If you will only spare my life I may be of great service to you .
4 I will do everything in my power for you ; for I am the King of the Mice , and if I perish the whole race will die out . '
5 ` So be it , ' said Waska . '
6 I will spare your life ; but in return you must do something for me .
7 In this castle there lives a Princess , the wicked wife of my dear master .
8 She has stolen away his magic ring .
9 You must get it away from her at whatever cost ; do you hear ?
10 Till you have done this I wo n't take my claws out of your fur . '
11 ` Good ! '
12 replied the mouse ; ' I will do what you ask . '
13 And , so saying , he summoned all the mice in his kingdom together .
14 A countless number of mice , small and big , brown and grey , assembled , and formed a circle round their king , who was a prisoner under Waska 's claws .
15 Turning to them he said : ` Dear and faithful subjects , who ever among you will steal the magic ring from the strange Princess will release me from a cruel death ; and I shall honour him above all the other mice in the kingdom . '
16 Instantly a tiny mouse stepped forward and said : ' I often creep about the Princess 's bedroom at night , and I have noticed that she has a ring which she treasures as the apple of her eye .
17 All day she wears it on her finger , and at night she keeps it in her mouth .
18 I will undertake , sire , to steal away the ring for you . '
19 And the tiny mouse tripped away into the bedroom of the Princess , and waited for nightfall ; then , when the Princess had fallen asleep , it crept up on to her bed , and gnawed a hole in the pillow , through which it dragged one by one little down feathers , and threw them under the Princess 's nose .
20 And the fluff flew into the Princess 's nose , and into her mouth , and starting up she sneezed and coughed , and the ring fell out of her mouth on to the coverlet .

1 The Hazel-nut child fastened the diamond firmly under the stork 's neck with a ribbon , and when he saw that the other storks were getting ready for their northern flight , he untied the silk cord from his stork 's wings , and away they went , getting nearer home every minute .
2 At length the Hazel-nut child came to his native village ; then he undid the ribbon from the stork 's neck and the diamond fell to the ground ; he covered it first with sand and stones , and then ran to get his parents , so that they might carry the treasure home , for he himself was not able to lift the great diamond .
3 So the Hazel-nut child and his parents lived in happiness and prosperity after this till they died .
4 THE STORY OF BIG KLAUS AND LITTLE KLAUS In a certain village there lived two people who had both the same name .
5 Both were called Klaus , but one owned four horses and the other only one .
6 In order to distinguish the one from the other , the one who had four horses was called Big Klaus , and the one who had only one horse , Little Klaus .
7 Now you shall hear what befell them both , for this is a true story .
8 The whole week through Little Klaus had to plough for Big Klaus , and lend him his one horse ; then Big Klaus lent him his four horses , but only once a week , and that was on Sunday .
9 Hurrah !
10 how loudly Little Klaus cracked his whip over all the five horses !
11 for they were indeed as good as his on this one day .
12 The sun shone brightly , and all the bells in the church-towers were pealing ; the people were dressed in their best clothes , and were going to church , with their hymn books under their arms , to hear the minister preach .
13 They saw Little Klaus ploughing with the five horses ; but he was so happy that he kept on cracking his whip , and calling out ` Gee-up , my five horses ! '
14 ` You must n't say that , ' said Big Klaus .
15 ` Only one horse is yours . '
16 But as soon as someone else was going by Little Klaus forgot that he must not say it , and called out ` Gee-up , my five horses ! '
17 ` Now you had better stop that , ' said Big Klaus , ` for if you say it once more I will give your horse such a crack on the head that it will drop down dead on the spot ! ' '
18 I really wo n't say it again ! '
19 said Little Klaus .
20 But as soon as more people passed by , and nodded him good-morning , he became so happy in thinking how well it looked to have five horses ploughing his field that , cracking his whip , he called out ` Gee-up , my five horses ! '

9 ` What else have you got in your pocket ? '

14 Alice thought the whole thing very absurd , but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh ; and , as she could not think of anything to say , she simply bowed , and took the thimble , looking as solemn as she could .

1 With these words she put the ring upon her left thumb , lifted the young man with one hand , and walked away with him under her arm .
2 This time she did not take him to a splendid palace , but to a deep cave in a rock , where there were chains hanging from the wall .
3 The maiden now chained the young man 's hands and feet so that he could not escape ; then she said in an angry voice , ` Here you shall remain chained up until you die .
4 I will bring you every day enough food to prevent you dying of hunger , but you need never hope for freedom any more . '
5 With these words she left him .
6 The old King and his daughter waited anxiously for many weeks for the Prince 's return , but no news of him arrived .
7 The King 's daughter often dreamed that her husband was going through some great suffering : she therefore begged her father to summon all the enchanters and magicians , that they might try to find out where the Prince was and how he could be set free .
8 But the magicians , with all their arts , could find out nothing , except that he was still living and undergoing great suffering ; but none could tell where he was to be found .
9 At last a celebrated magician from Finland was brought before the King , who had found out that the King 's son-in-law was imprisoned in the East , not by men , but by some more powerful being .
10 The King now sent messengers to the East to look for his son-in-law , and they by good luck met with the old magician who had interpreted the signs on King Solomon 's ring , and thus was possessed of more wisdom than anyone else in the world .
11 The magician soon found out what he wished to know , and pointed out the place where the Prince was imprisoned , but said : ` He is kept there by enchantment , and can not be set free without my help .
12 I will therefore go with you myself . '
13 So they all set out , guided by birds , and after some days came to the cave where the unfortunate Prince had been chained up for nearly seven years .
14 He recognised the magician immediately , but the old man did not know him , he had grown so thin .
15 However , he undid the chains by the help of magic , and took care of the Prince until he recovered and became strong enough to travel .
16 When he reached home he found that the old King had died that morning , so that he was now raised to the throne .
17 And now after his long suffering came prosperity , which lasted to the end of his life ; but he never got back the magic ring , nor has it ever again been seen by mortal eyes .

4 THE SNOW-DAUGHTER AND THE FIRE-SON -LRB- 25 -RRB- -LRB- 25 -RRB- From the Bukowinaer Tales and Legends .
5 Von Wliolocki .
6 There was once upon a time a man and his wife , and they had no children , which was a great grief to them .
7 One winter 's day , when the sun was shining brightly , the couple were standing outside their cottage , and the woman was looking at all the little icicles which hung from the roof .
8 She sighed , and turning to her husband said , ' I wish I had as many children as there are icicles hanging there . '
9 ` Nothing would please me more either , ' replied her husband .
10 Then a tiny icicle detached itself from the roof , and dropped into the woman 's mouth , who swallowed it with a smile , and said , ` Perhaps I shall give birth to a snow child now ! '
11 Her husband laughed at his wife 's strange idea , and they went back into the house .
12 But after a short time the woman gave birth to a little girl , who was as white as snow and as cold as ice .
13 If they brought the child anywhere near the fire , it screamed loudly till they put it back into some cool place .
14 The little maid throve wonderfully , and in a few months she could run about and speak .
15 But she was not altogether easy to bring up , and gave her parents much trouble and anxiety , for all summer she insisted on spending in the cellar , and in the winter she would sleep outside in the snow , and the colder it was the happier she seemed to be .
16 Her father and mother called her simply ` Our Snow-daughter , ' and this name stuck to her all her life .
17 One day her parents sat by the fire , talking over the extraordinary behaviour of their daughter , who was disporting herself in the snowstorm that raged outside .
18 The woman sighed deeply and said , ' I wish I had given birth to a Fire-son ! '
19 As she said these words , a spark from the big wood fire flew into the woman 's lap , and she said with a laugh , ` Now perhaps I shall give birth to a Fire-son ! '
20 The man laughed at his wife 's words , and thought it was a good joke .
21 But he ceased to think it a XXXXX when his wife shortly afterwards gave birth to a boy , who screamed lustily till he was put quite close to the fire , and who nearly yelled himself into a fit if the Snow-daughter came anywhere near him .	joke		comrade|house|joke|love|man|mouth|robes|son-in-law|sun|wine

1 The Amir had brought with him for a bodyguard eight hundred men and horses who had never seen a camp or a locomotive before in their lives -- savage men and savage horses from somewhere at the back of Central Asia .
2 Every night a mob of these horses would be sure to break their heel ropes and stampede up and down the camp through the mud in the dark , or the camels would break loose and run about and fall over the ropes of the tents , and you can imagine how pleasant that was for men trying to go to sleep .
3 My tent lay far away from the camel lines , and I thought it was safe .
4 But one night a man popped his head in and shouted , `` Get out , quick !
5 They 're coming !
6 My tent 's gone ! ''
7 I knew who `` they '' were , so I put on my boots and waterproof and scuttled out into the slush .
8 Little Vixen , my fox terrier , went out through the other side ; and then there was a roaring and a grunting and bubbling , and I saw the tent cave in , as the pole snapped , and begin to dance about like a mad ghost .
9 A camel had blundered into it , and wet and angry as I was , I could not help laughing .
10 Then I ran on , because I did not know how many camels might have got loose , and before long I was out of sight of the camp , plowing my way through the mud .
11 At last I fell over the tail-end of a gun , and by that knew I was somewhere near the artillery lines where the cannon were stacked at night .
12 As I did not want to plowter about any more in the drizzle and the dark , I put my waterproof over the muzzle of one gun , and made a sort of wigwam with two or three rammers that I found , and lay along the tail of another gun , wondering where Vixen had got to , and where I might be .
13 Just as I was getting ready to go to sleep I heard a jingle of harness and a grunt , and a mule passed me shaking his wet ears .
14 He belonged to a screw-gun battery , for I could hear the rattle of the straps and rings and chains and things on his saddle pad .
15 The screw-guns are tiny little cannon made in two pieces , that are screwed together when the time comes to use them .
16 They are taken up mountains , anywhere that a mule can find a road , and they are very useful for fighting in rocky country .
17 Behind the mule there was a camel , with his big soft feet squelching and slipping in the mud , and his neck bobbing to and fro like a strayed hen 's .
18 Luckily , I knew enough of beast language -- not wild-beast language , but camp-beast language , of course -- from the natives to know what he was saying .
19 He must have been the one that flopped into my tent , for he called to the mule , `` What shall I do ?
20 Where shall I go ?
21 I have fought with a white thing that waved , and it took a stick and hit me on the XXXXX . ''	neck		battery|boots|camels|locomotive|men|mule|neck|rings|sort|waterproof

1 The King , much moved , said , ` Adorable Princess , dry your tears .

3 My only wish is to make you the happiest person in the world . '
4 ` If you speak truth , my lord , ' replied the Princess , ` restore to me the liberty you have deprived me of .
5 Otherwise I can only look on you as my worst enemy . '
6 The King retorted that her opposition filled him with despair , but that he hoped to carry her to a place where all around would respect her , and where every pleasure would surround her .
7 So saying , he seized her once more , and in spite of all her cries he rapidly bore her off to the neighbourhood of his capital .
8 Here he gently placed her on a lawn , and as he did so she saw a magnificent palace spring up at her feet .
9 The architecture was imposing , and in the interior the rooms were handsome and furnished in the best possible taste .
10 The Princess , who expected to be quite alone , was pleased at finding herself surrounded by a number of pretty girls , all anxious to wait on her , whilst a brilliantly-coloured parrot said the most agreeable things in the world .
11 On arriving at this palace the King had resumed his own form , and though no longer young , he might well have pleased any other than this Princess , who had been so prejudiced against him by his violence that she could only regard him with feelings of hatred , which she was at no pains to conceal .
12 The King hoped , however , that time might not only soften her anger , but accustom her to his sight .
13 He took the precaution of surrounding the palace with a dense cloud , and then hastened to his Court , where his prolonged absence was causing much anxiety .
14 The Prince and all the courtiers were delighted to see their beloved King again , but they had to submit themselves to more frequent absences than ever on his part .
15 He made business a pretext for shutting himself up in his study , but it was really in order to spend the time with the Princess , who remained inflexible .

17 This idea made him horribly uneasy , and he resolved to remove the cause of his fears by sending the Prince on his travels escorted by a magnificent retinue .

1 The Queen consented with many tears , and the King at once bade his son set forth in search of the Tree of the Sun , from which he was to pluck a golden apple .
2 The Prince was delighted at the prospect , and set out on his travels that very day .
3 For a long time he wandered all through the world , and it was not till the ninety-ninth day after he started that he found an old man who was able to tell him where the Tree of the Sun grew .
4 He followed his directions , and rode on his way , and after another ninety-nine days he arrived at a golden castle , which stood in the middle of a vast wilderness .
5 He knocked at the door , which was opened noiselessly and by invisible hands .
6 Finding no one about , the Prince rode on , and came to a great meadow , where the Sun-Tree grew .
7 When he reached the tree he put out his hand to pick a golden apple ; but all of a sudden the tree grew higher , so that he could not reach its fruit .
8 Then he heard some one behind him laughing .
9 Turning round , he saw the girl in red walking towards him , who addressed him in these words : ` Do you really imagine , brave son of the earth , that you can pluck an apple so easily from the Tree of the Sun ?
10 Before you can do that , you have a difficult task before you .
11 You must guard the tree for nine days and nine nights from the ravages of two wild black wolves , who will try to harm it .
12 Do you think you can undertake this ? '
13 ` Yes , ' answered the Sun-Hero , ' I will guard the Tree of the Sun nine days and nine nights . '
14 Then the girl continued : ` Remember , though , if you do not succeed the Sun will kill you .
15 Now begin your watch . '
16 With these words the Red Girl went back into the golden castle .
17 She had hardly left him when the two black wolves appeared : but the Sun-Hero beat them off with his sword , and they retired , only , however , to reappear in a very short time .

1 I must fly away to warmer lands : will you come with me ?

3 Do come with me , dear little Thumbelina , who saved my life when I lay frozen in the dark tunnel ! '
4 ` Yes , I will go with you , ' said Thumbelina , and got on the swallow 's back , with her feet on one of his outstretched wings .
5 Up he flew into the air , over woods and seas , over the great mountains where the snow is always lying .
6 And if she was cold she crept under his warm feathers , only keeping her little head out to admire all the beautiful things in the world beneath .
7 At last they came to warm lands ; there the sun was brighter , the sky seemed twice as high , and in the hedges hung the finest green and purple grapes ; in the woods grew oranges and lemons : the air was scented with myrtle and mint , and on the roads were pretty little children running about and playing with great gorgeous butterflies .
8 But the swallow flew on farther , and it became more and more beautiful .
9 Under the most splendid green trees besides a blue lake stood a glittering white-marble castle .
10 Vines hung about the high pillars ; there were many swallows ' nests , and in one of these lived the swallow who was carrying Thumbelina .

12 said he .

14 Find a home for yourself in one of the lovely flowers that grow down there ; now I will set you down , and you can do whatever you like . '
15 ` That will be splendid ! '
16 said she , clapping her little hands .

6 THE GRATEFUL BEASTS -LRB- 11 -RRB- -LRB- 11 -RRB- From the Hungarian .
7 Kletke .
8 There was once upon a time a man and woman who had three fine-looking sons , but they were so poor that they had hardly enough food for themselves , let alone their children .
9 So the sons determined to set out into the world and to try their luck .
10 Before starting their mother gave them each a loaf of bread and her blessing , and having taken a tender farewell of her and their father the three set forth on their travels .
11 The youngest of the three brothers , whose name was Ferko , was a beautiful youth , with a splendid figure , blue eyes , fair hair , and a complexion like milk and roses .
12 His two brothers were as jealous of him as they could be , for they thought that with his good looks he would be sure to be more fortunate than they would ever be .
13 One day all the three were sitting resting under a tree , for the sun was hot and they were tired of walking .
14 Ferko fell fast asleep , but the other two remained awake , and the eldest said to the second brother , ` What do you say to doing our brother Ferko some harm ?
15 He is so beautiful that everyone takes a fancy to him , which is more than they do to us .
16 If we could only get him out of the way we might succeed better . ' '
17 I quite agree with you , ' answered the second brother , ` and my advice is to eat up his loaf of bread , and then to refuse to give him a bit of ours until he has promised to let us put out his eyes or break his legs . '
18 His eldest brother was delighted with this proposal , and the two wicked wretches seized Ferko 's loaf and ate it all up , while the poor boy was still asleep .
19 When he did awake he felt very hungry and turned to eat his bread , but his brothers cried out , ` You ate your loaf in your sleep , you glutton , and you may starve as long as you like , but you wo n't get a scrap of ours . '
20 Ferko was at a loss to understand how he could have eaten in his sleep , but he said nothing , and fasted all that day and the next night .
