4 Then the old man went away too , returned to the light of day , and went home .
5 Soon after he heard that the Princess was ill , and that the only thing that did her good was having stories told to her .
6 He therefore went to the royal castle , obtained an audience of the Princess , and told her about the strange things he had seen in the underground palace .
7 No sooner had he finished than the Princess asked him whether he could find the way to that palace .
8 ` Yes , ' he answered , ` certainly . '
9 And now she desired him to guide her thither at once .
10 The old man did so , and when they came to the palace he hid her behind the great picture and advised her to keep quite still , and he placed himself behind the picture also .
11 Presently the eagles came flying in , and changed themselves into young men , and in a moment the Princess recognised her husband amongst them all , and tried to come out of her hiding-place ; but the old man held her back .
12 The youths seated themselves at the table ; and now the Prince said again , while he took up the cup of wine : ' A health to my dearest lady , Long may she live and well !
13 But a curse on the cruel mother That burnt my golden shell ! '
14 Then the Princess could restrain herself no longer , but ran forward and threw her arms round her husband .

16 Now you see that I spoke the truth .
17 But all that bad time is past .
18 Now listen to me : I must still remain enchanted for three months .
19 Will you stay here with me till that time is over ? '

1 But another rushing wave arose and dragged him under once more .
2 The hunter 's wife , who had stood on the bank full of joy and hope , sank into despair when she saw her husband snatched away again before her eyes .
3 But for her comfort she dreamt the same dream a third time , and betook herself once more to the old witch 's hut in the flowery meadow .
4 This time the old woman told her to go the next full moon to the mill-pond , and to spin there with a golden spinning-wheel , and then to leave the spinning-wheel on the bank .
5 The hunter 's wife did as she was advised , and the first night the moon was full she sat and spun with a golden spinning-wheel , and then left the wheel on the bank .
6 In a few minutes a rushing sound was heard in the waters , and a wave swept the spinning-wheel from the bank .
7 Immediately the head of the hunter rose up from the pond , getting higher and higher each moment , till at length he stepped on to the bank and fell on his wife 's neck .
8 But the waters of the pond rose up suddenly , overflowed the bank where the couple stood , and dragged them under the flood .
9 In her despair the young wife called on the old witch to help her , and in a moment the hunter was turned into a frog and his wife into a toad .
10 But they were not able to remain together , for the water tore them apart , and when the flood was over they both resumed their own shapes again , but the hunter and the hunter 's wife found themselves each in a strange country , and neither knew what had become of the other .
11 The hunter determined to become a shepherd , and his wife too became a shepherdess .
12 So they herded their sheep for many years in solitude and sadness .
13 Now it happened once that the shepherd came to the country where the shepherdess lived .
14 The neighbourhood pleased him , and he saw that the pasture was rich and suitable for his flocks .
15 So he brought his sheep there , and herded them as before .
16 The shepherd and shepherdess became great friends , but they did not recognise each other in the least .
17 But one evening when the moon was full they sat together watching their flocks , and the shepherd played upon his flute .
18 Then the shepherdess thought of that evening when she had sat at the full moon by the mill-pond and had played on the golden flute ; the recollection was too much for her , and she burst into tears .
19 The shepherd asked her why she was crying , and left her no peace till she told him all her story .
20 Then the scales fell from the shepherd 's eyes , and he recognised his wife , and she him .
21 So they returned joyfully to their own home , and lived in XXXXX and happiness ever after .	peace		despair|dream|flute|friends|hut|peace|story|tears|wave|woman

1 But it is not known whether this ring was ever made by mortal hands : it is supposed that an angel gave it to the wise King . '
2 When the youth heard all this he determined to try and get possession of the ring , though he did not quite believe in all its wonderful gifts .
3 He wished the maiden would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .
4 A few days after they were again speaking of the magic ring , and the youth said , ' I do not think it possible that the ring can have all the power you say it has . '
5 Then the maiden opened the box and took the ring out , and it glittered as she held it like the clearest sunbeam .
6 She put it on the middle finger of her left hand , and told the youth to take a knife and try as hard as he could to cut her with it , for he would not be able to hurt her .
7 He was unwilling at first , but the maiden insisted .
8 Then he tried , at first only in play , and then seriously , to strike her with the knife , but an invisible wall of iron seemed to be between them , and the maiden stood before him laughing and unhurt .
9 Then she put the ring on her third finger , and in an instant she had vanished from his eyes .
10 Presently she was beside him again laughing , and holding the ring between her fingers .
11 ` Do let me try , ' said the youth , ` whether I can do these wonderful things . '
12 The maiden , suspecting no treachery , gave him the magic ring .
13 The youth pretended to have forgotten what to do , and asked what finger he must put the ring on so that no sharp weapon could hurt him ? '
14 ` Oh , the middle finger of your left hand , ' the maiden answered , laughing .
15 She took the knife and tried to strike the youth , and he even tried to cut himself with it , but found it impossible .
16 Then he asked the maiden to show him how to split stones and rocks with the help of the ring .
17 So she led him into a courtyard where stood a great boulder-stone .
18 ` Now , ' she said , ` put the ring upon the thumb of your left hand , and you will see how strong that hand has become .
19 The youth did so , and found to his astonishment that with a single blow of his fist the stone flew into a thousand pieces .
20 Then the youth bethought him that he who does not use his luck when he has it is a fool , and that this was a chance which once lost might never return .
21 So while they stood laughing at the shattered XXXXX he placed the ring , as if in play , upon the third finger of his left hand .	stone		astonishment|blow|box|courtyard|finger|maiden|pieces|possession|power|stone

1 You must be careful that the rolls last till our return . '
2 And Waska took leave of her beloved master , and set off with Schurka on their journey .
3 On and on they travelled , looking always to right and left for traces of the Princess , following up every track , making inquiries of every cat and dog they met , listening to the talk of every wayfarer they passed ; and at last they heard that the kingdom at the utmost ends of the earth where the twelve youths had borne the Princess was not very far off .
4 And at last one day they reached that distant kingdom , and , going at once to the palace , they began to make friends with all the dogs and cats in the place , and to question them about the Princess and the magic ring ; but no one could tell them much about either .
5 Now one day it chanced that Waska had gone down to the palace cellar to hunt for mice and rats , and seeing an especially fat , well-fed mouse , she pounced upon it , buried her claws in its soft fur , and was just going to gobble it up , when she was stopped by the pleading tones of the little creature , saying , ` If you will only spare my life I may be of great service to you .
6 I will do everything in my power for you ; for I am the King of the Mice , and if I perish the whole race will die out . '
7 ` So be it , ' said Waska . '
8 I will spare your life ; but in return you must do something for me .
9 In this castle there lives a Princess , the wicked wife of my dear master .
10 She has stolen away his magic ring .
11 You must get it away from her at whatever cost ; do you hear ?
12 Till you have done this I wo n't take my claws out of your fur . '
13 ` Good ! '
14 replied the mouse ; ' I will do what you ask . '
15 And , so saying , he summoned all the mice in his kingdom together .
16 A countless number of mice , small and big , brown and grey , assembled , and formed a circle round their king , who was a prisoner under Waska 's claws .
17 Turning to them he said : ` Dear and faithful subjects , who ever among you will steal the magic ring from the strange Princess will release me from a cruel death ; and I shall honour him above all the other mice in the kingdom . '
18 Instantly a tiny mouse stepped forward and said : ' I often creep about the Princess 's bedroom at night , and I have noticed that she has a ring which she treasures as the apple of her eye .
19 All day she wears it on her finger , and at night she keeps it in her mouth .
20 I will undertake , sire , to steal away the ring for you . '

3 By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back , the fight was over , and both the hedgehogs were out of sight : ` but it does n't matter much , ' thought Alice , ` as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground . '
4 So she tucked it away under her arm , that it might not escape again , and went back for a little more conversation with her friend .
5 When she got back to the Cheshire Cat , she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it : there was a dispute going on between the executioner , the King , and the Queen , who were all talking at once , while all the rest were quite silent , and looked very uncomfortable .
6 The moment Alice appeared , she was appealed to by all three to settle the question , and they repeated their arguments to her , though , as they all spoke at once , she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said .
7 The executioner 's argument was , that you could n't cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from : that he had never had to do such a thing before , and he was n't going to begin at HIS time of life .
8 The King 's argument was , that anything that had a head could be beheaded , and that you were n't to talk nonsense .
9 The Queen 's argument was , that if something was n't done about it in less than no time she 'd have everybody executed , all round .

12 Davenport 's Story It was a rainy afternoon , and we had been passing the time by telling ghost stories .
13 That is a very good sort of thing for a rainy afternoon , and it is a much better time than after night .
14 If you tell ghost stories after dark they are apt to make you nervous , whether you own up to it or not , and you sneak home and dodge upstairs in mortal terror , and undress with your back to the wall , so that you ca n't fancy there is anything behind you .
15 We had each told a story , and had had the usual assortment of mysterious noises and death warnings and sheeted spectres and so on , down through the whole catalogue of horrors -- enough to satisfy any reasonable ghost-taster .
16 But Jack , as usual , was dissatisfied .
17 He said our stories were all second-hand stuff .
18 There was n't a man in the crowd who had ever seen or heard a ghost ; all our so-called authentic stories had been told us by persons who had the story from other persons who saw the ghosts .
19 `` One does n't get any information from that , '' said Jack .
20 `` I never expect to get so far along as to see a real ghost myself , but I would like to see and talk to one who had . ''

1 exclaimed his mother in a great passion .
2 ` Leave the house at once , and go and beg your bread among strangers ; ' and as Martin did not dare to contradict her , he called Schurka and Waska and started off with them to the nearest village in search of work .
3 On the way he met a rich peasant , who asked him where he was going . '
4 I want to get work as a day labourer , ' he answered .
5 ` Come along with me , then .
6 But I must tell you I engage my labourers without wages .
7 If you serve me faithfully for a year , I promise you it shall be for your advantage . '
8 So Martin consented , and for a year he worked diligently , and served his master faithfully , not sparing himself in any way .
9 When the day of reckoning had come the peasant led him into a barn , and pointing to two full sacks , said : ` Take whichever of these you choose . '
10 Martin examined the contents of the sacks , and seeing that one was full of silver and the other of sand , he said to himself : ` There must be some trick about this ; I had better take the sand . '
11 And throwing the sack over his shoulders he started out into the world , in search of fresh work .
12 On and on he walked , and at last he reached a great gloomy wood .
13 In the middle of the wood he came upon a meadow , where a fire was burning , and in the midst of the fire , surrounded by flames , was a lovely damsel , more beautiful than anything that Martin had ever seen , and when she saw him she called to him : ` Martin , if you would win happiness , save my life .
14 Extinguish the flames with the sand that you earned in payment of your faithful service . '
15 ` Truly , ' thought Martin to himself , ` it would be more sensible to save a fellow-being 's life with this sand than to drag it about on one 's back , seeing what a weight it is . '
16 And forthwith he lowered the sack from his shoulders and emptied its contents on the flames , and instantly the fire was extinguished ; but at the same moment lo !
17 and behold the lovely damsel turned into a Serpent , and , darting upon him , coiled itself round his neck , and whispered lovingly in his ear : ` Do not be afraid of me , Martin ; I love you , and will go with you through the world .
18 But first you must follow me boldly into my Father 's Kingdom , underneath the earth ; and when we get there , remember this -- he will offer you gold and silver , and dazzling gems , but do not touch them .
19 Ask him , instead , for the ring which he wears on his little finger , for in that ring lies a magic power ; you have only to throw it from one hand to the other , and at once twelve young men will appear , who will do your bidding , no matter how difficult , in a single night . '
20 So they started on their way , and after much wandering they reached a spot where a great rock rose straight up in the middle of the road .
21 Instantly the Serpent uncoiled itself from his neck , and , as it touched the damp earth , it resumed the shape of the lovely XXXXX .	damsel		advantage|anything|damsel|hand|life|master|midst|passion|trick|wood

9 To talk of running away was one thing .

15 So hustle off -- and mind you behave yourself . ''
16 Chester heard the news gladly .
17 He had not yet devised any feasible plan for running away , and he always liked to work at the Stearns ' place .
18 To be sure , Mrs. Elwell received all the money he earned , but Mrs. Stearns was kind to him , and though he had to work hard and constantly , he was well fed and well treated by all .

1 Kletke .
2 There was once upon a time a King and Queen who had everything they could possibly wish for in this world except a child .
3 At last , after twelve years , the Queen gave birth to a son ; but she did not live long to enjoy her happiness , for on the following day she died .
4 But before her death she called her husband to her and said , ` Never let the child put his feet on the ground , for as soon as he does so he will fall into the power of a wicked Fairy , who will do him much harm . '
5 And these were the last words the poor Queen spoke .
6 The boy throve and grew big , and when he was too heavy for his nurse to carry , a chair was made for him on little wheels , in which he could wander through the palace gardens without help ; at other times he was carried about on a litter , and he was always carefully watched and guarded for fear he should at any time put his feet to the ground .
7 But as this sort of life was bad for his health , the doctors ordered him horse exercise , and he soon became a first-rate rider , and used to go out for long excursions on horseback , accompanied always by his father 's stud-groom and a numerous retinue .
8 Every day he rode through the neighbouring fields and woods , and always returned home in the evening safe and well .
9 In this way many years passed , and the Prince grew to manhood , and hardly anyone remembered the Queen 's warning , though precautions were still taken , more from use and wont than for any other reason .
10 One day the Prince and his suite went out for a ride in a wood where his father sometimes held a hunt .
11 Their way led through a stream whose banks were overgrown with thick brushwood .
12 Just as the horsemen were about to ford the river , a hare , startled by the sound of the horses ' hoofs , started up from the grass and ran towards the thicket .
13 The young Prince pursued the little creature , and had almost overtaken it , when the girth of his saddle suddenly broke in two and he fell heavily to the ground .
14 No sooner had his foot touched the earth than he disappeared before the eyes of the horrified courtiers .
15 They sought for him far and near , but all in vain , and they were forced to recognise the power of the evil Fairy , against which the Queen had warned them on her death-bed .
16 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
17 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen power , and hurried away he knew not whither .
18 A whole new world stretched out before him , quite unlike the one he had left .
19 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
20 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
21 No sooner had the XXXXX reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .	Fairy		Fairy|creature|day|ground|hoofs|husband|nurse|sound|warning|words

1 said Alice to herself , rather sharply ; ' I advise you to leave off this minute ! '
2 She generally gave herself very good advice , -LRB- though she very seldom followed it -RRB- , and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes ; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself , for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people .
3 ` But it 's no use now , ' thought poor Alice , ` to pretend to be two people !
4 Why , there 's hardly enough of me left to make ONE respectable person ! '
5 Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table : she opened it , and found in it a very small cake , on which the words ` EAT ME ' were beautifully marked in currants .
6 ` Well , I 'll eat it , ' said Alice , ` and if it makes me grow larger , I can reach the key ; and if it makes me grow smaller , I can creep under the door ; so either way I 'll get into the garden , and I do n't care which happens ! '
7 She ate a little bit , and said anxiously to herself , ` Which way ?
8 Which way ? '
9 , holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing , and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size : to be sure , this generally happens when one eats cake , but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen , that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way .
10 So she set to work , and very soon finished off the cake .
11 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * CHAPTER II .

7 `` So this is the manling , '' said Kaa .
8 `` Very soft is his skin , and he is not unlike the Bandar-log .
9 Have a care , manling , that I do not mistake thee for a monkey some twilight when I have newly changed my coat . ''
10 `` We be one blood , thou and I , '' Mowgli answered .
11 `` I take my life from thee tonight .

13 `` All thanks , Little Brother , '' said Kaa , though his eyes twinkled .

4 said Little Toomai .
5 `` Happen !
6 The worst that can happen .
7 Petersen Sahib is a madman .
8 Else why should he go hunting these wild devils ?
9 He may even require thee to be an elephant catcher , to sleep anywhere in these fever-filled jungles , and at last to be trampled to death in the Keddah .
10 It is well that this nonsense ends safely .
11 Next week the catching is over , and we of the plains are sent back to our stations .
12 Then we will march on smooth roads , and forget all this hunting .

14 Kala Nag will obey none but me , so I must go with him into the Keddah , but he is only a fighting elephant , and he does not help to rope them .
15 So I sit at my ease , as befits a mahout , -- not a mere hunter , -- a mahout , I say , and a man who gets a pension at the end of his service .

1 Whilst at luncheon he suddenly spied a little monkey of the brightest green sitting on a tree and gazing so tenderly at him that he felt quite moved .
2 He forbade his courtiers to frighten it , and the monkey , noticing how much attention was being paid him , sprang from bough to bough , and at length gradually approached the King , who offered him some food .
3 The monkey took it very daintily and finally came to the table .
4 The King took him on his knees , and , delighted with his capture , brought him home with him .
5 He would trust no one else with its care , and the whole Court soon talked of nothing but the pretty green monkey .
6 One morning , as Prince Alphege 's governess and her daughter were alone together , the little monkey sprang in through an open window .
7 He had escaped from the palace , and his manners were so gentle and caressing that Zayda and her mother soon got over the first fright he had given them .
8 He had spent some time with them and quite won their hearts by his insinuating ways , when the King discovered where he was and sent to fetch him back .
9 But the monkey made such piteous cries , and seemed so unhappy when anyone attempted to catch him , that the two ladies begged the King to leave him a little longer with them , to which he consented .
10 One evening , as they sat by the fountain in the garden , the little monkey kept gazing at Zayda with such sad and loving eyes that she and her mother could not think what to make of it , and they were still more surprised when they saw big tears rolling down his cheeks .
11 Next day both mother and daughter were sitting in a jessamine bower in the garden , and they began to talk of the green monkey and his strange ways .
12 The mother said , ` My dear child , I can no longer hide my feelings from you .
13 I can not get the thought out of my mind that the green monkey is no other than our beloved Prince Alphege , transformed in this strange fashion .
14 I know the idea sounds wild , but I can not get it out of my heart , and it leaves me no peace . '
15 As she spoke she glanced up , and there sat the little monkey , whose tears and gestures seemed to confirm her words .
16 The following night the elder lady dreamt that she saw the Good Queen , who said , ` Do not weep any longer but follow my directions .
17 Go into your garden and lift up the little marble slab at the foot of the great myrtle tree .

19 Take it with you and place the thing which is at present most in your thoughts into a bath filled with roses and rub it well with the green liquid . '

4 I JIMMY SKUNK IS PUZZLED Old Mother West Wind had just come down from the Purple Hills and turned loose her children , the Merry Little Breezes , from the big bag in which she had been carrying them .
5 They were very lively and very merry as they danced and raced across the Green Meadows in all directions , for it was good to be back there once more .
6 Old Mother West Wind almost sighed as she watched them for a few minutes .
7 She felt that she would like to join them .
8 Always the springtime made her feel this way , -- young , mad , carefree , and happy .
9 But she had work to do .
10 She had to turn the windmill to pump water for Farmer Brown 's cows , and this was only one of many mills standing idle as they waited for her .
11 So she puffed her cheeks out and started about her business .
12 Jimmy Skunk sat at the top of the hill that overlooks the Green Meadows and watched her out of sight .
13 Then he started to amble down the Lone Little Path to look for some beetles .
14 He was ambling along in his lazy way , for you know he never hurries , when he heard some one puffing and blowing behind him .
15 Of course he turned to see who it was , and he was greatly surprised when he discovered Old Mr. Toad .
16 Yes , Sir , it was Old Mr. Toad , and he seemed in a great hurry .
17 He was quite short of breath , but he was hopping along in the most determined way as if he were in a great hurry to get somewhere .
18 Now it is a very unusual thing for Mr. Toad to hurry , very unusual indeed .
19 As a rule he hops a few steps and then sits down to think it over .
20 Jimmy had never before seen him hop more than a few steps unless he was trying to get away from danger , from Mr. Blacksnake for instance .

4 THE GOLDEN CRAB -LRB- 5 -RRB- -LRB- 5 -RRB- ` Prinz Krebs , ' from Griechische Mahrchen .
5 Schmidt .
6 Once upon a time there was a fisherman who had a wife and three children .
7 Every morning he used to go out fishing , and whatever fish he caught he sold to the King .
8 One day , among the other fishes , he caught a golden crab .
9 When he came home he put all the fishes together into a great dish , but he kept the Crab separate because it shone so beautifully , and placed it upon a high shelf in the cupboard .
10 Now while the old woman , his wife , was cleaning the fish , and had tucked up her gown so that her feet were visible , she suddenly heard a voice , which said : ` Let down , let down thy petticoat That lets thy feet be seen . '
11 She turned round in surprise , and then she saw the little creature , the Golden Crab .
12 ` What !
13 You can speak , can you , you ridiculous crab ? '
14 she said , for she was not quite pleased at the Crab 's remarks .
15 Then she took him up and placed him on a dish .
16 When her husband came home and they sat down to dinner , they presently heard the Crab 's little voice saying , ` Give me some too . '
17 They were all very much surprised , but they gave him something to eat .
18 When the old man came to take away the plate which had contained the Crab 's dinner , he found it full of gold , and as the same thing happened every day he soon became very fond of the Crab .
19 One day the Crab said to the fisherman 's wife , ` Go to the King and tell him I wish to marry his younger daughter . '
20 The old woman went accordingly , and laid the matter before the King , who laughed a little at the notion of his daughter marrying a crab , but did not decline the proposal altogether , because he was a prudent monarch , and knew that the Crab was likely to be a prince in disguise .
21 He said , therefore , to the XXXXX 's wife , ` Go , old woman , and tell the Crab I will give him my daughter if by to-morrow morning he can build a wall in front of my castle much higher than my tower , upon which all the flowers of the world must grow and bloom . 1 ` You , my wife , the companion of my days , will follow me ere many moons have waned to the island of the blest .
2 But for you , O my children , whose lives are but newly begun , the wickedness , unkindness , and ingratitude from which I fled are before you .
3 Yet I shall go hence in peace , my children , if you will promise always to love each other , and never to forsake your youngest brother .
4 ` Never ! '
5 they replied , holding out their hands .
6 And the hunter died content .
7 Scarcely eight moons had passed when , just as he had said , the wife went forth , and followed her husband ; but before leaving her children she bade the two elder ones think of their promise never to forsake the younger , for he was a child , and weak .
8 And while the snow lay thick upon the ground , they tended him and cherished him ; but when the earth showed green again , the heart of the young man stirred within him , and he longed to see the wigwams of the village where his father 's youth was spent .
9 Therefore he opened all his heart to his sister , who answered : ` My brother , I understand your longing for our fellow-men , whom here we can not see .
10 But remember our father 's words .
11 Shall we not seek our own pleasures , and forget the little one ? '
12 But he would not listen , and , making no reply , he took his bow and arrows and left the hut .
13 The snows fell and melted , yet he never returned ; and at last the heart of the girl grew cold and hard , and her little boy became a burden in her eyes , till one day she spoke thus to him : ` See , there is food for many days to come .
14 Stay here within the shelter of the hut .
15 I go to seek our brother , and when I have found him I shall return hither . '
16 But when , after hard journeying , she reached the village where her brother dwelt , and saw that he had a wife and was happy , and when she , too , was sought by a young brave , then she also forgot the boy alone in the forest , and thought only of her husband .
17 Now as soon as the little boy had eaten all the food which his sister had left him , he went out into the woods , and gathered berries and dug up roots , and while the sun shone he was contented and had his fill .
18 But when the snows began and the wind howled , then his stomach felt empty and his limbs cold , and he hid in trees all the night , and only crept out to eat what the wolves had left behind .
19 And by-and-by , having no other friends , he sought their company , and sat by while they devoured their prey , and they grew to know him , and gave him food .
20 And without them he would have died in the snow .
21 But at last the snows melted , and the ice upon the great lake , and as the XXXXX went down to the shore , the boy went after them .	wolves		burden|father|fill|girl|ground|heart|ingratitude|man|peace|wolves

1 When you reach the bottom of the tree you will find yourself in a large hall ; it is light there , for there are more than three hundred lamps burning .
2 Then you will see three doors , which you can open -- the keys are in the locks .
3 If you go into the first room , you will see a great chest in the middle of the floor with a dog sitting upon it ; he has eyes as large as saucers , but you need n't trouble about him .
4 I will give you my blue-check apron , which you must spread out on the floor , and then go back quickly and fetch the dog and set him upon it ; open the chest and take as much money as you like .
5 It is copper there .
6 If you would rather have silver , you must go into the next room , where there is a dog with eyes as large as mill-wheels .
7 But do n't take any notice of him ; just set him upon my apron , and help yourself to the money .
8 If you prefer gold , you can get that too , if you go into the third room , and as much as you like to carry .
9 But the dog that guards the chest there has eyes as large as the Round Tower at Copenhagen !
10 He is a savage dog , I can tell you ; but you need n't be afraid of him either .
11 Only , put him on my apron and he wo n't touch you , and you can take out of the chest as much gold as you like ! '
12 ` Come , this is not bad ! '
13 said the Soldier .
14 ` But what am I to give you , old Witch ; for surely you are not going to do this for nothing ? '
15 ` Yes , I am ! '
16 replied the Witch .
17 ` Not a single farthing will I take !
18 For me you shall bring nothing but an old tinder-box which my grandmother forgot last time she was down there . '

1 The youth ran to look at it , and saw that a huge abyss had opened below the stone .
2 He went at once to fetch his brothers , and with their help dragged a lot of pine-wood and ropes to the spot .
3 They fastened some of the burning pine-wood to the end of the rope , and let it slowly down to the bottom of the abyss .
4 At first it was quite dark , and the flaming torch only lit up dirty grey stone walls .
5 But the youngest brother determined to explore the abyss , and letting himself down by the rope he soon reached the bottom .
6 Here he found a lovely meadow full of green trees and exquisite flowers .
7 In the middle of the meadow stood a huge stone castle , with an iron gate leading to it , which was wide open .
8 Everything in the castle seemed to be made of copper , and the only inhabitant he could discover was a lovely girl , who was combing her golden hair ; and he noticed that whenever one of her hairs fell on the ground it rang out like pure metal .
9 The youth looked at her more closely , and saw that her skin was smooth and fair , her blue eyes bright and sparkling , and her hair as golden as the sun .
10 He fell in love with her on the spot , and kneeling at her feet , he implored her to become his wife .
11 The lovely girl accepted his proposal gladly ; but at the same time she warned him that she could never come up to the world above till her mother , the old witch , was dead .
12 And she went on to tell him that the only way in which the old creature could be killed was with the sword that hung up in the castle ; but the sword was so heavy that no one could lift it .
13 Then the youth went into a room in the castle where everything was made of silver , and here he found another beautiful girl , the sister of his bride .
14 She was combing her silver hair , and every hair that fell on the ground rang out like pure metal .
15 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
16 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
17 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
18 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
19 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
20 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
21 As soon as her feet touched the XXXXX she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .	ground		abyss|apple-tree|girl|ground|hairs|love|skin|sword|torch|wife

1 `` Would she relent if Mrs. Allardyce were to call for you ? ''
2 Now , I have been cautiously sounding Aunt about Mrs. Allardyce , and I have discovered that she disapproves of her .
3 So I said : `` It would be useless .
4 I will ask Aunt if I may go , but I feel almost sure that she will not consent . ''
5 This evening , when Aunt was in an unusually genial mood , I plucked up heart of grace and asked her .
6 `` Marguer_ite , '' she said impressively , `` you know that I do not attend church here . ''
7 `` But , Aunt , '' I persisted , quakingly , `` could n't I go alone ?
8 It is not very far -- and I will be very careful . ''
9 Aunt merely gave me a look that said about forty distinct and separate things , and I was turning away in despair when Mrs. Saxby -- bless her heart -- said : `` I really think it would be no harm to let the child go . ''
10 As Aunt attaches great importance to Mrs. Saxby 's opinion , she looked at me relentingly and said : `` Well , I will think it over and let you know in the morning , Marguer_ite . ''
11 Now , everything depends on the sort of humour Aunt is in in the morning .
12 July Twentieth .
13 This morning was perfect , and after breakfast Aunt said , condescendingly : `` I think you may attend church if you wish , Marguer_ite .
14 Remember that I expect you to conduct yourself with becoming prudence and modesty . ''
15 I flew upstairs and pulled my prettiest dress out of my trunk .
16 It is a delicate , shimmering grey stuff with pearly tints about it .
17 Every time I get anything new , Aunt Martha and I have a battle royal over it .
18 I verily believe that Aunt would like me to dress in the fashions in vogue in her youth .
19 There is always a certain flavour of old-fashionedness about my gowns and hats .
20 Connie used to say that it was delicious and gave me a piquant uniqueness -- a certain unlikeness to other people that possessed a positive charm .
21 That is only XXXXX 's view of it , however .	Connie		Connie|charm|everything|gowns|harm|look|morning|prudence|things|uniqueness

1 He had hardly lost sight of his gaunt grey friend when he heard growls and snarls in the thicket close to him , and before he had time to think he found himself surrounded by the most dreadful-looking creatures .
2 On one side he saw the glittering eye of a cruel tiger , on the other the gleaming teeth of a great she-wolf ; here a huge bear growled fiercely , and there a horrible snake coiled itself in the grass at his feet .
3 But Iwanich did not forget the old man 's advice , and quickly put his hand into the bag and took out as many bread-crumbs as he could hold in his hand at a time .
4 He threw them to the beasts , but soon the bag grew lighter and lighter , and the Prince began to feel a little frightened .
5 And now the last crumb was gone , and the hungry beasts thronged round him , greedy for fresh prey .
6 Then he seized the hare and threw it to them .
7 No sooner did the little creature feel itself on the ground than it lay back its ears and flew through the wood like an arrow from a bow , closely pursued by the wild beasts , and the Prince was left alone .
8 He looked at his ring , and when he saw that it sparkled as brightly as ever he went straight on through the forest .
9 He had n't gone very far when he saw a most extraordinary looking man coming towards him .
10 He was not more than three feet high , his legs were quite crooked , and all his body was covered with prickles like a hedgehog .
11 Two lions walked with him , fastened to his side by the two ends of his long beard .
12 He stopped the Prince and asked him in a harsh voice : ` Are you the man who has just fed my body-guard ? '
13 Iwanich was so startled that he could hardly reply , but the little man continued : ' I am most grateful to you for your kindness ; what can I give you as a reward ? '
14 ` All I ask , ' replied Iwanich , ` is , that I should be allowed to go through this wood in safety . '
15 ` Most certainly , ' answered the little man ; ` and for greater security I will give you one of my lions as a protector .
16 But when you leave this wood and come near a palace which does not belong to my domain , let the lion go , in order that he may not fall into the hands of an enemy and be killed . '
17 With these words he loosened the lion from his beard and bade the beast guard the youth carefully .
18 With this new protector Iwanich wandered on through the forest , and though he came upon a great many more wolves , hyenas , leopards , and other wild beasts , they always kept at a respectful distance when they saw what sort of an escort the Prince had with him .
19 Iwanich hurried through the wood as quickly as his legs would carry him , but , nevertheless , hour after hour went by and not a trace of a green field or a human habitation met his eyes .
20 At length , towards evening , the mass of trees grew more transparent , and through the interlaced branches a wide plain was visible .
21 At the exit of the wood the XXXXX stood still , and the Prince took leave of him , having first thanked him warmly for his kind protection .	lion		beasts|bow|creature|friend|hand|legs|lion|man|side|wood

1 He wished the maiden would let him have it in his hand , but he did not quite like to ask her to do so , and after a while she put it back into the box .
2 A few days after they were again speaking of the magic ring , and the youth said , ' I do not think it possible that the ring can have all the power you say it has . '
3 Then the maiden opened the box and took the ring out , and it glittered as she held it like the clearest sunbeam .
4 She put it on the middle finger of her left hand , and told the youth to take a knife and try as hard as he could to cut her with it , for he would not be able to hurt her .
5 He was unwilling at first , but the maiden insisted .
6 Then he tried , at first only in play , and then seriously , to strike her with the knife , but an invisible wall of iron seemed to be between them , and the maiden stood before him laughing and unhurt .
7 Then she put the ring on her third finger , and in an instant she had vanished from his eyes .
8 Presently she was beside him again laughing , and holding the ring between her fingers .
9 ` Do let me try , ' said the youth , ` whether I can do these wonderful things . '
10 The maiden , suspecting no treachery , gave him the magic ring .
11 The youth pretended to have forgotten what to do , and asked what finger he must put the ring on so that no sharp weapon could hurt him ? '
12 ` Oh , the middle finger of your left hand , ' the maiden answered , laughing .
13 She took the knife and tried to strike the youth , and he even tried to cut himself with it , but found it impossible .
14 Then he asked the maiden to show him how to split stones and rocks with the help of the ring .
15 So she led him into a courtyard where stood a great boulder-stone .
16 ` Now , ' she said , ` put the ring upon the thumb of your left hand , and you will see how strong that hand has become .
17 The youth did so , and found to his astonishment that with a single blow of his fist the stone flew into a thousand pieces .
18 Then the youth bethought him that he who does not use his luck when he has it is a fool , and that this was a chance which once lost might never return .
19 So while they stood laughing at the shattered stone he placed the ring , as if in play , upon the third finger of his left hand .
20 ` Now , ' said the maiden , ` you are invisible to me until you take the ring off again . '
21 But the youth had no mind to do that ; on the contrary , he went farther off , then put the ring on the little finger of his left XXXXX , and soared into the air like a bird .	hand		box|eyes|fingers|fist|hand|maiden|rocks|stones|things|thumb

1 So the youth went with her , and soon they reached a beautiful garden , where stood a splendid house , which glittered in the moonlight as if it was all built out of gold and silver .
2 When the youth entered he found many splendid chambers , each one finer than the last .
3 Hundreds of tapers burnt upon golden candlesticks , and shed a light like the brightest day .
4 At length they reached a chamber where a table was spread with the most costly dishes .
5 At the table were placed two chairs , one of silver , the other of gold .
6 The maiden seated herself upon the golden chair , and offered the silver one to her companion .
7 They were served by maidens dressed in white , whose feet made no sound as they moved about , and not a word was spoken during the meal .
8 Afterwards the youth and the Witch-maiden conversed pleasantly together , until a woman , dressed in red , came in to remind them that it was bedtime .
9 The youth was now shown into another room , containing a silken bed with down cushions , where he slept delightfully , yet he seemed to hear a voice near his bed which repeated to him , ` Remember to give no blood ! '
10 The next morning the maiden asked him whether he would not like to stay with her always in this beautiful place , and as he did not answer immediately , she continued : ` You see how I always remain young and beautiful , and I am under no one 's orders , but can do just what I like , so that I have never thought of marrying before .
11 But from the moment I saw you I took a fancy to you , so if you agree , we might be married and might live together like princes , because I have great riches . '
12 The youth could not but be tempted with the beautiful maiden 's offer , but he remembered how the birds had called her the witch , and their warning always sounded in his ears .

14 Give me a few days to consider before we come to an understanding . '
15 ` Why not ? '
16 answered the maiden .

2 The animals went in two by two , The elephant and the battery mul ' , and they all got into the Ark For to get out of the rain !
3 Then I heard an old grizzled , long-haired Central Asian chief , who had come down with the Amir , asking questions of a native officer .
4 `` Now , '' said he , `` in what manner was this wonderful thing done ? ''
5 And the officer answered , `` An order was given , and they obeyed . ''
6 `` But are the beasts as wise as the men ? ''
7 said the chief .
8 `` They obey , as the men do .
9 Mule , horse , elephant , or bullock , he obeys his driver , and the driver his sergeant , and the sergeant his lieutenant , and the lieutenant his captain , and the captain his major , and the major his colonel , and the colonel his brigadier commanding three regiments , and the brigadier the general , who obeys the Viceroy , who is the servant of the Empress .
10 Thus it is done . ''
11 `` Would it were so in Afghanistan ! ''
12 said the chief , `` for there we obey only our own wills . ''
13 `` And for that reason , '' said the native officer , twirling his mustache , `` your Amir whom you do not obey must come here and take orders from our Viceroy . ''

1 How shall we travel about together without being odious the one to the other ? '
2 ` Do n't worry about that , ' replied the girl , ` for I 've thought it all over , and have settled on a plan which will make us each able to bear with the other !
3 See , I have had a fur cloak made for each of us , and if we put them on I shall not feel the heat so much nor you the cold . '
4 So they put on the fur cloaks , and set out cheerfully on their way , and for the first time in their lives quite happy in each other 's company .
5 For a long time the Fire-son and the Snow-daughter wandered through the world , and when at the beginning of winter they came to a big wood they determined to stay there till spring .
6 The Fire-son built himself a hut where he always kept up a huge fire , while his sister with very few clothes on stayed outside night and day .
7 Now it happened one day that the King of the land held a hunt in this wood , and saw the Snow-daughter wandering about in the open air .
8 He wondered very much who the beautiful girl clad in such garments could be , and he stopped and spoke to her .
9 He soon learnt that she could not stand heat , and that her brother could not endure cold .
10 The King was so charmed by the Snow-daughter , that he asked her to be his wife .
11 The girl consented , and the wedding was held with much state .
12 The King had a huge house of ice made for his wife underground , so that even in summer it did not melt .
13 But for his brother-in-law he had a house built with huge ovens all round it , that were kept heated all day and night .
14 The Fire-son was delighted , but the perpetual heat in which he lived made his body so hot , that it was dangerous to go too close to him .
15 One day the King gave a great feast , and asked his brother-in-law among the other guests .
16 The Fire-son did not appear till everyone had assembled , and when he did , everyone fled outside to the open air , so intense was the heat he gave forth .
17 Then the King was very angry and said , ` If I had known what a lot of trouble you would have been , I would never have taken you into my house . '
18 Then the Fire-son replied with a laugh , ` Do n't be angry , dear brother !
19 I love heat and my sister loves cold -- come here and let me embrace you , and then I 'll go home at once . '
20 And before the King had time to reply , the Fire-son seized him in a tight embrace .
21 The King screamed aloud in agony , and when his wife , the Snow-daughter , who had taken refuge from her XXXXX in the next room , hurried to him , the King lay dead on the ground burnt to a cinder .	brother		brother|brother-in-law|girl|heat|home|house|lives|state|wood|world

1 On the following morning he led the mare and foal to the fields as usual , but bound a cord round them both which he kept in his hand .
2 But after a few hours , by the magic arts of the old witch , he was overpowered by sleep , and the mare and foal escaped and did as they had been told to do .
3 The Prince did not awake till late in the evening ; and when he did , he found , to his horror , that the horses had disappeared .
4 Filled with despair , he cursed the moment when he had entered the service of the cruel witch , and already he saw his head sticking up on the sharp spike beside the others .
5 Then he suddenly remembered the fish 's scale , which , with the eagle 's feather and the fox 's hairs , he always carried about with him .
6 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the river he threw it in .
7 In a minute the grateful fish swam towards the bank on which Iwanich was standing , and said : ` What do you command , my friend and benefactor ? '
8 The Prince replied : ' I had to look after a mare and foal , and they have run away from me and have hidden themselves in the river ; if you wish to save my life drive them back to the land . '
9 ` Wait a moment , ' answered the fish , ` and I and my friends will soon drive them out of the water . '
10 With these words the creature disappeared into the depths of the stream .
11 Almost immediately a rushing hissing sound was heard in the waters , the waves dashed against the banks , the foam was tossed into the air , and the two horses leapt suddenly on to the dry land , trembling and shaking with fear .
12 Iwanich sprang at once on to the mare 's back , seized the foal by its bridle , and hastened home in the highest spirits .
13 When the witch saw the Prince bringing the horses home she could hardly conceal her wrath , and as soon as she had placed Iwanich 's supper before him she stole away again to the stables .
14 The Prince followed her , and heard her scolding the beasts harshly for not having hidden themselves better .
15 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .
16 If they did not do as she told them she would beat them till they bled .
17 The next morning , after Iwanich had led his horses to the fields , he fell once more into a magic sleep .
18 The horses at once ran away and hid themselves in the clouds , which hung down from the mountains in soft billowy masses .
19 When the Prince awoke and found that both the mare and the foal had disappeared , he bethought him at once of the eagle , and taking the feather out of his pocket he blew it into the air .

2 ` How ugly she is ! '
3 said all the lady chafers -- and yet Thumbelina was really very pretty .
4 The cockchafer who had stolen her knew this very well ; but when he heard all the ladies saying she was ugly , he began to think so too , and would not keep her ; she might go wherever she liked .
5 So he flew down from the tree with her and put her on a daisy .
6 There she sat and wept , because she was so ugly that the cockchafer would have nothing to do with her ; and yet she was the most beautiful creature imaginable , so soft and delicate , like the loveliest rose-leaf .
7 The whole summer poor little Thumbelina lived alone in the great wood .
8 She plaited a bed for herself of blades of grass , and hung it up under a clover-leaf , so that she was protected from the rain ; she gathered honey from the flowers for food , and drank the dew on the leaves every morning .
9 Thus the summer and autumn passed , but then came winter -- the long , cold winter .
10 All the birds who had sung so sweetly about her had flown away ; the trees shed their leaves , the flowers died ; the great clover-leaf under which she had lived curled up , and nothing remained of it but the withered stalk .
11 She was terribly cold , for her clothes were ragged , and she herself was so small and thin .
12 Poor little Thumbelina !
13 she would surely be frozen to death .
14 It began to snow , and every snow-flake that fell on her was to her as a whole shovelful thrown on one of us , for we are so big , and she was only an inch high .
15 She wrapt herself round in a dead leaf , but it was torn in the middle and gave her no warmth ; she was trembling with cold .
16 Just outside the wood where she was now living lay a great corn-field .
17 But the corn had been gone a long time ; only the dry , bare stubble was left standing in the frozen ground .
18 This made a forest for her to wander about in .
19 All at once she came across the door of a field-mouse , who had a little hole under a corn-stalk .
20 There the mouse lived warm and snug , with a store-room full of corn , a splendid kitchen and dining-room .

1 What shall I do with them ? '
2 Then the Hunter said that to the old donkey , which was the witch , three beatings and one meal ; to the younger one , which was the servant , one beating and three meals ; and to the youngest one , which was the maiden , no beating and three meals ; for he could not find it in his heart to let the maiden be beaten .
3 Then he went back into the castle , and he found there all that he wanted .
4 After a couple of days the miller came and said that he must tell him that the old donkey which was to have three beatings and only one meal had died .
5 ` The two others , ' he added , ` are certainly not dead , and get their three meals every day , but they are so sad that they can not last much longer . '
6 Then the Hunter took pity on them , laid aside his anger , and told the miller to drive them back again .
7 And when they came he gave them some of the good cabbage to eat , so that they became human again .

13 THE LITTLE GREEN FROG -LRB- 8 -RRB- -LRB- 8 -RRB- Cabinet des Fees .
14 In a part of the world whose name I forget lived once upon a time two kings , called Peridor and Diamantino .
15 They were cousins as well as neighbours , and both were under the protection of the fairies ; though it is only fair to say that the fairies did not love them half so well as their wives did .
16 Now it often happens that as princes can generally manage to get their own way it is harder for them to be good than it is for common people .
17 So it was with Peridor and Diamantino ; but of the two , the fairies declared that Diamantino was much the worst ; indeed , he behaved so badly to his wife Aglantino , that the fairies would not allow him to live any longer ; and he died , leaving behind him a little daughter .
18 As she was an only child , of course this little girl was the heiress of the kingdom , but , being still only a baby , her mother , the widow of Diamantino , was proclaimed regent .
19 The Queen-dowager was wise and good , and tried her best to make her people happy .
20 The only thing she had to vex her was the absence of her daughter ; for the fairies , for reasons of their own , determined to bring up the little Princess Serpentine among themselves .

3 Mr. Ralston got out a small pencil and a note book , and by dint of comparing the names attached to the gifts on the table they managed to divide theirs up pretty evenly among the little Josephs .
4 When all was done Mrs. Ralston said , `` Now , I 'm going to spread that tablecloth carelessly over the table .
5 We will be going before daylight , probably , and in the hurry of getting off I hope that Mr. and Mrs. Joseph will not notice the difference till we 're gone . ''
6 It fell out as Mrs. Ralston had planned .
7 The dawn broke fine and clear over a vast white world .
8 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph were early astir ; breakfast for the storm-stayed travellers was cooked and eaten by lamplight ; then the horse and sleigh were brought to the door and Mr. Ralston carried out his empty basket .
9 `` I expect the trail will be heavy , '' he said , `` but I guess we 'd get to Lindsay in time for dinner , anyway .
10 Much obliged for your kindness , Mr. Joseph .
11 When you and Mrs. Joseph come to town we shall hope to have a chance to return it .
12 Good-bye and a merry Christmas to you all . ''
13 When Mrs. Joseph went back to the kitchen her eyes fell on the heaped-up table in the corner .
14 `` Why-y ! ''
15 she said , and snatched off the cover .
16 One look she gave , and then this funny little mother began to cry ; but they were happy tears .
17 Mr. Joseph came too , and looked and whistled .
18 There really seemed to be everything on that table that the hearts of children could desire -- three pairs of skates , a fur cap and collar , a dainty workbasket , half a dozen gleaming new books , a writing desk , a roll of stuff that looked like a new dress , a pair of fur-topped kid gloves just Mollie 's size , and a china cup and saucer .
19 All these were to be seen at the first glance ; and in one corner of the table was a big box filled with candies and nuts and raisins , and in the other a doll with curling golden hair and brown eyes , dressed in `` real '' clothes and with all her wardrobe in a trunk beside her .
20 Pinned to her dress was a leaf from Mr. Ralston 's notebook with Maggie 's name written on it .
21 `` Well , this is XXXXX with a vengeance , '' said Mr. Joseph .	Christmas		Christmas|Mr.|burglary|contents|dawn|door|everything|kindness|mother|table

3 She always was an odd one .
4 I mind her when she was a girl -- a saucy , black-eyed baggage she was !

5 ALL THE BEASTS TOGETHER Children of the Camp are we , Serving each in his degree ; Children of the yoke and goad , Pack and harness , pad and load .
6 See our line across the plain , Like a heel-rope bent again , Reaching , writhing , rolling far , Sweeping all away to war !
7 While the men that walk beside , Dusty , silent , heavy-eyed , Can not tell why we or they March and suffer day by day .
8 I JIMMY SKUNK IS PUZZLED Old Mother West Wind had just come down from the Purple Hills and turned loose her children , the Merry Little Breezes , from the big bag in which she had been carrying them .
9 They were very lively and very merry as they danced and raced across the Green Meadows in all directions , for it was good to be back there once more .
10 Old Mother West Wind almost sighed as she watched them for a few minutes .
11 She felt that she would like to join them .
12 Always the springtime made her feel this way , -- young , mad , carefree , and happy .
13 But she had work to do .
14 She had to turn the windmill to pump water for Farmer Brown 's cows , and this was only one of many mills standing idle as they waited for her .
15 So she puffed her cheeks out and started about her business .
16 Jimmy Skunk sat at the top of the hill that overlooks the Green Meadows and watched her out of sight .
17 Then he started to amble down the Lone Little Path to look for some beetles .
18 He was ambling along in his lazy way , for you know he never hurries , when he heard some one puffing and blowing behind him .
19 Of course he turned to see who it was , and he was greatly surprised when he discovered Old Mr. Toad .

21 He was quite short of breath , but he was hopping along in the most determined XXXXX as if he were in a great hurry to get somewhere .	way		BEASTS|Mr.|Sir|course|directions|hurry|puffing|sight|springtime|way

1 groaned Little Klaus up in the shed , when he saw the good food disappearing .

3 asked the farmer , catching sight of Little Klaus .
4 ` Why are you lying there ?
5 Come with me into the house . '
6 Then Little Klaus told him how he had lost his way , and begged to be allowed to spend the night there .
7 ` Yes , certainly , ' said the farmer ; ` but we must first have something to eat ! '
8 The wife received them both very kindly , spread a long table , and gave them a large plate of porridge .
9 The farmer was hungry , and ate with a good appetite ; but Little Klaus could not help thinking of the delicious dishes of fish and roast meats and cakes which he knew were in the oven .
10 Under the table at his feet he had laid the sack with the horse-skin in it , for , as we know , he was going to the town to sell it .
11 The porridge did not taste good to him , so he trod upon his sack , and the dry skin in the sack squeaked loudly .
12 ` Hush ! '
13 said Little Klaus to his sack , at the same time treading on it again so that it squeaked even louder than before .
14 ` Hallo !
15 what have you got in your sack ? '
16 asked the farmer .
17 ` Oh , it is a wizard ! '
18 said Little Klaus .
19 ` He says we should not eat porridge , for he has conjured the whole oven full of roast meats and fish and cakes . '

1 Immediately the charm worked , and she became a donkey , and ran out to join the old witch , and the dish with the salad in it fell to the ground .
2 In the meantime , the messenger was sitting with the lovely maiden , and as no one came with the salad , and she wanted very much to taste it , she said , ' I do n't know where the salad is . '
3 Then thought the Hunter , ` The cabbage must have already begun to work . '
4 And he said , ' I will go to the kitchen and fetch it myself . '
5 When he came there he saw the two donkeys running about in the courtyard , but the salad was lying on the ground .
6 ` That 's all right , ' said he ; ` two have had their share ! '
7 And lifting the remaining leaves up , he laid them on the dish and brought them to the maiden . '
8 I am bringing you the delicious food my own self , ' he said , ` so that you need not wait any longer . '
9 Then she ate , and , as the others had done , she at once lost her human form , and ran as a donkey into the yard .
10 When the Hunter had washed his face , so that the changed ones might know him , he went into the yard , saying , ` Now you shall receive a reward for your faithlessness . '
11 He tied them all three with a rope , and drove them away till he came to a mill .
12 He knocked at the window , and the miller put his head out and asked what he wanted . '
13 I have three tiresome animals , ' he answered , ` which I do n't want to keep any longer .
14 If you will take them , give them food and stabling , and do as I tell you with them , I will pay you as much as you want . '
15 The miller replied , ` Why not ?
16 What shall I do with them ? '
17 Then the Hunter said that to the old donkey , which was the witch , three beatings and one meal ; to the younger one , which was the servant , one beating and three meals ; and to the youngest one , which was the maiden , no beating and three meals ; for he could not find it in his heart to let the maiden be beaten .
18 Then he went back into the castle , and he found there all that he wanted .
19 After a couple of days the miller came and said that he must tell him that the old donkey which was to have three beatings and only one meal had died .
20 ` The two others , ' he added , ` are certainly not dead , and get their three meals every day , but they are so sad that they can not last much longer . '
21 Then the Hunter took pity on them , laid aside his anger , and told the XXXXX to drive them back again .	miller		beating|castle|courtyard|donkey|ground|meantime|miller|one|rope|servant

10 XIX OLD MR. TOAD GETS HIS STOMACH FULL Pray do not tip your nose in scorn At things which others eat , For things to you not good at all To others are most sweet .
11 There are ants , for instance .
12 You would n't want to eat them even if you were dreadfully hungry .
13 But Old Mr. Toad and Buster Bear think there is nothing much nicer .
14 Now Buster Bear had found Old Mr. Toad catching ants , one at a time , as he kept watch beside their home , and it had pleased Buster to find some one else who liked ants .
15 Right away he invited Old Mr. Toad to dine with him .
16 But poor Old Mr. Toad was frightened almost to death when he heard the deep , grumbly-rumbly voice of Buster Bear , for he had been so busy watching the ants that he had n't seen Buster coming .
17 He fell right over on his back , which was n't at all dignified , and made Buster Bear laugh .
18 That frightened Mr. Toad more than ever .
19 You see he did n't have the least doubt in the world that Buster Bear meant to eat him , and when Buster invited him to dinner , he was sure that that was just a joke on Buster 's part .
20 But there was no way to escape , and after a little Old Mr. Toad thought it best to be polite , because , you know , it always pays to be polite .

1 Now , as the girl was sitting at her distaff , weeping bitterly because she could not spin , she heard the sound of hundreds of little feet , and from every hole and corner in the hut mice came pattering along the floor , squeaking and saying : ` Little girl , why are your eyes so red ?
2 If you want help , then give us some bread . '
3 And the girl gave them the bread that her grandmother had given her .
4 Then the mice told her that the witch had a cat , and the cat was very fond of ham ; if she would give the cat her ham , it would show her the way out of the wood , and in the meantime they would spin the yarn for her .
5 So the girl set out to look for the cat , and , as she was hunting about , she met her brother , in great trouble because he could not carry water from the well in a sieve , as it came pouring out as fast as he put it in .
6 And as she was trying to comfort him they heard a rustling of wings , and a flight of wrens alighted on the ground beside them .
7 And the wrens said : ` Give us some crumbs , then you need not grieve .
8 For you 'll find that water will stay in the sieve . '
9 Then the twins crumbled their bread on the ground , and the wrens pecked it , and chirruped and chirped .
10 And when they had eaten the last crumb they told the boy to fill up the holes of the sieve with clay , and then to draw water from the well .
11 So he did what they said , and carried the sieve full of water into the hut without spilling a drop .
12 When they entered the hut the cat was curled up on the floor .
13 So they stroked her , and fed her with ham , and said to her : ` Pussy , grey pussy , tell us how we are to get away from the witch ? '
14 Then the cat thanked them for the ham , and gave them a pocket-handkerchief and a comb , and told them that when the witch pursued them , as she certainly would , all they had to do was to throw the handkerchief on the ground and run as fast as they could .
15 As soon as the handkerchief touched the ground a deep , broad river would spring up , which would hinder the witch 's progress .
16 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
17 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
18 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
19 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
20 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
21 Then the XXXXX left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .	witch		boy|floor|girl|grandmother|help|hut|water|way|well|witch

1 For a moment she repented -- she would stay -- she could not go .
2 Then over the harbour flashed out the lights of Dalveigh .
3 The life behind them glittered , allured , beckoned .
4 Nay , she must go on -- she had made her choice .
5 There was no turning back now .
6 * * * * * Nora Shelley went away with the Camerons , and Dalveigh was deserted .
7 Winter came down on Racicot Harbour , and the colony of fisher folk at its head gave themselves over to the idleness of the season -- a time for lounging and gossipping and long hours of lazy contentment smoking in the neighbours ' chimney corners , when tales were told of the sea and the fishing .
8 The Harbour laid itself out to be sociable in winter .
9 There was no time for that in summer .
10 People had to work eighteen hours out of the twenty-four then .
11 In the winter there was spare time to laugh and quarrel , woo and wed and -- were a man so minded -- dream , as did Rob Fletcher in his loneliness .
12 In a Racicot winter much was made of small things .
13 The arrival of Nora Shelley 's weekly letter to her father and mother was an event in the village .
14 The post-mistress in the Cove store spread the news that it had come , and that night the Shelley kitchen would be crowded .
15 Isobel Shelley , Nora 's younger sister , read the letter aloud by virtue of having gone to school long enough to be able to pronounce the words and tell where the places named were situated .
16 The Camerons had spent the autumn in New York and had then gone south for the winter .
17 Nora wrote freely of her new life .
18 In the beginning she admitted great homesickness , but after the first few letters she made no further mention of that .
19 She wrote little of herself , but she described fully the places she had visited , the people she had met , the wonderful things she had seen .
20 She sent affectionate messages to all her old friends and asked after all her old interests .
21 But the letters came to be more and more like those of a stranger and one apart from the Racicot XXXXX , and the father and mother felt it .	life		Nay|autumn|event|homesickness|letters|life|mention|mother|summer|things

11 When Mowgli left the wolf 's cave after the fight with the Pack at the Council Rock , he went down to the plowed lands where the villagers lived , but he would not stop there because it was too near to the jungle , and he knew that he had made at least one bad enemy at the Council .
12 So he hurried on , keeping to the rough road that ran down the valley , and followed it at a steady jog-trot for nearly twenty miles , till he came to a country that he did not know .
13 The valley opened out into a great plain dotted over with rocks and cut up by ravines .
14 At one end stood a little village , and at the other the thick jungle came down in a sweep to the grazing-grounds , and stopped there as though it had been cut off with a hoe .
15 All over the plain , cattle and buffaloes were grazing , and when the little boys in charge of the herds saw Mowgli they shouted and ran away , and the yellow pariah dogs that hang about every Indian village barked .
16 Mowgli walked on , for he was feeling hungry , and when he came to the village gate he saw the big thorn-bush that was drawn up before the gate at twilight , pushed to one side .

7 Do cats eat bats ? '
8 and sometimes , ` Do bats eat cats ? '
9 for , you see , as she could n't answer either question , it did n't much matter which way she put it .

12 thump !
13 down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves , and the fall was over .
14 Alice was not a bit hurt , and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment : she looked up , but it was all dark overhead ; before her was another long passage , and the White Rabbit was still in sight , hurrying down it .
15 There was not a moment to be lost : away went Alice like the wind , and was just in time to hear it say , as it turned a corner , ` Oh my ears and whiskers , how late it 's getting ! '
16 She was close behind it when she turned the corner , but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen : she found herself in a long , low hall , which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof .
17 There were doors all round the hall , but they were all locked ; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other , trying every door , she walked sadly down the middle , wondering how she was ever to get out again .
18 Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table , all made of solid glass ; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key , and Alice 's first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall ; but , alas !
19 either the locks were too large , or the key was too small , but at any rate it would not open any of them .
20 However , on the second time round , she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before , and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high : she tried the little golden key in the lock , and to her great delight it fitted !

6 said the Hatter .
7 ` You might just as well say that `` I see what I eat '' is the same thing as `` I eat what I see '' ! '
8 ` You might just as well say , ' added the March Hare , ` that `` I like what I get '' is the same thing as `` I get what I like '' ! '
9 ` You might just as well say , ' added the Dormouse , who seemed to be talking in his sleep , ` that `` I breathe when I sleep '' is the same thing as `` I sleep when I breathe '' ! '
10 ` It IS the same thing with you , ' said the Hatter , and here the conversation dropped , and the party sat silent for a minute , while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks , which was n't much .
