2 And now the last crumb was gone , and the hungry beasts thronged round him , greedy for fresh prey .
3 Then he seized the hare and threw it to them .
4 No sooner did the little creature feel itself on the ground than it lay back its ears and flew through the wood like an arrow from a bow , closely pursued by the wild beasts , and the Prince was left alone .
5 He looked at his ring , and when he saw that it sparkled as brightly as ever he went straight on through the forest .
6 He had n't gone very far when he saw a most extraordinary looking man coming towards him .
7 He was not more than three feet high , his legs were quite crooked , and all his body was covered with prickles like a hedgehog .
8 Two lions walked with him , fastened to his side by the two ends of his long beard .
9 He stopped the Prince and asked him in a harsh voice : ` Are you the man who has just fed my body-guard ? '
10 Iwanich was so startled that he could hardly reply , but the little man continued : ' I am most grateful to you for your kindness ; what can I give you as a reward ? '
11 ` All I ask , ' replied Iwanich , ` is , that I should be allowed to go through this wood in safety . '
12 ` Most certainly , ' answered the little man ; ` and for greater security I will give you one of my lions as a protector .
13 But when you leave this wood and come near a palace which does not belong to my domain , let the lion go , in order that he may not fall into the hands of an enemy and be killed . '
14 With these words he loosened the lion from his beard and bade the beast guard the youth carefully .
15 With this new protector Iwanich wandered on through the forest , and though he came upon a great many more wolves , hyenas , leopards , and other wild beasts , they always kept at a respectful distance when they saw what sort of an escort the Prince had with him .
16 Iwanich hurried through the wood as quickly as his legs would carry him , but , nevertheless , hour after hour went by and not a trace of a green field or a human habitation met his eyes .
17 At length , towards evening , the mass of trees grew more transparent , and through the interlaced branches a wide plain was visible .
18 At the exit of the wood the lion stood still , and the Prince took leave of him , having first thanked him warmly for his kind protection .
19 It had become quite dark , and Iwanich was forced to wait for daylight before continuing his journey .
20 He made himself a bed of grass and leaves , lit a fire of dry branches , and slept soundly till the next morning .
21 Then he got up and walked towards a beautiful white XXXXX which he saw gleaming in the distance .	palace		arrow|beard|beasts|ears|feet|ground|hare|legs|palace|security

1 said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt .
2 ` I 've seen a good many little girls in my time , but never ONE with such a neck as that !
3 No , no !
4 You 're a serpent ; and there 's no use denying it .
5 I suppose you 'll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg ! ' '
6 I HAVE tasted eggs , certainly , ' said Alice , who was a very truthful child ; ` but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do , you know . ' '
7 I do n't believe it , ' said the Pigeon ; ` but if they do , why then they 're a kind of serpent , that 's all I can say . '
8 This was such a new idea to Alice , that she was quite silent for a minute or two , which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding , ` You 're looking for eggs , I know THAT well enough ; and what does it matter to me whether you 're a little girl or a serpent ? '
9 ` It matters a good deal to ME , ' said Alice hastily ; ` but I 'm not looking for eggs , as it happens ; and if I was , I should n't want YOURS : I do n't like them raw . '
10 ` Well , be off , then ! '
11 said the Pigeon in a sulky tone , as it settled down again into its nest .
12 Alice crouched down among the trees as well as she could , for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches , and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it .
13 After a while she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands , and she set to work very carefully , nibbling first at one and then at the other , and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter , until she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height .
14 It was so long since she had been anything near the right size , that it felt quite strange at first ; but she got used to it in a few minutes , and began talking to herself , as usual .
15 ` Come , there 's half my plan done now !
16 How puzzling all these changes are !
17 I 'm never sure what I 'm going to be , from one minute to another !
18 However , I 've got back to my right size : the next thing is , to get into that beautiful garden -- how IS that to be done , I wonder ? '
19 As she said this , she came suddenly upon an open place , with a little house in it about four feet high .
20 ` Whoever lives there , ' thought Alice , ` it 'll never do to come upon them THIS size : why , I should frighten them out of their wits ! '
21 So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again , and did not venture to go near the XXXXX till she had brought herself down to nine inches high .	house		contempt|feet|girls|house|nest|opportunity|plan|trees|use|wits

1 Soon afterwards he saw something big coming towards him , darkening the sky .
2 It kept coming nearer and growing bigger , and what was this after all but the Eagle ?
3 When she arrived the old man scolded her , and asked what had kept her so long behind . '
4 I could n't help it , ' she said ; ' I had more than twenty times further to come than any bird that has come here to-day . '
5 ` Where have you come from , then ? '
6 said the old man .
7 ` From the Blue Mountains , ' said she .
8 ` Indeed ! '
9 said the old man ; and what are they doing there ? '
10 ` They are making ready this very day , ' said the Eagle , ` for the marriage of the daughter of the King of the Blue Mountains .
11 For three years now she has refused to marry anyone whatsoever , until she should give up all hope of the coming of the man who released her from the spell .
12 Now she can wait no longer , for three years is the time that she agreed with her father to remain without marrying . '
13 The Irishman knew that it was for himself she had been waiting so long , but he was unable to make any better of it , for he had no hope of reaching the Blue Mountains all his life .
14 The old man noticed how sad he grew , and asked the Eagle what she would take for carrying this man on her back to the Blue Mountains . '
15 I must have threescore cattle killed , ' said she , ` and cut up into quarters , and every time I look over my shoulder he must throw one of them into my mouth . '
16 As soon as the Irishman and the old man heard her demand they went out hunting , and before evening they had killed three-score cattle .
17 They made quarters of them , as the Eagle told them , and then the old man asked her to lie down , till they would get it all heaped up on her back .
18 First of all , though , they had to get a ladder of fourteen steps , to enable them to get on to the Eagle 's back , and there they piled up the meat as well as they could .
19 Then the old man told the Irishman to mount , and to remember to throw a quarter of beef to her every time she looked round .
20 He went up , and the old man gave the Eagle the word to be off , which she instantly obeyed ; and every time she turned her head the Irishman threw a quarter of beef into her mouth .

1 After walking for some time he came to a forest , into which he went a little way and stopped .
2 Then he heard sweet music from a harp , and went in the direction of the sound until he came to a clearing , and there he saw three women , one of whom sat on a golden chair , and was beautifully and grandly dressed ; she held a harp in her hands , and was very sorrowful .
3 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
4 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
5 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
6 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
7 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
8 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
9 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the ship ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .
10 There he made a great feast , and celebrated his marriage with this woman ; and after that things are quiet for a time .
11 Hermod and Hadvor took but little notice of the Queen and her daughter , but , on the other hand , Hadvor and the Queen 's maid , whose name was Olof , were very friendly , and Olof came often to visit Hadvor in her castle .
12 Before long the King went out to war , and no sooner was he away than the Queen came to talk with Hermod , and said that she wanted him to marry her daughter .
13 Hermod told her straight and plain that he would not do so , at which the Queen grew terribly angry , and said that in that case neither should he have Hadvor , for she would now lay this spell on him , that he should go to a desert island and there be a lion by day and a man by night .
14 He should also think always of Hadvor , which would cause him all the more sorrow , and from this spell he should never be freed until Hadvor burned the lion 's skin , and that would not happen very soon .
15 As soon as the Queen had finished her speech Hermod replied that he also laid a spell on her , and that was , that as soon as he was freed from her enchantments she should become a rat and her daughter a mouse , and fight with each other in the hall until he killed them with his sword .
16 After this Hermod disappeared , and no one knew what had become of him ; the Queen caused search to be made for him , but he could nowhere be found .
17 One time , when Olof was in the castle beside Hadvor , she asked the Princess if she knew where Hermod had gone to .
18 At this Hadvor became very sad , and said that she did not . '
19 I shall tell you then , ' said Olof , ` for I know all about it .
20 Hermod has disappeared through the wicked devices of the Queen , for she is a witch , and so is her daughter , though they have put on these beautiful forms .
21 Because Hermod would not fall in with the Queen 's plans , and marry her daughter , she has laid a spell on him , to go on an island and be a lion by day and a man by night , and never be freed from this until you burn the XXXXX 's skin .	lion		chair|country|king|lion|music|proposal|sword|time|way|woman

3 On the Sunday referred to there was to be no evening service in the church owing to Mr. Sinclair 's absence .
4 They therefore appointed the missionary meeting for that night , and made arrangements to hold it in the church itself , as the classroom was too small for the expected audience .
5 Then the thunderbolt descended on the W.F.M.A. of Putney from a clear sky .
6 The elders of the church rose up to a man and declared that no woman should occupy the pulpit of the Putney church .
7 It was in direct contravention to the teachings of St. Paul .
8 To make matters worse , Mr. Sinclair declared himself on the elders ' side .
9 He said that he could not conscientiously give his consent to a woman occupying his pulpit , even when that woman was Mrs. Cotterell and her subject foreign missions .
10 The members of the Auxiliary were aghast .
11 They called a meeting extraordinary in the classroom and , discarding all forms and ceremonies in their wrath , talked their indignation out .
12 Out of doors the world basked in June sunshine and preened itself in blossom .
13 The birds sang and chirped in the lichened maples that cupped the little church in , and peace was over all the Putney valley .
14 Inside the classroom disgusted women buzzed like angry bees .
15 `` What on earth are we to do ? ''
16 sighed the secretary plaintively .
17 Mary Kilburn was always plaintive .

1 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the river he threw it in .
2 In a minute the grateful fish swam towards the bank on which Iwanich was standing , and said : ` What do you command , my friend and benefactor ? '
3 The Prince replied : ' I had to look after a mare and foal , and they have run away from me and have hidden themselves in the river ; if you wish to save my life drive them back to the land . '
4 ` Wait a moment , ' answered the fish , ` and I and my friends will soon drive them out of the water . '
5 With these words the creature disappeared into the depths of the stream .
6 Almost immediately a rushing hissing sound was heard in the waters , the waves dashed against the banks , the foam was tossed into the air , and the two horses leapt suddenly on to the dry land , trembling and shaking with fear .
7 Iwanich sprang at once on to the mare 's back , seized the foal by its bridle , and hastened home in the highest spirits .
8 When the witch saw the Prince bringing the horses home she could hardly conceal her wrath , and as soon as she had placed Iwanich 's supper before him she stole away again to the stables .
9 The Prince followed her , and heard her scolding the beasts harshly for not having hidden themselves better .
10 She bade them wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep and then to hide themselves in the clouds , and to remain there till she called .
11 If they did not do as she told them she would beat them till they bled .
12 The next morning , after Iwanich had led his horses to the fields , he fell once more into a magic sleep .
13 The horses at once ran away and hid themselves in the clouds , which hung down from the mountains in soft billowy masses .
14 When the Prince awoke and found that both the mare and the foal had disappeared , he bethought him at once of the eagle , and taking the feather out of his pocket he blew it into the air .
15 In a moment the bird swooped down beside him and asked : ` What do you wish me to do ? '
16 ` My mare and foal , ' replied the Prince , ` have run away from me , and have hidden themselves in the clouds ; if you wish to save my life , restore both animals to me . '
17 ` Wait a minute , ' answered the eagle ; ` with the help of my friends I will soon drive them back to you . '
18 With these words the bird flew up into the air and disappeared among the clouds .
19 Almost directly Iwanich saw his two horses being driven towards him by a host of eagles of all sizes .
20 He caught the mare and foal , and having thanked the eagle he drove them cheerfully home again .

5 THE LITTLE GREEN FROG -LRB- 8 -RRB- -LRB- 8 -RRB- Cabinet des Fees .
6 In a part of the world whose name I forget lived once upon a time two kings , called Peridor and Diamantino .
7 They were cousins as well as neighbours , and both were under the protection of the fairies ; though it is only fair to say that the fairies did not love them half so well as their wives did .
8 Now it often happens that as princes can generally manage to get their own way it is harder for them to be good than it is for common people .
9 So it was with Peridor and Diamantino ; but of the two , the fairies declared that Diamantino was much the worst ; indeed , he behaved so badly to his wife Aglantino , that the fairies would not allow him to live any longer ; and he died , leaving behind him a little daughter .
10 As she was an only child , of course this little girl was the heiress of the kingdom , but , being still only a baby , her mother , the widow of Diamantino , was proclaimed regent .
11 The Queen-dowager was wise and good , and tried her best to make her people happy .
12 The only thing she had to vex her was the absence of her daughter ; for the fairies , for reasons of their own , determined to bring up the little Princess Serpentine among themselves .
13 As to the other King , he was really fond of his wife , Queen Constance , but he often grieved her by his thoughtless ways , and in order to punish him for his carelessness , the fairies caused her to die quite suddenly .
14 When she was gone the King felt how much he had loved her , and his grief was so great -LRB- though he never neglected his duties -RRB- that his subjects called him Peridor the Sorrowful .
15 It seems hardly possible that any man should live like Peridor for fifteen years plunged in such depth of grief , and most likely he would have died too if it had not been for the fairies .
16 The one comfort the poor King had was his son , Prince Saphir , who was only three years old at the time of his mother 's death , and great care was given to his education .
17 By the time he was fifteen Saphir had learnt everything that a prince should know , and he was , besides , charming and agreeable .
18 It was about this time that the fairies suddenly took fright lest his love for his father should interfere with the plans they had made for the young prince .
19 So , to prevent this , they placed in a pretty little room of which Saphir was very fond a little mirror in a black frame , such as were often brought from Venice .
20 The Prince did not notice for some days that there was anything new in the room , but at last he perceived it , and went up to look at it more closely .

1 The whole court went out to see the wonder , and their astonishment was great at the sight which met their eyes .
2 A splendid palace reared itself on the hill just outside the walls of the city , made of the most exquisite flowers that ever grew in mortal garden .
3 The roof was all of crimson roses , the windows of lilies , the walls of white carnations , the floors of glowing auriculas and violets , the doors of gorgeous tulips and narcissi with sunflowers for knockers , and all round hyacinths and other sweet-smelling flowers bloomed in masses , so that the air was perfumed far and near and enchanted all who were present .
4 This splendid palace had been built by the grateful queen bee , who had summoned all the other bees in the kingdom to help her .
5 The King 's amazement knew no bounds , and the Princess 's eyes beamed with delight as she turned them from the wonderful building on the delighted Ferko .
6 But the two brothers had grown quite green with envy , and only declared the more that Ferko was nothing but a wicked magician .
7 The King , although he had been surprised and astonished at the way his commands had been carried out , was very vexed that the stranger should escape with his life , and turning to the two brothers he said , ` He has certainly accomplished the first task , with the aid no doubt of his diabolical magic ; but what shall we give him to do now ?
8 Let us make it as difficult as possible , and if he fails he shall die . '
9 Then the eldest brother replied , ` The corn has all been cut , but it has not yet been put into barns ; let the knave collect all the grain in the kingdom into one big heap before to-morrow night , and if as much as a stalk of corn is left let him be put to death .
10 The Princess grew white with terror when she heard these words ; but Ferko felt much more cheerful than he had done the first time , and wandered out into the meadows again , wondering how he was to get out of the difficulty .
11 But he could think of no way of escape .
12 The sun sank to rest and night came on , when a little mouse started out of the grass at Ferko 's feet , and said to him , ` I 'm delighted to see you , my kind benefactor ; but why are you looking so sad ?
13 Can I be of any help to you , and thus repay your great kindness to me ? '
14 Then Ferko recognised the mouse whose front paws he had healed , and replied , ` Alas I how can you help me in a matter that is beyond any human power !
15 Before to-morrow night all the grain in the kingdom has to be gathered into one big heap , and if as much as a stalk of corn is wanting I must pay for it with my life . '
16 ` Is that all ? '
17 answered the mouse ; ` that need n't distress you much .
18 Just trust in me , and before the sun sets again you shall hear that your task is done . '
19 And with these words the little creature scampered away into the fields .
20 Ferko , who never doubted that the mouse would be as good as its word , lay down comforted on the soft grass and slept soundly till next morning .

1 He was going uphill , but though Little Toomai watched the stars in the rifts of the trees , he could not tell in what direction .
2 Then Kala Nag reached the crest of the ascent and stopped for a minute , and Little Toomai could see the tops of the trees lying all speckled and furry under the moonlight for miles and miles , and the blue-white mist over the river in the hollow .
3 Toomai leaned forward and looked , and he felt that the forest was awake below him -- awake and alive and crowded .
4 A big brown fruit-eating bat brushed past his ear ; a porcupine 's quills rattled in the thicket ; and in the darkness between the tree stems he heard a hog-bear digging hard in the moist warm earth , and snuffing as it digged .
5 Then the branches closed over his head again , and Kala Nag began to go down into the valley -- not quietly this time , but as a runaway gun goes down a steep bank -- in one rush .
6 The huge limbs moved as steadily as pistons , eight feet to each stride , and the wrinkled skin of the elbow points rustled .
7 The undergrowth on either side of him ripped with a noise like torn canvas , and the saplings that he heaved away right and left with his shoulders sprang back again and banged him on the flank , and great trails of creepers , all matted together , hung from his tusks as he threw his head from side to side and plowed out his pathway .
8 Then Little Toomai laid himself down close to the great neck lest a swinging bough should sweep him to the ground , and he wished that he were back in the lines again .
9 The grass began to get squashy , and Kala Nag 's feet sucked and squelched as he put them down , and the night mist at the bottom of the valley chilled Little Toomai .
10 There was a splash and a trample , and the rush of running water , and Kala Nag strode through the bed of a river , feeling his way at each step .
11 Above the noise of the water , as it swirled round the elephant 's legs , Little Toomai could hear more splashing and some trumpeting both upstream and down -- great grunts and angry snortings , and all the mist about him seemed to be full of rolling , wavy shadows .
12 `` Ai ! ''
13 he said , half aloud , his teeth chattering .
14 `` The elephant-folk are out tonight .
15 It is the dance , then ! ''
16 Kala Nag swashed out of the water , blew his trunk clear , and began another climb .
17 But this time he was not alone , and he had not to make his path .
18 That was made already , six feet wide , in front of him , where the bent jungle-grass was trying to recover itself and stand up .
19 Many elephants must have gone that way only a few minutes before .
20 Little Toomai looked back , and behind him a great wild tusker with his little pig 's eyes glowing like hot coals was just lifting himself out of the misty river .
21 Then the XXXXX closed up again , and they went on and up , with trumpetings and crashings , and the sound of breaking branches on every side of them .	trees		Ai|coals|crest|gun|path|pistons|shadows|splash|stride|trees

1 Prizes ! '
2 Alice had no idea what to do , and in despair she put her hand in her pocket , and pulled out a box of comfits , -LRB- luckily the salt water had not got into it -RRB- , and handed them round as prizes .
3 There was exactly one a-piece all round .
4 ` But she must have a prize herself , you know , ' said the Mouse .
5 ` Of course , ' the Dodo replied very gravely .
6 ` What else have you got in your pocket ? '
7 he went on , turning to Alice .
8 ` Only a thimble , ' said Alice sadly .
9 ` Hand it over here , ' said the Dodo .
10 Then they all crowded round her once more , while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble , saying ` We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble ' ; and , when it had finished this short speech , they all cheered .
11 Alice thought the whole thing very absurd , but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh ; and , as she could not think of anything to say , she simply bowed , and took the thimble , looking as solemn as she could .
12 The next thing was to eat the comfits : this caused some noise and confusion , as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs , and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back .
13 However , it was over at last , and they sat down again in a ring , and begged the Mouse to tell them something more .
14 ` You promised to tell me your history , you know , ' said Alice , ` and why it is you hate -- C and D , ' she added in a whisper , half afraid that it would be offended again .
15 ` Mine is a long and a sad tale ! '
16 said the Mouse , turning to Alice , and sighing .
17 ` It IS a long tail , certainly , ' said Alice , looking down with wonder at the Mouse 's tail ; ` but why do you call it sad ? '

19 -- Come , I 'll take no denial ; We must have a trial : For really this morning I 've nothing to do . ''
20 Said the mouse to the cur , `` Such a trial , dear Sir , With no jury or judge , would be wasting our breath . ''

1 The youth looked at her more closely , and saw that her skin was smooth and fair , her blue eyes bright and sparkling , and her hair as golden as the sun .
2 He fell in love with her on the spot , and kneeling at her feet , he implored her to become his wife .
3 The lovely girl accepted his proposal gladly ; but at the same time she warned him that she could never come up to the world above till her mother , the old witch , was dead .
4 And she went on to tell him that the only way in which the old creature could be killed was with the sword that hung up in the castle ; but the sword was so heavy that no one could lift it .
5 Then the youth went into a room in the castle where everything was made of silver , and here he found another beautiful girl , the sister of his bride .
6 She was combing her silver hair , and every hair that fell on the ground rang out like pure metal .
7 The second girl handed him the sword , but though he tried with all his strength he could not lift it .
8 At last a third sister came to him and gave him a drop of something to drink , which she said would give him the needful strength .
9 He drank one drop , but still he could not lift the sword ; then he drank a second , and the sword began to move ; but only after he had drunk a third drop was he able to swing the sword over his head .
10 Then he hid himself in the castle and awaited the old witch 's arrival .
11 At last as it was beginning to grow dark she appeared .
12 She swooped down upon a big apple-tree , and after shaking some golden apples from it , she pounced down upon the earth .
13 As soon as her feet touched the ground she became transformed from a hawk into a woman .
14 This was the moment the youth was waiting for , and he swung his mighty sword in the air with all his strength and the witch 's head fell off , and her blood spurted up on the walls .
15 Without fear of any further danger , he packed up all the treasures of the castle into great chests , and gave his brothers a signal to pull them up out of the abyss .
16 First the treasures were attached to the rope and then the three lovely girls .
17 And now everything was up above and only he himself remained below .
18 But as he was a little suspicious of his brothers , he fastened a heavy stone on to the rope and let them pull it up .
19 At first they heaved with a will , but when the stone was half way up they let it drop suddenly , and it fell to the bottom broken into a hundred pieces .
20 ` So that 's what would have happened to my bones had I trusted myself to them , ' said the youth sadly ; and he began to cry bitterly , not because of the treasures , but because of the lovely girl with her swanlike neck and golden hair .
21 For a long XXXXX he wandered sadly all through the beautiful underworld , and one day he met a magician who asked him the cause of his tears .	time		brothers|castle|love|pieces|proposal|room|spot|time|treasures|way

1 If ye find that the Bullock can toss you , or the heavy-browed Sambhur can gore ; Ye need not stop work to inform us : we knew it ten seasons before .
2 Oppress not the cubs of the stranger , but hail them as Sister and Brother , For though they are little and fubsy , it may be the Bear is their mother .
3 `` There is none like to me ! ''
4 says the Cub in the pride of his earliest kill ; But the jungle is large and the Cub he is small .
5 Let him think and be still .
6 Maxims of Baloo All that is told here happened some time before Mowgli was turned out of the Seeonee Wolf Pack , or revenged himself on Shere Khan the tiger .
7 It was in the days when Baloo was teaching him the Law of the Jungle .
8 The big , serious , old brown bear was delighted to have so quick a pupil , for the young wolves will only learn as much of the Law of the Jungle as applies to their own pack and tribe , and run away as soon as they can repeat the Hunting Verse -- `` Feet that make no noise ; eyes that can see in the dark ; ears that can hear the winds in their lairs , and sharp white teeth , all these things are the marks of our brothers except Tabaqui the Jackal and the Hyaena whom we hate . ''
9 But Mowgli , as a man-cub , had to learn a great deal more than this .
10 Sometimes Bagheera the Black Panther would come lounging through the jungle to see how his pet was getting on , and would purr with his head against a tree while Mowgli recited the day 's lesson to Baloo .
11 The boy could climb almost as well as he could swim , and swim almost as well as he could run .
12 So Baloo , the Teacher of the Law , taught him the Wood and Water Laws : how to tell a rotten branch from a sound one ; how to speak politely to the wild bees when he came upon a hive of them fifty feet above ground ; what to say to Mang the Bat when he disturbed him in the branches at midday ; and how to warn the water-snakes in the pools before he splashed down among them .
13 None of the Jungle People like being disturbed , and all are very ready to fly at an intruder .
14 Then , too , Mowgli was taught the Strangers ' Hunting Call , which must be repeated aloud till it is answered , whenever one of the Jungle-People hunts outside his own grounds .
15 It means , translated , `` Give me leave to hunt here because I am hungry . ''
16 And the answer is , `` Hunt then for food , but not for pleasure . ''
17 All this will show you how much Mowgli had to learn by heart , and he grew very tired of saying the same thing over a hundred times .
18 But , as Baloo said to Bagheera , one day when Mowgli had been cuffed and run off in a temper , `` A man 's cub is a man 's cub , and he must learn all the Law of the Jungle . ''
19 `` But think how small he is , '' said the Black Panther , who would have spoiled Mowgli if he had had his own way .
20 `` How can his little head carry all thy long talk ? ''
21 `` Is there anything in the XXXXX too little to be killed ?	jungle		bear|boy|food|jungle|man|tiger|time|tribe|wolves|work

1 If you want help , then give us some bread . '
2 And the girl gave them the bread that her grandmother had given her .
3 Then the mice told her that the witch had a cat , and the cat was very fond of ham ; if she would give the cat her ham , it would show her the way out of the wood , and in the meantime they would spin the yarn for her .
4 So the girl set out to look for the cat , and , as she was hunting about , she met her brother , in great trouble because he could not carry water from the well in a sieve , as it came pouring out as fast as he put it in .
5 And as she was trying to comfort him they heard a rustling of wings , and a flight of wrens alighted on the ground beside them .
6 And the wrens said : ` Give us some crumbs , then you need not grieve .
7 For you 'll find that water will stay in the sieve . '
8 Then the twins crumbled their bread on the ground , and the wrens pecked it , and chirruped and chirped .
9 And when they had eaten the last crumb they told the boy to fill up the holes of the sieve with clay , and then to draw water from the well .
10 So he did what they said , and carried the sieve full of water into the hut without spilling a drop .
11 When they entered the hut the cat was curled up on the floor .
12 So they stroked her , and fed her with ham , and said to her : ` Pussy , grey pussy , tell us how we are to get away from the witch ? '
13 Then the cat thanked them for the ham , and gave them a pocket-handkerchief and a comb , and told them that when the witch pursued them , as she certainly would , all they had to do was to throw the handkerchief on the ground and run as fast as they could .
14 As soon as the handkerchief touched the ground a deep , broad river would spring up , which would hinder the witch 's progress .
15 If she managed to get across it , they must throw the comb behind them and run for their lives , for where the comb fell a dense forest would start up , which would delay the witch so long that they would be able to get safely away .
16 The cat had scarcely finished speaking when the witch returned to see if the children had fulfilled their tasks .
17 ` Well , you have done well enough for to-day , ' she grumbled ; ` but to-morrow you 'll have something more difficult to do , and if you do n't do it well , you pampered brats , straight into the oven you go . '
18 Half-dead with fright , and trembling in every limb , the poor children lay down to sleep on a heap of straw in the corner of the hut ; but they dared not close their eyes , and scarcely ventured to breathe .
19 In the morning the witch gave the girl two pieces of linen to weave before night , and the boy a pile of wood to cut into chips .
20 Then the witch left them to their tasks , and went out into the wood .
21 As soon as she had gone out of sight the children took the comb and the XXXXX , and , taking one another by the hand , they started and ran , and ran , and ran .	handkerchief		boy|comb|fright|handkerchief|lives|meantime|progress|sieve|something|twins

1 After searching as usual for nearly a whole day Prince Saphir began to feel overcome with thirst .
2 He was too tired to go any farther , when happily he discovered a little way off a bubbling fountain of the clearest water .
3 Being an experienced traveller , he drew from his pocket a little cup -LRB- without which no one should ever take a journey -RRB- , and was just about to dip it in the water , when a lovely little green frog , much prettier than frogs generally are , jumped into the cup .
4 Far from admiring its beauty , Saphir shook it impatiently off ; but it was no good , for quick as lightning the frog jumped back again .
5 Saphir , who was raging with thirst , was just about to shake it off anew , when the little creature fixed upon him the most beautiful eyes in the world , and said , ' I am a friend of the bird you are seeking , and when you have quenched your thirst listen to me . '
6 So the Prince drank his fill , and then , by the command of the Little Green Frog , he lay down on the grass to rest himself .
7 ` Now , ' she began , ` be sure you do exactly in every respect what I tell you .
8 First you must call together your attendants , and order them to remain in a little hamlet close by until you want them .
9 Then go , quite alone , down a road that you will find on your right hand , looking southwards .
10 This road is planted all the way with cedars of Lebanon ; and after going down it a long way you will come at last to a magnificent castle .
11 And now , ' she went on , ` attend carefully to what I am going to say .
12 Take this tiny grain of sand , and put it into the ground as close as you can to the gate of the castle .
13 It has the virtue both of opening the gate and also of sending to sleep all the inhabitants .
14 Then go at once to the stable , and pay no heed to anything except what I tell you .
15 Choose the handsomest of all the horses , leap quickly on its back , and come to me as fast as you can .
16 Farewell , Prince ; I wish you good luck , ' and with these words the Little Frog plunged into the water and disappeared .
17 The Prince , who felt more hopeful than he had done since he left home , did precisely as he had been ordered .
18 He left his attendants in the hamlet , found the road the frog had described to him , and followed it all alone , and at last he arrived at the gate of the castle , which was even more splendid than he had expected , for it was built of crystal , and all its ornaments were of massive gold .
19 However , he had no thoughts to spare for its beauty , and quickly buried his grain of sand in the earth .
20 In one instant the gates flew open , and all the dwellers inside fell sound asleep .

1 No sooner had Ferko entered the palace than all eyes were turned on the handsome youth , and the King 's daughter herself was lost in admiration , for she had never seen anyone so handsome in her life before .
2 His brothers noticed this , and envy and jealousy were added to their fear , so much so that they determined once more to destroy him .
3 They went to the King and told him that Ferko was a wicked magician , who had come to the palace with the intention of carrying off the Princess .
4 Then the King had Ferko brought before him , and said , ` You are accused of being a magician who wishes to rob me of my daughter , and I condemn you to death ; but if you can fulfil three tasks which I shall set you to do your life shall be spared , on condition you leave the country ; but if you can not perform what I demand you shall be hung on the nearest tree . '
5 And turning to the two wicked brothers he said , ` Suggest something for him to do ; no matter how difficult , he must succeed in it or die . '
6 They did not think long , but replied , ` Let him build your Majesty in one day a more beautiful palace than this , and if he fails in the attempt let him be hung . '
7 The King was pleased with this proposal , and commanded Ferko to set to work on the following day .
8 The two brothers were delighted , for they thought they had now got rid of Ferko for ever .
9 The poor youth himself was heart-broken , and cursed the hour he had crossed the boundary of the King 's domain .
10 As he was wandering disconsolately about the meadows round the palace , wondering how he could escape being put to death , a little bee flew past , and settling on his shoulder whispered in his ear , ` What is troubling you , my kind benefactor ?
11 Can I be of any help to you ?
12 I am the bee whose wing you healed , and would like to show my gratitude in some way . '
13 Ferko recognised the queen bee , and said , ` Alas !
14 how could you help me ?
15 for I have been set to do a task which no one in the whole world could do , let him be ever such a genius !
16 To-morrow I must build a palace more beautiful than the King 's , and it must be finished before evening . '
17 ` Is that all ? '
18 answered the bee , ` then you may comfort yourself ; for before the sun goes down to-morrow night a palace shall be built unlike any that King has dwelt in before .
19 Just stay here till I come again and tell you that it is finished . '
20 Having said this she flew merrily away , and Ferko , reassured by her words , lay down on the grass and slept peacefully till the next morning .

1 After due consideration she informed the Prince that the object of his search was not far distant , but that it was too difficult for him to attempt to enter the enchanted palace where she was , as the King his father had surrounded it with a thick cloud , and that the only expedient she could think of would be to gain possession of the Princess 's parrot .
2 This , she added , did not appear impossible , as it often flew about to some distance in the neighbourhood .
3 Having told the Prince all this , the Fairy went out in hopes of seeing the parrot , and soon returned with the bird in her hand .
4 She promptly shut it up in a cage , and , touching the Prince with her wand , transformed him into an exactly similar parrot ; after which , she instructed him how to reach the Princess .
5 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
6 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the parrot , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .
7 This soon reassured the Prince , and encouraged him to play his part well , and he began to say a thousand agreeable things which charmed the Princess .
8 Presently the King appeared , and the parrot noticed with joy how much he was disliked .
9 As soon as the King left , the Princess retired to her dressing-room , the parrot flew after her and overheard her lamentations at the continued persecutions of the King , who had pressed her to consent to their marriage .
10 The parrot said so many clever and tender things to comfort her that she began to doubt whether this could indeed be her own parrot .
11 When he saw her well-disposed towards him , he exclaimed : ` Madam , I have a most important secret to confide to you , and I beg you not to be alarmed by what I am about to say .
12 I am here on behalf of the Queen your mother , with the object of delivering your Highness ; to prove which , behold this portrait which she gave me herself . '
13 So saying he drew forth the miniature from under his wing .
14 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
15 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
16 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
17 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
18 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
19 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her parrot again .
20 As they rose through the air the Princess remarked a figure mounted on an eagle 's back flying in front of the chariot .

7 To talk of running away was one thing .

9 But Chester had a great deal of determination in his make-up when it was fairly roused , and his hard upbringing had made him older and shrewder than his years .
10 He lay awake late that night , thinking out ways and means , but could arrive at no satisfactory conclusion .

12 You might as well put in the time ` fore harvest that way as any other .
13 So hustle off -- and mind you behave yourself . ''
14 Chester heard the news gladly .
15 He had not yet devised any feasible plan for running away , and he always liked to work at the Stearns ' place .
16 To be sure , Mrs. Elwell received all the money he earned , but Mrs. Stearns was kind to him , and though he had to work hard and constantly , he was well fed and well treated by all .
17 The following fortnight was a comparatively happy one for the lad .
18 But he did not forget his purpose of shaking the dust of Upton from his feet as soon as possible , and he cudgelled his brains trying to find a way .

4 Frances kept count of the corners and the houses and found the manse .
5 Corona Sherwood herself came to the door .
6 Frances had been expecting an elderly personage with spectacles and grey crimps ; she was surprised to find that the minister 's sister was a girl of about her own age and possessed of a distinct worldly prettiness .
7 Corona was dark , with a different darkness from that of Frances , who had ivory outlines and blue-black hair , while Corona was dusky and piquant .
8 Her eyes brightened with delight when Frances told her errand .
9 `` How good of you and Miss Eleanor !
10 I am not strong enough to walk far yet -- or do anything useful , in fact , and Elliott so seldom has time to take me out . ''
11 `` Where shall we go ? ''
12 asked Frances when they started .

1 The King hoped , however , that time might not only soften her anger , but accustom her to his sight .
2 He took the precaution of surrounding the palace with a dense cloud , and then hastened to his Court , where his prolonged absence was causing much anxiety .
3 The Prince and all the courtiers were delighted to see their beloved King again , but they had to submit themselves to more frequent absences than ever on his part .
4 He made business a pretext for shutting himself up in his study , but it was really in order to spend the time with the Princess , who remained inflexible .
5 Not being able to imagine what could be the cause of so much obstinacy the King began to fear , lest , in spite of all his precautions , she might have heard of the charms of the Prince his son , whose goodness , youth and beauty , made him adored at Court .
6 This idea made him horribly uneasy , and he resolved to remove the cause of his fears by sending the Prince on his travels escorted by a magnificent retinue .
7 The Prince , after visiting several Courts , arrived at the one where the lost Princess was still deeply mourned .
8 The King and Queen received him most graciously , and some festivities were revived to do him honour .
9 One day when the Prince was visiting the Queen in her own apartments he was much struck by a most beautiful portrait .
10 He eagerly inquired whose it was , and the Queen , with many tears , told him it was all that was left her of her beloved daughter , who had suddenly been carried off , she knew neither where nor how .
11 The Prince was deeply moved , and vowed that he would search the world for the Princess , and take no rest till he had found and restored her to her mother 's arms .
12 The Queen assured him of her eternal gratitude , and promised , should he succeed , to give him her daughter in marriage , together with all the estates she herself owned .
13 The Prince , far more attracted by the thoughts of possessing the Princess than her promised dower , set forth in his quest after taking leave of the King and Queen , the latter giving him a miniature of her daughter which she was in the habit of wearing .
14 His first act was to seek the Fairy under whose protection he had been placed , and he implored her to give him all the assistance of her art and counsel in this important matter .
15 After listening attentively to the whole adventure , the Fairy asked for time to consult her books .
16 After due consideration she informed the Prince that the object of his search was not far distant , but that it was too difficult for him to attempt to enter the enchanted palace where she was , as the King his father had surrounded it with a thick cloud , and that the only expedient she could think of would be to gain possession of the Princess 's parrot .
17 This , she added , did not appear impossible , as it often flew about to some distance in the neighbourhood .
18 Having told the Prince all this , the Fairy went out in hopes of seeing the parrot , and soon returned with the bird in her hand .
19 She promptly shut it up in a cage , and , touching the Prince with her wand , transformed him into an exactly similar parrot ; after which , she instructed him how to reach the Princess .
20 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
21 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the XXXXX , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .	parrot		adventure|beauty|courtiers|distance|festivities|idea|matter|parrot|spite|travels

10 We 've broken out of our pickets , again and again , four hundred and fifty of us , just because a new recruit got to telling tales of whip snakes at home in Australia till we were scared to death of the loose ends of our head-ropes . ''

7 I shall never get to twenty at that rate !

9 He was taking off his old suit , and under it was a brand new one .
10 But such a time as he was having !
11 He was opening and shutting his big mouth , and drawing his hind legs under him , and rubbing them against his body .
12 Then Peter saw a strange thing .
13 He saw that Old Mr. Toad 's old suit had split in several places , and he was getting it off by sucking it into his mouth !
14 In a few minutes his hind legs were free of the old suit , and little by little it began to be pulled free from his body .
15 All the time Old Mr. Toad was working very hard to suck it at the corners of his big mouth .
16 He glared angrily at Peter , but he could n't say anything because his mouth was too full .
17 He looked so funny that Peter just threw himself on the ground and rolled over and over with laughter .
18 This made Old Mr. Toad glare more angrily than ever , but he could n't say anything , not a word .

3 Then she sent her away without doing her any harm .
4 Lagree was as much surprised as displeased at the happy result of this expedition , and Fairer-than-a Fairy waited anxiously for an opportunity of meeting Prince Rainbow and telling him her adventures .
5 She found , however , that he had already been told all about them by a Fairy who protected him , and to whom he was related .
6 The dread of fresh dangers to his beloved Princess made him devise some more convenient way of meeting than by the garden fountain , and Fairer-than-a-Fairy carried out his plan daily with entire success .
7 Every morning she placed a large basin full of water on her window-sill , and as soon as the sun 's rays fell on the water the Rainbow appeared as clearly as it had ever done in the fountain .
8 By this means they were able to meet without losing sight of the fire or of the two bottles in which the old Fairy kept her eye and her tooth at night , and for some time the lovers enjoyed every hour of sunshine together .
9 One day Prince Rainbow appeared in the depths of woe .
10 He had just heard that he was to be banished from this lovely spot , but he had no idea where he was to go .
11 The poor young couple were in despair , and only parted with the last ray of sunshine , and in hopes of meeting next morning .
12 Alas !

14 Fairer-than-a-Fairy eagerly ran to the window , but in her haste she upset the basin , and spilt all the water with which she had carefully filled it overnight .
15 No other water was at hand except that in the two bottles .
16 It was the only chance of seeing her lover before they were separated , and she did not hesitate to break the bottle and pour their contents into the basin , when the Rainbow appeared at once .
17 Their farewells were full of tenderness ; the Prince made the most ardent and sincere protestations , and promised to neglect nothing which might help to deliver his dear Fairer-than-a-Fairy from her captivity , and implored her to consent to their marriage as soon as they should both be free .

8 A young Prince was riding one day through a meadow that stretched for miles in front of him , when he came to a deep open ditch .

12 The Prince bent down and lifted her out of her living grave , asking her at the same time how she had managed to get there .

2 The King 's amazement knew no bounds , and the Princess 's eyes beamed with delight as she turned them from the wonderful building on the delighted Ferko .
3 But the two brothers had grown quite green with envy , and only declared the more that Ferko was nothing but a wicked magician .
4 The King , although he had been surprised and astonished at the way his commands had been carried out , was very vexed that the stranger should escape with his life , and turning to the two brothers he said , ` He has certainly accomplished the first task , with the aid no doubt of his diabolical magic ; but what shall we give him to do now ?
5 Let us make it as difficult as possible , and if he fails he shall die . '
6 Then the eldest brother replied , ` The corn has all been cut , but it has not yet been put into barns ; let the knave collect all the grain in the kingdom into one big heap before to-morrow night , and if as much as a stalk of corn is left let him be put to death .
7 The Princess grew white with terror when she heard these words ; but Ferko felt much more cheerful than he had done the first time , and wandered out into the meadows again , wondering how he was to get out of the difficulty .
8 But he could think of no way of escape .
9 The sun sank to rest and night came on , when a little mouse started out of the grass at Ferko 's feet , and said to him , ` I 'm delighted to see you , my kind benefactor ; but why are you looking so sad ?
10 Can I be of any help to you , and thus repay your great kindness to me ? '
11 Then Ferko recognised the mouse whose front paws he had healed , and replied , ` Alas I how can you help me in a matter that is beyond any human power !
12 Before to-morrow night all the grain in the kingdom has to be gathered into one big heap , and if as much as a stalk of corn is wanting I must pay for it with my life . '
13 ` Is that all ? '
14 answered the mouse ; ` that need n't distress you much .
15 Just trust in me , and before the sun sets again you shall hear that your task is done . '
16 And with these words the little creature scampered away into the fields .
17 Ferko , who never doubted that the mouse would be as good as its word , lay down comforted on the soft grass and slept soundly till next morning .
18 The day passed slowly , and with the evening came the little mouse and said , ` Now there is not a single stalk of corn left in any field ; they are all collected in one big heap on the hill out there . '
19 Then Ferko went joyfully to the King and told him that all he demanded had been done .
20 And the whole Court went out to see the wonder , and were no less astonished than they had been the first time .
21 For in a heap higher than the King 's palace lay all the XXXXX of the country , and not a single stalk of corn had been left behind in any of the fields .	grain		brother|brothers|creature|day|death|distress|envy|grain|nothing|paws

2 Then the old man told the Irishman to mount , and to remember to throw a quarter of beef to her every time she looked round .
3 He went up , and the old man gave the Eagle the word to be off , which she instantly obeyed ; and every time she turned her head the Irishman threw a quarter of beef into her mouth .
4 As they came near the borders of the kingdom of the Blue Mountains , however , the beef was done , and , when the Eagle looked over her shoulder , what was the Irishman at but throwing the stone between her tail and her neck !
5 At this she turned a complete somersault , and threw the Irishman off into the sea , where he fell into the bay that was right in front of the King 's Palace .
6 Fortunately the points of his toes just touched the bottom , and he managed to get ashore .
7 When he went up into the town all the streets were gleaming with light , and the wedding of the Princess was just about to begin .
8 He went into the first house he came to , and this happened to be the house of the King 's hen-wife .
9 He asked the old woman what was causing all the noise and light in the town .
10 ` The Princess , ' said she , ` is going to be married to-night against her will , for she has been expecting every day that the man who freed her from the spell would come . '
11 ` There is a guinea for you , ' said he ; ` go and bring her here . '
12 The old woman went , and soon returned along with the Princess .
13 She and the Irishman recognised each other , and were married , and had a great wedding that lasted for a year and a day .

1 It did n't seem possible that such a great paw could be so gentle .
2 `` Now , '' said Buster Bear in a voice which he tried to make sound pleasant , but which was grumbly-rumbly just the same , `` I know where there is a fine dinner waiting for us just a little way from here .
3 You follow me , and we 'll have it in no time . ''
4 So Buster Bear led the way , and Old Mr. Toad followed as fast as he could , because he did n't dare not to .
5 Presently Buster stopped beside a big decayed old log .
6 `` If you are ready , Mr. Toad , we will dine now , '' said he .
7 Old Mr. Toad did n't see anything to eat .
8 His heart sank again , and he shook all over .
9 `` I -- I 'm not hungry , '' said he in a very faint voice .
10 Buster Bear did n't seem to hear .
11 He hooked his great claws into the old log and gave a mighty pull .
12 Over rolled the log , and there were ants and ants and ants , hurrying this way and scurrying that way , more ants than Mr. Toad had seen in all his life before !
13 `` Help yourself , '' said Buster Bear politely .
14 Old Mr. Toad did n't wait to be told twice .

18 He forgot his manners .

5 Then she resumed her natural shape , and he found that the bird was no other than the Queen Constance , whom he had long believed to be dead .

9 Once upon a time there was a king who determined to take a long voyage .
10 He assembled his fleet and all the seamen , and set out .
11 They went straight on night and day , until they came to an island which was covered with large trees , and under every tree lay a lion .
12 As soon as the King had landed his men , the lions all rose up together and tried to devour them .
13 After a long battle they managed to overcome the wild beasts , but the greater number of the men were killed .
14 Those who remained alive now went on through the forest and found on the other side of it a beautiful garden , in which all the plants of the world flourished together .
15 There were also in the garden three springs : the first flowed with silver , the second with gold , and the third with pearls .
16 The men unbuckled their knapsacks and filled them with those precious things .

3 replied a weak voice . '

5 For three days I have not tasted food . '

9 At these words Martin 's joy knew no bounds , and he stroked her fondly , and she rubbed up against him and purred happily , while below Schurka bounded in the air , and barked joyfully .
10 Then Martin took the ring , and threw it from one hand into the other , and instantly the twelve youths appeared and asked what they were to do .
11 ` Fetch me first something to eat and drink , as quickly as possible ; and after that bring musicians hither , and let us have music all day long . '
12 Now when the people in the town and palace heard music coming from the tower they were filled with amazement , and came to the King with the news that witchcraft must be going on in Martin 's Tower , for , instead of dying of starvation , he was seemingly making merry to the sound of music , and to the clatter of plates , and glass , and knives and forks ; and the music was so enchantingly sweet that all the passers-by stood still to listen to it .
13 On this the King sent at once a messenger to the Starvation Tower , and he was so astonished with what he saw that he remained rooted to the spot .
14 Then the King sent his chief counsellors , and they too were transfixed with wonder .
15 At last the King came himself , and he likewise was spellbound by the beauty of the music .
16 Then Martin summoned the twelve youths , spoke to them , saying , ` Build up my castle again , and join it to the King 's Palace with a crystal bridge ; do not forget the trees with the golden and silver apples , and with the birds of Paradise in the branches ; and put back the church with the five cupolas , and let the bells ring out , summoning the people from the four corners of the kingdom .

1 Only the beautiful Princess rejoiced over Ferko 's success , and looked on him with friendly glances , which the youth returned .
2 The more the cruel King gazed on the wonder before him , the more angry he became , for he could not , in the face of his promise , put the stranger to death .
3 He turned once more to the two brothers and said , ` His diabolical magic has helped him again , but now what third task shall we set him to do ?
4 No matter how impossible it is , he must do it or die . '
5 The eldest answered quickly , ` Let him drive all the wolves of the kingdom on to this hill before to-morrow night .
6 If he does this he may go free ; if not he shall be hung as you have said . '
7 At these words the Princess burst into tears , and when the King saw this he ordered her to be shut up in a high tower and carefully guarded till the dangerous magician should either have left the kingdom or been hung on the nearest tree .
8 Ferko wandered out into the fields again , and sat down on the stump of a tree wondering what he should do next .
9 Suddenly a big wolf ran up to him , and standing still said , ` I 'm very glad to see you again , my kind benefactor .
10 What are you thinking about all alone by yourself ?
11 If I can help you in any way only say the word , for I would like to give you a proof of my gratitude . '
12 Ferko at once recognised the wolf whose broken leg he had healed , and told him what he had to do the following day if he wished to escape with his life .
13 ` But how in the world , ' he added , ` am I to collect all the wolves of the kingdom on to that hill over there ? '
14 ` If that 's all you want done , ' answered the wolf , ` you need n't worry yourself .
15 I 'll undertake the task , and you 'll hear from me again before sunset to-morrow .
16 Keep your spirits up . '
17 And with these words he trotted quickly away .
18 Then the youth rejoiced greatly , for now he felt that his life was safe ; but he grew very sad when he thought of the beautiful Princess , and that he would never see her again if he left the country .
19 He lay down once more on the grass and soon fell fast asleep .

5 He came to the King and said he had something to say to him .
6 ` What is that ? '
7 said the King .
8 Red said that he had just remembered the gold cloak , gold chess-board , and bright gold piece that the King had lost about a year before .

10 said the King .
11 Red , however , went on to say that , since Ring was such a mighty man that he could do everything , it had occurred to him to advise the King to ask him to search for these treasures , and come back with them before Christmas ; in return the King should promise him his daughter .
12 The King replied that he thought it altogether unbecoming to propose such a thing to Ring , seeing that he could not tell him where the things were ; but Red pretended not to hear the King 's excuses , and went on talking about it until the King gave in to him .

1 replied Old Mr. Toad indignantly .
2 `` If it was fastened at the other end , how could I run it out so far ? ''
3 `` But mine and all other tongues that I ever have seen are fastened way down in the throat , '' protested Peter .
4 `` Yours is fastened at the other end , way in the very front of your mouth .
5 I never heard of such a thing . ''
6 `` There are a great many things you have never heard of , Peter Rabbit , '' replied Old Mr. Toad drily .
7 `` Mine is the right way to have a tongue .
8 Because it is fastened way up in the front of my mouth that way , I can use the whole of it .
9 You see it goes out its full length .
10 Then , when I draw it in with a bug on the end of it , I just turn it over so that the end that was out goes way back in my throat and takes the bug with it to just the right place to swallow . ''
11 Peter thought this over for a few minutes before he ventured another question .
12 `` I begin to understand , '' said he , `` but how do you hold on to the bug with your tongue ? ''
13 `` My tongue is sticky , of course , Mr. Stupid , '' replied Old Mr. Toad , looking very much disgusted .
14 `` Just let me touch a bug with it , and he 's mine every time . ''
15 Peter thought this over .
16 Then he felt of his own tongue .
17 `` Mine is n't sticky , '' said he very innocently .
18 Old Mr. Toad laughed right out .
19 `` Perhaps if it was , you could n't ask so many questions , '' said he .
20 `` Now watch me catch that fly . ''
21 His funny little XXXXX darted out , and the fly was gone .	tongue		Yours|course|fly|front|mouth|questions|throat|time|tongue|tongues

1 It was great carelessness of him , she said , to leave no one to watch the ship with her .
2 Sigurd was greatly surprised to hear his Queen scold him so much , for she had never said an angry word to him before ; but he thought it was quite excusable in this case , and tried to quiet the child along with her , but it was no use .
3 Then he went and wakened the sailors , and bade them hoist the sails , for a breeze had sprung up and was blowing straight towards the harbour .
4 They soon reached the land which Sigurd was to rule over , and found all the people sorrowful for the old King 's death , but they became glad when they got Sigurd back to the Court , and made him King over them .
5 The King 's son , however , hardly ever stopped crying from the time he had been taken from his mother on the deck of the ship , although he had always been such a good child before , so that at last the King had to get a nurse for him -- one of the maids of the Court .
6 As soon as the child got into her charge he stopped crying , and behaved well as before .
7 After the sea-voyage it seemed to the King that the Queen had altered very much in many ways , and not for the better .
8 He thought her much more haughty and stubborn and difficult to deal with than she used to be .
9 Before long others began to notice this as well as the King .
10 In the Court there were two young fellows , one of eighteen years old , the other of nineteen , who were very fond of playing chess , and often sat long inside playing at it .
11 Their room was next the Queen 's , and often during the day they heard the Queen talking .
12 One day they paid more attention than usual when they heard her talk , and put their ears close to a crack in the wall between the rooms , and heard the Queen say quite plainly , ` When I yawn a little , then I am a nice little maiden ; when I yawn half-way , then I am half a troll ; and when I yawn fully , then I am a troll altogether . '
13 As she said this she yawned tremendously , and in a moment had put on the appearance of a fearfully ugly troll .
14 Then there came up through the floor of the room a three-headed Giant with a trough full of meat , who saluted her as his sister and set down the trough before her .
15 She began to eat out of it , and never stopped till she had finished it .
16 The young fellows saw all this going on , but did not hear the two of them say anything to each other .
17 They were astonished though at how greedily the Queen devoured the meat , and how much she ate of it , and were no longer surprised that she took so little when she sat at table with the King .
18 As soon as she had finished it the Giant disappeared with the trough by the same way as he had come , and the Queen returned to her human shape .
19 Now we must go back to the King 's son after he had been put in charge of the nurse .
20 One evening , after she had lit a candle and was holding the child , several planks sprang up in the floor of the room , and out at the opening came a beautiful woman dressed in white , with an iron belt round her waist , to which was fastened an iron chain that went down into the ground .

1 I will sing you the praise of the bottle-tailed Rikki , with eyeballs of red !
2 -LRB- Here Rikki-tikki interrupted , and the rest of the song is lost . -RRB-
3 Toomai of the Elephants I will remember what I was , I am sick of rope and chain -- I will remember my old strength and all my forest affairs .
4 I will not sell my back to man for a bundle of sugar-cane : I will go out to my own kind , and the wood-folk in their lairs .
5 I will go out until the day , until the morning break -- Out to the wind 's untainted kiss , the water 's clean caress ; I will forget my ankle-ring and snap my picket stake .
6 I will revisit my lost loves , and playmates masterless !
7 Kala Nag , which means Black Snake , had served the Indian Government in every way that an elephant could serve it for forty-seven years , and as he was fully twenty years old when he was caught , that makes him nearly seventy -- a ripe age for an elephant .
8 He remembered pushing , with a big leather pad on his forehead , at a gun stuck in deep mud , and that was before the Afghan War of 1842 , and he had not then come to his full strength .
9 His mother Radha Pyari , -- Radha the darling , -- who had been caught in the same drive with Kala Nag , told him , before his little milk tusks had dropped out , that elephants who were afraid always got hurt .
10 Kala Nag knew that that advice was good , for the first time that he saw a shell burst he backed , screaming , into a stand of piled rifles , and the bayonets pricked him in all his softest places .
11 So , before he was twenty-five , he gave up being afraid , and so he was the best-loved and the best-looked-after elephant in the service of the Government of India .
12 He had carried tents , twelve hundred pounds ' weight of tents , on the march in Upper India .
13 He had been hoisted into a ship at the end of a steam crane and taken for days across the water , and made to carry a mortar on his back in a strange and rocky country very far from India , and had seen the Emperor Theodore lying dead in Magdala , and had come back again in the steamer entitled , so the soldiers said , to the Abyssinian War medal .
14 He had seen his fellow elephants die of cold and epilepsy and starvation and sunstroke up at a place called Ali Musjid , ten years later ; and afterward he had been sent down thousands of miles south to haul and pile big balks of teak in the timberyards at Moulmein .
15 There he had half killed an insubordinate young elephant who was shirking his fair share of work .
16 After that he was taken off timber-hauling , and employed , with a few score other elephants who were trained to the business , in helping to catch wild elephants among the Garo hills .
17 Elephants are very strictly preserved by the Indian Government .
18 There is one whole department which does nothing else but hunt them , and catch them , and break them in , and send them up and down the country as they are needed for work .
19 Kala Nag stood ten fair feet at the shoulders , and his tusks had been cut off short at five feet , and bound round the ends , to prevent them splitting , with bands of copper ; but he could do more with those stumps than any untrained elephant could do with the real sharpened ones .
20 When , after weeks and weeks of cautious driving of scattered elephants across the hills , the forty or fifty wild monsters were driven into the last stockade , and the big drop gate , made of tree trunks lashed together , jarred down behind them , Kala Nag , at the word of command , would go into that flaring , trumpeting pandemonium -LRB- generally at night , when the flicker of the torches made it difficult to judge distances -RRB- , and , picking out the biggest and wildest tusker of the mob , would hammer him and hustle him into quiet while the men on the backs of the other elephants roped and tied the smaller ones .
21 There was nothing in the way of fighting that Kala Nag , the old wise Black XXXXX , did not know , for he had stood up more than once in his time to the charge of the wounded tiger , and , curling up his soft trunk to be out of harm 's way , had knocked the springing brute sideways in mid-air with a quick sickle cut of his head , that he had invented all by himself ; had knocked him over , and kneeled upon him with his huge knees till the life went out with a gasp and a howl , and there was only a fluffy striped thing on the ground for Kala Nag to pull by the tail . 1 The train hands were invited in to share it .
2 The minister carved the chicken with the brakeman 's jack-knife and the khaki boy cut up the tongue and the mince pies , while the sealskin lady mixed the raspberry vinegar with its due proportion of water .
3 Bits of paper served as plates .
4 The train furnished a couple of glasses , a tin pint cup was discovered and given to the children , Aunt Cyrilla and Lucy Rose and the sealskin lady drank , turn about , from the latter 's graduated medicine glass , the shop girl and the little mother shared one of the empty bottles , and the khaki boy , the minister , and the train men drank out of the other bottle .
5 Everybody declared they had never enjoyed a meal more in their lives .
6 Certainly it was a merry one , and Aunt Cyrilla 's cooking was never more appreciated ; indeed , the bones of the chicken and the pot of preserves were all that was left .
7 They could not eat the preserves because they had no spoons , so Aunt Cyrilla gave them to the little mother .
8 When all was over , a hearty vote of thanks was passed to Aunt Cyrilla and her basket .
9 The sealskin lady wanted to know how she made her pound cake , and the khaki boy asked for her receipt for jelly cookies .
10 And when two hours later the conductor came in and said the snowploughs had got along and they 'd soon be starting , they all wondered if it could really be less than twenty-four hours since they met .
11 `` I feel as if I 'd been campaigning with you all my life , '' said the khaki boy .
12 At the next station they all parted .
13 The little mother and the children had to take the next train back home .
14 The minister stayed there , and the khaki boy and the sealskin lady changed trains .
15 The sealskin lady shook Aunt Cyrilla 's hand .
16 She no longer looked discontented or cross .

1 Fairer-than-a-Fairy eagerly ran to the window , but in her haste she upset the basin , and spilt all the water with which she had carefully filled it overnight .
2 No other water was at hand except that in the two bottles .
3 It was the only chance of seeing her lover before they were separated , and she did not hesitate to break the bottle and pour their contents into the basin , when the Rainbow appeared at once .
4 Their farewells were full of tenderness ; the Prince made the most ardent and sincere protestations , and promised to neglect nothing which might help to deliver his dear Fairer-than-a-Fairy from her captivity , and implored her to consent to their marriage as soon as they should both be free .
5 The Princess , on her side , vowed to have no other husband , and declared herself willing to brave death itself in order to rejoin him .
6 They were not allowed much time for their adieus ; the Rainbow vanished , and the Princess , resolved to run all risks , started off at once , taking nothing with her but her dog , her cat , a sprig of myrtle , and the stone which the wife of Locrinos gave her .
7 When Lagree became aware of her prisoner 's flight she was furious , and set off at full speed in pursuit .
8 She overtook her just as the poor girl , overcome by fatigue , had lain down to rest in a cave which the stone had formed itself into to shelter her .
9 The little dog who was watching her mistress promptly flew at Lagree and bit her so severely that she stumbled against a corner of the cave and broke off her only tooth .
10 Before she had recovered from the pain and rage this caused her , the Princess had time to escape , and was some way on her road .
11 Fear gave her strength for some time , but at last she could go no further , and sank down to rest .
12 As she did so , the sprig of myrtle she carried touched the ground , and immediately a green and shady bower sprang up round her , in which she hoped to sleep in peace .
13 But Lagree had not given up her pursuit , and arrived just as Fairer-than-a-Fairy had fallen fast asleep .
14 This time she made sure of catching her victim , but the cat spied her out , and , springing from one of the boughs of the arbour she flew at Lagree 's face and tore out her only eye , thus delivering the Princess for ever from her persecutor .
15 One might have thought that all would now be well , but no sooner had Lagree been put to fight than our heroine was overwhelmed with hunger and thirst .
16 She felt as though she should certainly expire , and it was with some difficulty that she dragged herself as far as a pretty little green and white house , which stood at no great distance .
17 Here she was received by a beautiful lady dressed in green and white to match the house , which apparently belonged to her , and of which she seemed the only inhabitant .
18 She greeted the fainting Princess most kindly , gave her an excellent supper , and after a long night 's rest in a delightful bed told her that after many troubles she should finally attain her desire .
19 As the green and white lady took leave of the Princess she gave her a nut , desiring her only to open it in the most urgent need .
20 After a long and tiring journey Fairer-than-a-Fairy was once more received in a house , and by a lady exactly like the one she had quitted .

1 ` My son , ' answered the old woman , ' I am a very poor woman , and soon after midnight I set out for the neighbouring town in order to sell my eggs in the market on the following morning ; but I lost my way in the dark , and fell into this deep ditch , where I might have remained for ever but for your kindness .
