4 ` Over there , at the edge of the forest in the little hut you see in the distance , ' replied the old woman .
5 The Prince lifted her on to his horse , and soon they reached the hut , where the old woman got down , and turning to the Prince said , ` Just wait a moment , and I will give you something . '
6 And she disappeared into her hut , but returned very soon and said , ` You are a mighty Prince , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded .
7 Would you like to have the most beautiful woman in the world for your wife ? '
8 ` Most certainly I would , ' replied the Prince .
9 So the old woman continued , ` The most beautiful woman in the whole world is the daughter of the Queen of the Flowers , who has been captured by a dragon .
10 If you wish to marry her , you must first set her free , and this I will help you to do .
11 I will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the King of the Eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the King of the Foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the King of the Fishes by your side .
12 These will help you if you are in any difficulty .
13 Now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . '
14 She handed him the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed her up .
15 Then it dawned on the Prince that he had been speaking to a good fairy , and putting the little bell carefully in his pocket , he rode home and told his father that he meant to set the daughter of the Flower Queen free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid .
16 So the next morning the Prince mounted his fine horse and left his home .
17 He had roamed round the world for a whole year , and his horse had died of exhaustion , while he himself had suffered much from want and misery , but still he had come on no trace of her he was in search of .

1 The poor boy still clung on as if glued to the glass by his blood-stained hands .

1 So he endured the pangs of starvation all that day , but when night came his endurance gave way , and he let his right eye be put out and his right leg broken for a second piece of bread .
2 After his brothers had thus successfully maimed and disfigured him for life , they left him groaning on the ground and continued their journey without him .
3 Poor Ferko ate up the scrap of bread they had left him and wept bitterly , but no one heard him or came to his help .
4 Night came on , and the poor blind youth had no eyes to close , and could only crawl along the ground , not knowing in the least where he was going .
5 But when the sun was once more high in the heavens , Ferko felt the blazing heat scorch him , and sought for some cool shady place to rest his aching limbs .
6 He climbed to the top of a hill and lay down in the grass , and as he thought under the shadow of a big tree .
7 But it was no tree he leant against , but a gallows on which two ravens were seated .
8 The one was saying to the other as the weary youth lay down , ` Is there anything the least wonderful or remarkable about this neighbourhood ? ' '
9 I should just think there was , ' replied the other ; ` many things that do n't exist anywhere else in the world .
10 There is a lake down there below us , and anyone who bathes in it , though he were at death 's door , becomes sound and well on the spot , and those who wash their eyes with the dew on this hill become as sharp-sighted as the eagle , even if they have been blind from their youth . '
11 ` Well , ' answered the first raven , ` my eyes are in no want of this healing bath , for , Heaven be praised , they are as good as ever they were ; but my wing has been very feeble and weak ever since it was shot by an arrow many years ago , so let us fly at once to the lake that I may be restored to health and strength again . '
12 And so they flew away .
13 Their words rejoiced Ferko 's heart , and he waited impatiently till evening should come and he could rub the precious dew on his sightless eyes .
14 At last it began to grow dusk , and the sun sank behind the mountains ; gradually it became cooler on the hill , and the grass grew wet with dew .
15 Then Ferko buried his face in the ground till his eyes were damp with dewdrops , and in a moment he saw clearer than he had ever done in his life before .
16 The moon was shining brightly , and lighted him to the lake where he could bathe his poor broken legs .
17 Then Ferko crawled to the edge of the lake and dipped his limbs in the water .
18 No sooner had he done so than his legs felt as sound and strong as they had been before , and Ferko thanked the kind fate that had led him to the hill where he had overheard the ravens ' conversation .
19 He filled a bottle with the healing water , and then continued his journey in the best of spirits .
20 He had not gone far before he met a wolf , who was limping disconsolately along on three legs , and who on perceiving Ferko began to howl dismally .
21 ` My good friend , ' said the youth , ` be of good cheer , for I can soon heal your leg , ' and with these words he poured some of the precious water over the XXXXX 's paw , and in a minute the animal was springing about sound and well on all fours .	wolf		dew|eagle|gallows|ground|hill|howl|legs|moon|spot|wolf

10 Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life ; it was all ridges and furrows ; the balls were live hedgehogs , the mallets live flamingoes , and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet , to make the arches .
11 The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo : she succeeded in getting its body tucked away , comfortably enough , under her arm , with its legs hanging down , but generally , just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out , and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head , it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face , with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing : and when she had got its head down , and was going to begin again , it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself , and was in the act of crawling away : besides all this , there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to , and , as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground , Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed .
12 The players all played at once without waiting for turns , quarrelling all the while , and fighting for the hedgehogs ; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion , and went stamping about , and shouting ` Off with his head ! '

5 The Josephs ' Christmas The month before Christmas was always the most exciting and mysterious time in the Joseph household .
6 Such scheming and planning , such putting of curly heads together in corners , such counting of small hoards , such hiding and smuggling of things out of sight , as went on among the little Josephs !
7 There were a good many of them , and very few of the pennies ; hence the reason for so much contriving and consulting .
8 From fourteen-year-old Mollie down to four-year-old Lennie there were eight small Josephs in all in the little log house on the prairie ; so that when each little Joseph wanted to give a Christmas box to each of the other little Josephs , and something to Father and Mother Joseph besides , it is no wonder that they had to cudgel their small brains for ways and means thereof .
9 Father and Mother were always discreetly blind and silent through December .
10 No questions were asked no matter what queer things were done .
11 Many secret trips to the little store at the railway station two miles away were ignored , and no little Joseph was called to account because he or she looked terribly guilty when somebody suddenly came into the room .
12 The air was simply charged with secrets .
13 Sister Mollie was the grand repository of these ; all the little Josephs came to her for advice and assistance .
14 It was Mollie who for troubled small brothers and sisters did such sums in division as this : How can I get a ten-cent present for Emmy and a fifteen-cent one for Jimmy out of eighteen cents ?
15 Or , how can seven sticks of candy be divided among eight people so that each shall have one ?
16 It was Mollie who advised regarding the purchase of ribbon and crepe paper .
17 It was Mollie who put the finishing touches to most of the little gifts .
18 In short , all through December Mollie was weighed down under an avalanche of responsibility .
19 It speaks volumes for her sagacity and skill that she never got things mixed up or made any such terrible mistake as letting one little Joseph find out what another was going to give him .
20 `` Dead '' secrecy was the keystone of all plans and confidences .
21 During this particular XXXXX the planning and contriving had been more difficult and the results less satisfactory than usual .	December		Christmas|December|matter|planning|roses|secrecy|something|store|thing|touches

1 The daughter had her own way in everything , and whatever she did was right in her mother 's eyes ; but the poor step-daughter had a hard time .
2 Let her do what she would , she was always blamed , and got small thanks for all the trouble she took ; nothing was right , everything wrong ; and yet , if the truth were known , the girl was worth her weight in gold -- she was so unselfish and good-hearted .
3 But her step-mother did not like her , and the poor girl 's days were spent in weeping ; for it was impossible to live peacefully with the woman .
4 The wicked shrew was determined to get rid of the girl by fair means or foul , and kept saying to her father : ` Send her away , old man ; send her away -- anywhere so that my eyes sha 'n' t be plagued any longer by the sight of her , or my ears tormented by the sound of her voice .
5 Send her out into the fields , and let the cutting frost do for her . '
6 In vain did the poor old father weep and implore her pity ; she was firm , and he dared not gainsay her .
7 So he placed his daughter in a sledge , not even daring to give her a horse-cloth to keep herself warm with , and drove her out on to the bare , open fields , where he kissed her and left her , driving home as fast as he could , that he might not witness her miserable death .
8 Deserted by her father , the poor girl sat down under a fir-tree at the edge of the forest and began to weep silently .
9 Suddenly she heard a faint sound : it was King Frost springing from tree to tree , and cracking his fingers as he went .
10 At length he reached the fir-tree beneath which she was sitting , and with a crisp crackling sound he alighted beside her , and looked at her lovely face .
11 ` Well , maiden , ' he snapped out , ` do you know who I am ?
12 I am King Frost , king of the red-noses . '
13 ` All hail to you , great King ! '
14 answered the girl , in a gentle , trembling voice .
15 ` Have you come to take me ? '
16 ` Are you warm , maiden ? '
17 he replied .
18 ` Quite warm , King Frost , ' she answered , though she shivered as she spoke .
19 Then King Frost stooped down , and bent over the girl , and the crackling sound grew louder , and the air seemed to be full of knives and darts ; and again he asked : ` Maiden , are you warm ?
20 Are you warm , you beautiful girl ? '
21 And though her breath was almost frozen on her lips , she whispered gently , ` Quite warm , King XXXXX . '	Frost		Frost|daughter|face|father|hail|maiden|means|sight|truth|voice

1 They drank at the tanks and made the water all muddy , and then they fought over it , and then they would all rush together in mobs and shout : `` There is no one in the jungle so wise and good and clever and strong and gentle as the Bandar-log . ''
2 Then all would begin again till they grew tired of the city and went back to the tree-tops , hoping the Jungle-People would notice them .
3 Mowgli , who had been trained under the Law of the Jungle , did not like or understand this kind of life .
4 The monkeys dragged him into the Cold Lairs late in the afternoon , and instead of going to sleep , as Mowgli would have done after a long journey , they joined hands and danced about and sang their foolish songs .
5 One of the monkeys made a speech and told his companions that Mowgli 's capture marked a new thing in the history of the Bandar-log , for Mowgli was going to show them how to weave sticks and canes together as a protection against rain and cold .
6 Mowgli picked up some creepers and began to work them in and out , and the monkeys tried to imitate ; but in a very few minutes they lost interest and began to pull their friends ' tails or jump up and down on all fours , coughing .
7 `` I wish to eat , '' said Mowgli .
8 `` I am a stranger in this part of the jungle .
9 Bring me food , or give me leave to hunt here . ''
10 Twenty or thirty monkeys bounded away to bring him nuts and wild pawpaws .
11 But they fell to fighting on the road , and it was too much trouble to go back with what was left of the fruit .
12 Mowgli was sore and angry as well as hungry , and he roamed through the empty city giving the Strangers ' Hunting Call from time to time , but no one answered him , and Mowgli felt that he had reached a very bad place indeed .
13 `` All that Baloo has said about the Bandar-log is true , '' he thought to himself .
14 `` They have no Law , no Hunting Call , and no leaders -- nothing but foolish words and little picking thievish hands .
15 So if I am starved or killed here , it will be all my own fault .
16 But I must try to return to my own jungle .
17 Baloo will surely beat me , but that is better than chasing silly rose leaves with the Bandar-log . ''
18 No sooner had he walked to the city wall than the monkeys pulled him back , telling him that he did not know how happy he was , and pinching him to make him grateful .
19 He set his teeth and said nothing , but went with the shouting monkeys to a terrace above the red sandstone reservoirs that were half-full of rain water .
20 There was a ruined summer-house of white marble in the center of the terrace , built for queens dead a hundred years ago .
21 The domed roof had half fallen in and blocked up the underground passage from the palace by which the XXXXX used to enter .	queens		Law|fault|food|interest|jungle|mobs|nothing|queens|speech|years

1 ` You are a fine fellow ! '
2 said the Soldier , and put him on the Witch 's apron , took as much copper as his pockets could hold ; then he shut the chest , put the dog on it again , and went into the second room .
3 Sure enough there sat the dog with eyes as large as mill-wheels .
4 ` You had better not look at me so hard ! '
5 said the Soldier .
6 ` Your eyes will come out of their sockets ! '
7 And then he set the dog on the apron .
8 When he saw all the silver in the chest , he threw away the copper he had taken , and filled his pockets and knapsack with nothing but silver .
9 Then he went into the third room .
10 Horrors !
11 the dog there had two eyes , each as large as the Round Tower at Copenhagen , spinning round in his head like wheels .
12 ` Good evening ! '
13 said the Soldier and saluted , for he had never seen a dog like this before .
14 But when he had examined him more closely , he thought to himself : ` Now then , I 've had enough of this ! '
15 and put him down on the floor , and opened the chest .
16 Heavens !
17 what a heap of gold there was !
18 With all that he could buy up the whole town , and all the sugar pigs , all the tin soldiers , whips and rocking-horses in the whole world .
19 Now he threw away all the silver with which he had filled his pockets and knapsack , and filled them with gold instead -- yes , all his pockets , his knapsack , cap and boots even , so that he could hardly walk .
20 Now he was rich indeed .

1 Kletke .
2 Once upon a time there was a Glass Mountain at the top of which stood a castle made of pure gold , and in front of the castle there grew an apple-tree on which there were golden apples .
3 Anyone who picked an apple gained admittance into the golden castle , and there in a silver room sat an enchanted Princess of surpassing fairness and beauty .
4 She was as rich too as she was beautiful , for the cellars of the castle were full of precious stones , and great chests of the finest gold stood round the walls of all the rooms .
5 Many knights had come from afar to try their luck , but it was in vain they attempted to climb the mountain .
6 In spite of having their horses shod with sharp nails , no one managed to get more than half-way up , and then they all fell back right down to the bottom of the steep slippery hill .
7 Sometimes they broke an arm , sometimes a leg , and many a brave man had broken his neck even .
8 The beautiful Princess sat at her window and watched the bold knights trying to reach her on their splendid horses .
9 The sight of her always gave men fresh courage , and they flocked from the four quarters of the globe to attempt the work of rescuing her .
10 But all in vain , and for seven years the Princess had sat now and waited for some one to scale the Glass Mountain .
11 A heap of corpses both of riders and horses lay round the mountain , and many dying men lay groaning there unable to go any farther with their wounded limbs .
12 The whole neighbourhood had the appearance of a vast churchyard .
13 In three more days the seven years would be at an end , when a knight in golden armour and mounted on a spirited steed was seen making his way towards the fatal hill .
14 Sticking his spurs into his horse he made a rush at the mountain , and got up half-way , then he calmly turned his horse 's head and came down again without a slip or stumble .
15 The following day he started in the same way ; the horse trod on the glass as if it had been level earth , and sparks of fire flew from its hoofs .
16 All the other knights gazed in astonishment , for he had almost gained the summit , and in another moment he would have reached the apple-tree ; but of a sudden a huge eagle rose up and spread its mighty wings , hitting as it did so the knight 's horse in the eye .
17 The beast shied , opened its wide nostrils and tossed its mane , then rearing high up in the air , its hind feet slipped and it fell with its rider down the steep mountain side .
18 Nothing was left of either of them except their bones , which rattled in the battered golden armour like dry peas in a pod .
19 And now there was only one more day before the close of the seven years .
20 Then there arrived on the scene a mere schoolboy -- a merry , happy-hearted youth , but at the same time strong and well-grown .
21 He saw how many XXXXX had broken their necks in vain , but undaunted he approached the steep mountain on foot and began the ascent .	knights		arm|beast|bottom|earth|knights|man|neighbourhood|slip|stones|youth

1 Having told the Prince all this , the Fairy went out in hopes of seeing the parrot , and soon returned with the bird in her hand .
2 She promptly shut it up in a cage , and , touching the Prince with her wand , transformed him into an exactly similar parrot ; after which , she instructed him how to reach the Princess .
3 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
4 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the parrot , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .
5 This soon reassured the Prince , and encouraged him to play his part well , and he began to say a thousand agreeable things which charmed the Princess .
6 Presently the King appeared , and the parrot noticed with joy how much he was disliked .
7 As soon as the King left , the Princess retired to her dressing-room , the parrot flew after her and overheard her lamentations at the continued persecutions of the King , who had pressed her to consent to their marriage .
8 The parrot said so many clever and tender things to comfort her that she began to doubt whether this could indeed be her own parrot .
9 When he saw her well-disposed towards him , he exclaimed : ` Madam , I have a most important secret to confide to you , and I beg you not to be alarmed by what I am about to say .
10 I am here on behalf of the Queen your mother , with the object of delivering your Highness ; to prove which , behold this portrait which she gave me herself . '
11 So saying he drew forth the miniature from under his wing .
12 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
13 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
14 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
15 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
16 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
17 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her parrot again .
18 As they rose through the air the Princess remarked a figure mounted on an eagle 's back flying in front of the chariot .
19 She was rather alarmed , but the Prince reassured her , telling her it was the good Fairy to whom she owed so much , and who was now conducting her in safety to her mother .
20 That same morning the King woke suddenly from a troubled sleep .
21 He had dreamt that the Princess was being carried off from him , and , transforming himself into an XXXXX , he flew to the palace .	eagle		arms|cage|eagle|eagles|help|hopes|person|safety|wand|window

1 ` You must learn to do as you are told , ' was all the Frog would reply .
2 But poor Saphir was so unhappy , and begged so hard for forgiveness , that at last the Frog 's anger gave way , and she held up to him a tiny diamond stone .
3 ` Go back , ' she said , ` to the castle , and bury this little diamond close to the door .
4 But be careful not to return to the stable or to the bedroom ; they have proved too fatal to you .
5 Walk straight to the garden and enter through a portico , into a small green wood , in the midst of which is a tree with a trunk of gold and leaves of emeralds .
6 Perched on this tree you will see the beautiful bird you have been seeking so long .
7 You must cut the branch on which it is sitting , and bring it back to me without delay .
8 But I warn you solemnly that if you disobey my directions , as you have done twice before , you have nothing more to expect either of me or anyone else . '
9 With these words she jumped into the water , and the Prince , who had taken her threats much to heart , took his departure , firmly resolved not to deserve them .
10 He found it all just as he had been told : the portico , the wood , the magnificent tree , and the beautiful bird , which was sleeping soundly on one of the branches .
11 He speedily lopped off the branch , and though he noticed a splendid golden cage hanging close by , which would have been very useful for the bird to travel in , he left it alone , and came back to the fountain , holding his breath and walking on tip-toe all the way , for fear lest he should awake his prize .
12 But what was his surprise , when instead of finding the fountain in the spot where he had left it , he saw in its place a little rustic palace built in the best taste , and standing in the doorway a charming maiden , at whose sight his mind seemed to give way .
13 ` What !
14 Madam ! '
15 he cried , hardly knowing what he said .
16 ` What !
17 Is it you ? '
18 The maiden blushed and answered : ` Ah , my lord , it is long since I first beheld your face , but I did not think you had ever seen mine . '
19 ` Oh , madam , ' replied he , ` you can never guess the days and the hours I have passed lost in admiration of you . '

1 The Fire-son was delighted , but the perpetual heat in which he lived made his body so hot , that it was dangerous to go too close to him .
2 One day the King gave a great feast , and asked his brother-in-law among the other guests .
3 The Fire-son did not appear till everyone had assembled , and when he did , everyone fled outside to the open air , so intense was the heat he gave forth .
4 Then the King was very angry and said , ` If I had known what a lot of trouble you would have been , I would never have taken you into my house . '
5 Then the Fire-son replied with a laugh , ` Do n't be angry , dear brother !
6 I love heat and my sister loves cold -- come here and let me embrace you , and then I 'll go home at once . '
7 And before the King had time to reply , the Fire-son seized him in a tight embrace .
8 The King screamed aloud in agony , and when his wife , the Snow-daughter , who had taken refuge from her brother in the next room , hurried to him , the King lay dead on the ground burnt to a cinder .
9 When the Snow-daughter saw this she turned on her brother and flew at him .
10 Then a fight began , the like of which had never been seen on earth .
11 When the people , attracted by the noise , hurried to the spot , they saw the Snow-daughter melting into water and the Fire-son burn to a cinder .
12 And so ended the unhappy brother and sister .

1 He lay down once more on the grass and soon fell fast asleep .
2 All the next day he spent wandering about the fields , and toward evening the wolf came running to him in a great hurry and said , ' I have collected together all the wolves in the kingdom , and they are waiting for you in the wood .
3 Go quickly to the King , and tell him to go to the hill that he may see the wonder you have done with his own eyes .
4 Then return at once to me and get on my back , and I will help you to drive all the wolves together . '
5 Then Ferko went straight to the palace and told the King that he was ready to perform the third task if he would come to the hill and see it done .
6 Ferko himself returned to the fields , and mounting on the wolf 's back he rode to the wood close by .
7 Quick as lightning the wolf flew round the wood , and in a minute many hundred wolves rose up before him , increasing in number every moment , till they could be counted by thousands .
8 He drove them all before him on to the hill , where the King and his whole Court and Ferko 's two brothers were standing .
9 Only the lovely Princess was not present , for she was shut up in her tower weeping bitterly .
10 The wicked brothers stamped and foamed with rage when they saw the failure of their wicked designs .
11 But the King was overcome by a sudden terror when he saw the enormous pack of wolves approaching nearer and nearer , and calling out to Ferko he said , ` Enough , enough , we do n't want any more . '
12 But the wolf on whose back Ferko sat , said to its rider , ` Go on !
13 go on ! '
14 and at the same moment many more wolves ran up the hill , howling horribly and showing their white teeth .

1 XI OLD MR. TOAD 'S QUEER TONGUE Old Mother Nature doth provide For all her children , large or small .
2 Her wisdom foresees all their needs And makes provision for them all .
3 If you do n't believe it , just you go ask Old Mr. Toad , as Peter Rabbit did , how such a slow-moving fellow as he is can catch enough bugs and insects to keep him alive .
4 Perhaps you 'll learn something just as Peter did .
5 Peter and Old Mr. Toad sat in the rain watching the tiny Toads , who , you know , were Mr. Toad 's children , leaving their kindergarten in the Smiling Pool and starting out to see the Great World .
6 When the last little Toad had passed them , Old Mr. Toad suddenly remembered that he was hungry , very hungry indeed .
7 `` Did n't have time to eat much while I was in the Smiling Pool , '' he explained .
8 `` Could n't eat and sing too , and while I was down there , I was supposed to sing .
9 Now that it is time to quit singing , I begin to realize that I 've got a stomach to look out for as well as a voice .
10 See that bug over there on that leaf ?
11 Watch him . ''
12 Peter looked , and sure enough there was a fat bug crawling along on an old leaf .
13 He was about two inches from Old Mr. Toad , and he was crawling very fast .
14 And right while Peter was looking at him he disappeared .
15 Peter turned to look at Old Mr. Toad .
16 He had n't budged .
17 He was sitting exactly where he had been sitting all the time , but he was smacking his lips , and there was a twinkle of satisfaction in his eyes .

20 `` Nice bug , '' interrupted Old Mr. Toad .

1 Long before the five miles were covered , Chester began to wonder if he would hold out to the end of them .
2 He had to stop and rest frequently , when those queer dizzy spells came on .
3 His feet seemed like lead .
4 But he kept doggedly on .
5 He would not give in now !
6 The white and yellow church was the most welcome sight that had ever met his eyes .
7 Over the hill he met a man and inquired the way to Mount Hope Farm .
8 Fortunately , it was nearby .
9 At the gate Chester had to stop again to recover from his dizziness .
10 He liked the look of the place , with its great , comfortable barns and quaint , roomy old farmhouse , all set down in a trim quadrangle of beeches and orchards .
11 There was an appearance of peace and prosperity about it .

1 Why , your little feet would take an hour to go the distance an ordinary person could do in a minute ! '
2 But the Hazel-nut child replied , ` Nevertheless I mean to be a messenger !
3 Just send me a message and you 'll see that I shall be back in next to no time . '
4 So his mother said , ` Very well , go to your aunt in the neighbouring village , and fetch me a comb . '
5 The Hazel-nut child jumped quickly out of the egg-shell and ran out into the street .
6 Here he found a man on horseback who was just setting out for the neighbouring village .
7 He crept up the horse 's leg , sat down under the saddle , and then began to pinch the horse and to prick it with a pin .
8 The horse plunged and reared and then set off at a hard gallop , which it continued in spite of its rider 's efforts to stop it .
9 When they reached the village , the Hazel-nut child left off pricking the horse , and the poor tired creature pursued its way at a snail 's pace .
10 The Hazel-nut child took advantage of this , and crept down the horse 's leg ; then he ran to his aunt and asked her for a comb .
11 On the way home he met another rider , and did the return journey in exactly the same way .
12 When he handed his mother the comb that his aunt had given him , she was much amazed and asked him , ` But how did you manage to get back so quickly ? '
13 ` Ah !
14 mother , ' he replied , ` you see I was quite right when I said I knew a messenger was the profession for me . '
15 His father too possessed a horse which he often used to take out into the fields to graze .
16 One day he took the Hazel-nut child with him .
17 At midday the father turned to his small son and said , ` Stay here and look after the horse .
18 I must go home and give your mother a message , but I shall be back soon . '
19 When his father had gone , a robber passed by and saw the horse grazing without any one watching it , for of course he could not see the Hazel-nut child hidden in the grass .
20 So he mounted the horse and rode away .

1 He was too tired to keep awake all night , yet his anxiety prevented him from sleeping soundly , and when with the earliest dawn he looked up to the tree-top , he was glad to see his feathered companions still asleep with their heads under their wings .
2 He ate his breakfast , and waited until the birds should start , but they did not leave the place all day .
3 They hopped about from one tree to another looking for food , all day long until the evening , when they went back to their old perch to sleep .
4 The next day the same thing happened , but on the third morning one bird said to the other , ` To-day we must go to the spring to see the Witch-maiden wash her face . '
5 They remained on the tree till noon ; then they flew away and went towards the south .
6 The young man 's heart beat with anxiety lest he should lose sight of his guides , but he managed to keep the birds in view until they again perched upon a tree .
7 The young man ran after them until he was quite exhausted and out of breath , and after three short rests the birds at length reached a small open space in the forest , on the edge of which they placed themselves on the top of a high tree .
8 When the youth had overtaken them , he saw that there was a clear spring in the middle of the space .
9 He sat down at the foot of the tree upon which the birds were perched , and listened attentively to what they were saying to each other .
10 ` The sun is not down yet , ' said the first bird ; ` we must wait yet awhile till the moon rises and the maiden comes to the spring .
11 Do you think she will see that young man sitting under the tree ? '
12 ` Nothing is likely to escape her eyes , certainly not a young man , said the other bird .
13 ` Will the youth have the sense not to let himself be caught in her toils ? '
14 ` We will wait , ' said the first bird , ` and see how they get on together . '
15 The evening light had quite faded , and the full moon was already shining down upon the forest , when the young man heard a slight rustling sound .
16 After a few moments there came out of the forest a maiden , gliding over the grass so lightly that her feet seemed scarcely to touch the ground , and stood beside the spring .
17 The youth could not turn away his eyes from the maiden , for he had never in his life seen a woman so beautiful .
18 Without seeming to notice anything , she went to the spring , looked up to the full moon , then knelt down and bathed her face nine times , then looked up to the moon again and walked nine times round the well , and as she walked she sang this song : ` Full-faced moon with light unshaded , Let my beauty ne'er be faded .
19 Never let my cheek grow pale !
20 While the moon is waning nightly , May the maiden bloom more brightly , May her freshness never fail ! '
21 Then she dried her face with her long hair , and was about to go away , when her eye suddenly fell upon the spot where the young man was sitting , and she turned towards the XXXXX .	tree		To-day|bird|breath|cheek|dawn|freshness|heads|moments|south|tree

1 At this sight the Prince became more puzzled than ever , for he did not know how he was to warn Rosalie of his return .
2 Yet it broke his heart to see her weeping from dawn till dark .
3 One day , as Rosalie was walking up and down her room , she was surprised to see that the crystal which served for a wall had grown cloudy , as if some one had breathed on it , and , what was more , wherever she moved the brightness of the crystal always became clouded .
4 This was enough to cause the Princess to suspect that her lover had returned .
5 In order to set the Prince of the Air 's mind at rest she began by being very gracious to him , so that when she begged that her captivity might be a little lightened she should not be refused .
6 At first the only favour she asked was to be allowed to walk for one hour every day up and down the long gallery .
7 This was granted , and the Invisible Prince speedily took the opportunity of handing her the stone , which she at once slipped into her mouth .
8 No words can paint the fury of her captor at her disappearance .
9 He ordered the spirits of the air to fly through all space , and to bring back Rosalie wherever she might be .
10 They instantly flew off to obey his commands , and spread themselves over the whole earth .
11 Meantime Rosalie and the Invisible Prince had reached , hand in hand , a door of the gallery which led through a terrace into the gardens .
12 In silence they glided along , and thought themselves already safe , when a furious monster dashed itself by accident against Rosalie and the Invisible Prince , and in her fright she let go his hand .
13 No one can speak as long as he is invisible , and besides , they knew that the spirits were all around them , and at the slightest sound they would be recognised ; so all they could do was to feel about in the hope that their hands might once more meet .
14 But , alas !
15 the joy of liberty lasted but a short time .
16 The Princess , having wandered in vain up and down the forest , stopped at last on the edge of a fountain .
17 As she walked she wrote on the trees : ` If ever the Prince , my lover , comes this way , let him know that it is here I dwell , and that I sit daily on the edge of this fountain , mingling my tears with its waters . '
18 These words were read by one of the genii , who repeated them to his master .
19 The Prince of the Air , in his turn making himself invisible , was led to the fountain , and waited for Rosalie .
20 When she drew near he held out his hand , which she grasped eagerly , taking it for that of her lover ; and , seizing his opportunity , the Prince passed a cord round her arms , and throwing off his invisibility cried to his spirits to drag her into the lowest pit .
21 It was at this moment that the Invisible Prince appeared , and at the XXXXX of the Prince of the Genii mounting into the air , holding a silken cord , he guessed instantly that he was carrying off Rosalie .	sight		commands|disappearance|genii|hands|lover|order|sight|spirits|way|words

1 The young man ran after them until he was quite exhausted and out of breath , and after three short rests the birds at length reached a small open space in the forest , on the edge of which they placed themselves on the top of a high tree .
2 When the youth had overtaken them , he saw that there was a clear spring in the middle of the space .
3 He sat down at the foot of the tree upon which the birds were perched , and listened attentively to what they were saying to each other .
4 ` The sun is not down yet , ' said the first bird ; ` we must wait yet awhile till the moon rises and the maiden comes to the spring .
5 Do you think she will see that young man sitting under the tree ? '
6 ` Nothing is likely to escape her eyes , certainly not a young man , said the other bird .
7 ` Will the youth have the sense not to let himself be caught in her toils ? '
8 ` We will wait , ' said the first bird , ` and see how they get on together . '
9 The evening light had quite faded , and the full moon was already shining down upon the forest , when the young man heard a slight rustling sound .
10 After a few moments there came out of the forest a maiden , gliding over the grass so lightly that her feet seemed scarcely to touch the ground , and stood beside the spring .
11 The youth could not turn away his eyes from the maiden , for he had never in his life seen a woman so beautiful .
12 Without seeming to notice anything , she went to the spring , looked up to the full moon , then knelt down and bathed her face nine times , then looked up to the moon again and walked nine times round the well , and as she walked she sang this song : ` Full-faced moon with light unshaded , Let my beauty ne'er be faded .
13 Never let my cheek grow pale !
14 While the moon is waning nightly , May the maiden bloom more brightly , May her freshness never fail ! '
15 Then she dried her face with her long hair , and was about to go away , when her eye suddenly fell upon the spot where the young man was sitting , and she turned towards the tree .
16 The youth rose and stood waiting .
17 Then the maiden said , ` You ought to have a heavy punishment because you have presumed to watch my secret doings in the moonlight .
18 But I will forgive you this time , because you are a stranger and knew no better .
19 But you must tell me truly who you are and how you came to this place , where no mortal has ever set foot before . '
20 The youth answered humbly : ` Forgive me , beautiful maiden , if I have unintentionally offended you .
21 I chanced to come here after long wandering , and found a good place to sleep under this XXXXX .	tree		beauty|birds|forest|hair|maiden|middle|sense|spot|spring|tree

1 He wrapped her up in his cloak , placed her before him on his horse , and brought her to his castle .
2 There he had her dressed in rich clothes , and her beauty shone out as bright as day , but not a word could be drawn from her .
3 He set her at table by his side , and her modest ways and behaviour pleased him so much that he said , ' I will marry this maiden and none other in the world , ' and after some days he married her .
4 But the King had a wicked mother who was displeased with the marriage , and said wicked things of the young Queen .
5 ` Who knows who this girl is ? '
6 she said ; ` she can not speak , and is not worthy of a king . '
7 After a year , when the Queen had her first child , the old mother took it away from her .
8 Then she went to the King and said that the Queen had killed it .
9 The King would not believe it , and would not allow any harm to be done her .
10 But she sat quietly sewing at the shirts and troubling herself about nothing .
11 The next time she had a child the wicked mother did the same thing , but the King could not make up his mind to believe her .
12 He said , ` She is too sweet and good to do such a thing as that .
13 If she were not dumb and could defend herself , her innocence would be proved . '
14 But when the third child was taken away , and the Queen was again accused , and could not utter a word in her own defence , the King was obliged to give her over to the law , which decreed that she must be burnt to death .
15 When the day came on which the sentence was to be executed , it was the last day of the six years in which she must not speak or laugh , and now she had freed her dear brothers from the power of the enchantment .
16 The six shirts were done ; there was only the left sleeve wanting to the last .
17 When she was led to the stake , she laid the shirts on her arm , and as she stood on the pile and the fire was about to be lighted , she looked around her and saw six swans flying through the air .
18 Then she knew that her release was at hand and her heart danced for joy .
19 The swans fluttered round her , and hovered low so that she could throw the shirts over them .
20 When they had touched them the swan-skins fell off , and her brothers stood before her living , well and beautiful .
21 Only the youngest had a swan 's wing instead of his left XXXXX .	arm		air|arm|behaviour|clothes|death|enchantment|living|pile|time|word

1 So he kept watch half the night ; but a little after midnight he was overcome by an irresistible drowsiness , and fell fast asleep .
2 He did not awake till it was bright daylight , and all the fruit on the trees had vanished .
3 The following year Warza , the second brother , tried his luck , but with the same result .
4 Then it came to the turn of the third and youngest son .
5 Iwanich was not the least discouraged by the failure of his elder brothers , though they were both much older and stronger than he was , and when night came climbed up the tree as they had done , The moon had risen , and with her soft light lit up the whole neighbourhood , so that the observant Prince could distinguish the smallest object distinctly .
6 At midnight a gentle west wind shook the tree , and at the same moment a snow-white swan-like bird sank down gently on his breast .
7 The Prince hastily seized the bird 's wings in his hands , when , lo !
8 to his astonishment he found he was holding in his arms not a bird but the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
9 ` You need not fear Militza , ' said the beautiful girl , looking at the Prince with friendly eyes .
10 ` An evil magician has not robbed you of your fruit , but he stole the seed from my mother , and thereby caused her death .
11 When she was dying she bade me take the fruit , which you have no right to possess , from the trees every year as soon as it was ripe .
12 This I would have done to-night too , if you had not seized me with such force , and so broken the spell I was under . '
13 Iwanich , who had been prepared to meet a terrible magician and not a lovely girl , fell desperately in love with her .
14 They spent the rest of the night in pleasant conversation , and when Militza wished to go away he begged her not to leave him . '
15 I would gladly stay with you longer , ' said Militza , ` but a wicked witch once cut off a lock of my hair when I was asleep , which has put me in her power , and if morning were still to find me here she would do me some harm , and you , too , perhaps . '
16 Having said these words , she drew a sparkling diamond ring from her finger , which she handed to the Prince , saying : ` Keep this ring in memory of Militza , and think of her sometimes if you never see her again .
17 But if your love is really true , come and find me in my own kingdom .
18 I may not show you the way there , but this ring will guide you .
19 ` If you have love and courage enough to undertake this journey , whenever you come to a cross-road always look at this diamond before you settle which way you are going to take .
20 If it sparkles as brightly as ever go straight on , but if its lustre is dimmed choose another path . '
21 Then Militza bent over the Prince and kissed him on his forehead , and before he had time to say a word she vanished through the branches of the XXXXX in a little white cloud .	tree		arms|astonishment|courage|diamond|force|girl|hands|object|path|tree

1 Jerry Muskrat swam back and forth , making little silver lines on the surface of the Smiling Pool and squeaking contentedly , for it was the hour which he loves best .
2 Little Friend the Song Sparrow had tucked his head under his wing and gone to sleep among the alders along the Laughing Brook and Redwing the Blackbird had done the same thing among the bulrushes .
3 All the feathered songsters who had made joyous the bright day had gone to bed .
4 But this did not mean that the glad spring chorus was silent .
5 Oh , my , no !
6 No indeed !
7 The Green Meadows were silent , and the Green Forest was silent , but as if to make up for this , the sweet singers of the Smiling Pool , the hylas and the frogs and Old Mr. Toad , were pouring out their gladness as if they had not been singing most of the departed day .
8 You see it was the hour they love best of all , the hour which seems to them just made for singing , and they were doing their best to tell Old Mother Nature how they love her , and how glad they were that she had brought back sweet Mistress Spring to waken them from their long sleep .
9 It was so peaceful and beautiful there that it did n't seem possible that danger of any kind could be lurking near .
10 But Old Mr. Toad , swelling out that queer music bag in his throat and singing with all his might , never once forgot that wise saying of his , and so he was the first to see what looked like nothing so much as a little detached bit of the blackness of the Green Forest floating out towards the Smiling Pool .
11 Instantly he stopped singing .
12 Now that was a signal .
13 When he stopped singing , his nearest neighbor stopped singing , then the next one and the next , and in a minute there was n't a sound from the Smiling Pool save the squeak of Jerry Muskrat hidden among the bulrushes .
14 That great chorus stopped as abruptly as the electric lights go out when you press a button .
15 Back and forth over the Smiling Pool , this way and that way , floated the shadow , but there was no sign of any living thing in the Smiling Pool .
16 After awhile the shadow floated away over the Green Meadows without a sound .
17 `` Hooty the Owl did n't get one of us that time , '' said Old Mr. Toad to his nearest neighbor with a chuckle of satisfaction .
18 Then he swelled out his music bag and began to sing again .
19 And at once , as abruptly as it had stopped , the great chorus began again as joyous as before , for nothing had happened to bring sadness as might have but for the watchfulness of Old Mr. Toad .
20 VIII OLD MR. TOAD 'S BABIES The Smiling Pool 's a nursery Where all the sunny day A thousand funny babies Are taught while at their play .
21 Really the Smiling XXXXX is a sort of kindergarten , one of the most interesting kindergartens in the world .	Pool		Friend|Pool|chorus|gladness|head|hour|nothing|sound|way|wing

1 The Prince reached the palace in safety , but was so dazzled at first by the Princess 's beauty , which far surpassed his expectations , that he was quite dumb for a time .
2 The Princess was surprised and anxious , and fearing the parrot , who was her greatest comfort , had fallen ill , she took him in her hand and caressed him .
3 This soon reassured the Prince , and encouraged him to play his part well , and he began to say a thousand agreeable things which charmed the Princess .
4 Presently the King appeared , and the parrot noticed with joy how much he was disliked .
5 As soon as the King left , the Princess retired to her dressing-room , the parrot flew after her and overheard her lamentations at the continued persecutions of the King , who had pressed her to consent to their marriage .
6 The parrot said so many clever and tender things to comfort her that she began to doubt whether this could indeed be her own parrot .
7 When he saw her well-disposed towards him , he exclaimed : ` Madam , I have a most important secret to confide to you , and I beg you not to be alarmed by what I am about to say .
8 I am here on behalf of the Queen your mother , with the object of delivering your Highness ; to prove which , behold this portrait which she gave me herself . '
9 So saying he drew forth the miniature from under his wing .
10 The Princess 's surprise was great , but after what she had seen and heard it was impossible not to indulge in hope , for she had recognised the likeness of herself which her mother always wore .
11 The parrot , finding she was not much alarmed , told her who he was , all that her mother had promised him and the help he had already received from a Fairy who had assured him that she would give him means to transport the Princess to her mother 's arms .
12 When he found her listening attentively to him , he implored the Princess to allow him to resume his natural shape .
13 She did not speak , so he drew a feather from his wing , and she beheld before her a Prince of such surpassing beauty that it was impossible not to hope that she might owe her liberty to so charming a person .
14 Meantime the Fairy had prepared a chariot , to which she harnessed two powerful eagles ; then placing the cage , with the parrot in it , she charged the bird to conduct it to the window of the Princess 's dressing-room .
15 This was done in a few minutes , and the Princess , stepping into the chariot with the Prince , was delighted to find her parrot again .
16 As they rose through the air the Princess remarked a figure mounted on an eagle 's back flying in front of the chariot .
17 She was rather alarmed , but the Prince reassured her , telling her it was the good Fairy to whom she owed so much , and who was now conducting her in safety to her mother .
18 That same morning the King woke suddenly from a troubled sleep .
19 He had dreamt that the Princess was being carried off from him , and , transforming himself into an eagle , he flew to the palace .
20 When he failed to find her he flew into a terrible rage , and hastened home to consult his books , by which means he discovered that it was his son who had deprived him of this precious treasure .
21 Immediately he took the shape of a harpy , and , filled with rage , was determined to devour his XXXXX , and even the Princess too , if only he could overtake them .	son		cage|eagles|help|parrot|rage|safety|son|surprise|things|wing

1 A short time after this , when he was going early one morning to the usual grazing place with his horses , he noticed a flock of birds assembled together making a great noise and flying wildly backwards and forwards .
2 Full of curiosity , Iwanich hurried up to the spot , and saw that a large number of ravens had attacked an eagle , and although the eagle was big and powerful and was making a brave fight , it was overpowered at last by numbers , and had to give in .
3 But the Prince , who was sorry for the poor bird , seized the branch of a tree and hit out at the ravens with it ; terrified at this unexpected onslaught they flew away , leaving many of their number dead or wounded on the battlefield .
4 As soon as the eagle saw itself free from its tormentors it plucked a feather from its wing , and , handing it to the Prince , said : ` Here , my kind benefactor , take this feather as a proof of my gratitude ; should you ever be in need of my help blow this feather into the air , and I will help you as much as is in my power . '
5 Iwanich thanked the bird , and placing the feather beside the scale he drove the horses home .
6 Another day he had wandered farther than usual , and came close to a farmyard ; the place pleased the Prince , and as there was plenty of good grass for the horses he determined to spend the day there .
7 Just as he was sitting down under a tree he heard a cry close to him , and saw a fox which had been caught in a trap placed there by the farmer .
8 In vain did the poor beast try to free itself ; then the good-natured Prince came once more to the rescue , and let the fox out of the trap .
9 The fox thanked him heartily , tore two hairs out of his bushy tail , and said : ` Should you ever stand in need of my help throw these two hairs into the fire , and in a moment I shall be at your side ready to obey you . '
10 Iwanich put the fox 's hairs with the scale and the feather , and as it was getting dark he hastened home with his horses .
11 In the meantime his service was drawing near to an end , and in three more days the year was up , and he would be able to get his reward and leave the witch .
12 On the first evening of these last three days , when he came home and was eating his supper , he noticed the old woman stealing into the stables .
13 The Prince followed her secretly to see what she was going to do .
14 He crouched down in the doorway and heard the wicked witch telling the horses to wait next morning till Iwanich was asleep , and then to go and hide themselves in the river , and to stay there till she told them to return ; and if they did n't do as she told them the old woman threatened to beat them till they bled .
15 When Iwanich heard all this he went back to his room , determined that nothing should induce him to fall asleep next day .
16 On the following morning he led the mare and foal to the fields as usual , but bound a cord round them both which he kept in his hand .
17 But after a few hours , by the magic arts of the old witch , he was overpowered by sleep , and the mare and foal escaped and did as they had been told to do .
18 The Prince did not awake till late in the evening ; and when he did , he found , to his horror , that the horses had disappeared .
19 Filled with despair , he cursed the moment when he had entered the service of the cruel witch , and already he saw his head sticking up on the sharp spike beside the others .
20 Then he suddenly remembered the fish 's scale , which , with the eagle 's feather and the fox 's hairs , he always carried about with him .
21 He drew the scale from his pocket , and hurrying to the XXXXX he threw it in .	river		beast|hairs|home|horror|numbers|river|scale|side|sleep|supper

13 There was once upon a time a witch , who in the shape of a hawk used every night to break the windows of a certain village church .
14 In the same village there lived three brothers , who were all determined to kill the mischievous hawk .
15 But in vain did the two eldest mount guard in the church with their guns ; as soon as the bird appeared high above their heads , sleep overpowered them , and they only awoke to hear the windows crashing in .
16 Then the youngest brother took his turn of guarding the windows , and to prevent his being overcome by sleep he placed a lot of thorns under his chin , so that if he felt drowsy and nodded his head , they would prick him and keep him awake .
17 The moon was already risen , and it was as light as day , when suddenly he heard a fearful noise , and at the same time a terrible desire to sleep overpowered him .
18 His eyelids closed , and his head sank on his shoulders , but the thorns ran into him and were so painful that he awoke at once .

1 An elegant polished walnut-shell served Thumbelina as a cradle , the blue petals of a violet were her mattress , and a rose-leaf her coverlid .
2 There she lay at night , but in the day-time she used to play about on the table ; here the woman had put a bowl , surrounded by a ring of flowers , with their stalks in water , in the middle of which floated a great tulip pedal , and on this Thumbelina sat , and sailed from one side of the bowl to the other , rowing herself with two white horse-hairs for oars .
3 It was such a pretty sight !
4 She could sing , too , with a voice more soft and sweet than had ever been heard before .
5 One night , when she was lying in her pretty little bed , an old toad crept in through a broken pane in the window .
6 She was very ugly , clumsy , and clammy ; she hopped on to the table where Thumbelina lay asleep under the red rose-leaf .
7 ` This would make a beautiful wife for my son , ' said the toad , taking up the walnut-shell , with Thumbelina inside , and hopping with it through the window into the garden .
8 There flowed a great wide stream , with slippery and marshy banks ; here the toad lived with her son .
9 Ugh !
10 how ugly and clammy he was , just like his mother !
11 ` Croak , croak , croak ! '
12 was all he could say when he saw the pretty little girl in the walnut-shell .
13 ` Do n't talk so load , or you 'll wake her , ' said the old toad .
14 ` She might escape us even now ; she is as light as a feather .
15 We will put her at once on a broad water-lily leaf in the stream .
16 That will be quite an island for her ; she is so small and light .
17 She ca n't run away from us there , whilst we are preparing the guest-chamber under the marsh where she shall live . '
18 Outside in the brook grew many water-lilies , with broad green leaves , which looked as if they were swimming about on the water .
19 The leaf farthest away was the largest , and to this the old toad swam with Thumbelina in her walnut-shell .
20 The tiny Thumbelina woke up very early in the morning , and when she saw where she was she began to cry bitterly ; for on every side of the great green leaf was water , and she could not get to the land .

1 And she disappeared into her hut , but returned very soon and said , ` You are a mighty Prince , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded .
2 Would you like to have the most beautiful woman in the world for your wife ? '
3 ` Most certainly I would , ' replied the Prince .
4 So the old woman continued , ` The most beautiful woman in the whole world is the daughter of the Queen of the Flowers , who has been captured by a dragon .
5 If you wish to marry her , you must first set her free , and this I will help you to do .
6 I will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the King of the Eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the King of the Foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the King of the Fishes by your side .
7 These will help you if you are in any difficulty .
8 Now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . '
9 She handed him the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed her up .
10 Then it dawned on the Prince that he had been speaking to a good fairy , and putting the little bell carefully in his pocket , he rode home and told his father that he meant to set the daughter of the Flower Queen free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid .
11 So the next morning the Prince mounted his fine horse and left his home .
12 He had roamed round the world for a whole year , and his horse had died of exhaustion , while he himself had suffered much from want and misery , but still he had come on no trace of her he was in search of .
13 At last one day he came to a hut , in front of which sat a very old man .
14 The Prince asked him , ` Do you not know where the Dragon lives who keeps the daughter of the Flower Queen prisoner ? '
15 ` No , I do not , ' answered the old man .
16 ` But if you go straight along this road for a year , you will reach a hut where my father lives , and possibly he may be able to tell you . '
17 The Prince thanked him for his information , and continued his journey for a whole year along the same road , and at the end of it came to the little hut , where he found a very old man .
18 He asked him the same question , and the old man answered , ` No , I do not know where the Dragon lives .
19 But go straight along this road for another year , and you will come to a hut in which my father lives .
20 I know he can tell you . '
21 And so the Prince wandered on for another year , always on the same road , and at last reached the XXXXX where he found the third old man .	hut		difficulty|exhaustion|heaven|home|hut|journey|man|misery|morning|road

7 What was to be done now ?
8 The King determined to think of a still more impossible task .

1 Little Toomai lay back and slept all through the long afternoon and into the twilight , and while he slept Petersen Sahib and Machua Appa followed the track of the two elephants for fifteen miles across the hills .
2 Petersen Sahib had spent eighteen years in catching elephants , and he had only once before found such a dance-place .
3 Machua Appa had no need to look twice at the clearing to see what had been done there , or to scratch with his toe in the packed , rammed earth .
4 `` The child speaks truth , '' said he .
5 `` All this was done last night , and I have counted seventy tracks crossing the river .
6 See , Sahib , where Pudmini 's leg-iron cut the bark of that tree !
7 Yes ; she was there too . ''
8 They looked at one another and up and down , and they wondered .
9 For the ways of elephants are beyond the wit of any man , black or white , to fathom .
10 `` Forty years and five , '' said Machua Appa , `` have I followed my lord , the elephant , but never have I heard that any child of man had seen what this child has seen .
11 By all the Gods of the Hills , it is -- what can we say ? ''
12 and he shook his head .
13 When they got back to camp it was time for the evening meal .
14 Petersen Sahib ate alone in his tent , but he gave orders that the camp should have two sheep and some fowls , as well as a double ration of flour and rice and salt , for he knew that there would be a feast .
15 Big Toomai had come up hotfoot from the camp in the plains to search for his son and his elephant , and now that he had found them he looked at them as though he were afraid of them both .
16 And there was a feast by the blazing campfires in front of the lines of picketed elephants , and Little Toomai was the hero of it all .
17 And the big brown elephant catchers , the trackers and drivers and ropers , and the men who know all the secrets of breaking the wildest elephants , passed him from one to the other , and they marked his forehead with blood from the breast of a newly killed jungle-cock , to show that he was a forester , initiated and free of all the jungles .
18 And at last , when the flames died down , and the red light of the logs made the elephants look as though they had been dipped in blood too , Machua Appa , the head of all the drivers of all the Keddahs -- Machua Appa , Petersen Sahib 's other self , who had never seen a made road in forty years : Machua Appa , who was so great that he had no other name than Machua Appa , -- leaped to his feet , with Little Toomai held high in the air above his head , and shouted : `` Listen , my brothers .
19 Listen , too , you my lords in the lines there , for I , Machua Appa , am speaking !
20 This little one shall no more be called Little Toomai , but Toomai of the Elephants , as his great-grandfather was called before him .
21 What never man has seen he has seen through the long night , and the favor of the elephant-folk and of the XXXXX of the Jungles is with him .	Gods		Gods|cut|great-grandfather|light|lines|miles|plains|son|time|toe

8 There were once a King and a Queen , and they had a son called Sigurd , who was very strong and active , and good-looking .

10 Sigurd was not averse to this , and asked his father where he thought it best to look for a wife .
11 The King answered that in a certain country there was a King who had a beautiful daughter , and he thought it would be most desirable if Sigurd could get her .
12 So the two parted , and Sigurd prepared for the journey , and went to where his father had directed him .
13 He came to the King and asked his daughter 's hand , which he readily granted him , but only on the condition that he should remain there as long as he could , for the King himself was not strong and not very able to govern his kingdom .
14 Sigurd accepted this condition , but added that he would have to get leave to go home again to his own country when he heard news of his father 's death .
15 After that Sigurd married the Princess , and helped his father-in-law to govern the kingdom .
16 He and the Princess loved each other dearly , and after a year a son came to them , who was two years old when word came to Sigurd that his father was dead .

13 She left Frances in peace .

1 `` Take him away , '' he said to Father Wolf , `` and train him as befits one of the Free People . ''
2 And that is how Mowgli was entered into the Seeonee Wolf Pack for the price of a bull and on Baloo 's good word .
3 Now you must be content to skip ten or eleven whole years , and only guess at all the wonderful life that Mowgli led among the wolves , because if it were written out it would fill ever so many books .
4 He grew up with the cubs , though they , of course , were grown wolves almost before he was a child .
5 And Father Wolf taught him his business , and the meaning of things in the jungle , till every rustle in the grass , every breath of the warm night air , every note of the owls above his head , every scratch of a bat 's claws as it roosted for a while in a tree , and every splash of every little fish jumping in a pool meant just as much to him as the work of his office means to a business man .
6 When he was not learning he sat out in the sun and slept , and ate and went to sleep again .
7 When he felt dirty or hot he swam in the forest pools ; and when he wanted honey -LRB- Baloo told him that honey and nuts were just as pleasant to eat as raw meat -RRB- he climbed up for it , and that Bagheera showed him how to do .
8 Bagheera would lie out on a branch and call , `` Come along , Little Brother , '' and at first Mowgli would cling like the sloth , but afterward he would fling himself through the branches almost as boldly as the gray ape .
9 He took his place at the Council Rock , too , when the Pack met , and there he discovered that if he stared hard at any wolf , the wolf would be forced to drop his eyes , and so he used to stare for fun .
10 At other times he would pick the long thorns out of the pads of his friends , for wolves suffer terribly from thorns and burs in their coats .
11 He would go down the hillside into the cultivated lands by night , and look very curiously at the villagers in their huts , but he had a mistrust of men because Bagheera showed him a square box with a drop gate so cunningly hidden in the jungle that he nearly walked into it , and told him that it was a trap .
12 He loved better than anything else to go with Bagheera into the dark warm heart of the forest , to sleep all through the drowsy day , and at night see how Bagheera did his killing .
13 Bagheera killed right and left as he felt hungry , and so did Mowgli -- with one exception .
14 As soon as he was old enough to understand things , Bagheera told him that he must never touch cattle because he had been bought into the Pack at the price of a bull 's life .
15 `` All the jungle is thine , '' said Bagheera , `` and thou canst kill everything that thou art strong enough to kill ; but for the sake of the bull that bought thee thou must never kill or eat any cattle young or old .
16 That is the Law of the Jungle . ''
17 Mowgli obeyed faithfully .
18 And he grew and grew strong as a boy must grow who does not know that he is learning any lessons , and who has nothing in the world to think of except things to eat .
19 Mother Wolf told him once or twice that Shere Khan was not a creature to be trusted , and that some day he must kill Shere Khan .
20 But though a young wolf would have remembered that advice every hour , Mowgli forgot it because he was only a boy -- though he would have called himself a wolf if he had been able to speak in any human tongue .
21 Shere Khan was always crossing his path in the jungle , for as Akela grew older and feebler the lame tiger had come to be great friends with the younger XXXXX of the Pack , who followed him for scraps , a thing Akela would never have allowed if he had dared to push his authority to the proper bounds .	wolves		befits|books|branches|coats|everything|jungle|life|pads|price|wolves

1 No other water was at hand except that in the two bottles .

3 Their farewells were full of tenderness ; the Prince made the most ardent and sincere protestations , and promised to neglect nothing which might help to deliver his dear Fairer-than-a-Fairy from her captivity , and implored her to consent to their marriage as soon as they should both be free .
4 The Princess , on her side , vowed to have no other husband , and declared herself willing to brave death itself in order to rejoin him .
5 They were not allowed much time for their adieus ; the Rainbow vanished , and the Princess , resolved to run all risks , started off at once , taking nothing with her but her dog , her cat , a sprig of myrtle , and the stone which the wife of Locrinos gave her .
6 When Lagree became aware of her prisoner 's flight she was furious , and set off at full speed in pursuit .
7 She overtook her just as the poor girl , overcome by fatigue , had lain down to rest in a cave which the stone had formed itself into to shelter her .
8 The little dog who was watching her mistress promptly flew at Lagree and bit her so severely that she stumbled against a corner of the cave and broke off her only tooth .
9 Before she had recovered from the pain and rage this caused her , the Princess had time to escape , and was some way on her road .
10 Fear gave her strength for some time , but at last she could go no further , and sank down to rest .
11 As she did so , the sprig of myrtle she carried touched the ground , and immediately a green and shady bower sprang up round her , in which she hoped to sleep in peace .
12 But Lagree had not given up her pursuit , and arrived just as Fairer-than-a-Fairy had fallen fast asleep .
13 This time she made sure of catching her victim , but the cat spied her out , and , springing from one of the boughs of the arbour she flew at Lagree 's face and tore out her only eye , thus delivering the Princess for ever from her persecutor .
14 One might have thought that all would now be well , but no sooner had Lagree been put to fight than our heroine was overwhelmed with hunger and thirst .
15 She felt as though she should certainly expire , and it was with some difficulty that she dragged herself as far as a pretty little green and white house , which stood at no great distance .
16 Here she was received by a beautiful lady dressed in green and white to match the house , which apparently belonged to her , and of which she seemed the only inhabitant .
17 She greeted the fainting Princess most kindly , gave her an excellent supper , and after a long night 's rest in a delightful bed told her that after many troubles she should finally attain her desire .
18 As the green and white lady took leave of the Princess she gave her a nut , desiring her only to open it in the most urgent need .
19 After a long and tiring journey Fairer-than-a-Fairy was once more received in a house , and by a lady exactly like the one she had quitted .
20 Here again she received a present with the same injunctions , but instead of a nut this lady gave her a golden pomegranate .

1 It had been raining heavily for one whole month -- raining on a camp of thirty thousand men and thousands of camels , elephants , horses , bullocks , and mules all gathered together at a place called Rawal Pindi , to be reviewed by the Viceroy of India .
2 He was receiving a visit from the Amir of Afghanistan -- a wild king of a very wild country .
3 The Amir had brought with him for a bodyguard eight hundred men and horses who had never seen a camp or a locomotive before in their lives -- savage men and savage horses from somewhere at the back of Central Asia .
4 Every night a mob of these horses would be sure to break their heel ropes and stampede up and down the camp through the mud in the dark , or the camels would break loose and run about and fall over the ropes of the tents , and you can imagine how pleasant that was for men trying to go to sleep .
5 My tent lay far away from the camel lines , and I thought it was safe .
6 But one night a man popped his head in and shouted , `` Get out , quick !
7 They 're coming !
8 My tent 's gone ! ''
9 I knew who `` they '' were , so I put on my boots and waterproof and scuttled out into the slush .
10 Little Vixen , my fox terrier , went out through the other side ; and then there was a roaring and a grunting and bubbling , and I saw the tent cave in , as the pole snapped , and begin to dance about like a mad ghost .
11 A camel had blundered into it , and wet and angry as I was , I could not help laughing .
12 Then I ran on , because I did not know how many camels might have got loose , and before long I was out of sight of the camp , plowing my way through the mud .
13 At last I fell over the tail-end of a gun , and by that knew I was somewhere near the artillery lines where the cannon were stacked at night .
14 As I did not want to plowter about any more in the drizzle and the dark , I put my waterproof over the muzzle of one gun , and made a sort of wigwam with two or three rammers that I found , and lay along the tail of another gun , wondering where Vixen had got to , and where I might be .
15 Just as I was getting ready to go to sleep I heard a jingle of harness and a grunt , and a mule passed me shaking his wet ears .
16 He belonged to a screw-gun battery , for I could hear the rattle of the straps and rings and chains and things on his saddle pad .
17 The screw-guns are tiny little cannon made in two pieces , that are screwed together when the time comes to use them .
18 They are taken up mountains , anywhere that a mule can find a road , and they are very useful for fighting in rocky country .
19 Behind the mule there was a camel , with his big soft feet squelching and slipping in the mud , and his neck bobbing to and fro like a strayed hen 's .
20 Luckily , I knew enough of beast language -- not wild-beast language , but camp-beast language , of course -- from the natives to know what he was saying .
21 He must have been the one that flopped into my XXXXX , for he called to the mule , `` What shall I do ?	tent		camp|country|hen|king|lives|men|sight|sort|tail|tent

1 They hurried as quickly as they could to the old King , who received them with joy and gladness .
2 On the following day a most gorgeous wedding feast was held , and as far as we know the Prince and his bride lived happily for ever afterwards .
3 THE DEAD WIFE -LRB- 20 -RRB- -LRB- 20 -RRB- From the Iroquois .
4 Once upon a time there were a man and his wife who lived in the forest , very far from the rest of the tribe .
5 Very often they spent the day in hunting together , but after a while the wife found that she had so many things to do that she was obliged to stay at home ; so he went alone , though he found that when his wife was not with him he never had any luck .
6 One day , when he was away hunting , the woman fell ill , and in a few days she died .
7 Her husband grieved bitterly , and buried her in the house where she had passed her life ; but as the time went on he felt so lonely without her that he made a wooden doll about her height and size for company , and dressed it in her clothes .
8 He seated it in front of the fire , and tried to think he had his wife back again .
9 The next day he went out to hunt , and when he came home the first thing he did was to go up to the doll and brush off some of the ashes from the fire which had fallen on its face .
10 But he was very busy now , for he had to cook and mend , besides getting food , for there was no one to help him .
11 And so a whole year passed away .
12 At the end of that time he came back from hunting one night and found some wood by the door and a fire within .
13 The next night there was not only wood and fire , but a piece of meat in the kettle , nearly ready for eating .
14 He searched all about to see who could have done this , but could find no one .
15 The next time he went to hunt he took care not to go far , and came in quite early .
16 And while he was still a long way off he saw a woman going into the house with wood on her shoulders .
17 So he made haste , and opened the door quickly , and instead of the wooden doll , his wife sat in front of the fire .
18 Then she spoke to him and said , ` The Great Spirit felt sorry for you , because you would not be comforted , so he let me come back to you , but you must not stretch out your hand to touch me till we have seen the rest of our people .
19 If you do , I shall die . '
20 So the man listened to her words , and the woman dwelt there , and brought the wood and kindled the fire , till one day her husband said to her , ` It is now two years since you died .
21 Let us now go back to our XXXXX .	tribe		brush|face|front|haste|hunting|joy|one|thing|tribe|wife
