8 THE NIGHTINGALE In China , as I daresay you know , the Emperor is a Chinaman , and all his courtiers are also Chinamen .
9 The story I am going to tell you happened many years ago , but it is worth while for you to listen to it , before it is forgotten .
10 The Emperor 's Palace was the most splendid in the world , all made of priceless porcelain , but so brittle and delicate that you had to take great care how you touched it .
11 In the garden were the most beautiful flowers , and on the loveliest of them were tied silver bells which tinkled , so that if you passed you could not help looking at the flowers .
12 Everything in the Emperor 's garden was admirably arranged with a view to effect ; and the garden was so large that even the gardener himself did not know where it ended .
13 If you ever got beyond it , you came to a stately forest with great trees and deep lakes in it .
14 The forest sloped down to the sea , which was a clear blue .
15 Large ships could sail under the boughs of the trees , and in these trees there lived a Nightingale .
16 She sang so beautifully that even the poor fisherman who had so much to do stood and listened when he came at night to cast his nets .
17 ` How beautiful it is ! '
18 he said ; but he had to attend to his work , and forgot about the bird .
19 But when she sang the next night and the fisherman came there again , he said the same thing , ` How beautiful it is ! '
20 From all the countries round came travellers to the Emperor 's town , who were astonished at the Palace and the garden .
21 But when they heard the XXXXX they all said , ` This is the finest thing after all ! '	Nightingale		Nightingale|Palace|blue|courtiers|farewell|heart|lakes|thing|world|years

3 HERMOD AND HADVOR -LRB- 32 -RRB- -LRB- 32 -RRB- From the Icelandic .
4 Once upon a time there were a King and a Queen who had an only daughter , called Hadvor , who was fair and beautiful , and being an only child , was heir to the kingdom .
5 The King and Queen had also a foster son , named Hermod , who was just about the same age as Hadvor , and was good-looking , as well as clever at most things .
6 Hermod and Hadvor often played together while they were children , and liked each other so much that while they were still young they secretly plighted their troth to each other .
7 As time went on the Queen fell sick , and suspecting that it was her last illness , sent for the King to come to her .
8 When he came she told him that she had no long time to live , and therefore wished to ask one thing of him , which was , that if he married another wife he should promise to take no other one than the Queen of Hetland the Good .
9 The King gave the promise , and thereafter the Queen died .
10 Time went past , and the King , growing tired of living alone , fitted out his ship and sailed out to sea .
11 As he sailed there came upon him so thick a mist that he altogether lost his bearings , but after long trouble he found land .
12 There he laid his ship to , and went on shore all alone .
13 After walking for some time he came to a forest , into which he went a little way and stopped .
14 Then he heard sweet music from a harp , and went in the direction of the sound until he came to a clearing , and there he saw three women , one of whom sat on a golden chair , and was beautifully and grandly dressed ; she held a harp in her hands , and was very sorrowful .
15 The second was also finely dressed , but younger in appearance , and also sat on a chair , but it was not so grand as the first one 's .
16 The third stood beside them , and was very pretty to look at ; she had a green cloak over her other clothes , and it was easy to see that she was maid to the other two .
17 After the King had looked at them for a little he went forward and saluted them .
18 The one that sat on the golden chair asked him who he was and where he was going ; and he told her all the story -- how he was a king , and had lost his queen , and was now on his way to Hetland the Good , to ask the Queen of that country in marriage .
19 She answered that fortune had contrived this wonderfully , for pirates had plundered Hetland and killed the King , and she had fled from the land in terror , and had come hither after great trouble , and she was the very person he was looking for , and the others were her daughter and maid .
20 The King immediately asked her hand ; she gladly received his proposal and accepted him at once .
21 Thereafter they all set out , and made their way to the XXXXX ; and after that nothing is told of their voyage until the King reached his own country .	ship		chair|child|clearing|cloak|hand|music|servants|ship|shore|story

1 One day the Prince and his suite went out for a ride in a wood where his father sometimes held a hunt .
2 Their way led through a stream whose banks were overgrown with thick brushwood .
3 Just as the horsemen were about to ford the river , a hare , startled by the sound of the horses ' hoofs , started up from the grass and ran towards the thicket .
4 The young Prince pursued the little creature , and had almost overtaken it , when the girth of his saddle suddenly broke in two and he fell heavily to the ground .
5 No sooner had his foot touched the earth than he disappeared before the eyes of the horrified courtiers .
6 They sought for him far and near , but all in vain , and they were forced to recognise the power of the evil Fairy , against which the Queen had warned them on her death-bed .
7 The old King was much grieved when they brought him the news of his son 's disappearance , but as he could do nothing to free him from his fate , he gave himself up to an old age of grief and loneliness , cherishing at the same time the hope that some lucky chance might one day deliver the youth out of the hands of his enemy .
8 Hardly had the Prince touched the ground than he felt himself violently seized by an unseen power , and hurried away he knew not whither .
9 A whole new world stretched out before him , quite unlike the one he had left .
10 A splendid castle surrounded by a huge lake was the abode of the Fairy , and the only approach to it was over a bridge of clouds .
11 On the other side of the lake high mountains rose up , and dark woods stretched along the banks ; over all hung a thick mist , and deep silence reigned everywhere .
12 No sooner had the Fairy reached her own domain than she made herself visible , and turning to the Prince she told him that unless he obeyed all her commands down to the minutest detail he would be severely punished .
13 Then she gave him an axe made of glass , and bade him cross the bridge of clouds and go into the wood beyond and cut down all the trees there before sunset .
14 At the same time she cautioned him with many angry words against speaking to a black girl he would most likely meet in the wood .
15 The Prince listened to her words meekly , and when she had finished took up the glass axe and set out for the forest .
16 At every step he seemed to sink into the clouds , but fear gave wings to his feet , and he crossed the lake in safety and set to work at once .
17 But no sooner had he struck the first blow with his axe than it broke into a thousand pieces against the tree .
18 The poor youth was so terrified he did not know what to do , for he was in mortal dread of the punishment the wicked old Fairy would inflict on him .
19 He wandered to and fro in the wood , not knowing where he was going , and at last , worn out by fatigue and misery , he sank on the ground and fell fast asleep .
20 He did not know how long he had slept when a sudden sound awoke him , and opening his eyes he saw a black girl standing beside him .

1 He had almost forgotten the days when he won Mother Wolf in fair fight from five other wolves , when she ran in the Pack and was not called The Demon for compliment 's sake .
2 Shere Khan might have faced Father Wolf , but he could not stand up against Mother Wolf , for he knew that where he was she had all the advantage of the ground , and would fight to the death .
3 So he backed out of the cave mouth growling , and when he was clear he shouted : `` Each dog barks in his own yard !
4 We will see what the Pack will say to this fostering of man-cubs .
5 The cub is mine , and to my teeth he will come in the end , O bush-tailed thieves ! ''

11 `` He came naked , by night , alone and very hungry ; yet he was not afraid !
12 Look , he has pushed one of my babes to one side already .
13 And that lame butcher would have killed him and would have run off to the Waingunga while the villagers here hunted through all our lairs in revenge !
14 Keep him ?
15 Assuredly I will keep him .
16 Lie still , little frog .
17 O thou Mowgli -- for Mowgli the Frog I will call thee -- the time will come when thou wilt hunt Shere Khan as he has hunted thee . ''
18 `` But what will our Pack say ? ''
19 said Father Wolf .
20 The Law of the Jungle lays down very clearly that any wolf may , when he marries , withdraw from the Pack he belongs to .
21 But as soon as his XXXXX are old enough to stand on their feet he must bring them to the Pack Council , which is generally held once a month at full moon , in order that the other wolves may identify them .	cubs		Frog|Lie|O|cubs|sake|thieves|truth|villagers|wolf|wolves

1 He soon finished the skinning , and went to the water to wash the blood off his hands .
2 He had hardly dipped them in the pond when the nixy rose up in the water , and seizing him in her wet arms she dragged him down with her under the waves .
3 When the hunter did not come home in the evening his wife grew very anxious , and when his game bag was found close to the mill-pond she guessed at once what had befallen him .
4 She was nearly beside herself with grief , and roamed round and round the pond calling on her husband without ceasing .
5 At last , worn out with sorrow and fatigue , she fell asleep and dreamt that she was wandering along a flowery meadow , when she came to a hut where she found an old witch , who promised to restore her husband to her .
6 When she awoke next morning she determined to set out and find the witch ; so she wandered on for many a day , and at last she reached the flowery meadow and found the hut where the old witch lived .
7 The poor wife told her all that had happened and how she had been told in a dream of the witch 's power to help her .
8 The witch counselled her to go to the pond the first time there was a full moon , and to comb her black hair with a golden comb , and then to place the comb on the bank .
9 The hunter 's wife gave the witch a handsome present , thanked her heartily , and returned home .
10 Time dragged heavily till the time of the full moon , but it passed at last , and as soon as it rose the young wife went to the pond , combed her black hair with a golden comb , and when she had finished , placed the comb on the bank ; then she watched the water impatiently .
11 Soon she heard a rushing sound , and a big wave rose suddenly and swept the comb off the bank , and a minute after the head of her husband rose from the pond and gazed sadly at her .
12 But immediately another wave came , and the head sank back into the water without having said a word .
13 The pond lay still and motionless , glittering in the moonshine , and the hunter 's wife was not a bit better off than she had been before .
14 In despair she wandered about for days and nights , and at last , worn out by fatigue , she sank once more into a deep sleep , and dreamt exactly the same dream about the old witch .
15 So next morning she went again to the flowery meadow and sought the witch in her hut , and told her of her grief .
16 The old woman counselled her to go to the mill-pond the next full moon and play upon a golden flute , and then to lay the flute on the bank .
17 As soon as the next moon was full the hunter 's wife went to the mill-pond , played on a golden flute , and when she had finished placed it on the bank .
18 Then a rushing sound was heard , and a wave swept the flute off the bank , and soon the head of the hunter appeared and rose up higher and higher till he was half out of the water .
19 Then he gazed sadly at his wife and stretched out his arms towards her .
20 But another rushing wave arose and dragged him under once more .
21 The hunter 's wife , who had stood on the bank full of joy and hope , sank into despair when she saw her XXXXX snatched away again before her eyes .	husband		dream|hunter|husband|sleep|sound|time|water|wave|witch|woman

1 It was such a pretty sight !
2 She could sing , too , with a voice more soft and sweet than had ever been heard before .
3 One night , when she was lying in her pretty little bed , an old toad crept in through a broken pane in the window .
4 She was very ugly , clumsy , and clammy ; she hopped on to the table where Thumbelina lay asleep under the red rose-leaf .
5 ` This would make a beautiful wife for my son , ' said the toad , taking up the walnut-shell , with Thumbelina inside , and hopping with it through the window into the garden .
6 There flowed a great wide stream , with slippery and marshy banks ; here the toad lived with her son .
7 Ugh !
8 how ugly and clammy he was , just like his mother !
9 ` Croak , croak , croak ! '
10 was all he could say when he saw the pretty little girl in the walnut-shell .
11 ` Do n't talk so load , or you 'll wake her , ' said the old toad .
12 ` She might escape us even now ; she is as light as a feather .
13 We will put her at once on a broad water-lily leaf in the stream .
14 That will be quite an island for her ; she is so small and light .
15 She ca n't run away from us there , whilst we are preparing the guest-chamber under the marsh where she shall live . '
16 Outside in the brook grew many water-lilies , with broad green leaves , which looked as if they were swimming about on the water .
17 The leaf farthest away was the largest , and to this the old toad swam with Thumbelina in her walnut-shell .
18 The tiny Thumbelina woke up very early in the morning , and when she saw where she was she began to cry bitterly ; for on every side of the great green leaf was water , and she could not get to the land .
19 The old toad was down under the marsh , decorating her room with rushes and yellow marigold leaves , to make it very grand for her new daughter-in-law ; then she swam out with her ugly son to the leaf where Thumbelina lay .
20 She wanted to fetch the pretty cradle to put it into her room before Thumbelina herself came there .

1 He saw the glittering palace , which by the pale rays of the moon looked like a dim lamp ; and he saw the high windows , and round one of them a balcony in which the beautiful Princess sat lost in sad thoughts .
2 Then the boy saw that he was close to the apple-tree , and drawing a small knife from his belt , he cut off both the eagle 's feet .
3 The bird rose up in the air in its agony and vanished into the clouds , and the youth fell on to the broad branches of the apple-tree .
4 Then he drew out the claws of the eagle 's feet that had remained in his flesh , and put the peel of one of the golden apples on the wound , and in one moment it was healed and well again .
5 He pulled several of the beautiful apples and put them in his pocket ; then he entered the castle .
6 The door was guarded by a great dragon , but as soon as he threw an apple at it , the beast vanished .
7 At the same moment a gate opened , and the youth perceived a courtyard full of flowers and beautiful trees , and on a balcony sat the lovely enchanted Princess with her retinue .
8 As soon as she saw the youth , she ran towards him and greeted him as her husband and master .
9 She gave him all her treasures , and the youth became a rich and mighty ruler .
10 But he never returned to the earth , for only the mighty eagle , who had been the guardian of the Princess and of the castle , could have carried on his wings the enormous treasure down to the world .
11 But as the eagle had lost its feet it died , and its body was found in a wood on the Glass Mountain .
12 ... .
13 .
14 One day when the youth was strolling about in the palace garden with the Princess , his wife , he looked down over the edge of the Glass Mountain and saw to his astonishment a great number of people gathered there .
15 He blew his silver whistle , and the swallow who acted as messenger in the golden castle flew past .
16 ` Fly down and ask what the matter is , ' he said to the little bird , who sped off like lightning and soon returned saying : ` The blood of the eagle has restored all the people below to life .
17 All those who have perished on this mountain are awakening up to-day , as it were from a sleep , and are mounting their horses , and the whole population are gazing on this unheard-of wonder with joy and amazement . '
18 ALPHEGE , OR THE GREEN MONKEY Many years ago there lived a King , who was twice married .
19 His first wife , a good and beautiful woman , died at the birth of her little son , and the King her husband was so overwhelmed with grief at her loss that his only comfort was in the sight of his heir .

1 ` Never fear , little mother , ' answered Martin ; ` trust me , and you will see all will be well .
2 You may go to sleep with a quiet mind . '
3 And , stepping to the front of the hut , Martin threw his ring from the palm of one hand into the other , upon which twelve youths instantly appeared , and demanded what he wanted them to do .
4 Then he told them the King 's commands , and they answered that by next morning all should be accomplished exactly as the King had ordered .
5 Next morning when the King awoke , and looked out of his window , to his amazement he beheld a magnificent castle , just opposite his own palace , and joined to it a bridge of pure crystal .
6 At each side of the bridge trees were growing , from whose branches hung golden and silver apples , among which birds of Paradise perched .
7 At the right , gleaming in the sun , were the five golden cupolas of a splendid church , whose bells rang out , as if they would summon people from all corners of the earth to come and behold the wonder .
8 Now , though the King would much rather have seen his future son-in-law tarred , feathered , and burnt at the stake , he remembered his royal oath , and had to make the best of a bad business .
9 So he took heart of grace , and made Martin a Duke , and gave his daughter a rich dowry , and prepared the grandest wedding-feast that had ever been seen , so that to this day the old people in the country still talk of it .
10 After the wedding Martin and his royal bride went to dwell in the magnificent new palace , and here Martin lived in the greatest comfort and luxury , such luxury as he had never imagined .
11 But though he was as happy as the day was long , and as merry as a grig , the King 's daughter fretted all day , thinking of the indignity that had been done her in making her marry Martin , the poor widow 's son , instead of a rich young Prince from a foreign country .
12 So unhappy was she that she spent all her time wondering how she should get rid of her undesirable husband .
13 And first she determined to learn the secret of his power , and , with flattering , caressing words , she tried to coax him to tell her how he was so clever that there was nothing in the world that he could not do .
14 At first he would tell her nothing ; but once , when he was in a yielding mood , she approached him with a winning smile on her lovely face , and , speaking flattering words to him , she gave him a potion to drink , with a sweet , strong taste .
15 And when he had drunk it Martin 's lips were unsealed , and he told her that all his power lay in the magic ring that he wore on his finger , and he described to her how to use it , and , still speaking , he fell into a deep sleep .
16 And when she saw that the potion had worked , and that he was sound asleep , the Princess took the magic ring from his finger , and , going into the courtyard , she threw it from the palm of one hand into the other .
17 On the instant the twelve youths appeared , and asked her what she commanded them to do .
18 Then she told them that by the next morning they were to do away with the castle , and the bridge , and the church , and put in their stead the humble hut in which Martin used to live with his mother , and that while he slept her husband was to be carried to his old lowly room ; and that they were to bear her away to the utmost ends of the earth , where an old King lived who would make her welcome in his palace , and surround her with the state that befitted a royal Princess .
19 ` You shall be obeyed , ' answered the twelve youths at the same moment .
20 And lo and behold !
21 the following morning , when the King awoke and looked out of his window he beheld to his amazement that the palace , bridge , church , and trees had all vanished , and there was XXXXX in their place but a bare , miserable-looking hut .	nothing		courtyard|earth|lo|merry|mood|mother|nothing|state|stead|widow

1 ` Grieved as I was over the theft , I did not punish the gardener , of whose fidelity I was well assured , but I determined to pluck off all the fruit in the following year before it was ripe , as I had not much belief in the magician 's warning . '
2 I carried out my intention , and had all the fruit picked off the tree , but when I tasted one of the apples it was bitter and unpleasant , and the next morning the rest of the fruit had all rotted away .
3 ` After this I had the beautiful fruit of these trees carefully guarded by my most faithful servants ; but every year , on this very night , the fruit was plucked and stolen by an invisible hand , and next morning not a single apple remained on the trees .
4 For some time past I have given up even having the trees watched . '
5 When the King had finished his story , Szabo , his eldest son , said to him : ` Forgive me , father , if I say I think you are mistaken .
6 I am sure there are many men in your kingdom who could protect these trees from the cunning arts of a thieving magician ; I myself , who as your eldest son claim the first right to do so , will mount guard over the fruit this very night . '
7 The King consented , and as soon as evening drew on Szabo climbed up on to one of the trees , determined to protect the fruit even if it cost him his life .
8 So he kept watch half the night ; but a little after midnight he was overcome by an irresistible drowsiness , and fell fast asleep .
9 He did not awake till it was bright daylight , and all the fruit on the trees had vanished .
10 The following year Warza , the second brother , tried his luck , but with the same result .
11 Then it came to the turn of the third and youngest son .
12 Iwanich was not the least discouraged by the failure of his elder brothers , though they were both much older and stronger than he was , and when night came climbed up the tree as they had done , The moon had risen , and with her soft light lit up the whole neighbourhood , so that the observant Prince could distinguish the smallest object distinctly .
13 At midnight a gentle west wind shook the tree , and at the same moment a snow-white swan-like bird sank down gently on his breast .
14 The Prince hastily seized the bird 's wings in his hands , when , lo !
15 to his astonishment he found he was holding in his arms not a bird but the most beautiful girl he had ever seen .
16 ` You need not fear Militza , ' said the beautiful girl , looking at the Prince with friendly eyes .
17 ` An evil magician has not robbed you of your fruit , but he stole the seed from my mother , and thereby caused her death .
18 When she was dying she bade me take the fruit , which you have no right to possess , from the trees every year as soon as it was ripe .
19 This I would have done to-night too , if you had not seized me with such force , and so broken the spell I was under . '
20 Iwanich , who had been prepared to meet a terrible magician and not a lovely girl , fell desperately in love with her .
21 They spent the XXXXX of the night in pleasant conversation , and when Militza wished to go away he begged her not to leave him . '	rest		bird|fidelity|fruit|intention|luck|morning|rest|seed|servants|trees

1 I know who I am , and that is enough for me ! '
2 One day something thick lay near her which glittered so brightly that the Darning-needle thought it must be a diamond .
3 But it was a bit of bottle-glass , and because it sparkled the Darning-needle spoke to it , and gave herself out as a breast-pin .
4 ` No doubt you are a diamond ? '
5 ` Yes , something of that kind ! '
6 And each believed that the other was something very costly ; and they both said how very proud the world must be of them . '
7 I have come from a lady 's work-box , ' said Darning-needle , ` and this lady was a cook ; she had five fingers on each hand ; anything so proud as these fingers I have never seen !
8 And yet they were only there to take me out of the work-box and to put me back again ! '
9 ` Were they of noble birth , then ? '
10 asked the bit of bottle-glass .
11 ` Of noble birth ! '
12 said the Darning-needle ; ` no indeed , but proud !
13 They were five brothers , all called '' Fingers . ''
14 They held themselves proudly one against the other , although they were of different sizes .
15 The outside one , the Thumb , was short and fat ; he was outside the rank , and had only one bend in his back , and could only make one bow ; but he said that if he were cut off from a man that he was no longer any use as a soldier .
16 Dip-into-everything , the second finger , dipped into sweet things as well as sour things , pointed to the sun and the moon , and guided the pen when they wrote .
17 Longman , the third , looked at the others over his shoulder .
18 Goldband , the fourth , had a gold sash round his waist ; and little Playman did nothing at all , and was the more proud .

1 He made his bound before he saw what it was he was jumping at , and then he tried to stop himself .
2 The result was that he shot up straight into the air for four or five feet , landing almost where he left ground .
3 `` Man ! ''
4 he snapped .
5 `` A man 's cub .
6 Look ! ''
7 Directly in front of him , holding on by a low branch , stood a naked brown baby who could just walk -- as soft and as dimpled a little atom as ever came to a wolf 's cave at night .
8 He looked up into Father Wolf 's face , and laughed .
9 `` Is that a man 's cub ? ''
10 said Mother Wolf .
11 `` I have never seen one .
12 Bring it here . ''
13 A Wolf accustomed to moving his own cubs can , if necessary , mouth an egg without breaking it , and though Father Wolf 's jaws closed right on the child 's back not a tooth even scratched the skin as he laid it down among the cubs .
14 `` How little !
15 How naked , and -- how bold ! ''
16 said Mother Wolf softly .

20 The hunter 's wife did as she was advised , and the first night the moon was full she sat and spun with a golden spinning-wheel , and then left the wheel on the bank .

1 He ordered some nets to be prepared and painted of the same colours as the bird 's plumage , thinking that we are all easily caught by what is like ourselves .
2 In this he had to help him not only the fowlers by profession , but also his attendants , who excelled in this art .
3 For a man is not a courtier unless he can do everything .
4 After searching as usual for nearly a whole day Prince Saphir began to feel overcome with thirst .
5 He was too tired to go any farther , when happily he discovered a little way off a bubbling fountain of the clearest water .
6 Being an experienced traveller , he drew from his pocket a little cup -LRB- without which no one should ever take a journey -RRB- , and was just about to dip it in the water , when a lovely little green frog , much prettier than frogs generally are , jumped into the cup .
7 Far from admiring its beauty , Saphir shook it impatiently off ; but it was no good , for quick as lightning the frog jumped back again .
8 Saphir , who was raging with thirst , was just about to shake it off anew , when the little creature fixed upon him the most beautiful eyes in the world , and said , ' I am a friend of the bird you are seeking , and when you have quenched your thirst listen to me . '
9 So the Prince drank his fill , and then , by the command of the Little Green Frog , he lay down on the grass to rest himself .
10 ` Now , ' she began , ` be sure you do exactly in every respect what I tell you .
11 First you must call together your attendants , and order them to remain in a little hamlet close by until you want them .
12 Then go , quite alone , down a road that you will find on your right hand , looking southwards .
13 This road is planted all the way with cedars of Lebanon ; and after going down it a long way you will come at last to a magnificent castle .
14 And now , ' she went on , ` attend carefully to what I am going to say .
15 Take this tiny grain of sand , and put it into the ground as close as you can to the gate of the castle .
16 It has the virtue both of opening the gate and also of sending to sleep all the inhabitants .
17 Then go at once to the stable , and pay no heed to anything except what I tell you .
18 Choose the handsomest of all the horses , leap quickly on its back , and come to me as fast as you can .
19 Farewell , Prince ; I wish you good luck , ' and with these words the Little Frog plunged into the water and disappeared .
20 The Prince , who felt more hopeful than he had done since he left home , did precisely as he had been ordered .
21 He left his attendants in the hamlet , found the road the XXXXX had described to him , and followed it all alone , and at last he arrived at the gate of the castle , which was even more splendid than he had expected , for it was built of crystal , and all its ornaments were of massive gold .	frog		bird|close|courtier|eyes|fountain|frog|man|nets|profession|thirst

1 Last of all she took the Queen , put her into the boat , and said -- ` This spell I lay upon you , that you slacken not your course until you come to my brother in the Underworld . '
2 The Queen sat stunned and motionless , but the boat at once shot away from the ship with her , and before long she was out of sight .
3 When the boat could no longer be seen the child began to cry , and though the Witch tried to quiet it she could not manage it ; so she went below to where the King was sleeping with the child on her arm , and awakened him , scolding him for leaving them alone on deck , while he and all the crew were asleep .
4 It was great carelessness of him , she said , to leave no one to watch the ship with her .
5 Sigurd was greatly surprised to hear his Queen scold him so much , for she had never said an angry word to him before ; but he thought it was quite excusable in this case , and tried to quiet the child along with her , but it was no use .
6 Then he went and wakened the sailors , and bade them hoist the sails , for a breeze had sprung up and was blowing straight towards the harbour .
7 They soon reached the land which Sigurd was to rule over , and found all the people sorrowful for the old King 's death , but they became glad when they got Sigurd back to the Court , and made him King over them .
8 The King 's son , however , hardly ever stopped crying from the time he had been taken from his mother on the deck of the ship , although he had always been such a good child before , so that at last the King had to get a nurse for him -- one of the maids of the Court .
9 As soon as the child got into her charge he stopped crying , and behaved well as before .
10 After the sea-voyage it seemed to the King that the Queen had altered very much in many ways , and not for the better .
11 He thought her much more haughty and stubborn and difficult to deal with than she used to be .
12 Before long others began to notice this as well as the King .
13 In the Court there were two young fellows , one of eighteen years old , the other of nineteen , who were very fond of playing chess , and often sat long inside playing at it .
14 Their room was next the Queen 's , and often during the day they heard the Queen talking .
15 One day they paid more attention than usual when they heard her talk , and put their ears close to a crack in the wall between the rooms , and heard the Queen say quite plainly , ` When I yawn a little , then I am a nice little maiden ; when I yawn half-way , then I am half a troll ; and when I yawn fully , then I am a troll altogether . '
16 As she said this she yawned tremendously , and in a moment had put on the appearance of a fearfully ugly troll .
17 Then there came up through the floor of the room a three-headed Giant with a trough full of meat , who saluted her as his sister and set down the trough before her .
18 She began to eat out of it , and never stopped till she had finished it .
19 The young fellows saw all this going on , but did not hear the two of them say anything to each other .
20 They were astonished though at how greedily the Queen devoured the meat , and how much she ate of it , and were no longer surprised that she took so little when she sat at table with the King .
21 As soon as she had finished it the Giant disappeared with the XXXXX by the same way as he had come , and the Queen returned to her human shape .	trough		Underworld|charge|chess|child|deck|mother|talk|trough|wall|ways

1 The Monkey People !
2 Faugh ! ''
3 A fresh shower came down on their heads and the two trotted away , taking Mowgli with them .
4 What Baloo had said about the monkeys was perfectly true .
5 They belonged to the tree-tops , and as beasts very seldom look up , there was no occasion for the monkeys and the Jungle-People to cross each other 's path .
6 But whenever they found a sick wolf , or a wounded tiger , or bear , the monkeys would torment him , and would throw sticks and nuts at any beast for fun and in the hope of being noticed .
7 Then they would howl and shriek senseless songs , and invite the Jungle-People to climb up their trees and fight them , or would start furious battles over nothing among themselves , and leave the dead monkeys where the Jungle-People could see them .
8 They were always just going to have a leader , and laws and customs of their own , but they never did , because their memories would not hold over from day to day , and so they compromised things by making up a saying , `` What the Bandar-log think now the jungle will think later , '' and that comforted them a great deal .
9 None of the beasts could reach them , but on the other hand none of the beasts would notice them , and that was why they were so pleased when Mowgli came to play with them , and they heard how angry Baloo was .
10 They never meant to do any more -- the Bandar-log never mean anything at all ; but one of them invented what seemed to him a brilliant idea , and he told all the others that Mowgli would be a useful person to keep in the tribe , because he could weave sticks together for protection from the wind ; so , if they caught him , they could make him teach them .
11 Of course Mowgli , as a woodcutter 's child , inherited all sorts of instincts , and used to make little huts of fallen branches without thinking how he came to do it .
12 The Monkey-People , watching in the trees , considered his play most wonderful .
13 This time , they said , they were really going to have a leader and become the wisest people in the jungle -- so wise that everyone else would notice and envy them .
14 Therefore they followed Baloo and Bagheera and Mowgli through the jungle very quietly till it was time for the midday nap , and Mowgli , who was very much ashamed of himself , slept between the Panther and the Bear , resolving to have no more to do with the Monkey People .
15 The next thing he remembered was feeling hands on his legs and arms -- hard , strong , little hands -- and then a swash of branches in his face , and then he was staring down through the swaying boughs as Baloo woke the jungle with his deep cries and Bagheera bounded up the trunk with every tooth bared .
16 The Bandar-log howled with triumph and scuffled away to the upper branches where Bagheera dared not follow , shouting : `` He has noticed us !
17 Bagheera has noticed us .
18 All the Jungle-People admire us for our skill and our cunning . ''
19 Then they began their flight ; and the flight of the Monkey-People through tree-land is one of the things nobody can describe .
20 They have their regular roads and crossroads , up hills and down hills , all laid out from fifty to seventy or a hundred feet above ground , and by these they can travel even at night if necessary .
21 Two of the strongest monkeys caught Mowgli under the XXXXX and swung off with him through the treetops , twenty feet at a bound .	arms		None|arms|boughs|crossroads|flight|heads|howl|protection|shower|trees

1 he said .
2 Then he sat down beside us on the rocks at the Mermaid 's Pool and told us the whole story , and read his letter to us .
3 It was the most amazing thing .
4 It seems Father had had relations after all -- a brother and a sister in particular .
5 But when he was a young man he quarrelled with his brother , who did n't treat him very well -- but he 's been dead for years , so I wo n't say a word against him -- and had gone away from home .
6 He never went back , and he never even let them know he was living .
7 Father says that this was very wrong of him , and I suppose it was , since he says so ; but I do n't see how Father could do anything wrong .
8 Anyway , he had a sister Esther whom he loved very much ; but he felt bitter against her too , because he thought she took his brother 's part too much .
9 So , though a letter of hers , asking him to go back , did reach him , he never answered it , and he never heard anything more .
10 Years afterward he felt sorry and went back , but his brother was dead and his sister had gone away , and he could n't find out a single thing about her .
11 So much for that ; and now about the kite .
12 The letter Father had just received was from his sister , our Aunt Esther and the mother of Dick and Mimi .
13 She was living at a place hundreds of miles inland .
14 Her husband was dead and , as we found out later , although she did not say a word about it in the letter , she was very poor .
15 One day when Dick and Mimi were out in the woods looking for botany specimens they saw something funny in the top of a tree .
16 Dick climbed up and got it .
17 It was a big red kite with a patch on each side and names written on it .
18 They carried it home to their mother .
19 Dick has since told us that she turned as pale as the dead when she saw our names on it .
20 You see , Philippa was her mother 's name and Claude was her father 's .
21 And when she read the letter that was pasted over the hole in the kite she knew who we must be , for it was the very XXXXX she had written to her brother so long ago .	letter		Pool|anything|kite|letter|mother|name|names|part|patch|word

1 ` This would make a beautiful wife for my son , ' said the toad , taking up the walnut-shell , with Thumbelina inside , and hopping with it through the window into the garden .
2 There flowed a great wide stream , with slippery and marshy banks ; here the toad lived with her son .
3 Ugh !
4 how ugly and clammy he was , just like his mother !
5 ` Croak , croak , croak ! '
6 was all he could say when he saw the pretty little girl in the walnut-shell .
7 ` Do n't talk so load , or you 'll wake her , ' said the old toad .
8 ` She might escape us even now ; she is as light as a feather .
9 We will put her at once on a broad water-lily leaf in the stream .
10 That will be quite an island for her ; she is so small and light .
11 She ca n't run away from us there , whilst we are preparing the guest-chamber under the marsh where she shall live . '
12 Outside in the brook grew many water-lilies , with broad green leaves , which looked as if they were swimming about on the water .
13 The leaf farthest away was the largest , and to this the old toad swam with Thumbelina in her walnut-shell .
14 The tiny Thumbelina woke up very early in the morning , and when she saw where she was she began to cry bitterly ; for on every side of the great green leaf was water , and she could not get to the land .
15 The old toad was down under the marsh , decorating her room with rushes and yellow marigold leaves , to make it very grand for her new daughter-in-law ; then she swam out with her ugly son to the leaf where Thumbelina lay .
16 She wanted to fetch the pretty cradle to put it into her room before Thumbelina herself came there .
17 The old toad bowed low in the water before her , and said : ` Here is my son ; you shall marry him , and live in great magnificence down under the marsh . '
18 ` Croak , croak , croak ! '
19 was all that the son could say .
20 Then they took the neat little cradle and swam away with it ; but Thumbelina sat alone on the great green leaf and wept , for she did not want to live with the clammy toad , or marry her ugly son .
21 The little fishes swimming about under the XXXXX had seen the toad quite plainly , and heard what she had said ; so they put up their heads to see the little girl .	water		feather|girl|island|land|leaves|magnificence|mother|water|wife|window

3 But she swore to him that she would not tell who he was .
4 He then repeated his warning and went away .
5 In the evening , while the Princess , with her mother and sisters , was standing at the window , the Prince suddenly galloped past on his steed and threw her the golden apple .
6 Then her mother flew into a passion , gave her a box on the ear , and cried out , ` Does not even that prince please you , you fool ? '
7 The Princess in her fright exclaimed , ` That is the Crab himself ! '
8 Her mother was still more angry because she had not been told sooner , ran into her daughter 's room where the crab-shell was still lying , took it up and threw it into the fire .
9 Then the poor Princess cried bitterly , but it was of no use ; her husband did not come back .
10 Now we must leave the Princess and turn to the other persons in the story .
11 One day an old man went to a stream to dip in a crust of bread which he was going to eat , when a dog came out of the water , snatched the bread from his hand , and ran away .
12 The old man ran after him , but the dog reached a door , pushed it open , and ran in , the old man following him .
13 He did not overtake the dog , but found himself above a staircase , which he descended .
14 Then he saw before him a stately palace , and , entering , he found in a large hall a table set for twelve persons .
15 He hid himself in the hall behind a great picture , that he might see what would happen .
16 At noon he heard a great noise , so that he trembled with fear .
17 When he took courage to look out from behind the picture , he saw twelve eagles flying in .
18 At this sight his fear became still greater .
19 The eagles flew to the basin of a fountain that was there and bathed themselves , when suddenly they were changed into twelve handsome youths .
20 Now they seated themselves at the table , and one of them took up a goblet filled with wine , and said , ' A health to my father ! '

1 and other songs so prettily that the mole fell in love with her ; but he did not say anything , he was a very cautious man .
2 A short time before he had dug a long passage through the ground from his own house to that of his neighbour ; in this he gave the field-mouse and Thumbelina permission to walk as often as they liked .
3 But he begged them not to be afraid of the dead bird that lay in the passage : it was a real bird with beak and feathers , and must have died a little time ago , and now laid buried just where he had made his tunnel .
4 The mole took a piece of rotten wood in his mouth , for that glows like fire in the dark , and went in front , lighting them through the long dark passage .
5 When they came to the place where the dead bird lay , the mole put his broad nose against the ceiling and pushed a hole through , so that the daylight could shine down .
6 In the middle of the path lay a dead swallow , his pretty wings pressed close to his sides , his claws and head drawn under his feathers ; the poor bird had evidently died of cold .
7 Thumbelina was very sorry , for she was very fond of all little birds ; they had sung and twittered so beautifully to her all through the summer .
8 But the mole kicked him with his bandy legs and said : ` Now he ca n't sing any more !
9 It must be very miserable to be a little bird !
10 I 'm thankful that none of my little children are ; birds always starve in winter . '
11 ` Yes , you speak like a sensible man , ' said the field-mouse .
12 ` What has a bird , in spite of all his singing , in the winter-time ?
13 He must starve and freeze , and that must be very pleasant for him , I must say ! '
14 Thumbelina did not say anything ; but when the other two had passed on she bent down to the bird , brushed aside the feathers from his head , and kissed his closed eyes gently .
15 ` Perhaps it was he that sang to me so prettily in the summer , ' she thought .
16 ` How much pleasure he did give me , dear little bird ! '
17 The mole closed up the hole again which let in the light , and then escorted the ladies home .
18 But Thumbelina could not sleep that night ; so she got out of bed , and plaited a great big blanket of straw , and carried it off , and spread it over the dead bird , and piled upon it thistle-down as soft as cotton-wool , which she had found in the field-mouse 's room , so that the poor little thing should lie warmly buried .
19 ` Farewell , pretty little bird ! '
20 she said .
21 ` XXXXX , and thank you for your beautiful songs in the summer , when the trees were green , and the sun shone down warmly on us ! '	Farewell		Farewell|anything|children|cold|front|legs|mouth|none|piece|singing

2 With these words he handed the Herd-boy a belt , and walking on in front he led him to a fountain where hundreds of Giants and Giantesses were assembled preparing to hold a wedding .
3 They danced and played different games till midnight ; then one of the Giants tore up a plant by its roots , and all the Giants and Giantesses made themselves so thin that they disappeared into the earth through the hole made by the uprooting of the plant .
4 The wounded Giant remained behind to the last and called out , ` Herd-boy , where are you ? '
5 ` Here I am , close to you , ' was the reply .
6 ` Touch me , ' said the Giant , ` so that you too may come with us under ground . '
7 The Herd-boy did as he was told , and before he could have believed it possible he found himself in a big hall , where even the walls were made of pure gold .
8 Then to his astonishment he saw that the hall was furnished with the tables and chairs that belonged to his master .
9 In a few minutes the company began to eat and drink .
10 The banquet was a very gorgeous one , and the poor youth fell to and ate and drank lustily .
11 When he had eaten and drunk as much as he could he thought to himself , ` Why should n't I put a loaf of bread in my pocket ?
12 I shall be glad of it to-morrow . '
13 So he seized a loaf when no one was looking and stowed it away under his tunic .
14 No sooner had he done so than the wounded Giant limped up to him and whispered softly , ` Herd-boy , where are you ? '
15 ` Here I am , ' replied the youth .
16 ` Then hold on to me , ' said the Giant , ` so that I may lead you up above again . '
17 So the Herd-boy held on to the Giant , and in a few moments he found himself on the earth once more , but the Giant had vanished .
18 The Herd-boy returned to his sheep , and took off the invisible belt which he hid carefully in his bag .
19 The next morning the lad felt hungry , and thought he would cut off a piece of the loaf he had carried away from the Giants ' wedding feast , and eat it .

1 But the third said contemptuously , ` It is not worth the trouble !
2 Let him live ; he can not remain here , and if he goes higher up the mountain the clouds will take him and carry him off . '
3 Talking thus they went away .
4 But the Hunter had listened to their talk , and as soon as they had gone he rose and climbed to the summit .
5 When he had sat there a little while a cloud swept by , and , seizing him , carried him away .
6 It travelled for a time in the sky , and then it sank down and hovered over a large vegetable garden surrounded by walls , so that he came safely to the ground amidst cabbages and vegetables .
7 The Hunter then looked about him , saying , ` If only I had something to eat !
8 I am so hungry , and it will go badly with me in the future , for I see here not an apple or pear or fruit of any kind -- nothing but vegetables everywhere . '
9 At last he thought , ` At a pinch I can eat a salad ; it does not taste particularly nice , but it will refresh me . '
10 So he looked about for a good head and ate it , but no sooner had he swallowed a couple of mouthfuls than he felt very strange , and found himself wonderfully changed .
11 Four legs began to grow on him , a thick head , and two long ears , and he saw with horror that he had changed into a donkey .
12 But as he was still very hungry and this juicy salad tasted very good to his present nature , he went on eating with a still greater appetite .
13 At last he got hold of another kind of cabbage , but scarcely had swallowed it when he felt another change , and he once more regained his human form .
14 The Hunter now lay down and slept off his weariness .
15 When he awoke the next morning he broke off a head of the bad and a head of the good cabbage , thinking , ` This will help me to regain my own , and to punish faithlessness . '
16 Then he put the heads in his pockets , climbed the wall , and started off to seek the castle of his love .
17 When he had wandered about for a couple of days he found it quite easily .
18 He then browned his face quickly , so that his own mother would not have known him , and went into the castle , where he begged for a lodging . '

1 In a Keddah at least there was torchlight and shouting , but here he was all alone in the dark , and once a trunk came up and touched him on the knee .
2 Then an elephant trumpeted , and they all took it up for five or ten terrible seconds .
3 The dew from the trees above spattered down like rain on the unseen backs , and a dull booming noise began , not very loud at first , and Little Toomai could not tell what it was .
4 But it grew and grew , and Kala Nag lifted up one forefoot and then the other , and brought them down on the ground -- one-two , one-two , as steadily as trip-hammers .
5 The elephants were stamping all together now , and it sounded like a war drum beaten at the mouth of a cave .
6 The dew fell from the trees till there was no more left to fall , and the booming went on , and the ground rocked and shivered , and Little Toomai put his hands up to his ears to shut out the sound .
7 But it was all one gigantic jar that ran through him -- this stamp of hundreds of heavy feet on the raw earth .
8 Once or twice he could feel Kala Nag and all the others surge forward a few strides , and the thumping would change to the crushing sound of juicy green things being bruised , but in a minute or two the boom of feet on hard earth began again .
9 A tree was creaking and groaning somewhere near him .
10 He put out his arm and felt the bark , but Kala Nag moved forward , still tramping , and he could not tell where he was in the clearing .
11 There was no sound from the elephants , except once , when two or three little calves squeaked together .
12 Then he heard a thump and a shuffle , and the booming
